Title: Poll Reveals Discrepancy Between Sanders Supporters' Desires for Free Services and Willingness to Pay for Them

Article:

In a recent poll conducted by Vox and Morning Consult, it was found that supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders, known for his progressive policies, have strong support for initiatives like free college tuition and universal health care. However, the poll also revealed a significant discrepancy between their support for these initiatives and their willingness to pay for them.

The poll found that about 66 percent of Sanders supporters said they would not be willing to pay more than an additional $1,000 in taxes for universal health care. This includes the 8 percent of Sanders supporters who are not willing to pay anything at all. When asked what percentage of their income they would pay, voters seemed to be a bit more generous. While half of Sanders supporters said they are not willing to pay or that they would only pay less than 5 percent of their income, a quarter said they would pay between 5 and 10 percent.

Sanders supporters are far and away the most likely to want free public college tuition. However, 14 percent said they do not want to pay additional taxes for it, and another half said they would only pay up to $1,000 a year.

Sanders' plan would put an additional $5,000 of federal tax liability on households earning $50,000, but in exchange, he would nationalize vital services currently in the private sector. However, the majority of Sanders supporters in the poll (much less all voters) are not willing to pay enough to actually support those nationalized services.

The poll results undercut one of the main points pushed by Sanders on the campaign trail, which is that he is at the head of a political revolution that seeks to make America fairer by destroying the job-creating and investing class and usurping a corrupt campaign finance system that Democrats have used to win back-to-back presidential elections. The poll data shows his most ardent backers do not want to pay for anything he's promising; they just want it.

Moreover, it's hard to say this is the vestige of a left-wing swell in American politics when you can't win in the South. It's not a revolution, then–it's just some senior citizens saying what young, college-educated whites want to hear. Sanders' base is primarily young, college-educated whites, which is not earth-shattering, especially when you consider that Democrats have been losing the white vote nationally since the 1960s.

The poll results suggest that while Sanders supporters want a lot of government-provided services, they are not willing to pay for them, which could pose a challenge for Sanders' campaign if he is to implement his proposed policies.

Title: Film Director Dinesh D'Souza Indicted for Alleged Campaign Finance Violations

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, conservative filmmaker Dinesh D'Souza, known for his politically charged documentaries, was indicted Thursday on charges of violating federal campaign laws. The indictment, which was announced by U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, states that D'Souza will appear in U.S. District Court in New York on Friday.

According to the indictment, D'Souza, 52, is charged with one count of illegally donating to a Senate campaign and one count of causing false statements to be made to authorities in connection with the contributions. The donation in question was made to Republican Wendy Long, who lost a 2012 Senate bid against New York Democratic Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand.

The indictment alleges that D'Souza directed various donors to give contributions to Long's campaign totaling $20,000, and then reimbursed them. Individuals are only allowed to donate a maximum of $5,000 to a candidate per election cycle.

Gerald Molen, D'Souza's co-producer on the film "2016: Obama's America," told FoxNews.com that he believes D'Souza is being singled out by federal authorities. The 2012 film, which examined President Obama's past and early influences that may have shaped his political ideology, was a surprise hit, making over $33 million at the box office.

Molen, who won an Oscar as a co-producer for "Schindler's List," said the charges against D'Souza deeply disappoint him, as D'Souza is a "great American." The indictment states the alleged illegal contributions came to light during the FBI's routine examination of campaign contributions filed with the FEC during the 2012 election year.

D'Souza faces a maximum of two years in prison for the illegal contributions charge and a maximum of five years in prison for the false statements charge. The duo is teaming up again for a new film "America," which Molen said will be released on schedule in July 2014 regardless of what happens in the case.

Molen called on the American public to support the film's release, stating, "Neither the filmmakers nor the American public can allow this prosecution to deter us from the film's release." He added, "I look forward to my good friend Dinesh being vindicated for what appears to be nothing more than a misunderstanding."

Title: Trump's Legal Troubles Deepen as Mueller Investigation Intensifies

Article:

In a week marked by political upheaval and legal maneuvers, President Donald Trump has found himself in the midst of a deepening investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Despite the President's attempts to spin alternative narratives and dismiss the Russia probe, the growing body of evidence against him and his associates is raising new questions about potential collusion and obstruction of justice.

On Saturday, Trump announced the departure of his chief of staff, John Kelly, and took to Twitter to denounce the ongoing investigation as a "witch hunt" and a "collusion illusion." The President's tweets came in response to a series of legal filings and court actions this week that have significantly sharpened the threats facing Trump and key associates.

The filings and court actions suggest that Mueller's investigation has expanded beyond the 2016 campaign and is now delving into possible obstruction of justice following the firing of then-FBI Director James Comey in May 2017. This was underscored by reports that Mueller has spoken to Kelly in recent months, a development that is particularly significant given that Kelly did not take up his post until July 2017.

The filings also revealed that Trump directed his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, to make payments to women who claimed affairs with Trump, a move that allegedly violated campaign finance laws. Furthermore, Mueller has linked Trump's business interests to the Russian election meddling effort, pointing out that work on a proposed Trump Tower Moscow project continued until deep into the campaign in June 2016, a fact that Cohen had previously lied about.

Trump and his legal team maintain that the President is in the clear, with his attorney, Rudy Giuliani, stating that "there's nothing that links the President to collusion with the Russians." However, the depth of the President's legal and political difficulties will only become clear when Mueller files a final report, and Trump's team will have the opportunity to challenge his findings and make their defense.

Meanwhile, the President has been embroiled in a Twitter spat with French President Emmanuel Macron, taunting him over the ongoing protests in France. This diversionary tactic, while potentially pleasing to Trump's base, does little to change the reality of the widening special counsel probe.

As the investigation continues, it remains to be seen how the President and his associates will navigate the increasingly complex web of allegations and evidence. One thing is certain, however: the special counsel's accelerating pace is proving to be a formidable challenge to Trump's talent for creating alternative realities.

Title: Trump Frustrated Over Sessions Recusal, Staff Performance, and Overshadowed Agenda

Article:

Washington ( CNN ) - President Donald Trump is reportedly frustrated with his senior staff and communications team for allowing the controversy surrounding Attorney General Jeff Sessions to overshadow his address to Congress. Sources tell CNN that Trump is particularly upset with the communications team for not being prepared when the Sessions story broke.

On Thursday, Sessions recused himself from any current or future investigations into ties between Russia and the Trump campaign after it was reported he had met with the Russian ambassador to the US, something he had previously failed to disclose. This renewed focus on Russia is seen as a major letdown after Tuesday when top officials were riding high, congratulating one another on Trump's speech to Congress.

The President was reportedly "hot" and exasperated Thursday night after Sessions' recusal, a source familiar with the situation said, considering it hasty and overkill. When Trump returned to the White House Thursday evening from a day trip to Virginia, there were "a lot of expletives," the source said, adding that for more than a week Trump had been lamenting that his senior staff "just keep getting in their own way."

White House spokesman Sean Spicer responded to CNN's reporting, saying, "The President is showing increasing flashes of anger over the performance of his senior staff and daily developments about Russia overshadowing his message. The President is upset because he doesn't believe he is getting the credit he thinks he deserves for his time in office so far because of self-inflicted wounds and missteps."

Trump voiced his frustration to his inner circle in the Oval Office Friday, sources said. He feels attacked by the media, former Obama administration officials, and others, and frustrated that things are not going more smoothly. The President expressed his anger at non-stop leaks undermining his administration, the sources said.

One source familiar with the Friday meeting said Trump was angry at senior staff, including Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, about the state of affairs at the White House this week. Word had spread through the White House that Priebus had been chewed out, but those in the room dispute that. Priebus declined to comment on the record about the meeting.

With so much on the administration's plate - leaks, the Russia story, pending executive order, and Obamacare repeal and replacement - Priebus said he would not go to Florida with the President this weekend as had been previously planned, a source told CNN. He was on the manifest, and a big donor reception by the Republican National Committee which Priebus used to chair was on Preibus' schedule.

But the President said he thought it would not be a good idea since he is not happy with the state of matters right now, the same source said. A White House official disputed that Priebus was supposed to travel to Florida, adding that he stayed home this weekend for a family celebration.

White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon, who initially decided to also stay in Washington Friday, ended up traveling to Florida Saturday and is joining Trump, Sessions, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly, and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross at dinner at Mar-a-Lago.

Title: Conservative Defenses of Chris Christie's Bridge Scandal: A Closer Look

Article:

In the aftermath of the George Washington Bridge scandal, leading conservative figures have taken a unique approach in defending former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie. Instead of focusing on the details of the scandal itself, they have compared the attention given to the bridge closure to other controversies during the Obama administration, such as Benghazi and the IRS scrutiny of political nonprofits.

On Fox News Sunday, political strategist Karl Rove questioned the lack of attention from the Clinton camp on the bridge scandal, contrasting it with the extensive coverage of Benghazi and the IRS. He suggested that it would be challenging for Democrats to turn the bridge scandal into an issue due to the significant attention given to Christie.

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani made a similar argument on ABC's "This Week," stating that administrative mistakes occur, and during campaign mode, attention may be diverted. He compared the bridge scandal to the handling of the Benghazi incident during President Obama's term.

However, the comparison between the George Washington Bridge scandal and the "Obama scandals" has been criticized as an inherently dishonest tactic. The "Obama scandals" have been widely regarded as politically motivated and lacking in substance, while the bridge scandal has provided substantial evidence of malfeasance.

Critics argue that for the conservative meta-argument to hold up, the Obama administration's alleged scandals would have to be real. However, they are not real, making the comparison disingenuous.

The strategy of deflecting attention from the bridge scandal by attacking the media and implying that Democrats would have handled the situation less responsibly is unlikely to be effective. It is more likely to raise suspicions and further fuel the narrative that the conservative defense is motivated by political gain rather than a genuine concern for accountability.

Moreover, the bridge scandal is still unfolding, and new details continue to emerge. If the scandal worsens for Christie, the "What about Benghazi?" and other off-topic retorts are likely to fall on deaf ears.

In conclusion, while the George Washington Bridge scandal has provided substantial evidence of malfeasance, conservative efforts to deflect attention from the issue by comparing it to politically motivated controversies during the Obama administration may not be successful. The strategy is seen as disingenuous and is unlikely to be persuasive, especially as the bridge scandal continues to unfold.

Title: Hillary Clinton Acknowledges 'In-artful' Remark on Financial Status, Maintains Accuracy

In an interview with Fusion TV's Jorge Ramos, published Monday night, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton admitted that her comment about being "dead broke" when she and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, left the White House in 2001 was "in-artful." However, she maintained the statement's accuracy.

When asked, "Do you regret telling Diana Sawyer that you were once 'dead broke'?", Clinton responded, "Well, I regret it. It was in-artful." She continued, "It was accurate — but we are so successful and we're so blessed by the success we've had and my husband has worked incredibly hard."

Clinton then shifted the conversation towards her concern for working families, stating, "What I worry about is not my family. I worry about other families in our country who feel like they’re running in place, they’re not getting ahead or maybe they're falling backwards. What I want to do — and this is what Bill has always done since the very beginning of his public life — is to try to create more ladders of opportunity for more Americans so that they can have the same opportunities that Bill and I have had."

Ramos persisted with his line of questioning, asking, "Do you know your net worth? Do you know how much money you have?" Clinton responded, "Um, you know, within a range," before mentioning their two homes. When pressed about the value of their wealth, Clinton acknowledged, "Yes, indeed."

According to CNN, former President Bill Clinton earned $106 million between 2001 and early 2013. Hillary Clinton has reportedly earned an estimated $12 million since leaving the State Department in 2013. In a June 9 interview with ABC's Diane Sawyer, Clinton stated, "We came out of the White House not only dead broke, but in debt."

Title: Trump Plans Rebuttal to Clinton's Foreign Policy Criticism, Defends Iraq War Stance

Article:

In a move to counter Hillary Clinton's harsh criticism of his foreign policy, Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, has announced plans to deliver a rebuttal as early as Monday. Trump made the announcement during an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" Sunday.

"I think I'm going to devote a retort to her speech. Maybe I'll do it on Monday, before the election" in California and four other states, Trump said.

Trump mocked Clinton for working with speechwriters on her San Diego remarks and dismissed her characterization of him as "temperamentally unfit" for the presidency and driven by personal feuds, insisting he has "very strong, very thick skin."

"Most of the things, many of the things she said, are wrong," Trump said.

The Republican nominee also defended his claims that he opposed the Iraq War before it began. "I was against it from before it started," he said. However, it's clear Trump opposed the war by 2004, but there's not yet any public evidence that he opposed it before the war began in 2003. In a 2002 interview with Howard Stern, Trump said, "Yeah, I guess so" when asked whether he supported then-President George W. Bush's push to go to war.

Trump cast his comments in that 2002 interview as wishy-washy, saying they show he was moving toward opposing the war. "That interview was substantially before the war started," Trump said. "First time I was ever asked the question."

In a separate interview on "State of the Union," Clinton criticized Trump over his Iraq War claim. "Well, he supported it," the Democratic front-runner said. "We have evidence and audio of him supporting it, so I think that's another example of him trying to rewrite history."

Trump also criticized protesters who have been involved in violent clashes outside his campaign events, calling them "thugs" planted by Democrats. "They're thugs," he told Tapper. "The people that are outside -- they're thugs and they're agitators. They're bad people. I think they're sent by the Democrats."

Asked for evidence to back his claim that the protesters are being sent by Democrats, Trump said, "Well, they have Bernie signs." Anti-Trump protesters clashed with his supporters outside a rally last week in San Jose. Previously, protesters had thrown rocks and bottles and burned signs in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and protesters and Trump supporters fought in Chicago at an event Trump ultimately canceled.

Trump said police should be "very strong" with protesters at his events -- but said he's not criticizing police for how they've handled the protests so far. "I think the police forces are being treated very unfairly in this country. They're afraid to do anything because they don't want to lose their jobs, they don't want to lose their pension, they don't want to be criticized," he said.

Trump also vociferously defended his claims that a judge overseeing a lawsuit against Trump University is biased because of his Mexican heritage -- pushing back against criticism that his objections are racist. The presumptive GOP nominee told Tapper that U.S. District Court Judge Gonzalo Curiel, a federal district judge in the Southern District of California, has made "rulings that people can't even believe."

"He's proud of his his heritage. I respect him for that," Trump said, dismissing charges that his allegation was racist. "He's a Mexican. We're building a wall between here and Mexico." Trump first broached these waters in an interview with The Wall Street Journal published Thursday, in which he said Curiel, who was born in Indiana, had an "inherent conflict of interest" in the Trump University lawsuit.

"If he was giving me a fair ruling, I wouldn't say that," Trump told Tapper, pointing again to Curiel's background. "I think that's why he's doing it." "I'm building a wall. I'm trying to keep business out of Mexico. Mexico's fine," Trump continued. "He's of Mexican heritage, and he's very proud of it."

Title: Missouri State Trooper Condemns Violent Agitators Amidst Ongoing Ferguson Protests

Article:

In the aftermath of a night of unrest in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, Missouri Highway Patrol Captain Ron Johnson addressed the media early Tuesday, condemning "violent agitators" who he claimed were using largely peaceful protests as a cover for criminal activities.

Johnson reported that 31 individuals had been arrested during the night, following a day of largely peaceful protests that ensued after the death of 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was fatally shot by a white police officer on August 9. As Johnson spoke, two handguns and a Molotov cocktail, confiscated during the night by authorities, lay on a table in front of him.

The majority-black town of approximately 21,000 has been in turmoil since Brown's death. Local authorities have frequently used tear gas and smoke canisters against protesters who have been expressing their discontent with the response to the shootings by Ferguson Police.

Johnson stated that officers had come under heavy gunfire from protesters, and at least two individuals had been shot. He did not provide information on the condition of the shooting victims. Four officers had been injured when struck by rocks or bottles, though Johnson asserted that police had not fired a single shot.

Citing a "dangerous dynamic in the night," Johnson requested that protests take place during daylight hours, allowing officers to effectively isolate any troublemakers. However, Johnson acknowledged that his forces could not make protesters leave the streets after sunset if they did not wish to do so.

"This nation is watching each and every one of us," said Johnson. "I am not going to let the criminals that have come here from across this country, or live in this neighborhood, define this community." Johnson added that some of those arrested overnight had traveled from as far as New York and California. The trooper also directed his criticism towards the assembled media, stating they had put themselves and officers in danger by failing to clear areas when asked, and urged them not to "glamorize the acts of criminals."

"We do not want to lose another life in this community," Johnson added.

Shortly before midnight local time, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that police had fired tear gas at a group of protesters who had reportedly defied orders to leave the parking lot of a burned-QuikTrip convenience store that has been near the center of demonstrations over the past eight days. St. Louis County Police Chief Sam Dotson told reporters that shots had been fired in the area, and media members were told to go to a designated area about a quarter of a mile away.

Late Monday, reporters estimated that the number of protesters had dropped to around 100, far fewer than the number of media members who were covering them. A photographer for the Getty photo agency was arrested while covering the demonstrations and later released. Two German reporters were arrested and detained for three hours. Conservative German daily Die Welt said correspondent Ansgar Graw and reporter Frank Herrmann, who write for German regional papers, were arrested after allegedly failing to follow police instructions to vacate an empty street. They claimed they followed police orders.

At his news conference, Johnson stated in some cases it was not immediately clear who was a reporter, but that once it was established, police acted properly.

As darkness fell, National Guard units with armored vehicles were waiting at a staging area about a half-mile from the portion of West Florissant Avenue that has been the scene of the largest protests. Closer to the protest site, a crowd of demonstrators was marching and growing in size. Sheriff's deputies in body armor and state troopers carrying wooden bats and gas masks stood watch over the group.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported that some protesters began throwing bottles at police shortly after 10 p.m. local time. Authorities responded by ordering protesters to clear the streets and firing high-pitched sound cannons.

Another group of protesters marched toward the police lines and stopped, defying orders that demonstrators could not assemble in a single spot, but had to keep moving instead. The Post-Dispatch reported that an armored vehicle moved down the street trying to clear the crowd, and a group of pastors locked arms and helped to move protesters away from the police line.

In federal court earlier Monday, a judge denied a request from the American Civil Liberties Union for a restraining order that would have prevented authorities from enforcing the no-stopping rule.

A grand jury could begin hearing evidence Wednesday to determine whether the officer, Darren Wilson, should be charged in Brown's death, said Ed Magee, spokesman for St. Louis County's prosecuting attorney.

The St. Louis County medical examiner's autopsy found that Brown was shot six to eight times in the head and chest, office administrator Suzanne McCune said Monday. However, she declined further comment, stating that the full findings were not expected for about two weeks.

Lawyers for Brown's family and hired pathologists stated that an independent autopsy determined that Brown was shot six times, including twice in the head.

Forensic pathologist Shawn Parcells, who assisted former New York City chief medical examiner Dr. Michael Baden during the private autopsy, said a bullet grazed Brown's right arm. He said the wound indicates Brown may have had his back to the shooter, or he could have been facing the shooter with his hands above his head or in a defensive position across his chest or face.

"We don't know," Parcells said. "We still have to look at the other (elements) of this investigation before we start piecing things together."

A third and final autopsy was performed Monday for the Justice Department by one of the military's most experienced medical examiners, Attorney General Eric Holder said. Holder was scheduled to travel to Ferguson later this week to meet with FBI and other officials carrying out an independent federal investigation into Brown's death.

Due to the unrest, the Ferguson-Florissant School District announced late Monday that classes would be canceled for the remainder of the week. Students were due to return from summer vacation last week, but were held out due to the unrest.

Title: Trump Slams RNC, Accuses Party of Running a "Scam" and "Disgrace" in Presidential Nominating Process

Article:

NEW YORK — Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump has criticized the Republican National Committee (RNC) and its chairman, Reince Priebus, over the party's presidential nominating process, claiming it is a "scam" and a "disgrace."

During an exclusive interview with ███ at Trump Tower, Trump said, "It's a disgrace for the party. And Reince Priebus should be ashamed of himself. He should be ashamed of himself because he knows what's going on."

Trump is particularly upset with the way Colorado awarded all of its 34 delegates to Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) without holding a primary or a caucus. He disagrees with the fact that some delegates are not bound to vote for their state or district winner at this summer's GOP convention in Cleveland.

"It should go to a vote in Colorado like other places.... The best way to do it would be just a vote, should be a vote of the people. That's the way it should be done. The delegate situation is a very unjust way of doing things," Trump said.

Asked if he would call for Priebus to step down should he become the nominee, Trump responded, "I have not given that any thought."

In an emailed statement, Sean Spicer, the RNC's chief strategist and communications director, said, "Each state and territory submitted a plan on how to allocate and select their delegates last year. Those plans were made available to every campaign. Understanding the delegate selection and allocation is a basic part of the campaign."

Trump floated a possible lawsuit after winning Louisiana, stating the party did not give him enough delegates. His campaign later downplayed the legal threat.

On Sunday, Trump aide Paul Manafort accused the Cruz campaign of not playing by the rules in its attempt to woo delegates. On NBC's "Meet the Press," Manafort said the Trump campaign will "file several protests" to the RNC.

Priebus on Monday defended the RNC nominating system, saying the rules have not changed and there's "nothing mysterious" about what Colorado Republicans did. Last summer, the Colorado GOP opted to select unbound delegates to the Republican convention.

It is extraordinary for the Republican presidential front-runner and the head of the RNC to be at odds, especially less than 100 days before the convention begins. Last year, after Trump threatened to run as a third-party candidate, Priebus convinced the celebrity businessman and other GOP rivals to sign a pledge backing the party nominee. And earlier this month, Trump and Priebus met privately at the RNC headquarters on Capitol Hill. In a tweet, Trump said it was "a very nice meeting," adding he was "looking forward to bringing the party together."

On Tuesday, Trump's tone was sharply different: "I would have won Colorado. It's not democracy.... It's such a sad thing that the Republican Party has come to this."

He added, "The Republican system is unfair, unjust, and they should create a fair system based on votes—not a system like they have now that is based on politics as usual."

Asked whether he's talked to Priebus, Trump shrugged his shoulders and said, "Whatever happens, happens. I think the Republicans are being embarrassed. The whole country is talking about the scam that is going on, and it's politics. I mean, basically, the politicians put this in so that they can pick whoever they want, but I think we're going to have a big surprise for them."

Trump said he sees similarities on the other side of the aisle, saying the Democratic National Committee is favoring Hillary Clinton over Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.).

"I tell you, it's unfair even from the Democrats' side. Every time I turn on the television, Bernie wins, Bernie wins—for weeks—Bernie wins, Bernie wins, Bernie wins. And then I watch the commentators and they say, 'Bernie can't win.' How do you win every single week, every single state, and you can't win? You know why? Because it's a corrupt system. It's corrupt there, and it's more corrupt on the Republican side," he said.

More of ███'s interview with Trump will run Wednesday morning.

Title: Senate Confirmation Hearing for Brett Kavanaugh Marred by Last-Minute Document Release

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee's confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh on Tuesday was marked by a contentious start due to the late release of 42,000 pages of documents related to Kavanaugh's time in the George W. Bush White House. The documents were released the night before the hearing, leaving senators with little time to review them before the proceedings.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) criticized the timing, stating on Twitter, "Not a single senator will be able to review these records before tomorrow." He added that the Trump White House has been the "least transparent" in history.

The late release of documents led to a heated exchange between Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) and several Democratic senators, including Kamala Harris (D-CA), Amy Klobuchar (D-MN), and Richard Blumenthal (D-CT). These senators objected to the sudden influx of documents and called for the hearing to be postponed.

Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) questioned the timing, asking Grassley, "What is the rush? What are they trying to hide?"

During the Democrats' protest, a group of protesters in the chamber chanted about "obstruction of justice."

In response to the Democrats' objections, Grassley defended the committee's handling of the documents, stating that they had already reviewed 483,000 pages of Kavanaugh's executive branch service. He emphasized that this was more pages than the last five Supreme Court nominees combined and more materials than any Supreme Court nominee in history.

The timing of the document release was not only criticized by Democrats but also by some Republicans, such as Judge Andrew Napolitano on Fox News, who called the White House's release of documents "exquisitely unfair" due to the limited time it gave Democrats to sift through the information and prepare their questions.

Title: Pro-Gun Advocates Remain Silent Following Connecticut School Shooting as Gun Control Debate Intensifies

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, pro-gun organizations and politicians have largely remained silent, ceding their role in the ongoing national debate on gun control. The shooting, which resulted in the deaths of 20 first-graders and six school staff members, has sparked renewed calls for stricter gun laws and a re-evaluation of America's long-standing affinity for firearms.

On Friday, a 20-year-old resident of Newtown, Adam Lanza, took a high-powered rifle from his mother's collection, killed her, and then drove to the school. Once there, Mr. Lanza, a socially awkward individual described as being on the autism spectrum, forced his way into the school and, without uttering a word, killed the children and staff attempting to shield them.

Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh criticized gun control proponents as early as Friday for attempting to exploit the tragedy for political gain, a tactic that struck an awkward note in a country where even pro-gun rights Americans paused to consider the implications of America's long-running affinity for guns.

When David Gregory, host of NBC’s “Meet the Press,” sent out 31 invitations to pro-gun Senators in the new Congress to discuss the issue on Sunday, no takers emerged. The Shooting Sports Foundation, a pro-gun rights group headquartered just a few miles from where the shootings took place, also remained silent, as did the National Rifle Association (NRA).

In the absence of pro-gun rights voices, some conservative bloggers reminded readers of several instances in recent years when legal gun carriers thwarted potential mass shootings. In Portland, Oregon, one concealed weapons owner claims he brandished his gun after alleged mall shooter Jacob Roberts opened fire. According to the man, Roberts, whose rifle was jamming, fled the scene after seeing the gun and minutes later shot himself.

Even on the blog of Eugene Volokh, a Russian-born UCLA law professor whose article “The Commonplace Second Amendment” has been cited in recent court rulings favoring gun rights, commenters sounded less partisan than thoughtful in response to a blog entry where Mr. Volokh acknowledged no one knows if arming more Americans in anticipation of mass shootings would ultimately save lives.

“A decade ago, or so, there were a few high school shootings,” writes commenter Joe JP. “My interest would include why they occurred at that time, particularly since there did not seem to be some novel change in the law or presence of guns. Why are we having another slew of cases now as compared to five years ago? Is this a cyclical thing?”

After Friday’s massacre in Connecticut became the 7th major mass shooting in the US this year, police later Friday arrested a Cedar Lake, Indiana, man who owned 47 guns, after he threatened to go to a local elementary school and open fire.

On Sunday, a man in Newport Beach, California, fired 50 shots in a mall parking lot, hurting no one. In July, a college dropout proclaiming he was “The Joker” opened fire on a midnight screening of a “Batman” movie in Aurora, Colorado, killing 12 people and injuring 58, many of them seriously.

Previous massacres, including the Aurora shootings, have barely budged American support for the Second Amendment, which the Supreme Court in recent years has ruled applies to Americans armed to defend themselves and their homes. However, some polls suggest a majority of Americans do support some gradual restrictions on gun ownership.

Sensing a pause from pro-gun rights groups and individuals, pro-gun control advocates like Huffington Post columnist Robert Cavnar, a licensed gun owner, noted that “the conversation has finally begun.”

“The age and innocence of the victims in this massacre, coming right on the heels of the Oregon shootings and the Jovan Belcher murder-suicide, have finally caused the self-imposed discussion moratorium, enforced by the millions of dollars invested by the NRA and gun manufacturers, to be ended,” he writes. As proof, he says, “The NRA has uncharacteristically gone subterranean since the shooting, and its website is completely silent on the matter.”

Rep. Louie Gohmert (R) of Texas became the only national voice to wave the Second Amendment banner in the wake of the shootings. He told Fox News’ Chris Wallace on Sunday that the massacre could have been averted had the principal been heavily armed.

“Chris, I wish to God [slain principal Dawn Hochsprung] had had an M-4 in her office, locked up so when she heard gunfire, she pulls it out…and takes him out…before he can kill those precious kids,” he said.

As the nation grapples with the aftermath of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, the debate on gun control and the role of firearms in American society continues to intensify.

Title: Obama Administration Halts Arctic Oil Drilling Lease Sales Following Shell's Suspension of Exploration

Article:

WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has announced the cancellation of plans to sell oil drilling rights in the Arctic Sea through 2017, marking a significant shift in policy following Shell Oil's decision last month to suspend its oil exploration in offshore Alaskan waters. The Interior Department's decision to cancel further oil leases was prompted by Shell's announcement of disappointing results from a well in the Chukchi Sea.

Secretary of the Interior Sally Jewell stated, "In light of Shell's announcement, the amount of acreage already under lease and current market conditions, it does not make sense to prepare for lease sales in the Arctic in the next year and a half."

Environmental groups, who criticized the administration for approving permits for Shell to drill while President Obama was highlighting the effects of climate change in Alaska, have applauded Friday's move. The Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) called it "an essential reprieve" for Arctic Waters. NRDC's Franz Matzner commented, "The next step should be to take Arctic and Atlantic waters off the table to oil and gas drilling for good."

In addition to canceling further lease sales, the department also denied requests by Shell and the Norwegian company Statoil to extend their existing leases beyond 10 years. Both companies had asked for five-year extensions, arguing that they should have more time due to regulations preventing them from exploring for oil. Without those extensions, the leases will expire by 2020.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska) criticized the decision, calling it "absurd." She argued that the Interior Department is using the lack of drilling to justify canceling the lease sales, and that the department is throwing up regulatory roadblocks to prevent drilling. Murkowski, who chairs the Senate Energy Committee, stated, "This is a stunning, short-sighted move that betrays the Interior Department's commitments to Alaska and the best interests of our nation's long-term energy security." She added, "Today's decision is the latest in a destructive pattern of hostility toward energy production in our state that began the first day this administration took office, and continued ever since."

Title: Bipartisan Praise for Obama Administration's Diplomatic Post Closures Amid Terror Threat; National Security Debate Shifts

Article:

The Obama administration's decision to close diplomatic posts across various regions, from Central Asia to North Africa, has received bipartisan support from lawmakers who view it as a prudent response to a perceived serious threat of potential terrorist attacks.

In a series of interviews on Sunday, lawmakers from both parties commended the administration's decision, citing the credible nature of the intelligence that suggests the attacks could occur in the regions affected by the closures, or elsewhere.

House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul (R-Texas) praised the administration's move on CBS-TV's Face the Nation, stating, "The administration's call to close these embassies... was actually a very smart call."

Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md.) echoed similar sentiments on ABC-TV's This Week, saying, "What we have to do now is the most important issue, is protect Americans throughout the world."

Initially, the State Department had announced the closure of 19 diplomatic posts on Sunday, including Abu Dhabi, Amman, Cairo, Riyadh, Dhahran, Jeddah, Doha, Dubai, Kuwait, Manama, Muscat, Sanaa, Tripoli, Antanarivo, Bujumbura, Djibouti, Khartoum, Kigali, and Port Louis. However, posts in nine locations were set to reopen on Monday: Dhaka, Algiers, Nouakchott, Kabul, Herat, Mazar el Sharif, Baghdad, Basrah, and Erbil.

The heightened terror threat has not only brought lawmakers together but has also shifted the focus of the ongoing debate about National Security Agency (NSA) surveillance programs. The subject, which had been a contentious issue following the revelations by "NSA leaker" Edward Snowden, has now shifted to a discussion of the effectiveness of these programs.

As reported by NPR's Dina Temple-Raston, the weekend terror threat has opened up a new front in the debate over the NSA's surveillance programs. The Hill notes that a handful of lawmakers, primarily national security hawks, have used the Sunday news shows to argue that the NSA programs have been successful in uncovering potential terrorist attacks.

Title: Biden Secures Victory in Maine, Leading Democratic Presidential Race After Super Tuesday

Article:

In a significant turn of events, former Vice President Joe Biden has emerged victorious in the Democratic presidential primary in Maine, making it the last state to be called in the Super Tuesday contests. This victory marks a significant comeback for Biden, who now boasts 10 primary wins, leaving Sen. Bernie Sanders with four.

The self-proclaimed Democratic socialist, Sanders, managed to secure victories in his home state of Vermont, as well as Colorado and Utah. However, the largest prize of the night, the delegate-rich state of California, went to Biden.

Biden, initially the unrivaled front-runner, faced a setback in the early primary contests with lackluster performances in Iowa and New Hampshire. A slight rebound in Nevada's caucuses and a decisive victory in South Carolina, a state the campaign had long considered their "firewall," provided Biden with the momentum he needed to regain his position.

The withdrawal of more moderate candidates, such as former South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., and their endorsement of Biden, consolidated the moderate vote in Tuesday's states. Former New York City Mayor Mike Bloomberg also suspended his campaign and endorsed Biden, further narrowing the field. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who had a disappointing Super Tuesday performance, remains in the race.

Addressing his supporters Tuesday night, Biden said, "To those who've been knocked down, counted out, left behind, this is your campaign." He added, "It may be over for the other guy."

In response to Sanders' ad showing former President Barack Obama praising him, the Biden campaign issued a rebuke.

As of 2 p.m. ET Wednesday, Biden had 566 delegates, while Sanders had 501. A candidate needs 1,991 delegates to clinch the Democratic nomination for president.

Sanders, despite finishing behind Biden Tuesday night, expressed optimism about his campaign's position. "I am excited about where we are. We have come a long, long way," Sanders said Tuesday night.

The next tests for the candidates will be on March 10, when voters in Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, North Dakota, and Washington state head to the polls. On St. Patrick's Day, March 17, Arizona, Florida, Illinois, and Ohio will have their chance to vote. Georgia will hold its primary on March 24.

Title: The Rise of Donald Trump: A Symptom of Economic Disillusionment Among Republican Voters

Article:

In the last four decades, the Republican Party has been peddling an economic message that champions the prosperity of the wealthy as a shared success for all. However, the recent surge of Donald Trump, a candidate who has been described as a demagogue, marks a significant shift in the party's traditional voter base. The GOP establishment has faced a series of humiliating defeats at the hands of a candidate whose rhetoric echoes elements of fascist leaders like Benito Mussolini and George Wallace.

The economic narrative the right wing of the Republican Party, often referred to as the Money Party, has been selling to its voters since the 1970s is rooted in the belief that excessive government regulation, high taxes, and an overly generous welfare system have stifled the American economy. This narrative suggests that the American dream has been eroded due to government intervention, leaving ordinary Americans with stagnant bank accounts despite their hard work.

However, a closer examination of the economic history of the United States since 1945 reveals a different story. Inflation-adjusted per capita GDP in the U.S. grew from $17,490 in 1945 to $27,837 in 1974, and then jumped to $55,185 in 2014, nearly doubling since 1974. This indicates that the country is twice as rich per person now as it was then.

Yet, the average household income of the bottom 50% of American households was $25,475 in 1974, and $26,520 in 2014. In other words, half the population has not benefited from the additional $10 trillion of national wealth generated over the past four decades. This group includes half of the nation's middle class.

Meanwhile, the average household income of the top 5% of American households has increased from $187,729 to $332,347, while the income of the top 0.01% (approximately the nation's 13,000 wealthiest households) has grown by about seven-fold, from less than $5 million to more than $30 million per year.

Trump's appeal extends beyond his exploitation of racism and xenophobia, as he taps into the economic anxieties of white middle and working-class voters. These voters are angry about their economic circumstances and the empty promises of a Republican party that caters primarily to the rich. The half of America that lives on $40,000, $25,000, or even $10,000 per year is uninterested in issues like cutting capital gains taxes, eliminating the estate tax, or slashing Social Security and Medicare.

The contemporary Republican party, it seems, exists to protect the economic interests of the donor class, a fact that has been hidden behind culture war issues and racial and ethnic animosities for the past four decades. The disillusionment felt by many voters is a reflection of this disconnect between the party's rhetoric and the economic realities faced by middle- and working-class Americans.

The rise of Donald Trump is a stark reminder that the Republican Party must reevaluate its approach to economic policy if it hopes to regain the trust of its voters. The party's failure to address the economic concerns of its base has led to the election of a candidate whose message, crude and bombastic as it may be, resonates with the experiences of many Americans.

Title: Grand Jury Decision in Ferguson Shooting: A Look at the Latest Developments

Article:

In the aftermath of the grand jury's decision not to indict Officer Darren Wilson for the shooting of Michael Brown, several significant developments have unfolded in Ferguson, Missouri.

On Tuesday, Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson sat down with ABC News, marking his first public statement since the shooting on August 9. Wilson described the altercation, stating that Brown did not have his hands up when he was fatally shot.

President Obama, speaking from Chicago at a scheduled immigration event, condemned the "destructive" behavior that led to fires, gunfire, and property damage. He acknowledged the many peaceful protests across the country, expressing his support for them.

Missouri Governor Jay Nixon addressed safety measures going forward, promising to deploy more than 2,200 troops to maintain peace in Ferguson. Ferguson Mayor James Knowles criticized the National Guard for a slow response, stating that they were not deployed quickly enough to prevent violence and arson in the wake of the grand jury's decision.

Officer Darren Wilson will speak with ABC's George Stephanopoulos on World News Tonight at 6:30 p.m. ET, marking his first public interview since the shooting.

Benjamin Crump, a lawyer representing Michael Brown's family, criticized the prosecutor who handled the grand jury, stating, "We object as publicly and loudly as we can on behalf of Michael Brown Jr.'s family that this process is broken. The process should be indicted."

The grand jury documents, released following the decision, provide detailed accounts of the altercation. Wilson told the grand jury that Brown "looked like a demon" and that the altercation was like "fighting Hulk Hogan."

Authorities reported 61 arrests, with 59 of those arrested being local residents. St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar stated that it took "10,000 policemen" to control the chaos, describing the situation as worse than the worst night in August.

Twitter reported over 3.5 million tweets sent by midnight ET after the decision was announced at about 9 p.m. Social media users shared their thoughts and reactions on Twitter and Instagram.

The streets of Ferguson were calmer on Tuesday morning, with 29 people arrested, two police cars set on fire, at least a dozen buildings burned, and looting and rioting reported. One officer was shot (not seriously), and police used tear gas to disperse crowds. However, no deaths or serious injuries have been reported. Flight restrictions out of Lambert-St. Louis International Airport have expired.

St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar reported at a 1:30 a.m. CT news conference that at least a dozen buildings were burning and at least 150 gunshots had been fired, none by police.

In a letter released to KSDK-TV in St. Louis, Wilson thanked his supporters, stating, "I would like to thank you all for standing up for me during this stressful time. Your support and dedication is amazing and it is still hard to believe that all of these people that I have never met are doing so much for me."

Michael Brown's mother, Lesley McSpadden, reacted emotionally to the grand jury's decision. Attorney Benjamin Crump delivered the news to McSpadden, who screamed and sobbed. McSpadden expressed a desire to meet with the prosecutor, but no such meeting has been scheduled as of yet.

A police officer was shot and a woman killed in a St. Louis suburb south of Ferguson, with the suspect still at large. The Federal Aviation Administration restricted flights into and out of Lambert International Airport to "provide a safe environment for law enforcement activities."

Protests turned violent in Ferguson, with demonstrators taunting police, shattering windows, and setting fire to two St. Louis County police cars. Looters plundered a Walgreens and Autozone store, while a Little Caesars pizza restaurant and local beauty shop were set ablaze.

Demonstrators reacted more peacefully in several other cities, including New York, Oakland, Philadelphia, Detroit, and Washington, D.C. In New York, hundreds marched to Times Square chanting, "No justice, no peace, no racist police," and carrying signs that read, "Jail Killing Cops" and "Resistance Is Justified." Protesters in Oakland, Calif., laid in the middle of an intersection in silent protest, then marched down Broadway shouting, "Hands up, don't shoot," and "Black lives matter — all lives matter."

President Obama urged calm, stating, "We are a nation built on the rule of law. We need to accept this decision was the grand jury's to make." He also acknowledged that the situation in Ferguson speaks to broader problems that the nation still faces.

Title: Mueller's Indictment Deepens Legal Peril for Trump Campaign Aide Richard Gates

Article:

In a move that could potentially intensify the legal troubles for former Trump campaign aide Richard Gates, Special Counsel Robert Mueller unveiled new criminal charges against Gates and his longtime business partner, Paul Manafort, on Thursday. The charges include tax evasion, bank fraud, and money laundering.

The superseding indictment, released Thursday, increases the legal pressure on Gates, who had been expected to strike a deal with Mueller to avoid trial. According to Seth Waxman, a former federal prosecutor, the timing of the filing is strategically aimed at maximizing the pressure on Gates, in case he is wavering on cooperating with the investigation.

"It is designed to continue to ratchet up the pressure on Manafort and Gates to flip," Waxman said. He added that the new filings suggest Mueller is likely sending a clear signal to Gates "that he is not messing around."

Gates, who worked closely with Manafort for over a decade, is a key figure for Mueller due to his close relationship with Manafort. Their collaboration included lobbying work for a pro-Russia political party in Ukraine, and Gates' testimony at trial could prove damaging for Manafort.

Steven Cash, a lawyer at Day Pitney who specializes in criminal litigation and national security-related matters, said, "If Manafort really did have a second in command comparable to a close confidant, you don’t get much better than that. It’s like having the second in command of a company testify against the CEO."

A plea agreement with Gates would put significant pressure on Manafort to cut a deal of his own. If he flipped, it's possible he could provide Mueller with inside information about any contact between the Trump campaign and Moscow during the summer of 2016, a key period when Russia began orchestrating the release of hacked Democratic emails.

Ron Hosko, a former FBI assistant director, stated, "The Manafort indictment is serious, is ugly, and is very likely backed by large volumes of evidence." He added, "Gates can drive a final nail."

President Trump has consistently denied any collusion between his campaign and Russia, describing the allegations as a "hoax." Mueller's team first unveiled an indictment against Manafort and Gates in late October, which included bank transactions and accused them of money laundering, bank fraud, and other financial crimes stemming from work overseas that pre-dated their involvement in Trump's presidential campaign.

Former prosecutors suggest that Gates' testimony, should he choose to cooperate, could help prosecutors sort through their evidence against Manafort. He could also fill in holes in timelines and help walk prosecutors through some of the complex financial transactions that he and Manafort are accused of carrying out.

The possibility of Gates testifying could be enough to get Manafort to cooperate with Mueller's prosecutors, which is likely their main goal. Manafort worked for Trump's campaign for six months before resigning under pressure in August 2016 over reports of his dealings with a pro-Russia oligarch in Ukraine. He was in the room for a June 2016 meeting at Trump Tower with a Russian lawyer who had promised Donald Trump Jr. damaging information on Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign, and could provide inside information about any contact between the campaign and Russia.

If Gates were to strike a plea deal, he would be the fourth known witness to cooperate with Mueller's investigation, in addition to former national security adviser Michael Flynn, former Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos, and a California man ensnared in the probe for selling bank account numbers to foreigners committing identity fraud.

"I think the question is not are there going to be more indictments and guilty pleas," said Jack Sharman, a former Whitewater special counsel. "I think there will be. The larger question is ultimately what is the relation of any of those offenses to the original core mission of the special counsel, who was appointed because of concerns over presidential campaign involvement."

Title: Monsanto Ordered to Pay $289 Million in Landmark Glyphosate Cancer Case

In a landmark ruling, a California jury has ordered chemical giant Monsanto to pay $289 million in damages to Dewayne Johnson, a man who claimed that the company's Roundup and RangerPro weedkillers containing glyphosate caused his non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. This is the first lawsuit to go to trial alleging a glyphosate link to cancer.

The jury found that Monsanto knew its products were dangerous and failed to warn consumers about the potential risks. The company, which was recently acquired by the German conglomerate Bayer AG, has denied that glyphosate causes cancer and plans to appeal the ruling.

Dewayne Johnson, a groundskeeper, was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 2014. He regularly used a form of RangerPro while working at a school in Benicia, California. The implications of this verdict will likely lead to hundreds of other claims against Monsanto.

Glyphosate is the world's most common weedkiller, and the science about its safety is still far from settled. In 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organization's cancer agency, concluded that it was "probably carcinogenic to humans." However, the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) continues to insist that glyphosate is safe when used carefully.

The EPA's assessment has been questioned by campaigners, who cite evidence of inappropriate industry involvement in the decision-making process. Some Democrats have even called for a Department of Justice investigation into alleged collusion between government officials and Monsanto.

In California, where a judge recently ruled that coffee must carry a cancer warning, the agriculture industry sued to prevent a similar label for glyphosate. In Europe, the battle over glyphosate has been fierce, with French President Emmanuel Macron trying to ban it despite resistance from some lawmakers and the European Commission's recent granting of a five-year license.

Jurors found that Monsanto acted with "malice" and that its weedkillers contributed "substantially" to Johnson's terminal illness. The jury ordered the agricultural multi-national to pay $250 million in punitive damages, along with other costs that brought the total figure to almost $290 million.

Johnson's lawyer, Brent Wisner, said the jury's verdict showed that the evidence against the product was "overwhelming." He added that the ruling was just "the tip of the spear" of future legal cases.

In a statement after the ruling, Monsanto said it was "sympathetic to Mr. Johnson and his family" but would "continue to vigorously defend this product, which has a 40-year history of safe use." The company also stated that "more than 800 scientific studies and reviews - and conclusions by the US Environmental Protection Agency, the US National Institutes of Health, and regulatory authorities around the world - support the fact that glyphosate does not cause cancer, and did not cause Mr. Johnson's cancer."

Title: Nation on High Alert as Investigations Intensify Following Boston Marathon Explosions

Article:

In the aftermath of the Boston Marathon explosions, investigators have made significant progress in their search for the perpetrators. Remnants of the explosive devices, including parts of pressure cookers packed with nails, ball bearings, and black powder, a dark nylon backpack or duffel bag, circuit boards, wires, and other timing device components, have been recovered. Investigators aim to trace these items back to their point of sale and compile a list of potential buyers.

A piece of a pressure cooker lid was found on a rooftop near the blast site, providing a sense of the immense force of the explosion. The investigation, now in its third day, has also involved the scrutiny of numerous videos and photographs from surveillance cameras in nearby businesses, as well as from marathon spectators' smartphones and television crews filming the event. As of yet, no one has claimed responsibility for the explosions.

Across the nation, there has been a palpable sense of unease, with increased reports of suspicious packages. In New York City, the scene of a devastating bombing in 1995, City Hall was briefly evacuated Wednesday morning as authorities examined a stolen rental truck parked outside. Officials in Oklahoma City reported no bomb, while parts of two Senate office buildings were shut down in Washington due to reports of suspicious letters or packages. The Secret Service also reported a letter addressed to President Obama containing a suspicious substance, which was intercepted at a screening facility outside the White House, leading to the arrest of a suspect Wednesday evening.

In New York, the police department reported a 300% increase in reports of suspicious packages between Monday afternoon and Tuesday midnight, compared to the same time period last year. The John Joseph Moakley United States Court House in Boston was also evacuated Wednesday afternoon, with bomb-sniffing dogs called in for a "code red" investigation.

As the investigation into the Boston Marathon explosions continues, the nation remains on high alert, with authorities urging vigilance and cooperation in the face of these unprecedented events.

Title: Media's Portrayal of Hillary Clinton and the Benghazi Report: A Closer Look

Article:

The recent release of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence's report on the 2012 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, has sparked a media frenzy, with headlines suggesting a direct indictment of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. However, a closer examination of the report reveals that Clinton's name does not appear in the bipartisan portions of the review.

The media's portrayal of the report has been a Rorschach test, with many outlets stretching to find signs of wrongdoing on Clinton's part. The Washington Post, for instance, acknowledged that the only references to Clinton came from partisan Republicans in an addendum, not from the review itself. Yet, headlines such as "For Clinton, Benghazi report has some good, mostly bad - but no ugly" and "Benghazi report ups pressure on Hillary" suggest a more damning narrative.

CNN's Wolf Blitzer described the report as "fueling heated debate, partisan debate, about her leadership," while correspondent Elise Labbott argued that Clinton would "have to address Benghazi during" any 2016 campaign. Washington Post blogger Jennifer Rubin even accused the media of being "incurious" when it comes to Clinton, labeling Benghazi as Clinton's "drip, drip, drip problem."

The question of "leadership" has been a lopsided one, with many media outlets using the Senate report as an indictment of Clinton's leadership. However, it is important to note that Clinton has acknowledged ultimate responsibility for any bureaucratic shortcomings that played a role in the tragedy in Benghazi.

What is problematic about the media's use of the Senate's review as a reflection on Clinton's leadership is that the reports ostensibly exploring Clinton's leadership make no mention of the fact that one of her last acts as Secretary of State was to fully accept and begin implementing the findings of the Accountability Review Board (ARB), an independent, nonpartisan review panel that looked into what went wrong and how to prevent a similar tragedy in the future.

The ARB, like the Senate report, also singled out bureaucrats, not the Secretary of State, for scrutiny over diplomatic security failures. Four mid-ranked department officials were suspended for those failures; according to Ambassador Thomas Pickering, one of the chairmen of the ARB, their "future careers [s]" are "finished."

One of the pillars of the right-wing's Benghazi hoax has been to accuse Clinton of being dismissive of the tragedy during her Congressional testimony when she asked, "What difference, at this point, does it make" what led the attackers to target the diplomatic facility on that day. Often left out of the sound bite is what Clinton said next: "It is our job to figure out what happened and do everything we can to prevent it from ever happening again."

The ARB laid out dozens of recommendations as to how to prevent future tragedies, recommendations largely in line with those contained in the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence report. Those recommendations are being implemented. It's woefully inadequate to leave that fact out of a discussion of leadership.

Title: Trump's Trade War with China: A Look at the Current State of Affairs

Article:

In March 2018, President Donald Trump declared that "trade wars are good and easy to win." However, over a year later, it appears that Trump is losing the trade war he initiated with China.

The tariffs imposed by Trump on Chinese goods have reportedly slowed China's economic growth, with most data sources indicating a slight dip in 2018. This slowdown could be due to the Chinese government's efforts to control credit growth, but many experts believe that Trump's tariffs have also impacted business confidence and investment.

The U.S., on the other hand, has also been affected by the trade war. The increased cost of Chinese-made products due to tariffs has led to higher prices for American consumers and factories. Two studies by trade economists suggest that the U.S. economy has suffered losses in the tens of billions of dollars annually due to the trade war.

China's retaliation has been particularly hard on American farmers, with the country halting most soybean imports from the U.S. Inventories have piled up, agricultural exports have declined, and farm incomes have suffered. Desperate farmers have appealed to Trump for help, to which he responded with direct payments. However, relying on government aid is not a sustainable business model, and farm bankruptcies have begun to rise.

China's autocratic regime and its residents' willingness to endure economic hardship have given it an advantage in a trade war with the U.S. Trump's trade truce with China, enacted in late 2018, left most of the U.S.'s key goals, such as intellectual property theft, currency manipulation, forced technology transfer, and access to the Chinese market, unfulfilled.

The trade war is not just about tariffs; it also involves the struggle to control the future of high technology. The U.S. has been trying to pressure American allies not to buy 5G wireless technology from Huawei Technologies Co., China's leading telecommunications manufacturer. However, Germany recently announced it would not shut Huawei out, dealing a significant blow to this effort.

The U.S. has also implemented export controls on many technology products, which could hurt Chinese tech in the short term but could also push China to accelerate its efforts to replicate and surpass U.S. technology. If China becomes a technological peer, its companies will begin to compete more directly with American ones, as Japanese companies did in the 1970s and 1980s.

In conclusion, Trump's trade war with China is showing signs of weakness on multiple fronts. While it has inflicted some damage, China has proven resilient and is now fighting back effectively. It appears that trade wars may not be as easy to win as Trump initially believed.

Title: Second Circuit Court of Appeals Ruling on Trump's Twitter Account: A Closer Look at the Legal Implications

Article:

In a unanimous decision, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that former President Donald Trump cannot block Twitter users from following his @realDonaldTrump account. While the decision, at first glance, appears to be a straightforward application of First Amendment law, it contains a crucial error that reflects a fundamental misunderstanding of speech on private social-media platforms.

Boiled down to its essence, the court's reasoning contained two key elements. First, it ruled that Trump's Twitter account represents an outlet for official communications and interactions that is controlled by President Trump. Second, it found that under these circumstances, Trump's decision to block users represents impermissible state action undertaken to suppress dissent.

However, the first element is fundamentally mistaken. By no traditional legal measure of "control," Trump does not control his Twitter account. Twitter owns and controls his account, and he has no legal right to wrest control of it from Twitter. The court's misunderstanding of the platform is made evident by this deeply flawed analysis.

The fact that government control over property is temporary, or that the government does not "own" the property in the sense that it holds title to the property, is not determinative of whether the property is, in fact, sufficiently controlled by the government to make it a forum for First Amendment purposes. Temporary control by the government can still be control for First Amendment purposes.

There is no "control" at all, temporary or otherwise. When a politician rents a theater or other private venue, there is typically an exchange of money and a rental agreement that explicitly grants enforceable legal rights to access the property and control others' access to the property, and—critically—limits the landlord's power during the course of the rental.

Compare that level of control to the absolute lack of rights the user has under Twitter's terms of service:

We may suspend or terminate your account or cease providing you with all or part of the Services at any time for any or no reason, including, but not limited to, if we reasonably believe: (i) you have violated these Terms or the Twitter Rules or Periscope Community Guidelines, (ii) you create risk or possible legal exposure for us; (iii) your account should be removed due to prolonged inactivity; or (iv) our provision of the Services to you is no longer commercially viable.

There is no exchange of money, the user has no right to the platform, and Twitter can not only eliminate your access entirely but censor any single tweet. If it chooses, it can even remove Trump's ability to block, mute, or take any other action. And that's not all—when you use Twitter, your speech isn't even purely "your" speech anymore. Twitter grants itself the right to your communications, too:

By submitting, posting, or displaying Content on or through the Services, you grant us a worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free license (with the right to sublicense) to use, copy, reproduce, process, adapt, modify, publish, transmit, display, and distribute such Content in any and all media or distribution methods (now known or later developed).

Writing in response to the trial court's ruling against Trump last year, law professor Greg Dolin compared Twitter to a radio call-in show that is hosting a government official as a guest. The politician has no right to be on the show, the host can send the politician packing at any time, and the host has ultimate control over not only the politician's presence but also any callers' speech. In other words, Trump remains on Twitter entirely at Twitter's discretion.

In that circumstance, there is no "public forum." There is instead a public official using a private platform to attempt to amplify his specific message, with the permission of the entity that controls the platform. The court's ruling, in this circumstance, represents government intervention in Twitter's control of its own service. The court is overriding the permissions Twitter gave its own user.

Moreover, the court gives short shrift to Trump's own free-speech rights under the government-speech doctrine. Again, to borrow one of Professor Dolin's analogies, "If a politician is holding a rally in a park (a traditional public forum), it doesn't follow that he must permit critics to share the stage with him." The Twitter thread beneath any tweet can undermine or amplify the president's chosen message. So long as Twitter grants the user the ability to regulate his or her Twitter replies, then that regulation is an integral part of the user's expression.

If, say, Kamala Harris wins the White House and Twitter permits her to use its services to announce that she's forming a committee to study the feasibility of reparations for slavery, does she then have to allow that thread to be hijacked by white nationalists and other vile alt-right voices? I say no. The Second Circuit says yes.

It's common for social-media users to use phrases like "my Facebook page" or "my Twitter feed." Yes, it is "my" speech on social media, but it is not my page or my feed. A private company is allowing a public official to use the private company's services to amplify his message. The private company is in legal control, not the public official, and if members of the public don't want to be blocked on a Twitter feed, they should take their objections to Twitter, not to federal court.

Title: "Brooklyn Resident Turns Passion for Food and Service into Philanthropic Cafe"

Article:

In a quiet corner of Park Slope, Brooklyn, resides a unique culinary venture, the brainchild of a young entrepreneur, Ms. Brodie. At 27, she has transformed her passion for food and service into a philanthropic cafe, providing not only a dining experience but also a platform for personal and professional growth for its students.

Ms. Brodie's journey began as a simple idea, one that she had long believed someone else would pursue. However, as she recounted during our conversation, her husband's question, "What are you waiting for?", spurred her into action.

Her family's history is deeply intertwined with food and service. Her grandmother, a South African, published a well-known cookbook in the 1960s, with proceeds benefiting the Union of Jewish Women. Her father, a teacher, instilled in her the importance of service by driving her to deliver leftover food from local restaurants to shelters. Sundays were spent giving cooking lessons to friends and delivering extra meals to shelters to share with residents.

Post-college, Ms. Brodie volunteered at a homeless shelter before working at the Human Rights Campaign in Washington. It was during this time that she was struck by the idea of a different approach to food distribution and service to the less fortunate.

With no formal background in the food industry, Ms. Brodie honed her skills at the Institute of Culinary Education in Lower Manhattan and attended a food business boot camp in Harlem. She also gained practical experience by working shifts at restaurants.

After months of brainstorming, networking, and countless emails, Ms. Brodie's vision became a reality in June. Nearly half of her students had received job offers before completing the program.

Ms. Brodie's cafe is more than just a place to eat; it's a testament to the power of passion, service, and the transformative potential of education. Her story serves as an inspiration to many, demonstrating that with determination and a willingness to learn, anyone can make a difference in their community.

Title: California Farmers Frustrated Over Delayed Compensation for High-Speed Rail Project

Article:

California farmers in the Central Valley are expressing their dissatisfaction over the state's seizure of their land for the high-speed railway project and the subsequent delay in compensating them for the seized property and related expenses. The farmers claim that the California High-Speed Rail Authority has offered various excuses for the delayed payments.

John Diepersloot, a fruit farmer who cleared a large parcel of his peach orchard for the train, told The Los Angeles Times, "I am out a quarter-million bucks on infrastructure, and they haven't paid a dime for a year. I don't have that kind of money."

Mark Wasser, a Sacramento-based attorney representing more than 70 farmers and businesses affected by the project, stated, "The property owners are very frustrated that the high-speed rail authority don't seem to know what they actually need. We have farmers who the authority has come back four times to change where they want to take."

Rail authority officials acknowledged the delayed payments but have not provided a reason for the delay. Don Odell, the authority's chief of real property, said in a statement to Fox News, "We strive to work closely with affected property owners to minimize the impact the project has on them and to ensure that they receive fair market value, consistent with state law, for their land and other expenses they incur due to the construction of the high-speed rail system."

California's high-speed rail project has been plagued with delays, shifting plans, and questions over cost and funding since its inception. The projected $79 billion project is years behind schedule, with the latest estimate for completion set for 2033.

In February, California Governor Gavin Newsom announced a plan to put the rail line between Los Angeles and San Francisco on hold in favor of a much-shorter line between the cities of Bakersfield and Merced. This move had Republican lawmakers in the Golden State calling for a referendum vote on the project.

In his State of the State address in February, Newsom argued against the frequent complaint that the Merced-Bakersfield line would be a "train to nowhere" and said that a high-speed railway would "form the backbone of a reinvigorated Central Valley economy."

President Trump labeled the entire high-speed rail project a "disaster" and called for Sacramento to return the funds given to the state by the federal government. In March, the head of the state's rail authority fired back at Trump's effort to block more federal dollars from going to the California project. The Federal Railroad Administration had given California $2.5 billion to construct a Los Angeles-to-San Francisco link, with another $929 million pledged. However, federal authorities and the president claimed the terms of the federal grant had not been met and threatened to withhold any future payments while demanding repayment for the funds already doled out to California.

Title: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo Faces Challenges as Democratic Party Shifts Left

Article:

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, who is heavily favored to win a third term in November, is facing challenges as the Democratic Party nationwide moves to the left. The incumbent Democrat spent $18 million to fend off a challenge from political novice Cynthia Nixon in a bitter primary contest.

During the campaign, Cuomo agreed to restore voting rights for parolees and moved closer to marijuana legalization. However, he may need to address concerns about his progressive credentials as the Democratic Party increasingly prioritizes issues like increased ballot access and single-payer healthcare.

Patrick Egan, a politics professor at New York University, stated, "If he wants to have a chance in a Democratic primary, as Democratic voters really turn to the left, he’s going to have to lay out some progressive credentials." Cuomo has denied any intention of running for president in 2020.

Cuomo won the primary against Nixon, but the active challenge from his left nearly cost him his lieutenant governor, Kathy Hochul, who held off an unexpectedly strong challenge from an insurgent candidate. The primary also resulted in losses for several Democrats in the state Senate who had caucused with Republicans, giving that party control of the state's upper chamber.
