The election of President Donald Trump has sparked a call to action for voters on the party's left flank. Voters in more liberal states like Florida and Georgia have nominated more progressive candidates for governor's races, and the movement has been seen in more conservative states as well.

In Oklahoma and West Virginia, teachers went on strike earlier this year to secure higher pay, and voters later defeated some lawmakers who voted against those efforts in Oklahoma's state contests. Grant Reeher, professor of political science at Syracuse University's Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs, noted, "One of the things I’ve been most struck by is how the reaction to Trump has so deeply affected state-level contests, even at the district level."

In New York, progressive anger was centered in the challenges to Democratic state senators who had handed the state's senate majority to Republicans. Several of those incumbents lost in Thursday's primary. The more liberal senate may help Cuomo, as he has positioned himself as a critic of President Trump.

The primary saw a significant increase in Democratic voter turnout, with nearly 1.5 million Democrats voting compared to less than 600,000 in 2014. Daniel Lewis, associate professor at Siena College, stated, "He was able to effectively run against Washington and the Trump administration, messaging that may have helped draw energy from Democrats eager to participate in elections this year to check the President."

Title: Obama Names Susan Rice as National Security Advisor Amidst Ongoing Controversy over Benghazi

Article:

President Barack Obama announced on Wednesday the appointment of Susan Rice as his new National Security Advisor, a move that has been met with criticism from Republican lawmakers over her role in the aftermath of the 2012 Benghazi terror attack.

Speaking in the Rose Garden, Obama praised Rice as a "tireless advocate" for advancing America's interests. Rice will replace Tom Donilon, who is stepping down from the post. Notably, Rice does not require Senate confirmation for the job, as she currently serves as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

Rice was initially considered for the position of Secretary of State, which does require Senate confirmation, but she withdrew from consideration amid the ongoing fallout from the Benghazi attack. In the aftermath of the attack, Rice appeared on five Sunday shows and stated that the attack was triggered by protests over an anti-Islam film, a narrative that many lawmakers at the time deemed inaccurate.

The administration later acknowledged that there were no protests on the ground in Benghazi, though they have not officially ruled out the possibility that protests elsewhere may have played a role. Republicans have criticized Rice for this account, with Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) accusing her of "misleading" the public on Benghazi.

In response to the news of Rice's appointment, Paul stated, "How are they going to have the authority for people to believe what they're saying, when he's promoting someone who directly and deliberately misled the public over Benghazi?"

The administration, under pressure from the media and Republicans, recently released the so-called "talking points" that showed officials drafting and re-drafting their storyline in advance of Rice's appearances. The intelligence community did cite demonstrations, but references to militant and Islamic extremist groups, and to prior security warnings and incidents, were ultimately removed after objections from various administration officials.

It remains unclear to what extent Rice was involved in this process. Officials, speaking in her defense, have stated that she was merely citing the assessment she was given on Sept. 16.

Meanwhile, former Obama aide Samantha Power has been nominated to succeed Rice as U.S. ambassador to the U.N. Power was an aide to the Obama campaign in 2008 but resigned after a report was published in which she called then-candidate Hillary Clinton a "monster."

A senior official told Fox News that Donilon decided to leave the National Security Advisor post after his wife took a job that involves a lot of foreign travel. Donilon has been in the administration since the start, first as deputy national security adviser.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Express Concern Over Classified House Intelligence Committee Memo

Article:

A classified report compiled by the House Intelligence Committee has raised concerns among Republican lawmakers, who describe its contents as "shocking" and "explosive." The report, which is said to detail extensive Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) abuse, has been the subject of discussions among Republican representatives since Thursday.

According to National security journalist and Fox News contributor Sara Carter, the memo contains information about the Department of Justice (DOJ) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), as well as the infamous Trump-Russia dossier. Carter reports that sources have suggested the memo could potentially lead to the end of Robert Mueller's Special Counsel investigation into President Trump and his associates.

Texas Rep. Louie Gohmert and Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz are among the lawmakers who have publicly expressed their concerns about the report. Gohmert tweeted a link to Carter's story, urging the release of the memo. Gaetz called for the document to be made public, stating that the facts contained in the memo are "jaw-dropping" and demand full transparency.

Florida Rep. Matt Gaetz also issued a statement on his congressional website, writing that the House must immediately make the memo publicly available. He expressed belief that the release of the information is necessary to preserve democracy.

Pennsylvania Rep. Scott Perry told Fox News that the contents of the report are "alarming," likening the situation to the actions of the KGB. North Carolina Rep. Mark Meadows told Fox News that the report is "troubling" and "shocking."

The classified report is currently classified as Top Secret, and some lawmakers, including Rep. Ron DeSantis, have called for its public release as soon as possible. The report is said to raise serious questions about the upper echelon of the Obama DOJ and Comey FBI as it relates to the so-called collusion investigation.

Title: Paul Ryan's Shift in Political Ambitions: Focus on Congressional Leadership and Policy Influence

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Paul Ryan, the Republican Vice Presidential nominee in 2012, appears to be steering away from a potential White House bid and instead, is showing a growing interest in wielding influence within Congress. According to close associates, the grueling nature of presidential campaigns holds little appeal for Ryan, with one conservative source stating, "He has no interest in the sheer grind of campaigning. It's hard to see him having 'what it takes.'"

Rather than pursuing the presidency, Ryan seems to be captivated by the prospect of amassing power within Congress, using his influence in the House leadership to champion his signature Medicare plan and implement spending cuts. This strategy could eventually lead him to a bid for House GOP leader or even Speaker, a position he has reportedly warmed to since the 2012 election.

Since his return from the failed vice presidential run, Ryan has found himself in a central role among House Republicans. He played a significant part in devising the GOP's new debt ceiling strategy and will shape a budget plan that will guide the GOP caucus on key issues. This growing influence within the party has led Ryan to believe that a national political ambition might dilute his growing power as an unofficial wingman to Speaker John Boehner.

While Ryan continues to cultivate a national political and financial network, he has shown no signs of abandoning his congressional role. A top GOP source revealed that Ryan recently met with Spencer Zwick, Mitt Romney's fundraising guru, who expressed that a significant portion of the 2012 donor base is ready to back Ryan should he reconsider a White House run. Ryan also made a fundraising trip to Texas last month for his Prosperity PAC, where he was encouraged by top Romney donors to run for higher office.

Although some conservatives suggested Ryan challenge Boehner immediately after the election, this is not a move Ryan would make. However, in conversations with longtime associates, a shift in Ryan's mood has been noticed. He seems open to eventually running for leadership, suggesting to two friends that this is the best and safest way to get Medicare and budget cuts done.

Ryan would not challenge Boehner or his No. 2, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, for their current positions. However, many Republicans believe Boehner may leave in a few years, perhaps after the 2014 election, to make way for the next generation of leaders. The safest path of all, according to these Republicans, would be Ryan's current trajectory: running the Budget Committee until 2014 and then taking over the Ways and Means Committee, where he could shape tax policy as he did for entitlements and spending.

Title: Graham Calls for Special Counsel to Investigate FBI and DOJ, Citing Bias in 2016 Election Probes

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) has called for Congress to establish a special counsel to investigate the FBI and the Department of Justice (DOJ) over allegations of bias during the 2016 election campaign. Graham's call comes as newly released documents reveal the extent of anti-Trump sentiment among FBI employees who were instrumental in handling the investigation into Hillary Clinton's secret email server and the Russia investigation that became Robert Mueller's special counsel probe.

The documents, which include transcripts of interviews with fired FBI agent Peter Strzok and former FBI lawyer Lisa Page, show they were determined to prevent Donald Trump from becoming president and had impeachment on their minds once he took office.

Graham, speaking on the Senate floor, argued that Robert Mueller has had his chance to investigate President Trump, and it's now time to turn the microscope on the other side. He plans to introduce legislation to create another special counsel for this purpose.

"There's more than smoking guns here. There's overwhelming evidence that somebody outside the political system should look into," Graham said.

The Mueller investigation appears to be winding down, and Democrats are trying to ensure the findings are made public. The Democrat-led House approved a resolution Thursday morning urging Attorney General William P. Barr to release Mueller's final report. The resolution passed unanimously.

However, when Senate Democrats attempted to raise the issue in the upper chamber, Graham objected. He said he would have allowed it if Democrats, in exchange, supported the special counsel Graham wants. Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-NY) refused.

"We let [Robert] Mueller look at all things Trump related to collusion and otherwise. Somebody needs to look at what happened on the other side and find out whether the FBI and the DOJ had two systems—one supporting the person they wanted to win, and one out to get the person they wanted to lose," Graham said.

In remarks to The Heritage Foundation, Graham also announced that his committee will hold hearings on bias at the FBI and the DOJ. The hearings will focus on whether the bureau misled judges when it obtained a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant to spy on Trump campaign figure Carter Page.

Graham promised that the Senate will get to the bottom of how the FBI obtained the warrant using a salacious, unverified dossier written by former British spy Christopher Steele. The dossier is full of unsubstantiated claims about Trump's ties to Russia.

The FBI used the dossier as part of its argument to the court to obtain the surveillance warrant on Page, and used it in subsequent renewals of the warrant. The dossier claims Page met with Russian officials with ties to Kremlin strongman Vladimir Putin during the 2016 campaign. Page has vehemently denied the claim. It also claims longtime Trump fixer Michael Cohen met with Russians in the Czech Republic to coordinate plans—a charge he also has denied and has continued to deny even since turning against Trump.

Republicans have claimed the FBI has failed to disclose that the dossier's author was being funded by the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign as opposition research. The dossier, along with texts between Strzok and Page, are among the Republicans' top evidence for alleged misconduct at the FBI and DOJ.

The House Judiciary and Oversight and Government Reform committees, when they were controlled last year by Republicans, called in Strzok and Page to give testimony about their own behavior. Those transcripts were secret until this week, when Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, now the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, inserted them into the Congressional Record.

In a transcript released Thursday, Strzok said his favorable opinion of Clinton did not influence the investigation into her use of her home server to send classified emails. However, he acknowledged that Clinton was not a target, subject, or suspect during the investigation. Instead, investigators viewed her as "a critical player."

He also disputed assertions that his texts to Page showed animus toward Trump—though his memory didn't jibe with that of Page, with whom he was having an adulterous affair at the time. She testified that a text she sent to Strzok telling him the Trump investigation would save the country from a "menace" referred to Trump. Strzok told the committee that he thought the menace was Russia.

Strzok also disputed the meaning of the now-famous text in which Page fretted Trump would win the election. The former G-man responded "No. No he won't. We'll stop it." This has been widely taken to mean the FBI would do what it had to do to prevent a Trump victory. While Strzok said in his testimony that he didn't recall writing the text, he did add that he believes the "we" he meant was the American voters.

"My answer 'No' was my personal belief that I did not think he would be," the fired agent said, adding later, "My best sense looking at this text that I didn't recall until I read it very recently was that 'we' is my belief that the American people—there is no way that they're going to elect him."

"What it is not is any statement that I would ever consider, let alone take any official action, to impact the presidency of the United States," he said.

Title: The Return of the Government Shutdown: A Specter of the Past or a Hero of the Future?

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, the specter of a federal government shutdown has once again emerged in the nation's capital, after a four-year hiatus. The looming threat, often maligned and shunned by the political establishment, has sparked a flurry of activity in Washington D.C., reminiscent of a classic Western showdown.

The catalyst for this political drama, as per President Donald Trump, is a $1.6 billion demand for a border wall. This wall, as many may recall, was initially promised to be funded by Mexico. However, given the numerous assurances during the campaign that Mexico would foot the bill approximately 6,256,765 times, the current demand for U.S. funding might seem somewhat confusing.

The prospect of a government shutdown, if it were to occur, would be an unusual one, marked by a mix of humor and concern. While longtime politicians typically react with peeved dismissal or unmitigated horror to the idea of a government shutdown, some are hedging their bets on this particular instance, which, as previously stated, is almost spectacularly peculiar.

A look back at the last federal government shutdown in 2013 reveals a media-fueled panic, accompanied by an abundance of inside-the-Beltway lamentation. The shutdown was portrayed as a catastrophic event that would lead to mass chaos, disorder, and tragedy. However, upon closer examination, it appears that the majority of the government continued to function during the shutdown, and the nation managed to survive.

The 16-day shutdown, as many were warned, did not result in the political downfall of the Republicans, who ultimately recovered from their post-shutdown poll dip and went on to take back the Senate. The nation, thankfully, dodged the predicted mass tragedy. Washington D.C. returned to its usual business of self-importance, back-slapping, business-card swapping, and squandering money.

However, the shutdown did serve as a reminder that many government officials may be full of hot air, and that expansive government bureaucracies might not be as important as they claim. The shutdown also highlighted the potential for Americans to question the necessity of certain government functions and expenditures.

As for the current government shutdown threat, we will have to wait and see how events unfold. In the meantime, it is worth noting that some states, such as Texas, manage to function effectively with a legislature that shuts down every other year. The nation, it seems, can survive without the constant presence of its political leaders.

Title: Senate Democrats Seek to Delay or Repeal Parts of ObamaCare, Particularly the Medical Device Tax

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Senate Democrats who were instrumental in the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare) are now expressing doubts about the tax increases embedded in the legislation, particularly the medical device tax which is set to increase on January 1.

Senators such as Al Franken (D-MN), Dick Durbin (D-IL), Charles Schumer (D-NY), Patty Murray (D-WA), John Kerry (D-MA), Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Debbie Stabenow (D-MI), Richard Blumenthal (D-CT), and others, who all voted in favor of the law, are now aiming to delay or repeal parts of ObamaCare.

One of the first provisions to be repealed was the Community Living Assistance Services and Supports (CLASS) Act, a long-term care insurance measure that was initially projected to reduce the deficit. However, after the bill passed, it was revealed to be a disaster, and it was subsequently repealed.

Another contentious provision was the so-called "1099 provision," which would have required small businesses to file numerous new forms for various transactions. This provision, intended to pick up taxable transactions, was also repealed.

Now, health-care industry lobbies that supported the subsidy-and-mandate-laden bill are lobbying to kill the cost-control measures that offset the costs of its subsidies. The Independent Payment Advisory Board, a cost-control measure, is a target for many providers. Additionally, the medical-device industry has convinced two Democratic Obamacare-backing Senators to attempt to repeal the medical device tax.

David Bowen, who helped to craft the legislation, admitted after ObamaCare passed that it was not a cost reduction bill but a coverage bill. He explained that Senate Democrats had planned to provide insurance coverage first, "knowing that that would bring on a cost battle second."

The increased costs in Massachusetts' RomneyCare, which served as a model for ObamaCare, have led to never-before-seen controls on insurers and health care providers, as well as tax increases. As Senate Democrats have become more familiar with what is in ObamaCare, the cost-control measures have gradually been stripped from the legislation.

One of the most damaging taxes in the long term is the medical device tax. The tax, which is expected to double due to the Taxmageddon increase, will impose a 2.3% tax on gross receipts, rather than profits. This tax will be imposed even if a company sells its products at a loss, ensuring that the tax is deceptively large.

A recent study found that investment in medical research and development will fall by $2 billion per year due to the device tax—a cautious estimate. The tax's adverse effect on investment will keep expensive medical devices from becoming affordable and widely available in the future.

More immediately, the device tax will increase the cost of essential medical products for consumers. Taxes on companies often end up being passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices, and the device tax is no different. The actuary for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services made it clear that Obamacare's "fees and the [device] tax would generally be passed through to health consumers in the form of higher drug and device prices and higher insurance premiums."

The medical device industry is expected to be forced to fire between 14,500 and 47,100 workers due to the tax, according to one study. This could result in a shortage of medical device engineers, leading to a decay of medical device innovation and a decrease in life-saving devices.

While Democrats' efforts to repeal the medical device tax are welcome, the challenge remains to find a way to pay for ObamaCare without imposing such burdensome taxes.

Title: Mitt Romney Faces Challenges in Utah Senate Bid as State Auditor John Dougall Contemplates Primary Challenge

Article:

Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, has announced his candidacy for the Senate seat in Utah, a move that shows his sensitivity towards being labeled a carpetbagger. In a video shared on social media on Friday, Romney emphasized his connection to Utah, highlighting the state's unique character, work ethic, and community spirit.

However, Romney's candidacy is not without controversy, as two prominent Republicans have raised questions about his commitment to Utah and his criticism of President Donald Trump. State Auditor John Dougall is one such Republican, who has expressed interest in challenging Romney in the primary election.

Dougall, in a telephone interview on Friday, stated, "Some of the key things in Utah are that we want to make sure we have a senator who understands Utah issues, and those are clearly different than Massachusetts issues, for instance." He added that Romney had called him on Thursday evening to inform him of his impending announcement.

When asked about the encouragement he is receiving, Dougall declined to reveal the sources but suggested it would come from those concerned about electing someone not aligned with Trump. For weeks, Dougall has been vocal on his Facebook page against a "coronation" of Romney, arguing for a clear understanding of Romney's political stance.

Earlier this week, Utah Republican Party Chair Rob Anderson spoke dismissively of Romney's Utah credentials in an interview with the Salt Lake Tribune, stating, "I think he’s keeping out candidates that I think would be a better fit for Utah because, let’s face it, Mitt Romney doesn’t live here, his kids weren’t born here, he doesn’t shop here."

In response, Anderson later stated, "I’ve no doubt that Mitt Romney satisfies all qualifications to run for Senate, and as chairman of the Utah Republican Party, I will treat all candidates equally to ensure their path to the party nomination is honest and fair."

The primary election in Utah is expected to be a significant test of Romney's ability to overcome perceptions of being a political outsider in the state. Despite Romney's long-standing ties to Utah, the Democratic party is unlikely to pose a significant challenge for the Senate seat.

Title: Mitt Romney's Overseas Trip: A Focus on Foreign Policy and Fundraising Amidst Domestic Economy Concerns

In the lead-up to the 2012 presidential election, former one-term Governor Mitt Romney embarks on an overseas trip, a move aimed at highlighting his foreign policy positions. This journey, however, may prove challenging for Romney, as domestic issues, particularly jobs and the economy, remain a priority for American voters.

The itinerary includes stops in Israel, Poland, and London, with the former two destinations chosen to contrast Romney's foreign policy vision with President Obama's, particularly in relation to the Middle East peace process, the Arab Spring, and the American relationship with Russia.

Romney's advisers acknowledge the political risks of criticizing a sitting president abroad, but they believe that the candidate can make his points without explicit attacks. The trip also offers an opportunity to tap into the deep pockets of wealthy American expatriates, a strategy employed by both John McCain and Barack Obama during their previous campaigns.

The trip may present challenges for Romney, who has not spent his career focusing on national security issues. His earlier claim that Russia is the nation's "No. 1 geopolitical foe" drew criticism from foreign policy experts and even some Republicans.

The contrast between Romney and Obama is not entirely beneficial, as the latter's successes in the raid to kill Osama bin Laden and the winding down of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have been widely popular. Romney's absence from Afghanistan and Iraq may necessitate addressing his views on troop withdrawals.

The overseas trip also risks diverting attention from the domestic economy, a topic that Romney has emphasized as a key campaign issue. While Romney may discuss economic issues such as trade policy and the global banking system, Americans grappling with job loss or mortgage difficulties may find little relevance in his foreign policy discussions during his time abroad.

In contrast, President Obama will have the campaign trail to himself during Romney's absence, with a West Coast swing across Nevada, California, Oregon, and Washington, as well as stops in Louisiana before returning to the White House. Both candidates will speak early in the week at the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Reno, Nevada, but Romney's departure for Europe on Tuesday will leave Obama as the only candidate on the campaign trail.

Title: Post-Election Lunch at the White House: A Tradition of Polite Discourse and Policy Discussions

Article:

In a Washington tradition, President Obama is set to have lunch with congressional leaders at the White House on Friday, following the power shift away from his party. These post-election meetings, while often marked by a degree of awkwardness, serve as a platform for leaders to discuss policy matters and set the tone for the upcoming legislative session.

The discussions that take place behind closed doors can be frank, with the president advocating for his agenda, while the new majority presents its own legislative priorities, backed by the mandate of the voters. Despite the potential for contentious exchanges, these meetings are characterized by a spirit of professionalism and a shared goal of legislating effectively.

In the past, leaders have described these meetings using diplomatic terms, such as "very positive," "friendly," and "constructive." For instance, former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich once said, "I thought it was a very positive meeting." Similarly, former Speaker Nancy Pelosi described her meeting as, "We both extended the hand of friendship." Former President George W. Bush also noted, "I would call it a very constructive and very friendly conversation."

Sheila Burke, who served as chief of staff to Bob Dole, likens these meetings to a blend of camaraderie and tension, referring to them as "Kumbaya with an edge." In 1994, when Dole became majority leader of the Senate, he and Gingrich met with President Bill Clinton, marking the beginning of a contentious but ultimately productive relationship.

Bob Dole, after his meeting with Clinton, stated, "I think the president understands that we're going to hit the ground running." This relationship proved particularly fruitful, as they collaborated on significant legislation, such as welfare reform.

In 2006, when Nancy Pelosi visited the White House as the first female speaker of the House, she and President Bush discussed the challenges that lay ahead, with Pelosi expressing the Democrats' intent to pass bills on issues like raising the minimum wage. Bush signed these bills into law, marking a solid working relationship between the two parties.

John Lawrence, Pelosi's former chief of staff, emphasized the strength of this relationship, stating, "That level of trust and collaboration could not have been constructed if there had not been a harmonious working relationship, notwithstanding policy differences." This relationship was put to the test during the 2008 financial crisis, when Pelosi, at Bush's request, pushed through the TARP legislation.

As President Obama sits down with GOP leaders this Friday, there are numerous policy differences to discuss, including Obamacare and immigration. However, White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough remains optimistic, stating, "Judging from the conversations that he, the president, has been having and many of us have been having with our colleagues up on the Hill, I think it should be a productive conversation."

The menu for the lunch remains undisclosed, leaving the public to wonder if buttery biscuits or Kentucky bourbon will be served. Regardless, the focus remains on the discussions that will shape the legislative agenda for the coming years.

Title: CPAC 2020 Kicks Off with "America vs. Socialism" Theme, Focusing on Trump, Impeachment, and Conservative Values

Article:

The Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) commenced its four-day event on Wednesday, emphasizing an "America vs. Socialism" theme that aims to counter the perceived leftward shift within the Democratic Party, particularly its presidential candidates. The annual conservative gathering, held near Washington D.C., will feature speeches from President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, and a host of conservative figures, all aiming to argue against socialism.

Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union (ACU) that organizes the event, stated in an exclusive interview that the theme is intended to address the ongoing internal debates within the Democratic Party over big-government policies. The conference, which runs through Saturday, is set to delve into sensitive political territory, as the Democratic primary field grapples with the implications of socialist ideologies, as exemplified by front-runner Bernie Sanders' praise of Cuba's Fidel Castro and his policy proposals.

Schlapp emphasized that the conference will highlight the relevance of conservatism in the current political climate, stating that conservatism values the individual human being and upholds the rights to life, private property, and self-determination. In contrast, he argued, socialists believe in the federal government's entitlement to transform society.

In addition to socialism, the conference will address the impeachment proceedings against President Trump, with a focus on what Schlapp described as a "disgusting path" from 2015 onward to obstruct Trump, lie about him, and attempt a coup against him. The event will feature Republican lawmakers who have supported the president, including Reps. Mark Meadows, Jim Jordan, Devin Nunes, John Ratcliffe, and House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy.

As per tradition, the conference will conclude with a straw poll, allowing attendees to assess President Trump's performance. Notably, CPAC 2020 coincides with the South Carolina primary, the last early-state contest before Super Tuesday.

Title: Midterm Elections: A Look at the State of the Parties Ahead of Tuesday's Vote

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, the political landscape in the United States remains divided, with historical trends suggesting a potential loss for the incumbent party. However, a closer look at the performance of both parties reveals a different story.

On one side, the Republican Party, led by House Speaker Paul Ryan, has managed to deliver two significant legislative accomplishments under President Donald Trump's administration. The individual mandate, a contentious aspect of Obamacare, has been abolished, and Ryan's tax overhaul reduced the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, spurring economic growth.

The tax cut, combined with Trump's deregulation efforts, has led to strong growth, with consumer spending, capital investment, and exports all on the rise. Unemployment has dropped below 4%, and for the first time on record, job openings exceed the number of unemployed individuals seeking employment. This economic growth is reflected in the third quarter's 3.1% increase in wages and salaries, the highest jump in a decade.

On the other side, the Democratic Party has faced criticism for their focus on investigations and cultural issues rather than policy. Despite the 2016 election results, the party has not significantly adjusted their agenda, instead pursuing a series of conspiracy theories and championing controversial figures.

The Senate, controlled by the Republicans, has made significant strides in confirming Trump's judicial nominees, which could offer a rebalancing to the constitutional structure and help lower the temperature in the long term.

In contrast, the Democratic Party has been accused of undermining the legitimacy of the 2016 election and promoting divisive cultural issues. The party's response to the migrant caravan, for example, has been criticized as weak and out of touch with the concerns of many voters.

In the end, the midterm elections will determine the balance of power in Congress. While the Democratic Party may have a strong message for some voters, their approach to the 2016 election and their handling of cultural issues have raised concerns for many Americans. The Republican Party, on the other hand, has delivered on key legislative promises, particularly in the economic sphere.

As the nation prepares for Tuesday's vote, it is crucial to consider the performance of both parties and the impact they have had on the country. The outcome of the midterm elections will shape the direction of the United States for years to come.

Title: The Shift in Political Power: A Critical Examination of Executive Authority in the Modern Era

Article:

In the aftermath of the failed impeachment attempt against President Donald Trump, a critical question arises: Why haven't Democrats seriously considered the reverse - the potential reduction of power from the presidency? Over the past 33 months, the 45th president has been accused of various misconduct, including coordinating with the Kremlin, obstructing the Russia investigation, making controversial comments, and two articles of impeachment: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

However, what has been noticeably absent is a structural critique of the ever-accumulating executive branch power itself. Democrats may dislike Trump's use of authority, but they do not seem to desire less power in the White House, especially when they regain control. In fact, the opposite appears to be true.

During his response to Trump's State of the Union address, leading presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) criticized the president for not being punitive enough toward American companies. In her official Democratic Party response, Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer focused on the executive actions taken by Democratic governors in defiance of their legislatures, rather than Trump's perceived monarchical gestures during the speech.

The Democratic presidential field, with the notable exception of faltering front-runner Joe Biden, has been engaged in a race to see who can make the most elaborate promises of immediate executive action. The focus has shifted from 100 days to 100 hours, demonstrating a desire for swift action through executive orders rather than collaborative legislation.

On Day One, President Elizabeth Warren would wipe out student loans for 42 million people, ban fracking "everywhere," and block any future fossil fuel leases on public lands and offshore. Presidential hopeful Sanders' Day One list includes an executive order to "legalize marijuana in every state in this country."

While legalizing marijuana is a commendable and long-overdue idea, Sanders' method of achieving it is problematic. Federal law, including the Controlled Substances Act, is constitutionally required to originate from or be struck down by either Congress or constitutional amendment. A presidency with enough power to legalize Activity X irrespective of Congress or the desires of states is a presidency with enough power to criminalize that same activity when the other team wins. This seesaw of authoritarianism should be a concern for all.

Comparing the personal response to Trump's imperial actions with the structural reaction against President Nixon's reveals a stark contrast. In the wake of Watergate, Democrats (and some Republicans) embarked on a mission to prune back the runaway executive branch. The 1973 War Powers Resolution, the 1974 Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act, the 1974 upgrade of the Freedom of Information Act, and the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act were all enacted to reassert the legislative branch's authority and prevent governments from hiding their activities.

The 99% partisan impeachment process in both chambers of Congress and the Democratic presidential field's will to executive power are causes for concern for those who yearn for an independent legislature. If America is to break free from the populist seesaw, we will need to root less for politicians and more for the rules and mores that can restrain them.

Title: Bipartisan Discussions on Immigration Reform: Schumer, Ryan, and Gowdy Engage in Cross-Party Talks

Article:

In a significant development, Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer has been holding private talks on immigration with Republican Reps. Paul Ryan and Trey Gowdy. These discussions, which have not been disclosed until now, are part of a broader effort by key House Republicans to reach a deal with Democrats on immigration reform.

The talks, while not formal negotiations, provide a glimpse into the urgency and high stakes surrounding the immigration reform debate. The discussions, however, have not led to any agreement on contentious issues such as a pathway to citizenship for the estimated 11.7 million undocumented immigrants in the United States.

Sen. Schumer, who led immigration negotiations in the Senate in 2013, approached Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican, and the pair have met four times since then, according to multiple sources with knowledge of the talks. The discussions, which have encompassed various topics, including ice fishing and Asian carp, have immigration reform high on the agenda.

In a statement, Ryan spokesman Kevin Seifert confirmed the meetings, stating, "In 2013, Sen. Schumer reached out and Congressman Ryan agreed to talk with him. They discussed a number of issues, but with respect to immigration reform, Congressman Ryan made clear to Sen. Schumer that we’re doing things differently in the House."

Rep. Trey Gowdy, a South Carolina Republican and chair of the House Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security, has also met with Schumer. Gowdy, a respected figure on the right, has the ear of a broad swath of conservatives. Gowdy's office did not respond to an email regarding his discussions with Schumer.

In a statement, Gowdy spokeswoman Amanda Infield Duvall said, "Congressman Gowdy has met with people of all political persuasions on immigration. He meets with people all the time on the issue."

Schumer's office declined to comment on the talks with Ryan and Gowdy. A source close to the issue stated, "Sen. Schumer and Rep. Ryan did not negotiate any specifics of House legislation at all in these meetings."

The White House is also closely monitoring the developments in the House regarding immigration reform, with administration officials quietly taking the temperature of House Republicans. Katie Beirne Fallon, the president's new legislative affairs director, discussed immigration with top aides and lawmakers in Republican leadership during her first rounds on Capitol Hill.

The lack of substantive, across-the-aisle discussions has been a concern for many, with Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) expressing doubts about the prospects of a bill passing in 2014. "The biggest impediment to making progress on immigration that I’ve seen over the last year... is a complete lack of confidence that the law will be applied, that the enforcement measures will happen," Rubio said on Monday. "And I think that’s only been exacerbated by the actions the president and this administration have taken over the last year."

These cross-party and cross-chamber talks, despite their limited scope, demonstrate a commitment by leading figures in both parties to find common ground. However, it remains unclear whether these quiet discussions will lead to a breakthrough.

Title: "Confederate Statues Vandalized Across Southern States: A Call for Peaceful Protest and Respect for Public Property"

Article:

In a series of events that have swept across several southern states, Confederate monuments have been defaced, toppled, or vandalized in the past week. The latest incident occurred in Birmingham, Alabama, where a statue of Confederate officer Charles Linn was defaced and removed from a public park on Sunday evening. This follows similar incidents in other states, including the Confederate Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Birmingham, a statue of General Robert E. Lee in Richmond, Virginia, and Confederate statues in North and South Carolina.

The destruction of these monuments is part of a wave of protests sparked by the death of George Floyd. While some argue that the removal of these symbols of the Confederacy will alleviate racial tensions, others contend that they are symbols of state heritage. The protesters' actions, however, have raised questions about the appropriateness of using violence and property destruction as a means of protest.

The deliberate destruction of public property is not only illegal but also goes against the Lockean idea that property, both private and public, is sacred. Vandalizing property is a rejection of a fundamental principle of the American system and a disregard for the rule of law, which is toxic to the health of any republic.

In a civil society, citizens have the freedom to use their vote to change the government's decisions, but they also agree to submit to the state's judgment, even when they believe it to be in error. By vandalizing these statues, some protesters have shown that they are willing to break the law to prove their dissent. This spurning of the rule of law is harmful to the health of any republic and, if unchecked, could lead to further unforeseen consequences.

History has shown that revolutions that disregard basic rights to life and property can lead to chaos and devastating consequences. The French Revolution and the subsequent Reign of Terror serve as grim reminders that going beyond the law to address grievances can upset a nation's social and political order.

As citizens, we must remember that property, public and private, must be protected. If these Confederate statues are indeed causing discord, they should be removed in a manner determined by law. However, the wanton defacement and destruction of public property witnessed this week are as inexcusable as they are unlawful and unethical, and such vandalism must not be permitted to continue.

Title: "A Call for Unity: Condemning Extremism on Both Sides of the Political Spectrum"

Article:

In the tumultuous year of 2017, the political landscape of America was marred by incidents that challenged the nation's collective values and tested the resilience of its institutions. This was a year when reason seemed to take a backseat to unreason, as political tribalism overshadowed human decency.

The tragic events in Charlottesville, Virginia, marked a turning point, not only for the loss of a young woman's life but also for the distortion of our political culture. The President's response to the white supremacist rally, where he referred to some participants as "very fine people," sparked widespread controversy and concern.

However, it was not just the far-right that drew criticism. Some on the left-wing spectrum, in their response to the far-right, found themselves aligning with violent extremists. The rise of Antifa, a far-left-leaning anti-fascist movement, and the support it received from certain quarters, led to a comparison with American heroes who stormed Omaha Beach.

In a series of tweets that have since aged poorly, Jeffrey Goldberg, the editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, expressed his concerns about the actions of Antifa and its supporters. He questioned whether any gathering of Trump supporters, regardless of their political affiliations, risked a violent response in blue enclaves, and whether authorities had ceded control of the streets to a Marxist/anarchist mob.

Goldberg's sentiments echo those of David French, a senior writer for ███ and a senior fellow at the ███ Institute, who also condemned the actions of Antifa. French argued that Antifa and its elite apologists were sending a message of hate and loathing to millions of Americans, and that they were competing with the alt-right for control of the political sewer.

In the face of such extremism, it is crucial to uphold the values of unity, human decency, and the rule of law. Condemning violence and extremism, whether it comes from the far-right or the far-left, is essential for the preservation of a peaceful and democratic society. It is our collective responsibility to ensure that we do not lose our way in the pursuit of justice and equality.

Title: President Trump to Attend March for Life, First President to Do So in Event's History

Article:

In a tweet on Wednesday, President Donald Trump announced his plans to attend the annual March for Life in Washington, D.C. on Friday. The event, themed "Life Empowers: Pro-Life is Pro-Woman," is an annual anti-abortion rally that attracts thousands of participants.

Trump's attendance will make him the first president to attend the march, according to Jeanne Mancini, president of March for Life. In 2018, Trump became the first president to speak at the march via video feed.

The administration has consistently worked to regulate or restrict abortion access since Trump took office. The President's expected attendance at the march comes after his return from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, and as the Senate impeachment trial into his conduct regarding Ukraine is underway.

Mancini expressed excitement about Trump's visit, stating, "He will be the first president in history to attend and we are so excited for him to experience in person how passionate our marchers are about life and protecting the unborn." A press release for the march states that Trump will speak at the event.

House Minority Whip Steve Scalise, a Louisiana Republican, and GOP Rep. Chris Smith of New Jersey are also scheduled to speak at the march.

Marjorie Dannenfelser, the president of the anti-abortion group Susan B. Anthony List, described Trump's presence at the March for Life as a "watershed moment for the Pro-life Movement." Dannenfelser previously served as the national chairwoman of the 2016 Trump campaign's Pro-life Coalition.

Abortion rights activists criticized Trump's announcement, with NARAL Pro-Choice America President Ilyse Hogue calling it "an act of desperation." Hogue accused Trump of "turning to deception and disinformation about abortion to gin up a vocal and extreme minority as he faces the escalating reality that his presidency is crumbling around him."

Planned Parenthood Action Fund, the political arm of the nonprofit reproductive health care organization, tweeted that "since day one, the Trump-Pence administration has sought to undermine our access to health care, including safe, legal abortion." The group added, "But the 77% of us who support that access will have our say in November. Let's make sure that next year, he's there as a private citizen."

Title: House and Senate Face Impasse Over Government Funding and Obamacare Defunding

Article:

The U.S. House of Representatives could vote as early as this week on a short-term spending bill to avert a government shutdown, while simultaneously attempting to defund the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. However, the Senate is unlikely to support any proposal that does not fund the health care law, increasing the possibility of a government shutdown.

House Speaker John Boehner and other top House Republican leaders have been grappling with the challenge of avoiding a showdown over the health care law, spearheaded by President Barack Obama, and funding legislation that needs approval before the end of the fiscal year on September 30 to prevent a shutdown.

Last week, a significant number of House Republicans threatened to defeat the stop-gap measure because it did not directly link continued government funding with a ban on money for the new health care law. This reversal demonstrates the continued inability of Boehner to rally hard-line conservatives who insist the spending bill prohibit all Obamacare funding.

No decisions have been made, or will be made, until House Republican members meet and discuss the issue tomorrow, according to Michael Steel, Boehner's spokesman. House Republicans are scheduled to discuss the next steps on a vote on the "continuing resolution" Wednesday morning, with a Friday vote on a measure to fund the government through mid-December being the target.

However, the measure is unlikely to go far in the Senate, as majority Democrats have made it clear that any attempt to defund the new health care law is a non-starter. A senior House GOP aide expects Senate Democrats to strip the Obamacare defunding language and potentially send the spending bill back to the House with other changes.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid invoked Albert Einstein's definition of insanity when referring to House Republicans on Tuesday, accusing them of doing the same thing over and over—trying to defund Obamacare—and expecting a different result.

Another idea gaining traction, which is likely to be brought up as this fight plays out, is attaching a one-year delay of Obamacare to legislation that would raise the nation's borrowing authority.

President Obama, in a statement on Monday, criticized the Republican strategy, stating, "You have some Republicans in the House of Representatives who are promising to shut down the government at the end of the month if they can't shut down the Affordable Care Act. And if that scheme does not work, some have suggested they won't pay the very bills that Congress has run up, which would cause America to default on its debt for the first time in its history."

As the deadline for the end of the fiscal year approaches, the situation remains uncertain, with some Republican representatives, such as Louisiana's John Fleming and Steve Scalise, advocating for attaching a full delay of Obamacare for a year to the debt ceiling increase. The debate continues, and the outcome remains to be seen.

Title: North Korea's Economic Focus Amid Tensions: A Shift in Rhetoric and Actions

Article:

North Korea, in the midst of ongoing regional tensions with both the United States and South Korea, has begun its annual spring parliamentary session. In a surprising turn of events, the ruling party has declared a stronger economy as a top priority, alongside the expansion of its nuclear arsenal. This shift in rhetoric, as reported by The Associated Press, suggests a more balanced approach towards economic development and nuclear development.

Recent weeks have seen North Korea issuing threats against the United States and South Korea, including plans to "cut off" hotlines with the South and to launch military strikes against the US mainland. The regime has also reaffirmed its commitment to its nuclear weapons, stating it will never relinquish them under any circumstances. However, the parliamentary focus on economic reform indicates that North Korea may not be as consumed by its own paranoia as its propaganda suggests.

The North has not yet followed through on its threat to close the Kaesong Industrial Complex, a site inside North Korea where South Korean companies and managers oversee manufacturing performed by North Korean workers. The complex remained open on Monday, despite Pyongyang's threat on Saturday to shut it down unless South Korea stops "damaging our dignity."

The Kaesong Industrial Complex is a critical lifeline for the North. If closed, the regime would lose some $87 million a year in wages from the 54,000 North Korean workers there. A worker makes an average of $134 a month, but most of this goes directly into the regime's coffers. The closure would also heavily impact the families of North Korean workers and residents in Kaesong and surrounding areas.

Meanwhile, both the US and South Korea have been showing signs of increased military strength in the region. South Korean President Park Geun-hye has stated that if any provocations occur, the response should be swift and powerful, without any political considerations. The South has also changed its military policies to allow for a quicker and more retributive response to North Korean aggression.

The US has sent a squadron of F-22 fighters to the region, and in recent weeks, the US Air Force has flown "Eisenhower-era B-52s," "Reagan-era B-2s," and "George W. Bush-era F-22s" over the Korean Peninsula.

This development comes as both the US and South Korea continue to engage in joint military exercises in the region, which have prompted strong protests from the North. The ongoing tensions and military maneuvers serve as a reminder of the delicate balance of power in the region and the potential for conflict.

Title: Trump Narrows Secretary of State Pick to ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson

Article:

NEW YORK — President-elect Donald Trump is reportedly zeroing in on ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson as his nominee for secretary of State. Tillerson had a second interview with the president-elect on Saturday at Trump Tower, and has emerged as the favorite in the long-running competition to lead the State Department, according to a person familiar with the transition deliberations who spoke to media outlets on condition of anonymity because Trump has yet to announce his pick.

In an interview with Fox News, Trump praised Tillerson, saying, "He's in charge of an oil company that's pretty much double the size of his next nearest competitor. It’s been a company that's been unbelievably managed." Trump also highlighted Tillerson's extensive experience in dealing with world leaders, particularly in Russia, where Tillerson has negotiated numerous deals for the oil company.

However, Tillerson's ties to Russia and his personal relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin are likely to draw scrutiny, especially given the ongoing allegations of Russian interference in the recent U.S. election. Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) told CNN that he has concerns about Tillerson's relationship with Putin, and that the issue will be examined during Senate confirmation hearings.

Trump's search for a secretary of State has included multiple interviews with other candidates, including Mitt Romney, Rudy Giuliani, Bob Corker, and David Petraeus. Giuliani, who withdrew from the competition on Friday, accompanied Trump to the Army-Navy game on Saturday.

Tillerson, who has no previous governmental or diplomatic experience, has worked for Exxon since graduating from college with an engineering degree in 1975. As CEO of ExxonMobil, Tillerson has negotiated with countries all over the world for oil exploration rights, particularly in the Middle East and Russia.

Of particular interest in his Senate confirmation hearings would be the $2.2 billion Exxon investment in Russian oil exploration in the Arctic Ocean, which Tillerson negotiated in 2011. That agreement, which also allowed Russian investment in other Exxon ventures around the world, was eventually scuttled after U.S.-imposed sanctions following Russia's annexation of Crimea.

Tillerson has been critical of international sanctions, saying they're difficult to impose fairly. He has acknowledged that climate change has been caused by human activity, and has endorsed a carbon tax as "the most efficient means of reflecting the cost of carbon in all economic decisions." However, environmental groups are expected to oppose his Senate confirmation if he's nominated.

The secretary of State is also responsible for advancing U.S. policy on human rights. Tillerson, himself an Eagle Scout, was president of the Boy Scouts of America at the time when it began allowing gay scouts, and in 2015 ExxonMobil changed its anti-discrimination policy to include gays and lesbians. However, the Human Rights Campaign remains skeptical of the company's policy, saying it was prompted by Obama's 2014 executive order targeting federal contractors, not a change in corporate values.

Title: Stark Divisions Emerge in American Identity as Democrats and Republicans Disagree on Essential Qualities of U.S.

Article:

A new survey by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research has revealed a deep divide in the American public's perception of the country's identity, with Republicans and Democrats holding starkly different views on what constitutes the essence of American identity.

While there is a shared belief among 7 in 10 people, regardless of party, that the U.S. is losing its identity, the survey found significant differences in the characteristics that Democrats and Republicans view as inherent to American identity.

Lynele Jones, a 65-year-old accountant from Boulder, Colorado, and a Democrat, pointed to diversity and openness to refugees and other immigrants as central components of being American. On the other hand, Reggie Lawrence, a 44-year-old Republican from Midland, Texas, who runs a business servicing oil fields, emphasized the role of Christian values and the Constitution in shaping the country's identity.

The survey found that about 65 percent of Democrats considered a mix of global cultures as extremely or very important to American identity, compared with 35 percent of Republicans. Conversely, 29 percent of Democrats saw Christianity as that important, compared with 57 percent of Republicans.

Democrats are also far more likely than Republicans to view the ability of people to come to the U.S. to escape violence and persecution as very important, with 74 percent of Democrats expressing this view compared to 55 percent of Republicans.

Regarding the country's early European immigrants, 25 percent of Democrats considered their culture very important, versus 46 percent of Republicans.

The poll also found that Democrats were nearly three times as likely as Republicans to view the U.S. as a country made up of many cultures and values that change as new people arrive, with far more Republicans favoring an essential American culture that immigrants should adopt.

Republicans overwhelmingly viewed immigrants who arrived in the past decade as having retained their own cultures and values rather than adopting American ones.

The survey also revealed that Democrats coalesce around a fear of the country's political leaders, political polarization, and economic inequality, while most Republicans point instead to illegal immigration as a top concern.

The AP-NORC poll of 1,004 adults was conducted from February 16-20, using a sample drawn from NORC's probability-based AmeriSpeak panel, which is designed to be representative of the U.S. population. The margin of sampling error for all respondents is plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.

Title: Critique of Obama's Unilateral Reversal of U.S.-Cuba Policy: A Look Beyond the Headlines

Article:

The recent announcement by President Obama regarding the unilateral reversal of U.S.-Cuba policy has sparked a heated debate, with critics arguing that the move is based on a flawed premise. The argument posits that engagement with authoritarian regimes like Cuba will not lead to democratic change.

The deal, as it stands, does not hold the Castro regime accountable for its human rights abuses and lacks commitments to democratic principles. Instead, it appears to have granted Raul Castro's regime all the concessions it sought, while the White House has failed to secure any significant concessions in return.

The deal's most controversial aspect is the swap of American citizen Alan Gross for the Cuban Five spies. Gross, who was arrested in 2009, was essentially a hostage, while the Cuban Five, who were convicted spies, received due process, including trial by jury. The administration's decision to commute the sentences of three convicted spies in exchange for Gross's release has been criticized for undermining justice for the families of the slain Brothers to the Rescue heroes, who were American citizens and a U.S. resident.

Moreover, the deal has been met with disapproval from leaders of pro-democracy efforts in Cuba. Jorge Luis Garcia Perez, also known as "Antunez," the leader of the largest resistance coalition in Cuba, stated that the deal is a betrayal that leaves the democratic opposition defenseless.

The deal's impact on the freedom-loving people of Cuba is a significant concern. The increased tourism promoted by the administration will likely serve as a propaganda coup for the Castro regime, especially at a time when the regime is struggling economically due to its ties with Venezuela and Russia.

The administration's actions have been criticized for failing to uphold democratic values and for setting a dangerous precedent that could embolden other authoritarian regimes. As the world's lone superpower, it is the U.S.'s role to promote democracy and freedom, not just where it is convenient for the president's legacy.

Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Florida and chairman of the Subcommittee on the Middle East and North Africa, has been vocal in her criticism of the policy. The legislative branch now has a role to play in opposing this overreach of executive action and reaffirming the need to continue defending freedom and democracy worldwide.

Title: Unannounced Meeting Between Jared Kushner and Saudi Crown Prince Raises Questions Over Classified Information Sharing

Article:

In late October, Jared Kushner, senior advisor to President Donald Trump, made an unannounced trip to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, causing some intelligence officials to be taken aback. According to reports, Kushner and the Saudi Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman (MBS) stayed up until nearly 4 a.m. several nights, discussing and strategizing.

Following this meeting, MBS reportedly told confidants that Kushner had discussed the names of Saudis disloyal to the crown prince. Kushner, through his attorney's spokesperson, has denied this claim.

Just a week after Kushner's return to the U.S., MBS launched an anti-corruption crackdown, arresting dozens of members of the Saudi royal family and imprisoning them in the Ritz-Carlton Riyadh. Several figures named in the President's Daily Brief were among those rounded up, with at least one reportedly being tortured.

Now, Congressional Democrats have asked FBI Director Christopher Wray to investigate whether Jared Kushner leaked classified information from the Presidential Daily Brief to the crown prince. In a letter to Wray, Democratic Reps. Ted Lieu, Gerald Connolly, Donald Beyer, Pramila Jayapal, Peter Welch, and Ruben Gallego requested an immediate investigation to determine if these reports are accurate and to explore the extent to which information and sources may have been compromised.

The letter notes that the "integrity of classified information" falls within the purview of the FBI, but that "while the President has the authority to declassify and share information, the President's advisers do not." If Kushner discussed names with MBS without presidential authorization, he may have violated federal laws around the sharing of classified intelligence.

The Intercept also reported that after the meeting, MBS bragged to the UAE Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed and others that Kushner was "in his pocket." Access to the President's Daily Brief is tightly guarded, but Trump has the legal authority to allow Kushner to disclose information contained in it. If Kushner discussed names with MBS as an approved tactic of U.S. foreign policy, the move would be a striking intervention by the U.S. into an unfolding power struggle at the top levels of an allied nation.

It is important to note that only months before this meeting, Jared Kushner sought a $500 million loan from officials in Qatar for a troubled New York City real estate project. This has led to speculation that Kushner may have been trading classified information for his own financial benefit, as Kushner has been seeking financing from around the world.

The FBI's investigation into these matters is crucial to ensure the integrity of classified information and to maintain the trust between the U.S. and its allies.

Title: Texas Governor Abbott Clarifies Constitutionality of New Sanctuary City Law, Rebuts Critics

Article:

In an exclusive interview with Breitbart Texas, Texas Governor Greg Abbott has clarified the constitutionality of the recently signed bill that outlaws sanctuary jurisdictions in the state. The new law, which creates civil and criminal penalties for those who refuse to cooperate with immigration officials, has been met with criticism from Democrat legislators and left-of-center Texas news outlets.

Governor Abbott addressed the concerns about the constitutionality of a provision in the law allowing police officers to inquire about the immigration status of someone they have detained. In response to claims that the law is unconstitutional due to states being pre-empted by federal law in the area of immigration, Abbott stated that the Supreme Court's ruling on the Arizona immigration law does not apply to the Texas law.

"The so-called controversial part of this law is what some label as the'show your papers' component," Abbott explained. "And what everyone seems to get wrong is they think that that provision was stricken down in the Arizona law. To the contrary, the provision in the Arizona law is stricter than the Texas law. The Arizona law required that law enforcement ask for papers. The Texas law does not require it, it allows it, so there is that one difference."

Abbott also reassured American citizens living in Texas that the bill does nothing to change their daily lives. "For American citizens, this bill has no impact on them whatsoever, and they have absolutely nothing to be concerned about," Abbott said. "There's only one group of people that is targeted by this legislation and that is people who are in this country illegally, who have committed violent crimes, and are subject to an ICE detainer request."

The law's author, Senator Charles Perry (R-Lubbock), confirmed that police can already inquire about the immigration status of a person they detain, and that the bill does not change anything in this regard. He also stated that citizens and legal residents do not need to carry papers to prove they are here legally.

The new law poses a threat to law enforcement officials who choose to ignore detainer requests on illegal immigrants in their jails from immigration officials. "All law enforcement officers are going to be required to follow this law," Abbott stated. "If they refuse to follow this law, or if they adopt sanctuary city policies, they are subject now to the stiffest penalties in America for adopting sanctuary city policies – which includes jail time where sheriffs could wind up in the same jail they may be releasing inmates from who are the subject of ICE detainer requests."

Governor Abbott believes this law will make Texas a safer place and help avoid tragedies like the murder of Kate Steinle by a previously deported illegal alien released from the local jail in a sanctuary city. "This law makes Texans safer because it prevents the types of policies that California has that lead to the tragic murder of Kate Steinle," Abbott said. "It prevents the types of policies that were adopted by the Travis County sheriff who had policies that release back out on the street, people who are either accused of, or even convicted of, very dangerous crimes."

The new sanctuary city law goes into effect on September 1, 2017.

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie Stresses Balance in Vaccination Policies Amid Measles Outbreak

Article:

During a recent trip to the United Kingdom, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie emphasized the need for a balanced approach in addressing parental concerns over vaccinations as the U.S. grapples with a resurgence of measles.

In response to a question about whether he would advocate for vaccinations in the U.S., Mr. Christie stated, "We vaccinate ours, and so, you know that's the best expression I can give you of my opinion." He further added, "You know it's much more important what you think as a parent than what you think as a public official. That's what we do. But I also understand that parents need to have some measure of choice in things as well, so that's the balance that the government has to decide."

When asked if he believes some vaccines are dangerous, Mr. Christie clarified that he did not make such a statement. "I said different disease types can be more lethal, so that the concern would be measuring whatever the perceived danger is by vaccine and we've had plenty of that over a period of time versus what the risk to public health is. You have to have that balance, and that's exactly what I mean by what I said," he explained.

His office later issued a clarification on the remarks, stating that Mr. Christie believes vaccines are an essential public health protection. Regarding measles, there is "no question" children should be vaccinated, according to the clarification. However, different states have varying vaccination requirements, which is why Mr. Christie called for a balanced approach in determining which vaccinations should be mandated by the government.

In a separate interview with NBC's Savannah Guthrie, President Obama advised parents to get their children vaccinated, stating that measles is "preventable" and that the science supporting vaccines is "pretty indisputable."

Title: Bipartisan Support for Intelligence Community as Trump-Russia Allegations Persist

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisan unity, the two top Republicans in Congress offered strong support for the intelligence community on Monday, in stark contrast to President-elect Donald Trump's criticism of the CIA following reports that the agency found the Russian government had attempted to help him win the presidency.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) expressed his "highest confidence" in the intelligence agencies, while House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) praised them for their diligent efforts in addressing cyber threats from foreign governments. Both leaders, however, cautioned against using the issue for partisan gain or casting doubt on the outcome of the election.

McConnell singled out the Central Intelligence Agency for praise and announced that the Senate Intelligence and Armed Services committees would investigate findings by intelligence agencies that Russia hacked into emails and computers used in the presidential campaign.

"Any foreign breach of our cybersecurity measures is disturbing, and I strongly condemn any such efforts," McConnell told reporters. He later added, "The Russians are not our friends."

The Washington Post reported on Friday that the CIA has informed senators that Russian President Vladimir Putin's government was actively seeking to help Trump win the election, a step beyond an earlier finding that the goal was to undermine the credibility of the U.S. political process.

"Any intervention by Russia is especially problematic because, under President Putin, Russia has been an aggressor that consistently undermines American interests," Ryan said in a statement on Monday. "As we work to protect our democracy from foreign influence, we should not cast doubt on the clear and decisive outcome of this election."

President Barack Obama explained his reasons for ordering a full review of the evidence of Russian hacking in an appearance on Comedy Central's "The Daily Show With Trevor Noah" on Monday night.

"The reason that I called for a review is really to just gather all the threads of the investigations, the intelligence work that has been done over many months, and put it in a single document that can be shared with members of Congress, relevant intelligence agencies, that can be shared with the transition team so that they understand what exactly happened and so that the public and our elected representatives going forward can find ways to prevent this kind of interference from having an impact on elections in the future," Obama said, according to excerpts released by Comedy Central.

Trump's team has attacked the CIA for its findings and questioned the agency's credibility, citing faulty intelligence analysis that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction before the 2003 invasion of Iraq. Trump tweeted on Monday, "Can you imagine if the election results were the opposite and WE tried to play the Russia/CIA card. It would be called conspiracy theory!"

Trump spokesman Jason Miller did not comment directly on McConnell's remarks when asked by reporters on a conference call on Monday, but criticized the reports about the CIA's findings.

"What this is is an attempt to try to de-legitimize President-elect Trump's win," Miller said. "That really seems to be what's going on here."

The White House defended the intelligence community on Monday, with press secretary Josh Earnest saying that spy agencies are staffed by "patriots."

"President Obama has benefited enormously from their work, their expertise, their advice, and their service to the country," Earnest told reporters. "I'm confident the president-elect would benefit from that advice if he remains open to it."

Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain (R-AZ) and the incoming Senate Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer of New York, said on Sunday in an unusual joint statement that the Senate would investigate Russia's interference in the presidential election.

A small group of Electoral College members, including Christine Pelosi, the daughter of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, on Monday requested a briefing from the intelligence community on the possible scope of Russian interference in the U.S. election. On Dec. 19, the electors meet across the country to formally select the president and vice president.

The allegations concerning Russia have taken on new significance now that Trump is considering Exxon Mobil Corp. chief Rex Tillerson for secretary of state. Tillerson is known for having ties to Putin, and the oil chief was awarded Russia's Order of Friendship, a high civilian honor given to distinguished foreign nationals. As recently as 2015, he visited with officials in Putin's inner circle.

If Trump does nominate Tillerson, the Russian allegations could pose problems for his Senate confirmation, even for some Republicans.

"I don't know the man much at all, but let's put it this way: If you received an Order of Friendship award from Putin -- then we'll have some questions," Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) said in a statement over the weekend. "I don't want to prejudge the guy, but that's a bit unnerving."

On Monday, Schumer made clear that Democrats also would question Tillerson's Russian ties.

"Every one of these nominees, and particularly a guy like Tillerson, needs a thorough, thorough hearing," Schumer said on CBS. "He'll be questioned thoroughly should he be the nominee, and all of these allegations and talks about his closeness with Putin will come forward."

McConnell declined to comment on the potential nomination of Tillerson, saying he wouldn't discuss a "phantom nominee."

Title: President Obama Seeks to Learn from Past Mistakes as He Faces Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

As President Obama prepares for a series of challenging talks on the debt ceiling and the impending fiscal cliff, the stakes are high. Lawmakers have until Dec. 31 to reach a deal to prevent $700 billion in federal budget cuts, a move that could almost certainly trigger a recession and set the tone for the beginning of Obama's second term.

Obama is reportedly approaching these talks with a newfound determination, aiming to rewrite history after the contentious debt ceiling talks in 2011. NPR's Mara Liasson told Guy Raz, host of weekends on All Things Considered, that the president is bringing lessons from those failed talks to the table.

"He's starting out with some clear bottom lines [and] he's not making concessions upfront the way he did with the stimulus package," Liasson said. "I think the president is getting a do-over, and also he's in a stronger position now."

The fiscal cliff negotiations will be a significant part of Obama's legacy, a legacy that every president begins to consider. In fact, during his first three years in office, Obama hosted small dinners at the White House, inviting noted presidential historians such as Doris Kearns Goodwin, Robert Caro, Michael Beschloss, and Robert Dallek.

According to Jodi Kantor, who reported on these dinners for The New York Times, the purpose of these gatherings was not merely for historical discussion. Instead, the president sought historical perspective to inform his strategy and learn from the mistakes and triumphs of his predecessors.

The historians primarily focused on transformative presidents like Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Ronald Reagan. During the third dinner, historian H.W. Brands suggested that President Roosevelt might be a better model for Obama's presidency.

Brands told Raz that Roosevelt was able to push the country and the government in a progressive direction while presiding over 7 1/2 years of peace and prosperity. Roosevelt also dealt with a hostile Congress, and, despite being a Republican, he supported universal health care.

The historians were honest with Obama, telling him that there was one quality they wished he shared more with Theodore Roosevelt: a stronger relationship with the American people. The president took this advice to heart, and a few months later, when laying out his vision for a second term in Osawatomie, Kansas, the president quoted from Teddy Roosevelt.

As Obama faces the fiscal cliff negotiations, he may find himself channeling some of that inner Roosevelt, as he negotiates with many of the same people in Congress as he did in 2011. The difference this time is the legacy he, and those in the debt talks, will leave behind.

Title: AOC Defends Campaign Activities Amidst Allegations of Election Law Violation

Article:

New York Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has come under scrutiny for her campaign activities, with her primary challenger, Michelle Caruso-Cabrera, accusing her of violating election law. The allegations stem from a graduation party AOC hosted over the weekend, which was held next to an early voting site.

In an interview with The Post, Ocasio-Cortez clarified her stance on debates, stating, "The good thing is I'm not skipping debates. My predecessor, he had skipped debates until he was forced to show up." The congresswoman is referring to her predecessor, Joe Crowley, who infamously skipped a debate in 2018, leading to his eventual defeat.
