However, Ocasio-Cortez has opted for virtual debates due to concerns over social distancing rules. She cited the ongoing phase one and phase two reopening guidelines issued by Governor Andrew Cuomo as the reason for this decision. The congresswoman has already participated in two online debates with her primary challengers, including one on May 18.

The Parkchester Times-sponsored debate, the same one Crowley shirked in 2018, is the one Ocasio-Cortez is currently avoiding due to social distancing concerns. Despite this, the congresswoman has been active in other group events, such as handing out masks to George Floyd protesters in Queens on June 2 and hosting a socially distanced graduation party in a church parking lot on Sunday.

Caruso-Cabrera, Ocasio-Cortez's well-funded challenger, has criticized the freshman rep for the alleged election law violation. "AOC directly violated the election law. She doesn't pay her taxes. She said yes to a salary increase. Who wants this type of person in Congress when we're all in trouble?" Caruso-Cabrera's spokesman, Hank Sheinkopf, told The Post.

A representative for Ocasio-Cortez did not return a request for comment on the alleged violation. The congresswoman's campaign activities continue to be a topic of discussion as the primary election approaches.

Title: Google Employees Urge Cancellation of Military AI Project, Citing Ethical Concerns

Article:

Thousands of Google employees have signed an open letter urging the tech giant to cease work on a military project involving the use of artificial intelligence to improve the precision of drone strikes. The project, known as Project Maven, has sparked controversy among Google's workforce, with employees expressing concerns about the company's involvement in warfare technology.

The letter, addressed to Google CEO Sundar Pichai, calls for the cancellation of Project Maven and the establishment of a clear policy prohibiting Google from developing warfare technology. The letter, which has been signed by 3,100 employees, including "dozens of senior engineers," according to the New York Times, states that staff have already raised concerns with senior management internally. Google employs over 88,000 people worldwide.

The letter argues that Google should not be involved in warfare, stating, "We believe that Google should not be in the business of war." The employees contend that the company's involvement in Project Maven puts users' trust at risk and ignores Google's "moral and ethical responsibility."

"We cannot outsource the moral responsibility of our technologies to third parties," the letter states. "Google's stated values make this clear: every one of our users is trusting us. Never jeopardize that. Ever."

The letter further argues that using Google's technology for military surveillance and potentially lethal outcomes is unacceptable. Google confirmed in March that it was allowing the Pentagon to use some of its image recognition technologies as part of a military project, following an investigative report by tech news site Gizmodo.

In response to the concerns, Google's cloud business head, Diane Greene, assured employees that the technology would not be used to launch weapons or operate or fly drones. However, the employees who signed the letter feel that the technology's use in military applications still poses ethical dilemmas.

Google maintains that Project Maven is for non-offensive purposes and uses open-source object recognition software available to any Google Cloud customer. The models are based on unclassified data only, and the technology is used to flag images for human review, with the intention of saving lives and reducing the need for humans to perform tedious work.

Google is currently engaged in a comprehensive discussion about the development and use of its machine learning technologies, and is also seeking input from outside experts as it develops policies for their use. The company's spokesperson stated, "Any military use of machine learning naturally raises valid concerns. We're actively engaged across the company in a comprehensive discussion of this important topic and also with outside experts, as we continue to develop our policies around the development and use of our machine learning technologies."

Title: Senate Approves Impeachment Trial Plan for Trump, Setting Stage for Oral Arguments

Article:

In a late-night session on Tuesday, the U.S. Senate, along party lines, voted 53-47 to approve Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's impeachment trial plan for President Donald Trump. The decision paves the way for oral arguments to commence as early as Wednesday.

The Senate rejected 10 Democratic amendments to the trial plan by the same margin. An 11th amendment, proposed by Senator Susan Collins (R-ME), aimed at extending the timetable for the prosecution and defense to file trial motions, received one Republican vote but ultimately failed.

At the core of the trial are charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, which the Democratic-led House approved last month. The charges allege that President Trump abused the power of his office by pressuring Ukraine to investigate his political rivals, withholding military aid and a White House meeting as leverage. The president is also accused of concealing his actions from Congress by blocking witness testimony and documents.

President Trump's legal team argues that the charges are baseless and equate to criminalizing a president's prerogative to make foreign policy. In a departure from most constitutional scholars, they also claim that the impeachment is unconstitutional because the articles of impeachment do not outline a specific violation of a law.

Tuesday's debate primarily revolved around what constitutes a fair trial.

"This initial step will offer an early signal to our country," said Mr. McConnell before the proceedings began. "Can the Senate still serve our founding purpose?"

Senator McConnell also experienced a reminder of the inherent unpredictability of the trial, as he was compelled to make last-minute changes to the trial rules under pressure from Republican moderates. The initial rules would have condensed opening arguments by both sides into two 12-hour marathon days. Mr. McConnell's rules also would have refused to admit the findings of the House impeachment inquiry as evidence without a separate vote during the trial.

Title: Graduate Student Workers at Harvard End Strike Despite Lack of Contract Agreement

Article:

BOSTON – After 29 days of striking, graduate student workers at Harvard University have returned to work on Wednesday, despite the fact that the university and the union have not reached an agreement on a new contract. The strike, which began on December 3, marked the first strike of graduate students on the Ivy League campus since 1973.

The union, the Harvard Grad Students Union-UAW, has hailed the strike as a victory, pointing to agreements reached in negotiations and a statement from Harvard on December 19 that named the end of January as a possibility for finalizing a contract. In an email to supporters on Monday, members of the bargaining committee vowed to "hold them accountable to this stated goal."

The decision to call off the strike came after the union agreed to let federal mediators assist in negotiations. The school's spring semester begins this month.

The graduate students, who include teaching assistants, teaching fellows, tutors, and researchers, are seeking a $25-an-hour minimum wage, expanded health care benefits, and new employment protections.

Harvard has not set a deadline for finalizing a contract, and similar contracts at other universities can take 12 to 18 months to complete. The union has singled out a statement from Harvard Provost Alan Garber that finalizing a contract is "something that we hope can be resolved in the month ahead."

The strike resulted in six tentative agreements on different parts of the contract, along with others reached before the work stoppage. Harvard has committed to begin mediation for the full contract on Tuesday.

The union has sought a collective bargaining agreement with several guarantees that have proven to be sticking points during negotiations, including a $25 minimum wage for hourly workers, expanded health care benefits, and stronger protections against sexual harassment and discrimination with a new third-party arbitration process for complaints.

The university has proposed compensation changes that would include 8.2% raises over three years for research assistants and 7.2% for teaching fellows, in addition to a $17 per hour minimum wage for instructional work. The current rate is $12 per hour.

The graduate student union has drawn support from Democratic politicians, including presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, as well as Massachusetts U.S. Reps. Ayanna Pressley, Kathleen Clark, and Joe Kennedy III, who joined the picket line last month in a show of solidarity.

Title: White House Releases Transcript of First Trump-Zelensky Call, Showcasing Initial Congratulatory Exchange

The White House has released a transcript of President Donald Trump's first phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, a brief, congratulatory conversation that took place on April 21, 2019, and lacks the controversy of their later call that sparked an impeachment inquiry.

The initial call, which took place aboard Air Force One, began with President Trump congratulating President Zelensky on a "job well done" and on "a fantastic election." In response, President Zelensky expressed gratitude for the congratulations and acknowledged the efforts made during the election.

The conversation, which lasted six minutes, saw President Trump expressing confidence in President Zelensky's ability to do a great job, mentioning his personal connections in Ukraine, and praising the Ukrainian leader's election victory. The transcript of this call contrasts starkly with their subsequent call on July 25, during which President Trump asked President Zelensky to investigate matters related to the 2016 election and the Biden family.

White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham stated that the president "took the unprecedented steps to declassify and release the transcripts of both of his phone calls with President Zelensky so that every American can see he did nothing wrong." The transcript was read in full by Devin Nunes, the ranking Republican on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, during the second public impeachment hearing on Friday.

In the April call, President Trump extended an invitation to President Zelensky to visit the White House, to which the Ukrainian leader accepted. President Trump also invited President Zelensky to attend his inauguration, with both leaders expressing anticipation for their future meetings.

This release of the transcript comes amidst the ongoing impeachment inquiry, with House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff expressing gratitude for the transcript's release but urging the Trump administration to provide the rest of the requested documents throughout the inquiry.

Title: FBI Acquires Hillary Clinton's Email Server, Server Reportedly Found Empty

Article:

In a development that has been the focus of discussions all week, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has complied with the FBI's request to hand over her personal email server, which she used during her tenure as Secretary of State. Earlier this week, it was revealed that Clinton had at least two emails containing classified, top-secret information on her server. It is important to note that the server was not secure and it is illegal to send or receive classified information on a private email account or server.

Yesterday, the FBI took possession of Clinton's server from a private data center in New Jersey. Barbara Wells, an attorney for Denver-based computer services firm Platte River Networks, confirmed to The Washington Post that the server "was blank" and no longer contained useful information. According to Wells, the information had been migrated over to a different server for purposes of transition. She added that the company had cooperated with the FBI and had been told it was not a target of the investigation.

The Justice Department is investigating whether classified information was improperly stored on or passed through the server, which Clinton used for all her correspondence during her time as Secretary of State. In March, a defiant Clinton declared that the private server would never be turned over because it contained personal emails between herself and her husband Bill Clinton, in addition to details about her daughter's wedding.

The revelation that the server is now empty raises questions about the integrity and transparency of Clinton's handling of official government business. The FBI's investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what, if any, further information will be uncovered.

Title: House GOP Report Questions Hillary Clinton's Awareness of Security Issues in Benghazi Attack

Article:

In a new report released on Friday, House Republicans have accused former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton of being aware of security problems in Libya prior to the 2012 terrorist attack on the U.S. diplomatic outpost in Benghazi. The report also questions the validity of the State Department's own internal review, known as the Accountability Review Board (ARB), stating it had serious deficiencies.

The report suggests that Clinton should have been held accountable for the security breaches that led to the deaths of four Americans, including the U.S. ambassador to Libya. The report concludes that systemic failures during Clinton's tenure at the State Department resulted in a grossly inadequate security posture in Benghazi, contributing to the deaths of four Americans, including the first U.S. ambassador killed in the line of duty since 1979.

The report points to Clinton's own testimony that she was aware of the security concerns in Benghazi, though other reviews have stated she was never made aware of the specifics, including some of the requests for additional security or military protection that were denied.

House Republicans, through the new website www.gop.gov/benghazi, aim to keep Benghazi as a political issue in 2014. The report appears to be designed to raise questions about Clinton in particular, as she considers another run for the White House in 2016.

The report contrasts the State Department's performance with that of the Defense Department, which the investigators said "held military commanders accountable for what happened on their watch in Afghanistan." The report also faults Clinton's successor, Secretary John F. Kerry, for failing to take action regarding the security breaches.

A separate review released last month by the Senate intelligence committee, run by Democrats, also found that the State Department should have done more to boost security. However, that review laid more blame on Ambassador Christopher Stevens, who the report said failed to ask for stiffer security in the immediate run-up to the attack. Stevens was killed in the initial assault.

The report's findings come as the Senate prepares to vote on Clinton's nomination as Secretary of State in President Biden's administration. The vote is expected to take place in the coming weeks.

Title: Journalist Documents Extent of Destruction in Minneapolis Following George Floyd Protests

Article:

In the aftermath of the George Floyd protests in Minneapolis, journalist Michael Tracey has been documenting the extent of the destruction in the city. Tracey, who has been in Minneapolis for five days, noted that he had initially expected threats of violence from Antifa, but had not encountered any.

In a series of tweets, Tracey shared images of businesses that had been looted and destroyed, including a grocery and tobacco store owned by an Iranian, a Halal market, a Metro PCS store, a gas station convenience store, a wig shop, and a small deli. The deli owner shared that his security had fired shots to fend off the rioters, with the instigators primarily being white, while the blacks hung back.

Tracey also documented the destruction of a dentist's office that provided care to underprivileged children and the uninsured. He noted that the breadth of the destruction is probably not being covered by the media because it could be seen as helping President Trump, who has promised to maintain law and order during the chaos.

Tracey's tweets offer a glimpse into the aftermath of the protests and the impact they had on the community. The images and accounts shared by Tracey highlight the destruction and loss that businesses and residents in Minneapolis have experienced. The tweets also raise questions about the media's coverage of the protests and the extent of the destruction they caused.

Title: Organizing for Action and White House Urge Commemoration of Sandy Hook Anniversary, Push for Gun Control Measures

Article:

In a joint effort, Organizing for Action (OFA) and the White House have called upon supporters to commemorate the first anniversary of the Sandy Hook Elementary School tragedy by hosting remembrance events on December 14. The events aim to reflect on the loss and advocate for stricter gun control measures to prevent future incidents.

OFA's email to supporters encourages individuals to host events in their communities, providing resources to ensure the events serve as a poignant reminder of the 26 lives lost a year ago. Newtown green ribbons will be distributed during these events, both in person and online, to symbolize solidarity with the families of Sandy Hook.

The White House, through Vice President Joe Biden, also sent out an email via WhiteHouse.gov, focusing on President Obama's gun control executive orders and the need for further gun control legislation. The email highlights the progress made in implementing the 23 executive actions announced by President Obama in January, which aim to keep guns out of dangerous hands, provide support for school resource officers, and reduce the stigma around mental illness.

However, it is important to note that none of the proposed gun control measures, as mentioned by Vice President Biden and OFA, would have prevented the Sandy Hook tragedy or other similar incidents. These incidents were not related to gun trafficking or the lack of universal background checks, as Vice President Biden suggests. Furthermore, under President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder's leadership, prosecutions of gun-related crimes have decreased by 45 percent.

Despite these facts, both OFA and the White House continue to advocate for stricter gun control measures, emphasizing the need for expanded background checks and serious penalties for gun trafficking to protect children and keep communities safer. The emails serve as a reminder of the ongoing efforts to address gun violence in the United States.

Title: White House Defends Clinton Foundation Donations Amid Uranium Deal Controversy

Article:

The White House is facing mounting questions regarding foreign donations to the Clinton Foundation during Hillary Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, particularly in relation to a deal that reportedly helped Russia secure a significant portion of the global uranium market with State Department approval.

The Clinton campaign has been grappling with similar questions, but neither the campaign nor the White House has provided sufficient answers to quell the growing uproar. The scrutiny surrounding foreign money associated with the Clintons, including substantial speaking fees for former President Bill Clinton and substantial donations to their charitable foundation following Hillary Clinton's appointment as America's top diplomat, is expected to intensify and persist throughout her campaign trail.

During a press briefing, White House press secretary Josh Earnest insisted that President Obama is not troubled by reports that the Clinton Foundation accepted $2.35 million from a businessman involved in Russia's uranium deals, which required approval from the U.S. State Department as well as other countries.

"At this point, there has not been any evidence presented that would prompt the president or anybody at the White House to be unsettled by Secretary Clinton's conduct as secretary of state," said Mr. Earnest. "In fact, everyone here at the White House, including the president, continues to be very proud of her service to this country."

However, it was reported that the Clintons did not publicly disclose these donations, despite a memorandum of understanding between Clinton and the Obama administration that required donations to the foundation to be disclosed to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest.

The deal granted Russia's atomic energy agency, Rosatom, control of uranium mines spanning from Asia to the Western U.S., including half of America's uranium supply. Shortly after the Russians announced plans to buy mining giant Uranium One, a Russian investment bank with ties to the Kremlin and the deal paid Mr. Clinton $500,000 for a speech in Moscow, according to The New York Times.

When asked about the administration's concerns regarding questionable donations from foreign governments or foreign entities to the Clinton Foundation, Mr. Earnest said no. He also declined to answer a reporter's question on whether it is now "clear" that Mrs. Clinton did not abide by the agreement she signed with the administration before becoming secretary of state in 2009 to disclose donations to the foundation and the speaking fees paid to her husband.

The Clinton campaign did not respond to questions about violating the memorandum of understanding.

Mrs. Clinton, who is the odds-on favorite to win the Democratic presidential nomination, also faced criticism from her potential Republican rivals. Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard who plans to announce her Republican presidential run on May 4, wrote on her Facebook page, "It's the Clinton way: raking in millions from foreign governments behind closed doors while making promises about transparency that they never intended to keep. Now they're scrambling to refile their taxes and account for her decisions as Secretary of State."

The Clinton campaign has attempted to downplay the controversy since it emerged this week in previews of the book "Clinton Cash: The Untold Story of How and Why Foreign Governments and Businesses Helped Make Bill and Hillary Rich." The book, by conservative political adviser Peter Schweizer, argues that the Clintons amassed wealth through speaking fees and donations in return for favors from Mrs. Clinton to various foreign interests while running the State Department.

Other dealings include a free trade agreement in Colombia that benefited a major foundation donor's investments in the South American nation, development projects in Haiti after a devastating earthquake in 2010, and more than $1 million in payments to Mr. Clinton by a Canadian bank and major shareholder in the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which occurred while the project was under State Department review, according to reports.

The Clinton campaign has dismissed the accusations as a right-wing "smear project," but this becomes increasingly difficult as mainstream news outlets pick up the story. Clinton campaign spokesman Brian Fallon sent a memo Thursday to supporters and donors in an attempt to counter the accusations.

"The bottom line remains that the book fails to produce a shred of evidence supporting the theory that Hillary Clinton ever took action as Secretary of State for the purposes of supporting the interests of donors to the Clinton foundation," he wrote.

At a campaign stop in New Hampshire this week, Mrs. Clinton dismissed questions about connections between contributions from foreign entities and her actions as secretary of state, calling them merely "distractions and attacks."

"I know that that comes, unfortunately, with the territory," she told The Associated Press.

Title: Federal Strategy in Oregon Standoff Proves Effective, Minimizing Casualties and Damage

Article:

The standoff at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, which began in early January, has come to a close with the arrest of several self-appointed militiamen, led by the sons of right-wing radical Cliven Bundy. The group, who took over the refuge, demanded that federal lands be handed over to private interests, sparking concerns among liberals about the potential for violent confrontations.

However, contrary to initial expectations, the federal government adopted a wait-and-see approach, allowing the militiamen to remain on the refuge for several weeks. This strategy, while initially criticized by some, has proven to be a successful approach in resolving the standoff peacefully.

The strategy of patience and restraint was a far more sensible way of dealing with the situation, as rushing the refuge would have given the militiamen the martyrdom they craved and potentially resulted in loss of innocent lives, as well as costly damage to the building. The federal strategy also effectively neutralized the propaganda value of the occupation, as the militiamen's true colors were exposed through their daily antics, proving them to be more clownish than courageous.

The arrest of the militiamen, which took place on an open highway, resulted in one fatality and eight arrests. The leaders of the occupation are now in custody, and the remaining militiamen holed up in the refuge are expected to surrender soon, given the absence of leadership and access to the outside world.

The federal strategy of patience and restraint, while initially criticized, has proven to be a more effective approach in resolving the standoff peacefully, minimizing casualties and damage. This incident serves as a reminder of the importance of smarter, less aggressive policing, and the dangers of the "shoot first" philosophy of policing. The nation is currently engaged in a discussion about the dangers of this approach, prompted by the Black Lives Matter movement, and this story serves as a powerful example of why patience and focus on minimizing damage is a more effective and humane approach to policing.

Title: International Aid Efforts Intensify as Typhoon Haiyan's Devastation in the Philippines Reveals Thousands of Missing and Dead

The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, also known as Yolanda in the Philippines, continues to unfold in the Southeast Asian nation, with hundreds of thousands of people struggling to survive and authorities grappling to deliver aid to the hardest-hit areas.

According to reports, Richard Gordon, head of the Philippine Red Cross, described the situation as "absolute bedlam" to the BBC. He stated, "There's an awful lot of casualties, a lot of people dead all over the place, a lot of destruction."

Lynette Lim of Save the Children, who recently visited Tacloban, one of the most affected cities, described the scene as "completely flattened" and "truly catastrophic."

Freelance journalist Aurora Almendral, speaking to NPR from the town of Hilongos en route to Tacloban City, reported that some people who managed to secure food, water, and medicine were concerned about potential looters.

One young woman Almendral encountered had not heard from her family since before the storm. She lamented, "Her father, mother, brother, and four-year-old daughter. She has absolutely no news."

In an effort to assist the typhoon relief efforts, U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has ordered the aircraft carrier USS George Washington (CVN 73) and other U.S. Navy ships to the Philippines. Approximately 215 U.S. military personnel are currently deployed in the Philippines to aid in the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan.

United Nations officials report that about 9.5 million people in the Philippines have been affected by the typhoon and its aftermath, with around 620,000 forced from their homes. The number of confirmed deaths, which was just over 200 on Sunday, is now estimated to be around 1,000. However, officials are warning that the death toll could rise to 10,000.

As the U.S. military joins the rescue effort, foreign governments and aid groups have begun shipping food, medicine, and supplies to the hard-hit Visayas region on the Philippines' eastern seaboard. According to NPR's Anthony Kuhn, the U.S. military is bringing in water, generators, and trucks.

Meanwhile, Typhoon Haiyan moved out into the South China Sea on Saturday and hit Vietnam on Monday in a significantly weakened state, although it still retained enough strength to uproot trees and tear roofs off hundreds of homes. National disaster officials in Vietnam reported no deaths on Monday, although state media stated that five people had died during preparations for the typhoon.

For those seeking information on missing family members in the Philippines, the International Red Cross has a webpage for "restoring family links."

Title: Synthetic Grass Advocates Push for Mandatory Installation in Drought-Stricken California

Article:

In a bid to conserve water amidst the ongoing drought, The Synthetic Grass Warehouse, the nation's largest distributor of artificial grass, is urging California Governor Jerry Brown to consider a law mandating the use of synthetic grass across the state. The proposal aims to reduce the state's water consumption, particularly in the 6.4 billion gallons used daily for lawn care.

The Anaheim-based company suggests that Brown propose a law allowing and encouraging synthetic grass in various settings, including residential and commercial properties, parks, and pet areas. Victor Lanfranco, co-founder of The Synthetic Grass Warehouse, argues, "If everyone in California switched to synthetic grass, eliminating just the need to water our lawns, we would no longer be in a drought. We need to welcome this idea in today's day and age as droughts are becoming more and more severe."

The synthetic grass offered by the company is not reminiscent of the astroturf of yesteryears. The fibrous tufts are richly textured and colored, available in a dozen varieties for home use alone. The grass part, non-absorbent and anti-bacterial, is groomed with a brush rather than a mower. The company's poster proclaims, "Imagine a California where water was no longer wasted on grass!"

The Atlanta-based Synthetic Turf Council estimates that replacing a typical 1,800 square-foot lawn with artificial grass could save 99,000 gallons of water per year, per lawn. Additionally, there would be no pesticide or fertilizer run-off.

Governor Brown has already proposed fines of up to $10,000 for excessive water use and has ordered a 25% reduction in statewide water usage. City and county agencies, along with retail and wholesale water agencies, will be able to issue penalties and enforce restrictions.

However, homeowners face a dilemma as many homeowners associations require residents to water their lawns, while the state is simultaneously reducing water usage. Moreover, some associations do not allow homeowners to install synthetic grass. Lanfranco states, "This is where we need our governor to step in."

The proposal for mandatory synthetic grass installation in California is a contentious issue, with proponents arguing for water conservation and opponents expressing concerns about the environmental impact and aesthetic appeal of artificial grass. The debate continues as California grapples with the ongoing drought.

Title: President Trump Responds to Jay-Z's Remarks on Black Unemployment Rate

Article:

In a series of tweets on Sunday morning, President Donald Trump responded to rapper Jay-Z's comments about the black unemployment rate during a CNN talk show interview. Trump stated, "Somebody please inform Jay-Z that because of my policies, Black Unemployment has just been reported to be at the LOWEST RATE EVER RECORDED!"

The president's comments seem to be a reaction to an appearance Jay-Z made on CNN host Van Jones' show. During the interview on Saturday night, Jay-Z stated that while the black unemployment rate has decreased, it does not necessarily mean that Trump is a good leader.

"It’s not about money at the end of the day. Money does not equate to happiness," Jay-Z said. "You’re missing the whole point. You treat people like human beings. That’s the main point. You can’t treat someone like: you’re going to treat me badly but pay me really well."

The black unemployment rate has reached its lowest levels since the 1970s, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which began recording the unemployment rate in America during that decade.

The ███ News Foundation, a non-profit organization dedicated to providing balanced and independent journalism, is currently working hard to counteract the biased nature of American media. For as little as $3, readers can support the quality journalism of TheDCNF, an organization that does not rely on commercial or political support and does not accept any government funding.

Title: US Deploys National Guard to Mexico Border, Trump Aims to End "Catch and Release" Policy

Article:

The United States state of Texas is deploying National Guard members to the border with Mexico following a call from President Donald Trump. A Guard spokesman stated that 250 personnel would be sent to patrol the area within the next 72 hours. Arizona is also planning to deploy 150 troops there next week.

President Trump has expressed his intention to send up to 4,000 National Guard members to secure the border with Mexico, pending the construction of his proposed border wall. The states of New Mexico and California have been asked to take similar action to Texas and Arizona.

On Friday, President Trump outlined plans to end a practice known as "catch and release," as part of his stricter anti-immigration policies. The aim is to detain illegal immigrants while they await deportation hearings, rather than releasing them.

The President has requested a detailed list of military and other facilities from the US Department of Defense that could perform this function. He has also sent several tweets over the past seven days, criticizing illegal immigration, accusing Democrats of allowing "open borders, drugs, and crime," and urging Republicans to pass tougher immigration laws.

In response to President Trump's actions, Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto has condemned what he called "threatening or disrespectful attitudes" from the US President. The President has described sending troops to the Mexico border as a "big step," but both his predecessors, Barack Obama and George W. Bush, also dispatched the National Guard there.

The US Department of Defense has approved funding for up to 4,000 National Guard troops from the Pentagon budget until the end of September. However, constructing a "big, beautiful wall" along the Mexican border, a signature Trump campaign promise, has been thwarted by lawmakers and appears to have stalled.

A major government spending bill, which President Trump signed last month, included $1.6 billion for the border wall - far short of the $25 billion the White House sought. Most of the funding can only be used to repair existing sections of the border wall, not to build new segments.

Last month, the Pentagon confirmed that President Trump had held "initial" talks with his defense secretary about using some of the Pentagon's budget to build a wall. However, two Democratic senators wrote to the defense secretary on Monday, stating that his department had "no legal authority" to use its funds for such a purpose.

In December, US Border Patrol announced that arrests at the southern border had fallen to their lowest level since 1971, indicating that fewer people were attempting the crossing.

Title: New Mexico's Quay County Declares Itself a "Second Amendment Sanctuary County" in Protest of New Gun Laws

Article:

In a move of resistance against pending legislation that expands background check requirements for gun purchases, Quay County, New Mexico, has declared itself a "Second Amendment Sanctuary County," according to Fox News. The county's decision comes in response to two controversial bills, HB 8 and HB 83, currently under consideration in the New Mexico House of Representatives.

HB 8, if passed, would require background checks for gun purchases, even between private citizens. This measure has been criticized by the New Mexico Sheriff's Association as an unenforceable law. HB 83, on the other hand, would establish an "Extreme Risk Protection Order" that would allow for the seizure of guns and ammunition from individuals deemed to be a danger to themselves or others.

New Mexico House Republicans have expressed support for Quay County's decision, with state Rep. Rod Montoya (R-Farmington) stating, "We see counties starting to fight back against the over-reach of House Democrats. New Mexicans who are not even accused of a crime can lose their 2nd Amendment rights under this bill, and that's beyond wrong."

Under HB 8, it would be a misdemeanor to buy or sell a gun privately without a federal background check. The National Rifle Association (NRA) has come out against both HB 8 and HB 83, with the NRA Institute for Legislative Action stating that HB 83 "violates due process and puts law enforcement in a more dangerous situation, and does nothing to protect citizens."

The NRA's statement further reads, "Unchallenged statements made by a petitioner before a judge, alleging that someone is a danger to themselves or others in an ex parte proceeding — prior to any formal court hearing at which the respondent can be represented by counsel and present counter evidence — would be sufficient for law enforcement to enter that person's home and confiscate their private property."

State Representative Black has also voiced his agreement with the sheriffs and county commissions, stating, "I agree with our sheriffs and our county commissions, both of which are telling us these bills only harm law-abiding New Mexicans." The debate over these gun laws continues as they move through the legislative process.

Title: Democrats Alter Senate Filibuster Rule to Advance Judicial and Executive Nominations

Article:

In a dramatic shift, the United States Senate, led by the Democratic Party, has altered the filibuster rule to expedite the confirmation of judicial and executive nominations. The move comes in response to the Republican Party's obstructionist tactics, which have hindered the confirmation process for several key appointments during the Obama administration.

The decision, made by all but three Senate Democrats, was prompted by the Republicans' refusal to confirm appointments to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. This move was seen as an attempt to maintain a conservative majority on this influential court.

The Republicans had previously employed similar tactics earlier this year, aiming to impede the National Labor Relations Board and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, two agencies they have been critical of, by blocking all appointments to these agencies. This obstruction was lifted in July, following Harry Reid's threat to end the filibuster, which the Republicans eventually relented to.

The latest blockade of judges to the D.C. appellate court was the catalyst for the rule change. Republicans had warned that such a move could have repercussions if the Democrats lost the White House and the Senate. However, the Constitution grants presidents the right to nominate top officials in their administration and name judges, and it does not stipulate the ability of a Senate minority to obstruct these appointments.

The rule change now means that presidents are more likely to see their nominations approved if their party controls the Senate. In the past half of all filibusters waged against nominations in Senate history have occurred since President Obama was elected. Twenty of his district court nominees were filibustered, while only three such filibusters took place before he took office.

The rule change does not abolish the 60-vote threshold for blocking legislation, a practice that has been argued to be worth preserving. However, the rule change could pave the way for broader filibuster reforms. A proposal by several younger Democratic senators to require "talking filibusters" - forcing objecting lawmakers to stand up at length and make their cases - may gain momentum, potentially ending logjams that have prevented important legislation from reaching votes.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Denies Attempting to Flee Scene of 1998 DWI Accident

In a recent debate against U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, Democratic candidate Beto O'Rourke denied attempting to flee the scene of a 1998 drunken car crash, contradicting police reports published by the Houston Chronicle last month.

During the debate at Southern Methodist University, O'Rourke stated, "I did not try to leave the scene of the accident, though driving drunk, which I did, is a terrible mistake for which there is no excuse or justification or defense." He further added, "I can only tell you that I was able to have a second chance in my life."

However, the police report, which was published by the Houston Chronicle last month, claimed that O'Rourke "attempted to leave the accident" after he lost control of his car and hit another vehicle in 1998. The report also stated that a witness "turned on his overhead lights to warn oncoming traffic and to try to get [O'Rourke] to stop."

This is the first time O'Rourke has challenged reports of the incident. Last month, he acknowledged that he "drove drunk and was arrested for DWI in 1998." He did not deny he tried to flee the scene in his previous statements.

The police report also stated that O'Rourke was visibly intoxicated and "unable to be understood due to slurred speech." O'Rourke recorded 0.136 and 0.134 blood alcohol levels on Breathalyzer tests, the records said. The state legal limit at the time was 0.10. The charges of DWI were later dismissed after he completed a court-approved diversion program, the Chronicle reported.

Title: EU Members Rush to Address Future of Union as UK Exit Looms, Possible Exodus of Other Nations a Concern

Article:

As the European Union's founding nations convened in an emergency meeting on Saturday to discuss the future of the alliance, Germany's government reportedly expressed concerns that the United Kingdom could be the first of several nations to withdraw. The fear is that if the EU were to sever ties with Britain, other countries such as France, the Netherlands, Hungary, Austria, and Finland may lose incentive to remain.

In a plea for the EU to maintain a relationship with the UK, the government-run German newspaper Die Welt called for the UK to be considered an "associated partner country." Nigel Farage, leader of the UK Independence Party, celebrated the Brexit vote results, describing the EU as "doomed" and "dying." Far-right leaders in France and the Netherlands have also called for their own referendums on EU membership, according to Sky News.

Foreign ministers from Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg met in Berlin on Saturday and issued a statement expressing their desire for Britain to quickly invoke the article in the EU charter that allows it to begin negotiations on departure. They acknowledged the need to find better ways to address the varying levels of commitment to closer European unity among member states.

An online petition seeking a second Brexit referendum drew over 1 million signatures, reflecting the deep divisions caused by Thursday's vote to leave the 28-nation bloc. The petition site hosted by the House of Commons website crashed on Friday due to the unprecedented interest in the measure.

Scotland plans to initiate talks with EU nations and institutions to explore ways to remain in the bloc despite Britain's vote to leave. Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon also indicated that a new referendum on Scottish independence from the United Kingdom is "on the table."

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban and Danish Prime Minister Lars Loekke Rasmussen both weighed in on the situation, with Orban stating that "Brussels must hear the voice of the people, this is the biggest lesson from this decision." Rasmussen added that Britain's exit "will echo for years to come and change the Europe as we know it."

German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Britain should not take an excessive amount of time to deliver formal notification of its intent to leave the EU, but also made it clear that the decision is in London's hands. Merkel expressed a desire for an "objective, good" climate in the negotiations, stating that they should be conducted properly without any unnecessary hostility.

French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault suggested that Britain should name a new prime minister in the coming days to expedite the departure process. However, given the political turmoil in Britain, it is likely to take months to name a replacement for outgoing Prime Minister David Cameron. Ayrault stated that designating a new prime minister would require several days.

Title: Voting Irregularities: Long Lines in Florida, Confusion in New Jersey and Other States

Article:

As the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election day progresses, reports of irregularities have surfaced across several states. In this article, we will be tracking significant voting issues that have emerged so far, with a focus on long lines and confusion in Florida, New Jersey, and other states.

One of the most prevalent problems on Election Day has been long lines at polling stations. In Florida, some voters have reported waiting up to three hours to cast their ballots. The Miami Herald reported dramatic cases where voters refused to leave the line despite fainting, and in one instance, a man suffering a seizure while filling out his ballot. At the Miami-Dade election headquarters in El Doral, the paper spoke to one woman who was in line holding a catheter bag.

The long lines in Florida can be attributed to the length of the ballot. With the proposed amendments, which are backed by Republican state lawmakers, the ballot is significantly longer than in previous elections. One amendment, which proposes tax breaks for owners of vacation homes, comes in at 640 words. If voters have not done their homework, they have to read their way through a ballot that in some counties is 12 pages long.

Long lines were also a problem in battleground Virginia, where people were late for work due to the lengthy queues. In New Hampshire, voters struggled to find parking spaces and were anticipating long wait times in lines. The New York Times reports that the combination of Superstorm Sandy and heavy turnout yielded long lines, confusion, frustration, and anger in the city.

Because of Superstorm Sandy, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie authorized the use of fax and email voting. However, the Newark Star-Ledger reports that some voters who requested ballots through those methods never received them. Perhaps most problematic, however, is that when the state announced the new provisions, they did not mention that those people voting by email or fax also need to send a hardcopy via mail. The Star-Ledger reports that one expert thinks email voting could lead to problems:

"You must have a paper ballot backup," said Penny Venetis, a professor at Rutgers University School of Law in Newark. "What's puzzling is that the lieutenant governor's directives allow Internet voting without requiring this protection that is necessary to ensure the integrity of the vote."

Voters using the e-mail option still must print, sign, and scan a physical ballot, then send it to their county clerk via email. However, hackers can forge those ballots or signatures, send in fraudulent votes, and then erase their tracks online, said Andrew Appel, a computer science professor at Princeton University.

In Pinellas County, Florida, the Supervisor of Elections Office mistakenly made robocalls that told voters they had until 7 p.m. "tomorrow" to turn in mail-in ballots. "But that is wrong. Polls close at 7 p.m. Tuesday. Any ballots turned in after that time won't be accepted," the calls stated. The calls went out between 8 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. because of a glitch with the SOE's phone system. About 12,000 calls, however, did not get through, said SOE spokeswoman Nancy Whitlock. They were stored in a queue and recycled Tuesday morning. The "tomorrow" in the message meant for Monday was incorrect when it was delivered.

The SOE told the paper that they stopped sending out calls as soon as they noticed the problem.

Title: "Jane Mayer's Analysis of Fox News and White House Relationship Sparks Controversy"

Article:

In a recent article for The New Yorker titled "The Making of the Fox News White House," investigative journalist Jane Mayer has sparked a heated debate with her analysis of the relationship between Fox News and the current White House. The article suggests that the alignment between the two entities is unprecedented, with Fox News executive Bill Shine's move from Fox to the White House communications operation being a key point.

However, Mayer's assertion of this being an unprecedented relationship has been met with skepticism. Critics argue that the notion of a friendly relationship between news networks and the White House, or media executives moving into politics, is not a new phenomenon.

On MSNBC's Morning Joe, Mayer expressed concern about the closeness between Fox News and the White House, stating, "We've really never had a whole national network like this... it's incredibly close with this White House."

Critics point out instances of media bias in the past, such as journalists covering up Franklin D. Roosevelt's disability, or downplaying John F. Kennedy's debauchery. They also highlight Obama strategist Ben Rhodes' boast to The New York Times about creating an "echo chamber" in the press, and the Times' positive response.

Mayer's criticism of Fox News' "rage-based model" has also been met with criticism, as she is accused of ignoring similar models in liberal media outlets. Some argue that networks like MSNBC and CNN, which she mentions in her criticism of Fox News, also have partisan agendas that contribute to the polarization of the country.

The article has sparked a larger conversation about media bias and the role of news networks in shaping public opinion. Critics argue that Mayer's analysis is hypocritical, as she overlooks instances of media bias in liberal media outlets while criticizing Fox News.

The article has also brought attention to the close relationship between media figures and political figures, with examples such as Chris Matthews' public support for Obama and David Remnick's adoring interviews with Obama and book about Valerie Jarrett.

In response to the criticism, Mayer and The New Yorker have not issued a statement. The article has, however, sparked a larger conversation about media bias and the role of news networks in shaping public opinion.

Title: Justice Department Threatens Lawsuit Against Harvard Over Alleged Discrimination Against Asian-American Applicants

Article:

In a significant development, the U.S. Justice Department has issued a warning to Harvard University, threatening to sue the prestigious Ivy League institution over potential violations of civil rights laws due to alleged discrimination against Asian-American applicants. The threat comes as part of an investigation into Harvard's admission policies, which the Justice Department believes may be in breach of Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

The Justice Department's letter, dated Friday and obtained by various media outlets, sets a Dec. 1 deadline for Harvard to hand over documents detailing its admission policies. The department is investigating Harvard's compliance with Title VI, which prohibits institutions receiving federal funding from discriminating based on race, color, or national origin.

The investigation follows reports of a broader probe into whether university affirmative action admission policies may be discriminating against white applicants. The Justice Department's letter states that it has concluded that Harvard is out of compliance with its Title VI access obligations.

Harvard's attorneys, in an October 6 letter to the Justice Department, have questioned the timing of the investigation, stating that it is unusual for the department to resurrect a complaint filed nearly 2-1/2 years earlier.

Harvard has consistently maintained that its admissions policies are in line with U.S. laws. The university has also worked to increase financial aid to ensure economic and racial diversity in its classes. In 2017, more than one in five freshmen admitted were Asian, and almost 15 percent were African-American.

In response to the investigation, Harvard spokeswoman Anna Cowenhoven stated, "The university will certainly comply with its obligations under Title VI. We have an obligation to protect the confidentiality of student and applicant files and other highly sensitive records."

Affirmative action programs in higher education were designed to address racial discrimination. The Supreme Court has ruled that universities may use affirmative action with the aim of helping minority applicants gain admission to colleges. However, critics argue that such policies can inadvertently disadvantage white applicants and Asian-Americans.

In response to the investigation, a Justice Department spokesperson, Devin O' Malley, stated, "The Department of Justice takes seriously any potential violation of an individual's civil and constitutional rights."

This development marks a significant escalation in the ongoing debate over affirmative action in higher education and the balance between promoting diversity and ensuring fairness in the admissions process.

Title: Iowa Democratic Chairman Endorses Sanders Over Clinton Amidst Wall Street Ties Controversy

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent Democratic debate, John Wittneben, the Democratic chairman in Emmet County, Iowa, has endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders in the presidential race. This decision comes as Hillary Rodham Clinton faces criticism over her ties to Wall Street, a controversy that has become a significant vulnerability in states with early nomination contests.

Mr. Wittneben, who lost 40 percent of his savings in individual retirement accounts during the Great Recession, expressed his disapproval of Clinton's financial ties to Wall Street executives. "People knew what they were doing back then, because of greed, and it caused me harm," he said, emphasizing the importance of fairness in his community.

Clinton's windfalls from Wall Street banks and other financial services firms - $3 million in paid speeches and $17 million in campaign contributions over the years - have been a contentious issue. Some undecided party officials view her as overly cozy with big banks and other special interests. This image problem, which Clinton attempted to address in an October debate by reminding viewers that she "represented Wall Street as a senator from New York," seems difficult for her to shake off.

Despite her criticism of the American economy as being "rigged" for the rich, Clinton's perceived leniency towards Wall Street excess if elected has led to a loss of support from some party members. Her refusal to support the reinstatement of the Glass-Steagall Act, a law that separated commercial and investment banks until its repeal under President Bill Clinton, is a point of contention. Sanders, on the other hand, favors its restoration.

Furthermore, Clinton's strong support from wealthy donors and a big-money "super PAC" undermines her increasingly progressive rhetoric on free trade and other economic issues, according to many Democrats. This endorsement from Mr. Wittneben, a representative of the grassroots, underscores the growing concern among some Democrats that Clinton's ties to Wall Street may compromise her ability to enact the progressive economic policies they desire.

Title: President Trump Responds to Report of FBI Investigation Launched After Firing of James Comey

Article:

In a series of tweets on Saturday, President Donald Trump responded to a report by The New York Times that the FBI had launched an investigation of the president in 2017, following his firing of FBI Director James B. Comey.

The Times reported Friday night that FBI officials opened a probe of Mr. Trump immediately after he fired Mr. Comey in May 2017. The report, citing former officials and others familiar with the probe, said law enforcement officials "became so concerned by the president's behavior that they began investigating whether he had been working on behalf of Russia against American interests." Part of the probe was criminal in nature, looking at whether the president obstructed justice.

Special counsel Robert Mueller took over the probe several days later upon his appointment by Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein.

In his tweets, Mr. Trump defended his actions and criticized Mr. Comey, who he fired. He said he has been "FAR tougher on Russia than Obama, Bush or Clinton."

"At the same time, & as I have often said, getting along with Russia is a good thing, not a bad thing," he tweeted. "I fully expect that someday we will have good relations with Russia again!"

Mr. Trump also said, "Everybody wanted him fired, Republican and Democrat alike." He added, "My firing of James Comey was a great day for America. He was a Crooked Cop."

White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders called the development "absurd." She said, unlike former President Barack Obama, Mr. Trump "has actually been tough on Russia."

Rep. Devin Nunes of California, ranking Republican on the House Intelligence Committee, said the Times' report is "yet more evidence that FBI leaders actually had no real evidence against the Trump team."

"Instead, they were simply trying to undermine a president they didn't like and avenge Comey's firing," said Mr. Nunes, who as chairman of the panel in the previous Congress issued a report clearing the Trump campaign of collusion with Russia.

House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler, New York Democrat, indicated that he plans to look into the development.

"In the coming weeks, the Judiciary Committee will take steps to better understand both the president's actions and the FBI's response to that behavior, and to make certain that these career investigators are protected from President Trump's increasingly unhinged attacks," Mr. Nadler said in a statement.

"There is no reason to doubt the seriousness or professionalism of the FBI, as the president did in reaction to this story. Indeed, his go-to complaints—about former Director Comey and Secretary Clinton—do nothing to address the incredibly serious nature of these allegations," Mr. Nadler added.

Title: President Obama Acknowledges U.S. Torture of al Qaeda Detainees, Expresses Support for CIA Director

Article:

In a significant admission, President Barack Obama acknowledged on Friday that the United States did torture al Qaeda detainees captured following the 9/11 attacks. This statement marks one of the most expansive comments he has made on the controversial CIA practices he banned upon taking office.

"We tortured some folks," Obama said during a televised news conference at the White House. "We did some things that were contrary to our values."

Addressing the forthcoming release of a Senate report that criticizes the CIA's treatment of detainees, Obama attributed the mistreatment to the pressure national security officials felt to prevent further attacks. He urged Americans not to be overly "sanctimonious" when judging the actions of the past through the lens of the seemingly safer present day.

This stance, which Obama adopted as a presidential candidate in 2008 and early in his presidency, explains why he did not push for criminal charges against Bush-era officials who carried out the CIA program. Many of these officials maintain that their actions were not torture, which is a felony under U.S. law.

In contrast to his previous comments on the subject, Obama's remarks on Friday were more emphatic, including a 2009 speech where he declared his ban on "so-called enhanced interrogation techniques" and "brutal methods," but did not explicitly state that the U.S. had engaged in torture.

"I believe that waterboarding was torture, and whatever legal rationales were used, it was a mistake," he said in April 2009.

The administration of President George W. Bush authorized the use of harsh interrogation techniques on militant detainees in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, after deciding they did not constitute torture. Obama explained that the techniques were employed due to the fear of imminent further attacks.

"It's important for us not to feel too sanctimonious in retrospect about the tough job that those folks had," he said. "A lot of those folks were working hard under enormous pressure and are real patriots."

On Friday, Obama did not address two other central arguments of the soon-to-be-released Senate report: that the brutal interrogations did not yield life-saving intelligence, and that the CIA deceived other elements of the U.S. government about its actions.

The president also expressed confidence in his CIA Director, John Brennan, in the face of an internal CIA report documenting improper access to Senate computers. There have been calls for his resignation on Capitol Hill.

Title: Ongoing Nuclear Negotiations with Iran: A Delicate Balance of Power and Uncertainty

Article:

In the ongoing diplomatic standoff, another deadline passed this week in the protracted negotiations over Iran's nuclear weapons programs, with U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry warning that a failure to reach a deal could signal the end of the process. Kerry emphasized, "If the tough decisions don't get made, we are absolutely prepared to call an end to this process."

The ongoing negotiations, taking place in Vienna among Iran, Russia, China, Britain, France, Germany, and the United States, are not aimed at eliminating Iran's nuclear weapons program. Instead, the focus is on determining how much nuclear infrastructure Iran can retain, the extent of inspections on remaining facilities, and the concessions offered in return.

Inspections are crucial to any agreement aimed at reducing the threat posed by Iran's nuclear weapons programs. The negotiations aim to increase the "breakout time" – the length of time it would take Iran, using known equipment and nuclear materials, to construct a nuclear bomb. The current estimate places Iran's breakout time at 2-3 months, and the negotiations are seeking to extend this to a year.

Iran's reluctance to accept several favorable deals offered so far suggests that the negotiations may serve as a satisfactory end in themselves for the Iranian government. This is particularly true for Ayatollah Khameni, who may fear domestic political repercussions from reintegrating with the international community.

It is essential to acknowledge that the extent of Iran's nuclear weapons work and the number of its facilities remain largely unknown. This is not due to a lack of effort by intelligence services but rather the fact that much of what is known about Iranian nuclear programs was revealed, and there remains much that is not.

The U.S. Congress has played a significant role in shaping Iran policy, imposing sanctions that the Obama administration now claims credit for. Senators Corker and Cardin have ensured that, should an agreement be reached in Vienna, the Congress will now have 60 days to review the president's handiwork, a move the administration had sought to avoid.

Any agreement reached will result in the easing of sanctions on Iran, with Russia unlikely to reinstate them, regardless of Iranian violations. The $100 billion in revenue resulting from the lifting of nuclear-related sanctions will primarily benefit the Revolutionary Guards and Iranian citizen militia, who control much of the Iranian economy.

An Iran deal would alleviate a political problem for President Obama, who has pledged to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon but has expressed reluctance to use military force against Iran. A nuclear deal resolves this political issue, but it has already created security concerns as regional allies adjust to the U.S.'s perceived intentions.

A continuing negotiation, free from deadlines, might help alleviate some of the insecurity. It prevents the lifting of sanctions that would be impossible to reimpose once removed. It provides exposure to Iranian leaders and potentially valuable intelligence on their nuclear infrastructure. It maintains alignment with the three European Union states whose sanctions have been a significant constraint on the Iranian government. It makes it more difficult for Russia and China to support Iran. And it allows for continued espionage, the kind that has prevented Iran from crossing the nuclear threshold so far, as we understand it.

Iran does not appear to have made the fundamental choice to abandon its nuclear weapons programs. Until it does, continued negotiations may be a better outcome than an agreement.

Title: Poll Shows Shift in American Perceptions of Race, Potential Impact on 2020 Election

Article:

NEW YORK ( ███ ) - A comprehensive analysis of public opinion over the past four years suggests that U.S. President Donald Trump's brand of white identity politics may be less effective in the 2020 election campaign. The analysis comes amid widespread criticism of Trump's racially charged comments and the fallout from a mass shooting in El Paso, Texas, that many Democratic presidential candidates swiftly blamed on the president's rhetoric.

According to a ███/Ipsos poll of 4,436 U.S. adults in July, people who rejected racial stereotypes were more interested in voting in the 2020 general election than those who expressed stronger levels of anti-black or anti-Hispanic biases. In 2016, the reverse was true. The analysis shows that Trump's narrow win came at a time when Americans with strong anti-black opinions were the more politically engaged group.

The July poll found that among Americans who feel that blacks and whites are equal, or that blacks are superior to whites, 82% expressed a strong interest in voting in 2020. That was 7 percentage points higher than people who feel strongly that whites are superior to blacks.

University of Michigan political scientist Vincent Hutchings, who reviewed the ███ findings, said, "There is some indication that racial liberals are more energized than the racially intolerant. That would seem to be good news for the Democrats and bad news for the Republicans."

The July poll did have a silver lining for Trump. Most white Republicans approve of his performance in office, and over the past four years, they have become increasingly supportive of his signature issue: expanding the wall along the U.S.-Mexico border. Some 82% now support it compared to 75% last year.

Trump is still as popular as ever with conservatives who dominate the predominantly white, working-class communities that helped him win in 2016, said Duke University political scientist Ashley Jardina, who also reviewed the poll findings. In his 2016 campaign, Trump focused on the grievances of white voters who feared the global economy was leaving them behind and who wanted more restrictions on immigration. He employed put-downs of Latino immigrants and inner-city, typically black, residents.

Responding to the ███ polling analysis, a spokesman for Trump's reelection campaign, Daniel Bucheli, said the president "enjoys broad support from diverse groups of Americans, and this coalition of supporters, to include minorities and first-time voters, continues to grow daily."

The White House did not respond to a request for comment on the poll findings. The ███ analysis also found that Americans were less likely to express feelings of racial anxiety this year, and they were more likely to empathize with African Americans. This was also true for white Americans and whites without a college degree, who largely backed Trump in 2016.

White Americans are also 19 percentage points more supportive of a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants and 4 points less supportive of increased deportations, when their responses from the July poll were compared with a ███/Ipsos poll in January 2015. The July 17-22 poll also found that 29% of whites agreed that "America must protect and preserve its White European heritage," down 7 points from a ███/Ipsos poll conducted in August 2017 and 9 points down from another ███/Ipsos poll in August 2018.

Paula Ioanide, an expert in American race relations at Ithaca College, said the poll findings were consistent with her research that racial anxieties among whites peaked during the presidency of Barack Obama. Some white Americans "are not feeling as under attack as they did in 2016," Ioanide said. With Trump in the White House, "they've seen a kind of endorsement of the kinds of things that they wanted: A restoration of a white identity that they previously had felt was under attack."

Title: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan's Rising Profile and Potential 2020 Presidential Bid

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, Maryland Governor Larry Hogan's name is gaining traction, with some speculating whether he could challenge President Donald Trump in the 2020 Republican primary. Hogan, a two-term governor with a reputation for bipartisan cooperation, has been making waves in the political sphere, particularly during the recent government shutdown, where he publicly criticized the President's handling of the situation.

Hogan, a 62-year-old businessman before entering politics, is known for his no-nonsense demeanor and his ability to work across party lines. He has been vocal in his criticism of Trump, particularly during the government shutdown, which had a significant impact on Maryland due to its large federal workforce.

At Baltimore-Washington International Airport in January, Hogan highlighted the plight of TSA workers and took a jab at Trump, who many blamed for the shutdown. "It's crazy. It's like, 'If I don't get my wall, I'm going to shut down the government.' 'If we don't open the government, you can't speak in our chamber.' It's a bunch of 2-year-olds, you know?" Hogan said, mocking both Trump and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

Hogan's approach to governance, characterized by moderation and centrism, has made him popular in Maryland. However, this same approach may not translate well in the early primary states like Iowa or South Carolina, where conservative, religiously-minded voters are more likely to support Trump.

Despite this, Hogan has not ruled out a potential 2020 run. In a recent interview on CNN, he stated, "I would only run if I thought that I could actually win." Hogan's expected visit to the early caucus state of Iowa in March further fuels speculation about his political ambitions.

Jerry Taylor, head of the libertarian-leaning think tank Niskanen Center, is one of Hogan's most vocal supporters. Taylor believes Hogan represents a "different vision of the Republican Party" and could be popular among voters in both parties.

However, knocking off an incumbent president in the primaries is a daunting task. The last time a sitting president lost his party's re-nomination battle was in 1856. Melissa Deckman, a political science professor at Washington College in Maryland, echoes this sentiment, stating, "Trump remains enormously popular with the base of his party. And I think that it would in some respects be a fool's errand for just about anyone to challenge Donald Trump at this point."

As Hogan focuses on his second term in Maryland, the question of a potential presidential bid remains a topic of discussion. Whether Hogan will indeed challenge Trump in 2020 remains to be seen, but one thing is certain: the political landscape is watching what Maryland's governor is doing.

Title: Controversial Song by South Bend Pastor Criticizes Evangelical Support for President Trump

A worship pastor in South Bend, Indiana, has gained attention for a song he wrote titled "Hymn for the 81%," a reference to white evangelical Christian voters who helped secure President Trump's victory in 2016. The song, which has over 400,000 views on YouTube, is a plea, according to Daniel Deitrich, the pastor for arts and worship at South Bend City Church, for these voters to return to the teachings of Jesus.

The anti-Trump pastor's song accuses Trump evangelicals of "putting kids in cages, ripping mothers from their babies" and "weaponizing religion." Deitrich told Religion News Service he originally wrote the song's bridge as "an angry middle finger to the listener" and found it "cathartic," but he toned it down and plans on releasing more songs.

Trump's spiritual adviser, Paula White, has stated that Deitrich's prayer was taken "out of context for political gain." However, Faithwire editor Tré Goins-Phillips argues that the song is not a worship song, stating that "Deitrich’s words are not elevating or edifying; they are divisive." Goins-Phillips believes that worship and discipleship should challenge individuals, but in a way that calls them back to Scripture, not to their anger towards one another.

In recent weeks, anti-Trump evangelicals have been vocal in their opposition to the president and his supporters. Former editor-in-chief of Christianity Today, Mark Galli, wrote an op-ed titled "Trump Should be Removed from Office," and a group of "Never Trump" Republicans released an attack ad called "The MAGA Church," mocking Trump's character and evangelicals' support of him. The two events surrounded the Trump 2020 campaign's launch of "Evangelicals for Trump," where more than 70 prominent pastors came out in support of Trump's re-election bid.

Deitrich told RNS that he wrote the song as a response to the issues of white supremacy, homophobia, transphobia, and sexism that he sees in society. He stated, "There’s so much work to do to combat white supremacy, homophobia, transphobia, sexism — all the ways in which people are treated as less than the children of God that they are." The pastor's song has sparked a debate among Christians regarding the role of faith in politics and the appropriate tone for worship music.

Title: Democrats Push for Full Release of Mueller Report and Testimony from Attorney General Barr

Article:

In the aftermath of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report concluding that there was no evidence of collusion between Trump campaign associates and Russia during the 2016 election, Democrats have shown no signs of letting up. Congressional leaders are calling for the release of the full report, underlying documents, and testimony from Attorney General Bill Barr.

Barr, who released a four-page summary of Mueller's findings on Sunday, noted that while the special counsel did not find evidence of collusion, he did not come to a conclusion on whether President Trump obstructed justice. Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversaw the majority of the Russia investigation after former Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself, concluded that the evidence was "not sufficient to establish that the President committed an obstruction-of-justice offense."

This conclusion has raised red flags for Democrats, who have signaled that the Mueller report is by no means the end of Trump investigations. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, in a joint statement Sunday night, blasted Barr as "not a neutral observer" and claimed he "is not in a position to make objective determinations about the report."

"Congress requires the full report and the underlying documents so that the Committees can proceed with their independent work, including oversight and legislating to address any issues the Mueller report may raise," they continued. "The American people have a right to know."

Fox News has learned that Mueller told Barr and Rosenstein three weeks ago that he would not be able to reach a conclusion on obstruction of justice.

With Mueller's decision not to issue a conclusion on the obstruction of justice issue, Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee said that it "seems like the Department of Justice is putting matters squarely in Congress's court." House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler has vowed to have Barr testify before the committee "in the near future," and said there "must be full transparency" on what Mueller uncovered "to not exonerate the President from wrongdoing."

Nadler, House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff, and House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings, in a joint statement, called into question Barr's "objectivity" and called for the release of the Special Counsel's full and complete report and all underlying documents.

Meanwhile, other House Democrats have aggressively ramped up their own Trump-related investigations, which are likely to include a network of committee probes and high-profile hearings that are likely to last well into the 2020 election year. At this point, the House Intelligence Committee is probing the president's foreign business dealings and Russian election meddling, and the House Foreign Affairs Committee, led by Chairman Eliot Engel, is also probing the president's foreign business dealings.

Title: The Rise of Asian-American Republicans: A New Era of Political Representation

Article:

In the 2014 midterm elections, Asian-Americans, the fastest-growing minority group in the United States, demonstrated a significant shift in political allegiance, with nearly half of Asian-American voters backing the Republican candidate for the House of Representatives. This 46-point swing in Asian support from 2012, when Asians voted overwhelmingly for President Obama's re-election, has left political pundits questioning the sudden change in party affiliation.

However, the eye-popping exit poll data may not accurately reflect long-term success. This shift in support is not a result of the traditional Republican outreach methods, such as nominating minority candidates in long-shot districts or last-minute ads in another language. Instead, the Republican Party has been strategically building a bench of Asian-American candidates, with more than three-dozen winning elections at the state and local level in the 2014 elections.

These victories, while not high-profile, are significant, as they will contribute to long-term success for the Republican Party. As Lanhee Chen, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution, noted in his post-election analysis, the Republican Party has finally devoted time, attention, and resources to cultivating Asian voters.

One of the most notable victories was Aumua Amata Radewagen, a member of the Republican National Committee, who will become American Samoa's first female representative to Congress. In Arizona, State Sen. Kimberly Yee, the first Asian-American elected to the state legislature, cruised to re-election by 18 points. Even in traditionally Democratic strongholds like California, the Republican Party backed four successful Asian-American women running for the state legislature and county board of supervisors.

The election of these Asian-American candidates has a compounding effect.
