"Once a community member is elected to a prominent position, it could inspire others with similar backgrounds to lead as well," argues Tim Nguyen, chair of the Asian Pacific American Coalition. Newly elected California State Sen. Janet Nguyen, the highest-ranking Vietnamese-American in the country, can recruit candidates from Little Saigon to run as Republican candidates for school board and city council.

Connecticut State Sen. Tony Hwang can raise money from the Taiwanese-American community that would otherwise never see its way to Republican coffers. San Diego City Council Chris Cate, the first Asian-American in half a century to be elected to the San Diego City Council, has the charisma to introduce GOP presidential candidates to Filipino-American voters in swing states, such as Nevada, Florida, and Virginia.

Any one of these rising stars is poised to win a conservative Republican primary for Congress. Take Oklahoma State Sen.-elect Ervin Yen, a first-generation Taiwanese-American immigrant, who is rock-solid on gun rights. "America was built by patriots who used guns to provide for their families, protect their homes, and overthrow tyranny," Mr. Yen, who immigrated to the United States after the Communist takeover of China, writes on his campaign website. "I am a strong believer that those principles are what still makes America great and that the Second Amendment must be defended from liberals who would take away our hard-won rights."

For the next two years, Republicans like Mr. Yen will be featured almost daily in Asian-language newspapers, sharing a conservative message with communities who have for too long been taken for granted by the Democrats. The Republican Party has elected a bench of bilingual stars who have real political power. And you can expect their influence to dramatically increase when the 2016 presidential candidates start calling.

Shawn Steel, a former chairman of the California Republican Party and the state's national committeeman on the Republican National Committee, is one of these stars. His influence, along with the other Asian-American Republicans, will be crucial in the upcoming elections and beyond.

Title: The Militarization of Police: A Rise in SWAT Raids and the Concerns Surrounding Tactics and Equipment

Article:

In his book "Rise of the Warrior Cop," Radley Balko recounts the escalation of police Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) teams, which began as a specialized unit for handling violent situations such as hostage-takings. The use of SWAT teams, armed with heavy military equipment, has increased significantly over the past few decades, with the number of SWAT raids rising from approximately 300 per year in the 1970s to 100 to 150 per day as of 2005.

The transformation of SWAT teams from a few specialized groups into small armies conducting raids on organic farms and legal medical marijuana dispensaries has raised concerns about the potential for terrorizing innocent people, raiding the wrong homes, and causing violence. The increase in SWAT raids began under Nixon-era politicians who sought to appear tough on crime, even if it meant exaggerating the threat posed by illegal drugs.

As the war on drugs escalated, police stopped announcing themselves when entering homes to avoid drug users destroying evidence. This change in centuries-old practice has led to numerous instances of innocent people being killed during SWAT raids. For example, Iraq War veteran Jose Guerena was killed in 2011 when police raided his home, suspecting drugs were present. After Guerena was killed, no drugs or evidence of drug dealing were found, and his brother was arrested on drug charges. Balko states, "It appears Guerena's crime was being related to someone."

The War on Terror has also contributed to the militarization of police, with the Pentagon and the Department of Homeland Security offering armored vehicles, body armor, and stun grenades to police departments, large or small. Local police have eagerly accepted these new resources, expanding the circumstances under which such equipment is used.

The police chief in Concord, New Hampshire, for instance, cited the presence of libertarians who moved to the state seeking increased individual freedom as a reason for obtaining an armored vehicle from the Department of Homeland Security. This raises concerns about the potential for overreach and the blurring of lines between military and police functions.

Libertarians, who generally support the legitimacy of police, courts, and military, argue that the ability to sleep securely in one's home without armored men bursting through the door is a fundamental freedom. As the public begins to question the effectiveness and morality of the drug war and the War on Terror, it is crucial to examine the role of SWAT teams and the potential for excessive force and overreach in domestic policing.

Title: Education Department Proposes Revisions to Title IX Standards for College Campus Sexual Harassment Cases

The Education Department is reportedly revising the Title IX standards for addressing sexual harassment and assault on college campuses. The revisions, which have not yet been finalized, aim to bolster the rights of accused students, narrow the definition of sexual harassment, and hold schools accountable only for formal complaints filed through proper authorities and for conduct said to have occurred on their campuses.

According to a draft obtained by The New York Times, the Department recognizes that despite well-intentioned efforts by school districts, colleges, and universities, advocacy organizations, and the Department itself, sexual harassment and assault continue to present serious problems across the nation's campuses. The lack of clear regulatory standards has contributed to processes that have not been fair to all parties involved, lacked appropriate procedural protections, and undermined confidence in the reliability of the outcomes of investigations of sexual harassment allegations.

However, the revisions have sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that Education Secretary Betsy DeVos isn't operating in good faith. DeVos's choice of Candice Jackson to head the department's Office for Civil Rights, which investigates Title IX complaints, has raised eyebrows. In the past, Jackson asserted to The Times that "90 percent" of assault complaints "fall into the category of 'we were both drunk,' 'we broke up, and six months later I found myself under a Title IX investigation because she just decided that our last sleeping together was not quite right.'"

Furthermore, in 2017, DeVos reached out to several men's rights groups to discuss the issue of rape on campus. The secretary met with members of Families Advocating for Campus Equality and Stop Abusive and Violent Environments, which advocate for students accused of sexual misconduct, and the National Coalition for Men, which refers to itself as "the oldest Men's Rights organization in America." The latter group recently filed its own Title IX complaint against the University of Pennsylvania because the school has "over 20 women programs... but nothing similar for men."

The revisions to Title IX standards are expected to have a significant impact on how colleges and universities handle sexual harassment and assault cases. The final rule is yet to be released, and it remains to be seen how the changes will be received by both advocates and critics.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Reports Increased Terrorist Chatter Ahead of 9/11 Anniversary

Article:

In the lead-up to the 13th anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, the U.S. intelligence community has reported a significant increase in chatter among Islamic terrorist organizations. A U.S. government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Blaze that there has been an uptick in communications, both online and via phone lines, from these groups.

While the intelligence community cannot confirm whether an attack is imminent, the official noted that similar levels of chatter were observed before the September 11 attacks. The increased chatter is attributed to the rise of the Islamic State group, which has been vying for dominance in Iraq and Syria, and has openly declared its intent to target American interests worldwide.

The threat posed by the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, is twofold. First, it is in conflict with al Qaeda, from which it was expelled in February. The two groups have been engaged in an internal power struggle, with ISIS currently gaining the upper hand. ISIS has attracted a significant number of young Muslims from around the world, potentially depriving al Qaeda of its own fighters.

Former CIA case officer Brian Fairchild told The Blaze that the approaching 9/11 anniversary could potentially benefit both terrorist groups, as an attack on U.S. soil would serve their interests. "ISIS was kicked out of al Qaeda in February and they’ve been fighting each other internally for leadership," Fairchild said. "ISIS is winning right now. They have captured the imagination of young Muslims from around the world and depriving al Qaeda of its own fighters. Al Qaeda is split down the middle and now you have 9/11 [ anniversary approaching ]. It would be beneficial to both camps that on 9/11, some great attack in the United States takes place."

The Islamic State executed American photojournalist James Foley on Aug. 19, and has used social media platforms to issue terror threats against American soil. Recently, Chicago's WGN network reported a tweet from the terror group on June 20, which included a picture taken on Michigan Ave. The tweet reads "Soldiers of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria will pass from here soon." An Arabic message held up in the picture was translated "We are in your streets."

The U.S. intelligence community continues to monitor the situation closely and remains vigilant in its efforts to protect American interests.

Title: "Unprecedented Profits and Constitutional Crisis: A Tale of Two Headlines"

Article:

In a stark contrast to the ongoing political drama surrounding the Trump administration, the U.S. economy has been thriving, as evidenced by the Wall Street Journal's front-page headline on Monday, "Profits Soar as Economy Advances." This robust economic growth, despite global economic challenges, has positioned the U.S. favorably should a trade war ensue.

However, the political landscape has been anything but tranquil. The Washington Post and New York Times have been filled with headlines about the Trump family and their associates, with stories about Donald Trump Jr.'s meeting with a Russian source and the shopping habits of Paul Manafort, among others.

The meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and the Russian source was not unusual, given the numerous scandals and instances of wrongdoing that have surrounded Hillary Clinton throughout her public life. From the Clinton Foundation to her fundraising operation, and issues such as Benghazi, Clinton's record is one that few have matched without legal consequences.

The ongoing investigation into Russian collusion with the President, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, has been a source of controversy. Critics argue that the investigation, which has taken almost two years to run its course, is akin to the Clintons' meddling in the American presidential election.

The origins of this Constitutional crisis can be traced back to Hillary Clinton's anger and frustration following her unexpected defeat in the 2016 election, as revealed in the book "Shattered: Inside Hillary Clinton's Doomed Campaign." In the aftermath of her loss, Clinton directed her aides to assemble her communications team to engineer the case that the election was not entirely on the up and up, with Russian hacking being the centerpiece of the argument.

While the book provides a starting point for understanding the current political climate, the full story is more complex. The ongoing investigation, the media's role, and the actions of the Democratic Party have raised questions about the legitimacy of the 2016 election and the motives behind the ongoing investigation. As the investigation continues, the nation waits to see how this Constitutional crisis will unfold.

Title: A Closer Look at Capitalism: An Examination of Pope Francis' Critique and the Role of Profits

In his latest apostolic exhortation, Pope Francis has taken aim at free market capitalism, arguing that it is not the panacea for global justice and inclusiveness. He has labeled unfettered capitalism as a "new tyranny." This article aims to provide a balanced perspective on the pope's critique and the role of profits in capitalism.

While it is true that capitalism, compared to heaven or a utopia, may fall short, it is essential to consider that capitalism is a practical system among the alternatives that exist on earth. For the common man, capitalism has proven superior in meeting everyday needs and desires.

Capitalism, a relatively new economic system in human history, has revolutionized the way wealth is created. Prior to capitalism, wealth was primarily amassed through looting, plundering, and enslaving fellow humans. With the advent of capitalism, wealth could be accumulated by serving and pleasing one's fellow man. Capitalists aim to discover what people want, produce, and market it as efficiently as possible to generate profit. Examples such as J.D. Rockefeller, whose successful marketing of kerosene lowered prices, and Henry Ford, who made cars affordable for the common man, demonstrate the positive impact of capitalism on everyday life.

The question arises: Are those who, through their actions, have created unprecedented convenience, longer life expectancy, and a more pleasant life for the ordinary person, while becoming wealthy in the process, deserving of the scorn and ridicule heaped upon them by intellectuals, politicians, and now the pope?

Profits play a crucial role in guiding resources to their highest-valued uses and satisfying people. A survey might reveal that profit-making enterprises, such as supermarkets, theaters, clothing stores, and computer stores, are more satisfying than services provided by nonprofit government organizations, such as public schools, post offices, and departments of motor vehicles.

Profits force entrepreneurs to find ways to please people in the most efficient ways or face bankruptcy. Nonprofits, on the other hand, have an easier time of it, as they continue to operate regardless of their effectiveness or popularity, often relying on coercive property taxes for compensation.

Arthur C. Brooks, president at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Really Cares," has shown that Americans are the most generous people on earth. Generosity, it seems, is more prevalent in countries closer to the free market end of the economic spectrum than to the socialist or communist end. Given Pope Francis' emphasis on charity as a key aspect of godliness, it is worth reconsidering the demonization of capitalism.

Title: The New York Times Faces Criticism Over Interpretation of James Hodgkinson's Motives

Article:

In the aftermath of the congressional shooting last week, the New York Times has faced criticism for a story that seemingly attempted to redefine the motives of the lone gunman, James Hodgkinson. The shooting, which left House Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) gravely injured, has been widely believed to be a result of hyper-partisan politics.

While the exact motive behind the attack may never be known, the evidence points towards partisan hatred as a significant factor. Hodgkinson's social media postings, which emerged after authorities confirmed his identity as the shooter, revealed a clear political stance: Hodgkinson was a staunch supporter of progressive politics and had a deep-seated hatred for President Donald Trump and the Republican party.

However, on Saturday, the Times published a story with a different narrative. The headline, "Before the Gunfire in Virginia, a Volatile Home Life in Illinois," suggests that Hodgkinson's personal life, rather than his political beliefs, may have been a primary factor in his actions.

The story delves into Hodgkinson's life as a foster parent, detailing instances of domestic abuse and the suicide of one foster child. It also suggests that Hodgkinson may have suffered from some form of mental illness, implying that his political beliefs had "little" to do with his targeting of only congressional Republicans.

This narrative has been met with criticism from various quarters, with some accusing the Times of trying to obscure Hodgkinson's political motives. Tweets from several users, including Caroline Arnold, Mike Stewart, Ivan Alaska, and JR Hansen, express their disapproval of the story, claiming it downplays the political aspect of the shooting and attempts to whitewash Hodgkinson's ideological beliefs.

However, it is important to note that the Times does not always shy away from highlighting the ideological beliefs of individuals who commit atrocities. For instance, in the case of the racist man who killed two people on a Portland commuter train, the Times emphasized his racist and anti-Muslim views.

In conclusion, the controversy surrounding the Times' story on James Hodgkinson's motives underscores the importance of balanced and unbiased reporting in the aftermath of tragic events. While it is crucial to understand the personal background of the perpetrator, it is equally important to acknowledge and report the political context in which such events occur.

Title: FBI Documents Reveal Hillary Clinton's Alleged Misstatement Regarding Email Advice from Colin Powell

Article:

In a recent development, FBI documents handed over to Congress this week have revealed that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton told investigators that her Republican predecessor, Colin Powell, advised her to use a personal email account. However, Powell soon issued a statement that he could recall no such conversation.

According to The New York Times, Clinton's seemingly false statement was made during a three-and-a-half-hour interview with FBI agents in early July. The alleged conversation between Clinton and Powell, as reported by journalist Joe Conason in his upcoming book "Man of the World: The Further Endeavors of Bill Clinton," took place at a small dinner party hosted by Madeleine Albright, another former secretary of state, at her home in Washington. Henry Kissinger and Condoleezza Rice also attended.

Conason's book describes a conversation in the early months of Clinton's tenure at the State Department, where Albright asked all the former secretaries to offer one piece of counsel to the nation's next top diplomat. Powell reportedly advised Clinton to use her own email, as he had done, for unclassified communications, with classified communications sent and received via a State Department computer.

It is important to note that Clinton has not publicly claimed that Powell told her to use private email. The Times notes that the efforts by Clinton and her supporters to compare her server scheme to the use of private email by earlier Secretaries of State are questionable.

Powell's office released a statement on Thursday night, stating that he had no recollection of the dinner conversation. The statement also mentioned that Powell may have written Clinton an email memo describing his use of his personal email account for unclassified messages and how it improved communications within the State Department.

However, Powell's use of personal email and Clinton's aren't entirely parallel. Powell did not have a server at his house or rely on outside contractors, as Clinton did at her home in Chappaqua, NY. A State Department inspector general report released in May stated that Powell and other senior officials had used personal email accounts for official business, but by the time Clinton took office, the rules were clear that using a private server in such a manner was neither allowed nor encouraged due to "significant security risks."

Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-IA) has criticized the FBI for allegedly improperly limiting access to its files, creating an unusual situation where Hillary Clinton cannot be prosecuted for her actions, but congressional staffers who discuss her actions will be prosecuted.

Clinton's campaign communications director, Jennifer Palmieri, responded to the allegations, stating, "Would remind all that this material is classified. So this is leaking of classified material." However, the officials seemed less concerned about the safeguarding of classified information when it was housed on a private server owned by Clinton. Indeed, Palmieri denied the existence of such emails.

As the FBI continues to release documents, it remains to be seen how this development will impact the ongoing discussions surrounding Clinton's email practices during her tenure as Secretary of State.

Title: The Bubble: Trump's Executive Order on Family Separation Met with Skepticism from Liberals and Conservatives

Article:

In a swift turn of events, President Donald Trump issued an executive order to end the controversial policy of family separation at the U.S.-Mexico border. However, the move has been met with skepticism and criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, with liberals questioning the order's effectiveness and conservatives accusing Democrats of politicizing the issue.

Each week, ███'s OnPolitics blog takes a look at how media from the left and the right reacted to a political news story, giving liberals and conservatives a peek into the other's media bubble. This week, commentators reacted to President Trump's decision to issue an executive order to end his own immigration policy that involves separating families.

Liberals were unsparing in their attacks on the policy, which they called "cruel and inhumane." Many criticized the order as merely swapping family separation for jailing children, with some going as far as to compare the situation to Nazi death camps.

Conservatives were also critical of Trump's policy and his handling of the controversy. However, they also attacked Democrats for refusing to compromise on immigration, with some accusing those on the left of not wanting the separations to stop because they wanted to continue using the issue as a political football.

CNN's Chris Cillizza described Trump's shift on his immigration policy as a "fundamental miscalculation." Being "tough" on immigration is not a political positive when it leads to images of kids being ripped from their parents, Cillizza said. He added that Trump's strategic decision to cast the border crisis as something that was not his fault and that he was powerless to fix was not true.

Radio host Rush Limbaugh said the media and Democrats would react to Trump's executive order by both triumphantly crying that they forced Trump to "cave" on the issue while also backing legal challenges to keep the issue alive. Limbaugh accused Democrats of not caring about the children and using them as political pawns.

New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo wrote in a New York Times op-ed that the Trump administration's inhumane treatment of immigrant children has left a "dark stain" on the history of the nation. He called the executive order a "no solution at all" and said it still leaves open the long-term detention of immigrant children and the potential for irreparable harm to those children who were used as pawns in the president's political agenda.

The Federalist's David Harsanyi conceded that family separation is "callous and ineffective," but he said the Democrats' defense of the policy and their unwillingness to make any compromise on the issue is "ginned-up moral panic, pious grandstanding, and comparisons to Nazi death camps."

With this executive order, the policy of separating families appears to cease. However, child internment will continue, with families together as prisoners in federal custody. Young children will still be locked in "tender age" camps, asylum-seekers will still be criminalized as dangers and threats to national integrity, and there is still the matter of those children already separated from their parents.

In conclusion, the executive order ending family separation at the U.S.-Mexico border has been met with skepticism and criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. While the policy of separating families appears to cease, the long-term detention of immigrant children and the potential for irreparable harm to those children who were already separated remains a contentious issue.

Title: Reflecting on Two Decades of U.S. Involvement in Afghanistan: A Historical Perspective

Article:

In the annals of history, the U.S. involvement in Afghanistan may be seen as a mirror image of other great powers that have attempted to exert influence in the country's rugged terrain. Historians might conclude that, much like the British, the Soviet Union, and potentially the United States, these powers found themselves frustrated, stalemated, and reluctant to bear the significant costs associated with their presence.

The British withdrawal in 1842, marked by 4,500 casualties and preceded by massacres, was a precursor to the invention of the roadside bomb. They relinquished their sovereignty over Afghanistan in 1919, signaling the beginning of the unraveling of their empire. The Soviet Union departed in 1989, concluding a decade-long effort to control the country, months before the fall of the Berlin Wall, a symbol of the collapse of the Communist superpower.

The U.S.-led operation, named "Operation Enduring Freedom," commenced on October 7, 2001, following the attacks on the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and a plane crash in Pennsylvania. In a speech from the Treaty Room of the White House, President George W. Bush pledged to "win this conflict by the patient accumulation of successes, by meeting a series of challenges with determination, will, and purpose."

In the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, the country rallied behind Bush. While some cautioned against entering the "graveyard of empires," the war was perceived more as a retaliatory and justice-seeking mission rather than a nation-building endeavor.

The capture of Osama Bin Laden in Pakistan in May 2011 and the diminished threat of Al Qaeda left politicians grappling to define the purpose of American troops' continued presence. Over 2,400 service members have lost their lives in combat since the invasion, according to icasualties.org. Neither President Obama nor President Trump could convincingly argue that, after nearly two decades, the U.S. had a significant role to play other than propping up a fragile democracy.

Title: Elizabeth Warren's Rallying Cry for "Nasty Women" Amidst Political Hypocrisy

Article:

In a fiery speech during her campaigning for Hillary Clinton on Monday, Senator Elizabeth Warren, in a nod to Donald Trump's infamous phrase from the third debate, declared, "Get this Donald: Nasty women are tough, nasty women are smart, and nasty women vote. And on November 8th, we nasty women are going to march our nasty feet to cast our nasty votes to get you out of our lives forever."

Warren's speech was a scathing critique of Trump's treatment of women, accusing him of disrespecting more than half the human population. "Donald Trump aggressively disrespects more than half the human beings in this country," she said. "He thinks that because he has money, that he can call women fat pigs and bimbos. He thinks that because he is a celebrity, he can rate women's bodies from one to 10. He thinks that because he has a mouth full of Tic-Tacs, he can force himself on any woman within groping distance."

The speech, however, raised questions about Warren's own political history, given her past praise for the late Senator Ted Kennedy, who was known for his loutish behavior towards women, including causing the death of one. Warren, in her Senate race, had called Kennedy her moral compass in politics.

Warren, in her speech, spoke fondly of Kennedy, saying, "Ted Kennedy changed my life. He changed how I understood what it is that a public servant does. I think of him in this race every single day, and I come to this convention and think about him every single hour." She also spoke of the "special" inscription Kennedy had carved on the desk she now sits at in the Senate.

The speech, however, drew attention to the hypocrisy of the political landscape, with the election of a woman who has been accused of sexual misconduct holding onto the coattails of a credibly accused rapist, Bill Clinton, and making the basis of her victory the unacceptability of a "pig" in the White House.

Critics have also pointed out the irony of a candidate who takes money from Islamic countries that kill and maim women, supports sex-selection abortion, champions the disabled while defending partial-birth abortions aimed at them, and relies on deep-pocketed male cronies to save her from prosecution, being portrayed as a champion of women's rights.

In one of Hillary Clinton's ads, a young girl can be seen looking into a mirror, with a series of Trump's remarks about women playing in the background. The ad ends with the question, "Is this the president we want for our daughters?" If the young girl looked into that mirror, she would see a corrupt pol standing on the shoulders of Bill Clinton and Ted Kennedy. As the parents of Monica Lewinsky could tell her, the Democrats long ago ceased to be a party safe for anyone's daughters.

Title: Democrats and Republicans Clash Over Trump Administration's Proposed CHIP Funding Cuts

Article:

In a heated exchange on Tuesday, Democrats and Republicans found themselves on opposite sides of the aisle regarding the Trump administration's proposal to roll back $15 billion in previously allocated funding, with a significant portion coming from the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP). The administration's request seeks to claw back money from CHIP, a move that has sparked strong opposition from Democrats.

The controversy stems from the March $1.3 trillion spending bill, in which a majority of congressional Democrats, including House and Senate Democrats, voted to rescind CHIP funding. However, the White House argues that nearly half of the requested rescissions come from two accounts within CHIP—$7 billion from funds that can't be or won't be spent under law and an additional $2 billion in contingency funds. The White House stated on Monday evening that a substantial portion of the $7 billion cut to CHIP funding comes from 2017, which has now expired.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer was among the first to speak out against the proposal, setting the tone for an upcoming fight. "Let's be honest about what this is: President Trump and Republicans in Congress are looking to tear apart the bipartisan (CHIP), hurting middle-class families and low-income children, to appease the most conservative special interests and feel better about blowing up the deficit to give the wealthiest few and biggest corporations huge tax breaks," Schumer said on Monday.

Similarly, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi stated that her colleagues were not ready to strike a deal. "These Republican rescissions show the hypocrisy of a GOP Congress that insists on tight budgets for children and families while handing enormous, unpaid-for giveaways to corporations and the wealthiest," Pelosi said in a statement to members on Monday.

The confusion arises as many of the same Democrats who are now speaking out against the proposed cuts had already voted to rescind CHIP funding not even three months ago in March. Members of Congress voted to rescind $3.1 billion from the CHIP Contingency Fund and $3.6 billion in funds provided to states, totaling just under $7 billion.

The administration's proposal has also drawn criticism from Democratic senators, who took to Twitter to express their disdain for the proposal due to its requests for cuts to the CHIP program. Senators such as Mark Warner, Tammy Baldwin, Catherine Cortez Masto, Debbie Stabenow, and Bob Casey all tweeted their opposition to the proposal, with many emphasizing the bipartisan effort that was made to secure 10 years of CHIP funding in early February.

This development comes after lawmakers agreed to a 10-year extension of CHIP funding in early February, which included $7 billion towards community health centers, $6 billion to address opioids and mental health care, and other provisions supported on a bipartisan basis.

In 2011, Democratic Sen. Debbie Stabenow of Michigan put forth an amendment that called for the rescinding of $44 billion in unobligated funds—an amount three times the size of the administration's proposal. The amendment garnered the support of 81 senators, including Democratic Sens. Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, Dianne Feinstein of California, Chris Coons of Delaware, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Claire McCaskill of Missouri, Bob Menendez of New Jersey, Bill Nelson of Florida, and Ron Wyden of Oregon.

GOP Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, who is ambivalent about the president's proposal due to CHIP funding, also voted for Stabenow's amendment in 2011. The ongoing debate over the administration's proposed CHIP funding cuts promises to be a contentious issue in the coming weeks.

Title: Pelosi Suggests Trump's Actions May Be Building His Own Case for Impeachment, Calls for Attorney General Barr to be Held in Contempt

Article:

In a live interview with The Washington Post on Wednesday, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) suggested that President Donald Trump's actions could be contributing to his own case for impeachment due to his continued obstruction of lawmakers' demands for testimony and documents from the White House.

Pelosi stated, "He's becoming self-impeachable in terms of some of the things he's doing." The speaker has consistently cautioned against the divisive process of impeachment, warning that it should not be taken lightly. On Tuesday and Wednesday, she suggested that Trump might be attempting to provoke Democratic lawmakers into initiating impeachment proceedings.

During the interview with The Washington Post's Robert Costa, Pelosi noted that one of the articles of impeachment against President Richard Nixon charged obstruction of Congress, but she declined to commit to a similar narrow impeachment push against Trump.

Pelosi also asserted that Attorney General William Barr should be held in contempt for his refusal to release an unredacted version of the Mueller report. However, she stopped short of calling for Barr's impeachment. While acknowledging the need to protect certain parts of Mueller's findings, Pelosi argued that lawmakers had tried to accommodate some of those concerns when the White House intervened.

The House Judiciary Committee is scheduled to meet Wednesday to vote on a contempt motion against Barr for missing the committee's self-imposed deadline for turning over the full report last week. Pelosi noted that Wednesday's contempt motion did not account for Barr's refusal to appear before the Judiciary Committee last week, objecting to being questioned by committee staff in addition to lawmakers. She took a swipe at Barr's no-show, suggesting he felt "safer in the Republican majority in the Senate," where he had testified the day before.

Title: "Justice on Trial: A Behind-the-Scenes Look at the Kavanaugh Confirmation and the Future of the Supreme Court"

Article:

In their new book, "Justice on Trial: The Kavanaugh Confirmation and the Future of the Supreme Court," authors Mollie Hemingway and Carrie Severino offer an in-depth account of the tumultuous confirmation process of Brett Kavanaugh, detailing the behind-the-scenes strategy employed by the White House and Kavanaugh's team during the height of the controversy surrounding Christine Blasey Ford's allegations.

The book, which includes interviews with Trump, top White House officials, several Supreme Court justices, and numerous others, reveals a central conundrum for Kavanaugh and his supporters. According to the authors, the team "understood that any criticism of Ford would be treated as a smear" and depicted as "victim shaming."

Despite the potential damage to Kavanaugh's reputation, the book states that the team chose to focus on his record and the allegations against him. The authors touch on some of the alleged details involving Ford, but they are also critical of the coverage of the nomination drama, particularly in the New York Times and Washington Post. They blame, in part, "the media's irrational personal dislike of Kavanaugh."

The authors are particularly critical of The New Yorker for publishing the allegations of Deborah Ramirez, a Yale classmate of Kavanaugh who claimed that he exposed himself to her and caused her to touch his genitals. The magazine was unable to find a corroborating witness, acknowledging that Ramirez had "significant gaps" in her memories and that it took her six days of assessing those memories and consulting with a lawyer to name Kavanaugh. He flatly denied the allegations.

The book also discusses the allegations made by Julie Swetnick, another accuser who claimed that Kavanaugh and a friend became inebriated and sexually assaulted women at house parties in the early 1980s. The authors call the allegations "obviously ridiculous," stating that "no one could have hidden such crimes for decades, much less a man who went on to hold high-profile positions in the White House and then became a judge on the second-most prominent federal court."

The authors offer numerous examples of what they call "the media's irrational personal dislike of Kavanaugh," citing instances such as the New York Times publishing a story co-authored by Emily Bazelon, who had already announced her opposition to Kavanaugh, and USA Today columnist Erik Brady suggesting that Kavanaugh should give up his school coaching duties because "credibly accused sex offenders" should "stay off basketball courts for now when kids are around."

The book also highlights the support Kavanaugh received from his wife, Ashley, who reportedly sustained herself through the ordeal by praying regularly and studying the Bible. The book concludes with a lengthy speech by Sen. Susan Collins, a key swing vote, in which she announced her decision to vote to confirm Kavanaugh. Ashley made an emotional call to her husband and told him to watch it, while Kavanaugh texted her a message of thanks and promised that he would not disappoint her.

Title: Congress Faces Challenges in Addressing DACA as Supreme Court Ruling Looms

Article:

As the Supreme Court's conservative majority casts doubt on the future of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, Congress is grappling with the possibility of taking on the contentious immigration issue. With a ruling expected in the spring, during an election year, the politics of immigration are set to become even more complex.

The Senate has struggled to pass substantial immigration bills since passing a comprehensive overhaul in 2013, which was largely ignored by the House. The chamber did manage to pass a spending bill providing aid to the border this year, but internal party disputes made the process difficult.

The trust deficit between Senate Democrats and the president is a significant hurdle. Many Democrats feel burned by past negotiations, citing failed attempts at transportation, gun safety, and immigration reform. Centrist Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) expressed his frustration, stating, "It is exceptionally difficult to make any deal that sticks."

The president's tweet this week, stating that a deal would be made with Democrats if the Supreme Court rules in favor of DACA, has been met with skepticism. In 2018, a bipartisan immigration proposal received support from only eight Republicans, a number that advocates believe could have been higher without the president's intervention.

The House passed legislation addressing DACA protections earlier this year, but the Senate has yet to take action. With the Senate's 60-vote requirement, any immigration bill would need either seven Democrats or 13 Republicans to cross party lines. Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) bluntly stated, "We don't have the votes in the Senate, OK?"

The GOP, which controls the Senate, is generally more divided on the issue than the Democratic Party. Trump lost 14 votes from the Senate GOP on his 2018 immigration bill, indicating that any legislation providing a path to citizenship for some undocumented immigrants may be a bridge too far for some Republicans.

Despite these challenges, some senators believe that Congress should begin working on a plan now rather than waiting for the Supreme Court to force their hand. Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) expressed concern, stating, "If they strike it down, there's going to be chaos."

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), a supporter of the 2013 comprehensive immigration bill, suggested narrowing legislation to cover only the 660,000 young people whose status could be affected by the Supreme Court's decision. Rubio emphasized the need to focus on the Dreamers, stating, "The challenge here on immigration at large is that any limited bill is never enough."

However, this time, there are more hurdles than usual. Lawmakers' primary legislative objective is to fund the government, a task that's proving difficult. Impeachment is also looming, with a trial likely to paralyze the Senate for weeks and make tackling other legislation even more challenging.

The Democratic primary is heating up, and the general election will be in full swing when the Supreme Court decides whether to allow Trump to terminate President Barack Obama's executive action protecting the immigrants. Trump has campaigned as an immigration hard-liner, and a pivot to the middle would surprise most in Washington.

The biggest problem may be securing Democratic votes for any plan that doesn't have the president's full and explicit support. The bipartisan immigration deal cut by Sens. Angus King (I-Maine) and Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) last year received the vote of every Democrat but three. King, who caucuses with the Democrats, stated, "We had a bill, he could have his whole wall and DACA would have been fixed and he killed it."

Title: Opinion: The Iowa Caucuses: A Persistent and Valuable Part of the Presidential Nominating Process

Article:

In a recent column for the Des Moines Register, Kathie Obradovich argues that the Iowa caucuses, despite their perceived flaws, serve a valuable function in the presidential nominating process. Obradovich acknowledges the criticisms leveled against the caucuses, but maintains that they offer a unique and important opportunity for voters to engage with candidates and make informed decisions.

According to Obradovich, the Iowa caucuses are often seen as a nuisance, particularly by those who do not understand them. However, she argues that the caucuses are not undesirable pests, but rather perform a valuable function for the state and the country. Obradovich highlights the "nobility" of the caucuses in their persistence, despite efforts to crush them by other states and powerful individuals.

One of the main challenges facing the Iowa caucuses is the issue of absentee voting. In an effort to expand participation and prevent disenfranchisement, the Democratic National Committee (DNC) has required Iowa, and other caucus states, to come up with an absentee voting process. However, Obradovich notes that absentee voting has long posed a problem for the Iowa caucuses due to the need to maintain the state's first-in-the-nation status and avoid trespassing on New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary election.

The DNC has expressed concerns about the security of a potential telephonic caucus process, but Obradovich argues that this is a misunderstanding of the nature of caucuses. Caucuses are not elections and should not be held to the same standards for participation or security as elections. Obradovich also points out that the DNC's concerns seem to arise from a fundamental misunderstanding of caucuses, as caucuses are not intended to be convenient and are meant to be inconvenient in order to force voters to educate themselves about the issues and candidates.

Obradovich concludes by arguing that the Iowa caucuses are a vital part of the American democratic process and that efforts to eliminate them would be a blow to the American dream of anyone being able to grow up to be president. She suggests that the DNC should reconsider its blanket prohibition on telephone caucuses or rethink its requirement for an absentee caucus process.

Kathie Obradovich is the opinion editor for the Des Moines Register, where this column originally appeared. Follow her on Twitter @ KObradovich.

Title: A Closer Look at the Sessions-Russia Controversy: Separating Fact from Fiction

Article:

In the wake of the recent revelation that U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions had undisclosed meetings with Russia's ambassador, a cloud of uncertainty has been cast over the Trump administration. Initially, the story seemed to suggest collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials, but upon closer examination, the narrative appears to be more complex.

The Washington Post reported that Sessions, during his confirmation hearing to become attorney general, did not disclose two meetings he had with Russia's ambassador to the United States last year. This omission has sparked a heated debate, with some, like former President George W. Bush's chief White House ethics lawyer Richard W. Painter, calling it a "bombshell of a story." On the other hand, Senator Ted Cruz has dismissed it as a "nothing burger."

Upon reevaluating the situation, I initially proposed three possible explanations for Sessions' actions: (1) Sessions was colluding with Moscow and trying to hide it, (2) Sessions wasn't colluding but forgot about the meetings, or (3) Sessions wasn't colluding but decided to lie about contacts with Russians.

However, after a thorough review of the facts, I find all three hypotheses to be flawed. The key question is: did Sessions perjure himself, and was there a cover-up?

To answer this question, it's essential to examine the specifics of the situation. During Sessions' confirmation hearing, Senator Patrick Leahy asked, "Several of the President-Elect's nominees or senior advisers have Russian ties. Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after election day?" Sessions responded, "No."

This response, in light of the subsequent revelation of the meetings, raises questions about Sessions' honesty. However, it's important to note that the question asked by Leahy was specific and focused on contacts related to the 2016 election. Sessions' meetings with the Russian ambassador occurred in the context of his role as a senator, not as a member of the Trump campaign.

In conclusion, while the Sessions-Russia controversy has generated much speculation, a closer examination of the facts suggests that the situation is more nuanced than initially perceived. The key question is whether Sessions intentionally misled Congress during his confirmation hearing, and that remains to be determined. The investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election is ongoing, and it's crucial that all parties involved cooperate fully to ensure transparency and accountability.

Title: Iran's Foreign Minister Expresses Assumptions on US Withdrawal from Nuclear Deal, Threatens to Abandon Limitations

Article:

Iran's Foreign Minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, has expressed his assumption that the United States will withdraw from the international nuclear deal, restricting Iran's nuclear activities. In an interview with two British newspapers, the Financial Times and the Guardian, Zarif expressed hope that Europe would maintain the agreement.

US President Donald Trump, a critic of the deal, is expected to announce next month whether he believes Iran has complied with the agreement's terms. If Trump determines that Iran has not adhered to the agreement, US Congress will initiate the process of reimposing sanctions on Iran. Trump previously described the agreement as an "embarrassment" in a speech to the United Nations this month.

France, Germany, and the UK, which, along with Russia and China, signed the deal, have recently defended it. If the deal collapses, Iran would no longer be bound by its limitations on uranium enrichment, centrifuge numbers, and the production of plutonium, according to Zarif. However, he insisted that Iran would only use nuclear technology for peaceful purposes.

"You either live by it [the deal] or you set it aside," Zarif told the Financial Times and the Guardian. "You can not be half pregnant."

Zarif stated that if the deal collapses, Iran would be walking away with improved technology, as the agreement allowed Iran to continue its research and development. He criticized Trump, stating, "I think he has made a policy of being unpredictable, and now he's turning that into being unreliable as well. He has violated the letter, spirit, everything of the deal."

Zarif added that Iran's options would depend on how the rest of the international community responds to the US. "If Europe and Japan and Russia and China decided to go along with the US, then I think that will be the end of the deal," he said. "Europe should lead."

European Union officials have stated they could act to legally protect European investors in Iran if the US reimposes sanctions. However, they have also criticized Iran over its non-nuclear activities in the region.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Resurrection of Reagan-Era Rule Aimed at Planned Parenthood

Article:

In a move that has been met with both praise and criticism, the Trump administration has announced plans to reinstate a rule that would prohibit federally funded family planning clinics from discussing abortion with patients. The policy, often referred to as the "gag rule," is expected to face legal challenges and could potentially impact Planned Parenthood, a major recipient of grants for family planning and basic preventive care.

White House senior adviser Kellyanne Conway stated to Fox News that the administration is merely recognizing that "abortion is not family planning, this is family planning money." An administration official confirmed that the Department of Health and Human Services officially filed the rule with the Office of Management and Budget on Friday.

Planned Parenthood, a target of President Trump's campaign promises during the 2016 election, could face implications due to this policy. Dawn Laguens, the organization's executive vice president, expressed concern, stating, "The end result would make it impossible for women to come to Planned Parenthood, who are counting on us every day."

However, the administration maintains that Planned Parenthood can still receive Title X grants if they separate family-planning funds from those used for abortions. An administration official explained, "This proposal does not necessarily defund Planned Parenthood, as long as they're willing to disentangle taxpayer funds from abortion as a method of family planning."

The nation's family planning program, known as Title X, serves approximately four million women annually at a cost of about $260 million to taxpayers. The policy, which was rescinded under President Bill Clinton, was originally implemented during the Reagan era.

The new proposal aims to roll back the Clinton-era requirement that abortion should be discussed as an option along with prenatal care and adoption. Critics argue that the ban on counseling women infringes upon the doctor-patient relationship, while abortion opponents claim that the federal family planning program inadvertently cross-subsidizes abortion services provided by Planned Parenthood.

The Republican-led Congress has previously attempted, unsuccessfully, to deny federal funds to Planned Parenthood. The Trump administration has pledged to continue this effort, as part of its commitment to religious and social conservatives. The policy's implementation and potential legal challenges remain to be seen.

Title: Study Finds No Significant Differences in Intellectual Humility Between Liberals and Conservatives

Article:

A new study published in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology has found that both liberals and conservatives are similarly motivated to avoid information that contradicts their beliefs, challenging the common perception that conservatives are more prone to intellectual isolation.

The study, led by psychology professor Jeremy Frimer of the University of Winnipeg in Canada, was inspired by a conversation with a liberal philosophy professor who expressed a reluctance to engage with opposing viewpoints. This conversation prompted Frimer to investigate the reasons behind confirmation bias and whether political ideologies play a role in the willingness to remain in ideological bubbles.

The study, which involved over 2,400 participants across five experiments, identified several issues that people are particularly keen to avoid debating, including climate change, the merits of presidential candidates, and same-sex marriage. In the case of same-sex marriage, the majority of people on both sides of the debate were willing to forgo a chance to win money to avoid hearing from someone with an opposing view.

The study's authors found that this avoidance of opposing viewpoints was not due to election fatigue or a feeling of being well-informed about both sides of the issue. Instead, participants from both sides were trying to avoid the discomfort that comes with conflicting opinions and were concerned that disagreeing with someone would damage their relationship with them.

Frimer and his colleagues also found that this lack of interest in opposing viewpoints was not unique to conservatives, as the dominant view within social psychology has been that conservatives are more prone to avoiding dissenting opinions than liberals. The study suggests that both liberals and conservatives perceive themselves as being on the right side of an epic moral battle, leading to self-righteousness and the belief that their side is motivated by love and reason, while the other side is motivated by hatred and ignorance.

The study comes with a few caveats. The participants were disproportionately wealthy, well-educated, and white, and the opinions included in the analysis were ones that the subjects had already developed. Additionally, the study did not ask subjects to form a new opinion on a novel or hypothetical issue.

The study's authors also acknowledge that one side may have better reasons to want to ignore the other or be justifiably disinterested in what the other side has to say. For example, they cite the fact that Trump lied much more often than Clinton on the campaign trail during the 2016 presidential campaign and the emergence of fake news aimed at undermining Clinton's credibility as potential asymmetries in the defensibility of the two sides.

Regardless of political affiliation, people tend to see their own views as unquestionably right and others' as unquestionably wrong. Frimer and his colleagues write that "Liberals may think that conservatives' views truly are irrational, indefensible, and the product of fear — and thus not worth hearing," but "a conservative might have a similar impression of liberals' beliefs, opinions, and reasoning." The result is a situation where "What could ultimately be a contest of ideas is being replaced by two, non-interacting monopolies" — a situation we are all responsible for helping to create.

Title: Kentucky Senate Race: McConnell and Grimes Clash in First Debate, Accusing Each Other of Obstructing Jobs and Agenda

Article:

In a heated and contentious debate on Monday, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell and his Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes engaged in a lively exchange, each accusing the other of obstructing jobs and furthering their respective agendas.

The one-hour televised debate, the only Senate debate this season, sparked fireworks as McConnell accused Grimes of supporting President Obama's "jobs-killing agenda" and being complicit in the "war on coal." Grimes, in turn, accused McConnell of being a self-serving Washington insider who has profited from his government job while keeping Kentuckians poor.

McConnell, who has been in office for five terms, opened the debate by stating, "The biggest problem we've got is this Obama jobs-killing agenda that my opponent supports." He went on to criticize the administration's policies, particularly its impact on the coal industry in Kentucky.

Grimes countered McConnell's accusations, stating, "It's due to gridlock and the partisanship he has championed." She also defended herself against McConnell's attempts to link her to Obama, emphasizing that the president is not on the ballot this year.

Grimes, who has called herself a Clinton Democrat, declined to state whether she voted for President Obama, citing her constitutional right to privacy at the ballot box. This is the second time in a few days that Grimes has declined to disclose her voting record.

McConnell, who has been a vocal critic of Obama throughout the campaign, accused Grimes of trying to "deceive Kentuckians" and "hide her views." He also reiterated his opposition to ObamaCare and the president's economic recovery efforts, labeling ObamaCare as "the worst piece of legislation in the last half century" and calling for its complete removal.

Grimes, the current Kentucky Secretary of State, emphasized her jobs plan, stating, "My jobs plan would grow the middle class." She also accused McConnell of opposing legislation to help children.

The closely-watched race is considered one of the toughest in McConnell's 30-year Senate career and is among the six or seven races that will determine whether Republicans take control of the Senate. A McConnell loss would make the Republicans' task of winning back the upper chamber more challenging.

Both candidates agreed that creating jobs was their top priority, with Grimes adopting the role of the aggressive underdog. The race is expected to be the most expensive of the cycle, with millions poured in by both parties. The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee recently contributed $1.4 million to Grimes, in addition to the half-million already spent on the race.

According to a nonpartisan website, RealClearPolitics.com, McConnell, who survived a primary Tea Party challenge, currently leads by 3 percentage points. The 72-year-old McConnell would likely become the Senate majority leader if his party takes control of the upper chamber, potentially derailing the remainder of Obama's second term.

Grimes has consistently stated that McConnell's conservative leadership has denied Kentuckians jobs and healthcare. Much of their campaign money is coming from interests outside of the state. Hollywood types are eager to upset a top Capitol Hill Republican, while McConnell supporters are trying to stop what they consider overspending and overreaching by the Obama administration, including the Environmental Protection Agency's crackdown on the coal industry.

The McConnell campaign and its allies throughout the election cycle have continuously run TV ads comparing Grimes to Obama. Two of these groups, Kentuckians for Strong Leadership and the Kentucky Opportunity Coalition, have put down a combined $5.2 million in General Election ad time.

Grimes, in response to the ad campaigns, stated, "You and your henchmen, the Koch brothers, have misled Kentuckians with $50 million in deceptive ads." The Koch brothers are prominent conservative donors.

The debate highlighted the stark differences between the two candidates and the issues that will likely dominate the campaign in the coming weeks. The race will be a crucial determinant in the balance of power in the Senate and the direction of the country's political landscape.

Title: Democrats' Tactics in Kavanaugh Hearing: Screaming, Whining, and Misinformation

Article:

In the ongoing Supreme Court confirmation hearings for President Trump's nominee, Judge Brett Kavanaugh, Democrats have resorted to unconventional tactics in their attempts to oppose his ascension. With their limited power, they have been left with two options: protests and accusations.

Senators Kamala Harris and Cory Booker, both vocal opponents of Kavanaugh's nomination, disrupted the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. Harris called for an adjournment to review more of Kavanaugh's documents, while Booker interrupted the hearing ten times within the first 40 minutes. Other senators, including Richard Blumenthal, Mazie Hirono, Amy Klobuchar, Sheldon Whitehouse, Patrick Leahy, and Chris Coons, also disrupted the proceedings.

Protests outside the hearing room were equally contentious. Women's March activist Linda Sarsour was arrested for disrupting the proceedings, while several feminist protesters dressed as characters from "The Handmaid's Tale" and others shouted during the hearing, leading to their ejection.

In a bizarre twist, Planned Parenthood Action tweeted, "This is what the resistance looks like, and we're going to fight like hell to #StopKavanaugh."

The Democrats' second tactic was to engage in accusations and misinformation. A viral Twitter storm erupted over Zina Bash, a former Kavanaugh law clerk, who was accused of using a white supremacy signal during the hearing. However, Bash, who is half-Mexican and half-Jewish, and whose paternal grandparents were Holocaust survivors, was not making a white power gesture as claimed.

Another instance of misinformation emerged when Fred Guttenberg, the father of a Parkland shooting victim, claimed that Kavanaugh refused to shake his hand. However, it was later revealed that security had intervened before Kavanaugh could shake Guttenberg's hand.

With the political landscape increasingly polarized, the judicial confirmation hearings have become largely performative, with nominees and senators carefully avoiding direct questions about judicial rulings and philosophy. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell could end this circus by bringing Kavanaugh up for a vote. However, the political theater will likely continue, with Democrats maintaining their presence in the ring.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Affordable Care Act: Three Potential Scenarios for the White House

Article:

The Supreme Court is expected to deliver its ruling on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) later this month. The court's questions during the arguments are notoriously unpredictable, but conventional wisdom suggests that the law may lose its keystone provision, the individual mandate, or even be entirely dismantled.

President Barack Obama's administration is bracing for the decision, aiming to keep the health care law from becoming a defining issue of the 2012 election. The election, according to a top Democrat with close ties to the campaign, is expected to focus on the economy, with health care being significant only in the context of the larger economy.

The administration is reportedly preparing for three main scenarios, each with varying degrees of severity, in the event that the Supreme Court rules against the ACA.

1. The court may strike down the individual mandate while keeping the rest of the law intact. This would preserve popular provisions such as covering pre-existing conditions, eliminating the "donut hole" gap for senior prescription benefits, and allowing young adults to stay on their parents' health plans until age 26.

2. Another scenario under consideration is that the court could eliminate both the individual mandate and the provision covering pre-existing conditions. This would leave a fragmented law that might not function effectively.

3. The third scenario, considered less likely but still a possibility, is that the court upholds the ACA in its entirety.

Polls suggest that a majority of voters prefer a hybrid solution, with 51% either wanting the individual mandate struck down or the law upheld in its entirety. This aligns with years of polling showing that individual components of the ACA, particularly the ban on discrimination based on pre-existing conditions, are more popular than the law as a whole.

However, some argue that a piecemeal approach would result in political confusion and flawed policy, as the popular provisions would not function effectively without the mandate, which provides the funding for these benefits.

The Supreme Court's decision on the ACA will have significant implications for the future of health care in the United States, and the Obama administration is preparing for a range of possible outcomes.

Title: Republican National Convention Shaping Up to Be a Contentious Spectacle Amidst Trump's Controversial Campaign

Article:

The Republican National Convention, traditionally a grand spectacle of political unity and celebration, is expected to take a different turn this year as the party grapples with the divisive and controversial nature of presumptive nominee Donald Trump's campaign.

While the Democrats are likely to follow the conventional script in Philadelphia, with Hillary Clinton emerging as the party's nominee and the party unified for the general election campaign, the GOP convention in Cleveland is shaping up to be a contentious affair.

The convention is facing a significant challenge as numerous high-profile Republican politicians are declining to speak or attend the event. Trey Gowdy, the Republican Congressman from South Carolina, and Florida Rep. Carlos Curbelo are among those who have announced they will not be attending.

The list of non-attendees is growing, with Sen. Ben Sasse, Sen. Mark Kirk, Sen. Kelly Ayotte, Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner, Sen. Lindsey Graham, Rep. Mark Sanford, and many others opting out. The reasons for their absence range from scheduling conflicts to a reluctance to associate with Trump's campaign.

The reluctance of these politicians to speak or attend the convention is not unexpected, given that a significant portion of the country (approximately 70%) opposes Trump's campaign, as noted by Stuart Stevens. Supporting Trump is a risky move for most politicians, as it could potentially damage their political careers in the long term.

Further complicating matters is the ongoing #NeverTrump movement, which is reportedly planning to stage a coup at the convention. The plan, according to reports, is to "unbind" the GOP delegates, allowing them to vote according to their conscience rather than the will of their constituents. However, this plan is unlikely to succeed, as the majority of delegates oppose the move and the RNC is aware of the potential damage such an action could cause.

Despite the efforts of the #NeverTrump movement, their actions are likely to keep the convention awkward and potentially chaotic. With a shortage of relevant and respectable speakers, the RNC will struggle to paper over the cracks in the party's unity. The convention will serve as a stark reminder of a party divided and struggling to find a cohesive identity or a viable path to victory in November.

Title: Unemployment Claims Decrease, but High Number of Americans Remain Jobless Amidst Ongoing Economic Downturn

Article:

In a recent report, the Department of Labor revealed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits totaled 2.1 million last week, marking a decrease from the previous week's upwardly revised 2.438 million. This figure, while lower, still indicates that a historically high number of Americans remain separated from their jobs. Economists surveyed by Dow Jones had anticipated 2.05 million claims.

The decline in initial claims suggests a potential improvement in the job market, but the total number of continuing claims, or those who have been collecting for at least two weeks, remains high. The number of continuing claims dropped sharply, falling 3.86 million from the previous week, indicating that some businesses are rehiring workers as states reopen.

Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, noted that while the data shows progress, it may not be entirely accurate due to noisy data, particularly from California, which may not accurately represent some states' situations.

The insured unemployment rate, a basic calculation of those collecting benefits versus the total labor force, dropped sharply to 14.5% from 17.1% the previous week. Gus Faucher, chief economist at PNC, stated, "Layoffs continue at a massive scale, according to the latest unemployment insurance report, but it may be that the job market is nearing a turning point."

The four-week moving average, which helps smooth out weekly volatility, rose to 22.72 million, an increase of 760,250 from the previous week. Since the pandemic was declared in mid-March, 40.8 million have filed claims as social distancing measures aimed at containing the coronavirus outbreak resulted in much of the $21.5 trillion U.S. economy being in lockdown for 2½ months.

A separate report Thursday showed that first-quarter GDP contracted by 5%, while the Atlanta Fed's GDPNow tracker is indicating a 41.9% plunge in Q2, which would be the worst in U.S. history. This would place the U.S. firmly in recession territory, though most economists are expecting a rebound in the second half of the year after restrictions are lifted.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Faces Scathing Criticism Over Inspector General Report

Article:

In a highly anticipated report, the Department of Justice Inspector General has accused former FBI Director James Comey of politically motivated actions, lying, and leaking confidential information. The report, released yesterday, states that Comey violated FBI rules, protocol, and laws in his attempt to undermine President Trump's administration through the launch of a Special Counsel investigation.

The report found that Comey failed to uphold his responsibility by not safeguarding sensitive information obtained during his tenure at the FBI and using it to create public pressure for official action. The Inspector General stated, "In a country built on the rule of law, it is of utmost importance that all FBI employees adhere to Department and FBI policies, particularly when confronted by what appear to be extraordinary circumstances or compelling personal convictions."

Despite these findings, Comey has demanded an apology from his critics. However, the report found no evidence that Comey or his attorneys released any of the classified information contained in any of the memos to members of the media.

The report's release has sparked harsh responses from legal experts on both sides of the aisle. Democrat and George Washington University Law Professor Jonathan Turley, writing for The Hill, stated, "Comey is the very antithesis of the ethical leader he described." Turley criticized Comey for violating both federal law and regulations for personal gain and making decisions that put personal interests over institutional ones.

Republican Gregg Jarrett, writing for Fox News, argued that it is Comey who owes the American public an apology. Jarrett accused Comey of abusing his position as FBI director, violating government rules, concealing information from his former agency, leaking sensitive documents without authorization, and improperly retaining records in an unsecured location.

The report's findings and the subsequent criticism have left Comey's future unclear. However, with former colleague and fellow leaker Andrew McCabe recently hired at CNN, some speculate that Comey may not be far behind.

Title: President Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Spending Bill, Criticizes Democrats for Excessive Spending and Vows to Reform Congressional Rules

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Donald Trump signed the $1.3 trillion omnibus spending bill on Friday, despite earlier threats of a potential government shutdown. The bill, which provides funding for various government agencies until October, includes significant investments in the military, but the president expressed displeasure over the bill's excessive spending and lack of funding for other priorities.

Speaking at the White House, President Trump criticized the legislative process that produced the bill, labeling it "ridiculous." He stated, "I've told Congress, I will never sign a bill like this again." The president's veto threat, which came hours before the bill's enactment, had initially startled Washington, as it followed assurances from White House officials that the president would sign the massive spending package.

The president signed the bill, he said, because of the gains made for the military. He lambasted the bill for unnecessary spending, failure to address the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, and inadequate funding for the border wall. In response, he called for changes to Congress's rules to facilitate progress on critical issues.

The president demanded a line-item veto for the president and the elimination of the filibuster rule, which requires 60 votes to advance most legislation in the Senate. Allowing a line-item veto would require a constitutional amendment, as the Supreme Court ruled the procedure unconstitutional in the 1998 decision Clinton v. City of New York.

President Trump highlighted the bill's historic boost to military spending, including the largest pay increase for troops in a decade. He claimed these investments fulfilled his promise to rebuild the U.S. military into the most formidable fighting force in the world. He criticized years of defense cuts, stating, "They hollowed our readiness as a military unit and put America at really grave risk." The omnibus bill, he argued, reverses this trend.

The president attributed the bill's high price tag to Democrats, who he accused of demanding extra spending in exchange for funding the military. He asserted, "If we take something for the military, they want something that in many cases are a wasted sum of money." He concluded, "It's not right, and it's very bad for our country."

Title: Sarah Palin Responds to Martin Bashir's Resignation, Calls for Higher Media Standards

Article:

In her first comments since Martin Bashir's resignation from MSNBC, Sarah Palin has expressed her views on the matter, stating that she is "used to" such attacks. In an interview on Fox News' "Fox & Friends," Palin discussed her thoughts on Bashir's controversial comments and his subsequent resignation.

Bashir, who resigned on Wednesday, made derogatory remarks about Palin during his Nov. 15 broadcast, referring to her as a "world class idiot" and suggesting she would be a suitable candidate for a historical act of cruelty involving slavery.

Palin acknowledged that it was refreshing to see many in the media speak out against such behavior, stating, "Those with that platform, with a microphone, a camera in their face, they have to have some more responsibility taken."

When asked whether Bashir's resignation was sufficient, Palin responded that she must move past it. She referred to Bashir's on-air apology during his Nov. 18 broadcast and expressed a need to accept his apology and move on.

Palin also mentioned that, five or six years ago, such attacks would have personally hurt her, but she now feels "kind of calloused." She echoed her previous response to Bashir's comments and apology, stating that the attacks are often directed at conservative women and that there is an "obvious" double standard.

Palin added that she has not heard from any feminist groups or organizations regarding the incident. This suggests that, despite the controversy, there may be a lack of support or solidarity from certain groups that typically advocate for women's rights.

Title: WikiLeaks Founder Julian Assange Disputes Claims of Russian Involvement in Democratic Hacks

Article:

In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has stated that the Obama administration's focus on Russia's alleged role in the Democratic hacks leading up to the 2016 U.S. Presidential election is an attempt to "delegitimize the Trump administration as it goes into the White House."

Assange, who has been residing at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London, claimed that the Obama administration is trying to portray President-elect Donald Trump as an illegitimate president by suggesting that Russia interfered in the election.

"Our publications had wide uptake by the American people. They’re all true," Assange said during the interview. "But that’s not the allegation that’s being presented by the Obama White House."

Assange reiterated WikiLeaks' denial that Russia was the source of the Democratic documents released over the summer. "Our source is not a state party, so the answer for our interactions is no," he said.

In December, Assange told Hannity that the documents received by WikiLeaks "looked very much like they’re from the Russians" but emphasized that the source was not them.

When asked if WikiLeaks influenced the 2016 election, Assange pointed to private comments from members of the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign in documents published by the group.

"Did [WikiLeaks] change the outcome of the election? Who knows, it’s impossible to tell," Assange said. "But if it did, the accusation is that the true statements of Hillary Clinton and her campaign manager, John Podesta, and the DNC head Debbie Wasserman Schultz, their true statements is what changed the election."

Title: Putin Suggests Consideration of Statehood for Eastern Ukraine, Blames West for Crisis

Article:

In a significant shift in Russia's stance on the conflict in eastern Ukraine, President Vladimir Putin has called for immediate talks on the political organization of society and statehood in the war-torn region. This marks the first time that the idea of statehood has been proposed for the region, which is predominantly Russian-speaking.

Speaking on a TV show broadcast in the far east of the country, Putin said, "We need to immediately begin substantive talks... on questions of the political organization of society and statehood in southeastern Ukraine with the goal of protecting the lawful interests of the people who live there."

Russia has previously advocated for greater rights under a decentralized federal system for the eastern regions of Ukraine. However, in the program taped on Friday, Putin did not directly address additional Western sanctions on Russia.

Putin, in the TV show, blamed the crisis in Ukraine on the West, accusing it of supporting a "coup" against pro-Kremlin president Viktor Yanukovych in February. He said, "They should have known that Russia can not stand aside when people are being shot almost at point-blank range."

Putin has denied that Moscow has sent regular troops to fight in Ukraine, but pro-Russian rebels have claimed that many Russian soldiers have volunteered while "on vacation." The West accused Moscow this week of having its troops spearhead a counter-offensive that has put Ukrainian government forces on the back foot in the nearly five-month conflict.

NATO said on Thursday that Moscow had well over 1,000 troops on the ground in Ukraine and 20,000 massed by the border.
