Analysts, including Russian experts, see Putin as aiming to create a statelet in eastern Ukraine, much as Moscow has helped carve out de facto separatist states in Moldova and Georgia.

Putin, on Friday, called the fighters in eastern Ukraine defenders of "Novorossiya," or New Russia, a loaded Tsarist-era name for what is now southern and eastern Ukraine. He first used the term in April, after annexing Crimea from Ukraine, sparking outrage in Kiev and the West.

Despite saying that Russia supports a negotiated political solution to the crisis, Putin has used fiery, uncompromising rhetoric in recent days. In a talk with youth activists on Friday, he compared the shelling of the rebel-held cities of Lugansk and Donetsk to the Nazi siege of Leningrad.

Aid groups have condemned indiscriminate shelling by both sides in the conflict which has claimed almost 2,600 lives. Putin put the blame for fighting in eastern Ukraine squarely on Kiev, stating, "What is now happening, it seems to me, to be an absolutely natural reaction by people who live there and who are defending themselves -- they were not the first to take up arms."

While people in eastern Ukraine had been concerned about attempts to downgrade the status of the Russian language, there had been no serious incidents of violence in the region until pro-Russian rebels took control of several cities in April.

Title: AP Reveals Hillary Clinton's Image Control Strategy and Email Scandal Concerns

Article:

In a recent report by The Associated Press, emails obtained by the news agency offer insights into the meticulous image-control apparatus of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton. The emails reveal a behind-the-scenes effort to review introductory remarks for speakers presenting Clinton as a speaker, as well as suggesting questions that align with her campaign platform.

The campaign's focus on controlling the minutest details of Clinton's appearances, from her green room's glassware to the questions posed by local officials, has raised concerns about the potential deployment of a similar image-control apparatus in a Clinton White House. The exchanges also contradict Clinton's campaign's efforts to portray her as less wooden and scripted than in her previous run for the presidency.

The emails reveal that Clinton's campaign suggested questions for college presidents and students, such as inquiries about college affordability, an issue that Clinton has made a campaign priority. This careful planning has sometimes caused discomfort for local officials, as seen in an email from Becky Mann, the head of public relations for South Carolina's Greenville Technical College, who declined an offer from Clinton's campaign to write her introduction.

Meanwhile, the FBI's investigation into Clinton's email scandal has taken a new turn, with government sources telling Fox News that the recently released State Department inspector general report increases the likelihood and pressure for the Justice Department to pursue criminal charges against Clinton. The source stated that the report "clears up confusion [about] Department of State rules and makes the IG a witness, and the people they interviewed, to her computer antics being done without permission."

As the presidential race heats up, concerns have also been raised about the potential national security risks posed by Donald Trump's unpredictable campaign style. Eight senior security officials told Reuters they had concerns over briefing Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, once he is formally anointed. Despite their worries, the officials said the "Top Secret" briefing to each candidate would not deviate from the usual format to avoid any appearance of bias.

In the midst of these developments, the Clinton campaign's handling of sensitive information and her email scandal continues to be a point of contention. RNC spokesman Michael Short stated, "The only candidate who has proven incapable of handling sensitive information is Hillary Clinton. If there is anyone they should be worried about it is Hillary Clinton."

As the race for the White House continues, the email scandal and national security concerns will likely remain a significant factor in the campaign.

Title: Romney Delivers Aggressive Speech, Accuses Obama of Divisive Campaign Tactics

Article:

In a fiery speech on Tuesday night, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, delivered a scathing critique of President Obama's campaign, accusing it of running a "campaign of division and anger and hate." The speech, which was personally written by Romney over two days, was the most aggressive of his bid for the presidency and set the tone for the rest of the week.

During a rally in Chillicothe, Ohio, Romney took aim at his White House rival, citing Vice President Biden's recent remarks in Virginia that Romney and the Republicans intend to roll back Wall Street regulations and "put y'all back in chains." Romney's campaign labeled the statement a "new low," while Romney himself accused the president of being "intellectually exhausted" and out of ideas.

"His campaign and his surrogates have made wild and reckless accusations that disgrace the office of the presidency," Romney told a crowd of thousands at the final stop on his five-state bus tour. "Another outrageous charge came a few hours ago in Virginia. And the White House sinks a little bit lower. This is what an angry and desperate presidency looks like."

Romney also mocked Obama's statements during the 2008 campaign that without fresh ideas "you use stale tactics to scare voters." Romney accused Obama of now making that strategy "the heart of his campaign."

In response, Obama campaign spokesman Ben LaBolt described Romney as "unhinged" during the campaign speech. "Particularly strange coming at a time when he's pouring tens of millions of dollars into negative ads that are demonstrably false," he said.

Earlier, the Obama campaign defended Biden's comments, likening them to language used repeatedly by Republican officials. Stephanie Cutter, deputy campaign manager, said in a written statement, "For months, Speaker Boehner, Congressman Ryan, and other Republicans have called for the 'unshackling' of the private sector from regulations that protect Americans from risky financial deals and other reckless behavior that crashed our economy."

Biden made the remarks during a stop in Danville, Va. He took a swipe at Romney's plan to ease financial regulations, by recycling a Romney bank analogy and creating an analogy of his own. "He said in the first 100 days, he's going to let the big banks once again write their own rules," Biden said. "Unchain Wall Street! They're gon na put y'all back in chains."

The remark's context is unclear. Some conservative blogs claimed Biden had just made a reference to slavery. Danville, aside from being the last capital of the Confederacy, is racially split -- the city is nearly half black and half white. The crowd at Tuesday's event reflected that makeup. The Romney campaign fired back without accusing Biden of any racial reference.

In his speech Tuesday evening, however, Romney accused Obama of seeking to divide America -- whether by race, occupation, or party affiliation -- as a campaign strategy. "But he won't win that way," Romney said. "America is one nation under God. American history has been a story of the many becoming one -- uniting to preserve liberty, uniting to build the greatest economy in the world, uniting to save the world from unspeakable darkness."

Romney championed himself as the savior of the middle class, ticking off areas where Obama and his policies have failed the American people. "After four years, it's clear that President Obama's policies are not fixing these problems, they're making them worse," Romney said.

Title: France to Grant All-Expenses-Paid Scholarships for U.S. Scientists in Response to U.S. Withdrawal from Paris Climate Agreement

Article:

In a move aimed at countering the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris Climate Agreement, French President Emmanuel Macron is set to award all-expenses-paid grants for U.S. scientists to relocate to France. This initiative, known as the "Make Our Planet Great Again" competition, was conceived by Macron in June following U.S. President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw the U.S. from the agreement.

On Monday evening, Macron will announce the winners of the competition, which was announced in response to Trump's decision. In a speech from the Elysée Palace, Macron had urged scientists displeased with the move to "come to France and work with us together" on climate policy-related research.

Out of a shortlist of 90 projects, around 50 will be chosen for the grants, which will be funded by the state. However, some French researchers have expressed dissatisfaction with the president's decision to fund foreign scientists at a time when funding for domestic projects is reportedly lacking.

While the majority of candidates who entered are from the U.S., the competition for research grants was expanded to include climate scientists from other countries outside of France.

Macron's attacks on Trump over the Paris agreement were widely praised by the French and international media, but the French leader's "tough stance" may have "backfired," according to a report by The Guardian. The report suggested that the U.S. leader may have been prompted to remind people he "was elected to serve the citizens of Pittsburgh — not Paris."

Speaking in the Rose Garden after his announcement that the U.S. would be leaving the Paris Climate Agreement, President Trump said that the accord signed by the Obama administration in 2015 without the consent of Congress "disadvantages the United States to the exclusive benefit of other countries."

"In order to fulfill my solemn duty to protect America and its citizens, the United States will withdraw from the Paris Climate Accord," Trump said at the time, explaining that the agreement would have left American taxpayers having to "absorb the cost in terms of lost jobs, lower wages, shuttered factories, and vastly diminished economic production."

Title: A Political Pioneer: The Journey of Senator Bernie Sanders in the 2020 Presidential Race

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic race for the presidency, Senator Bernie Sanders, a 78-year-old independent from Vermont, is making waves as a front-runner. His political career, marked by defying odds and challenging the establishment, has been a rollercoaster ride, as evidenced by his victories in the first states to vote.

Born in Brooklyn, New York, to Jewish parents, Sanders' humble upbringing in a small apartment instilled a class-consciousness in him at an early age. He attended the University of Chicago and participated in anti-war and civil rights activism, including the 1963 March on Washington.

Sanders' political journey began in 1971, when he ran for a U.S. Senate seat in Vermont as a Liberty Union candidate, a party with anti-war and socialist roots. He lost that race, as well as a few campaigns to become governor. However, his first major political success came in 1980 when he was elected mayor of Burlington, Vermont, beating a six-term incumbent.

During his time as mayor, Sanders met and married his current wife, Jane O'Meara, the former president of Burlington College. Together, they have four children from previous relationships.

Sanders was first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1990, making him the first independent to do so in 40 years. He served there until he ran for and won a seat in the Senate in 2007. During his time in Washington, Sanders has been a vocal critic of both Republican and Democratic politicians, often being dismissed as a gadfly.

In 2010, Sanders famously spoke for eight-and-a-half hours to attempt to block the extension of Bush-era tax policies, which he believed benefited the rich and worsened the nation's income gap. He became the chairman of the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs in 2013 and helped negotiate bipartisan solutions for former soldiers facing delayed and inadequate care.

Sanders is known for his advocacy for social policies akin to those of Nordic countries, such as universal healthcare and paid leave for new parents. He also wants to make college free and erase all student debt.

Criticism has been leveled at Sanders for his voting record on gun control, including his opposition to various forms of the Brady Bill, which required background checks and waiting periods for gun purchasers. Sanders argues that his record reflects the priorities of his Vermont constituents.

In 2016, Sanders entered the Democratic race as a long-shot candidate, squaring off against establishment favorite Hillary Clinton. Despite the odds, Sanders set fundraising records and, for a time, cast doubt on the once-seemingly inevitable nomination of Mrs. Clinton.

Now, with an anti-establishment tone intact, Sanders is running on a characteristically progressive platform, featuring Medicare for all, a $15 minimum wage, and tuition-free public college. He is quick to note that many items on his agenda - once deemed radical - are now embraced by Democrats.

However, some Democratic leaders remain skeptical that Sanders could win their party's nomination. This doubt seems to galvanize Sanders, who, in October, appeared to be in peril after suffering a minor heart attack and suspending his campaign. The episode reignited criticism that Sanders is too old to compete for the presidency.

Within weeks, Sanders was back, bolstered by an endorsement from Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the party's liberal darling and youngest ever U.S. congresswoman. Sanders is an unapologetic curmudgeon, who, in response to a recent claim by Clinton that nobody likes him, quipped, "On a good day, my wife likes me."

Sanders now draws crowds in the tens of thousands, making the case that the 2020 election will be won because of his principles and policy, not in spite of it. If the outsider candidate is able to clinch victory in Iowa, he may be poised to beat the odds once again.

Title: Texas Abortion Law's 20-Week Limit May Face Constitutional Challenges Due to Calculation Method

Article:

The recent Texas law banning most abortions after 20 weeks, making it the 12th state to enact such a restriction, may face challenges due to the method used to calculate the 20-week limit. The law, like many other state abortion bans, defines the starting point for the 20 weeks based on fertilization, not the more commonly used method of measuring pregnancy from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP).

According to Dr. Daniel Grossman, an assistant professor of obstetrics, gynecology, and reproductive sciences at the University of California, San Francisco, and a vice president of IBIS Reproductive Health, the age of the embryo or fetus is essentially two weeks less than the number of weeks measured from the LMP. This discrepancy could cause confusion for women and their doctors and potentially affect the constitutionality of these laws.

"When we refer to the weeks of pregnancy, weeks of gestation, we measure pregnancy from the date of the last normal menstrual period," Grossman explains. "For a woman who has a normal menstrual period, ovulation or fertilization would generally occur two weeks later, after the start of that normal menstrual period."

The use of LMP as a measurement standard developed in the days before ultrasound was widely available, Grossman notes. "The last menstrual period was something that was knowable and was measurable, whereas it wasn't always known when fertilization took place."

However, most state laws, including the Texas law, peg the beginning of pregnancy to fertilization, according to Elizabeth Nash, who tracks state issues for the Guttmacher Institute, an abortion rights think tank. "When we talk about a law that bans abortion at 20 weeks post-fertilization, we're really talking about a law that bans abortion at 22 weeks of pregnancy," she says.

The discrepancy in terminology has led to confusion, with laws being referred to as 20-week laws when they actually ban abortion at 22 weeks. Nash attributes this to the term used in the bill becoming the headline.

Despite the semantic differences, the impact of these laws is clear. The ban they would impose is earlier than what's currently considered viability, or when a fetus can survive outside the womb. "I think there's definitely consensus that viability doesn't happen before 24 menstrual weeks," Grossman says. "So when we're talking about banning abortion at 20 or 22 weeks even, that's clearly at least two weeks before the earliest point in pregnancy where viability would be a concern."

The constitutionality of these laws is a concern, as current Supreme Court precedent states that states cannot ban abortion before viability. However, those pushing these laws hope that by the time one of these laws makes its way to the Supreme Court, they might change their minds.

Similar doubts were raised about the constitutionality of an earlier ban, according to Douglas Johnson of the National Right to Life Committee. "The Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act was struck down by every lower federal court that considered it," Johnson said last week at a press conference on the federal version of the 20-week ban. "Three U.S. District Courts; three U.S. Courts of Appeals all ruled it was in clear violation of U.S. Supreme Court precedent. But when it reached the U.S. Supreme Court, they said otherwise."

The ultimate number that will matter most is five—the number of Supreme Court justices needed for a majority.

Title: Obama Surprises National Security Team, Seeks Congressional Approval for Syria Strike

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Barack Obama has decided to seek congressional approval for a military strike against Syria, a move that reportedly took his national security team by surprise.

According to three senior administration officials, Obama informed his advisers during a National Security Council meeting last weekend that he was considering action against Syria, but had not made a final decision. However, when Obama announced his decision to launch a limited strike against the Bashar Assad regime on Friday night, he also revealed his intention to seek congressional authorization.

Obama's decision to seek congressional approval was a departure from the advice given by his aides, who had advised against it. The president's reasoning for this decision was shared with his advisers on Friday night and Saturday morning in the Situation Room.

The president's decision to seek congressional approval comes after the British Parliament rejected Prime Minister David Cameron's call for military action last week, making it clear that a groundswell of international support was not forthcoming. With Russia, Syria's most powerful patron, blocking any United Nations Security Council resolution against Syria, Obama's desire for broad support for any potential action against Syria has not been realized.

Notably, Obama spoke with President Francois Hollande of France, the one major U.S. ally that has endorsed a military strike, before publicly announcing his decision to seek backing from Congress.

Obama's decision to seek congressional approval is in line with his long-held view that the credibility of military action comes with numbers. The president is expected to address Congress and the nation on the matter in the coming weeks.

Congress is set to return from its summer recess on September 9 and is expected to debate and vote on an authorization that week. Obama has not ruled out taking action immediately if Assad deploys chemical weapons before Congress is set to vote.

The officials also stressed that the president's decision to seek congressional approval was his own, and no congressional leaders directly asked him to do so. They declined to speculate on what Obama would do if Congress does not approve use of force, while maintaining that Obama retains the authority to go it alone.

Obama made clear in his remarks on Saturday that a "no" vote would send the wrong message to Assad and America's enemies. "Here's my question for every member of Congress and every member of the global community: What message will we send if a dictator can gas hundreds of children to death in plain sight and pay no price?" Obama said. "What's the purpose of the international system that we've built if a prohibition on the use of chemical weapons that has been agreed to by the governments of 98% of the world's people and approved overwhelmingly by the Congress of the United States is not enforced?"

Title: Partisan Divide on Vote-by-Mail Expansion Ahead of November Elections

Article:

WASHINGTON ( ███ ) - The push to expand vote-by-mail options during the coronavirus pandemic has become a contentious issue in the lead-up to the November elections. President Donald Trump and his Republican allies have expressed concerns about the potential for fraud in mail balloting, while Democrats and voting rights groups argue that it is a necessary measure to protect voters from the virus and ensure accessibility for all.

Last week's turbulent Wisconsin elections, which took place despite Republican efforts to block Democratic attempts to delay in-person voting and expand absentee balloting, highlighted the partisan divide and the urgency to find a solution before the Nov. 3 U.S. election.

Republicans argue that voting by mail is more susceptible to fraud since voters do not have to appear in person at a polling place. President Trump recently stated, without evidence, that mail ballots are "cheaters" and "fraudulent in many cases." However, Trump himself cast an absentee ballot by mail in Florida's Republican primary last month.

Trump's opposition to vote-by-mail has been interpreted by Democrats as a strategy to suppress voter turnout, as they believe easier voting would lead to higher turnout and potentially disadvantage Republican candidates. Trump has stated that a shift to making voting easier would mean "you'd never have a Republican elected in this country again."

Trevor Potter, a Republican former chairman of the Federal Election Commission who founded the Washington-based Campaign Legal Center, found Trump's reaction puzzling, as Republicans often perform well in mail-in balloting. Potter noted that older Americans, who are thought to be most vulnerable to the virus and are more likely to support President Trump, are more likely to vote by mail. Conservative states such as Utah, which votes entirely by mail, have little evidence of fraud.

A series of academic, government, and news investigations over the years have found little evidence of election fraud of any kind. Utah and four other states that vote entirely by mail have reported little fraud. While there have been scattered incidents of "ballot harvesting," where people collect and manipulate absentee ballots, these instances are rare.

More than a dozen states have already postponed primaries or expanded vote-by-mail to avoid crowded polling places. Vote-by-mail was used by about one-quarter of all voters in the 2018 midterm elections, according to a report by the U.S. Election Assistance Commission. Along with the five states that vote entirely by mail, 28 states will allow voters to request a mail ballot without any excuse in November, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

Senator Ron Wyden, co-sponsor of a bill to expand vote-by-mail and early voting to all states, stated that the expansion is not a novelty, but rather an upscaling of what is already taking place. There are still 17 states, such as Texas, New York, and Louisiana, that would need to change their policies to guarantee that everyone who wants to vote by mail in November can, the Brennan Center said.

The cost of ensuring that vote-by-mail is available for all voters could be up to $1.4 billion, with postage alone costing up to $600 million. Even advocates of vote-by-mail acknowledge that states should keep the option of in-person voting for voters with disabilities, those who need language access assistance, or those who do not have regular mail access.

Democratic and Republican-aligned groups across the country are already engaged in legal battles over whether and how to expand access to mail-in voting. In New Mexico, county clerks have petitioned the state Supreme Court to conduct their June 2 primary almost entirely by mail and allow all voters to be mailed an absentee ballot. State Republicans have sued to oppose both changes. In Texas, the Democratic Party sued the state's Republican leadership in federal court to allow no-excuse absentee voting. In Georgia, the American Civil Liberties Union sued the Republican secretary of state for requiring voters to pay their own postage when submitting mail-in absentee ballots and applications, arguing that this is akin to a poll tax.

Title: Majority of Americans Disapprove of COVID-19 Protests, Poll Finds

A new poll by The University of Chicago Divinity School and The ███-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research reveals that a majority of Americans disapprove of protests against restrictions aimed at preventing the spread of the coronavirus. The poll also indicates a decrease in support for such measures in recent weeks.

The survey, conducted April 30-May 4, found that 55% of Americans disapprove of the protests that have taken place across the country, while 31% approve. The poll also found that 8% of Americans believe public protests, marches, and rallies should be unrestricted during the outbreak, while 41% think they should be allowed only with restrictions and 50% think they should not be allowed at all.

The poll comes as some states have begun to ease restrictions on businesses and individuals. The survey found that 71% of Americans favor requiring people to stay in their homes except for essential errands, down slightly from 80% two weeks earlier. Similarly, 67% of Americans now say they favor requiring bars and restaurants to close, down from 76% in the earlier poll.

The poll also suggested a dip in support for requiring Americans to limit gatherings to 10 people or fewer (from 82% to 75%) and requiring postponement of nonessential medical care (from 68% to 57%).

The poll found that Democrats are more likely than Republicans to disapprove of such protests, with 67% of Democrats disapproving compared to 51% of Republicans. Thirty-two percent of Republicans and 25% of Democrats say they approve.

Shelley Luther, a Texas hair salon owner who was sentenced to seven days in jail last week after refusing to apologize to a judge for opening her salon in defiance of Republican Gov. Greg Abbott's emergency orders, was released less than 48 hours later after Abbott removed jail as a punishment for defying virus safeguards.

In Michigan, thousands of people rallied outside the state capitol last month to protest Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's restrictions. Hundreds returned two weeks later, some of them armed, to demonstrate inside the statehouse.

Adam Blann, a Republican-leaning voter who works in the natural gas industry, said he doesn't personally favor the protests but does not believe they should be restricted.

"Its a tough situation," said Blann. "But I also think that one of the reasons we live in a great country is that we have freedom of expression, freedom of speech, freedom to protest."

The poll also found that most Americans in favor of some kind of restriction on in-person worship, with 42% saying that should be allowed with restrictions and 48% that it should not be allowed at all.

Marilou Grainger, a retired nurse anesthetist and registered Republican in Washington, Missouri, said she's torn between the need to take precautions against the virus while also allowing people to make their own decisions.

"I think we should still be under a bit of quarantine, especially people who are 60 or older," said Grainger. "Did we make a mistake? Did we totally annihilate our economy, or did we actually save some people issuing this quarantine?"

The AP-NORC poll of 1,002 adults was conducted using a sample drawn from NORC's probability-based AmeriSpeak Panel, which is designed to be representative of the U.S. population. The margin of sampling error for all respondents is plus or minus 4.2 percentage points.

Title: Hillary Clinton Faces Challenges in Appealing to Young Female Voters Amidst Controversial Remarks and FBI Investigation

Article:

In a recent development, former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's comment, "There's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other," has stirred controversy and raised questions about Hillary Clinton's ability to appeal to women voters. The statement, intended to support Clinton, has instead exposed a potential problem for the Democratic candidate.

An email from Clinton's campaign team, asking "Are you by my side?" is a question she should be posing to young women, as they seem to be the demographic she is struggling to win over. Despite Clinton's efforts to break the glass ceiling in the 2008 presidential race, it remains intact, and her chances of shattering it in 2016 appear uncertain.

The comment has sparked debate, with some outside the US labeling the situation as misogyny. However, the issue seems to run deeper than gender bias in certain circles. In a vox pop conducted at a casino in Las Vegas, during the first Democratic debate, people expressed a unified dislike and distrust of Clinton.

Furthermore, the numbers from the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary reveal a significant disparity in support from young women. In Iowa, 84% of women under 30 voted for Bernie Sanders, while only 14% supported Clinton. The projection for New Hampshire shows an even more striking disparity, with 92% of young women under 30 planning to back Sanders, and only 11% supporting Clinton among women aged 30-39.

The Clinton campaign faces challenges in understanding why they are failing to win over this demographic group, who early in the campaign would have been considered low-hanging fruit for the candidate. Some speculate that this generation may feel that the gender of their next leader is irrelevant, or that they are yearning for change, with Sanders offering a socialist prescription for America.

The Clinton campaign is also grappling with the ongoing FBI investigation into Clinton's email arrangements while serving as Secretary of State. This has further fueled concerns about Clinton exceptionalism, with some perceiving the Clintons as having a unique modus operandi that is not shared by other US citizens.

As the primary race progresses, Clinton's campaign strategy will be crucial in addressing these challenges and winning over young female voters. However, recent comments from Albright, such as her statement about women not helping each other, may not help Clinton's cause, as they risk alienating potential supporters and reinforcing the perception of Clinton as an elitist candidate.

Title: Federal Budget Deficit Drops Below $500 Billion for First Time Since 2008, CBO Reports

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) released new estimates on Wednesday, revealing a significant decrease in the federal budget deficit for the fiscal year 2014, which ended on September 30. The deficit for the year totaled $486 billion, marking a return to the $459 billion deficit recorded in 2008, the last full year of the Bush administration.

According to the CBO, the deficit for 2014, as a percentage of the gross domestic product (GDP), was 2.8 percent, slightly below the average experienced over the past 40 years. This indicates that President Obama has surpassed his self-imposed goal of cutting the deficit in half from its peak of $1.4 trillion, or 9.8 percent of GDP, in 2009.

The decrease in the deficit is attributed to a combination of reduced spending and increased tax revenue. Government revenue surpassed the $3 trillion mark for the first time in history in 2014, while spending, which reached $3.6 trillion in 2011, has decreased since then, rising only 1 percent, or $44 billion, in 2014.

New spending on Medicaid and Obamacare's subsidies for health insurance purchased on the exchanges increased by $49 billion, accounting for more than the overall increase. Social Security spending rose 5 percent, or $37 billion, while the government's student loan subsidies boosted education spending.

On the spending side, the Defense Department experienced a 5 percent cut, totaling $30 billion, and unemployment benefit spending decreased as the jobless rate declined.

Spending began to decrease after Republicans took control of the House in 2011 and began to challenge President Obama's budget plans. A series of spending cuts, including the budget sequesters, helped keep spending in check.

On the revenue side, President Obama implemented a tax hike for the wealthiest at the beginning of 2013, and the recovering economy has contributed to a 17.5 percent increase in corporate income taxes over the past year.

The White House budget office did not respond to a request for comment, but outside budget analysts cautioned that the decrease in the deficit should be viewed with caution. "While the deficit has indeed dropped significantly, this drop followed a massive increase, was largely expected, and does not suggest the country is on a sustainable fiscal path," the Committee for a Responsible Federal Deficit said in its analysis.

The CBO's projections from the summer suggest that $1 trillion deficits will return within a decade, and debt will also continue to grow. The long-term debt is primarily driven by entitlement spending, particularly major programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. Net interest on the debt will also rise rapidly in future years as interest rates increase. However, for now, low interest rates continue to help keep the deficit down. The government paid $271 billion in interest costs in 2014, according to the CBO. Final 2014 numbers will be released by the Treasury Department later this month.

Title: Hannity and Moore Face Allegations, Media Criticism in Alabama Senate Race

Article:

In the midst of the Alabama Senate race, Republican candidate Judge Roy Moore has found himself embroiled in a controversy following allegations of sexual misconduct with underage girls decades ago. Vice-President Mike Pence and several Republican senators have called for Moore to step down if the allegations are true, but have not specified how the women involved could prove the events.

Moore, in a series of tweets, has vehemently denied the claims, stating that he is the victim of a campaign to "silence and shut up Christian conservatives like you and me." He has also accused the media of launching a "vicious and nasty round of attacks" against him.

On his Fox News show, Sean Hannity, a vocal supporter of Moore, discussed the allegations extensively. Hannity, in a segment that generated controversy, appeared to call the candidate's alleged behavior with a 14-year-old "consensual." Hannity later clarified that he was referring to Moore's romantic overtures to the older teenage girls, not the 14-year-old.

Other conservative media outlets, such as Breitbart and National Review, have taken different approaches. Breitbart has been critical of the Washington Post report, while National Review has urged fellow conservatives not to defend Moore. Jonah Goldberg wrote, "If you can prove it, Roy Moore will end up owning the Post after his lawsuit."

Fox News legal analyst Mercedes Colwin, during a segment on Hannity's show, claimed that women frequently make false sexual-harassment allegations in an attempt to make money. This statement drew criticism, as it did not mention the many women who had accused former Fox News executives Roger Ailes and Bill O'Reilly of sexual harassment.

The controversy has sparked a debate within the Republican Party and the conservative media, with some defending Moore and others calling for him to step down. The race is scheduled for December 12, 2017.

Title: White House Denies 'Amnesty' Claims on Trump's Immigration Plan, Proposes Temporary Legal Status for Certain Immigrants

Article:

In a significant development, the White House has proposed a new immigration plan that aims to address the ongoing government shutdown and the contentious issue of border security. The plan, presented by President Trump in an address from the Oval Office on Saturday, has been met with mixed reactions, with some conservatives labeling it an "amnesty" for illegal immigrants, while the White House maintains that it offers only a temporary solution and does not provide a pathway to citizenship.

Vice President Mike Pence, acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, and Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser and the president's son-in-law, described the plan as a compromise between hard-right and hard-left factions, each of which has strong opposing views on the issue. The plan is intended to end the government shutdown, which is approaching its fourth week, and prevent federal employees from missing a second paycheck.

The proposal includes $5.7 billion for the construction of a border wall, as well as changes to expedite the deportation of illegal immigrant families and address abuses in the asylum system. In return, it offers humanitarian aid, reinstates a program that allows Central American children to apply for U.S. asylum from their home countries, and provides a three-year legal status for approximately 1 million people, including those currently under the Obama-era DACA program and those under humanitarian protections.

The plan also includes measures that both sides generally agree on, such as increased technology for drug detection at legal border crossings and an increase in the number of immigration judges to reduce the backlog of cases. The Senate is expected to vote on the plan next week, and the fate of the shutdown and workers' paychecks hinges on the outcome of this vote.

While Democrats have criticized the bill from the left, some of President Trump's supporters on the right have expressed disapproval of the proposal's provision of temporary legal status for some illegal immigrants. The plan has been met with criticism from some conservative figures, with Ann Coulter, a prominent conservative activist, tweeting, "Trump proposes amnesty. We voted for Trump and got Jeb!"

Vice President Pence and Jared Kushner, however, have suggested that if agreement can be reached with Democrats on this issue, it could pave the way for broader negotiations on comprehensive immigration reform. Pence emphasized that the three-year legal status offered in the plan is not a pathway to citizenship, and that the plan is intended as a temporary solution to address the current impasse.

The White House's proposal represents a significant shift in the immigration debate, as it offers a compromise that addresses both border security and the status of certain illegal immigrants. The plan's fate remains uncertain, as it faces opposition from both the left and the right, and the government shutdown continues to impact federal employees and services.

Title: North Charleston Police Chief Speaks Out on Walter Scott Shooting: "I Have Not Watched the Video Since"

Article:

In the aftermath of the Walter Scott shooting incident, North Charleston Police Chief Ed Driggers has spoken out, expressing his dismay and condemnation of the actions of former officer Michael Thomas Slager. Unlike in similar cases across the nation, Driggers did not defend Slager, who shot an unarmed African-American man, Walter Scott, during a traffic stop.

Driggers stated, "I have watched the video and I was sickened by what I saw. I have not watched it since." This public appearance by Driggers, while reminiscent of recent events in Ferguson, Missouri; Cleveland, Ohio; Staten Island, New York; and Los Angeles, California, differed in substance. Driggers did not defend Slager, who claimed that he shot Scott after a physical altercation in which he feared for his life.

The only version of the story the world would have known, had it not been for Feidin Santana's brave act of recording the incident on his smartphone, would have been Slager's account, which, in essence, was a monstrous lie. There is no evidence that Scott tried to use Slager's taser against him, as the officer claimed; the taser was found near Scott's body because that's where Slager put it. Contrary to Slager's claims, he never feared for his personal safety during the incident.

Neither Driggers nor Mayor Keith Summey of North Charleston sought to condemn Slager; instead, they distanced his behavior from the overall North Charleston Police Department (NCPD). Driggers stated, "The one does not totally throw a blanket across the many." He and the mayor noted that the NCPD is composed of more than 340 officers, and the video, while horrific, told us nothing of the overall law enforcement system; it was merely a single man making a terrible mistake.

However, the incident was not isolated, as Slager was not the only officer present during the shooting. After Scott fell to the ground, prostrate and bleeding, officer Clarence Habersham, who is African-American, arrived at the scene. His body language indicated this was not the first time he had come upon such a scene. He seemed unperturbed as he knelt down to check Scott's pulse, making no real attempt to save the back-shot man's life.

The details of the interactions between Slager, Habersham, and the third officer, who is Caucasian, are still unclear. What is clear, though, is that the NCPD was content to treat Slager's story as fact, and this was not the first time a member of the force had engaged in acts that could be described as thuggery. In the past five years, police officers in South Carolina have used their guns against 209 human beings, and they were exonerated of wrongdoing every single time.

Walter Scott, a father, brother, cousin, and veteran, died after being shot multiple times with his back turned. If he lived long enough to be conscious as Slager tightened the cuffs around each of his wrists, his final moments on Earth were spent alone and enchained.

Title: Kentucky Gubernatorial Race Heats Up as Health Co-op Collapse Takes Center Stage

Article:

The collapse of the Kentucky Health Cooperative, a nonprofit health plan established with federal loan dollars under the Affordable Care Act, has become a contentious issue in the tight gubernatorial race in Kentucky. The co-op's failure, which occurred earlier this month, has sparked a political debate over the health law's effectiveness and its impact on the state's residents.

More than a third of the 23 nonprofit health plans created under Obamacare with $2.4 billion in federal loan dollars have collapsed, and experts predict more failures are on the horizon. The co-op dominated exchange enrollment during the first two years of operations, capturing approximately 60% of customers in a traditionally Republican state. As a result, Kentucky residents who relied on the co-op for health coverage will now need to find new plans during the upcoming open-enrollment period, which begins on November 1.

Republican candidate Matt Bevin has seized on the co-op's collapse as evidence of the health care law's shortcomings and has criticized his Democratic opponent, Attorney General Jack Conway, for his support of the law. Conway, on the other hand, attributes the co-op's failure to "market forces" and argues that consumers still have more choices under the health law, with seven insurers to choose from during the upcoming open-enrollment period, compared to just three plans two years ago.

The nonprofit co-op program was designed as a compromise to appease liberals who were dissatisfied with the health care law's lack of a government-run insurance option. However, the program was reportedly undermined by funding cuts and restrictive rules that prohibited the use of federal funds for marketing and limited the types of customers the co-ops could target.

The co-op's collapse is not the only health care issue with political significance in the Kentucky gubernatorial race. The vast majority of Kentuckians who have gained coverage under Obamacare are enrolled in public programs, with over 500,000 individuals added to the Medicaid and CHIP rolls since 2013. During the Republican primary, Bevin expressed a desire to roll back Obamacare's Medicaid expansion, a stance that has led to criticism from Democrats for potentially abandoning half a million low- and middle-income residents.

The health care issue has the potential to sway voters in the tight gubernatorial race, with some political observers suggesting that the co-op's collapse could become a significant factor in the election. However, others are skeptical that health care issues will ultimately prove decisive, as voters are notoriously uninformed about the details of policy arguments.

The race between Bevin and Conway is expected to be close, with Conway currently holding a minuscule lead in the polls. The Republican Governor's Association has announced plans to spend $1.6 million on ad buys supporting Bevin in the final two weeks of the campaign. The outcome of the election could hinge on minor changes in the political landscape, particularly in an off-year election where voter turnout is expected to be low.

Title: Democrat Representative Adam Schiff Implies Failed Impeachment of President Trump Contributed to COVID-19 Casualties

In an interview on MSNBC Monday night, Democratic Representative Adam Schiff suggested that the victims of the COVID-19 pandemic can be considered victims of the failed impeachment of President Trump. Schiff argued that the impeachment trial, in some instances, was "equivalent to the number of people we lost on 9/11."

During the interview, anchor Lawrence O' Donnell questioned Schiff about the timing of the impeachment trial and the onset of the pandemic. In response, Schiff stated, "We certainly told the senators that he was not going to change, and there was no way to constrain him. That he is who he is, and he would continue to operate the way he had, and indeed, that's exactly what we've seen since."

Schiff continued, "We said a lot, but little did we know just how great the casualties would be. Some days we lose the equivalent of the number of people we lost on 9/11. You know, I think that there is no way we could have foreseen just how tragic his malfeasance would be in his remaining months in the administration."

Fox News' Sean Hannity previously reminded viewers in March that perhaps if Democrats had been less focused on the impeachment trial and more attentive to actual threats, more could have been done to protect and warn Americans about the coronavirus. Hannity argued that the impeachment trial diverted attention from the early stages of the pandemic, during which China lied about the virus and suppressed physician whistleblowers.

According to Hannity, the first person with coronavirus arrived in the U.S. from China on January 21, while Democrats were in the midst of the impeachment trial. Hannity also pointed out that on January 31, the president declared a national health emergency, ordered mandatory two-week quarantines, and issued a travel ban on all travel to and from China. At the same time, Hannity argued, Democrats were still focused on impeaching the president.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard Calls on Biden and Sanders to Urge DNC for Debate Participation

Article:

Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) has appealed to former Vice President Joe Biden and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) to intervene in the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) debate qualification criteria, which has barred her from participating in the upcoming primary debates.

In a tweet late Friday, Gabbard called on Biden and Sanders, the two remaining heavyweights in the 2020 primary race, to stand with her against the DNC's "transparent effort to exclude" her from the debates.

"@JoeBiden @BernieSanders I ’ m sure you would agree that our Democratic nominee should be a person who will stand up for what is right. So I ask that you have the courage to do that now in the face of the DNC's effort to keep me from participating in the debates. #LetTulsiDebate," Gabbard tweeted.

The DNC announced that candidates must have garnered at least 20 percent of the delegates awarded thus far to make the debate stage in Phoenix on March 15. Gabbard, who has refused to drop her long-shot White House bid despite dismal results in the first several nominating states, has garnered just two of the 1,385 delegates awarded thus far, falling way below the threshold.

Six states will hold primaries and caucuses on Tuesday, though it is virtually impossible that Gabbard will net enough delegates from the contests to hit the 20 percent mark.

Gabbard has repeatedly criticized the DNC, accusing it of seeking to undermine her campaign. She specifically cited a rule change last month regarding the polling qualifications for debates that allowed former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg to appear onstage twice before he dropped out of the race.

"To keep me off the stage, the DNC again arbitrarily changed the debate qualifications. Previously they changed the qualifications in the OPPOSITE direction so Bloomberg could debate. I ask that you stand w/ me against the DNC's transparent effort to exclude me from the debates," Gabbard tweeted.

The Hawaii lawmaker, an Iraq War veteran, has centered her long-shot White House bid around reducing America's military entanglements abroad, but she has faced criticism over a 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad and her past positions opposed to LGBTQ rights.

Title: Wall Street Braces for Tariffs as Gary Cohn Exits White House, NAFTA Talks Loom

Article:

Wall Street is bracing for potential tariffs as Gary Cohn, President Trump's top economic adviser, leaves the White House. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by as much as 349 points on Wednesday, but recovered most of its losses and closed down 82 points.

Quincy Krosby, chief market strategist at Prudential Financial, described the market as "jittery." Investors were holding out hope that Trump would soften his vow to impose a 25% tariff on imported steel and 10% on aluminum, but the White House is moving forward with the plan. Cohn, who fought the tariffs, has left the administration.

"We expect that the president will sign something by the end of the week," Press Secretary Sarah Sanders said Wednesday. She added that there could be "carve-outs" for Canada and Mexico.

Wall Street fears that broad tariffs could trigger a trade war that could harm the economy. Trump's tariff announcement last week caused a shake-up on Wall Street and led to backlash from top US trading partners, including Canada and the European Union.

Brad McMillan, chief investment officer for Commonwealth Financial Network, said that tariffs would "hurt business and investor confidence, which are two of the pillars holding up the markets."

NAFTA talks also loom in the background. Trump has threatened to tear up the 1994 trade agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The three countries have made little progress on a re-negotiated deal since beginning talks in August.

"The market is holding its breath and getting ready for a clearer picture," said Ryan Detrick, senior market strategist for LPL Financial.

US companies with less investment overseas are emerging as winners from the trade uncertainty. The Russell 2000 index, which tracks small companies, closed up for the fifth straight day.

However, investors grappled with Cohn's impending exit. Cohn, a former Goldman Sachs president, helped design Trump's tax cuts and was one of the administration's leading proponents of free trade. He served as a calming influence on the market.

"His departure has caught investors off guard," said Alec Young, FTSE Russell's managing director of global markets research.

McMillan said Cohn was seen as "the voice of economic stability and a spokesperson for financial markets."

"His resignation leaves the president with a set of economic advisers largely seen as outside of the mainstream, or at least perceived as less aligned with Wall Street interests," he said.

Investors view Trump's choice for Cohn's replacement as a window into the president's future trade moves. They "want to see Cohn 2.0," Detrick said.

Title: The Reality of ISIS Threat: A Closer Look at Terrorist Activities Beyond Mainstream Narrative

Article:

In recent discussions, the mainstream media has been debating the threat posed by the Islamic State (ISIS) to the United States. Some commentators argue that this perspective is a "rush to war," while others question the immediacy of the threat. However, a closer examination of events on the ground paints a different picture.

On June 21, 19-year-old Brendan Tevlin was brutally murdered in the United States by a self-proclaimed jihadi, who claimed it was an act of retribution for U.S. military action against Muslims in the Middle East. This incident, which occurred in New Jersey, is one of several instances where ISIS-inspired terrorism has manifested on American soil.

In a series of suburban raids in Sydney and Brisbane, Australia, counterterrorism forces detained 15 individuals last week. Intelligence suggested that ISIS was planning public beheadings in these cities to demonstrate its reach. The plan involved kidnapping random members of the public, beheading them, and releasing the recordings through ISIS's propaganda arm in the Middle East.

The Islamic State does not need to physically be present in cities like Miami, New York, Toronto, or Sydney to pose a threat. The group's continued success in the Middle East and its propaganda serves as a catalyst for sociopaths worldwide. The Islamic State's plans for terrorism in the United States are already in motion, as evidenced by the warnings from New York Police Commissioner Bill Bratton about ISIS targeting Times Square and calls for radicalized individuals to target U.S. military personnel.

The reality of the ISIS threat is a stark contrast to the White House's preferred narrative. Pretending that the threat does not exist will not make it disappear. Ignoring the facts on the ground will only lead to more lives lost to terrorism on American soil. As long as the Islamic State exists, it will continue to inspire disturbed individuals to carry out acts of terror.

Tammy Bruce, a radio talk-show host, author, and Fox News contributor, underscores the importance of acknowledging the ISIS threat. The Australians, who have been proactive in addressing the issue, have saved countless lives on their soil by understanding the reality of the ISIS threat. It is crucial for the United States to follow suit and prioritize national security over political correctness and leftist politics.

Title: Pope Francis Navigates Political Divides with Subtlety and Humility During U.S. and Cuba Visits

Article:

In a week marked by political divisiveness, Pope Francis, the "pope of the periphery," has demonstrated a quiet moral authority that has resonated around the world. His actions, rooted in personal gestures and a humble lifestyle, have transcended the historic teachings of the Catholic Church.

During his visit to the United States and Cuba, Francis wielded his papal power with remarkable subtlety and shrewdness, navigating the two most contentious political issues in the U.S.: immigration and climate change.

Upon his arrival in the U.S., Francis immediately addressed these issues, praising President Obama's proposals to combat air pollution and expressing his gratitude for being a guest in a country built by immigrant families. He later made an unplanned visit to the Little Sisters of the Poor, showing support for the nuns suing the president over the Obamacare birth control provision.

In Cuba, the pope's quiet moral authority was evident in his visits to symbolic locations and his homilies. He spoke of a "revolution of tenderness," a subtle reinterpretation of one of Cuba's national themes. His visit to the Felix Varela Institute, named for a 19th-century advocate for Cuban independence, bolstered the slow-moving economic reforms in the communist country.

Throughout his visits, Francis invoked symbols of both Cuban and American heritage, urging reconciliation, compassion, and pastoral service. He addressed a joint session of Congress, the first pope to do so, using four American figures—Abraham Lincoln, Martin Luther King Jr., Dorothy Day, and Thomas Merton—to emphasize the need for lawmakers to defend and preserve the dignity of their fellow citizens.

Despite his political maneuvering, Francis remained circumspect, cloaking his political forays in gentle moral exhortations. He steered clear of divisive issues such as abortion, instead focusing on the need to end the death penalty.

As Francis concludes his visit to the U.S. and moves on to the United Nations, he will continue to emphasize his main themes of immigration and climate change. He will visit Our Lady Queen of Angels School in East Harlem, a school serving poor immigrant children, and Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility in Philadelphia.

Professor John Sniegocki of Xavier University in Cincinnati, Ohio, notes that Francis has been more attentive to the symbolism of the papacy, which resonates with people and gives more impact to his broader words and broader critiques of global systems.

Title: Trump Holds Off-the-Record Meeting with Network Executives, Kicks off Presidential Transition with Mixed Signals

Article:

In a move that signifies the beginning of the presidential transition, President-elect Donald Trump has held an off-the-record meeting with network executives and anchors at Trump Tower. The meeting, described as "tough" by Variety, reportedly saw Trump reserving particularly harsh words for CNN and NBC News.

According to sources, the meeting was "very candid and very honest," with Trump expressing his displeasure with certain aspects of the coverage during the campaign. He reminded his guests of their misjudgments, such as underestimating his ability to win states like Michigan, where he campaigned in the final days.

The New York Post reported a more dramatic version of the meeting, stating that Trump told CNN President Jeff Zucker, who worked with him at NBC during "The Apprentice," "I hate your network, everyone at CNN is a liar, and you should be ashamed."

Kellyanne Conway, Trump's counselor, described the meeting as "very cordial, very productive, very congenial." She added, "It was also very candid and very honest. From my own perspective, it's great to hit the reset button."

The meeting, it seems, was an opportunity for both sides to discuss media access, news conferences, and press pools. Trump is set to meet today with executives from The New York Times and other outlets.

As the 45th president, Trump's relationship with the mainstream media is expected to be adversarial, given his past criticisms of their organizations as dishonest and corrupt. However, it would be beneficial for both parties to find a way to work together, given Trump's popularity with the cable networks during the primaries.

Meanwhile, a culture war seems to be brewing against Trump. Less than two weeks after his election, his vice president received a stern lecture from the cast of "Hamilton," and Model Gigi Hadid mocked Melania Trump's accent and demeanor at the American Music Awards.

These entertainers and cultural figures, offended by Trump's election, are refusing to "normalize" the 45th president, as media and political elites are also doing. This is seen as a finger in the eye of the 60 million Americans who voted for Trump.

While Trump's policies and appointments can be criticized, it is important to maintain a level of acceptance, even after a bitter campaign. A honeymoon period, once a tradition, now seems to be a thing of the past.

In the political arena, former Attorney General Eric Holder, who was more liberal than part of the country, asked media people paying their respects at a funeral for Gwen Ifill, "Will you cower? Will you normalize that which is anything but?"

It remains to be seen how the relationship between Trump and the media will evolve during his presidency. However, it is hoped that both sides can find common ground and work together for the betterment of the country.

Title: Facebook Discovers Potential Russian Interference Ahead of U.S. Midterm Elections

Article:

Facebook has identified and removed a series of pages and accounts on its platform that exhibited coordinated inauthentic behavior, which may be linked to the Internet Research Agency (IRA), a Russian-based organization with ties to the Kremlin. The social media giant took down 32 pages and accounts on Tuesday, which had a combined total of 290,000 followers and had been promoting American political viewpoints and organizing events, including a protest against the Unite the Right rally scheduled in Washington next week.

In a call with reporters, Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, stated, "It's clear whoever set up these accounts went to much greater lengths to obscure their identities than the Internet Research Agency did in the run-up to the 2016 presidential election."

In October 2017, Facebook admitted that Russia-backed content reached as many as 126 million Americans during the 2016 presidential election. These accounts sometimes used Russian IP addresses and paid for advertising in roubles. The accounts removed this week used virtual private networks (VPNs) to conceal their locations and internet phone services to hide their identities. They spent approximately $11,000 (in US and Canadian dollars) on about 150 ads on Facebook and Instagram.

Nathaniel Gleicher, Facebook's head of cybersecurity policy, stated, "At this point, we don't have enough technical evidence to state definitively who is behind this, but they have shown similar activity and have connected with known IRA accounts."

Alex Stamos, the company's chief security officer, noted that a known IRA account was a co-admin on one of the pages for seven minutes before the account was removed from Facebook. However, Stamos stated it was not clear whether this was the IRA with improved capabilities or a separate group.

Intelligence agencies are in a better position to make an attribution by combining the technical details from Facebook with their own knowledge of the political motivations and goals of countries and other threat actors, according to Stamos.

Members of Congress, who were briefed by the company this week, were quick to attribute the activity to Russia. Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, stated, "Today's disclosure is further evidence that the Kremlin continues to exploit platforms like Facebook to sow division and spread disinformation, and I am glad that Facebook is taking some steps to pinpoint and address this activity."

Some of the deleted pages included "Aztlan Warriors," "Resisters," and "Black Elevation." The "Resisters" page created a Facebook event for a protest on 10-12 August titled "No Unite The Right 2." Admins for the page connected with the admins of five legitimate pages to promote the event and post logistical information for protesters. About 600 users said they would attend the event, and 2,600 expressed an interest in attending.

Facebook disabled the event earlier today and reached out to the legitimate admins of five other pages. The company also pledged to inform the people considering attending the protest about what happened.

There was also coordinated activity around the #AbolishICE campaign, a left-wing movement aimed at shutting down the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency. The activity appears to echo the Kremlin's creation and promotion of black activism pages such as "Blacktivist" in the run-up to the presidential election.

Facebook revealed that the bad actors had created 30 Facebook events since May 2017, most of which had been scheduled over the past year. The company stated it did not know if people had shown up to those events.

Facebook said it would continue to investigate the activity and share any further findings with law enforcement and Congress. Mark Zuckerberg, the company's CEO, stated, "Security isn't a problem you ever completely solve. We face sophisticated and well-funded adversaries, including nation-states, that are always evolving and trying new attacks."

Cybersecurity researcher Lukasz Olejnik commented, "Artificially inducing civil unrests or protests via internet platforms is a worrying development, and incorporation of Instagram is quite novel." He added, "This development touching Washington indicates that concerns about European parliament 2019 elections might now be viewed in rather intriguing light."

Title: "Rising Concerns Over Affordable Care Act's Impact on Employment Hours"

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, is facing criticism from labor unions and other critics who claim that the law is causing employers to reduce full-time employees' hours to avoid additional costs associated with the legislation. The concern is that this trend could affect millions of families across the United States.

The Affordable Care Act requires mid-sized and large employers to sponsor health insurance for all full-time employees, defined as those who work 30 hours a week or more. However, big labor unions, who initially supported the new law, are now expressing concerns due to the premium hikes, leading businesses to cap hours for employees to avoid offering health insurance.

Jason Furman, chairman of Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, has stated that there is no evidence of an adverse impact on job growth or the number of hours employees are working due to the Affordable Care Act. However, United Food and Commercial Workers Union President Joseph Hansen argues that the impact is already being felt, with workers having their hours reduced and incomes affected.

Analysts suggest that three key groups that will be hit hardest are unions, school workers, and local government workers. In states like Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Indiana, school workers such as teacher aides, bus drivers, and cafeteria workers are expected to lose hours. In California, Texas, and Michigan, government workers including parks and recreation officials, librarians, and secretaries could also have their hours and benefits reduced.

Fast-food CEOs at Subway and Papa John's have already reported feeling the impact of the health care overhaul. Papa John's CEO, John Schnatter, estimates that the change will cost his company $5 million to $8 million annually. He expects franchise owners to cut employees' hours due to the costs of health insurance plans.

While not everyone agrees with the critics' claims, an informal survey by NBC News found that roughly 20 businesses are cutting workers to 29 hours a week due to the health care law. However, a recent Bloomberg analysis questions the methodology used by critics, stating that the Bureau of Labor Statistics household survey data is too volatile to draw reliable conclusions from small samples.

In conclusion, the Affordable Care Act is facing criticism for potentially causing employers to reduce full-time employees' hours to avoid additional costs. While the White House maintains that there is no evidence of an adverse impact, critics argue that the trend could affect millions of families across the United States. The debate continues as both sides present their arguments and data.

Title: President-elect Trump Praises Electoral College System, Reflects on Campaign at Final "Thank You" Rally

Article:

In his final "Thank You" rally of the 2016 campaign trail, President-elect Donald Trump expressed gratitude for the Electoral College system and praised the Founding Fathers for their foresight in creating a system that required candidates to campaign across the country.

Speaking at Ladd-Peebles Stadium in Mobile, Alabama, Trump said, "I never appreciated it until now. How genius it was, what they had in mind." He highlighted the Electoral College system as a means that required him to canvass the nation to talk directly to voters.

Trump visited 17 states in the last month of the campaign, he said, and emphasized that the Electoral College system allowed him to reach areas that might have been overlooked in a popular vote system.

"If you go with the popular vote, I'd go New York State, California, back and forth," Trump said. "It would be much easier. The problem is that every other place—you stop in Florida, you stop in Texas—you wouldn't see anyplace else."

Trump won 306 electoral votes on November 8, with electors set to meet on Monday to officially cast their votes for the president-elect and Vice President-elect Mike Pence. Democrat Hillary Clinton won 232 electoral votes, but she won the popular vote with 65.8 million votes to Trump's 62.9 million.

Trump pledged to continue holding rallies after moving into the White House, stating, "This is the last time I'll be speaking at a rally for maybe a while." He added, "We've done everything else the opposite. This is the way you get an honest word out."

Trump's choice for attorney general, Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions, spoke at the rally, praising the historic role Mobile played in the campaign. Sessions, who was the first senator to endorse Trump, said, "It is just no doubt about it. The American people have spoken in so many ways in this election."

Kellyanne Conway, now a senior adviser to the transition team, also spoke at the rally, highlighting Trump's electoral victory statistics, including his win in more than 2,600 counties and 31 of the nation's 50 states. Conway noted that Trump would have won the popular vote if that had been the method needed to get to the presidency.

Trump closed the event with an admonition, saying, "Never, ever give up. I should have given up in this campaign five times. I could take you over 10 different things that happened where people would have given up. But I never gave up." He encouraged his supporters, saying, "Never stop believing, and never, ever stop dreaming."

Title: Presidential Candidates Target Corporations for Taxes and Labor Practices, with Amazon, Facebook, McDonald's, and Walmart in the Spotlight

Article:

In the 2020 presidential race, candidates are garnering significant online engagement by targeting corporations for paying little or no taxes, according to data from High Lantern Group, a firm specializing in corporate reputation analysis. The companies are facing increased pressure to align with the Democratic candidates' visions for the future, which include offering employees a living wage, paying more in taxes, and allowing workers to unionize.

Trump's criticisms often focus on tech, communications, and social media companies, with allegations that their messages are being repressed or censored, or that they are peddling "fake news." The big picture reveals that candidates have criticized corporations before, but the companies facing attacks today differ from those targeted in 2016, when Wall Street was the primary focus.

In the current landscape, Amazon, Facebook, McDonald's, and Walmart have been the most-called-out companies. Presidential candidates have been vocal about their criticisms since last summer, with several 2020 Democrats marching with McDonald's workers during their strike against sexual harassment in the workplace and low wages.

Matt Levy, director of issue analysis at HLG, noted, "We've noticed that companies really pay attention when they or their competitors are called out by huge players." Unlike many other companies, Amazon has responded to candidates' criticisms, threatening to break up Big Tech if they become president.

Walmart, in a statement to ███, urged candidates to engage with the company to learn more about its practices and initiatives before "recycling critiques that haven't been relevant for years." The company added, "From our investments in wages and training to our work on environmental sustainability, some candidates have a lot to learn about who we are today."

Interestingly, between the lines, the finding that Sanders and Warren have led the pack in publicly criticizing companies on Twitter is not the most surprising. What is surprising is that Trump is the next most-likely 2020 candidate to publicly criticize companies on Twitter. Trump's lines of attack are not usually about a living wage or workplace safety. Twitter itself is among the top companies called out by candidates, ranking No. 8.

Title: Trump's Hardline Immigration Stance Contrasts with Shifting Union Attitudes Toward Immigrant Workers

Article:

In a stark contrast to his hardline immigration stance, President Donald Trump's recent speech in Phoenix revealed a more nuanced approach, acknowledging the presence of "good people" among the undocumented population. However, he warned of an impending wave of deportations, emphasizing the perceived threat of undocumented immigrants to American workers.

During the speech, Trump pledged to begin deportations on the first day of his second term, in collaboration with local, state, and federal law enforcement. He linked his promise to carry out deportations with anti-globalist economic ideas, but also drew a direct line between the fortunes of native-born laborers and the presence of undocumented immigrants, a connection he has rarely made in his immigration-related remarks.

"While there are many illegal immigrants in our country who are good people, this does not change the fact that most illegal immigrants are lower-skilled workers with less education, who compete directly against vulnerable American workers," Trump said. He emphasized his commitment to reform legal immigration to serve the best interests of America and its workers.

However, the globalization that Trump denounces has also contributed to a decades-long reshaping of unions – a traditional voice for workers and often vocal opponents of globalization – toward greater inclusion of immigrants, even those without legal status. This shift in union attitudes may undercut Trump's narrative of foreigners arriving to America to crowd out the native-born.

Lowell Turner, a professor at Cornell University’s School of Industrial and Labor Relations, stated in an interview with The ███, "If you have a union job, you know that immigrants are not stealing your jobs." He further explained that the reality around union workers shows that this is not happening.

This electoral season, Trump has seen greater support among union members than any Republican candidate in recent memory. His core support in the primaries was from white men who worked with their hands, and they tended to look favorably upon both unions and economic policies typically considered progressive.

Despite Trump's inroads into the white working class, he has garnered endorsements from only two unions – those representing border patrol and New England police. His low approval among Hispanics and other minorities has likely helped ensure that the vast majority of union endorsements have chosen to remain firmly in the Democrats' camp.

One of those Hillary Clinton supporters is Richard Trumka, president of the AFL-CIO, who was the guest at a Monitor Breakfast earlier this week. Trumka expressed confidence in organized labor’s ability to turn out votes for Clinton, despite Trump’s inroads into the white working class. “We’re probably about where we were with Barack Obama at this point with the election,” Trumka said, adding that the more organized labor gets information out to workers, “the better off we get.”

For much of their early history in the United States, unions viewed certain groups of immigrants with suspicion, if not outright animus. The Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, passed largely at the behest of the organized labor, is a prime example. The fear of job replacement faded after the passage of a 1924 national-origins quota, as immigration levels fell for several decades.

When national reform came up for passage again in 1986, unions' focus was on winning sanctions against employers that hired the undocumented, whom they saw as potential strikebreakers. But by then, changes in unions' attitudes were already beginning. Deregulation measures had sent membership numbers reeling, and in urban areas like Los Angeles, deteriorated wages, benefits, and working conditions caused many native-born workers to abandon certain lines of low-skilled manual jobs.

When they left, immigrants stepped in to take their place, mostly from Central America and Mexico. Union leaders in favor of organizing immigrants thought they were likely to be too nervous for collective action, but campaigns like the Service Employees International Union's Janitors for Justice, first conceived in 1985, won important victories from employers and showed unions that immigrants, including the undocumented, were capable of loud advocacy.

As those efforts were replicated across labor, especially in meatpacking, hospitality, restaurants, and other service industries, immigrants and native-born Hispanics began to exercise growing clout within the ranks. In 2000, the AFL-CIO, the largest union confederation in the country, called for an end to employer sanctions and for legal status for 6 million undocumented immigrants. The move came largely as a result of pressure from an immigrant-led coalition known as the Change to Win Federation, and it caused a sea change in thought.

"I think there was a shift in consciousness," says Mae Ngai, a historian at Columbia University who specializes in immigration and labor. "Even if some of these older unions like the Machinists were not organizing immigrants, they could see other people doing it. They could see that immigrants were not their enemy, not their competition, not their enemy they had to fear."

Title: Analysis: Obama Shores Up Chances in Final Debate, but Romney's Performance Keeps Race Unpredictable

Article:

In the final stretch of the 2012 presidential race, the focus is on the upcoming election, and the question on everyone's mind is, "Who will win?" After the conclusion of the final debate, political analyst David Gergen shares his insights on the current state of the race.

Gergen, a political adviser to four U.S. presidents, believes that President Obama has strengthened his campaign following his clear victories in the final two debates. However, he also acknowledges that Mitt Romney has performed well in the debates and could potentially pull off an upset. Gergen estimates the chances of Obama winning at 53%, while Romney's chances are 47%.

Obama's performance in the debates has been crucial in restoring the faith and energy of his supporters, particularly those who felt he had let them down in the first debate. The President also effectively addressed key demographics, such as minorities, women, and youth, during the debates.

Romney, on the other hand, has managed to present himself as a more human candidate, albeit with some inconsistencies in his foreign policy stance. His calculated strategy of being more deliberative and avoiding direct attacks during the debates has been effective in avoiding a "warmonger" label while also passing the commander-in-chief test.

The race remains tight, and the outcome will depend on the ground game of both candidates.
