Obama's campaign appears to have a stronger ground game, with a more robust field organization, particularly in key battleground states like Ohio. However, the Romney team disputes this assessment and will continue to fight for every vote.

The debates have shifted the narrative of the campaign, with voters now viewing both candidates as qualified for the presidency. Romney has gained ground on the central issues of the campaign: jobs, deficits, and growth. These factors could potentially help Romney come from behind in key battleground states.

The race remains unpredictable, and the next two weeks will be a "wild ride" to the finish. The online prediction market Intrade shows that the odds in favor of Obama have dropped from 74% before the debates to 59% after the final debate. The race is still too close to call, and the final outcome will be determined by the voters.

Title: Gun Range Operator Near Dallas Shooting Suspect's Home Speaks Out on Gun Violence

Article:

Mesquite, Texas — In the aftermath of the deadly shooting of five police officers in Dallas, a local gun range operator has expressed her disbelief and concern over the incident, while also questioning the focus on gun control. Vickie Kale, who runs Gibson's Outpost & Shooting Range, is located just a mile from the residence of Micah Xavier Johnson, the suspect in the attack.

Kale, a certified firearms instructor, shakes her head in disbelief as she watches her customers fire rounds at targets. She questions how someone could point a gun at another human and pull the trigger, expressing her confusion over what could drive someone to such violence.

Johnson, who is believed to have practiced at the range if he did so, is not recognized by the regular customers at Gibson's. If he did practice, they say he likely did so elsewhere. Dallas police have yet to release details about the type of rifle Johnson used, the number of rounds he fired, or where he may have practiced before the attack.

WFAA-TV reported on Saturday that authorities believe Johnson had planned a larger attack, based on the ammunition he was carrying and his access to explosives.

The gun owners at the range, who prefer to remain anonymous, view their firearms as tools or objects of beauty. They are wary of speaking to reporters, fearing it could bring trouble to their homes or make them a target of a government they are skeptical or afraid of.

In Texas, open carrying of rifles is legal, and many firearms owners argue that the media focuses too much on the presence of guns and not enough on the individuals who misuse them. They question the lack of individual accountability and the absence of family values that teach respect for authority and obedience to police officers.

At the range, the unnamed gun owners express their frustration that their guns are often blamed for acts of violence, despite never being used against another person. Kale echoes their sentiments, stating, "It's not the gun. It's not the car. It's the people driving, the person firing."

Johnson reportedly learned to shoot during his six years in the U.S. Army Reserve and served one tour of duty in Afghanistan. He was a private first class with a specialty in carpentry and masonry but did not appear to have specialized training as a sniper.

Dallas police have yet to release a complete timeline of Johnson's movements during the shootings. He was killed by police using a pound of C-4 explosive delivered by a remote-controlled robot. During the standoff with police, Johnson told negotiators that he was upset over recent police-involved shootings of blacks and wanted to kill white people, especially white police officers.

Authorities who searched Johnson's home in Mesquite found a personal journal of combat tactics, as well as bomb-making materials, ballistic vests, rifles, and ammunition. Mesquite is about a 20-minute drive east of downtown Dallas, and the drive takes visitors past multiple firearms stores tucked near nail salons and doughnut shops. Few of the gun dealers wanted to discuss the incident, but at least one store made it clear that President Obama would not be welcome inside its aisles selling noise-suppressors and cases of ammunition.

Gun-control advocates have used Johnson's attack to rally support for stricter laws, including against open carrying of firearms, which is legal in Texas.

Back at the range near Johnson's house, Kale said she and her friends often remark that their guns never clean the kitchen or take out the trash, but somehow get blamed for killing other people, even though they've never fired a shot in anger.

"It's not the gun. It's not the car. It's the people driving, the person firing," she said. "Why don't we talk about that?"

Title: Supreme Court to Clarify Interpretation of 1964 Civil Rights Act in Discrimination Cases

Article:

The Supreme Court's new term has commenced with significant oral arguments on Tuesday, focusing on two cases that highlight contrasting perspectives on statutory interpretation. The cases aim to establish whether workplace discrimination based on sexual orientation is prohibited under the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which outlaws discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.

At the heart of the matter is the question of whether "sex" in the Act also encompasses discrimination based on sexual orientation. The Supreme Court will revisit arguments first presented in 2017 in another case, where the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit ruled that Congress, in effect, has implicitly outlawed such discrimination without explicitly stating so.

Kimberly Hively, a part-time adjunct professor at an Indiana community college, claims she was denied a full-time position and her part-time contract was not renewed due to her being a lesbian. The Seventh Circuit majority argued that the question is whether "actions taken on the basis of sexual orientation" are a "subset of actions taken on the basis of sex."

The majority based their decision on the broader context of the statute, acknowledging but disregarding Congress' repeated refusals to add "sexual orientation" to the Act. The majority argued that they had "no idea what inference to draw from congressional inaction." They also pointed out that the meaning of the phrase "sex discrimination" has evolved over time, and Congress in 1964 may not have fully understood the scope of the words they chose.

A concurring judge argued that times have changed, and the meaning of the statute has evolved, with the word "sex" now encompassing both gender and sexual orientation. The judge contended that homosexuality was not a significant factor in the minds of the legislators in 1964, and since then, attitudes towards sex have broadened.

The minority, however, argued that the Supreme Court should interpret the statutory language as it was understood at the time of enactment. They contend that the terms "sex" and "sexual orientation" are not used interchangeably and that the Seventh Circuit's interpretation cannot be reconciled with the constitutional design, which requires bicameralism and presentment.

The minority also pointed out that the Violence Against Women Act and the Hate Crimes Act, which forbid discrimination on the basis of both "sex" and "sexual orientation," and impose heightened punishment for harms inflicted because of these factors, support their argument.

The Seventh Circuit's minority concluded that, while Hively was unjustly treated, her case does not fall under the 1964 Civil Rights Act's prohibition of sex discrimination. The Supreme Court's decision will serve as a reminder to Congress and the courts about the importance of adhering to the constitutional design and the role of Congress in statutory updating.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies' Assessment of Russia's Involvement in Afghanistan and Presidential Briefings

Article:

In a discussion on Fox & Friends on June 30, 2020, the hosts discussed the potential involvement of foreign powers, particularly Russia, in Afghanistan. Republican Representative Michael Waltz, a guest on the show, stated that for years, Russia has been supporting the Taliban through arms, while Iran has been providing cash, equipment, and training. Pakistan has also been implicated in supporting the Taliban.

The hosts emphasized that if information about foreign involvement in Afghanistan is not verified by the U.S.'s 16 intelligence agencies, it does not reach the President's desk. The President is expected to make decisions based on the intelligence that is presented to him. If he is not briefed on certain information, he may not be aware of it. However, if he is briefed on it, he can act accordingly.

The hosts also discussed a report from The New York Times that suggested the President was briefed about Russia's involvement in Afghanistan on February 27th. It was noted that not all presidents read all of their briefings, and a briefing aide may summarize the content of the briefing for the President. Therefore, the President may not have personally read or been aware of the information if it was only briefly mentioned in his daily briefing.

The discussion concluded with the hosts expressing concern about the potential dangers of the President taking action based on unverified information, as it could lead to complications. The hosts emphasized the importance of verifying information before making decisions that could have significant consequences.

Title: Christie Fundraising Tour in Florida Amidst Ongoing Political Scandal

Article:

In the midst of a political scandal that has engulfed New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, he has embarked on a fundraising tour in Florida, assisting Republican Governor Rick Scott in his statewide campaigning. The allegations of a traffic jam in Fort Lee, New Jersey, being orchestrated as political retaliation against the town's mayor by Christie's team, have been circulating for over a week.

Christie's weekend itinerary includes stops in Orlando, Fort Lauderdale, and Palm Beach. However, the impact of the scandal on Christie's popularity remains unclear, as all the meetings are closed-door events. Accompanying Christie, Governor Scott has shown unwavering support, stating to CNN affiliate WSVN that Christie "did the right thing. He apologized. He went to the community and apologized. And I look forward to seeing him."

As chairman of the Republican Governors Association, Christie will also be raising funds for the organization and networking with potential donors who could be significant contributors if Christie decides to run for president in 2016. The main political event is scheduled for Saturday night at the home of billionaire Ken Langone, the co-founder of Home Depot.

Langone shared that he has been inundated with requests to meet the governor, regardless of the ongoing scandal. However, the Democrats have not been silent on the matter. Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is tracking Christie's movements in Florida and has criticized the governor for the private nature of his campaign events.

"I think that means that Chris Christie does not want to answer any questions or Rick Scott does not want to be seen with Chris Christie in public – probably a little of both," Wasserman Schultz told CNN.

Lenny Curry, Florida's Republican Party chairman, countered the Democrats' criticism, stating, "Chris Christie apologized. Chris Christie took action. He's the head of the Republican Governors Association, and he's down here doing his job, and that's raising money to make sure that Rick Scott gets re-elected."

The political landscape in Florida remains dynamic as the Christie scandal unfolds, with both parties offering their perspectives on the situation.

Title: Trump Declares Houses of Worship "Essential," Urges Governors to Allow Reopening

Article:

In a move aimed at easing restrictions on religious gatherings during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, President Donald Trump on Friday announced that new Centers for Disease Control (CDC) guidance will classify houses of worship as "essential." The President called on governors to allow churches, synagogues, and mosques to reopen "right now" following their closure during lockdowns.

During a briefing at the White House, Trump stated, "The governors need to do the right thing and allow these very important essential places of faith to open right now -- for this weekend." He added, "If they do not do it, I will override the governors."

The CDC released interim guidelines on Friday for communities of faith, acknowledging the importance of worship in many Americans' lives while also warning of the potential risks associated with gatherings. The guidelines encourage the use of cloth face coverings during services, limiting the size of gatherings, and social distancing during services. They also suggest suspending or decreasing choirs and singing in church due to the potential for increased transmission of COVID-19.

Last week, the CDC released new guidelines for schools, businesses, and other organizations as states reopen from coronavirus shutdowns. However, the document did not include guidance for churches and faith-based groups due to concerns raised by the White House regarding the recommended restrictions.

Cities across the country have been following their governors' lead on when and how to reopen. In New York City, houses of worship never closed but have been under reasonable capacity requirements that prohibit large gatherings.

The White House's announcement comes after Trump had a conference call with over 1,600 pastors and faith leaders from around the country, including Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council. Trump reassured them that he wants to get churches reopened.

Churches across the country had to close down due to stay-home orders necessary to stop the spread of the contagious virus. Faith leaders set up online services, and families tuned in Sunday mornings from their computers at home.

Some faith leaders have argued that social distancing rules have violated First Amendment religious freedoms. Others have defied state and local rules and tried to reopen. However, other faith leaders have warned that congregating is too dangerous at this time.

The coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant number of deaths and job losses, and many families are grappling with these challenges while unable to seek respite in their places of worship. The White House's decision to classify houses of worship as essential is a response to these concerns.

The CDC's interim guidelines for communities of faith can be found on their website. It is recommended that faith leaders review these guidelines and implement measures to ensure the safety of their congregations during services.

Title: HealthCare.gov Apology, Website Malfunctions, and Insurance Plan Cancellations: Sebelius Testifies Before Congress

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday, taking responsibility for the malfunctioning HealthCare.gov website and addressing concerns over the cancellation of health insurance plans.

Sebelius apologized for the broken Obamacare website, stating that it would take another month to fix. Despite the ongoing issues, she defended the Affordable Care Act as a good deal for most Americans, emphasizing its role in helping not only the uninsured but also the underinsured.

President Obama also addressed the controversy, using a campaign-style speech in Boston to clarify his 2010 promise that his health care program wouldn't force Americans out of their existing insurance. Obama stated that while some may be kicked off their plans, they will end up getting better deals from their insurance companies.

The HealthCare.gov website, intended to be the main way for many Americans to buy insurance from state-based health care exchanges, has been plagued by glitches since its launch on October 1. The site even crashed during Sebelius' testimony on Wednesday morning.

Sebelius took accountability for the debacle, stating, "Hold me accountable for the debacle. I'm responsible." This marked the first time she has answered to Congress for the website's problems.

Calls for Sebelius to resign took a back seat to complaints about who knew what and when about the flawed website and stories of constituents who have lost their health care plans and could face higher premiums. Lawmakers also employed backhanded humor and personal challenges to make their points.

Rep. Cory Gardner (Colorado Republican) questioned Sebelius about her enrollment in a health care plan from the Obamacare exchanges. Sebelius refused, citing her employer-based coverage from the federal government.

Sebelius appeared to confuse the law when she told lawmakers, "If I have available employer-based coverage, I am not eligible for the market." HealthCare.gov states that if individuals are eligible for job-based insurance, they can consider switching to a marketplace plan but may put their subsidies at risk.

Sebelius' testimony followed that of Marilyn Tavenner, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, who testified to another House committee the day before. Both women laid some of the blame for the website's problems on the lead company they hired to help build the site.

However, vendors have stated that the Obama administration did not test the system "end to end" until days before its launch, and a CMS memo revealed that the website had not completed security testing as of September 27.

Making matters worse for the administration, website problems have been overshadowed this week by concerns that many Americans in the individual market will not be able to keep their health care plans, as President Obama had promised.

Sebelius told lawmakers that if a plan was in place in 2010, when Congress passed the legislation, then it could have been grandfathered in as long as the companies didn't make major changes. She reminded lawmakers that the individual market covers a small percentage of Americans—many are covered by their employers or by programs such as Medicare—and that some consumers will gain better health plans at similar or lower costs, especially with the help of government subsidies.

Committee Chairman Fred Upton (Michigan Republican) stated that Americans are "scared" and "frustrated" with the situation because many of these people cannot use the Obamacare websites to explore their options—just weeks after Sebelius and her lieutenants assured lawmakers that the federal exchange system was ready to launch.

Rep. Marsha Blackburn (Tennessee Republican) told Sebelius that the law is taking away a personal choice to hold a bare-bones plan. "I will remind you," she said, "some people like to drive a Ford, not a Ferrari, and some people like to drink out of a red Solo cup, not a crystal stem."

Title: Biden's Role in Financial Reform and Consumer Protection During Obama Administration Highlighted

Article:

In a recent discussion, Jared Bernstein, who served as President Joe Biden's chief economist and economic adviser during his first term as vice president, highlighted Biden's significant role in financial reform and consumer protection during the Obama administration.

During his tenure as vice president, Biden led the Middle Class Task Force, which organized a meeting five years ago to address consumer protection issues. The Obama administration's influence led to the passage of legislation that required clearer monthly statements, protected against retroactive interest rate increases, and limited the fees banks charge merchants on debit card purchases.

Biden's efforts were praised by Stephen Spector, a spokesman for the vice president, who stated, "The vice president's efforts made the administration unparalleled in its support for financial reform and consumer protection." Spector pointed to Biden's support for the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act, intended to protect consumers from unfair billing practices, and the Dodd-Frank Act, the 2010 financial overhaul legislation that provided new consumer safeguards and created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

The extent to which Biden can claim credit for these bills could be significant in a primary campaign, according to Bernstein. "He was very much on the team," Bernstein said, "and back then it was extremely important that not only did we pass these measures, but that they were elevated for all to see."

Christopher J. Dodd, a former Democratic senator from Connecticut, noted that Biden, as vice president, was not necessarily a central player in the passage process. However, Dodd, a sponsor of the Dodd-Frank Act with Barney Frank, a former Democratic congressman from Massachusetts, described Biden as a "classic progressive Democrat" on economic issues.

"As vice president, I certainly can not think of a single instance that he was hostile," said Dodd. "Biden, as vice president, was not a significant player behind the scenes—for or against credit-card companies," added Frank.

However, Frank also suggested that the Obama administration's record on financial issues could serve as a "pretty good defense for Joe" against criticism of his earlier ties to the credit-card industry, before he was freed from representing the interests of his home state.

Title: Former Prosecutor Predicts Indictment of President Trump on Campaign Finance Charges

Article:

In a recent analysis, former Assistant U.S. Attorney Andrew McCarthy suggests that prosecutors in the Southern District of New York are likely to indict President Donald Trump on charges related to violations of federal campaign finance laws. McCarthy, a conservative legal analyst, bases his prediction on the sentencing memo for Michael Cohen, Trump's former personal attorney, released on Friday.

The 40-page sentencing memorandum filed by federal prosecutors for Cohen highlights the president's potential involvement in the campaign finance violations. McCarthy argues that the prosecutors would not have emphasized Cohen's relatively minor campaign finance violations if they did not intend to charge Trump for payments made to two women before he became president.

McCarthy acknowledges that Trump has a strong defense, but suggests that prosecutors may be focusing on him regardless. In August, Cohen pleaded guilty and made an extraordinary statement in open court, stating that the payments to the women were made "in coordination with and at the direction of" the candidate for federal office – Donald Trump. Prosecutors would not have made this statement if the president was not a subject of their investigation.

Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and one of Trump's current lawyers, dismissed the legal danger to the president on Friday. He pointed to Cohen's conviction for lying to the FBI, which could make his testimony on other matters unreliable. "You have to believe Cohen. Who believes Cohen?" Giuliani reportedly said.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, offers a different perspective. He is a winner of the 2018 Robert Novak Journalism Alumni Fellowship and co-author of How Trump Won: The Inside Story of a Revolution. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Title: Connecticut Senator Richard Blumenthal's Response to Candy Crowley's Question on Gun Control Legislation

Article:

In a recent interview, Connecticut Senator Richard Blumenthal, a former Attorney General of the state, faced a question from CNN's Candy Crowley regarding the effectiveness of the proposed gun control legislation in preventing tragedies like the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting.

"How would anything in the bill, as it currently stands, have stopped anything that went on in Newtown?" Crowley asked. Blumenthal responded by stating that amendments on both the assault-weapons ban and the prohibition on high-capacity magazines would be offered, and he intends to propose an amendment to ban high-capacity magazines.

Blumenthal's response, in essence, acknowledges the limitations of the current bill and the need for further measures. This admission underscores the growing divide within the Democratic party on gun control, with President Obama criticizing gun control opponents as insensitive to the Sandy Hook victims, while Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has reportedly blocked a ban on assault weapons due to insufficient support within the Democrat-controlled Senate.

Crowley's question, and Blumenthal's response, prompt a broader examination of the proposed legislation's effectiveness. This article will consider three key aspects of the bill: background checks, "assault weapons" bans, and magazine limits.

1. Background checks: The Newtown shooter obtained his weapons illegally from his mother, who purchased them legally. Existing mechanisms for checking potential gun buyers who are determined to obtain a firearm illegally are inadequate. This is not a Republican talking point; the Vice President has acknowledged this reality himself.

2. "Assault weapons" ban: Connecticut, where the Sandy Hook shooting occurred, has a federal-style assault weapons ban in place. The weapons used in the Sandy Hook massacre were not prohibited by that law.

3. Magazine limits: Forcing a mass shooter to reload may provide a brief opportunity for unarmed victims to intervene, as occurred during the Tucson shooting. However, the likelihood of defenseless, terrified children, such as those at Sandy Hook, successfully overpowering a deranged gunman is negligible.

It is crucial to consider whether the proposed restrictions are effective, duplicative, and respectful of law-abiding citizens' Second Amendment rights. The "if it saves one life" argument, while emotionally appealing, should not be used to gloss over these important questions.

This article is not an endorsement or rejection of gun control measures, but rather an invitation to engage in a thoughtful, informed discussion about the potential impact of proposed legislation. It is essential to avoid hasty, ill-conceived action, as history has shown that such actions can lead to unworkable prohibitions and oversights, as seen in New York under Governor Andrew Cuomo.

In closing, a quotation from the nation's foremost gun safety expert, Senator Blumenthal, serves as a reminder that the proposed gun control measures are just the beginning of the conversation: "The Assault Weapons ban and the limitation on the size of magazines, let me say this as clearly as I can: this is just the beginning."

Title: Trump Imposes Tough New Sanctions on Iran, Sparking Concerns Over Economic Impact

Article:

In a series of tweets, US President Donald Trump has issued a stern warning to anyone engaging in trade with Iran, following the re-imposition of sanctions on the Middle Eastern country. The sanctions, which took effect overnight, are part of a broader strategy to pressure Iran into negotiating a new deal over its nuclear program and other contentious issues.

The president tweeted, "Anyone doing business with Iran will NOT be doing business with the United States." He also praised the "most biting sanctions ever imposed" and said they would "ratchet up to another level" in November. "I am asking for WORLD PEACE, nothing less!" he said.

The sanctions, which follow the US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal earlier this year, target the purchase or acquisition of US banknotes by Iran's government, graphite, aluminum, steel, coal, and software used in industrial processes. A second phase, set to come into effect on 5 November, will have implications for Iran's energy and shipping sectors, petroleum trading, and transactions by foreign financial institutions with the Central Bank of Iran.

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has criticized the US government, saying it has "turned their back on diplomacy" and is engaged in "psychological warfare" against the Iranian people. Rouhani said, "Negotiations with sanctions does not make sense. We are always in favor of diplomacy and talks... but talks need honesty."

The European Union, which remains committed to the original nuclear deal, has spoken out against the sanctions and vowed to protect firms doing "legitimate business" with Iran. The foreign ministers of Germany, the UK, and France released a statement on Monday, saying the nuclear deal remains "crucial" to global security. They also unveiled a "blocking statute," which is intended to protect European firms doing business with Iran despite the new US sanctions.

The impact of the sanctions is already being felt in Iran, with rising food prices, unemployment, and even poor water supplies leading to protests in a number of cities. The sanctions may bite hardest in November, when the US blocks Iranian oil sales, potentially halting about half of Iran's exports of some two million barrels a day. However, Iran may look to China and Russia to keep its industry afloat.

The International Monetary Fund has predicted that Iran's net official reserves could decline this year to $97.8 billion, which would finance about 13 months of imports. Analysts at BMI Research say Iran's economy could contract by 4.3% in 2019.

As the first tranche of new US sanctions kicks in, young Iranians have been sharing their stories with BBC Persian, detailing the economic hardships they are facing. Many have lost their jobs, with some turning to alternative means of income, such as taxi driving or overtime work, to support their families. Many are also going without pay, struggling to make ends meet.

The sanctions have sparked concerns that they could lead to increased unrest in Iran, but some analysts argue that such economic hardship often makes people more dependent on their government, rather than leading to its downfall. As the situation unfolds, the world watches with bated breath, hoping for a peaceful resolution to the ongoing tensions between the US and Iran.

Title: U.S. Re-imposition of Iran Sanctions and the Global Response

Article:

In a move that could significantly alter international relations, President Donald Trump's decision to re-impose sanctions on Iran and withdraw from the 2015 nuclear deal has left U.S. allies in Europe, China, Russia, and Iran grappling with their next steps.

Trump, in a statement on Tuesday, described the deal as a "horrible, one-sided deal" that "didn’t bring peace" and "never will." The President's decision not to re-issue the waivers required under the nuclear agreement could have a "devastatingly chilling effect on any kind of economic activity" between Europe and Iran, according to Tony Blinken, a former deputy secretary of State under President Barack Obama.

Robert Einhorn, a former arms control official at the State Department under Obama, explained that the practical effect of not issuing the waivers is to put banks, businesses, and purchasers of Iranian crude oil on notice that they must either stop importing Iranian crude oil or make significant reductions within the next 180 days.

Trump's decision to withdraw from the deal stems from his long-standing criticism of the agreement, which he has called the worst ever negotiated. He has identified several weaknesses in the deal, including the elimination of expiration dates on the most important restrictions on Iran's nuclear activity, allowing inspections of military sites, and addressing Iran's support for terrorist groups across the Middle East.

French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson have all urged Trump to stay with the deal and work to address his concerns. They have agreed with U.S. intelligence agencies and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who testified that the agreement limited Iran's nuclear activities for now and that Iran has complied with it.

Iran's President Hasan Rouhani has said his country would respond to the U.S. action, but he and other signatories to the deal have also expressed a desire to stay in it. Russia, a crude oil exporter, does not import much, if any, crude oil from Iran. China could potentially direct its oil purchases through its Kunlun Bank, which is already under U.S. sanctions.

The European Union has announced plans to protect companies if Trump pulls out of the deal, but Einhorn predicts that banks and businesses will likely pull out of Iran due to the risks associated with the U.S.-led financial system. The poor management and corruption of Iran's economy could further deter businesses from engaging with the country.

Stephen Rademaker, a former arms control official at the State Department under President George W. Bush, believes Trump's ideal goal is to negotiate a better deal with Iran. Even after refusing to waive sanctions and those sanctions go back into effect, Trump will still have the waiver authority, according to Rademaker.

Trump's decision to re-impose sanctions on Iran and withdraw from the nuclear deal will have far-reaching consequences for the global community, particularly for U.S. allies in Europe, China, and Russia. The next few months will be critical as these nations decide how to respond to the U.S.'s actions and navigate the complexities of the global economy.

Title: Opponents Ramp Up Efforts to Prevent "Bad Deal" in Iran Nuclear Negotiations

Article:

As the interim nuclear deal negotiations with Iran continue in Geneva, opponents and skeptics are intensifying their efforts to prevent what they fear could be a "bad deal" that would allow Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon.

While it is acknowledged that neither Congress nor the vocal opposition of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu can derail an accord agreed upon by world powers, attention is shifting towards ensuring immediate consequences for Iran if it fails to comply with the provisions of any such agreement.

The six world powers, meeting with Iran in Geneva, reported no progress on Thursday in narrowing the remaining differences between the two sides, with some Iranian officials suggesting that the gaps may have widened since their last meeting earlier this month.

However, this apparent lack of progress did not deter some members of Congress from meeting with administration officials at the White House to express their concerns. At least one Republican senator announced that he was proposing legislation to reinstate any lightened sanctions on Iran upon any evidence of Iran not abiding by the terms of a first-step deal.

An interim deal with Iran would aim to freeze progress in Iran's nuclear program while a comprehensive agreement, verifiably stopping Iran's program short of a nuclear weapon, could be worked out. Opponents appear most concerned that a short-term plan accepting some level of uranium enrichment - a process that can result in the fuel for a nuclear weapon - could turn into permanent acceptance of Iran's "right" to enrich.

John Bolton, the former US ambassador to the United Nations and a prominent critic of the Obama administration's Iran diplomacy, stated, "The Iranian nuclear program has been fundamentally a weapons program from the beginning, and I don't see that changing - certainly not if we go with an interim deal that accepts uranium enrichment."

Such a deal, Bolton added, would be "fatally flawed" because, without any vision for what a final plan should look like, the risks are great that an interim accord "becomes permanent" - enshrining Iran's enrichment program and leaving Iran on a path to a nuclear weapon.

Fears that an interim deal could evolve into a permanent deal - and one leaving Iran with an operating enrichment program - prompted Sen. Bob Corker (R-TN) to introduce legislation on Thursday "to keep the pressure on Iran" in the period between a first-step and a final deal.

The bill would defer any additional lifting of sanctions - beyond what the White House says would be "limited and reversible" sanctions relief as part of an interim deal - until after Iran agreed to the "essential terms of an acceptable final deal," Senator Corker said. The legislation also calls for any sanctions lifted as part of an interim deal to "snap back" in the event of any violation of the deal's obligations, he added.

In order to secure substantial US sanctions relief as part of a final agreement, Iran would have to verifiably "eliminate the threat of its nuclear program," Corker said.

Even as negotiations were underway in Geneva, the White House continued to brief members of Congress in an effort to head off debilitating criticism should a deal be reached.

One member of a delegation invited to the White House on Thursday, Rep. Brad Sherman (D-CA), said he "remains a skeptic" that a good interim deal is possible. But he said he left the meeting, which he said was attended by 10 Democratic representatives, "a little more convinced that they [in the administration] are focused on getting this right" and not above all on getting any deal.

Earlier in the day, Representative Sherman had cut short his attendance at a Capitol Hill meeting of Iranian dissidents addressing the plight of Iranian refugees in Iraq, telling a cheering crowd that he had to leave for the White House "to convince them not to accept a bad deal in Geneva."

After the White House meeting, Sherman said, "I still fear they would be willing to enter a deal that [to them] would be better than no deal at all" - echoing a charge leveled against President Obama not just by other members of Congress but also by French leaders, who are also involved in the Geneva talks.

"But after what I heard," he added, "I'm a little less concerned about that than I was before."

Sherman said a key challenge after an interim deal - and one reason he never favored the idea of a "first step" before a comprehensive agreement - will be the thinking expected to bloom in international business circles "that it's OK to do business with Iran now."

To battle such trends and to keep the pressure up on Iran, Sherman says he and other members of the House will continue to press the Senate to proceed with considering a new round of sanctions. The point, he says, would be to keep Iran motivated to reach a comprehensive agreement on its nuclear program.

More ardent critics of the administration's Iran diplomacy say any rush into a "bad deal" won't just leave Iran's nuclear challenge unaddressed, but could embroil Obama in another losing political battle.

Americans largely favor reaching a diplomatic solution with Iran, polls show, but, critics add, that doesn't mean that an Iran allowed to continue moving toward a nuclear weapon is acceptable.

"I think the administration is set on getting some deal," says Mr. Bolton, now a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. "But if they go with a deal with such deficiencies that the opposition here in Washington is swift and sustained, they're not going to get that."

Title: Trump Advocates for Expanded Childcare and Family Leave, Pursuing Bipartisan Effort on Working Parents' Assistance

Article:

In a move aimed at addressing a key issue emphasized by Democratic candidates in the 2020 race, President Donald Trump called for expanded access to childcare and family leave during a White House meeting on Thursday. The event, arranged by Trump's daughter, Ivanka Trump, was part of an administration push to improve assistance for working parents and potentially move forward related legislation.

Trump emphasized the need to expand childcare options and reduce unnecessary regulations, allowing parents to choose the best care for their children. He advocated for the expansion of in-home and faith-based programs for children, stating, "We want to expand childcare options and reduce unnecessary regulations so that parents can choose the best care for their children."

Ivanka Trump, in a speech, highlighted the impact of lack of childcare and paid leave, stating, "Lack of child care and paid leave is not a women's issue — it is a family issue." She continued, "That said, they disproportionately impact women, who provide the vast majority of unpaid care to our nation's children and adult dependents."

Childcare and family leave have been a focus for several Democratic presidential candidates, including Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey, who has proposed legislation to increase eligibility for the childcare block-grant subsidy and provide free childcare to some student parents. Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts has called for universal childcare for all children under 5, and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota has proposed three months of paid family leave.

In a bipartisan effort, House Democrats this week reportedly struck a deal with the White House, providing 12 weeks of paid parental leave for federal workers in exchange for establishing the president's proposed space force as a new branch of the government in the defense authorization bill. White House domestic policy adviser Joe Grogan called the possible new benefit for federal workers an "important first step" toward the administration's priority of providing paid family leave for all Americans.

The administration is also asking lawmakers to reauthorize and overhaul a block-grant program that provides childcare subsidies to low-income working families. Last year, lawmakers increased the amount of childcare funds distributed to states through the program by $2.4 billion to $5.6 billion overall. However, the White House argues the program could benefit more families if lawmakers removed "overly stringent regulations" on facilities and staff that the administration says drive up childcare costs.

As part of the White House effort, the Council of Economic Advisers completed a report detailing the impact of childcare costs on the economy. The report found that while women with young children are about twice as likely to participate in the labor force as they were 50 years ago, some 3.8 million parents with children under the age of 6 are currently outside the labor force. The report argues that expanding childcare options, particularly by removing some regulations, could meaningfully increase the number of Americans who work rather than stay home out of concern over childcare costs.

Title: Marco Rubio Downplays Significance of Recent Poll Results in Republican Presidential Race

Article:

In an interview on ABC's "This Week," Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) expressed skepticism about the significance of his current standing in the race for the Republican presidential nomination, following a new CNN/ORC poll that placed him in fourth place with 11 percent support.

When asked by host George Stephanopoulos if his "breakout moment" had arrived, Rubio responded, "No, these polls do not really mean anything at this stage." He went on to say, "You're a veteran of campaigns, and I'm not sure the mid-September winners are where you want to be."

Rubio acknowledged the importance of polls in determining who qualifies for the debates, but emphasized that they would not ultimately decide the election. "They're not going to decide this election," he said, reiterating a stance he has maintained throughout the campaign.

As Pope Francis prepares to visit Washington this week, Rubio, a Catholic who also attends an evangelical church, addressed the pope's doctrinal authority while emphasizing his political independence. "For me, the pope is the successor of [St.] Peter. He's the spiritual head of the church, who has authority to speak on matters, doctrinal matters and theological matters," Rubio said. "I follow him 100 percent on those issues."

However, Rubio added that the pope, as an individual, has political opinions that are separate from the church's doctrinal teachings. "The pope, as an important figure in the world, also has political opinions," Rubio said. "And those, of course, we are free to disagree with."

Rubio also expressed support for the pope meeting with dissidents during his nine-day visit to Cuba and the United States. On the issue of the pope's political stance on economic and geopolitical matters, Rubio said, "The pope is just trying to bring people together. That's his role as a spiritual leader. And I respect that very much."

Rubio also took the opportunity to clarify President Barack Obama's religious affiliation and nationality, stating that Obama is a Christian born in the United States.

Title: Facebook-Organized Protests Attended by Hundreds Possibly Linked to Disinformation Network

Article:

Investigations have revealed that at least three events co-organized on Facebook by a group now suspected of being part of a coordinated disinformation network were held, and attended by hundreds of people. The events, which took place in New York City and Springfield, Missouri, were all co-hosted by a group called the Resisters, and were critical of President Trump.

The events, including the "We Stand with DREAMers! Support DACA!" event in New York on September 9, 2018, and "The People's Protest. Springfield against Trump" in Missouri on August 30, 2018, were attended by hundreds of people, according to archived versions of the event pages. The New York Post reported that thousands gathered in Midtown, New York, to protest Trump's decision to unwind the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, while hundreds of protesters showed up in Springfield, Missouri, to protest President Trump's trip to the town at the time.

Facebook executives have stated that "inauthentic" groups, including the Resisters, created roughly 30 events. Facebook has highlighted fake pages set up by the groups, but has no evidence that the events actually took place. There is some evidence that the events set up by Resisters were meant to piggyback on existing, legitimate events by opponents of Trump.

Indivisible St. Louis told reporters that its Springfield event was already being organized when Resisters contacted them on Facebook. They also stated that they did not encounter any representatives from Resisters at the protest. The Columbus Circle in New York protest, which was similar to the one organized by Resisters, may have been organized regardless, as protests against the DACA policy had already occurred early in September 2017.

Roger Ray of the Emerging Church in Springfield stated that the protest he was involved in would have happened regardless. "I don't doubt there were lots of fake groups that might have tried to glom on, but they didn't have any physical representation. They wouldn't have had any influence," he told reporters in a phone interview.

Facebook executives did not blame Russia or the Russian troll group the Internet Research Agency (IRA), but said that the behavior matched past work by the IRA. The IRA during the 2016 presidential election created events that were highlighted on Facebook, including one in New York City attended by thousands. Multiple organizers told reporters that they were frustrated by the possibility that the involvement of a fake account could undermine their actual cause and stressed that they were engaged in real organizing.

"I certainly was not inspired by Russia or anything like that," Ray said.

Title: Pennsylvania and Delaware Voters Embrace Trump as GOP's Presumptive Nominee

Article:

YORK, Penn. — Despite concerns from some Republican leaders in Washington, rank-and-file voters are wholeheartedly supporting the GOP's presumptive nominee, Donald Trump. Voters who backed Trump's primary opponents have expressed their readiness to back the billionaire businessman.

In the aftermath of Trump's landslide victory in the Pennsylvania primary, he appears to be winning over not only Republicans but also independents and Democrats crucial for capturing deep-blue states like Pennsylvania and Delaware, which haven't voted for a Republican president in a generation.

A Pennsylvania State Police trooper, who requested anonymity due to his job, voted for Sen. Ted Cruz in the primary but is now backing Trump. He explained, "I'm a Republican. One of our problems in this country is money management, and he certainly can assist with that problem."

Gun shop owner Joe Staudt, who also voted for Cruz, is now on the Trump Train. He expressed frustration with top Republicans for not joining the bandwagon, stating, "It's childish or maybe even selfish. The power brokers in Washington certainly don't want to give up their gravy train—that's both parties."

Megan Sweeney, spokeswoman for the Republican Party of Pennsylvania, echoed the sentiment, stating, "We are a bottom-up organization. The voters spoke loud and clear about who they wanted as the nominee."

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus has called for party unity behind Trump, but establishment figures like House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney, and several primary rivals have refused to pledge their support.

Trump and Ryan are set to meet on Thursday in Washington, and the speaker has offered to give up his role presiding over the Republican National Convention this summer in Cleveland if requested by Trump.

Republican strategist and pollster Jim McLaughlin noted that Trump beat Cruz, a tea party favorite, in the Pennsylvania primary by 25 points among evangelicals and by 30 points among self-described conservatives.

Trump's economic message of making America "win" again resonates with disaffected working-class voters in Pennsylvania, one of five Northeast states, including Delaware, that Trump swept on April 26 as he moved to secure the nomination.

Katie Nimon, a 22-year-old registered Democrat who waits tables at Otto's Kitchen & Cocktails, voted for Sen. Bernie Sanders in the primary but plans to cast her ballot for Trump if he faces likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. She criticized Clinton as a "manipulative liar."

The same solid support for Trump was heard in nearby Delaware, which, like Pennsylvania, hasn't voted for a Republican since George H.W. Bush won the White House in 1988. Donna Pusey, a 64-year-old barber and registered Democrat, vowed to vote for Trump in November, stating, "There's a lot of Trump support here because a lot of people are like me—sick and tired of the way things are."

Pusey sat out the Democratic primary, preferring to "rather get run over by a semi" than choose between Clinton and Sanders. She also criticized the treatment of Trump by GOP leaders as an "abomination."

"They're afraid he's going to stop a lot of cash flow into their pockets," she said.

Title: Bill Cosby Convicted of Sexual Assault: First Celebrity Conviction Since #MeToo Movement

Article:

In a landmark decision, comedian Bill Cosby was found guilty on Thursday of drugging and sexually assaulting Andrea Constand in 2004, marking the first such conviction of a celebrity since the #MeToo movement. The 80-year-old, best known for his role as the lovable father on the 1980s TV hit "The Cosby Show," faces up to 10 years in prison for each of three counts of aggravated indecent assault.

Following a three-week trial at the Montgomery County courthouse in Norristown, Pennsylvania, Cosby exploded in court when prosecutors asked the judge to take him into custody, stating, "He doesn't have a plane, you asshole!" After the verdict was read, Cosby looked down with a sad expression, while Lili Bernard, one of his accusers, began sobbing. Constand sat stone-faced.

Judge Steven O'Neill ruled that Cosby could remain out of jail on $1 million bail pending sentencing, as long as he surrendered his passport and remained at home. Cosby then left the courthouse with his lawyers and publicist, with defense lawyer Thomas Mesereau stating, "The fight will go on, and we will appeal the conviction." Sentencing is expected within 60 to 90 days, after Cosby submits to a "sexually violent predator assessment."

Although he could get up to 10 years for each count, state sentencing guidelines suggest a term of less than 10 years. The conviction marks the downfall of a man once celebrated as "America's Dad" but whose reputation was ruined after some 50 women accused him of similar offenses going back decades.

Cosby had been a transcendent figure in show business, coming up as a black comedian during the civil rights movement of the 1960s and winning over white audiences with a clean routine. He went on to several successful television series when African-Americans were largely absent from TV. In "The Cosby Show" from 1984 to 1992, he played the wise and witty Dr. Heathcliff Huxtable, the father of an affluent black family.

All the while, his accusers say, he had been drugging and molesting women. Only one of those cases was recent enough to be eligible for prosecution, that of Constand, a former administrator for the women's basketball team at Temple University, Cosby's alma mater. She had no comment after the verdict.

"The most important person in our team was Andrea Constand," District Attorney Kevin Steele told reporters. "She was the first courageous person who stood up in public and went to authorities and said, 'Bill Cosby drugged and raped me.'"

Attorney Gloria Allred, who represents 33 of the Cosby accusers, rejoiced that Cosby was found "guilty, guilty, guilty."

"We are so happy that finally we can say, women are believed, and not only on #MeToo, but in a court of law," Allred told reporters.

Other Cosby accusers celebrated the verdict with hugs, cries, and applause.

"I feel like my faith in humanity is restored," Bernard said.

The seven-man, five-woman jury reached a unanimous verdict after deliberating for 14 hours over two days. Less than a year ago, a different jury was deadlocked after six days of deliberations on the same charges, prompting the judge to declare a mistrial.

Soon after the first trial, a series of women leveled sexual assault and harassment accusations against men in media, entertainment, and politics, giving rise to the #MeToo and #TimesUp movements that encouraged women to go public with personal stories of abuse, in some cases after years of silence.

Like many of Cosby's other accusers, Constand said she was drugged and violated while unable to defend herself. Cosby has said any sexual encounters were consensual, and his lawyers portrayed the accusers as fabricating stories in search of wealth and fame.

"Mob rule is not due process," defense lawyer Kathleen Bliss said, referring to the #MeToo movement.

The verdict comes as the #MeToo movement continues to reshape the landscape of power dynamics in the entertainment industry and beyond, with high-profile figures such as U.S. President Donald Trump facing accusations of sexual misconduct. Trump, whose inauguration and first anniversary as president were met with nationwide women's protests, denies accusations of sexual misconduct and accuses rival Democrats and the media of a smear campaign. He faces a defamation lawsuit from Summer Zervos, a contestant on his former reality show who accuses him of sexually harassing her. Trump's lawyer has said her accusations are false and politically motivated.

Title: House Democrats' Support for Impeachment Inquiry: A Closer Look at the Semantics

Article:

The ongoing debate among House Democrats regarding an impeachment inquiry has been a topic of interest for many political analysts. A recent surge in the number of Democrats expressing support for an inquiry has led to the impression of a significant divide within the party. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals a more nuanced picture.

Reporters have noted a spike in the number of House Democrats supporting an impeachment inquiry, with 116 currently in favor, just short of a majority. This increase is significant, but the full story is more complex. It appears that those who do not support an inquiry are instead advocating for continuing the current investigations. In essence, these two positions amount to the same thing, as House lawyers admitted last week.

In the past, the House Judiciary Committee required special grants of power to move toward impeachment, making an inquiry a substantial step. However, this is no longer the case under current House rules and procedures. Officially opening an impeachment inquiry is, for the most part, a formality.

Therefore, all those lawmakers who say they oppose an inquiry are not preventing anything, and all those who have publicly supported an inquiry are not asking for anything that isn't already happening (aside from perhaps a symbolic vote).

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi is using this illusion of a dispute to her advantage. A formal vote in the full House might not set any wheels in motion, but it would increase the pressure to make a decision on impeachment one way or the other. Pelosi is right to avoid this pressure on behalf of her caucus. It is true that there appears to be plenty to investigate, so it is both in the party's interest to keep the inquiry going and the responsible thing to do.

However, actual articles of impeachment might not have the votes on the House floor, and a failed effort would likely be a victory for President Donald Trump. Even if Pelosi could whip enough votes to send impeachment to the Senate, it would be an extremely weak statement unless Democrats were unified. A bare majority in the House for impeachment would almost certainly produce a majority against removal in the Senate, with 53 Republicans united and the 47 Democrats quite possibly split.

By contrast, keeping the investigation going is good politics, and fighting the administration's stonewalling in court is the responsible thing to do. Maintaining the fiction that there is some significant tension over whether to move to an impeachment inquiry reduces the pressure to make a premature decision and gives House Democrats an opportunity to "vote" by declaring themselves for or against the inquiry itself.

In other words, the whole thing is a very useful fiction, harming no one. But there is no reason for the rest of us to go along with it.

This article is based on an opinion piece by Jonathan Bernstein, a political science professor and columnist for the Washington Post. Bernstein argues that the current debate among House Democrats over an impeachment inquiry is largely semantic, with those who do not support an inquiry advocating for continuing the current investigations. He suggests that the illusion of a dispute is useful for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, as it increases pressure to make a decision on impeachment while not significantly altering the ongoing investigations. Bernstein concludes that the whole debate is a useful fiction, harming no one.

Title: WannaCry Ransomware: Researchers Link Attack to North Korea's Lazarus Group

The global WannaCry ransomware attack, which affected over 150 countries, has been linked to the Lazarus Group, a hacking group known to have ties with North Korea, according to security experts. The connection was made by Google security researcher Neel Mehta, who identified similarities between WannaCry and malware used by Lazarus.

The Lazarus Group has been associated with the Sony Pictures hack of 2014 and the theft of millions of dollars from a Bangladeshi bank in 2016. After Mehta highlighted the code similarities, other researchers confirmed that WannaCry, also known as WannaCrypt, Wana Decryptor, or WCry, shared malware tools used by Lazarus.

While the connection is the most substantial public information about the cyberattack's origin, it is not enough to assign blame, as it is common to copy code. However, similarities in malware have been traced to earlier Lazarus attacks as far back as 2013, when South Korean media companies were targeted.

If validated, this would make the latest iteration of WannaCry the first nation-state-powered ransomware, according to Dubai-based security researcher Matt Suiche. This would also mean that a foreign hostile nation would have leveraged lost offensive capabilities from the Equation Group, a hacking group believed to be associated with the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA).

The identity of the attacker remains a mystery, but it is widely known that the WannaCry "exploit" used to take control of vulnerable Windows computers was stolen from the NSA. A rogue group published the malware online in April. After it was used, Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith called out the U.S. government for "stockpiling" vulnerabilities.

The WannaCry attack made headlines on Friday after it disrupted the U.K.'s health system and Spain's largest telecom. There were no signs that the attack sought to single out the U.S. or South Korea, despite its emergence at a time of high tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

Security firm Symantec has identified tools exclusively used by Lazarus on machines also infected with earlier versions of WannaCry, which could have been used to help spread the worm to vulnerable computers. The company adds that the shared code is based on a specific sequence of 75 ciphers, which to date have only been seen across Lazarus tools.

However, malware researcher Paul Burbage of Flashpoint, a business risk intelligence company, has not seen a solid connection between the ransomware and North Korea. "We compared the code samples between WannaCry and previous Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) activity, but the only similarities are public libraries," Burbage said. "Perhaps Symantec has more to go on than us at this point, but we are not seeing a DPRK link with the WannaCry worm campaign at this point."

The WannaCry cyberattack has affected over 300,000 computers, according to White House homeland security adviser Tom Bossert. He also stated that while U.S. investigators do not know who is responsible for WannaCry, there are clues to follow.

Title: Uncertainty Surrounds Cruz's Endorsement as GOP Unity Takes Center Stage at Republican National Convention

Article:

As the Republican National Convention in Cleveland approaches, one question remains unanswered: will Texas Senator Ted Cruz board the Trump train or remain a bitter rival? Cruz is set to deliver a prime-time address on Wednesday, with no indication yet that he plans to endorse the Republican nominee. It is believed that Cruz is positioning himself for a future presidential run, either in four or eight years.

While party unity was on display on Tuesday, Cruz's address could have an impact. He placed second in the delegate count during the nominating process and still has loyal supporters in the convention hall, some of whom disrupted proceedings on Monday. However, on Tuesday night, after Trump and his running mate Mike Pence were formally nominated, House Speaker Paul Ryan and other party leaders tried to bring the delegates and GOP voters together.

Paul Manafort, Trump's campaign manager, said their operations have been "talking back and forth" about Cruz's speech. Manafort said he planned to look at a draft soon and was comfortable that Cruz would talk about his vision for America. While party unity was the focus of many speeches, some speakers, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, focused heavily on Hillary Clinton.

Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, a former primary rival turned supporter, warned that the country "may never recover" from another Clinton presidency. Trump also addressed the convention via video message, saying, "This is a movement... but we have to go all the way." While party leaders called for unity, the focus on Clinton and her controversial actions and tactics remained a recurring theme throughout the convention.

Title: Trump Administration Considers Conservative and Libertarian-Minded Candidates for 5th Circuit Vacancies

Article:

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which covers federal districts in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas, is facing two vacancies. According to a report by Legal Times, the Trump administration is moving quickly to fill these positions and has shortlisted six candidates. The names being considered include Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett, U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor of Fort Worth, former Texas Solicitor General James Ho, Andy Oldham, a deputy general counsel to Gov. Greg Abbott, Michael Massengale, a justice on Houston's First Court of Appeals, and Brett Busby, a justice on Houston's Fourteenth Court of Appeals.

Two candidates on this list stand out.

The first is Texas Supreme Court Justice Don Willett, a prominent figure in conservative and libertarian legal circles who was also on Trump's list of potential U.S. Supreme Court nominees. Willett is best known for his concurring opinion in the 2015 case of Patel v. Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation. In this case, the Texas Supreme Court struck down a regulation requiring eyebrow threaders to obtain an occupational license before they could lawfully thread a piece of cotton string through their eyebrows. Willett's 49-page concurrence is a call to judicial arms in defense of economic liberty.

The second name on the 5th Circuit shortlist that stands out is former Texas Solicitor General James Ho. A former clerk to Justice Clarence Thomas, Ho is known for a 2006 law review article defending the constitutionality of birthright citizenship for the U.S.-born children of undocumented immigrant parents. This position is directly at odds with the stated views of Donald Trump, who has vowed to "end birthright citizenship."

An intriguing thought experiment arises: if Trump were to challenge his theory of birthright citizenship in the 5th Circuit, he might find himself in the courtroom of Trump-appointee Judge James Ho. The outcome of such a trial would be uncertain, but it would certainly make for an interesting legal debate.

Title: U.S. Stock Markets Rebound Amid Iran Tensions as Trump Announces No Casualties

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, U.S. equity markets surged on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all flirting with record highs, just hours after Iran launched a missile attack on two U.S. military bases in Iraq in response to the killing of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani. The unexpected resilience of the stock market, despite the escalating tensions between the U.S. and Iran, can be attributed to President Donald Trump's reassuring statements during an afternoon speech, where he stated that no American casualties were reported from the Iranian attack.

President Trump, flanked by top U.S. generals and Vice President Mike Pence, declared that all U.S. soldiers were safe, and only minimal damage was sustained at the military bases. He also noted that Iran appeared to be standing down, which he described as a good thing for all parties concerned and a very good thing for the world.

The less bellicose posture adopted by the president, who had previously warned that any action by Iran would be met harshly, helped to push the S&P 500 index, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and Nasdaq Composite to intraday records. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was on the verge of breaking a significant level at 29,000, and its own intraday record.

The calming words from Trump and Iranian officials, as well as the market's historical tendency to shake off or discount entirely military conflicts, contributed to the rebound. LPL Financial senior market strategist Ryan Detrick stated, "No doubt worries over Iran have investors on edge. Stocks could be volatile for a while, but the impact to stocks from geopolitical events historically has tended to be short-lived."

Indeed, the S&P 500 has declined 5% on average in 20 major geopolitical events dating back to the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941. However, the S&P 500 recovered those losses in fewer than 50 calendar days on average. The stunning assassination of President John F. Kennedy on Nov. 22, 1963, for example, led to a 2.8% decline in the S&P 500, which was recovered in a day. It took markets 307 sessions to rebound from the Pearl Harbor attacks in 1941, which resulted in a total decline of nearly 20%.

Crude-oil prices, however, took a hit as they fell back from an overnight spike. West Texas Intermediate crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange for February delivery fell $3.09, or 4.9%, to settle at $59.61 a barrel, after touching an intraday peak at $65.65, its highest level since April. Oil has been the biggest beneficiary of the rising tensions in the oil-rich Middle East, and some investors point to the strong gains oil has seen in the face of rising Mideast tensions as a reason for the strong pullback.

Title: Impact of the Proposed Tax Reform Bill on Individual Taxpayers: A Comprehensive Analysis

Article:

The recently proposed tax reform bill is set to bring about a significant shift in the tax landscape for individual taxpayers, with the effects varying based on income, location, and common tax deductions claimed.

The bill proposes a revised income tax bracket system. For married taxpayers filing jointly, earnings up to $90,000 will be taxed at 12%, while earnings up to $260,000 will fall in the 25% bracket, and earnings up to $1 million will be taxed at the 35% rate. For unmarried individuals and those filing separately, the bracket thresholds would be half of these amounts, except for the 35% bracket, which would be $200,000 for unmarried individuals. Those making up to $24,000 will pay no income tax.

The bill aims to boost the standard deduction for middle-class families, expanding it to $24,000 for married couples and $12,000 for individuals. The child tax credit is also set to increase to $1,600 from $1,000, with an additional $300 credit for each parent and non-child dependent. However, the child tax credit eligibility is tightened, a change that could affect about three million children in working families, including approximately 80% of those born in the United States.

The bill also introduces changes that will impact taxpayers differently. For instance, it repeals certain tax credits, such as the 15% credit for individuals aged 65 or over or retired on disability, a credit that currently allows up to $7,500 for a joint return, $5,000 for a single individual, or $3,750 for a married individual filing a joint return. The bill would entirely repeal this tax credit.

Other repealed provisions include the adoption tax credit, deductions for tax preparation, and credits for alimony payments. Deductions for moving expenses will also no longer be allowed.

One of the most contentious changes is the proposed modification to the popular mortgage interest deduction. Under the Republican plan, existing homeowners can keep the deduction, but future purchases will be capped at $500,000, down from the current $1 million limit.

This article aims to provide a neutral and factual overview of the proposed tax reform bill's impact on individual taxpayers. It is essential for taxpayers to understand these changes and consult with a tax professional to determine how the bill may affect their personal tax situation.

Title: FBI Decision Not to Pursue Criminal Charges Against Hillary Clinton in Email Investigation

Article:

FBI Director James Comey announced Tuesday that the bureau will not recommend to the Department of Justice that criminal charges be brought against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in connection with her use of a private email server for government business.

"Our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case," Comey said during a press conference.

Clinton's spokesman, Brian Fallon, issued a statement shortly after the announcement, saying, "We are pleased that the career officials handling this case have determined that no further action by the Department is appropriate."

"As the Secretary has long said, it was a mistake to use her personal email and she would not do it again," the statement continued. "We are glad that this matter is now resolved."

Following the announcement, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, Clinton's rival, took to Twitter to express his disapproval of the FBI's decision.

"FBI director said Crooked Hillary compromised our national security. No charges. Wow! #RiggedSystem," Trump tweeted.

Trump later issued two separate statements on the matter, including one that read, "Comey let Clinton off the hook... The fix was final. The Obama administration's anointed successor has had an indictment removed from her path and will now be able to glide to the rigged Democrat nomination."

Despite not recommending charges, Comey delivered a scathing rebuke of Clinton's actions, stating that the FBI found that 110 emails were sent or received on Clinton's server containing classified information. He added that it was possible that people hostile to the U.S. had gained access to her personal email account.

"Although we did not find clear evidence that Secretary Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate laws governing the handling of classified information, there is evidence that they were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive, highly classified information," Comey said.

Comey also revealed that seven email chains were classified at the "Top Secret/Special Access Program level" when they were sent and received on Clinton's server.

"There is evidence to support a conclusion that any reasonable person in Secretary Clinton's position, or in the position of those government employees with whom she was corresponding about these matters, should have known that an unclassified system was no place for that conversation," Comey said.

The FBI's decision removes what was arguably the biggest threat to Clinton's presidential campaign going forward – a criminal referral that could have led to an indictment – just weeks before her party's national convention in Philadelphia, where she is set to seal her nomination as the Democrat standard-bearer.

Clinton consistently downplayed the FBI investigation, even calling it a "security review," and as recently as June 3 said there was "absolutely no possibility" she'd be indicted. Weeks ago, a scathing State Department inspector general report directly countered her long-running claim that her personal email use was allowed, though her campaign continued to defend the candidate's actions.

In the wake of that report, Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, stepped up his criticism of Clinton's email actions and said she belongs in "jail."

The DOJ decision does not strip the email controversy as a campaign issue – Trump and the Republicans are sure to keep hammering it as the campaign lurches into full general election mode post-conventions – but shows the federal investigation did not determine the actions to be criminal, even if they were ill-advised and potentially damaging to national security.

House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, a Republican, said the decision not to prosecute Clinton defied explanation, adding, "No one should be above the law."

The decision comes more than a year after knowledge of Clinton's use of a personal email account and server first became public. Clinton responded at the time with a point-by-point written explanation and a press conference in which she said she had opted to use her personal server for "convenience."

However, critics said she was clearly circumventing government systems in order to try to shield her communications from public records requests, potentially putting sensitive and highly classified government secrets at risk in the process.

During a subsequent review, more than 2,000 emails on the server were found to have contained information now deemed classified, though they apparently were not marked classified when sent.

Title: Tennessee Governor Grants Clemency to Cyntoia Brown, Convicted Murderer Who Was Sentenced as a Juvenile

Article:

In a historic decision, Tennessee Governor Bill Haslam has granted clemency to Cyntoia Brown, a woman who was sentenced to life in prison for a murder committed when she was 16 years old. Brown, now 30, is set to be released on parole supervision on August 7, 2019, after serving almost 15 years behind bars.

Brown was tried as an adult and convicted in 2006 for the murder of a Nashville estate agent, Johnny Allen, following a sexual encounter that turned violent. Prosecutors argued that the crime was a robbery, while Brown maintained that she was a child sex-trafficking victim who acted in self-defense.

The case gained significant public attention, with celebrities such as singer Rihanna, reality TV personality Kim Kardashian West, comedian Amy Schumer, and NBA star LeBron James voicing their support. Brown's incarceration was the subject of the 2011 documentary "Me Facing Life: Cyntoia's Story."

According to the documentary, Brown was picked up in Nashville by Allen, who agreed to pay her $150 for sex and drove her to his home. However, she claimed that once at Allen's home, he groped her roughly and reached for a gun, prompting her to shoot him in self-defense. Prosecutors alleged that she killed the victim while he was sleeping and stole his money, guns, and truck before fleeing the scene. They claimed that she was motivated by greed, but her defense lawyers argued that she was afraid of returning home empty-handed to her violent pimp, who went by the nickname Kutthroat.

After entering a plea of self-defense, a jury found her guilty of first-degree premeditated murder, first-degree felony murder, and aggravated robbery.

In a statement on Monday, the state's Republican governor said he had ordered that Brown be released to parole supervision on August 7, 2019. "Cyntoia Brown committed, by her own admission, a horrific crime at the age of 16," the statement said. "Yet, imposing a life sentence on a juvenile that would require her to serve at least 51 years before even being eligible for parole consideration is too harsh, especially in light of the extraordinary steps Ms. Brown has taken to rebuild her life."

Nashville Mayor David Briley called the decision a "great day for social justice and our city." Brown, who has earned an associate degree while in prison, said she would do everything to justify Governor Haslam's faith in her. "I am thankful for all the support, prayers, and encouragement I have received," she said in a statement. "We truly serve a God of second chances and new beginnings."

After the announcement was made, Kim Kardashian West tweeted her thanks. Actresses Alyssa Milano and Sophia Bush were also among the celebrities voicing their support on Twitter. Stacey Abrams, who ran as the first black female nominee for governor in the US during the mid-term elections, said the victory belonged to Brown and the activists "who refused to concede injustice."

Title: Hillary Clinton Calls for Adult Summer Camps to Bridge Political Divide, Outlines 2016 Campaign Themes

Article:

In a speech to more than 3,000 camp professionals at the American Camp Association of New York and Jersey's annual Tri-State CAMP Conference in Atlantic City, New Jersey, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton emphasized the need for Americans to come together and bridge political differences. The former first lady, who is expected to launch her 2016 presidential campaign in April, steered clear of controversial issues and instead focused on the need for a pragmatic approach to a gridlocked Washington.
