Clinton opened her remarks by advocating for adult summer camps to help close the "serious fun deficit" in America and bridge political differences. She joked about the idea of adult campers in the "blue cabin" and "red cabin" having to "come together and actually listen to each other."

The former senator lamented the growth of political division and partisanship, pointing to changes in the media and campaign finance laws as culprits. She called out the Supreme Court's Citizens United decision and criticized the "insatiable pressure to raise money" as "crazy" and "no way to run a country."

Clinton also spoke about her advocacy for children, her book It Takes a Village, and praised camp professionals for teaching life skills to kids. She reiterated her call for universal pre-kindergarten education, portraying it as an economic and national security issue.

In a speech light on policy, Clinton also poked fun at former Vice President Al Gore, praising American ingenuity. "Yes, we did invent the Internet, and we did give it to the world," she said.

Clinton's team has been quietly assembling in advance of her expected April launch date, with staffers already working, formally or not. Unlike Republicans testing the waters for a 2016 bid, Clinton has no entity to raise money or pay staff. Most aides are volunteering their time until she formally declares her run.

A specific launch date remains uncertain, but a formal declaration sometime in April is all but assured. Despite all the planning, Clinton's team insists she has not made a final decision on a run. The moment Clinton says she's decided, she has to comply with more stringent campaign finance and disclosure regulations, so her team wants to wait until after April 1, which marks the start of a new financial quarter and clean slate for fundraising.

In a CNN/ORC poll, little has changed for Clinton in the wake of her personal email controversy, with Clinton leading Joe Biden in a potential Democratic field, 62 to 15 percent. Clinton's campaign themes for 2016 have been a pragmatic approach to getting things done in a gridlocked Washington and the need for Americans to come together. Her foil thus far has been congressional Republicans, whom she portrays as obstructionists.

Title: Trump Announces Intent to Participate in Fall Debates Despite Perceived Bias, Predicts AOC Challenge for Schumer, and Criticizes Bolton

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Donald Trump has announced his intention to participate in the fall debates, despite his past criticisms of the Commission on Presidential Debates. The president also made a prediction that Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York would challenge Senator Chuck Schumer in a Democratic primary, stating that she would "kick his ass."

Looking ahead to his speech on Tuesday night, the president hinted at the possibility of Rush Limbaugh, the conservative radio host who announced his advanced lung cancer on Monday, being in the audience. Trump added that he might award Limbaugh the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Tensions were palpable as the president expressed his displeasure about Speaker Nancy Pelosi sitting behind him and next to Vice President Mike Pence during the speech. "There’s one person behind me who’s going to be friendly and one who’s not going to be friendly," Trump said, according to those in the room.

The president spent a significant portion of his time criticizing John Bolton, whose unpublished book confirms a central allegation of the impeachment charges by reporting that the president conditioned security aid to Ukraine on its willingness to announce political investigations of former Vice President Joe Biden Jr. and other Democrats. "He turned on me," Trump said of Bolton.

The Iowa debacle unfolded as Gallup reported that Trump's approval rating had climbed to 49 percent, its highest in that survey since his presidency began. Despite polls showing that most Americans want the Senate to call witnesses, the impeachment trial is set to end Wednesday with an assured acquittal. It is possible, though not certain, that one or more Democratic senators will vote with Trump.

Matt Schlapp, the chairman of the American Conservative Union, commented on the situation, stating, "What other people would look at as a moment of completely political meltdown for this president, it all appears to accrue to his benefit. He actually looks like the adult in the room."

Moreover, Schlapp suggested that the delayed count in Iowa would sow discord and suspicion within Democratic ranks. "The problem for the Democrats is it will make people think and assume the fix is in again because they don’t like who is leading," he said.

Title: Trump's Pardons Under Scrutiny: A Look at the Controversial Use of Presidential Power

Article:

In a move that has once again brought the presidential power of pardon under scrutiny, President Donald Trump announced on Thursday the pardon of conservative commentator Dinesh D’Souza. This decision follows recent pardons for the late heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson and Lewis "Scooter" Libby, a former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney during the George W. Bush administration.

D’Souza, who pleaded guilty to making illegal campaign contributions, had been sentenced in September 2014. His claims of a politically-motivated prosecution by the Obama-era Department of Justice (DOJ) were dismissed by the judge at his sentencing hearing as "all hat, no cattle."

In addition to D’Souza and Libby, Trump also pardoned Joe Arpaio, the former sheriff of Maricopa County, Arizona, in August 2017. Arpaio, known for his hardline stance on immigration, was convicted of criminal contempt of court for ignoring a judge's orders to stop detaining migrants who were not suspected of a crime.

The political nature of some of Trump’s pardons has raised concerns among his critics, particularly in light of his criticisms of the DOJ, FBI, and special counsel Robert Mueller. Lisa Gilbert of Public Citizen, a not-for-profit watchdog group, expressed her worries, stating, "Trump’s feeling that people who say the right things or show some kind of loyalty or play on his team should be pardoned is completely antithetical to how our justice system works."

Comparing Trump’s pardons to those of other recent presidents, Grant Reeher, a professor of political science at Syracuse University, noted that Trump’s pardons appear "more politically oriented." He added that Trump is focusing on people whose political actions are consistent with his own, in that they have been advancing points of view that he shares or working toward his goals.

Defenders of the president argue that he is not unusual in this regard. They point to President Clinton's controversial pardon of Marc Rich, a fugitive financier whose ex-wife, Denise Rich, was a major fundraiser for the Democratic Party. Trump backers also note that, when asked about the pardon of D’Souza by reporters on Thursday, the president indicated he had also been considering pardons for businesswoman Martha Stewart and Rod Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois.

The other question that has dogged Trump’s pardons is whether he is seeking to send a signal to erstwhile aides who are now feeling the heat from Mueller’s investigation into allegations of collusion with Russia. Some in liberal circles theorize that Trump is displaying his willingness to issue pardons so that people who might otherwise feel pressure to cut a deal and cooperate with Mueller might be less inclined to do so. However, there is no hard evidence to support this theory.

Observers across the political spectrum have raised the issue of whether Trump might have a bias in favor of celebrities or celebrity-backed causes over more anonymous figures. The Jack Johnson pardon was prominently backed by actor and director Sylvester Stallone. Trump told reporters on Thursday that he did not know D’Souza personally but "I read the papers, I see him on television."

The pardon of D’Souza came the day after Trump received an Oval Office visit from Kim Kardashian. In addition to advocating for the broader cause of prison reform, Kardashian is seeking a pardon for Alice Marie Johnson, a 63-year-old woman serving a life sentence for drug offenses.

"The narrative may build that he’s only focused on famous people," said Republican strategist Matt Mackowiak. "Often, famous people have the best legal defense money can buy, and others don’t have that opportunity."

White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley pushed back on suggestions that the president was mostly focused on celebrity pardons when he spoke to reporters on board Air Force One on Thursday. "Look, there are plenty of people the president is looking at right now under the pardon process," Gidley said.

However, the fact that Trump had tended to issue pardons without going through the usual process of review at the DOJ concerns some skeptics. While they acknowledge that a president has expansive power to pardon, they worry about Trump’s propensity to flout norms.

"There is a process set up for pardoning people and he is ignoring it," Gilbert said. "I am not saying he is running afoul of the Constitution. But this is off-the-cuff, and he is doing things that a DOJ that he is simultaneously attacking might not be that into."

Meanwhile, the reverberations from the decision to pardon D’Souza will continue to be felt. Late Thursday, the lead prosecutor in his case, Carrie H. Cohen, released a statement plainly critical of Trump's decision. The debate over the presidential power of pardon will likely continue to be a contentious issue throughout Trump's presidency.

Title: Analysis: Pennsylvania Special Election Results Signal Trouble for GOP in November Midterms

Article:

The results of the special election in Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional District, where Democrat Conor Lamb has likely won by a thin margin, have sent shockwaves through the Republican Party. With a possible recount pending, the GOP is grappling with the implications of this unexpected loss in a traditionally Republican district. Here are the top three lessons that can be drawn from Tuesday's election:

1. The GOP should brace for a challenging November: The historical trend of midterm elections working against the president's party, the president's low approval rating, and the intensity gap between the two parties are all factors that should concern the GOP. In the 2018 midterms, Democrats need to net 24 seats to regain control of the House. Pennsylvania-18, a district that was considered safe for the GOP, was a close race, indicating that the opposition party has a strong chance of putting many seats in play.

2. Candidates matter: The underwhelming performance of Republican candidate Rick Saccone, who was not a strong campaigner, fundraiser, or grassroots favorite, played a significant role in the loss. Democrat Conor Lamb, on the other hand, ran a strong campaign, with a robust fundraising operation and impressive retail politics skills. His moderate stance on social issues, such as his opposition to an assault weapons ban, helped him neutralize the Pelosi Factor, a key element of the GOP's strategy against him.

3. More Democrats will try to neutralize the Pelosi Factor: The Lamb campaign's decision to publicly oppose Nancy Pelosi as Democratic leader was successful in distancing him from the unpopular San Francisco liberal. More Democrats in purple-to-red districts will likely follow suit, as the inability to take a clean hit at Pelosi hurt Republicans in PA-18.

In conclusion, the Pennsylvania special election results suggest that the GOP should be concerned about the upcoming midterms. The Democrats' ability to run a strong candidate and neutralize the Pelosi Factor in a traditionally Republican district is a worrying sign for the GOP, especially considering the historical trend of midterm elections and the president's low approval rating. The election also underscores the importance of candidates in shaping the political landscape and the potential impact of the Pelosi Factor in certain districts.

Title: House Republican Announces Imminent Release of Alleged Surveillance Abuse Memo

Article:

In a significant development, a House Republican has announced that the release of a secret memo detailing alleged government surveillance abuses is imminent. Rep. Dave Joyce (R-Ohio) stated Saturday that the House Intelligence Committee plans to begin the release process soon, if not immediately.

The release process could take up to 19 congressional working days, according to Rep. Joyce. This means the earliest the document could be released is sometime in mid-March, as per the House's 2018 calendar. A meeting has reportedly taken place to discuss the memo's potential public release, according to a source confirmed to the Washington Examiner.

The memo, which broke last week, has been a top story behind the impending government shutdown. House members who have viewed the highly classified Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court document allege it provides evidence of unlawful surveillance of the Trump campaign and transition by the Obama administration, a claim that former administration officials have long denied.

Numerous GOP congressmen have demanded the memo's release, with some suggesting it could lead to the end of special counsel Robert Mueller's Trump-Russia investigation and to the dismissal of senior FBI and CIA officials. Led by Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.), 65 GOP lawmakers wrote to House Intelligence Committee chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) on Friday demanding the memo's release.

Gaetz, speaking on Fox News Saturday, said the memo will "shock the conscience of this country." He stated, "There are four pages of a memorandum prepared by the intelligence committee that will shock the conscience of this country when it comes to the horrific abuses that occurred during the last administration and that I believe continue to pose a threat to Donald Trump’s presidency."

The memo, containing highly classified information, must be reviewed by federal records reviewers and must receive multiple levels of approval before it can be released. On Thursday, Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) explained on Fox News that the document's release would first need approval from the House Intelligence Committee and then President Donald Trump would have to give it the green light.

Title: John Conyers and Nancy Pelosi's Strategy Under Scrutiny: A Call for Fair and Equal Application of Rules

Article:

In a recent interview on NBC's Meet the Press, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi found herself in a precarious position when she advocated for "due process" for Representative John Conyers, who is facing a series of allegations of improper conduct. This stance has sparked criticism from both sides of the political spectrum, raising questions about the application of rules and the concept of fairness in politics.

Pelosi's defense of Conyers, as well as Senator Al Franken who has also been accused of sexual misconduct, has been seen as a partisan double standard by many. While she insists on due process for Conyers, Pelosi has labeled Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore as a "child molester." This inconsistency has been a source of frustration for many, particularly among Republicans who believe that the political establishment protects its own.

The backlash against Pelosi's stance is not limited to the political sphere. Her support for Conyers and Franken, as well as her opposition to Education Secretary Betsy DeVos's reforms to Title IX regulations, has been criticized as a selective application of standards of conduct. These criticisms highlight the anger and mistrust felt by many who believe that the rules are not applied fairly and equally, but rather used strategically to delegitimize and destroy political enemies while exempting the powerful.

In this context, it is worth considering the philosophical concept of the "original position" proposed by philosopher John Rawls. This thought experiment imagines individuals in a state of limbo, hidden behind a "veil of ignorance," unaware of their future identity. The goal is to imagine what fair and just rules for society would look like if one did not know their own identity, such as gender, race, or socio-economic status.

The original position is a useful tool for thinking about fairness and equality in society. In a time marked by tribalism and identity politics, it serves as a reminder that neutral rules should be applied fairly and equally to all, regardless of tribal identity. The current political climate, marked by partisanship and selective application of rules, underscores the need for a return to this fundamental principle of classical liberalism.

In conclusion, the cases of John Conyers and Nancy Pelosi highlight the need for a more nuanced and fair approach to allegations of misconduct. The application of rules should be based on the principles of fairness and equality, as envisioned by the original position, rather than on tribal identity or partisan interests. This is not a call for leniency, but rather a call for a more thoughtful and consistent approach to the application of rules in politics.

Title: Obama Urges House Republicans to End Government Shutdown, Warns of Potential Economic Consequences

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing federal government shutdown, President Obama on Saturday called on House Republicans to immediately pass a "clean" spending bill to reopen the government. In his weekly radio and internet address, the President read two letters from Americans affected by the shutdown, highlighting the real-world consequences of the impasse in Washington.

The President recounted the story of an Alabama woman whose Head Start agency was forced to close its doors on Tuesday, and a North Dakota family in danger of losing their federal home loan due to the government shutdown. These anecdotes are part of the President's strategy to pressure Congress to take action.

"There's only one way out of this reckless and damaging shutdown: pass a budget that funds our government, with no partisan strings attached," Obama said. "There are enough Republican and Democratic votes in the House of Representatives... to end this shutdown immediately. But the far right of the Republican party won't let Speaker John Boehner give that bill a yes-or-no vote."

The White House has been increasingly trying to drive a wedge between House Republicans, pitting moderate members against their tea party counterparts. The administration maintains that a "clean" spending bill, one that doesn't include measures to repeal, delay, or defund Obamacare, could pass the House with bipartisan support.

However, Speaker Boehner has yet to allow such a bill to come up for a vote. As the speaker and his Democratic counterparts search for a way out of the crisis - the first federal government shutdown in 17 years - Obama continues to ramp up his rhetoric.

"The American people don't get to demand ransom in exchange for doing their job. Neither does Congress," Obama said. "They don't get to hold our democracy or our economy hostage over a settled law. They don't get to kick a child out of Head Start if I don't agree to take her parents' health insurance away. That's not how our democracy is supposed to work."

With the shutdown ongoing, Obama also looks several weeks down the road, to when the U.S. is expected to hit its "debt ceiling." Analysts say the nation will reach its debt limit sometime in late October or early November, and the administration is warning that the economic damage from a default will be much worse than the current shutdown.

"For as reckless as a government shutdown is, an economic shutdown that comes with default would be dramatically worse," Obama said.

Title: Diverse Interpretations of Martin Luther King Jr.'s Legacy on the 50th Anniversary of His March on Washington

Article:

As the nation commemorates the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s historic march on Washington, various groups across the political spectrum are seizing the opportunity to advocate for their respective causes, despite the tenuous connection to King's original mission of fighting racial injustice.

From gun control activists protesting Florida's'stand your ground' laws, to advocates for D.C. statehood, the Republican National Committee, and even Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban, everyone seems to want a piece of the King action. The anniversary events, which began on Saturday with a march retracing the 1963 route and continue Wednesday with speeches at the Lincoln Memorial, have sparked a range of activities, from political discussions to entertainment auditions.

Martin Luther King III, the civil rights leader's oldest living child, is not concerned that the events dilute his father's core message. Instead, he aims to "arouse a new coalition of conscience" that can counter the energy of the tea party movement. King III attributes the recent Supreme Court ruling dismantling a key part of the Voting Rights Act, the Trayvon Martin shooting, and rising income inequality as reasons for communities of color to continue protesting and lobbying Congress for action.

However, the run-up to the anniversary has exposed disagreement over what continuing the movement means. Alveda King, Martin Luther King Jr.'s niece, worries that tying specific social causes to her uncle diminishes his overarching significance. She emphasizes that her uncle was "an imperfect human who served a perfect God" and wants the celebrations to focus on a unifying message of love.

One of the most contentious debates revolves around whether King would have embraced gay marriage as the next frontier for civil rights. The gay community has closely aligned itself with the tributes, with multiple events honoring the late Bayard Rustin, who helped organize the 1963 march and was openly gay. A coalition of over 40 groups signed an open letter calling for "clear federal laws barring discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity."

President Barack Obama endorsed gay marriage last year, and the NAACP followed suit shortly after. However, many African-Americans still oppose gay marriage. Grammy-winning gospel singer Donnie McClurkin was uninvited from a concert at the King Memorial after a few activists complained about his past comments regarding homosexuality. McClurkin described the situation as "bullying...discrimination...intolerance," and a civil rights infringement.

Despite the disagreements, the anniversary events serve as a reminder of the enduring impact of Martin Luther King Jr.'s message and the ongoing struggle for civil rights and social justice in America.

Title: Analysis: Bernie Sanders' Millionaire Status and the Fox News Town Hall

Article:

In a recent Fox News town hall, Senator Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, addressed concerns about his millionaire status and the potency of his political ideas. The event was hailed as a success by his supporters, who argue that Sanders' wealth does not diminish the validity of his policy proposals.

Sanders' argument against the accumulation of wealth in the hands of a small elite is rooted in the disproportionate political power wielded by the super-rich. He contends that the wealthy class, through funding campaigns and lobbying politicians, exerts undue influence on the political landscape. Sanders' campaign, which is funded by small donors, seems to contradict this critique, as he has not amassed his wealth through such means.

The issue of wealth and politics is further complicated by the question of how politicians and ex-politicians capitalize on their fame. Speaking engagements at big Wall Street banks, for example, are often criticized for potential corruption, as bankers may be paying for access to future political leaders rather than for the content of the speeches.

Some argue that Sanders' wealth does not make him a hypocrite, as he may genuinely hold socialist views that reject the notion of charity. However, others question why someone with millions of dollars would not use their wealth to improve the lives of many, rather than hoard it.

The Fox News town hall was praised for Sanders' ability to rally a majority of Americans, offering a clear contrast to President Trump's right-wing populism. The event served as a reminder of Sanders' ability to unite those struggling for a better life across the country.

Meanwhile, the impeachment inquiry into President Trump has taken a new turn, with the release of a summary of a call between Trump and Ukraine's president. The call is said to reveal Trump's pursuit of unsubstantiated conspiracy theories, potential quid pro quo arrangements, and the use of the U.S. government in his personal political schemes.

Trump's defenders argue that the evidence is circumstantial, but experts contend that such evidence is not weak. They point out that circumstantial evidence can be strong, as it is based on the circumstances in which an act of wrongdoing is committed. The focus of the impeachment investigation will now shift to the context and circumstances surrounding the call, with enough evidence present to support impeachment proceedings.

The outcome of the impeachment process remains uncertain, but the events surrounding both Sanders' wealth and the Trump-Ukraine call have sparked significant debate and political intrigue.

Title: East Coast Storm Disrupts Political Campaigns as Hurricane Sandy Approaches

Article:

As Hurricane Sandy, a potentially devastating storm, approaches the East Coast, political campaigns are canceling events and making contingency plans to ensure voting machines remain operational. The unpredictable nature of the storm has left even seasoned politicos uncertain about its impact on the final week of the campaign.

President Barack Obama, in a show of leadership, has canceled his campaign trips to Florida and Colorado to monitor the situation from the White House. Former Republican presidential candidate and ex-House Speaker Newt Gingrich found this interesting, commenting that the president canceled his trips over the hurricane but not over the Benghazi issue.

Both the president and Republican presidential contender Mitt Romney have canceled appearances in the weather-threatened swing state of Virginia to avoid consuming resources and interfering with storm preparations. Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell is making plans to prioritize power restoration for polling stations, moving them up to the same level as hospitals and police stations.

In states where polls are already open, such as Maryland, early voting has been canceled for Monday. The uncertainty surrounding the election stumps has master politicos concerned, with David Axelrod, Obama's senior adviser, stating, "Obviously we want unfettered access to the polls because we believe that the more people come out, the better we'll do, and so to the extent that it makes it harder, you know, that's a source of concern."

The Romney-Ryan ticket, not in power, can do little but pay attention. Romney expressed his concern for those in the path of the storm, stating, "Our thoughts and prayers are with the people who will find themselves in harm's way." The Romney campaign has stopped fundraising e-mails in affected states, made a campaign bus available for relief efforts, started taking up collections in campaign offices, and set up a blog with weather-related advice.

The Romney campaign's optics are tricky, with a top Republican noting that the schedule may change depending on the storm's path. Mixing politics and weather is to double-down on the unknown, a situation that could make campaigning anywhere difficult.

Title: "Barnum's Animals Crackers Unveil New Packaging, Reflecting a Shift in Cultural Perception Towards Animal Welfare"

Article:

In a significant move reflecting the evolving societal attitudes towards animal welfare, the iconic Barnum's Animals crackers have undergone a redesign, with the animals now depicted in a natural habitat rather than confined within a circus boxcar.

For over a century, the animal cracker packaging has portrayed the mighty beasts in cages, a depiction that Mondelez International, Nabisco's parent company, felt was due for an update. Kimberly Fontes, a spokeswoman for Mondelez, stated, "To continue to make the brand relevant for years to come, we felt this was the right time for the next evolution in our design, now showing the animals in a natural habitat."

The new design features the animals standing shoulder to shoulder, proudly walking in the wild. The packaging proclaims, "NEW LOOK, Same Great Taste!" The redesign follows pressure from animal rights groups, including People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA), who have long opposed the use of animals in circuses.

Last year, Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus announced its closure after nearly 150 years due to pressure from animal rights groups and declining ticket sales. In 2015, the circus made the decision to stop using elephants in its shows, one of the reasons the company believed attendance was dropping.

PETA has hailed the new box design as a symbol of a cultural shift. "Big victories can come in small packages," PETA said in a statement, "and no matter where we look, we find new evidence that people are embracing compassion for animals like never before." PETA participated in discussions with the company about the redesign.

"The new box for Barnum's Animals perfectly reflects that our society no longer tolerates caging and chaining exotic animals for circus shows," PETA added. "No living being exists simply to be a spectacle or to perform tricks for human entertainment, yet all circuses and traveling shows that use animals treat them as mere props, denying them everything that's natural and important to them."

Mondelez has previously used its classic design to raise awareness about animal and environmental issues, as evidenced by limited-time special editions. The company notes that it continues to evolve its design to drive awareness and promote positive change.

Title: House Rules Committee Finds Speaker Pelosi's Remarks Violate House Rules, but Remarks Remain in Official Record

The House of Representatives ruled Tuesday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi's criticism of President Trump violated the chamber's rules, but members voted to keep her words in the official record. The House also allowed Pelosi to continue debating on the House floor.

Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer took over the gavel to announce Pelosi's violation of the rules. "The words used by the gentlewoman from California contained an accusation of racist behavior on the part of the president," Mr. Hoyer said. "The words should not be used in debate."

Pelosi, the top-ranking House Democrat, had previously called President Trump's comments about four freshman congresswomen – Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts, and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan – "divisive and dangerous" to the country.

"Every single member of this institution, Democratic and Republican, should join us in condemning the president's racist tweets," she said. "To do anything less would be a shocking rejection of our values and a shameful abdication of our oath of office to protect the American people."

House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy argued that Pelosi could have just taken back her words and apologized. "What we just saw was a very sad day in this House – probably a historic day – so the very person who is supposed to uphold the rules broke the rules of the House," the California Republican told reporters.

Following the vote, Pelosi told reporters that she stood by her statement. "I'm proud of the attention that is being called to it because what the president said was completely inappropriate against our colleagues, but not just against them, but against so many people in our country to say, 'Go back where you came from,'" the California Democrat said.

The rules, which trace back to Thomas Jefferson's writings, allow members to criticize the government or the president on the House floor in an official capacity, but they are prohibited from using language that is "personally offensive" to the president. On the matter of racial rhetoric, Jefferson's Manual explicitly states that any reference to "racial or other discrimination on the Part of the President" is not allowed.

According to the Congressional Research Service, Pelosi could be punished by being barred from speaking on the floor for the rest of the day. Several other warnings about this rule, which also extends to other members of Congress, had to be issued throughout the debate.

However, earlier Tuesday, Mr. Hoyer argued that the resolution itself wouldn't cross any lines because the criticism was aimed at tweets, not the president. "We're condemning the language that was used, not the president himself," he said.

Rep. Emanuel Cleaver, who was serving as chairman, stepped down out of frustration. "Unfairness is not enough because we want to just fight," the Missouri Democrat said before dropping the gavel. Mr. Cleaver continued to express his frustration with reporters after the vote, saying he was trying to be fair and not escalate complaints from either side of the aisle.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul to Attend White House Meeting on Promise Zones Initiative, Despite Political Differences with President Obama

Article:

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), a known critic of President Obama, is among a bipartisan group of senators expected to attend the president's announcement on Thursday regarding the designation of "Promise Zones" to aid communities in addressing poverty. Paul is also expected to join Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell and other lawmakers in a private meeting with the president at the White House prior to the announcement, an aide for Paul confirmed to Fox News.

Though Paul's presence may seem unexpected, the conservative senator recently introduced separate legislation to establish "economic freedom zones" in struggling cities like Detroit, where taxes and bureaucratic hurdles would be reduced to foster growth. In response to the announcement, Paul told Fox News, "They say the sincerest form of flattery is imitation," confirming his attendance at the White House on Thursday. However, he questioned why the president's plan does not include Detroit, as his does.

President Obama's announcement is part of a focus on income inequality in the lead-up to his State of the Union address. Promise Zones are areas where the federal government offers tax incentives and grants. Obama first announced the initiative during last year's State of the Union speech.

The White House will announce an eight-county region of southeastern Kentucky, among five locations, as "Promise Zones" this week. The proposed zones also include San Antonio, Texas; Philadelphia; Los Angeles; and the Choctaw Nation of Oklahoma.

The invitation to Paul could signal another Obama "charm offensive" to engage with Republicans, as he did early in 2013 in an attempt -- unsuccessfully -- to achieve a "grand bargain" budget deal. Paul, who has recently filed a class-action lawsuit against the administration over the National Security Agency's spying practices and has pressed Obama on various issues, including a filibuster over his drone policy, may prove an elusive legislative partner.

Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said in a statement Wednesday that he was pleased the Obama administration decided to include Eastern Kentucky in its promise zone designation. "I wrote a letter last year supporting this designation because this region has suffered enormous economic hardship over the last several years," McConnell said. "Thousands of jobs have been lost, and economic opportunity is extremely limited, particularly because of this administration's hostile policies toward the coal industry."

Title: Trump's Tacit Support of White Supremacy: A Closer Look at the President's Record Amid Rising Far-Right Attacks

Article:

In the aftermath of the horrific Christchurch mosque shootings in New Zealand, where a gunman killed 50 Muslims, a reporter at the White House asked President Donald Trump if he believed that white nationalism was a growing threat around the world. Trump responded, "I don't, really. I think it's a small group of people."

This response came on the same day that White House adviser Kellyanne Conway dismissed the alleged shooter's murderous racism, instead labeling him an "eco-terrorist." Two days later, the acting White House chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, appeared on Fox News Sunday, where he was asked if the president had considered giving a major speech condemning anti-Muslim, white supremacist bigotry. Mulvaney responded, "The president is not a white supremacist."

However, Trump's record speaks louder than any of their words. While the president may try to evade the issue, the fact remains that a dangerous and global white supremacy is on the march, and Trump himself is at least partly to blame.

One example of this can be seen in the January 2017 mosque shooting in Quebec City, where a man stormed a mosque and shot six people dead while they prayed. The man was an ardent Trump supporter, and the New Zealand shooter scrawled the Quebec City shooter's name on one of his ammunition cartridges. The New Zealand shooter also directly applauded Trump in his own manifesto.

According to the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), far-right attacks in Europe have jumped 43% between 2016 and 2017. On the domestic front, the rise is even more disturbing. According to CSIS, the number of terrorist attacks by far-right perpetrators in the United States more than quadrupled between 2016 and 2017.

The intimate connections between the president and white nationalists are well known. In 2017, the president refused to condemn the white nationalists who marched through the streets of Charlottesville, Virginia, screaming such disgusting nonsense as "Jews will not replace us." Heather Heyer, a counter-protester, was also killed during the rally. Days later, the president defended the marchers and claimed that there were "some very fine people on both sides" of that rally.

The president's words and actions have emboldened a dangerous and racist fringe, leading to a rise in hate crimes across the country. Nationwide, hate crimes rose by 17% in 2017, according to FBI statistics, the third year in a row to see an uptick.

The president's words and actions set the national tone for what is permissible speech and impermissible speech in the political arena. Trump, on the other hand, merely revels in the impermissible. Before the dead Muslim worshipers in Christchurch had even been collected and buried, the president was tweeting that Fox News should reinstate Jeanine Pirro, who had been suspended from the network for her despicable anti-Muslim comments directed at Representative Ilhan Omar.

In conclusion, Trump's record speaks for itself. While he may not be criminally responsible for the acts of white supremacists, he is politically responsible, and understanding that distinction will be the first step to rejuvenating our politics.

Title: Four Killed, Including Shooter, in Gilroy Garlic Festival Shooting; 12 Injured

A tragic shooting incident occurred at the annual Gilroy Garlic Festival in Christmas Hill Park, Gilroy, California, on Sunday, resulting in four fatalities and at least 12 injuries.

The Gilroy Police Department confirmed that one suspect, identified as Santino William Legan, 19, was shot and killed by police at the scene. Reports suggest that there may have been a second suspect, though the search for this individual is ongoing, and it remains unclear if they were involved in the shooting.

The gunman used an assault-style rifle and began firing around 5:41 pm local time. Witnesses described the shooter as wearing Army fatigues and indiscriminately firing rounds. The police engaged the shooter within one minute, as stated by Gilroy Police Chief Scot Smithee, and the suspect was shot dead.

Security at the event was tight, with bag searches and metal detector wands in place. However, investigators believe the shooter entered the festival by cutting through a perimeter fence. Festivalgoers fled in panic, and shots rang out. Videos of the chaotic scene were posted to Twitter.

One of the victims was a 6-year-old boy named Stephen Romero. Two other victims were a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s. Their names have not yet been released.

A witness who had a brief interaction with the shooter reported that they asked him, "Why are you doing this?" The Associated Press reports that the shooter replied by saying, "Because I'm really angry."

Heavy tracked down an Instagram page that is believed to belong to the shooter. One post from the Instagram page, posted just before the shooting, reportedly promotes racist and misogynistic principles.

The Gilroy Garlic Festival is an annual event that attracts thousands of people and is known for its garlic-themed food, music, and activities. The city of Gilroy, located about 33 miles south of San Jose, issued a statement expressing their condolences and gratitude to the first responders. The investigation into the shooting is ongoing.

Title: Trump's Decision to Withdraw U.S. Troops from Syria Leaves Turkey in a Delicate Position

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Donald Trump's decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria has left Turkey scrambling to respond to the changing battlefield on its southern border. The unexpected move, made during a phone call with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan two weeks ago, has reshaped U.S. policy in the Middle East, abandoning a quarter of Syrian territory and handing Ankara the job of finishing off Islamic State in Syria.

According to U.S. officials, Trump was initially expected to deliver a standard warning to Erdogan over his plan to launch a cross-border attack targeting U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in northeast Syria. Instead, in the course of the conversation, Trump reshaped U.S. policy, abandoning a quarter of Syrian territory and handing Ankara the job of finishing off Islamic State in Syria.

"Trump asked, 'If we withdraw our soldiers, can you clean up ISIS?'" a Turkish official told Reuters. Erdogan replied that Turkish forces were up to the task. "Then you do it," Trump told him abruptly. To his national security adviser John Bolton, also on the call, Trump said, "Start work for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria."

The decision was a shock in Washington, where senior administration officials, including Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, tried for days to change the president's mind. When Trump made clear he would not back down, Mattis and a senior official coordinating the fight against Islamic State, Brett McGurk, both resigned.

On a visit to a U.S. airbase in Iraq this week, Trump said that military commanders had repeatedly requested extensions for the 2,000 U.S. troops in Syria - requests that he finally turned down because he said Islamic State was largely beaten.

Ankara has complained bitterly for years that the United States, a NATO ally, had chosen the Kurdish YPG militia as its main partner on the ground in Syria against Islamic State. Turkey says the YPG is a terrorist group, inseparable from the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) which has waged an insurgency in southeast Turkey in which 40,000 people have been killed.

The U.S. withdrawal potentially frees Turkey's military to push the YPG back from 500 km of border without risking a confrontation with American forces. It also removes a main cause of this year's diplomatic crisis between the two countries. However, it also opens up an area of Syria far larger than anything Turkey had expected to fill, potentially pitting it against not just Kurdish forces but also the Damascus government - which is committed to regaining control of all of Syria - and its Russian and Iranian backers.

The YPG on Friday asked the Syrian government to take over the town of Manbij, which the Kurdish militia currently controls with U.S. support, to protect it from Turkish attack. If Turkish forces are to take on Islamic State in its last pocket of Syrian territory near the Iraqi border, they would first have to cross 250 km of territory controlled by the Kurdish-dominated Syrian Democratic Forces.

"Erdogan got more than he bargained for," said Soner Cagaptay, Director of the Turkish Program at the Washington Institute. "He had asked the U.S. to drop the YPG, but not withdraw from Syria."

As it takes stock of the new challenge, Turkey is launching intensive talks with Washington and Moscow. Ankara expects U.S. military officials to visit within days, as well as Bolton and possibly the U.S. special Syria envoy, James Jeffrey. Turkey's intelligence chief and defense and foreign ministers are also due in Moscow on Saturday, the spokesman for Erdogan's AK Party said.

"Of course, it will be difficult. The whole issue needs to be planned again from the start," a Turkish security official said.

A U.S. official said military planners were drafting plans that could see a withdrawal over the course of several months. One of the proposals under consideration is a 120-day withdrawal period, according to a person familiar with discussions.

Washington is also grappling with what to do with weapons it provided to the YPG militia and promised to take back after the campaign against Islamic State ended. Turkey says the weapons must be collected so they are not used against Turkish troops, but U.S. officials say they cannot disarm their own allies when the fight is not yet over.

Erdogan announced last week that Turkey is postponing its planned military operation against the YPG in light of Trump's decision. The Turkish military has already carried out two incursions into northern Syria, backed by pro-Turkey Syrian rebels. In 2016, they targeted Islamic State and Kurdish fighters, and earlier this year took control of the YPG-held Afrin region. However, Ankara and its Syrian rebel allies alone do not have the capacity to take over the whole region which the United States is abandoning. Turkey's priority, therefore, may be to secure its southern frontier.

"Distancing the YPG from the border and wiping out these elements is of critical importance," the security official said. He stressed the need for careful coordination over who should fill other areas which departing U.S. forces will leave, and warned of problems ahead if agreement could not be reached.

"Is it a big victory for Turkey?" another official said. "I'm not sure right now."

Title: Congressional Shooting: House Majority Whip Steve Scalise Remains in Critical Condition

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, House Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-LA) remains in critical condition following a shooting incident at a congressional baseball practice in Alexandria, Virginia, on Wednesday morning. The shooting, which also left four others injured, took place during a practice session for an annual charity baseball game between Democratic and Republican lawmakers.

The attack occurred near Eugene Simpson Stadium Park, with the game scheduled for Thursday evening. Scalise, the third-highest-ranking House Republican, was admitted to MedStar Washington Hospital Center in critical condition on Wednesday, with doctors stating he arrived "at imminent risk of death." He underwent surgery on Wednesday, with further surgeries required in the future.

As of Friday afternoon, Scalise remains in intensive care, with his condition described as "critical" by Dr. Jack Sava of MedStar. Sava stated that Scalise will "hopefully" be able to walk and run again at some point in the future, but there is no set timetable for his recovery.

The shooter has been identified as James T. Hodgkinson, a 66-year-old man from Illinois, according to police officials. The FBI is actively investigating Hodgkinson, including his associates, whereabouts, social media impressions, and potential motivations. The ATF is also conducting a trace on two weapons, including a 9 mm handgun and a 7.62 caliber rifle.

The incident unfolded at approximately 7:09 a.m. on June 14, with the Alexandria Police Department responding to the scene. Multiple members of Congress were present during the practice, resulting in the presence of United States Capitol Police officers. The shooter was engaged by law enforcement and shot at approximately 7:14 a.m., with five individuals transported to local hospitals with gunshot wounds.

In addition to Scalise, the victims include a United States Capitol Police officer, a congressman, a congressional staffer, a lobbyist, and the shooter. A second congressman sustained minor injuries and was also transported by a medic unit. One additional United States Capitol Police officer was transported to the hospital in a police cruiser for minor injuries and has since been released.

Rep. Mo Brooks (R-AL) used his belt as a tourniquet to stop the bleeding from an unidentified victim, while Rep. Brad Wenstrup (R-OH), a doctor, also tended to Scalise. Zachary Barth, a staffer for Rep. Roger Williams (R-TX), posted on Facebook that he was among those shot but is "at the hospital and okay." Matt Mika, a lobbyist who is the director of government relations for Tyson Foods, was also shot in the attack.

Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-WI) identified Special Agent David Bailey and Special Agent Crystal Griner, both of Capitol Police, as other victims of the attack. Special Agent Crystal Griner is also at MedStar Washington and is in good condition as of Friday afternoon, according to the hospital.

Two Alexandria police officers and two Capitol Police officers exchanged gunfire with the shooter, according to law enforcement officials. The FBI is leading the investigation, with Special Agent Tim Slater, the special agent in charge of the bureau's Washington field office, stating that it is too early to determine the shooter's motive. Eyewitnesses, including Sens. Rand Paul (R-KY) and Jeff Flake, described the officers as members of the Capitol Police force, which is responsible for protecting Capitol Hill and individual members of the House and Senate leadership.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Controversial Arizona Immigration Law's "Reasonable Suspicion" Provision

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Supreme Court's ruling on Arizona's controversial immigration law on Monday upheld the provision that was the subject of much criticism from President Obama, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., and other top officials over potential racial profiling. The provision, which allows police to check the immigration status of individuals they have "reasonable suspicion" are in the country illegally, was upheld unanimously by the court.

The law, signed by Arizona Governor Jan Brewer in 2010, had four main components. Three sections that set up state criminal penalties for immigration violations were struck down in the 5-3 ruling. Justice Elena Kagan recused herself from the case.

However, all eight justices upheld the provision allowing police to check the status of those they had "reasonable suspicion" were in the country illegally, and then report their identity to federal authorities. The federal government could then decide whether it wanted to pick up and deport the illegal immigrants, or let them go.

When Arizona was debating the law, President Obama, Attorney General Holder, and other top officials expressed concerns that the provision would lead to racial profiling. In 2010, President Obama said, "Now suddenly if you don't have your papers and you take your kid out for ice cream and you're going to be harassed—that's not the right way to go."

However, when the Justice Department filed its lawsuit challenging the law, it left out the racial profiling argument, instead focusing on issues of federal versus state power over immigration. Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli told the court during oral arguments in April, "We're not making any allegation about racial or ethnic profiling in the case."

Representative Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has emerged as a top voice for legalizing illegal immigrants, expressed concerns about the potential for racial profiling. "Experience has shown us that police are highly unlikely to stop an individual with the last name of Kennedy or Roberts on suspicion of not being a legal U.S. citizen, but if you are a Gutierrez or Martinez, watch out," he said.

Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the majority that there is "basic uncertainty about what the law means and how it will be enforced." He added that it would be "inappropriate to assume" that the provision will be construed in a way that creates a conflict with federal law.

The court left open the chance for further challenges if the law becomes discriminatory. In particular, the justices seemed concerned that immigration checks could unconstitutionally prolong the amount of time an officer detained someone during the status checks.

Arizona Governor Jan Brewer said in a statement Monday that police need to be aware that opponents are watching them. "Our critics are already preparing new litigation tactics in response to their loss at the Supreme Court, and undoubtedly will allege inequities in the implementation of the law," she said. "As I said two years ago on the day I signed SB 1070 into law, 'We can not give them that chance. We must use this new tool wisely, and fight for our safety with the honor Arizona deserves.'"

Title: Reflecting on the Iraq War: A Decade of Lessons Learned

Article:

In the aftermath of the Iraq War, a decade has passed since the United States' military withdrawal in 2011, and the consequences of the conflict continue to reverberate across the Middle East. The war, which was initiated to destroy weapons of mass destruction and later to nation-build, has left a lasting impact on American society and the region as a whole.

The Iraq War, one of the longest in American history, has resulted in thousands of American deaths, tens of thousands of casualties, and trillions of dollars in expenditure. Yet, the benefits of this costly endeavor remain elusive. The primary reason for this, according to many analysts, is the failure to recognize the unique cultural and political dynamics of the Middle East.

The West tends to view peace as the default state, with war being a temporary aberration. In contrast, the Middle East perceives war as the norm, with peace being a temporary interlude between conflicts. This fundamental difference in perspectives has been a significant factor in the failure of the Iraq War.

The Iraq War began under the administration of President George W. Bush, who was later criticized for the questionable grounds on which the war was initiated. The war was initially won, but was later lost, only to be won again with the surge. The war's end, marked by President Obama's decision to withdraw troops in 2011, has proven to be anything but final.

The city of Fallujah, a leading city in Iraq's Anbar province, serves as a stark reminder of the war's futility. A battleground in 2004, Fallujah is once again a battleground, with a reconstituted Al Qaeda seizing control. The predominantly Shiite Iraqi government has vowed to retake the city, but the prospect of another civil war between Shiite and Sunni Arabs looms large.

It is crucial to acknowledge that the military personnel who served in Iraq performed heroically throughout the conflict. They fought valiantly, innovated, and rose to the challenge of nation-building tasks they were not trained for. The blame for the Iraq War, however, lies not with the military, but with the political leaders of both parties and both presidencies.

The Iraq War was marked by tragic missteps, from the flawed intelligence that led to the invasion to the failure to anticipate the insurgency and the premature withdrawal of troops. The war's aftermath has left Iraq on the brink of another civil war, a stark reminder of the region's millennia-old conflicts.

As the United States recovers from the Iraq War, it is essential to learn from the past and approach future conflicts with a more sober, shrewd, and strategic mindset. The hope is that the lessons of the Iraq War will lead to a more peaceful and prosperous future, not just for the United States, but for the world.

Title: Business Groups Lobby for TPP Approval Amidst Political Divide

Article:

In the midst of the political fervor surrounding the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal, business groups have launched a nationwide lobbying effort to secure its approval. This push comes as both major political parties have expressed opposition to the agreement during their respective conventions.

Caterpillar Inc., a leading manufacturer, has hosted lawmakers such as Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland and Republican Rep. Erik Paulsen of Minnesota at its factories. These meetings aim to highlight the benefits of the TPP for the company's workers.

Trade Benefits America, a prominent business coalition, is coordinating a grassroots advertising campaign, sending approximately 60 to 70 pro-TPP letters to members of Congress daily. The Association of Equipment Manufacturers is also actively promoting the agreement, touring the Midwest with an interactive truck display and running digital ads in key Senate races.

Kevin Madden, a strategist working with the Trade Benefits America coalition, emphasized the impact of these personal stories on lawmakers. "When you see trade, when it's just a sign being waved on a convention floor... that's one thing," Madden said. "But when it's somebody who has a small- or medium-size enterprise in your local economy, who is directly responsible for the employment of people whose jobs are tied to exporting... that has an impact on lawmakers, and that's important."

Despite the opposition from both major-party presidential candidates and a majority of Democratic leadership, proponents of the TPP remain optimistic. They point to polls showing a majority of Americans support free trade and argue that the negative rhetoric at the party conventions has amplified a minority of anti-TPP voices that do not fully understand the agreement's facts.

Supporters believe that lawmakers will ultimately vote in the interests of their districts rather than following the positions of the presidential candidates. The current political climate has increased the urgency to pass the TPP before either Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump becomes president and potentially scraps or freezes the agreement.

Ed Gerwin, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute, a centrist Democrat think tank that supports TPP, stated, "Donald Trump apparently doesn't want to trade with anyone; he wants to withdraw from the WTO and basically turn us into North Korea. And if Secretary Clinton says that she is not a supporter of TPP, that puts even more pressure on supporters of TPP to try to get it done now."

The administration will need to address concerns from lawmakers, particularly regarding protections for biologic drug firms and tobacco companies. However, a compromise on financial services companies was reached the week before the Republican convention, which could serve as a model for resolving the remaining issues.

Bill Miller, a senior vice president in charge of lobbying operations at the Business Roundtable, stated, "It's not going to be easy, but it's certainly doable." Linda Dempsey, vice president of international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers, echoed this sentiment, saying, "It's not going to be easy, but it's certainly doable."

Lobbying groups are employing various strategies to connect with lawmakers, including op-eds, town halls, and flooding congressional offices with handwritten letters from company employees. John Michael Gonzalez, a Democratic lobbyist and strategist who works on trade, expressed optimism, stating, "From my experience, it always looks so bleak. But it always prevails. At the end of the day, our government and our elected officials move forward, not backwards."

Some groups are also taking advantage of the summer recess to show lawmakers the importance of trade deals on their home turf. For example, the agriculture community is using summer fairs to highlight the benefits of trade deals. In mid-September, executives from footwear companies will visit Capitol Hill to meet with lawmakers and emphasize the TPP's impact on the cost of shoes.

Matt Priest, president of the Footwear Distributors and Retailers of America trade association, said, "This is an all-hands-on-deck moment. We can not leave any stone unturned, any email not sent or call not made." The intensity of the lobbying effort reflects the urgency felt by proponents of the TPP to secure its approval before the presidential election.

Title: Court of Military Commission Review Overturns Conviction of Guantánamo Detainee, Raising Questions on Terrorism Trials

Article:

In a significant ruling, the Court of Military Commission Review has overturned the conviction of a Guantánamo detainee, Ahmed al-Darbi, who was accused of being a member of Al-Qaeda but not of plotting a specific terrorist attack. The decision, penned by Judge Brett Kavanaugh, has been hailed as a major blow to the legitimacy of the Guantánamo military commissions, which have been conducting trials for alleged war crimes since their inception.

Al-Darbi, a Yemeni national, traveled from Yemen to Pakistan and Afghanistan in 1996. He attended a Qaeda training camp, met Osama Bin Laden, and became a driver for jihadis and their weapons. He later drove Bin Laden personally and was told by Bin Laden several days before Sept. 11, 2001, that they would have to evacuate their compound due to an impending operation that might provoke retaliation.

Al-Darbi was captured in Afghanistan in 2001 and was sent to Guantánamo Bay soon after it opened in early 2002. His legal journey was slow, partly due to legal challenges to the Bush administration's new system of military commissions for terrorism suspects. He was charged with conspiracy as well as eight counts of material support in 2008. He was acquitted of the conspiracy charge, which could have resulted in a longer sentence. He was sentenced to 66 months of confinement and credited for the time he had already served since being charged.

The verdict was a setback for military prosecutors, who had argued that they could detain him indefinitely. However, even after his release, he continued to challenge his conviction. The Court of Military Commission Review upheld his conviction in 2011, but the Appeals Court has now reversed this decision.

The ruling calls into question whether other Guantánamo detainees accused of being part of Al-Qaeda but not of plotting any specific terrorist attack can receive military trials. Zachary Katznelson, senior staff attorney at the American Civil Liberties Union, stated, "This decision strikes the biggest blow yet against the legitimacy of the Guantánamo military commissions, which have for years now been trying people for a supposed war crime that in fact is not a war crime at all." He suggested that the government should prosecute in civilian courts any Guantánamo prisoners against whom it has enough admissible evidence.

The opinion was largely joined by Chief Judge David Sentelle and Judge Douglas Ginsburg, appointees of Ronald Reagan. The decision is expected to have far-reaching implications for the future of military commissions at Guantánamo Bay.

Title: Nationwide Commemorations Mark 50 Years Since JFK Assassination

Article:

As the United States commemorates the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, cities across the nation are hosting events to honor the late president. In Dallas, where the tragic event took place, a public observance is scheduled for Friday, Dealey Plaza, the site of the assassination.

The commemoration will feature Pulitzer Prize-winning historian David McCullough, who will read excerpts from Kennedy's presidential speeches. The U.S. Naval Academy Men's Glee Club will perform, and religious leaders will offer prayers and a benediction. Approximately 5,000 tickets have been issued for this event.

In a unique tribute, the Texas Theatre in Dallas will screen War is Hell, the film that was playing when Lee Harvey Oswald, Kennedy's assassin, entered the theater. The film will be shown at 1:20 p.m. on Friday, with approximately 40 minutes of the original footage being shown due to the loss of the full copy. Admission is 90 cents, the price of a ticket in 1963.

A day of service, #JFKDay, is being held in Dallas on November 23 to honor Kennedy's memory and service legacy.

In Washington D.C., the Newseum will host "JFK Remembrance Day" on Friday, featuring a rebroadcast of three hours of CBS News' live television coverage of the assassination. President Obama will deliver a speech at the Smithsonian American History Museum on Wednesday evening on Kennedy's legacy of service. On Friday, he will meet privately with leaders and volunteers from the Peace Corps, an organization Kennedy established in 1961.

The Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, where Kennedy's funeral was held, will host a Choral Mass of Remembrance on Friday.

In Arlington, Virginia, the eternal flame at Kennedy's grave site at Arlington Cemetery was restored last month and is open to the public over the anniversary weekend. President Obama, accompanied by First Lady Michelle Obama, former President Bill Clinton, and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, will visit the grave on Wednesday.

In Brookline, Massachusetts, the John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site, the neighborhood and house where the president spent his childhood, will offer free admission to the public on Saturday and Sunday. A brief memorial ceremony will be held at the president's birthplace at 2 p.m. on Sunday, including a reading of President Lyndon Johnson's 1963 National Day of Mourning Proclamation and a wreath-laying.

John F. Kennedy University in Pleasant Hill, California, the only university in the country with Kennedy's name, will hold a memorial on Friday, including an unveiling of a bust of Kennedy and the announcement of a project for students to honor Kennedy's service legacy.

In Chicago, city and state flags will fly at half-staff on Friday, with a citywide moment of silence at 1 p.m. and church bells tolling to commemorate the assassination of the president.

In Dearborn, Michigan, the 1961 Lincoln Continental that carried Kennedy through Dallas on the day he was assassinated is on permanent display at The Henry Ford Museum. The museum offers special programs this week, including sold-out events with newscaster Dan Rather, who covered the assassination, and former Secret Service agent Clint Hill, who was on duty that day in Dallas.

Finally, in San Antonio, Kennedy's last official act as president took place at Brooks Air Force Base School of Aerospace Medicine, where he gave his "Cap over the Wall" speech, one day before his death. Brooks City-Base will hold a commemorative event at the same location on Thursday at 2 p.m., including remarks by San Antonio Mayor Julián Castro and Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff. A commemorative video of the speech, along with historic photos, will also be presented.

Title: Federal School Safety Commission Recommends Rescinding Discipline Guidance, Emphasizes Mental Health Services and Armed Personnel

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida, the Federal Commission on School Safety has released a report detailing recommendations to enhance school safety. The report, which focuses on various aspects of school safety, including mental health care and infrastructure security, suggests rescinding existing discipline guidance that aimed to protect minority students from disproportionate disciplinary actions.

The 200-page report, compiled by the commission formed after the Parkland high school massacre, avoids discussing gun laws and does not recommend arming teachers. Instead, it offers guidelines for schools to consider arming "highly trained school personnel" in rural areas where law enforcement response times may be extended.

The commission's report emphasizes that there is no single policy that will ensure school safety, with Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos stating, "What will work for schools in Montana will be different than what will work for schools in Manhattan."

The report recommends reviewing school infrastructure, including windows, hallways, and doors, and in some instances, having someone on school grounds armed with a firearm to collaborate with law enforcement. The report also encourages more coordination between schools and local law enforcement, suggesting that some communities may benefit from hiring military veterans or retired law enforcement officers into school roles.

The report includes recommendations aimed at the media, urging news outlets to exercise responsibility in covering school shootings and refrain from publishing pictures of the perpetrator. The commission also emphasizes the importance of mental health services for students, social and emotional learning, and the adoption of "extreme risk protection orders" that would temporarily withhold guns from those who pose a risk to themselves or others.

President Trump hosted the commissioners and individuals affected by school shootings at the White House, with Trump calling the report "a very important thing." The report has received mixed reactions from families affected by school shootings, with some praising its comprehensive approach to school safety, while others criticize the report for not addressing the role of guns in school shootings.

Andy Pollack, whose daughter Meadow died in Parkland, called the report "the most comprehensive report by any administration on a school shooting." Lori Alhadeff, the mother of 14-year-old Parkland victim Alyssa, expressed her support for the commission's findings. Fred Guttenberg, whose daughter Jaime Guttenberg, 14, was killed in Parkland, criticized the report for not considering the role of guns in school shootings.

Mark Barden, whose son Daniel was one of the 20 first-graders killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, issued a statement praising the report's emphasis on mental health resources but expressed concern over the commission's continued support for arming school personnel. Barden stated, "We believe that teachers and school administrators should be focused on education, not weapons training."

The report's recommendations will now be considered by the administration and Congress as they work towards improving school safety in the United States.

Title: ObamaCare Exchanges: Analysts Warn of Limited Doctor Access, Potential Rationing

 Article:

 As the enrollment period for private health care coverage under ObamaCare begins, analysts are warning that the plans may provide insurance but limited access to doctors and hospitals. The concern is that the system could resemble Medicaid, the health care program for low-income Americans, due to the potential for lower payments leading to doctors refusing to see patients.

 Merrill Matthews, director of the Council for Affordable Health Insurance, stated, "Indeed, I think this will eventually be like Medicaid." He explained that insurers will control costs by "clamping down on the amount they are willing to pay."

 James Capretta, of the Ethics and Public Policy Center, noted that about half of physicians in many communities already refuse to take Medicaid patients due to low payments. Doug Holtz-Eakin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, suggested that some plans on the exchanges are heading in the same direction.

 By the end of March, the Obama administration hopes to increase the number of people on Medicaid by 9 million and the number in private plans by 7 million. However, the rapid expansion of Medicaid and the potential for lower payments for private insurance raises the prospect of rationing, as too many people chase too few doctors.

 Robert Laszewski, president of Health Policy and Strategy Associates, stated, "These networks are going to be jammed with people. Far more than they're treating now, and I do not doubt that we're going to have problems with access to these doctors. There just aren't going to be enough of them."

 The Obama administration is currently trying to move past a year of ups and downs for its health care law and encourage people to sign up during the final three months of open enrollment. President Obama stated in his year-end press conference that enrollment has picked up considerably as problems with the federal exchange website have been addressed. He emphasized that the law is providing health insurance to those previously unable to get it.

Title: Biden's Focus Shifts to Trump as Sanders Chapter Closes in Democratic Race

Article:

In a significant shift in strategy, former Vice President Joe Biden, during a rally in Henderson, Nevada on February 14, 2020, emphasized the need to replace President Donald Trump, rather than focusing on his rival, Senator Bernie Sanders. This strategic move comes after Biden's decisive victory in the recent debate, which, despite his win, was not a scintillating event, according to political analysts.

The debate, which was initially scheduled for another round in April, might not take place due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The conventional wisdom from the previous ten debates was that Biden benefited from the time constraints on a crowded stage, as it limited opportunities for gaffes and Bidenisms. However, in a one-on-one matchup, Sanders' disciplined, surgical strikes came across as repetitive and canned, while Biden appeared more composed.

Senator Bernie Sanders, who had previously been perceived as a formidable contender, is now, according to Biden, a single-issue candidate. Sanders' focus on healthcare and economic inequality, while effective in the past, seems disconnected from the current crisis and ill-suited to deal with it, as evidenced by his responses during the debate.

Sanders' repeated attacks on the "health-care industry" during the debate, particularly during a public health emergency, were criticized as tone-deaf, given that this industry is on the front lines of the COVID-19 crisis. Similarly, his repeated focus on income inequality during the economic consequences of the pandemic was seen as ideological ax-grinding, rather than providing immediate and practical solutions.

Biden, on the other hand, has shifted his focus to the imperative of replacing Trump, a unifying message for all of his potential voters. The general election, in Biden's view, has begun, and the last thing the Democratic Party needs is more debates about its direction. The Sanders chapter, according to Biden, is over, and it's time to unite behind a candidate who can defeat Trump in November.

This strategic shift by Biden indicates a recognition that the primary race is nearing its end and the focus should now be on the upcoming general election. By emphasizing the need to replace Trump, Biden is positioning himself as a unifying figure who can appeal to a broad spectrum of voters, rather than getting bogged down in internal party debates.

Title: Trump Announces Increased Tariffs on Turkish Steel and Aluminum Amidst Ongoing Diplomatic Dispute

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a move that escalates the ongoing diplomatic dispute between the United States and Turkey, President Donald Trump announced on Friday that he would increase tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Turkey. The decision comes as the Turkish Lira, the country's currency, continues to depreciate against the U.S. dollar.

In a series of tweets, Trump wrote, "I have just authorized a doubling of Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum with respect to Turkey as their currency, the Turkish Lira, slides rapidly downward against our very strong Dollar! Aluminum will now be 20 % and Steel 50 %. Our relations with Turkey are not good at this time!"

The tweeted tariff threat follows the Trump administration's imposition of sanctions on Turkish officials over the imprisonment of American pastor Andrew Brunson, which the administration has deemed "unjust" and "unacceptable." The sanctions targeted Turkey's Minister of Justice, Abdulhamit Gul, and Minister of Interior, Suleyman Soylu.

Bulent Aliriza, an expert on Turkey with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington-based think tank, stated that Trump's latest decision to increase tariffs will push Turkey's economy "into more difficult waters."

White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said that Trump "has authorized the preparation of documents" to raise steel and aluminum tariffs on Turkey, citing a section of the U.S. trade law that allows penalties "on imports from particular countries whose exports threaten to impair national security."

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan responded defiantly to Trump's announcement on Friday. "We will not lose the economic war," Erdogan said during a tour of Black Sea provinces, according to the Hurriyet Daily News, an English language outlet. "This is a national struggle."

Ruhsar Pekcan, Turkey's trade minister, said Trump's decision would harm U.S. companies and consumers. "Turkey is deeply disappointed by the U.S. Administration’s decision to double steel and aluminum tariffs. The tariffs were groundless when they were announced in June, and remain so now," Pekcan said.

Aliriza stated that Trump's move will strengthen Erdogan in the short run, because it allows him to fan existing anti-American sentiment in Turkey. "It's difficult to be optimistic" about reaching a resolution to the standoff and lowering tensions between the two countries, he said.

The proposed tariff hikes come just days after Turkey’s deputy foreign minister was in Washington to meet with U.S. officials on a range of contentious issues, including Brunson's detention. State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert declined to detail those conversations during a briefing with reporters on Thursday.

"Obviously you all know that we have a very broad relationship with Turkey and a host of issues that we talk about with the Turkish government whenever we do meet," Nauert said Thursday. "Yesterday we had a wide-ranging conversation with Turkish government officials. We made it clear that Pastor Brunson needs to be returned home."

She declined to say whether the two sides made any progress on the release of Brunson. "We would define progress as Pastor Brunson being brought home," she said.

More: Trump administration sanctions Turkish officials over American pastor's arrest
Previously, Trump has used tariffs against countries he claims are engaging in unfair trade practices against the United States. The action against Turkey appears to flow from political differences between the two countries, particularly the Brunson case.

Turkey accuses Brunson, arrested in 2016, of being a spy and says he was involved in an attempted coup. The United States says he has been falsely charged. Trump has discussed the Brunson case with Erdogan but has been unable to obtain the pastor's release.
