Erdogan said last week that U.S. sanctions will not affect the Brunson case. "We will not give any credit to this type of threatening language," Erdogan told reporters Wednesday in Ankara. "It is not possible for us to accept that America gets up, especially with an evangelist, Zionist mentality, and uses this kind of threat-filled language."

Title: Ellen DeGeneres and George W. Bush Share Friendship Amidst Controversy

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, talk show host Ellen DeGeneres and former President George W. Bush were spotted together at a Dallas Cowboys football game on Sunday. The duo, along with their respective partners, were seen enjoying the game in a series of pictures and video clips.

The sighting sparked controversy, as some took to social media to express their disapproval. Tweets ranged from accusations of rehabilitating a "war criminal" to criticisms of the pair's political differences.

Hasan Abi (@hasanthehun) tweeted, "Ellen DeGeneres is rehabilitating a war criminal and any liberal who buys into the lie that GWB is a sweet old man is a trog."

Oliver Willis (@owillis) wrote, "George W. Bush literally ran for reelection on a constitutional amendment so @TheEllenShow would be barred from being able to marry. I know they're both rich, but that's not a mere 'difference of opinion.' That's an attempt to make one person less of a person than the other."

Rafael (@rafaelshimunov) tweeted, "This is what Bush brought Iraqi families, daily, for his oil friends. @TheEllenShow and @gwenstefani are patting themselves on the back for rainbow capitalism, comparing a war criminal to 'disagreements' while actively sanitizing them in service of endless greed and selfishness."

In response to the backlash, DeGeneres addressed the controversy during her show on Tuesday. She highlighted a supportive tweet that read, "Seeing Ellen and George Bush together makes me have faith in America again."

DeGeneres defended their friendship, stating, "I'm friends with George Bush. In fact, I'm friends with a lot of people who don't share the same beliefs I have. We're all different, and I think that's okay that we're all different."

She continued, "Just because I don't agree with someone on everything doesn't mean I'm not going to be friends with them. When I say, 'Be kind to one another,' I don't mean only the people that think the same way that you do."

The controversy highlights the ongoing cultural dialogue's emphasis on canceling individuals who have done or said something wrong. The debate raises questions about the importance of maintaining friendships and civility, even in the face of political differences. As Senior Editor Brian Doherty has argued, ending relationships over politics is rarely a good idea. Gratuitous cruelty toward those who are part of the "other side," tribe, or team does not make the world a better place.

Title: Declassified Documents Detail U.S. Surveillance Programs and Minimization Procedures

Article:

The National Security Agency (NSA) has declassified a series of documents that offer insights into previously secret programs that collect vast amounts of metadata on domestic phone calls and electronic communications of foreigners, as well as some Americans. The Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, stated that the release was "in the public interest."

The most significant document is a 17-page ruling by the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) that outlines the minimization procedures, or safeguards, the government must follow when dealing with the collected data. The New York Times reports that the releases also include two formerly classified briefing papers to Congress from 2009 and 2011, when the provision of the Patriot Act that the court relied on to issue the order was up for reauthorization.

These briefing papers portray the bulk collection of metadata as an "early warning system" that allows the government to quickly identify connections to terrorism suspects. The 2011 briefing paper states, "Both of these programs operate on a very large scale, but only a tiny fraction of such records are ever viewed by N.S.A. intelligence analysts."

The documents released contain numerous redactions, and at first glance, they do not seem to reveal much more detail than what was already known from the leaked documents provided to The Guardian and The Washington Post by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden.

One of the mysteries that remains is the legal rationale for allowing the bulk collection of the electronic data of Americans. The government's authorization for the collection of phone metadata is based on section 215 of the USA Patriot Act. The briefing document, however, points out that no "content" is being collected. Instead, the program is only collecting information that the Supreme Court has decided is "not protected by the Fourth Amendment."

The government's interpretation of the law is a subject of debate among legal scholars and civil libertarians, who are waiting for the Judicial Branch's interpretation. The FISC order also includes an exception for technical personnel, who are allowed to query the data without adhering to the safeguards, but any information queried is not allowed to be used for "intelligence analysis purposes."

The Washington Post frames the release of the FISC order as an attempt by the government to calm privacy concerns. The documents will continue to be analyzed, and noteworthy findings will be reported as they emerge.

Title: Hillary Clinton Accuses Donald Trump of Catering to Racist and Conspiratorial Elements in Campaign Speech

Article:

In a speech delivered today in Reno, Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton accused her Republican counterpart, Donald Trump, of embracing and amplifying extremist and conspiratorial viewpoints. Clinton's speech, titled "Donald Trump and his advisors' embrace of the disturbing 'alt-right' political philosophy," was an extended critique of Trump's character, his policies, and his alleged associations with hate groups and controversial figures.

While the alt-right, an umbrella term for a collection of racist micro-movements and online subcultures, was a significant focus of the speech, it was not the primary antagonist. The primary target of Clinton's criticism was Donald Trump himself. The alt-right, Breitbart, Alex Jones, David Duke, Nigel Farage, and Vladimir Putin were all mentioned in the speech, but in a supporting role.

Some of Clinton's arguments were met with criticism for their lack of clarity. For instance, she began her litany by quoting Trump's recent comments about the struggles faced by the African-American community. While many might view these comments as an attempt to demonstrate empathy, Clinton characterized them as a "dog whistle to his most hateful supporters." She also overstated the alt-right's influence, claiming that the "de facto merger between Breitbart and the Trump campaign" had resulted in the alt-right "effectively taking over the Republican Party."

However, Clinton's speech was not without merit. She highlighted Trump's history of retweeting white nationalists and his false claim that he witnessed thousands of New Jersey Muslims celebrating the 9/11 attacks.

Throughout the speech, a consistent theme emerged: Donald Trump is a bigot and a conspiracy theorist. While this idea has been prevalent since Trump entered the presidential race, Clinton's speech represented a forceful and concentrated expression of this notion. The speech is likely to energize her supporters and may help mobilize voters.

The speech's impact on the alt-right, however, remains to be seen. The minute-long section of the speech dedicated to the alt-right may receive significant media coverage in the coming days, potentially leading some curious conservatives to research the term "alt-right."

Meanwhile, one individual who is likely to be pleased with the speech is Alex Jones. Clinton's direct criticism of him is sure to be a topic of discussion among Jones' listeners for some time.

Title: GOP and Fox News Pursue Course Correction in Wake of 2012 Election

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2012 election, the Republican Party and Fox News are taking decisive steps to tone down the partisan rhetoric that has characterized both in recent years. The aim is to appeal to a broader electorate and regain credibility.

Fox News, the leading cable news network in the U.S., has parted ways with two of its most divisive personalities, Sarah Palin and Dick Morris. The network, which has seen a dip in ratings since the election, is reportedly seeking to distance itself from the controversial figures who stoked the Republican base but alienated many voters.

Meanwhile, Karl Rove, a key figure in the Republican Party who was sidelined by Fox after the election, has helped establish the Conservative Victory Fund, a super PAC designed to prevent controversial conservatives from winning Senate primaries.

Senate Republican leaders have also implemented a strategy to collaborate with popular tea party members, Senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Ted Cruz of Texas, to manage anti-establishment conservatives within their own ranks.

Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal has been vocal in his criticism of the Republican Party, urging it to avoid nominating extreme candidates. He stated, "The fact that we lost a winnable election has caused Republicans to take this very, very seriously. I don't think it's just a marketing change. I don't think it's just cosmetic changes. It is going to require some serious changes, not in principles, but in the way we talk and act."

A high-profile Republican strategist, who wished to remain anonymous to avoid antagonizing the segments of the party they are trying to silence, confirmed a deliberate effort by party leaders to "marginalize the cranks, haters, and bigots—there's a lot of underbrush that has to be cleaned out."

For the Republican Party, this shift is a matter of survival, following two consecutive elections in which extremely conservative candidates lost winnable Senate races. For Fox News, it's about credibility: the network, while still the top-ranked in news, has seen its ratings decline since the election, in part, due to conservative viewers feeling misled by the coverage.

Roger Ailes, Fox's chairman and CEO, has a keen understanding of his audience—Fox viewers. He revolutionized television by tapping into Republican disdain and anger towards the mainstream media. This strategy has been successful, creating not only the most-watched cable news channel in the country but also political celebrities, several of whom dominated Republican politics in the 2012 cycle. However, the network faced criticism for its coverage during the 2012 election, particularly on election night when Rove, a Fox contributor, argued against the consensus that President Barack Obama would win Ohio.

In the wake of the 2012 election, both the Republican Party and Fox News are working to redefine their images and regain the trust of the American electorate.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Response to Slaughter of Egyptian Christians

Article:

Egypt's military carried out a series of airstrikes against ISIS militants in Libya on Monday, in retaliation for the brutal slaughter of 21 Egyptian Christians by the jihadist group. The bombing raids, which targeted 10 sites in the ISIS stronghold of Derna, have drawn Egypt deeper into the international fight against ISIS and highlighted the extremist group's growing presence in North Africa.

Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry told CNN that the airstrikes were aimed at degrading ISIS' capabilities within the city of Derna. However, an umbrella group of Islamist militias in Derna issued a statement claiming that the city's residents, including women and children, were the targets of the bombings.

The airstrikes came after ISIS released a gruesome video on Sunday that appeared to show militants beheading at least a dozen Egyptian Christians on a Libyan beach. The video, produced by ISIS' propaganda wing al-Hayat Media, has intensified international concerns about ISIS' deepening reach into countries far beyond its strongholds in Syria and Iraq.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi had warned on Sunday that his country "reserves the right of retaliation and with the methods and timing it sees fit for retribution for those murderers and criminals who are without the slightest humanity." He also declared a week of mourning in the Muslim majority nation for the slain Christians.

In a statement, Egypt's Foreign Ministry called for other nations battling ISIS to support Egypt's efforts and to target terrorists in Libya as well. The U.S. government condemned the killings, with U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry calling Egyptian Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry on Sunday to offer condolences.

Egypt is already fighting against ISIS-allied militants on its own territory in the Sinai Peninsula, where dozens of people were killed in a series of attacks in January. Concern has increased over ISIS' rising influence in Libya amid the power and security vacuum prevalent in the country since the 2011 uprising that overthrew former dictator Moammar Gadhafi.

CNN reported in November that fighters loyal to ISIS had complete control of the city of Derna, which has a population of about 100,000 and is situated not far from the Egyptian border. Jihadists with allegiance to ISIS had also expanded their presence westward along the Libyan coast, forming chapters in cities including Benghazi, Sirte, and even Tripoli, the capital, according to Noman Benotman, a former Libyan jihadist now involved in counterterrorism for the Quilliam Foundation.

The links between the different branches of ISIS present a real challenge for Western leaders, as U.S. President Barack Obama asked Congress to formally authorize the use of military force in the war against ISIS. "While we can come up with a military solution or a military operation in a restricted area like Syria and Iraq, what do we do when it expands to North Africa?" Lt. Col. Rick Francona, a retired U.S. Air Force intelligence officer, asked.

Title: Trump Kicks Off First Official Week in Office with Busy Agenda, Reaching Out to Congress and Foreign Leaders

Article:

WASHINGTON -- President Donald Trump commenced his first official week in the White House by meeting with congressional leaders from both parties to discuss his ambitious agenda, as he works to begin delivering on his campaign promises.

Trump, who considers Monday his first real day in office, has a packed schedule that suggests an open ear, with a heavy focus on jobs and national security.

"Busy week planned with a heavy focus on jobs and national security," Trump tweeted early Monday. "Top executives coming in at 9:00 A.M. to talk manufacturing in America."

The president's schedule includes a breakfast and a listening session with business leaders in the morning, another listening session with union leaders and workers in the afternoon, and a reception later with members of Congress he'll need on board to overhaul the nation's health care system, among other goals. He will also hold his first meeting as president with the speaker of the House, Paul Ryan.

The outreach effort comes after a tumultuous first weekend in the White House that included lambasting news organizations for correctly reporting on the size of the crowds at his inauguration and mass protests against his presidency on the following day.

Trump delivered a more unifying message Sunday and sought to reassure Americans he was up to the daunting task ahead. Speaking in the White House East Room during a swearing-in ceremony for top aides, the president warned his staff of the challenges ahead but declared he believed they were ready.

"But with the faith in each other and the faith in God, we will get the job done," he said. "We will prove worthy of this moment in history. And I think it may very well be a great moment in history."

Trump said his staff was in the White House not to "help ourselves" but to "devote ourselves to the national good."

"This is not about party, this is not about ideology. This is about country, our country. It's about serving the American people," he said.

Earlier Sunday, Trump offered a scattershot response to the sweeping post-inauguration protests, first sarcastically denigrating the public opposition and then defending the right to demonstrate a short time later.

"Watched protests yesterday but was under the impression that we just had an election! Why didn't these people vote?" Trump tweeted early Sunday morning. Ninety-five minutes later, he struck a more conciliatory tone.

"Peaceful protests are a hallmark of our democracy. Even if I don't always agree, I recognize the rights of people to express their views," the president tweeted, still using his personal account.

Trump also spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accepted an invitation to visit the White House in early February. The prime minister said he is hoping to forge a "common vision" with the newly inaugurated U.S. president that could include expanded settlement construction and a tougher policy toward Iran.

Trump also announced that he's set up meetings with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto.

"We're going to start some negotiations having to do with NAFTA," he said of his meeting with Pena Nieto. Mexico is part of the free trade agreement with the U.S. and Canada. Trump said he also will discuss immigration and security at the border. He has promised to build a wall along the length of the southern border and insisted that Mexico will pay for it.

Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, said on "Fox News Sunday" the president would spend his first full week in office undoing some of former President Barack Obama's agenda and planned to sign executive orders on immigration and trade. Trump planned to sign some executive orders on Monday, but it was unclear which.

Trump has pledged to scuttle trade deals such as a pending Asia-Pacific agreement and overturn Obama's executive order deferring deportations for 700,000 people who were brought into the country illegally as minors.

Later in the week, he'll address congressional Republicans at their retreat in Philadelphia and meet with British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Title: Eva Longoria Advocates for Immigration Reform as a Key Priority for President Obama's Second Term

Article:

In an exclusive interview on "This Week," award-winning actress and emerging Washington power player Eva Longoria has expressed her belief that immigration reform should be a top priority for President Obama during his second term. Longoria, who has been labeled a "Hispanic activist and power player in Washington, D.C." by the Wall Street Journal, has been a strong supporter of President Obama, serving as a co-chair of his reelection campaign and delivering a speech at the Democratic National Convention last September.

This week, Longoria is making headlines as an executive producer and host of the Latino Inaugural, a concert at the Kennedy Center featuring performances by several artists including Jose Feliciano, Melanie Griffith, and New York City's Ballet Hispanico. As a co-chair of the Presidential Inauguration Committee, Longoria is actively involved in the preparations for Obama's second inauguration.

For those interested in following the inauguration events, live streaming video coverage of Inauguration 2013: Barack Obama will be available on the ███.com Live page starting at 9:30 a.m. EST on Monday, with additional coverage available on the ███ iPad App and mobile devices.

Longoria emphasized the economic importance of immigration reform, stating, "We have to understand that we are dependent upon a labor force in this country, specifically in agriculture, to provide low-cost products, and they're jobs that nobody else is doing." She believes that there is room for compromise on both sides of the aisle on immigration, and that the benefits of reform are significant for all parties involved.

Longoria, who was one of President Obama's leading Latino fundraisers during his reelection campaign, noted the historic mobilization of the Latino vote in the recent election. She expressed optimism that the Republicans will recognize the political, moral, and economic imperatives for immigration reform.

Despite her political activism, Longoria has no plans to run for office in her home state of Texas. "I respect everything that politicians do. I think it's a very, very big job," she said. "It's not my day job, so I'm just doing what I can to help the communities in which I came from."

Title: President Obama Issues Executive Order on Gun Control: Constitutionality and Implications

Article:

President Obama announced Tuesday the issuance of an executive order on gun control, focusing on background checks, licensing, and reporting requirements. The order aims to address occasional gun sales and the requirement for physicians to report conversations about guns to the Department of Homeland Security.

An executive order is a written instruction from the president to the executive branch of the federal government, outlining the president's desired enforcement of federal laws or regulations. Executive orders do not apply to private persons or branches of government other than the executive. Executive orders remain in effect until abandoned or rescinded by the president who issued them or a successor president.

However, President Obama's executive order on guns faces constitutional challenges due to the extensive, detailed, and clear nature of congressional legislation on the matter. Congress has expressly removed occasional sales from the obligation of obtaining federal licenses and conducting background checks. The president's attempt to require background checks for occasional sellers may be deemed unconstitutional, as it negates the congressional will on this matter.

The president's order also requires physicians to report conversations about guns to the Department of Homeland Security, potentially infringing on the patient-physician privilege. This requirement may encourage governmental intrusion into private conversations, a fundamental liberty protected by the Constitution.

The right to keep and bear arms is a fundamental liberty under the Constitution, accorded the highest protection from governmental intrusion. The president's executive order, which expands the scope of gun control, may be seen as a step towards totalitarianism, as it potentially infringes on this fundamental right.

Under the Constitution, Congress writes the laws, the president enforces them, and the courts interpret them. President Obama's executive order, which effectively writes new laws and interprets existing ones, may be deemed unconstitutional. The courts will ultimately determine the validity of the president's executive order on guns.

Title: Nasa's Parker Solar Probe Launches Successfully, Aims to Unravel Sun's Mysteries

Article:

The United States' space agency, Nasa, has successfully launched its mission to send the Parker Solar Probe closer to the Sun than any before. The probe, named after astrophysicist Eugene Parker, lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, on August 12, 2018.

The Parker Solar Probe is set to become the fastest-moving manmade object in history. Its data promises to crack longstanding mysteries about the Sun's behavior. The mission is the first spacecraft to be named after a living person, with Parker, 91, having first described solar wind in 1958.

The launch took place at 03:31 local time (07:31 GMT) with the Delta-IV Heavy rocket. The launch came after a failed attempt the previous day due to a last-minute alarm that caused the agency to miss its 65-minute window. Just under an hour after the launch, Nasa confirmed that the spacecraft had successfully separated and the probe had been released into space.

The probe aims to dip directly into our star's outer atmosphere, or corona. It will zip past Venus in six weeks and make a first rendezvous with the Sun a further six weeks after that. Over the course of seven years, Parker will make 24 loops around our star to study the physics of the corona, the place where much of the important activity that affects the Earth seems to originate.

The probe will dip inside this tenuous atmosphere, sampling conditions, and getting to just 6.16 million km (3.83 million miles) from the Sun's broiling "surface". Dr. Nicky Fox, the UK-born project scientist who is affiliated with the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory, explained, "I realize that might not sound that close, but imagine the Sun and the Earth were a meter apart. Parker Solar Probe would be just 4cm away from the Sun."

The probe will also be the fastest man-made object ever, traveling at speeds of up to 430,000mph [690,000km/h] - a speed that would take it from New York to Tokyo in under a minute. The mission is expected to provide valuable insights into the Sun's behavior, potentially improving our understanding of solar activity and its impact on Earth.

Title: Reporters Committee Urges Washington Court to Quash Subpoena Aimed at Seattle News Outlets Over Protest Footage

A legal organization, the Reporters Committee, has filed a brief with the King County Superior Court, urging it to quash a subpoena issued to five Seattle news organizations. The subpoena, served earlier this month by the Seattle Police Department, demands the outlets to hand over all raw footage and photographs taken within a several block radius during a 90-minute period on May 30, a day marked by protests against police violence and racial injustice.

The police department seeks the footage to aid in identifying suspects involved in the arson of a police car and the theft of firearms during the protest. In a friend-of-the-court brief filed on June 29, the Reporters Committee argues that the subpoena is unenforceable, as it allegedly violates the Washington shield law, the First Amendment, and creates an impression that journalists serve as an extension of law enforcement.

The brief expresses concern that enforcing the subpoena could lead to further violence against journalists, as some protesters view journalists as being allied with the police. A journalist covering a Tucson protest, despite wearing press credentials, was assaulted by protesters who believed he was working with the police.

The brief states, "Enforcement of the Subpoena could mislead the public into perceiving reporters at protests as a mere arm of law enforcement, thus eroding public trust in the news media and increasing the already-significant risk of physical harm that journalists face when covering protests."

The Reporters Committee, which regularly files friend-of-the-court briefs and represents journalists and news organizations pro bono in court cases involving First Amendment freedoms, newsgathering rights of journalists, and access to public information, encourages readers to stay informed about their work by signing up for their monthly newsletter and following them on Twitter or Instagram.

Title: Morgan Stanley Strategist Sees Parallels Between Current Market Recovery and 2009, Predicts Rally in Financial Sector

Article:

In the wake of the coronavirus-induced recession, the financial crisis of a decade ago serves as a significant point of reference for investors, with some arguing that the ensuing bear market took 18 months to reach its lowest point, while others believe swift government intervention has prevented a similar fate for the current market.

Michael Wilson, the head of U.S. equity strategy at Morgan Stanley, is among the optimists, likening the current market recovery to March 2009, when the U.S. economy was emerging from the crisis, and the S&P 500 index was beginning its longest bull-market run in history.

In a note to clients on Monday, Wilson noted that the market's trajectory closely mirrors the Great Financial Crisis period in many ways. He observed that stocks have rebounded in a "similar pattern" to March 2009, with the number of individual stocks trading above their 200-day moving average beginning to climb, supported by cyclical stocks like small-capitalization stocks, which typically lead at the beginning of recoveries.

Another similarity between the two periods is the equity-risk premium, or the expected earnings yield for the S&P 500 minus the 10-year Treasury yield, which gives investors a rough estimate of the extra return they'll get investing in stocks compared with risk-free government bonds. Wilson's bullish call in March, when he predicted a stock-market bottom on March 16, was based on the equity-risk premium reaching the same levels observed in March 2009.

Though traditional cyclical stocks like small-caps have outperformed of late, other sectors, such as financial stocks, have not. In fact, bank stocks are performing worse relative to the S&P 500 than during the bank-driven financial crisis. Wilson attributes this dynamic to the Federal Reserve's stimulus measures, which he believes are repressing government bond yields in a way that is scaring bank investors.

"The biggest headwind for banks is the persistently low level of rates," particularly for longer-term debt, Wilson wrote. Low interest rates hurt banks because they lower the profit margins they can earn by issuing loans.

However, Wilson believes the market is underestimating the chances that longer-term bond yields, like the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note, will rise significantly as the economy recovers from the coronavirus, and is therefore underestimating chances for a huge rally in financial-sector stocks. He points to Congress passing at least $3 trillion in fiscal stimulus, the potential for a faster and more sustained recovery in the post-coronavirus economy, and unexpected inflation as demand returns before supply chains can adjust as possible catalysts for higher inflation and long-term interest rates.

"While hypothetical, these are real possibilities and worth considering given current levels of inflation and 10-year Treasury yields," Wilson wrote. "We continue to think higher 10-year rates would be perhaps the biggest surprise to markets at the moment and would have significant implications for equity markets and leadership."

Title: Key Democratic Figures Remain Neutral in 2016 Presidential Primary Race

Article:

As the 2016 Democratic presidential primary race heats up, key party figures are remaining neutral, according to a report by The Hill. Despite Hillary Clinton's alleged backing from the Democratic establishment, she has not been able to attract the support of several prominent party figures.

President Barack Obama, who previously named Clinton as the nation's top diplomat, has announced his intention to vote in the March 15 primary in Illinois. This decision could send a strong signal as he could potentially abstain from voting for Clinton.

Vice President Joe Biden, who declined to challenge Clinton for the nomination in October, has yet to announce his support for the former first lady. Instead, he criticized her for a statement made at a debate and warned against candidates attacking President Obama's record.

Senate minority leader Harry Reid, who announced in June that he would soon endorse a candidate, has yet to make an official endorsement. House minority leader Nancy Pelosi, who has strongly indicated her support for Clinton, has not yet formally endorsed her.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts senator and a prominent progressive Democrat, adamantly insisted that she was not running for the nomination despite being heavily recruited by fellow Democrats.

Richard Trumka, the head of the nation's largest federation of labor unions, the AFL-CIO, has praised both Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden. However, some labor leaders have criticized Clinton for her support of some of President Obama's trade legislation.

California Governor Jerry Brown, who challenged Bill Clinton for the nomination in 1992, has been critical of Hillary Clinton during her email scandal, but has spoken warmly of her in recent months.

Clinton currently holds the most endorsements in the primary race, with 145 House members, 38 of the 46 senators who caucus with Democrats, 12 governors, and 17 national unions backing her. By comparison, Bernie Sanders has been endorsed by two members of Congress and three labor groups.

As the primary race continues, several key Democrats and groups remain on the sidelines, including President Obama, Vice President Biden, Sen. Harry Reid, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, Richard Trumka, and Gov. Jerry Brown. The lack of endorsements from these influential figures could potentially impact the outcome of the primary race.

Title: Trump Disputes Media Perception of Assange Allegiance, Cites Intelligence Community Support

Article:

In a series of tweets on Thursday, President-elect Donald Trump disputed the media's portrayal of his perceived agreement with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, stating that he merely reports what Assange states and leaves the interpretation of truth to the public.

Trump's tweets read, "The dishonest media likes saying that I am in Agreement with Julian Assange - wrong. I simply state what he states, it is for the people to make up their own minds as to the truth. The media lies to make it look like I am against ‘Intelligence’ when in fact I am a big fan!"

The U.S. intelligence community has long maintained that Russia was responsible for cyberattacks targeting American political entities, with the hacked emails from prominent Democratic individuals and institutions being released by WikiLeaks and similar sites. Assange, who has been residing in the Ecuadorian embassy in London since 2012 to avoid extradition on sexual assault charges, has stated that his source for the emails was not a foreign state.

Trump's citation of Assange stems primarily from his Wednesday tweet, which read, "Julian Assange said ‘a 14-year-old could have hacked Podesta’ - why was DNC so careless? Also said Russians did not give him the info!"

Trump's stance on WikiLeaks in 2010, when the website published thousands of pages of classified information provided by Chelsea Manning, an Army private at the time, was markedly different. A tape uncovered by CNN revealed that Trump, in a conversation with Fox News host Brian Kilmeade, said, "I think it's disgraceful, I think there should be like death penalty or something" when asked about WikiLeaks.

Rather than accepting the assessment of the intelligence community, Trump has argued that identifying the true culprit behind the cyberattacks would be nearly impossible and has suggested that he possesses information regarding the cyberattacks that others do not. He and his team have argued that the assessment of the CIA and the FBI that Russia acted to aid Trump's candidacy and install him as president represents an attempt to delegitimize the incoming administration.

Trump is scheduled to receive a briefing on Friday from the nation's top intelligence officials outlining the government's evidence implicating Russia in the cyberattacks. Trump had previously stated that the briefing was scheduled for earlier in the week, but a U.S. official disputed this claim, telling ███ that the president-elect's briefing was always scheduled for Friday.

Sen. Tim Kaine (D-Va.), who ran against Trump as Democrat Hillary Clinton's vice presidential pick, expressed shock at Trump's citation of Assange. While the FBI and CIA are the only two intelligence agencies whose assessments regarding Russia's motives have been made public, Kaine, a member of the Senate Armed Services and Foreign Relations committees, told CNN's "New Day" that it was the "unanimous conclusion" of the intelligence professionals who had briefed him that Russia had indeed sought to aid Trump's campaign.

"I note that he does not go to his intelligence briefings most days. I do go to my intelligence briefings, and I know what the evidence is. If he went to his intelligence briefings, maybe he'd have a different conclusion about this," Kaine said in his first national TV interview since the presidential election. "There's something very unusual, indeed even sort of suspicious, about the degree to which he casually kicks aside the intelligence community when he won't even go to the briefings and again and again takes the Assange-Vladimir Putin line on this important question."

Title: " Obama's Approach to National Security Policies: A Shift from Bush Era, Yet a Continuation of Counterterrorism Measures"

Article:

In a recent interview, Michael Allen, a former Bush aide and author of "Blinking Red," has raised questions about President Obama's response to reviews of his national security policies. Allen suggests that when disagreeing with such reviews, Obama should make it clear that he is largely adopting the recommendations, but not without reservations.

Allen, now managing director of Beacon Global Strategies, expresses concern that Obama's response might lead to overcorrection, potentially exposing the country to more danger. He anticipates Obama might say, "We need to make a major course correction."

Upon taking office, President Obama inherited many of the counterterrorism measures from President Bush's second term. Bush had already moderated his counterterrorism program, ceasing waterboarding, emptying secret C.I.A. prisons, transferring many prisoners from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and securing bipartisan legislation on detention, interrogation, and surveillance.

Obama made adjustments to these policies but largely kept the program intact, even expanding it in the case of drone strikes. This shift in policy was further influenced by an extremist's attempt to detonate an airliner with explosives during Obama's first presidential Christmas in Hawaii.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, a Republican critic, has characterized Obama as more authoritarian than Bush on privacy issues. Paul, who has been alarmed by disclosures about N.S.A. programs, believes they are more alarming than he had initially anticipated.

White House officials dispute such characterizations, but the momentum to revamp N.S.A. rules comes at a time when Obama also faces other decisions on how much to shift course. Allies are pressing him to support the release of a comprehensive Senate report on the history of interrogations and torture. The president is also left to decide how much to scale back drone strikes, as he signaled he planned to do in a speech this year.

Adm. Dennis C. Blair, Obama's first director of national intelligence, urges a broader debate on national security policies, not just surveillance. Blair criticizes the administration's approach as "small-ball play," suggesting that the administration is not genuinely seeking debate but rather a debate about the balance between security and privacy that the nation desires.

Title: Obama's Second-Term Legacy Takes Shape as President Pursues Unilateral Action on Key Policy Issues

Article:

In the final years of his second term, President Barack Obama has intensified his efforts to advance his policy agenda without securing congressional approval, a strategy that could yield swift results but may also face potential undoing by lawmakers or a future president.

The latest example of this approach was the President's policy, announced Thursday, to shield more than four million illegal immigrants from deportation. The President has also announced an aggressive climate deal with China, presided over an Environmental Protection Agency plan to order carbon-emission cuts at power plants, and pursued nuclear negotiations with Iran.

Furthermore, the White House has been exploring options to close the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay without Congress's approval.

Unlike earlier this year when the President took steps, for instance, to raise the minimum wage for federal contractors, the current actions are more comprehensive in scope.

With prospects uncertain for passing major legislation in the new, Republican-controlled Congress, President Obama has begun to build a second-term legacy that is likely to be defined in large part by unilateral action.

However, this strategy comes with risks. Republican lawmakers have threatened to undo the President's actions, and a future president may potentially reverse some of President Obama's moves on immigration and climate change.

More immediately, the President's decision to bypass lawmakers could diminish the chances of forging agreements with Republican leaders on other issues. GOP lawmakers warned that President Obama would "poison the well" by acting unilaterally on immigration.

In an interview that aired Sunday on ABC, President Obama said, "What the American people expect is that if we disagree on one thing... then we work on everything else."

Suggesting that the legislative process wasn't at an end, some Republicans said the party should respond to President Obama by taking the reins on policy and passing GOP-sponsored immigration bills, though it remained unclear what policy the party would put forward and whether President Obama would sign on.

"It's incumbent on Republicans to come up with our own agenda, a positive, constructive agenda," said Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX) on CBS on Sunday. McCaul, who leads the House Homeland Security Committee, said such an effort likely would lead with a border-security bill, but noted that Congress wouldn't take up the issue until next year.

President Obama said in the interview that both Republican and Democratic presidents have taken similar executive actions.

"The history is that I have issued fewer executive actions than most of my predecessors, by a longshot," he said. "Take a look at the track records of the modern presidency; I've actually been very restrained. And I've been very restrained with respect to immigration."

The first two years of President Obama's second term yielded few legislative victories and little progress on the White House's top goals, such as raising the minimum wage and enacting comprehensive immigration legislation.

President Obama largely was sidelined during this fall's campaigns, and Republicans cast Democratic defeats in the midterm elections as a rejection of the President's policies.

The White House has resolved to push forward on President Obama's agenda during the remaining two years.

"He does feel the pressure of time," Dan Pfeiffer, an Obama senior adviser, said Friday at a breakfast sponsored by the Christian Science Monitor. "We all do."

On both immigration and climate change, the President tried but failed to work with Congress to pass legislation before acting on his own. In addition to striking a deal with China to cut carbon pollution, President Obama has laid out aggressive limits on power-plant emissions, another unilateral move that could stand as one of the more far-reaching actions of the second term.

William Galston, a former policy adviser to President Bill Clinton, said acting on immigration and climate change always have been priorities for President Obama, but they have risen in importance as legislative avenues have been closed off.

"Things that you can get done through executive decisions look much more attractive in highly polarized circumstances," said Mr. Galston, who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

White House officials also see a range of opportunities to define the President's second term in the foreign-policy realm.

The Obama administration has continued to press for an agreement with Iran on its nuclear program, despite skepticism in Congress. Some Republican lawmakers have suggested that they would move to impose more sanctions on Iran if they aren't comfortable with a deal. President Obama said in the ABC interview that he remained confident that if an agreement is reached, he could convince Congress it is the right thing to do.

President Obama also appears determined to make good on a campaign promise to close the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba—another potentially dramatic use of executive power. The White House has discussed ways to override a congressional ban on bringing detainees to the U.S., senior administration officials have said.

While the President has said he wants to work with Congress, he and his advisers recently have struck a more defiant tone about President Obama's powers to act on his own. President Obama has said he has an answer for lawmakers who question his authority on immigration: "Nobody is stopping them from passing a bill."

John Podesta, counselor to the President, predicted that Republicans who want to undo the President's power-plant rules would fail, saying, "I don't believe they can stop us from doing that."

Such statements have fanned discord between the White House and the GOP. But on Sunday, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) placed blame on both his party and the President, saying "shame on us as Republicans" for failing to pass legislation to overhaul the immigration system.

"My party has failed," he said on CNN. "This president has failed miserably, and he's made it worse."

Title: The Transformation of the Republican Party: A Look Back at the 2010 Elections and the Rise of Donald Trump

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the Republican Party is currently undergoing a significant transformation, a shift that can be traced back to the 2010 elections and the emergence of Donald Trump as a prominent figure in the party.

Conservative activist and talk-radio host Laura Ingraham recently commented, "They have to come to terms with what they created. They'll talk about everything except the fact that their policies are unpopular." This statement underscores the growing disconnect between the Republican establishment and their downscale voters, a divide that was magnified by the Supreme Court's 2010 decision in the Citizens United case, which increased the influence of wealthy donors in Republican circles.

In the years leading up to Trump's presidential campaign, these voters had largely abandoned the increasingly liberal and cosmopolitan Democratic Party. They found a champion in Trump, a blue-collar billionaire who promised to expand Social Security, reject big donor money, challenge Chinese central bankers, and alleviate Americans from unfair competition from foreign workers.

The Democratic Party is also grappling with a populist insurgency this year, driven in part by economic pain and growing anger towards Washington and Wall Street. However, while Senator Bernie Sanders trails Hillary Clinton in delegates, Trump's unlikely campaign has become a seemingly unstoppable force, one that Republican lawmakers, donors, and activists are only now fully confronting.

Foster Friess, a Wyoming investor and significant GOP donor, has noted the neglect of "the people who truly make our country work—the truck drivers, farmers, welders, hospitality workers."

Six years ago, as the 2010 elections neared, everything seemed to be falling into place for the Republican Party. Republicans celebrated an impending repudiation of President Obama in congressional races, in which they would eventually pick up 63 seats. On the ninth floor of the Beresford apartment building on Central Park West, guests clinked glasses at a fund-raiser for Republican Senate candidates hosted by Paul Singer, the billionaire investor. Singer, a self-described Goldwater conservative and proponent of an immigration overhaul deal, had tripled his campaign giving, doling out almost $3 million in contributions to Republicans in 2010.

Today, the Republican Party, once a stronghold of traditional conservatism, is being reshaped by the populist sentiments of its voters, a transformation that continues to unfold.

Title: Special Counsel Recommends Up to Six Months' Imprisonment for George Papadopoulos for Lying to FBI in Russia Investigation

Article:

In a recent court filing, special counsel Robert Mueller has recommended a sentence of up to six months in prison for George Papadopoulos, a former aide to Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, for lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russian officials during the campaign. The recommendation, which includes a strong rebuke of Papadopoulos for failing to assist with the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 elections, was made in documents filed with the court.

Prosecutors did not make a specific recommendation but urged the judge to give Papadopoulos jail time and said a sentence within the guideline range of up to six months imprisonment was "appropriate and warranted." The government stated that Papadopoulos should be held accountable for having repeatedly misled them about critical facts in an investigation of national importance, after having been explicitly warned that lying to the FBI was a federal offense.

Papadopoulos' wife, Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos, told ABC7 Chicago I-Team on Friday evening that "unfortunately they [prosecutors] didn't value George's cooperation." She said that federal authorities have ignored evidence favorable to her husband.

Papadopoulos, who had served as a volunteer to the Trump team, traveled as an emissary from the campaign to foreign leaders in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. In July 2017, he was charged with lying to the FBI about his contacts during the campaign with a professor who had "substantial connections to Russian government officials."

Court records filed by special counsel Robert Mueller describe how the professor approached Papadopoulos after learning of his role in the Trump campaign. The professor, who has since been widely identified as Joseph Mifsud, told Papadopoulos the Russians had "dirt" on Democrat Hillary Clinton in the form of "thousands of emails" that they had procured, according to the court documents.

Papadopoulos reportedly bragged about that offer to an Australian diplomat, who then tipped off the FBI and launched that agency's counterintelligence investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Papadopoulos was arrested by the FBI when he arrived at Dulles International Airport in July 2017 and charged under seal. He agreed to cooperate with investigators in exchange for a lighter sentence.

The government's sentencing recommendation includes clear signs that the Mueller team felt betrayed by Papadopoulos after he struck a plea agreement and pledged his full cooperation. The filing says Papadopoulos repeatedly withheld key details about his contacts with Russians and neglected to turn over the cell phone he used to communicate with Mifsud until the government expressly asked for it.

"His lies negatively affected the FBI's Russia investigation, and prevented the FBI from effectively identifying and confronting witnesses in a timely fashion," the filing says. "His lies were not momentary lapses. He lied repeatedly over the course of more than two hours, and his lies were designed to conceal facts he knew were critical: the importance of the information he received from the Professor, and his own communications and contacts with Russians and Russian intermediaries during the Trump campaign."

The filing also says that, even after his initial FBI interview, Papadopoulos made repeated attempts to land jobs with the fledgling Trump administration, including a high-level post with the National Security Council.

Papadopoulos' legal team will file their own sentencing assessment to the court in two weeks, and is expected to ask for probation. The sentence recommendation comes as Simona Mangiante Papadopoulos has mounted the latest in a series of publicity campaigns, this one suggesting her husband has misgivings about his plea agreement.

Back in December, in an interview with ABC's George Stephanopoulos, she had described her spouse as the "John Dean" of the Russia probe, a reference to the Watergate-era former White House counsel who pleaded guilty to conspiracy to obstruct justice and became a key witness against President Richard Nixon and his aides.

Earlier this month, Papadopoulos received a sealed sentencing document prepared for the court. After that, the defendant's wife began an aggressive media blitz in which she strongly hinted her husband is considering changing lawyers and rescinding his plea deal.

After appearing before Democratic members of the House intelligence committee earlier this summer, she said that Papadopoulos has come to believe the professor may have been working for Western intelligence agencies and set him up.

"I actually never said explicitly that it was an entrapment from the FBI. I just said that he definitely was... the target of a different set-up," she said.

In June, the Daily Caller News Foundation reported that Simona Papadopoulos said, "It looks to be one among a series of attempts to entrap George," adding, "The question today to me [is whether] these people are simply shady businessmen or are they part of a greater attempt to entrap George in illegal activity."

Since her husband's guilty plea in exchange for cooperation with the Mueller probe, Papadopoulos has been living in Chicago. Federal investigators have imposed restrictions on his travel until his sentencing, which is now scheduled for September 7.

Title: Garza v. Hargan: A Controversial Court Case Divides Judge Brett Kavanaugh on Abortion Rights for Illegal Immigrant Minors

Article:

The ongoing court case, Garza v. Hargan, has become a significant point of contention for Judge Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's nominee to the Supreme Court. The case, which revolves around an illegal immigrant teen held in government custody seeking an abortion, has drawn criticism from both pro-life and pro-choice activists for Kavanaugh's attempts to find a middle ground.

The case, known as Jane Doe, involved an unaccompanied minor who crossed the U.S. border last year and was sent to a government-funded facility. After undergoing a medical examination, she was informed that she was pregnant. She expressed her desire for an abortion, but the Trump administration delayed the request, citing its interest in protecting the fetus while the girl was in government custody.

The girl had the necessary funding for the abortion procedure and obtained a judge's consent in Texas. However, the government argued that it would still be required to transport her and provide post-procedure care, which Justice Department lawyers argued would violate federal law prohibiting taxpayer spending on elective abortions.

The government proposed that it should be given the opportunity to place the girl with a family member or willing sponsor in the U.S., arguing that they would be best equipped to help her make such a significant decision. A lower court ruled in favor of the girl and the American Civil Liberties Union, which represented her in the case.

However, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court for the District of Columbia, led by Judge Kavanaugh, sided with the government, overturning the lower court's decision. The full D.C. Circuit later overturned the three-judge panel's decision, ruling that illegal immigrants have a right to abortion and that the Trump administration's efforts to delay in order to find a sponsor were infringing on that right.

Judge Kavanaugh penned a dissent, stating that the majority's decision established "a new right for unlawful immigrant minors in U.S. government detention to obtain immediate abortion on demand." The Supreme Court later erased the lower court's opinion, citing that the girl had rushed to get an abortion, and thus, there was no longer a live controversy.

The ruling has left activists on all sides frustrated. Sen. Kamala Harris, a California Democrat, expressed her opposition to Judge Kavanaugh's nomination, stating that he disregarded Supreme Court precedent and opposed the health care rights of a vulnerable young woman.

From the right, the American Family Association and the Susan B. Anthony List have expressed concerns with Judge Kavanaugh's ruling, finding it insufficient in upholding abortion rights restrictions. They also raised questions about a 2015 opinion Kavanaugh authored in another major case, Priests for Life v. HHS, where he ruled for the priests but not broadly enough for some conservatives.

However, the Rev. Frank Pavone, national director of Priests for Life, expressed delight at Judge Kavanaugh's selection, while the Susan B. Anthony List praised Kavanaugh for reaching the right conclusions in both Priests for Life and Garza, where they said he rejected the ACLU's assertion of a constitutional right to abortion on demand for illegal immigrants.

In conclusion, the Garza v. Hargan case has become a significant point of contention for Judge Brett Kavanaugh, with activists on both sides of the abortion debate expressing concerns about his rulings on the matter. The case has left a lasting impact on the debate surrounding abortion rights for illegal immigrant minors in government custody.

Title: Modest Deficit Reduction Goals Raise Concerns for Future Fiscal Policy

Article:

In a recent development, some on the political left are defining successful deficit reduction as stabilizing the federal debt at about 70 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by 2022. This goal, according to several economists and financial experts, is far too modest and could leave future fiscal policy perilously constrained.

Under current assumptions, achieving this goal would require combined reductions in spending growth and/or increases in taxes of $1.4 trillion over the 2014-2022 period. This is significantly less than the total deficit reduction provided by the 2011 Budget Control Act (BCA) and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2013 (ATRA), which resolved the 2011 debt ceiling debate and avoided the fiscal cliff, respectively.

Richard Kogan of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, supported by Martin Wolf of the Financial Times, argues for more modest deficit reduction. The editorial page of the Washington Post shares similar concerns, stating that the proposed goals are dangerously modest.

The potential consequences of such a low deficit reduction target become particularly evident when considering the next economic recession. With a debt-GDP ratio already above 70 percent, a recession would likely push the ratio above 100 percent, making it harder to argue for stimulus measures and potentially leading to a more severe recession.

However, if the economy manages to maintain a steady growth path without a recession, the deficit associated with stabilizing the debt-GDP ratio at 70 percent of GDP would be more than 10 percent higher than that consistent with a 60 percent ratio – the limit chosen by the drafters of the Maastricht treaty that created the Euro. This significant increase in the rate at which the nation's wealth is being depleted could have long-term negative effects on the standard of living for future generations.

Kogan and Wolf assume that the discretionary spending caps imposed by the BCA through 2021 will be enforced successfully. These caps imply that discretionary spending will fall to the lowest level relative to GDP since World War II. They would also require both defense and non-defense outlays to grow less than the rate of inflation from 2014 to 2021, after already falling considerably from the levels inflated by the stimulus and the recession.

The biggest risk is that it will be impossible to maintain defense at such low levels, as demonstrated by the ongoing war on terror and the rapid growth of the Chinese defense budget. In non-defense, population growth will put upward pressure on spending for programs like education, infrastructure, and national parks. True reforms in Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid have a better chance of lasting than arbitrary caps on discretionary spending that do not specify individual program cuts.

Rudolph G. Penner, an Institute Fellow at the Urban Institute and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987, warns that sovereign debt crises occur at all manner of debt-GDP ratios and are impossible to predict. However, it is hard to believe that a higher ratio does not increase the risk to some degree. In 2008, just before their crises, the net debt to GDP ratio in Spain was less than 31 percent and in Ireland less than 25 percent.

Title: Impact of Scalia's Death on Texas Abortion Case and Future Reproductive Rights

Article:

The death of Justice Antonin Scalia, who passed away over the weekend, may significantly alter the outcome of the upcoming U.S. Supreme Court abortion case, and potentially reshape the future of reproductive rights in the United States.

The Supreme Court is set to hear its most significant abortion case in at least a decade, concerning a Texas law that requires doctors to have local hospital admitting privileges and clinics to undergo costly building upgrades to operate as outpatient surgical centers. With Scalia's absence, a 4-4 split in the court could leave the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that upheld these provisions in place, potentially leading to the closure of several abortion clinics in Texas.

Ilyse Hogue, president of NARAL Pro-Choice America, states, "We would be looking at an even greater healthcare crisis in Texas than we're already facing." This situation would exacerbate existing issues, as Texas already has half its clinics closed due to other state-imposed restrictions.

However, a 4-4 split decision would not set a national precedent. This means that other appeals court rulings striking down similar laws would also stand. Hogue notes, "There are so many laws looking to restrict not only abortion access and abortion rights but a broader set of reproductive rights in front of the court right now."

Another significant case set to be heard next month involves a challenge to the Affordable Care Act's mandate on covering birth control for female employees. Additionally, there is a wave of abortion restrictions passed since 2011, with many cases making their way through the appeals courts.

Abortion opponents, who had relied on Scalia's support, view him as a staunch ally in their efforts to restrict abortion. Clarke Forsythe, senior counsel with Americans United for Life, states, "He was one of the two justices on the court who has publicly opposed Roe v. Wade in prior cases and prior votes."

With a potential liberal majority, Forsythe foresees a significant rollback of decades of abortion restrictions. He suggests that a liberal Supreme Court may overturn the ban on public funding for the procedure, known as the Hyde Amendment, a policy both presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have pledged to overturn.

Forsythe also anticipates a liberal Supreme Court "will probably throw out all parental notice and parental consent laws in the country, will throw out all informed consent laws in the country, and virtually any regulation, and create an absolute right to abortion for any reason at any time that we have not seen in 42 years."

Abortion rights groups, however, view these predictions as speculative at best. As both sides prepare for a fierce battle over Scalia's replacement, the future of reproductive rights in the United States hangs in the balance.

Title: Income Growth and Poverty Rate Decline in 2015: A Significant Shift in Economic Trends

Article:

The United States Census Bureau's annual report on household incomes and poverty rates for 2015 has revealed a significant shift in economic trends, with median household income growing by 5.2 percent in real terms, or $2,800, and the poverty rate decreasing from 14.8 percent to 13.5 percent.

According to the report, the income growth was particularly pronounced at the lower end of the income distribution. People at the 10th percentile, or the poor, saw their incomes grow by 7.9 percent, compared to a 3.7 percent increase for those at the 95th percentile. This income growth led to a decrease in income inequality between 2014 and 2015, although it does not reverse the long-term upward trend in inequality.

The report also showed a decline in the supplemental poverty measure (SPM), a metric that takes into account all important social programs and the cost of basic goods like food, clothing, shelter, and utilities. The SPM fell by a full percentage point, from 15.3 percent to 14.3 percent, with 45.7 million people in poverty in 2015, 2.7 million fewer than in 2014.

The report also highlighted the ongoing rollout of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), which continued a trend toward lower and lower uninsured rates. The rate for 2015 was 9.1 percent, and more recent federal data shows that in the first quarter of 2016, that rate fell even further to 8.6 percent, the lowest on record. The drops in uninsurance for poor Americans were concentrated in states that participated in the law's Medicaid expansion, but even non-expanding states saw some declines.

Overall, the report suggests that the gains of the ongoing economic recovery are finally being broadly shared, although it would take multiple reports like this to reverse longstanding trends in income inequality and poor median income growth.

Title: U.S. Capitol Hosts Controversial Netanyahu Speech Amidst Political Tensions

Article:

The highly anticipated speech of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to the U.S. Congress has become a focal point of political tension, with the Democrats' decision to boycott the address causing a shift in the narrative. Instead of sidelining Netanyahu, as initially intended, the speech has garnered global attention, with the U.S. Capitol now the center of attention.

What was once expected to be a one-day story has evolved into a continuing saga, raising questions for President Barack Obama and the Democrats. The Democrats, once staunch supporters of Israel, have recently expressed criticism towards the Jewish state. Secretary of State John F. Kerry has referred to Israel as an "apartheid state," while former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has denounced Israel for the "brutal occupation" of the West Bank and the deprivation of "dignity and self-determination" for the Palestinians.

The Democrats' cooled stance on Israel has left many wondering about President Obama's motivations, as he prepares to face the plain-spoken Netanyahu. Speculation surrounds potential disclosures that may emerge from discussions between Israel and Obama's administration, with some reports suggesting that Obama once threatened to shoot down Israeli bombers attempting to reach Iranian nuclear reactors.

In his speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, Netanyahu emphasized the longstanding friendship between Israel and the United States, recalling three instances where Israel acted independently to ensure its survival despite American misgivings: the declaration of statehood in 1948, the Six Day War in 1967, and the bombing of the Osirak nuclear reactor in 1981.

The friendship between the two nations has been a topic of debate, with some questioning the current administration's commitment to Israel. President Obama's perceived indecisiveness and lack of resolve has led to comparisons with Netanyahu, who is known for his robust defense of Israel.

As Netanyahu delivers his speech to the joint session of Congress, he aims to remind Americans of their nation's exceptional status, as described by Abraham Lincoln, and to challenge President Obama's approach to Israel. The speech is intended to underscore the importance of maintaining a resolute stance in the face of adversity, a message that resonates in times of uncertainty.

Title: World Bank Forecasts Moderate Global Growth Amidst European Sovereign Debt Crisis

Article:

The World Bank has released its latest global economic outlook, predicting a slightly more pessimistic growth trajectory compared to other forecasters. The International Monetary Fund (IMF), for instance, forecasts a growth of 3.5 percent in 2012 and 4.1 percent in 2013.

The global economic outlook brightened early in 2012, as European leaders pledged to allocate more funds to resolve their sovereign debt crisis and implement policy changes to further unite the Continent. This led to a decrease in European bond yields and an increase in investment. However, the tranquility of winter has given way to market volatility in the spring.

Investors have once again started to punish various European bonds, prompting Spain to request a bailout for its faltering banks last weekend. Political uncertainty is rampant, with a potential Greek exit from the eurozone becoming a more frequent topic of discussion.

In the last few months, fearful investors have reduced their risk exposure, withdrawing funds from around the world and parking them in the safety of assets like American bonds. Capital flows to developing countries fell an astonishing 44 percent from April to May, according to the World Bank's data.

The bank expects such market fluctuations to be common in the post-crisis period, and their effects to be felt globally. "Sharp swings in investor sentiment and financial conditions will continue to complicate the conduct of macro policy in developing countries," the report stated.

Despite the challenges, the World Bank anticipates Europe to navigate its sovereign debt crisis without a market catastrophe, and the world to maintain its sluggish but steady growth path. However, the forecast is not entirely reassuring, as economists at the World Bank, like most forecasters, have a history of failing to predict crises.

"This is the third May or June in a row where Europe has been embroiled in tensions," said World Bank President Robert B. Zoellick. "In each and every previous incident, it has calmed towards the end of June. That is our baseline expectation."

The bank strongly advised developing countries to prepare for market turbulence by strengthening their balance sheets, such as by cutting deficits and reducing short-term debt exposures.

According to the bank's data, about 40 percent of developing countries were running a surplus in 2007, before the global downturn began. Last year, just 19 percent were. "That doesn't mean that their policies have deteriorated," Zoellick said, suggesting that the swing was largely the result of the crisis. However, Zoellick noted that the countries' relatively strong fiscal position heading into the crisis served them well, and he urged them to "move in that direction once again."

More generally, the bank's economists stated that while Europe might pose a short-term threat to middle- and lower-income countries, in the long term, their prospects and growth trajectories remained strong.

In the case of China, for instance, growth "doesn't depend on domestic demand in high-income countries, and ultimately it doesn't depend on their export demand," said Hans Timmer, the director of the World Bank's development prospects group. Future growth would instead come largely from within the country and other poorer but fast-growing economies, he said.

Officials at the bank also warned that high-income countries were not making the necessary changes to ensure their economies would be competitive, prolonging their periods of economic malaise and losing ground to the rest of the world. Such changes might include reducing long-term deficits, making certain industries more competitive, or investing in infrastructure.

"In high-income countries, a good crisis is being wasted," said Timmer.

On Tuesday, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, also warned of a global growth slowdown and renewed threats to financial markets.

"We need a strategy that is good for stability and good for growth," said Lagarde at a Center for Global Development event in Washington, according to her prepared remarks. "This must start with the advanced economies, especially in Europe." Lagarde urged "very accommodating monetary policy," "direct support to banks," and "growth-friendly" fiscal policies.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Takes Lead in National Democratic Primary Polls, Ahead of Biden and Sanders

Article:

In a significant shift in the Democratic primary race, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has surpassed former Vice President Joe Biden in several recent national polls, marking a notable change in the race's dynamics.

According to most national polls since the end of September, Warren, who has been consistently growing in strength since the start of her campaign, is now leading the pack. This change is particularly significant as Biden had led in almost every national poll since 2018, often by double-digit margins.

In the past five polls, Warren has come out on top in four, and in the past ten, she has led in six. The RealClearPolitics average, a frequently cited polling benchmark, now shows Warren ahead of Biden by 0.2%, marking the first time Biden has not held the lead in the race's RCP average since December.

The most recent poll to place her at the top was released Tuesday by Quinnipiac University. This poll found Warren ahead of Biden 29% to 26%, with Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont coming in third at 16%. Among those who described themselves as "very liberal", Warren led Biden 38% to 26%, and among the "somewhat" liberals she led 37% to 23%. Biden led among moderate and conservative Democrats 35% to 22%.

Warren's strong performance extends to the early primary states, which are crucial in securing the nomination. Last month, a Des Moines Register/CNN/Mediacom Iowa Poll found her leading in the first-in-the-nation caucus state, and a Monmouth University poll put her narrowly ahead of Biden in New Hampshire. A Suffolk University/███ Network Poll released on Sept. 24 placed her just 4 points behind Biden in Nevada, the third state where primary voters will cast their ballots.

Elizabeth Warren's latest challenge to the presidency comes as she navigates the ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump. Tuesday's poll from Quinnipiac shows that voters approve of the impeachment inquiry 53% to 43% and that 45% think Trump should be removed from office while 49% do not. This shift in opinion is significant, as the margin was 37% to 57% in a Quinnipiac poll before the inquiry launched.

The poll also reveals that only 34% approve of the way Trump has responded to the impeachment inquiry, compared with 57% who disapprove. However, 43% agreed with the president that it was a "political witch hunt", while 51% said it was a "legitimate investigation".

As the race heats up, both Warren and Biden are seen as strong contenders who could beat Trump in a general election. When asked whom they would vote for if the election was held today, Quinnipiac found that both Warren and Biden would beat the incumbent president – Biden by a margin of 51% to 40%, and Warren by a margin of 49% to 41%.

The shift in the polls has not gone unnoticed by President Trump, who indirectly acknowledged Warren's rise in a tweet Tuesday, calling on his 2016 Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton to "enter the race to try and steal it away from Uber Left Elizabeth Warren".

As the race continues, Warren will face challenges and criticism from her Democratic rivals, but her consistent growth in the polls and strong performance in early primary states suggest she is a formidable contender in the race for the Democratic nomination.

Title: Trump Campaign Loyalists Face Exclusion from Federal Agencies, Alleging Discrimination and Leaks

Article:

Tensions are rising between Donald Trump's campaign workers and GOP veterans as they compete for key positions in federal agencies, with the former group finding themselves losing out more frequently, according to a report by Politico.

From the State Department to the Environmental Protection Agency, campaign staffers, who self-identify as "originals," claim they are being sidelined, as per the website. These individuals allege they have been kept out of meetings and targeted by damaging leaks. A number of Trump supporters, many of whom volunteered to work for him during the campaign, have already resigned from their new roles.

Sid Bowdidge, a Trump campaign staffer who reportedly quit his Energy Department job after allegations of anti-Muslim slurs on social media, blames these stories on leaks by rival coworkers, as noted by Politico. Bowdidge stated, "You're always watching your back." He further added, "How can you when people are looking over their shoulder to see if they have a knife in their back?"

Many of the campaign loyalists were placed in agencies on Inauguration Day to help smooth the presidential transition. They are often referred to as the "beachhead" team. CBS News reports that about a dozen members of the beachhead team at the U.S. Agriculture have been informed they would not receive permanent positions at the department. Other agencies, including Treasury and Transportation, have notified former campaign workers that their jobs are ending, according to the network news.

One former campaign staffer, who was not offered a full-time role at his agency, commented, "The perception (among agency staff) is, we were Mr. Trump's goons who were good at knocking on doors, but can't do much else."

Meanwhile, some Cabinet secretaries have privately expressed concerns about being forced to take employees with little, if any, relevant expertise, as reported by Politico. However, the Trump loyalists insist they do not deserve to be cast aside.

A former campaign aide lamented, "As we get further away from Inauguration Day, it is very obvious that no one cares what happens to the people who worked for the campaign or who have loyalty to the president." The aide concluded, "The swamp is winning the battle. And longtime campaign staffers are proving to be the first casualties."

Title: Trump Denies Firing Comey Over Russia Investigation, Amidst Ongoing Obstruction of Justice Inquiry

Article:

WASHINGTON — In a series of tweets on Thursday, President Donald Trump asserted that he did not dismiss FBI Director James Comey due to the Russia investigation, despite video and documentary evidence suggesting otherwise.

"Not that it matters but I never fired James Comey because of Russia!" Trump tweeted before departing for a fundraising trip to Texas. "The Corrupt Mainstream Media loves to keep pushing that narrative, but they know it is not true!"

This statement comes two days after Trump's May 9, 2017, dismissal of Comey. Initially, Trump told NBC News that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein had endorsed Comey's firing, but he would have taken the same action without the recommendation, citing Russia as a reason.

"And, in fact, when I decided to just do it, I said to myself, I said, 'you know, this Russia thing with Trump and Russia is a made-up story,'" Trump told NBC's Lester Holt. "It’s an excuse by the Democrats for having lost an election that they should’ve won."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., responded to Trump's claim, tweeting, "Let's go to the videotape."

The assertion came a day after news broke that former deputy FBI director Andrew McCabe authored a memo quoting Rosenstein as saying that Trump asked him to refer to the Russia investigation as a reason for recommending Comey's dismissal.

However, the Rosenstein memo focused on Comey's overall management of the bureau, including his handling of the Hillary Clinton private email server case.
