The day after Comey's firing, Trump reportedly told visiting Russian diplomats that "I just fired the head of the FBI. He was crazy, a real nut job. I faced great pressure because of Russia. That’s taken off."

Additionally, Trump and his aides criticized Comey for stating privately that he was not a subject of investigation but would not say so publicly. Meanwhile, Comey has stated that he believes he was fired because he rebuffed Trump's request to go easy on a central figure in the Russia probe, former national security adviser Michael Flynn.

The FBI director's firing is central to an obstruction of justice investigation being conducted by special counsel Robert Mueller, who is also looking into Russian attempts to influence the 2016 election in order to help Trump.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler Outlines Democratic Strategy for Mueller Report Release and Document Requests

Article:

In an interview on ABC's This Week, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler outlined the Democratic strategy for revealing the findings of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation and requested documents from dozens of individuals close to the White House this week. However, Nadler downplayed the possibility of impeaching President Trump, stating that they do not yet have sufficient evidence to initiate impeachment proceedings.

Nadler emphasized the importance of convincing the American people before moving forward with impeachment, stating, "Before you impeach somebody, you have to persuade the American people that it ought to happen." He acknowledged that the high bar of convincing Trump supporters they aren't trying to overturn the last election is a significant challenge.

On Monday, the Democrats will request documents from 60 people, including Donald Trump Jr. and Trump Organization chief financial officer Allan Weisselberg, as part of investigations into obstruction of justice, corruption, and abuse of power. Nadler expressed a desire to see what the special counsel uncovers in terms of Russian meddling in the 2016 campaign, and he plans to subpoena that information if the Justice Department keeps it under wraps.

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy countered that Democrats are on a "fishing expedition" and will latch onto whatever they can to impeach the president. Despite Nadler's claims, McCarthy asserted that there is no collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Nadler responded to these allegations by stating that his side is conducting due diligence after Trump's former attorney, Michael Cohen, implicated the president in crimes, including pay-offs to a porn actress, Stormy Daniels, on the cusp of the election to cover up an alleged affair. Nadler emphasized that seeking to sabotage a fair election would be an impeachable offense, but they are far from making decisions about that.

McCarthy, in turn, argued that Cohen, as an attorney, had a responsibility to advise Trump on the law, and any violations would not be impeachable. The ongoing political drama between the two parties continues to unfold as the Democrats push for transparency and the Republicans maintain their support for the president.

Title: Trump Administration Halts Risk Adjustment Payments for Obamacare Insurers, Sparking Industry Backlash

Article:

In a move that has sparked backlash from the health insurance industry, the Trump administration announced Saturday evening that it is temporarily freezing billions of dollars of payments to health insurance companies intended to help them manage higher-risk patients. The federal government provides Obamacare insurers risk adjustment payments, which are designed to cushion insurers from taking steep losses on high-risk patients in the Obamacare marketplace.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) announced the abrupt halt of these payments Saturday evening, citing a February 2018 ruling from the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico that invalidates them.

"We were disappointed by the court's recent ruling," CMS Administrator Seema Verma said in a statement. "As a result of this litigation, billions of dollars in risk adjustment payments and collections are now on hold. CMS has asked the court to reconsider its ruling, and hopes for a prompt resolution that allows CMS to prevent more adverse impacts on Americans who receive their insurance in the individual and small group markets."

The insurance industry is already speaking out against the administration's decision, calling it a crucial blow during a time when insurance companies are trying to come up with premiums and packages for 2019.

"We are very discouraged by the new market disruption brought about by the decision to freeze risk adjustment payments. This decision comes at a critical time when insurance providers are developing premiums for 2019 and states are reviewing rates," trade group America's Health Insurance Plans (AHIP) said in a statement Saturday. "We encourage the Administration to reevaluate its decision and work with all stakeholders to make health care more affordable for all Americans."

Insurers themselves are voicing concerns for market destabilization following the announcement.

"This action will significantly increase 2019 premiums for millions of individuals and small business owners and could result in far fewer health plan choices," Blue Cross Blue Shield Association President and CEO Scott Serota said in a statement. "It will undermine Americans' access to affordable coverage, particularly those who need medical care the most."

Over the course of his first 18 months in office, the president has targeted Obamacare with a series of moves intended to undermine the system and disrupt the marketplace. The president has rolled back funding for a program intended to help individuals navigate the insurance marketplace, Obamacare's navigator program, signed an executive order to allow for groups to purchase insurance across state lines, stopped federal funding for Obamacare subsidies, pushed for consumer access to more affordable short-term, limited duration health insurance plans, cut Obamacare's open enrollment period in half and its advertising budget 90 percent.

Trump made repealing and replacing Obamacare a key part of his successful bid for the presidency in 2016, but he has, thus far, been unable to materialize that goal. House Republicans passed a bill — the American Health Care Act — in May 2017 after a few months of rocky negotiations that nearly stopped the effort in its tracks. Senate Republicans had a more difficult time, given their 52- and subsequently slim 51-seat majority in the upper chamber. The Senate tried roughly a handful of times in 2017 to repeal and replace Obamacare, offering up a "skinny repeal" in July 2017 with no replacement as a last-ditch effort to overhaul the American health care system. That, too, failed to pass muster within the entirety of either the Republican or Democratic conferences.

Ultimately, Republicans and the White House have moved on from repealing and replacing Obamacare, although a coalition of outside conservative groups have hopes of reviving the debate in the Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has made it clear he is ready to move on from the issue, but he has said he would entertain a proposal that was guaranteed to get enough votes to pass.

Title: Ambassador Gordon Sondland and Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman Recalled Amidst Impeachment Inquiry

In a series of personnel moves that have been met with bipartisan criticism, U.S. Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland and Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, both key witnesses in the ongoing impeachment inquiry, have been recalled.

In a statement released Friday, Ambassador Sondland announced, "I was advised today that the president intends to recall me effective immediately as United States Ambassador to the European Union." He expressed gratitude to President Trump "for having given me the opportunity to serve."

The statement comes hours after Lt. Col. Vindman, another witness in the impeachment inquiry, was ousted from his White House job with the National Security Council.

During the House impeachment inquiry, Ambassador Sondland testified that "everyone was in the loop" about an effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic presidential candidate Joseph R. Biden. This allegation forms the crux of the Democrats' impeachment case against the president.

Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democrat, commented, "Firing Ambassador Sondland and a hero like LTC Vindman for telling the truth is yet more abuse of power by the president." He further tweeted, "These self-serving acts won’t stop until Donald Trump is out of office, or Republicans finally decide to stand up against this petty retaliation."

Tom Fitton, an ally of the president who heads the watchdog group Judicial Watch, approvingly referred to the personnel moves as "cleaning house."

Sen. Bob Menendez of New Jersey, the top Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, described the ousters of Ambassador Sondland, Lt. Col. Vindman, and his twin brother, Yevgeny, from the National Security Council as "clear political retaliation, the likes of which is seen only in authoritarian countries around the world."

Sen. Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, noted that Ambassador Sondland is a political appointee who serves at the pleasure of the president. He tweeted, "No point in having a political appointee who no longer has the President's confidence." Regarding Lt. Col. Vindman, Sen. Rubio stated, "He was assigned to NSC to serve the President who has a right to have people he trusts on his staff."

The ousters of Ambassador Sondland and Lt. Col. Vindman have sparked widespread criticism and concern, with many viewing these moves as an attempt to silence witnesses and obstruct the impeachment inquiry. The developments underscore the ongoing political tension and the high stakes of the impeachment process.

Title: "Rove Critiques Affordable Care Act: Unintended Consequences of Job Hours and Self-Funded Health Plans"

Article:

In a recent opinion piece for The Wall Street Journal, Republican strategist Karl Rove argues that the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has several unintended negative consequences. One of these consequences, according to Rove, is a shift in job hours, with more part-time and fewer full-time jobs being created.

Rove points out that the Affordable Care Act requires companies with at least 50 employees to provide health insurance to any employee working more than 30 hours a week or face a fine. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of hourly employees working 30-34 hours a week has decreased by an average of 146,500 per month over the past year, while the number working 25-29 hours has increased by 119,000 per month.

Rove suggests that this lack of hours can particularly impact single working mothers and younger workers. He also argues that the 50-employee threshold may discourage businesses from growing beyond that size, leading the U.S. to follow in the footsteps of countries with slower economies, such as France.

Another issue Rove raises is the impact of Obamacare on businesses with self-funded health plans. These companies act as their own insurer, collecting premiums and paying claims filed by their workers. According to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey, 61 percent of workers are in self-funded plans. Rove claims that these companies have an incentive to choose self-funding because the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) governs self-funded plans, not the Affordable Care Act.

ERISA allows self-funded plans to charge premiums based on risk, offer a wider menu of options, and avoid expensive provisions such as Obamacare's new tax on insurance policies. However, Rove notes that Obamacare supporters are not fond of the success of these programs in curbing premium increases and managing costs. He mentions that Delaware, New York, and Oregon have already prohibited small- and mid-size companies from using self-insurance plans.

Rove also expresses concern that the new Labor Secretary, Thomas Perez, may issue regulations that erode the attractiveness of self-funded plans and push more companies' health policies into Obamacare's system.

Finally, Rove states that the number of uninsured Americans will not drop below 30 million in the next 10 years, according to the Congressional Budget Office, contradicting Obamacare's promise of "universal" coverage.

Title: Court Documents Reveal Trump University's Sales Techniques and Media Guidelines

Article:

A collection of hundreds of pages of court documents related to Trump University, the real estate and investment training venture of former President Donald Trump, has been released by a federal judge this week. The documents, which include a detailed guide for selling courses and mentoring sessions, as well as dealing with the media, were made available in response to a request from The Washington Post.

The documents, which span several years, can be categorized into two main sections: depositions from Trump University executives and "playbooks" - marketing and strategy plans for selling courses and mentoring sessions. The playbooks emphasize the selling of the "Gold" level courses, which cost nearly $35,000.

The topics covered in the Trump University documents range from expense reporting to sales strategies in various environments, from one-off preview events to three-day sessions. The majority of the pages are marked "Confidential."

The 2008 edition of the playbook includes tips for dealing with the media, starting with directing any reporters to a Trump media contact. The guide also suggests that courtesy gets you a long way.

The playbooks, which span several years, also include Trump University employees' suggested responses to customers who balk at a sale, offering rebuttals to objections that range from a need to consult a spouse to a reluctance to go into debt.

The 2010 Playbook also requires sales staff to "Be Deliberate." Here's that paragraph:

"Be deliberate and conscious when communicating to potential students. Remember that we have time to think and plan and develop questions and commands that lead people into a flow that they must deal with and respond to. Without a game plan you are required to respond to them and do much more thinking on your feet. Remember that we need to stay on 'offense.'"

The playbook also advises Trump's sales teams not to let a lack of money be used as an excuse for turning down Trump University's three-day training.

"Money is never a reason for not enrolling in Trump University," the sales guide states, adding, "if they really believe in you and your product, they will find the money."

The documents and records were ordered to be released by U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel of the Southern District of California, who has been a target of personal attacks from Donald Trump. Trump previously questioned whether Curiel's Hispanic heritage made him biased due to Trump's support for building a wall on the Mexican border.

The documents stem from lawsuits filed by Trump University's customers back in 2013; their case gained new prominence back in February, when Trump's Republican rival Marco Rubio brought them up during a debate. After that debate, Michael Isikoff, the chief investigative correspondent for Yahoo! News, spoke to NPR's Robert Siegel about the former students' complaints against Trump.

Title: Mistrial Declared in Corruption Trial of New Jersey Senator Bob Menendez

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the corruption trial of New Jersey's Democratic U.S. Senator Bob Menendez ended in a mistrial on Thursday, as the jury reported an impasse, unable to reach a unanimous verdict on bribery, fraud, and other charges. The hung jury marks a victory for Menendez and a setback for federal prosecutors in what was the Justice Department's first high-profile corruption trial since the U.S. Supreme Court's decision last year that limited the department's ability to bring such cases.

Menendez, a 63-year-old political veteran who has been a senator since 2006, was accused of accepting private flights, campaign contributions, and other bribes from a wealthy Florida ophthalmologist, Salomon Melgen, in exchange for official favors. One juror, Ed Norris, revealed to reporters that the panel was split 10-2 in favor of acquittal, which could discourage the government from pursuing a second trial.

The Justice Department has yet to announce whether it will seek to retry Menendez, who is expected to run for re-election next year. In a statement, the department said it would "carefully consider next steps." Republican Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, called for the Senate's ethics committee to investigate the allegations against Menendez. The committee confirmed it would resume its inquiry, which was put on hold in 2013 to allow the criminal probe to proceed.

A tearful Menendez thanked God, his family, the jurors, and two senators who testified on his behalf as character witnesses, Democrat Cory Booker and Republican Lindsey Graham, outside the courthouse in Newark, New Jersey. "The way this case started was wrong," said Menendez, flanked by his grown children. "The way it was investigated was wrong. The way it was prosecuted was wrong. The way it was tried was wrong as well."

The mistrial provides at least a temporary measure of relief for Menendez's Democratic colleagues in the Senate, where Republicans would likely have pushed for resignation or expulsion if Menendez had been convicted. The case was seen as a test for prosecutors in the wake of last year's Supreme Court ruling that vacated the bribery conviction of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell. In doing so, the high court narrowed the grounds for corruption cases.

During the 10-week trial, prosecutors accused Menendez of pressuring Medicare officials to change the agency's billing practices after it concluded that Melgen overbilled it by millions of dollars. Melgen, Menendez's co-defendant in the corruption trial, was separately convicted in Florida earlier this year of a massive Medicare fraud. According to the government, Menendez also helped secure visas for the married Melgen's foreign girlfriends and asked U.S. officials to resolve a port dispute in the Dominican Republic involving one of Melgen's businesses. In exchange, Melgen allegedly showered the senator with luxury vacations and hundreds of thousands of campaign dollars. Defense attorneys argued that prosecutors cherry-picked gifts exchanged between close friends to suggest impropriety when none existed.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Warns of Ongoing Russian Election Meddling, Calls for Congressional Action

Article:

The U.S. intelligence community has issued a stark warning that President Putin has personally ordered a campaign to undermine American democracy and sow chaos in the electoral system. This assertion, made with high confidence, follows a series of well-documented Russian efforts to hack political organizations and state election boards, as well as disinformation campaigns on social media platforms.

Russia, as a perceived adversary not only to the United States but to freedom-loving people worldwide, has been employing disinformation and chaos as a tactic since the Soviet era. This strategy, updated with modern tools, has resulted in a widespread proliferation of Russian disinformation throughout the Western world. From elections in Britain, France, and Montenegro to invasions of Georgia and Ukraine, Moscow has pursued an aggressive foreign policy aimed at spreading disorder and expanding Russian influence in states that were once under the control of Soviet Communism.

The threat of Russian meddling in U.S. elections is not a relic of the past. Just last week, Dan Coats, the director of national intelligence, cautioned that "the warning lights are blinking red" that Russia and other adversaries will continue to launch cyberattacks on the digital infrastructure, including many energy companies in South and West Texas.

In response to these threats, many of the author's constituents have inquired about the role Congress can play in protecting the American people and providing a check on the executive branch's actions following the Helsinki summit. The author suggests that Congress could take the lead on European security issues, as it has in recent years.

During the Obama administration, Congress repeatedly pressured the president, using the power of the purse through appropriations bills, to send lethal weaponry to assist Ukraine in its fight against Russian-backed separatists. Last year, Congress passed the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act to impose severe sanctions on Russia as a response to its meddling in the U.S. presidential election. This year, the House passed the Ukraine Cybersecurity Cooperation Act to enhance Ukraine's ability to respond to Russian-supported disinformation and propaganda efforts.

The author is also optimistic about the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations' decision to invite Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to testify on the president's recent meetings with Kim Jong-un and Vladimir Putin. This transparency is crucial in maintaining a balanced and informed discussion on foreign policy matters.

Title: An Unbiased Analysis of the Leaked 1995 Trump Tax Returns and the Implications for the Presidential Race

Article:

In a recent development, the New York Times published a report based on a leaked 1995 Donald Trump tax return, revealing a significant financial loss of over $900 million. This revelation has sparked a heated debate, with some viewing it as a potential political blow to the Republican presidential nominee, while others argue that it is a common business practice.

The tax return, which shows a loss that could have allowed Trump to carry forward against taxable income for up to 18 years, has raised questions about Trump's business acumen and financial stability. The report suggests that Trump's substantial losses were a result of poor investments in the Atlantic City gaming and tourism market in the early 1990s.

While the tax return itself may not necessarily paint Trump in a negative light, the manner in which it was obtained has sparked controversy. The leak, which is believed to have originated from within Trump's inner circle, has been criticized for violating the candidate's right to privacy and potentially breaching confidentiality agreements.

It is important to note that the practice of carrying forward losses to offset future taxable income is a common business strategy. According to the Tax Foundation, about 1 million taxpayers had a net operating loss (NOL) in 1995, a result of business deductions exceeding business income in a particular year. Under tax rules, this loss can be carried back up to two years and carried forward up to twenty years.

The use of NOLs is not unique to Trump, as the New York Times and Hillary Clinton have also made use of this tax strategy. The practice is legal and serves as a means for businesses to hold onto their money during lean years and reinvest during profitable periods.

The controversy surrounding the leak of Trump's tax return has diverted attention from the issues at hand and has raised questions about the ethics of political journalism. It is crucial that the identity of the leaker is uncovered and the villain is prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

Regardless of one's political leanings, it is essential to uphold the rule of law and respect the privacy rights of American citizens. The leak of Trump's tax return, while potentially damaging to his campaign, does not pose a threat to our freedom or the rule of law. However, the outlaw character of those who conspired to violate Trump's confidentiality is a matter of concern for all Americans.

Title: Trump Transition Team Accuses Special Counsel Mueller's Office of Unlawful Obtaining of Emails; Mueller's Team Denies Allegations

Article:

In a seven-page letter sent to the Senate Homeland Security Committee and the House Oversight Committee, Kory Langhofer, attorney for President Donald Trump's transition team, has accused the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's office of unlawfully obtaining tens of thousands of emails from the General Services Administration (GSA). The GSA, which holds all transition documents, allegedly handed over the requested "copies of emails, laptops, cell phones, and other materials" of 13 members of the transition team, despite the agency not owning or controlling the records in question.

Langhofer claimed that the transition team was never informed that the documents were handed over, and there were potential violations of attorney-client privilege as well as the Fourth Amendment, which protects against unlawful search and seizure. Axios reports that the transition emails are said to include sensitive exchanges on matters such as potential appointments, gossip about the views of particular senators involved in the confirmation process, speculation about vulnerabilities of Trump nominees, strategizing about press statements, and policy planning on everything from war to taxes.

A source told Axios that the transition team will be sending a letter to Mueller asking for some emails to be returned because they're privileged. However, Mueller's team has pushed back, with spokesman Peter Carr stating, "When we have obtained emails in the course of our ongoing criminal investigation, we have secured either the account owner's consent or appropriate criminal process."

GSA Deputy Counsel Lenny Loewentritt also contradicted the claims made by Trump's transition team. Loewentritt specifically rejected a claim by the transition lawyer that the late GSA general counsel made a commitment to inform Trump's team if there were specific requests for any documents because the campaign "owned and controlled" emails that were sent at the time. In an interview with BuzzFeed, Loewentritt said that the truth is the exact opposite because the transition team was clearly told that "in using our devices," materials "would not be held back in any law enforcement" actions.

Former federal prosecutor Renato Mariotti took to Twitter to explain why Trump's transition team is "playing politics" but the issue itself "is a bad sign for them." Mariotti wrote that what is unusual in this case is that Mueller's team got the emails from the GSA rather than the Trump transition. He suggests that "Mueller was concerned that he wouldn't receive all of the emails if he obtained them from the Trump team," which, according to Mariotti, "suggests that he has reason to distrust Trump's team."

Mariotti also noted that disputes over privilege are common when prosecutors obtain emails and documents from third parties. He wrote, "The biggest conclusion I'd draw from their letter is that they're concerned about Mueller's investigation and are doing whatever they can to discredit it."

Rep. Eric Swalwell also dismissed the supposed complaints by the transition team as much ado about nothing, writing on Twitter, "Private documents on a U.S. Government, public email system? What are they afraid was found? Baloney. This is another attempt to discredit Mueller as his #TrumpRussia probe tightens."

Title: John Bolton's Departure from Trump Administration: A Closer Look at His Decision to Testify

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, John Bolton, former National Security Advisor to President Donald Trump, has decided to testify before the Senate in the ongoing impeachment trial. This move comes after months of speculation about his stance on the matter.

Bolton's decision to testify could be seen as a departure from the Trump administration, a move that was reportedly prompted by his disagreements with the President's foreign policy decisions and actions. In 2018, when Trump mused about withdrawing the United States from NATO, Bolton was said to have been distressed and worked to prevent it. His disagreements with Trump's foreign policy extend to the President's relationship with Russia, with Bolton reportedly characterizing Trump's meddling with aid to Ukraine as a "drug deal."

Bolton's professional principles, honed over a career in government, may have also played a role in his decision. As a seasoned government professional, Bolton has an informed respect for the institutional architecture and ethos of American foreign policy. Before becoming Trump's National Security Advisor, he served as Ambassador to the United Nations, Undersecretary of State, Assistant Secretary of State, and Assistant Attorney General.

However, speculation also suggests that personal indignation and financial gain could have influenced Bolton's decision. He reportedly lobbied the President for the National Security Advisor job for years and received a reported $2 million advance for his upcoming book, due out on March 17. The revelations in the book are expected to make it an instant bestseller.

Despite the potential for personal gain, it is likely that Bolton's sense of patriotic duty and professional principles played a more significant role in his decision. Bolton served almost a year and a half in a job under a famously mercurial President, and towards the end, was reportedly unhappy in it. His book, which didn't need the impeachment trial revelation to make it a hot item or line his pockets, suggests a more honorable motivation behind his decision.

In conclusion, John Bolton's decision to testify before the Senate in the impeachment trial is a complex one, driven by a combination of personal, professional, and patriotic factors. While the financial gain from his book is a factor, it is unlikely to be the primary motivation for his decision.

Title: Civil Rights Leader Jesse Jackson Criticizes Lack of Focus on Everyday People's Issues in Presidential Debates

Article:

In an interview with ███, civil rights leader and activist Rev. Jesse Jackson expressed his disappointment over the lack of discussion on key issues, such as poverty and gun violence, in the presidential and vice presidential debates.

Jackson criticized the candidates for focusing on reconciliation of a $5 trillion dollar figure, a sum he described as incomprehensible, while ignoring the impact of foreclosed housing driving the middle class into poverty. He argued that the moderators missed opportunities to discuss issues like controlling semi-automatic weapons and poverty in areas where these subjects are particularly relevant.

"With their questions, if you have a debate in Denver, how can you miss semi-automatic weapons in Aurora, which is [near] Denver and Columbine? How can you have a debate in Kentucky and don't mention poverty?" Jackson said, referencing shootings in both locations.

The poorest county in America is in Kentucky, the state that hosted the vice presidential debate, according to Jackson. He also pointed out that not one moderator has raised the issue of poverty or the issue of low credit scores, with 50 million people living in poverty and another 50 million having a credit score so low they can't borrow money from banks.

Jackson also expressed frustration with the scarce attention given to "voter suppression" during the debates. He stated, "The most glaring omission from the discussion is, you can conceivably win the debate and lose the election because of the impact of voter suppression and roll purging."

Despite his criticisms, Jackson had high praise for President Obama's performance in Tuesday's presidential debate, describing him as "alive and vibrant" and "punching and counterpunching."

Regarding his son, Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. (D-Ill.), who is currently on medical leave and under criminal investigation, Jackson said, "My son is still recovering and under medical supervision."

Title: Joe Biden Criticizes Trump's Handling of Coronavirus Pandemic, Emphasizes Unity and Cooperation

Article:

In a highly anticipated public address on the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joe Biden took aim at President Donald Trump's administration, criticizing its response to the crisis while emphasizing the need for unity and cooperation.

During his speech on Thursday, Biden, who is widely expected to secure the Democrat nomination, did not shy away from criticizing the current administration's handling of the pandemic. He accused the administration of ignoring science, having an "adversarial relationship with the truth," and promoting racism.

"Unfortunately, this virus has laid bare the severe shortcomings of the current administration," Biden said. "Public fears are being compounded by a pervasive lack of trust in this president, fueled by an adversarial relationship with the truth."

Biden proposed that leadership that is open-minded and willing to cooperate across national boundaries is crucial to combat the virus. He argued that the government's ability to respond effectively has been undermined by the Trump administration's actions, including the hollowing out of agencies and the disparagement of science.

"Our ability to derive a global response is dramatically undercut by the damage Trump has done to our credibility and our relationships around the world," Biden said.

While many of the solutions Biden proposed are already being implemented by the federal government, he accused Trump of sowing fear and racial division. In particular, Biden claimed that Trump's attempt to hold China accountable for failing to contain the virus were emboldening racism and "xenophobia."

"Labeling COVID-19 a 'foreign virus' does not displace accountability for the misjudgments that have been taken thus far by the Trump administration," Biden said. "Let me be crystal clear: the coronavirus does not have a political affiliation."

Biden also condemned acts of racism and xenophobia against the Asian American and Pacific Islander community, stating that they must not be tolerated.

The speech came a day after the Biden campaign unveiled its "Public Health Advisory Committee," which is tasked with providing the former vice president guidance on the pandemic. The political leanings of some of the individuals tapped for the committee were made evident by a plan Biden touted on Thursday, which included among its proposals for combatting the virus the rejoining of the Paris climate accord.

Title: Pennsylvania Woman Dies in Jail While Serving Sentence for Unpaid School Fines: A Call to Question the Criminalization of Poverty

A 55-year-old Pennsylvania woman, Eileen DiNino, passed away in a Berks County jail cell over the weekend while serving a 48-hour sentence for unpaid school fines related to her children's attendance. The cause of her death is yet to be determined, but it is not considered suspicious.

District Judge Dean Patton, who expressed reluctance in sentencing DiNino, stated to the Associated Press, "We don't do debtors' prisons anymore. That went out 100 years ago." However, more than 1,600 people have been jailed in Berks County alone due to similar fines, with the majority being women.

DiNino, a mother of seven, was reportedly struggling financially and did not work or appear to have much help with four children still at home. She frequently missed hearings or arrived without the necessary documents. Judge Patton described her as a woman who "cared about her kids, but her kids ruled the roost."

Despite her struggles, DiNino presented herself clean and neat when she surrendered to serve her sentence on Friday. "She was a different person. She was cleaned up, smiling," Patton said, adding that he believes she realized the weight was lifted off her shoulders upon completion of the sentence.

Berks County Commissioner Kevin Barnhardt, chairman of the county prison board, expressed outrage that DiNino died alone and away from her family while serving a sentence for being poor. "This woman died in prison, away from her family," Barnhardt told the Reading Eagle. "And for what?"

The circumstances of DiNino's death serve as a stark reminder of the criminalization of poverty in the United States. Thousands have been jailed in Berks County for failure to pay truancy fines, while court fees and other fines have put thousands of others behind bars across the country.

An investigation by National Public Radio revealed instances such as a homeless man being sentenced to a year in jail for inability to pay a $2,600 penalty for shoplifting a $2 can of beer, and a teenager being jailed for three days for catching a fish off-season due to an unpaid fine.

The tragic death of Eileen DiNino raises questions about the justice system's treatment of the economically disadvantaged and the criminalization of poverty in the United States.

Title: Three American Detainees Return Home from North Korea, Clearing Path for Trump-Kim Summit

Article:

In a significant development, three American citizens, who were previously detained in North Korea, have been released and returned home early Thursday morning. The prisoners, who were welcomed by President Donald Trump and his wife Melania, were handed over to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo during his visit to Pyongyang on Tuesday.

The three men, Kim Dong Chul, Kim Hak Song, and Kim Sang Dok (also known as Tony Kim), are Korean-American and share the common surname Kim, but are not related. They were greeted at Joint Base Andrews by an American flag strung between two fire trucks parked on the tarmac, and their homecoming was broadcast live on cable news networks.

Kim Dong Chul, who was sentenced to 10 years of hard labor in 2016 for espionage, expressed his gratitude upon returning home. "It's like a dream," he said through a translator. "We are very, very happy."

The return of these prisoners, whom the U.S. has called "hostages," clears an obstacle for direct talks between Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The president expects to announce a date and location for the summit within days and has ruled out the Korea Peninsula's Demilitarized Zone. An administration official later stated that he is leaning toward Singapore as the summit location.

Trump thanked Kim for releasing the men and expressed optimism about the upcoming summit. "I really think we have a very good chance of doing something very meaningful," Trump said. "I really think he wants to do something and bring that country into the real world."

Senator Angus King of Maine, an independent who caucuses with Democrats, cautioned against celebrating prematurely. "We're not there yet," King said on CNN.

Vice President Mike Pence, who joined Trump at the homecoming, stated that all three men "seem to be in good health" and were glad to be heading home. Pence also spoke with the parents of Otto Warmbier, an American college student who was detained in North Korea for trying to steal a propaganda poster from a hotel and died shortly after being returned home in a coma last year.

After meeting Trump and Pence, the former detainees were taken to Walter Reed military hospital in Bethesda, Maryland, for evaluation and treatment. Vice President Pence is scheduled to sit for interviews with NBC, ABC, and CBS to be broadcast on their morning news programs.

Pence also stated during an interview with CBS News that Kim's agreement to release the three gives hope that this may be different from past negotiations with North Korea, where promises were made but not kept.

Title: CNN Dismisses Donna Brazile: A Call for Reevaluation of Paid Political Pundits in News Media

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, CNN has terminated the contract of Donna Brazile, the former interim chair of the Democratic National Committee, following the revelation of her leaking debate questions to the Hillary Clinton campaign. The decision, while appropriate in light of Brazile's actions, has brought to light a broader issue within the news media: the reliance on paid partisan pundits.

According to leaked emails from the Podesta hack, Brazile provided the Clinton campaign with advance knowledge of debate questions, as evidenced by an email with the subject line, "From time to time I get the questions in advance." In another email, she previewed a question that would be asked by a Flint resident, inquiring about Clinton's plans for the city.

Brazile's actions were wrong, and her breach of trust is undeniable. While CNN hired her to represent and advocate for the Democratic Party, her actions directly compromised the integrity of CNN, a clear violation of the implied oath of partisanship. Brazile's deceit has exposed a troubling aspect of news talk, one that may not be easily remedied as she is now being scrutinized by the ethics committee.

The issue at hand is not just Brazile's corrupt act, but the entire ecosystem of paid partisan yakkers that populates news shows. These individuals, who include figures such as Tim Russert, Bill Bradley, George Stephanopoulos, Joe Scarborough, and many more, are not hired for their political insights but for their recognizable faces and predictable commentary.

The presence of these partisan contributors creates an illusion of impartiality and inclusion, as they are divided between Republicans and Democrats. In reality, they provide safe and predictable chatter, filling airtime with platitudes and generalizations. Their role in the news shows is a result of practicality, as they are a cheap and readily available source of on-air talent for the 24/7 programming needs of television.

The contributions of these paid pundits are not journalism, nor are they politics. They often dilute political conversations to the weakest of teas, making it difficult for the average viewer to follow. The paid contributor segments are, more often than not, a tasteless and uninformative filler, offering little value to the political discourse.

It is time for news shows to reconsider their reliance on political hacks and instead hire journalists whose job it would be to extract meaningful information from these pundits. Under this new system, Brazile and others like her could still be interviewed, but they would no longer be paid, and they would be held accountable for providing substantive and valuable insights.

As Donna Brazile reflects on her actions and the consequences that followed, it is a reminder of the need for transparency, accountability, and integrity in the news media. The dismissal of Brazile should serve as a catalyst for change, pushing news shows to prioritize journalism over partisanship and to hold their contributors to a higher standard.

Title: SeaTac, Washington, to Implement Highest Minimum Wage in the Nation, Sparking Job Cuts and Business Concerns

Article:

As the debate on increasing the federal minimum wage continues in Washington D.C., the city of SeaTac, Washington, is set to establish the highest minimum wage rate in the nation, starting on January 1. Approximately 1,600 hotel and transportation workers in SeaTac will see their pay rise to $15 per hour, a 60% increase from the state's current minimum wage of $9.32.

While many workers welcome the higher pay, employers are grappling with the significant increase in labor costs. Some are considering job cuts as a means to absorb the increased expenses. Cedarbrook Lodge General Manager Scott Ostrander stated, "We're going to be looking at making some serious cuts. We're going to be looking at reducing employee hours, reducing benefits, and eliminating some positions."

In the short term, these job cuts are expected, but the Cedarbrook Lodge plans to offset the higher labor costs by building an addition to the hotel. The aim is to increase revenue to compensate for the increased wages. However, not every employer is as ambitious. One has announced plans to close one of its two restaurants, eliminating 200 jobs.

The SeaTac minimum wage increase has also caused Han Kim, who runs Hotel Concepts, a company that owns and manages 11 hotels in Washington state, to postpone plans to build a hotel in SeaTac. The company already has three hotels in SeaTac, and Kim and a business partner were looking to build a fourth on land they own. "Uncertainty is bad for business, and right now we're right in that area, so we're just putting everything on hold," Kim said.

Opponents of the $15 minimum wage scored a legal victory last week when a King County, Washington, judge ruled that it does not apply to any of the workers at the SeaTac airport. Superior Court Judge Andrea Darvas ruled that only the Port of Seattle can set wage and other work rules at the airport, eliminating 4,700 workers from the successful ballot initiative.

Backers of the $15 minimum wage have vowed to appeal the ruling up to the state Supreme Court. One of the biggest supporters is Kshama Sawant, a socialist who also won her election to the Seattle City Council. She plans on making Seattle the next city to have a $15 minimum wage. "There may be a few jobs lost here and there, but the fact is, if we don't fight for this, then the race to the bottom will continue," Sawant said.

Sawant is skeptical that the higher minimum wage will lead to mass layoffs. However, the American Car Rental Association estimates that 5% of low-wage jobs will be cut, and another 5-10% of those workers will be replaced by more experienced workers. The owner of Dollar Rental Cars told Fox News she will outsource some functions, change schedules, and cut some staff in response to the new policy.

Title: Minneapolis Mayor and City Council Members Diverge on Police Department's Future Amid Ongoing Protests

Article:

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey and a majority of the city council members find themselves at odds over the future of the city's police department, following the death of George Floyd. On Sunday, Frey reiterated his stance against abolishing the police force, while a veto-proof majority of city council members expressed their desire to take that drastic step.

Frey, who ordered the evacuation of a police station during the riots last month, faced a hostile crowd outside his home on Saturday. Protesters shouted him down when he defied their demands to dismantle the city's police forces entirely.

"I'll work relentlessly with Chief [Medaria] Arradondo and alongside the community toward deep, structural reform and addressing systemic racism in police culture," Frey said in a statement to KARE. "We're ready to dig in and enact more community-led, public safety strategies on behalf of our city. But, I do not support abolishing the Minneapolis Police Department."

Before the crowd, Frey had prefaced his comments by saying he was "coming to grips" with his "own brokenness," and by promising to put the police union "in its place." However, many protesters were unconvinced, shouting, "It's not about you!" and "Go home, Jacob, go home!"

On Sunday, nine city council members spoke at a protest at Powderhorn Park, a neighborhood in Minneapolis. The number of supporters in attendance represented a veto-proof majority to push the measure through, according to Fox 9. Council President Lisa Bender, VP Andrea Jenkins, and Councilmembers Alondra Cano, Jeremiah Ellison, Steve Fletcher, Phillipe Cunningham, Cam Gordon, and Jeremy Schroeder were among those in attendance.

Councilmember Jeremiah Ellison, the son of state Attorney General Keith Ellison, has openly declared his support for Antifa, the left-wing group that President Trump has sought to designate as a terrorist organization. Most members of the city council have belonged to the Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party.

"Our commitment is to end our city's toxic relationship with the Minneapolis Police Department," Bender said. "It is clear that our system of policing is not keeping our communities safe. Our efforts at incremental reform have failed, period."

Bender went on to say she and the eight other council members that joined the rally were committed to ending the city's relationship with the police force and "to end policing as we know it and recreate systems that actually keep us safe."

On Monday, Bender told CNN that people worried about having no one to call during a home invasion were speaking from a "place of privilege." Those comments drew widespread backlash.

Ellison, for his part, promised that the council would "dismantle" the department.

Nationally, efforts to defund the police have been broadly unpopular, with only about 20 percent of Americans favoring reductions in police forces. Citing publicly available data, commentators have asserted that the very idea of systemic racism by police is questionable.

In 2018, African-Americans made up 53% of known homicide offenders in the U.S. and committed about 60% of robberies, though they are 13% of the population, according to Heather Mac Donald's article in The Wall Street Journal this week. In 2018, there were 7,407 black homicide victims. Assuming a comparable number of victims last year, those nine unarmed black victims of police shootings represent 0.1% of all African-Americans killed in 2019. By contrast, a police officer is 18½ times more likely to be killed by a black male than an unarmed black male is to be killed by a police officer.

Mac Donald continued, "A 2015 Justice Department analysis of the Philadelphia Police Department found that white police officers were less likely than black or Hispanic officers to shoot unarmed black suspects. Research by Harvard economist Roland G. Fryer Jr. also found no evidence of racial discrimination in shootings." Any evidence to the contrary fails to take into account crime rates and civilian behavior before and during interactions with police.

Fryer's work has also determined that when police pull out of communities, black deaths tend to increase. "The false narrative of systemic police bias resulted in targeted killings of officers during the Obama presidency," Mac Donald concluded.

Disbanding an entire department has happened before. In 2012, with crime rampant in Camden, New Jersey, the city disbanded its ineffective union-run police department and replaced it with a new force that covered Camden County. Compton, California, took the same step in 2000, shifting its policing to Los Angeles County.

The move to defund or abolish the Minneapolis department is far from assured, with the civil rights investigation likely to unfold over the next several months.

Title: Voter Fraud Ring Busted in Los Angeles: Nine Accused of Forging Signatures for Ballot Measures and Voter Registration

Article:

In a significant development, a voter fraud ring has been uncovered in Los Angeles, with nine individuals accused of forging signatures on state ballot measure petitions and voter registration forms. The defendants, who face several criminal charges including circulating a petition with fake names, voter fraud, and registering a fictitious person, reportedly lured the homeless with cash and cigarettes in exchange for their signatures.

The district attorney's office announced the charges on Tuesday, three weeks after they were filed but made public only recently. The alleged fraud scheme, which took place on L.A.'s skid row during the 2016 election cycle and this year, was part of a Los Angeles Police Department crackdown on suspected election fraud on skid row earlier in the year.

Officer Deon Joseph, the senior lead officer on skid row, told The Times in September, "They paid individuals to sign the names. That's an assault on our democracy."

LA elections chief, Dean Logan, told the publication that he is confident his staff, which manually compares signatures, did not let the forgeries slip through. However, he expressed concern about any activity that shakes the trust of the voter in our system.

This incident is not an isolated one, as voter fraud does occur in the United States. Similar incidents have been reported in states like Pennsylvania, Texas, and Wisconsin. The issue, though not common, has been a topic of debate, with some arguing that it doesn't happen often, while others maintain that even rare instances of voter fraud can undermine the integrity of the electoral process.

Title: Trump Attorney Michael Cohen Revealed as Third Client: Fox News Host Sean Hannity

In a surprising turn of events, it has been revealed that Donald Trump's longtime attorney, Michael Cohen, has been representing Fox News host Sean Hannity. This information was unveiled in a federal court on Monday.

Federal Judge Kimba Wood ordered Cohen's legal team to disclose the identity of a client that Cohen's team had withheld in earlier court documents. The disclosure was part of a dispute over evidence seized by the FBI from Cohen's home and office earlier this month.

Cohen and Trump had sought either to permit them to review the material before prosecutors got to see it or to appoint an independent "special master." The judge stated that she could not decide about how seriously to treat Cohen's and Trump's claims about attorney-client privilege unless she knew what clients Cohen had been representing.

An attorney for Cohen, who had asked whether he could submit the name to the judge in a sealed envelope or to the "special master," had no choice but to reveal it in open court. Cohen's attorney had previously identified two other clients: Trump and Republican fundraiser Elliott Broidy. These men are involved in cases in which Cohen allegedly arranged payments to women to keep them quiet about alleged sexual encounters.

Cohen has acknowledged paying pornographic actress Stormy Daniels $130,000 shortly before the 2016 election for what her lawyer said was silence about her alleged liaison with Trump in 2006. Cohen also reportedly arranged a deal for Broidy in which model Shera Bechard was paid $1.6 million when she became pregnant after an affair.

Trump denies any sexual relationship with Daniels. Broidy acknowledged the affair with Bechard and apologized to his family. There was no immediate indication as to whether Hannity might have been involved in such an arrangement. Hannity issued a statement on Monday afternoon that said his discussions with Cohen had never involved anyone else.

"Michael Cohen has never represented me in any matter," Hannity said. "I never retained him, received an invoice, or paid legal fees. I have occasionally had brief discussions with him about legal questions about which I wanted his input and perspective. I assumed those conversations were confidential, but to be absolutely clear, they never involved any matter between me and a third party."

Hannity said separately on Twitter that his discussions with Cohen "dealt almost exclusively about real estate."

Hannity has been a vocal supporter of Trump and Cohen on his show and a critic of the FBI and Justice Department. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich said on Hannity's show last week that the FBI raid on Cohen was like the abuses of the "Gestapo."

After a long hearing on Monday, Wood said she had concluded the hearing without deciding whether to appoint the "special master" sought by Cohen or to permit the Justice Department's "filter team" to continue its work. While federal investigators will retain possession of what was seized, they still cannot look at the substance yet even as they are cataloging the amount of papers, electronic files, and other materials.

Title: Americans' Dissatisfaction with Obama's Handling of ISIS and National Security, According to New CNN/ORC Poll

Article:

Washington ( CNN ) - A new CNN/ORC poll released Monday indicates that Americans are increasingly displeased with President Barack Obama's handling of ISIS, and a growing number of the nation believes that the fight against the terrorist organization is going poorly.

The poll shows that 57% disapprove of Obama's handling of foreign affairs overall, and 54% disapprove of his handling of terrorism. Additionally, 60% rate Obama negatively on his handling of electronic national security.

The declining approval ratings for Obama on national security come as a weekend of international turmoil further underscores the growing threats abroad. Egypt launched a second round of airstrikes against Islamic State strongholds in Libya on Monday, in response to a video released Sunday that appeared to show ISIS militants beheading a group of 21 Egyptian Christians.

Obama issued a statement condemning the killing of the Christians on Sunday night, but his Republican opponents have consistently argued that the growing ISIS threat is exacerbated by what they see as his weak leadership.

In the poll, Americans increasingly believe that U.S. military action against ISIS is going badly, with 58% saying so in the latest survey, up from 49% who said the fight was not going well in October. Even among Democrats, nearly half—46%—say things are not going well in the battle against ISIS.

About half of respondents, 51%, say they trust the President as Commander-in-Chief of the military. However, with ISIS affiliates continuing to commit brutal, gruesome murders and multiple terrorist attacks abroad grabbing international headlines over the past few months, support for sending ground troops to Iraq and Syria to confront the threat appears to be growing.

The survey suggests that Americans are warming up to the idea of sending ground troops to combat the terrorist organization. In November, just 43% supported deploying ground troops, while 55% of Americans opposed it; now the number in support has ticked up to 47%, the highest level of support yet measured, with just half of Americans opposed.

The parties have become more polarized on the prospect since November, with 61% of Democrats opposed and a similar majority of Republicans supportive of the prospect, an eight-point increase. Independents, meanwhile, are split, with 48% in favor and 50% opposed.

The prospect of sending in ground troops remains a sticking point for both congressional Democrats and Republicans in the debate over Obama's Authorization for the Use of Military Force, which would give him legal authority to combat ISIS. But the AUMF, and Obama's decision to go to Congress for the official authority to continue battling ISIS, is widely popular, according to the new poll.

Seventy-eight percent of Americans say Congress should give Obama the authority to fight ISIS, a slight decline from 82% who supported it in December. A similarly large majority say Obama was right to ask Congress for the authority, rather than proceeding with the battle unilaterally.

The survey was conducted among 1,027 adult Americans from Feb. 12-15, and has a margin of sampling error of 3%.

Title: White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer's Assertions Prove False in Quick Succession

Article:

In the early days of the Trump administration, Press Secretary Sean Spicer found himself in a series of missteps that led to the revelation of false assertions made during his press briefings.

During his inaugural briefing on the first official workday of President Donald Trump's term, Spicer's statement about the size of the inaugural crowd was met with skepticism and ridicule. This was followed by his defense of National Security Advisor Mike Flynn's contact with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak.

On the issue of Flynn's contact with Kislyak, Spicer stated during a briefing on Monday that there had only been one call, and that it dealt with four subjects: a plane crash, Christmas, a conference about ISIS, and setting up a call between Trump and Vladimir Putin. However, three weeks later, it was reported that Flynn had allegedly discussed U.S.-imposed sanctions on Russia with Kislyak, and had misled the White House regarding the nature of their conversation. Flynn resigned on February 13.

In a further twist, it was revealed that Spicer's assertion that there had been no other conversations between Flynn and Kislyak was also false. The White House confirmed that Flynn had met with Kislyak alongside Jared Kushner, the president's senior adviser and son-in-law, in December. This meeting was first reported by The New York Times and confirmed by The Hive.

The White House has been grappling with questions about the meetings, discussions, and reasons for the frequent interactions between members of the Trump administration and Kislyak, particularly during the election season and the transition period. The lack of transparency and the subsequent revelation of false statements have raised questions about the administration's honesty and its dealings with Russia.

As the investigation into Russia's involvement in the 2016 election continues, it remains unclear who within the Trump administration was aware of these meetings and discussions, and why they chose to conceal this information from others, including Vice President Mike Pence and Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Spicer, Trump, and Sessions have all stated that they were not aware of these meetings. The unfolding events have cast a shadow of doubt over the Trump administration's dealings with Russia and its commitment to transparency.

Title: Army Regulations Determine Fate of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl as Active Duty Commitment Ends

Article:

The fate of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who walked off his base in Afghanistan in 2009 and was held captive by the Taliban until last May, hangs in the balance as he approaches the end of his active duty commitment. According to military law expert Charles Gittins, the Army must either court-martial him or give him an honorable discharge, as he has completed his service.

Under Army regulations, service members who are still serving their enlistment commitment are treated differently than those, like Sgt. Bergdahl, who have completed their active duty service. An active duty soldier whom the Army wishes to discharge can be sent to an administrative board. However, Sgt. Bergdahl, who is awaiting an Army decision on whether he will face criminal charges, is not in this category.

If the Army wishes to seek an other-than-honorable discharge, it would have to pursue criminal charges. In such a case, the soldier could negotiate a less-than-honorable discharge in lieu of a trial, according to Mr. Gittins. A conviction at court-martial could result in a bad conduct or dishonorable discharge.

Maj. Gen. Kenneth Dahl, the officer tasked with investigating Sgt. Bergdahl's actions in Afghanistan, has completed his report and submitted it to the office of Army Secretary John McHugh. A source familiar with the probe stated that Sgt. Bergdahl has denied deserting and provided an explanation for his actions on June 30, 2009. Soldiers from Sgt. Bergdahl's unit have accused him of desertion.

Sgt. Bergdahl is currently at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, assigned to the company headquarters. He was interviewed last August by Gen. Dahl, with his attorney, Eugene Fidell, present. Mr. Fidell, a military law expert and Yale Law School instructor, praised Gen. Dahl's professionalism and expressed hope for his future career.

The source familiar with the investigation did not know Gen. Dahl's conclusions, which have implications beyond Sgt. Bergdahl's fate. The investigation's outcome could fuel the ongoing debate about President Obama's decision to release five Taliban leaders in exchange for Sgt. Bergdahl's release and the subsequent criticism of the administration for not notifying Congress ahead of time, as required by law.

The White House's initial praise for Sgt. Bergdahl brought rebuttals from his battlemates, who portrayed him as a deserter who abandoned his unit and caused unnecessary missions to find him. The source familiar with the investigation revealed that Sgt. Bergdahl, while a captive, tried to escape and was abused. The Rolling Stone published emails from then-Private Bergdahl expressing disenchantment with his combat role in Afghanistan.

Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-CA) has accused the Pentagon of orchestrating a ransom payment for Sgt. Bergdahl, with the money allegedly paid to an "Afghan intermediary." The Pentagon denies making a ransom payment, and Rep. Hunter has asked the Defense Department inspector general to investigate.

The Army is yet to make a decision on the next steps, with Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby stating that it is up to the Army to decide what the next steps are and that they will not rush the process. The Army is expected to make the investigation public at an appropriate time.

Title: Congresswoman Rashida Tlaib's Criticism of Facial Recognition Technology and Workforce Diversity Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a visit to Detroit's "Real-Time Crime" center, which employs facial recognition technology, Democratic Representative Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) expressed concerns about the racial makeup of the analysts working in the facility. Tlaib, a member of the progressive "Squad," criticized the predominantly white workforce in a city that is 80 percent black, stating that analysts should be African American, not non-African American.

During her tour of the facility, Tlaib expressed her belief that non-African Americans may struggle to identify African Americans and other people of color. She cited personal experiences and anecdotal evidence, such as misidentifying Congressmen Elijah Cummings and John Lewis, as examples. In response, Craig, the Detroit Police Chief, stated that the diverse group of crime analysts in the center was a slap in the face to all the men and women working there.

Tlaib's comments have sparked controversy, with critics labeling her remarks as reverse racism. In response to questions about whether non-whites should be barred from working as crime analysts in mostly white communities, Tlaib suggested looking up the issue, citing numerous studies, events, and anecdotal evidence that show facial recognition technology and white people often misidentify non-white faces.

Several studies have shown that facial recognition technology is flawed due to its reliance on human programmers, who are predominantly white and male. For instance, the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences reported in July that facial recognition algorithms misidentify black faces 5 to 10 times more often than white faces. Researchers at MIT have also noted that the technology is flawed because it learns from human programmers, who are almost all white and male.

Tlaib's comments have been met with criticism from conservatives and the Detroit Police Chief, who have condemned her remarks as reverse racism. However, Tlaib has repeatedly invoked these scientific studies to support her position. Despite the controversy, the issue of workforce diversity and the potential biases in facial recognition technology remains a topic of ongoing debate.

Title: Legal Challenges Mount Against Trump's National Emergency Declaration for Border Wall Funding

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to use emergency powers to secure funding for the construction of a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border is facing legal challenges from several states and advocacy groups. California and New York have announced their intention to challenge the move, which they argue is a bypass of Congress and a gross abuse of power.

Building the wall was a key campaign promise for President Trump. Democrats have criticized the move, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Democrat leader Chuck Schumer vowing to contest it in Congress and the courts. On Friday, Mr. Trump signed an emergency declaration along with a spending bill aimed at preventing a repeat of the recent government shutdown.

Within hours of the declaration, the first legal challenge against the national emergency was launched by the liberal advocacy group Public Citizen, on behalf of a nature reserve and three Texas landowners who have been told the wall may be constructed on their properties. Governor Gavin Newsom of California dismissed the president's decision as "political theatre."

New York state's Democratic attorney general, Letitia James, said the state would not "stand for this abuse of power and will fight back with every legal tool at our disposal." The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) also announced plans to file a lawsuit in the coming days to curb "this blatantly illegal executive action."

The trouble with going nuclear, as some analysts suggest, is that it creates fallout. This has been presented as a predictably partisan issue, with Republicans on one side and Democrats on the other. However, the president's move has made it more complicated than that, with a number of Republican senators expressing unease about the president invoking a national emergency.

The National Emergencies Act contains a clause that allows Congress to terminate the emergency status if both houses vote for it and the president does not veto. With a comfortable majority in the House, Democrats could pass such a resolution to the Senate. The Republicans control the Senate, but a number of Republican senators have been vocal in their unease about the president's move.

The resolution would still require Mr. Trump's signature to pass, allowing him to veto it. A supermajority in both houses of Congress is needed to overturn a presidential veto. The National Emergencies Act is intended for times of national crisis, and Mr. Trump has claimed that there is a migration crisis at the nation's southern border - a claim strongly refuted by migration experts.

Declaring a national emergency would give the president access to special powers that effectively allow him to bypass the usual political process, and he would be able to divert money from existing military or disaster relief budgets to pay for the wall. Emergency declarations by previous presidents have been overwhelmingly used for addressing foreign policy crises.

On Friday, Mr. Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, told reporters that Mr. Trump's move "creates zero precedent." He added, "This is authority given to the president in law already. It's not as if he just didn't get what he wanted so he's waving a magic wand and taking a bunch of money."

The $8 billion for the wall would be made up of funds from the Department of Defense, with the largest amount coming from the military construction budget. This is almost certain to bring a legal challenge, as projects that could be cancelled include constructions at Guantanamo Bay, a military school in Japan, and special forces facilities in North Carolina.

Poor living conditions for military families have become a concern, but a Pentagon spokesman, Bill Speaks, insisted "military family-housing projects will not be affected." Trump officials also said that projects affecting force-readiness would not be compromised. Mr. Trump said military officials had told him the wall was more important, and that what he was told would be cut "didn't sound too important to me."

Title: Over 50 Pakistani Journalists Test Positive for Coronavirus as Country Eases Lockdown Measures

Article:

Islamabad, Pakistan - A total of 54 journalists and media workers have tested positive for the coronavirus across Pakistan, according to data released by the Freedom Network rights group on Monday. This marks a significant increase in infections within the journalism community, highlighting the need for stricter adherence to safety guidelines as the South Asian nation continues to ease its lockdown amid a spike in cases and deaths.

One of the first journalists to test positive for the virus in the country was Salman Ashraf, a reporter for local television station Geo News in the southwest city of Quetta. Ashraf, who was one of seven people to test positive for the coronavirus in his organisation's Quetta bureau, shared his experience, stating, "I was in the office and my body felt like I had a fever, and I felt really dizzy. I left the office before my shift ended. When I returned home, it was very difficult. I had a high fever, and a lot of body pain. I could not stand up."

The data shows a similar pattern of clusters of coronavirus cases in newsrooms and bureaus across the country, where journalists, technical staff, and media assistants often work in close proximity to each other. The number of infections in Pakistan began spiking last week, with several consecutive days of record increases in new infections and deaths. On Sunday, reported infections rose by a further 1,476 to 30,941, with at least 667 deaths and 8,212 patients having recovered.

As the country implements a government-mandated easing of lockdown measures, provinces have begun allowing smaller markets and several industries to reopen for up to five days a week, operating from sunrise until 5 pm each day. Prime Minister Imran Khan's government has insisted that a full lockdown is not economically sustainable for a country that was already in the midst of an economic crisis when its outbreak began in late February.

Last month, the International Monetary Fund estimated that Pakistan's economy would contract by 1.5 percent owing to the coronavirus-related lockdowns, close to the worst such figures since the country gained independence in 1947. Khan has insisted that industries be required to follow government-mandated standard operating procedures to keep workers safe, or face being closed down again.

For journalists working across the country, individual news organisations have issued guidelines regarding social distancing and protective equipment while reporting. However, implementation on the ground has been inconsistent, with many journalists disregarding or ignoring the guidelines.

"We are going into the field in the same way," said one journalist in Quetta, speaking on condition of anonymity fearing reprisals from his employer. "We are working in the same way, in the field and in the office. We are contacting the public in the same way."

Competition in Pakistan's news media landscape is cut-throat, with more than 30 24-hour television news channels competing with each other for ratings, in addition to dozens of national and regional newspapers.

"The general behavior that we are seeing, I am mentally prepared that I am going to get the virus. And I do not feel like I can save myself from this," said Syed Shahzad Kazmi, a cameraman for the local Roze News television station in the northwestern city of Peshawar. "They are not taking it as seriously as it should be."

Kazmi, who tested positive for the coronavirus late last month, spent two weeks in quarantine at home before being certified as having recovered by health authorities. Asad Ali, a cameraman for the Gourmet News Network in Peshawar, tested positive for the coronavirus after being infected by a co-worker at his organisation's bureau. After spending two weeks in quarantine, he said he was back at work on the night shift, working as normal.

Iqbal Khattak, representative for the global media rights group Reporters Without Borders in Pakistan, stated, "The protocol is quite good, but still, I think the protocol needs some [additional] steps." RSF's recommendations to Pakistani news organisations include no longer requiring television reporters to report live from places with large crowds, restricting coverage of press conferences where large numbers may gather, and avoiding commissioning reports from hospitals.

"I was just watching the 3 pm bulletin... and these journalists were all on the streets, close to the public," said Khattak. "This is a worrying sign. [...] Getting live hits from the field is a risk that they are taking, and I think media houses should avoid taking these risks."

Title: Retired General John Allen Tapped to Lead International Coalition Against ISIS

Article:

In a move that marks a return to a challenging and complex mission, retired four-star Marine General John Allen has been appointed to coordinate the international coalition against the Islamic State (ISIS), Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Friday. The appointment comes as President Barack Obama has vowed to destroy the militant organization that has taken control of portions of both Syria and Iraq.

Allen, a veteran of many of the Middle East's most challenging conflicts, is well-acquainted with the difficult terrain he is about to enter. He was one of the top commanders in western Iraq during the "Sunni Awakening," a program that worked to turn Sunni tribes in Anbar province against the al Qaeda affiliate operating in Iraq at the time. The militant organization now known as ISIS is the successor to that al Qaeda group.

Allen, who graduated with honors from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1976, has a long and distinguished list of accomplishments. He took command of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan in 2011, after General David Petraeus, then the coalition's commander, was nominated to become director of the CIA. Allen was the first Marine to head up the military effort in Afghanistan.

Before his command in Afghanistan, Allen was deputy commander at U.S. Central Command, which oversees all military operations in the Middle East. He is also a decorated veteran of the armed forces, having received the Defense Distinguished Service Medal and the Defense Superior Service Medal among others.

Allen was briefly caught up in the 2012 scandal involving Petraeus' infidelity that led to the retired general's resignation from his CIA post. An investigation into "flirtatious" email exchanges between Allen and Jill Kelley, the Florida woman whose complaints about threatening emails from Petraeus' mistress, Paula Broadwell, brought the scandal into the public, led Allen to withdraw his nomination by Obama to become NATO's supreme allied commander in 2013. The Defense Department eventually cleared him of any wrongdoing, and Allen retired from the Marines.

Allen is the married father of two daughters and holds master's degrees from Georgetown University, the Defense Intelligence College, and the National War College.

Title: U.S. Defense Workers Return to Duty as Shutdown Enters Second Week

Article:

The second week of the ongoing U.S. government shutdown is mirroring the events of the previous week, with no significant progress in negotiations between the political parties. However, one notable development is the return to work of U.S. civilian defense workers.

As reported by NPR's Bill Chappell, the Department of Defense has ordered most of its furloughed civilian employees, approximately 400,000 workers, to return to work starting Monday. This decision was announced by Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel over the weekend and is based on the "Pay Our Military Act," a legislation passed by Congress and signed by President Obama last week.

Hagel clarified that the law does not allow for a blanket recall of all civilians, but it can be used to bring back workers who support service personnel. The move is aimed at ensuring the smooth operation of military operations and the well-being of service members.

The shutdown has been marked by a series of partisan exchanges, with more than a dozen lawmakers appearing on Sunday shows to present their perspectives on the ongoing stalemate. The longer the standoff persists, the closer it comes to the October 17 deadline for raising the debt ceiling, setting the stage for a potential showdown on fiscal policy in the coming weeks.

In a critical assessment, The Washington Post noted that no party in Washington, including President Obama, House Republicans, and Senate Democrats, is emerging unscathed from the shutdown. However, the Post also points out that Republican governors with White House aspirations seem to be faring better than their counterparts in Congress.
