According to the Post, governors such as Bobby Jindal and Chris Christie are benefiting from the shutdown, with the chaos and name-calling in Washington serving as evidence that a problem-solver from outside the political establishment is needed. The shutdown, along with the partisan bickering, is seen as a testament to the broken nature of Washington politics.

Title: President Obama's Shift in Perspective: A Look at His Changing Views on Construction Jobs and the Keystone XL Pipeline

Article:

In a stark contrast to his previous stance, President Barack Obama has expressed skepticism towards the creation of blue-collar jobs associated with the Keystone XL oil pipeline. During a speech in Chattanooga, Tennessee, on Tuesday, the President chuckled derisively when discussing the pipeline project's potential to generate thousands of jobs over two years.

"They keep on talking about this—an oil pipeline coming down from Canada that’s estimated to create about 50 permanent jobs," Mr. Obama said. "That’s not a jobs plan."

In a recent interview, the President estimated that the pipeline project would create "maybe 2,000" construction jobs, referring to these jobs as "a blip" in comparison to the nation's employment needs. This contrasts sharply with Mr. Obama's attitude during his first term, when he expressed enthusiasm for construction jobs and called for more temporary stimulus spending on infrastructure projects to aid unemployed construction workers.

In 2011, as part of his "We Can’t Wait" campaign, Mr. Obama held an event at the Key Bridge in Georgetown to urge Congress to approve more temporary stimulus spending on infrastructure projects. At the time, he emphasized the importance of construction jobs in the economic recovery.

"Of all the industries hammered by the economic downturn, construction has been among the hardest hit," Mr. Obama said. "I’m joining many of these workers to say that it makes absolutely no sense when there’s so much work to be done that they’re not doing the work."

In February 2009, Mr. Obama urged Congress to approve an $800 billion-plus economic stimulus package, citing the need for construction jobs. He argued that the stimulus legislation would create 3 to 4 million jobs and lay the groundwork for long-term growth by repairing infrastructure and moving the country toward energy independence.

Even before taking office in January 2009, Mr. Obama was promoting government-funded infrastructure projects, many of which would have been temporary jobs given the act's proposed life of two or three years. Two years later, amid criticism that the stimulus law hadn't produced the promised number of construction jobs, Mr. Obama joked, "Shovel-ready was not as shovel-ready as we expected."

The President's top aides have defended his recent comments, stating that he was not disparaging the value of construction jobs but rather highlighting the lack of a comprehensive jobs strategy from House Republicans. Dan Pfeiffer, senior adviser to Mr. Obama, told reporters that the President's latest comments are "not inconsistent" with previous statements about construction jobs.

"One infrastructure project is not a jobs strategy," Mr. Pfeiffer said. "That would be like saying our jobs strategy is to repair the Key Bridge. We’re talking about one thing, and it would have some temporary jobs which would be significant. But in the overall scale of the employment situation in this country, as the president said, it’s a blip."

Mr. Pfeiffer suggested that the President's comments about Keystone are aimed at September confrontations with Republicans over spending and borrowing.

"He’s put his jobs ideas on the table, he’s calling on Republicans to do the same," Mr. Pfeiffer said. "To date, the core of the Republican jobs package… is vote to repeal Obamacare for the 40th time and build the Keystone pipeline. There’s a legitimate debate over whether you should build that pipeline or not. The president’s point is that’s not a jobs strategy."

Republican lawmakers have criticized the President's job estimates for the project, with House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton stating, "The president famously pledged to ‘do whatever it takes’ to create jobs—but this is a new low."

The State Department has estimated that the pipeline project would create 5,000 to 6,000 construction jobs per year, with TransCanada Corp., the pipeline builder, estimating about 13,000 jobs over two years. The State Department also said the project could support another 42,000 jobs per year for two years across the U.S. in related industries.

Title: Trump Endorses Paul Ryan, Shocks Grassroots Conservatives

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump endorsed House Speaker Paul D. Ryan on Friday, marking an end to his days-long hesitation to back the party's most influential leader.

"In our shared mission to make America great again, I support and endorse our speaker of the House, Paul Ryan," Mr. Trump said at a campaign rally in Mr. Ryan's home state of Wisconsin.

The endorsement signaled a readiness from the New York billionaire to work with the Republican Party establishment that had initially opposed his candidacy. However, it also sparked outrage among grass-roots conservatives who wanted Mr. Trump to challenge establishment figures like Mr. Ryan, viewed as fake conservatives or RINOs, the derogatory acronym for those deemed to be Republicans in name only.

Mr. Trump had previously withheld his endorsement in Mr. Ryan's primary race against an anti-establishment rival, Paul Nehlen, a strong Trump supporter. In recent days, Mr. Trump had stated that he "wasn't there yet" in backing Mr. Ryan, echoing the speaker's earlier comments when he resisted endorsing Mr. Trump.

At the rally in Green Bay, Wisconsin, Mr. Trump referenced Ronald Reagan's tenet, stating, "We may disagree on a couple of things, but mostly we agree. And we're going to get it done, and we're going to do a lot of wonderful things."

In addition to endorsing Mr. Ryan, Mr. Trump also announced endorsements for two Senate Republican incumbents in tight races who had been tentative in their support for him: Arizona Sen. John McCain and New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte.

The trio of endorsements, particularly the one for Mr. Ryan, caught some of Mr. Trump's diehard supporters off guard.

"He has broken our heart doing this tonight," said Trump supporter Sue Payne, a conservative activist working to defeat Mr. Ryan. "We finally thought we had a voice to stand up against the RINO establishment. He sold us out."

"What happened tonight is the establishment got their claws in him and they are pulling the strings. What do we believe now?" she added.

Mr. Nehlen, who faced an uphill battle in taking on the powerful House speaker, understood Mr. Trump's decision to back the party leadership.

"Given his stature as our party's official nominee, Mr. Trump's decision to support the Republican Speaker is appropriate and is a display of true leadership," Mr. Nehlen said in a statement.

"Mr. Trump's early refusal to endorse Ryan sent a clear signal to Wisconsin voters that Ryan is not his preferred candidate in this race. Speaker Ryan's globalist agenda stands in clear opposition to the will of the Republican electorate, who want safe communities, immigration control, smart trade deals, and leaders who put the needs of the American people first," he added.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Rule to Limit Food Stamp Benefits, Sparking Controversy

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a move that has sparked controversy, the Trump administration has proposed a rule that could potentially affect as many as 3.1 million recipients of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). The proposed rule, unveiled Tuesday, aims to eliminate what the administration deems as "loopholes" and save taxpayer funds.

Under the proposed rule, the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) SNAP would no longer provide benefits to families solely because they are enrolled in food assistance programs run by the states where they reside. This change is intended to address a situation where some states have expanded eligibility to recipients who would not otherwise qualify for the federal program based on asset or income limitations.

USDA officials argue that the proposed rule would "fix a loophole" that has allowed households to receive assistance "when they clearly don’t need it." The agency claims the proposal could save billions in taxpayer funds. Recipients who lose their benefits could reapply and qualify if they meet the federal standards for assistance.

Critics, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), have denounced the proposal, with Pelosi calling it an "act of staggering callousness." Anti-poverty advocates argue that the rule will make working Americans hungrier and make it harder for families to work their way out of poverty.

Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue defended the proposal, stating, "The American people expect their government to be fair, efficient, and to have integrity – just as they do in their own homes, businesses, and communities."

The proposed rule comes after the administration's December proposal to tighten work requirements for SNAP recipients. This previous proposal would restrict states from exempting work-eligible adults from receiving food stamps if they are not seeking employment.

In response to the latest proposal, Rep. Marcia Fudge (D-Ohio) criticized the move as a hypocritical dictate from a party that often preaches states' rights. "When it comes to putting that rhetoric into practice for SNAP, they take the opposite position," she said.

The debate over the food stamp program, often considered an example of government waste by conservatives, continues to be a contentious issue in Washington. In December, Congress rejected Republican-sponsored changes to SNAP as part of a $400 billion farm bill.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Disrupt U.S. House Impeachment Inquiry, Prevent Pentagon Official's Testimony

Aritcle:

In a dramatic turn of events, Republican lawmakers disrupted the U.S. House of Representatives impeachment inquiry on Wednesday, preventing a Pentagon official from testifying. The incident occurred during a closed-door hearing with Laura Cooper, the U.S. defense official who oversees Ukraine and Russia matters.

The impeachment inquiry, which focuses on President Donald Trump's request for Ukraine to investigate his political rival, Democrat Joe Biden, was the center of the confrontation. In a highly charged atmosphere, Republican lawmakers stormed into a hearing room where Cooper was due to testify, causing a commotion and prompting the intervention of Capitol police.

Republican Representative Ted Lieu described the situation, stating, "They're freaked out. They're trying to stop this investigation. They don't want to hear from witness Cooper today. They know more facts are going to be delivered which are absolutely damning to the president of the United States."

Republican Representative Mark Meadows explained the lawmakers' actions, saying, "There's about 20 members (lawmakers) down there, at least a dozen that are not on the three committees. And they're going to wait until there's a more open and transparent process."

The Republicans' actions have been met with criticism from Democrats, who view it as an attempt to obstruct the impeachment inquiry and intimidate witnesses. Democratic Representative Eric Swalwell stated, "We see this as an effort not only to intimidate this witness but also to intimidate future witnesses from coming forward. It's not going to work. We're not going to be deterred."

The impeachment inquiry could lead to the House passing formal charges, known as articles of impeachment, prompting a trial in the Republican-controlled Senate on whether to remove Trump from office. However, Senate Republicans have shown little appetite for removing Trump.

This is not the first time Republicans have criticized the impeachment process, with some calling it a "joke," a "railroad job," a "charade," and "Soviet-style." The inquiry, triggered by a whistleblower complaint against Trump, has seen several key witnesses testify, including William Taylor, the top U.S. diplomat in Ukraine, who testified that Trump had made the aid contingent on Ukraine announcing investigations into Biden and his son Hunter Biden's tenure on the board of a Ukrainian energy company.

Cooper, the deputy assistant secretary of defense for Russia, Ukraine, and Eurasia, did not testify on Wednesday, and the day's impeachment-related proceedings were suspended. As the impeachment inquiry continues, the focus remains on the allegations against President Trump and the actions of the U.S. Congress in addressing them.

Title: Bernie Sanders Calls for Unprecedented Measures to Address COVID-19 Crisis, Emphasizes Long-term Policy Changes

Article:

In the face of the unprecedented medical and economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, has called for immediate and far-reaching measures to protect all Americans. Sanders emphasized the need for a response that is guided by medical professionals, not politicians, and for long-term policy changes to ensure the country is better prepared for future emergencies.

Sanders, in a commentary published by CNN, stated, "Our response must meet the enormous scale of the pandemic." He called for increased availability of coronavirus test kits, accelerated processing of tests, and the building out of more intensive care units and obtaining additional ventilators. Sanders also emphasized the importance of collaboration with other countries to learn about the novel coronavirus.

In the short term, Sanders believes that the response must prioritize the health and safety of all people, regardless of their income. He stated, "In the short term, we must respond with unprecedented measures to make sure we protect all people regardless of their income."

However, Sanders also called for long-term policy changes, particularly in the areas of healthcare and paid family and medical leave. He argued that the current healthcare system in the U.S. is inadequate, with many Americans uninsured or underinsured, and that the pandemic has put a spotlight on the shortcomings of the current system. Sanders called for a guarantee of healthcare as a human right, not a privilege.

Sanders also highlighted the need for paid family and medical leave, stating that many workers may be going to work while sick due to financial constraints. He called for the U.S. to join other major countries in guaranteeing paid family and medical leave to all workers.

Sanders also criticized globalization and disastrous trade policies, stating that they have outsourced jobs and factories overseas, leaving the U.S. dependent on other countries for essential goods during a national crisis. He called for fair trade policies that bring production and manufacturing back to the U.S.

Sanders concluded by stating, "That is what our presidential campaign has been all about — and that is what our whole country must be about in the months ahead." The days ahead will be difficult and challenging, but Sanders emphasized the need for urgent short-term measures and long-term policy changes to fundamentally transform the country for the better.

Title: Democrats Secure Virginia Governor's Seat, Boosting National Morale Amidst Trump Era

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) - Democrat Ralph Northam clinched a hard-fought victory in the Virginia gubernatorial race on Tuesday, marking a setback for President Donald Trump as Northam defeated Republican Ed Gillespie in a contest that saw a series of contentious exchanges on divisive issues.

Northam, the state's lieutenant governor, managed to withstand a barrage of attack ads from Gillespie, who targeted the soft-spoken Democrat on issues such as immigration, gang crime, and Confederate statues. Trump, who endorsed Gillespie but did not campaign with him, had sent tweets and recorded messages in support of the former Republican National Committee chairman on Tuesday. However, after the election results, Trump quickly distanced himself from Gillespie.

"Ed Gillespie worked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for," Trump tweeted. "With the economy doing record numbers, we will continue to win, even bigger than before!"

At his victory party, Northam told supporters that the Democratic sweep in Virginia sent a message to the nation.

"Virginia has told us to end the divisiveness, that we will not condone hatred and bigotry, and to end the politics that have torn this country apart," Northam said.

The Virginia race was part of a series of state and local elections that also included a governor's race in New Jersey, where Democrat Phil Murphy, a former investment banker and ambassador to Germany, defeated Republican Kim Guadagno for the right to succeed Republican Chris Christie. Murphy had pledged to serve as a check on Trump in Democratic-leaning New Jersey. Guadagno, the lieutenant governor, was hindered by her association with the unpopular Christie.

Murphy's win, along with Northam's victory in Virginia, a state that Clinton won by 5 percentage points in the 2016 presidential election, provided a much-needed boost for national Democrats who were eager to translate grassroots resistance to Trump into election victories. Democrats had already lost four special congressional elections earlier this year.

A strong turnout in the Democratic-leaning northern Virginia suburbs of Washington helped propel Northam, who, in the end, won relatively easily. With nearly all precincts reporting, he led by a 53 percent to 45 percent margin.

Exit polls in Virginia showed that one-third of the voters went to the polls to oppose Trump, and only 17 percent went to support him. Democrats also swept the other top statewide Virginia races, winning the offices of lieutenant governor and attorney general, and gaining seats in the Virginia House of Delegates. Democrat Danica Roem became the first transgender person to win a state legislative race.

"This is a comprehensive political victory from statehouse to courthouse. Thank you, Donald Trump!" Democratic U.S. Representative Gerald Connolly of Virginia told Northam's supporters at a victory party in northern Virginia.

In Virginia, Democrats had feared that a Gillespie win would embolden Republicans to emphasize divisive cultural issues in their campaigns for next year's elections, when all 435 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives and 33 of the U.S. Senate's 100 seats come up for election. Republicans now control both chambers.

Gillespie, speaking to crestfallen supporters in Richmond, Virginia, said he had run a "very policy-focused campaign." However, voters in Arlington County - a suburban Democratic stronghold bordering Washington - said national politics were important to their votes.

"Trump talks about draining the swamp, but Gillespie kind of is the swamp," said Nick Peacemaker, who works in marketing and considered himself a Republican until Trump won the party's presidential nomination. Peacemaker said Gillespie seemed to shift closer to Trump's policies after securing the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

In local races across the country, Democratic Mayor Bill de Blasio in New York and Marty Walsh in Boston both easily won re-election. Voters were also picking mayors in Detroit, Atlanta, Seattle, and Charlotte, North Carolina.

Title: U.S. Restores Sanctions on Iran, Exempts Eight Countries for Oil Imports

Article:

WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Friday reinstated U.S. sanctions on Iran that were lifted under the 2015 nuclear deal, but granted exemptions for eight countries that can continue to import oil from the Islamic Republic without penalty. The sanctions, which take effect on Monday, cover Iran's shipping, financial, and energy sectors, marking the second batch of sanctions re-imposed since President Trump withdrew from the landmark accord in May.

The 2015 deal, one of former President Obama's biggest diplomatic achievements, provided Iran with billions of dollars in sanctions relief in exchange for curbs on its nuclear program, which many believed was being used to develop atomic weapons. President Trump repeatedly denounced the agreement as the "worst ever" negotiated by the United States and argued it gave Iran too much in return for too little.

Proponents, as well as the other parties to the deal—Britain, China, France, Germany, Russia, and the European Union—have vigorously defended it. The Europeans have launched a drive to save the agreement without the U.S., fearing that the new sanctions will drive Iran to pull out and resume all of its nuclear work.

The new measures are expected to impact Iranians significantly. In Tehran, one man said the harder the U.S. pushes, the more people will resist. In a wealthier area, ███ met the Hossein family. "I want to escape from Iran," said Essam, an accountant, who is disillusioned with both the U.S. and Iranian governments.

Friday's announcement came just days before the U.S. congressional midterm elections, allowing President Trump to highlight his decision to withdraw from the deal—a move that was popular among Republicans. Shortly after the announcement, President Trump tweeted an image of himself that resembles the TV series "Game of Thrones" with the tagline "Sanctions are Coming, November 5."

"Our objective is to force the regime into a clear choice: either abandon its destructive behavior or continue down the path toward economic disaster," President Trump said in a statement issued Friday night. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the sanctions are "aimed at fundamentally altering the behavior of the Islamic Republic of Iran."

Pompeo has issued a list of 12 demands that Iran must meet to have the sanctions lifted, including an end to its support for terrorism and military engagement in Syria and a halt to nuclear and ballistic missile development. Pompeo said eight nations will receive temporary waivers allowing them to continue to import Iranian petroleum products as they phase out such imports entirely. He said these countries, which include U.S. allies such as Turkey, Italy, India, Japan, and South Korea, had made efforts to eliminate their imports but could not complete the task by Monday.

The waivers will be valid for six months, during which time the importing country can buy Iranian oil but must deposit Iran's revenue in an escrow account. Iran can spend the money but only on a narrow range of humanitarian items.

Pompeo defended the oil waivers and noted that since May, when the U.S. began to pressure countries to stop buying Iranian oil, Iran's exports had dropped by more than 1 million barrels per day. He said the Iranian economy is already reeling from the earlier sanctions, with the currency losing half its value since April. The government has ensured basic services like trash collection are working normally, and it's kept gas prices low at about 90 cents a gallon. However, prices in general have skyrocketed, according to ███'s Palmer. That's for "cheese, for butter, for jam, for meat, for chicken, everything," said Reza Eidiyuon, who, like everybody else in Tehran, is worried about the new U.S. sanctions.

Some Iran hawks in Congress and elsewhere said Friday's move should have gone even further. They were hoping for Iran to be disconnected from the main international financial messaging network known as SWIFT.

With limited exceptions, the re-imposed U.S. sanctions will affect Iran as well as countries that do not stop importing Iranian oil and foreign firms that do business with blacklisted Iranian entities, including its central bank, a number of private financial institutions, and state-run port and shipping firms, as well as hundreds of individual Iranian officials.

"Our ultimate aim is to compel Iran to permanently abandon its well-documented outlaw activities and behave as a normal country," Pompeo told reporters in a conference call with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Mnuchin said 700 more Iranian companies and people would be added to the sanctions rolls. Those, he said, would include more than 300 that had not been included under previous sanctions.

On Saturday, the eve of the anniversary of the 1979 takeover of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, Iran's Supreme Leader said the Islamic Republic is the "victorious party" after nearly 40 years of confrontation by the United States. Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said that despite military, economic, and propaganda wars waged by the U.S. against Iran over the last four decades, "the U.S. is the defeated side and the Islamic Republic is the victorious party."

Khamenei said the U.S. has failed to dominate Iran in the way it did before the 1979 Islamic Revolution that ousted a pro-Western monarchy. He said the U.S. is weaker than it was in 1979.

Title: Weinstein Company Requests Removal of Controversial Interviews from 'Fed Up' Documentary on YouTube, Counter-Notification Filed

The Weinstein Company, the distributor of the 2014 documentary 'Fed Up,' has requested that two interviews at the center of allegations of deceptive editing be removed from YouTube. The takedown request, listed as "manually detected" in YouTube's documentation, was made by the Weinstein Company.

The ███ has since initiated a counter-notification, requesting that the videos be reinstated on fair use grounds as they are the subject of a news report. The Free Beacon has moved the videos to another video platform and reinserted them into the original story while the dispute is settled by YouTube.

The videos in question feature two interviews from 'Fed Up' where the producers are accused of unethical editing techniques. In one of the videos, Dr. David Allison is shown stumbling during an answer and then pausing for several seconds before the film cuts to another interview, with an answer to the question he was asked never shown. Dr. Allison stated that he did provide an answer to the question and that Katie Couric, the film's producer and narrator, assured him he could pause to rework answers if needed.

"What she did to me is antithetical to not only just human decency and civility but it is antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue," Dr. Allison told the Free Beacon.

The other video features an interview with former Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation spokesperson Lisa Gable. Industry sources claim the audio of the off-camera interview was manipulated to embarrass Gable. An audio clip of the off-camera interviewer saying she did not believe Gable was answering her questions did not occur at the moment it is portrayed in the film, according to the sources. "That response from the producer didn’t actually follow that particular exchange and was edited to make it look like that was how their conversation actually went," one source said.

The Weinstein Company did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Title: Trump Administration Revokes Obama-Era Transparency Rule on Drone Strike Civilian Deaths

Article:

In a move that has sparked criticism from lawmakers and human rights groups, President Donald Trump has revoked an executive order implemented by his predecessor, Barack Obama, requiring U.S. intelligence officials to disclose the number of civilians killed in drone strikes outside of war zones.

The 2016 executive order, which aimed to increase transparency, was a response to pressure on Obama to be more open about the use of drone strikes, a practice that has become increasingly common since the 9/11 terror attacks. The Trump administration has deemed the rule as "superfluous" and distracting.

The order applied to the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), which has carried out drone strikes in countries such as Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Somalia. The revoked order required the head of the CIA to release annual summaries of U.S. drone strikes and assess how many civilians were killed as a result.

Since Trump's presidency began in 2016, there have been 2,243 drone strikes, compared to 1,878 in Obama's eight years in office, according to the Bureau of Investigative Journalism, a UK-based think tank. During Obama's tenure, 1,878 drone strikes were carried out, according to researchers.

Critics of the drone program under the Obama administration argued that the operations were overly secretive and failed to acknowledge instances of civilian casualties. In response, Obama stated that strikes were carried out in a precise manner, and intelligence officials would release data on civilians who were accidentally killed in strikes outside of war zones.

President Trump has expanded upon the existing program, making it more ambitious. However, some operations outside of war zones have become more secretive under Trump's administration, leading to less transparency.

Lawmakers and rights groups have criticized Trump's decision, expressing concern that it could allow the CIA to conduct drone strikes without accountability. Rita Siemion of Human Rights First stated, "The Trump administration's action is an unnecessary and dangerous step backwards on transparency and accountability for the use of lethal force, and the civilian casualties they cause."

Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat who chairs Congress's intelligence committee, called the requirement issued by Obama "an important measure of transparency," and stated, "there is simply no justification" for cancelling it.

Title: Nike's Controversial Decision to Feature Colin Kaepernick in "Just Do It" Campaign Escalates NFL Protest Controversy

Article:

In a bold move that has further ignited the ongoing debate surrounding athlete activism and the NFL, Nike has chosen to make Colin Kaepernick the face of its 30th anniversary "Just Do It" campaign. The controversial quarterback, who is currently unemployed and taking legal action against the NFL, has become a polarizing figure in America due to his kneel-down protest against police brutality.

The announcement of the campaign has sparked a significant backlash, with Nike stock falling 3 percent, and other athletic shoe companies experiencing similar or greater dips. The hashtag #NikeBoycott trended on Twitter, and reports of Nike gear-burning and other protests have surfaced.

The NFL season is set to kick off this Thursday, and the partnership between Nike and the NFL, which runs through 2028, could potentially cause tension. Every NFL player wears a Nike-made uniform, and all sideline gear worn by players and coaches is likewise logoed. Any player or coach who wishes to protest the Kaepernick-Nike partnership might have to deface their own uniform.

The NFL player-protest issue is currently in limbo, with team owners voting in the offseason to punish players who protest on the field, but the rule is on hold pending negotiations with the players union. Cowboys owner Jerry Jones has stated that any of his players who protest will be punished or banned. His team opens Sunday at Carolina.

The demonstrations are a pet cause of President Trump, who has openly urged owners to fire protesting players. Many NFL team owners are known to quake in fear at Trump's demands and threats. The protests had all but disappeared from everyone's radar until Trump revived the movement early last NFL season with insulting and demeaning tweets.

Last week, Kaepernick's grievance against the NFL for colluding to deny him employment received a boost when an arbitrator denied the NFL's request for a dismissal. A portion of the money Nike pays the league for sponsorship could potentially wind up in Kaepernick's pocket.

Nike reportedly plans to sell Kaepernick shoes and sportswear, and to back up the initial "Believe" ad with billboards, TV commercials, and online ads. A billboard of the first Kaepernick ad went up near Niketown at Union Square on Tuesday.

Nike's corporate sincerity in backing Kaepernick's cause has been called into question. After all, the company plans to make money by selling Kaepernick gear. However, if Nike didn't have its heart and soul in this campaign, why would the company take the enormous and obvious risk in alienating millions of customers?

The NFL released a statement from Jocelyn Moore, the NFL's vice president of communications and public affairs, saying, "The National Football League believes in dialogue, understanding, and unity. We embrace the role and responsibility of everyone involved with this game to promote meaningful, positive change in our communities. The social justice issues that Colin and other professional athletes have raised deserve our attention and action."

A recent NBC News and Wall Street Journal poll showed 54 percent of Americans feel the NFL protests are "inappropriate," while 43 percent go with "appropriate." Whatever profits Nike might make on Kaepernick gear would seem to be more than offset by the loss of revenue from protests of Nike.

Nike could have avoided the backlash by simply remaining out of the fray, or by quietly backing Kaepernick. This had to be a decision made at the Phil Knight level. Maybe Knight and his knights were heeding the words of Martin Luther King Jr.: "There comes a time when silence is betrayal."

The NFL is now caught in a difficult position. If the owners follow the lead of Trump, Jones, and a majority (however narrow) of Americans, the league risks alienating about half its fans and maybe more than half its players. Almost all the protesting players are black, and 70 percent of the league's players are black. That's a powerful lobby.

However, if the NFL caves to the players' union, and allows at least some protests, the league risks suffering boycotts of games and team and league sponsors. Other than the racial component of the debate, there are many shades of gray. Support for Kaepernick is problematical for those who can't forget or forgive him wearing cartoon-pig socks to protest police brutality.

For some, the new Nike campaign casts doubt on his rebel persona. "Revolutionaries aren't sponsored by major corporations," said Fox Sports commentator Jason Whitlock. But if a revolution is being waged against forces backed by money and power, isn't money and power needed by the revolutionaries?

And does anyone really believe Kaepernick willingly gave up a pro football career in order to cash in on his revolution by selling shoes? This is a man who, while unemployed, donated $1 million to hand-selected causes and who continues to lead educational camps for inner-city kids.

If that's all been a Kaepernick scheme to get rich selling shoes, it's certainly revolutionary.

Title: Columbia University's cultureSHOCK Event: Comedian Nimesh Patel Removed for Controversial Performance

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, comedian Nimesh Patel, a former Saturday Night Live writer, was removed from the stage during Columbia University's cultureSHOCK: Reclaim event. The annual charity showcase, which aims to promote Asian-American artistic expression and challenge harmful stereotypes, saw Patel's performance cut short due to jokes deemed homophobic and racist.

According to the Columbia Daily Spectator, Patel's set included commentary on his experience living in a diverse area of New York City, which included a joke about a gay black man in his neighborhood. This material was found inappropriate by the Columbia Asian American Alliance (AAA), the organizers of the event.

During the performance, Patel made a remark about sexual orientation, stating, "No one looks in the mirror and thinks, 'This black thing is too easy; let me just add another thing to it.'" This comment, along with his remarks about racial identities, prompted members of AAA to interrupt the performance and denounce his material.

After a few moments for closing remarks, Patel pushed back, asserting that none of his jokes were offensive. He claimed that he was merely exposing the audience to ideas that would be found "in the real world." However, his microphone was cut from offstage, and he exited the event.

In a statement on Facebook, AAA defended its decision, stating, "Patel's remarks ran counter to the inclusive spirit and integrity of cultureSHOCK, and as such, the choice was made to invite him to leave." The group added, "We acknowledge that discomfort and safety can coexist, however, the discomfort Patel caused was unproductive in this space." AAA also expressed regret for inviting Patel in the first place.

Reactions from the audience were reportedly split on AAA's decision to remove Patel. As of now, Patel has yet to comment on the event. The 32-year-old comedian was the first Indian-American writer for SNL, but he left after last season. He has since been nominated for an Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing and has opened for comedians such as Chris Rock.

Title: "2020 Presidential Election: Trump Trailing in Polls, but Incumbency Advantage Remains a Factor"

Article:

In the latest polls, President Donald Trump is trailing most Democratic candidates in the 2020 general election, even in traditionally Republican strongholds like Texas. While this may seem like a promising sign for Democratic voters, they should exercise caution in interpreting these results. The 2016 election demonstrated that polls taken 14 months before an election are not always predictive, and the race becomes more meaningful when a specific Democrat is pitted against a specific Republican.

The latest polling data from Texas, for instance, shows Trump polling behind not only Joe Biden but also Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Kamala Harris. The numbers from Latino Decisions, North Star Opinion Research, and the University of Houston indicate that Trump's support ranges between 41% and 44% in the Lone Star State.

Similarly, a recent poll from the Washington Post and ABC News at the national level among registered voters shows Trump failing to breach 45% against any of his potential Democratic opponents.

While it may be tempting to analyze the minor differences between the Democratic candidates in these polls, political analysts advise against over-interpreting these variations. The results, they argue, reveal more about Trump's vulnerability than they do about the relative strengths of the Democratic candidates.

"The results tell us a lot more about Trump's vulnerability than it shows the strength of the different Democratic candidates relative to each other," one pollster working with a 2020 campaign said.

Trump has time to turn his position around, but he currently appears to be in a weaker position for re-election compared to the last two presidents who won second terms. A recent CNN poll shows that six in ten Americans believe Trump does not deserve a second term, a higher percentage than was reported for Obama or George W. Bush at the same stage of their presidencies.

Furthermore, Trump's approval rating has consistently been unpopular throughout his first two years in office. According to the RealClearPolitics average of the president's approval rating, Trump has been 7 points more unpopular than popular, a stark contrast to the traditional driver of presidential approval, the economy.

In conclusion, while the Democratic primary remains focused on the concept of electability, these polls suggest that Trump is in a weak position, and his path to victory becomes increasingly narrow if he fails to win over more voters. His low approval rating coupled with his poor showing in hypothetical head-to-head match-ups indicate that he may not be finding a winning strategy despite holding a winning hand.

Title: Rep. Peter T. King Urges FBI to Focus on Muslim Community in Wake of Boston Marathon Bombings

Article:

In the aftermath of the Boston Marathon bombings, Rep. Peter T. King, a leading GOP congressman and chairman of the House Homeland Security subcommittee on counterintelligence and terrorism, has called for the FBI to focus their investigations on threats from within the Muslim community.

During an interview on "Fox News Sunday," King stated, "If you know a threat is coming from a certain community, that's where you look." He emphasized that the strategy of terrorists has evolved since September 11, 2001, with groups like al Qaeda planning massive attacks from Middle Eastern training camps less frequently. Instead, they are using individuals, such as the two suspected Boston bombers, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who died during a shootout with police on Thursday night, and his brother, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was shot and remains in serious condition in a hospital. Both men were of Islamic faith.

King also criticized the FBI for failing to apprehend the two men before the bombings, which killed three and injured over 160 at the iconic Boston race on Monday. The FBI reportedly interviewed Tamerlan Tsarnaev but found no links to terrorism.

In response to King's comments, the Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center issued a statement expressing their condolences and regret for the tragedy. They acknowledged that both suspects were known to their community, yet no one was able to predict the alleged suspects' actions. The statement read, "This hurts, and we wish we all could have done something to prevent this."

The call for increased scrutiny of the Muslim community in the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings has sparked controversy and debate, with many questioning the effectiveness and fairness of such an approach. The FBI and other law enforcement agencies continue to investigate the bombings and have not yet determined the motives behind the attack.

Title: GSK Accelerates Production of Ebola Vaccine Amid Ongoing West African Outbreak

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing Ebola epidemic in West Africa, the drug company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has announced an unprecedented move to start mass production of a vaccine that is currently in the early stages of human testing. This decision comes after the World Health Organization (WHO) declared it ethical to use unproven and experimental treatments in this public health emergency.

The push to discover Ebola therapies could potentially be a silver lining of the epidemic, as companies involved in Ebola drug development have pledged to bring their treatments to those in need if they prove effective. However, the road to market for new drugs is long, tedious, and fraught with failure.

The process of bringing a drug or vaccine to market in the United States typically involves three phases of clinical trials in humans. Before testing it on humans, researchers must first present promising data from animal studies to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and receive approval to recruit patients. This pre-clinical phase of drug development can take several years, and for every 5,000 compounds discovered at this stage, only about five are allowed to proceed to human trials.

If a drug moves forward, researchers must find hundreds and then thousands of volunteers to participate in clinical trials. In the first phase, they test the drug's safety on a small group of healthy individuals to ensure it doesn't cause immediate harm or worsen health conditions, and to determine the maximum tolerable dose.

In a larger group of participants, they test to ensure the treatment delivers on its promise and monitor its effectiveness against the best-available therapies or a placebo. The third phase involves an even larger group, up to 3,000 people, and researchers compare how the drug works against other treatments on the market and analyze safety data.

This entire drug development process takes an average of 12 years, and costs between $100 million and $1 billion. Only one in five therapies make it through this process, and it usually takes the FDA a couple of years to consider the data and bring the drug to market if it chooses to do so.

GSK is already manufacturing an Ebola vaccine that has only promising animal studies behind it, but has not yet been fully tested in humans. The company has said it will have 10,000 doses stockpiled should the science for the vaccine prove out. However, the vaccine is only in phase one, a long way from the end of the development road.

When asked about the timeline for bringing the Ebola vaccine to market, GSK representatives explained that the normal pathway for bringing a vaccine to market takes 10 years, and they are already three years into the process with the Ebola vaccine. While the crisis has focused attention on Ebola drug development and helped to galvanize resources, they were not yet clear on what would happen after a successful phase one trial and how much longer it would take to scale-up manufacturing and get the vaccine approved for use in people.

There is a chance that the usual process might be condensed or phases of clinical testing skipped, since Ebola is an unusually deadly pathogen and will be treated differently by regulators. However, even in dire situations, developing safe, new therapies takes time, and unfortunately, mostly ends in failure. We are only in phase one with the Ebola vaccine. If data look promising, hopefully, regulators will find ways to ensure it's not seven more years until we can prevent another Ebola epidemic.

Title: Trump's Apology and Kavanaugh's Swearing-In: A Turning Point in American Politics

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, President Donald Trump delivered a compassionate and apologetic speech at the swearing-in ceremony of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court on Monday night. The president expressed remorse for the "terrible pain and suffering" Kavanaugh and his family endured during the contentious confirmation process, which he described as a violation of fairness and the presumption of innocence.

Trump also addressed Kavanaugh's young daughters, praising their father as a "great man, a man of decency, character, kindness, and courage." The event, which took place in front of a cheering White House audience, was a display of Republican solidarity, with Senators Mitch McConnell, Charles Grassley, Lindsey Graham, and Susan Collins in attendance.

The ceremony, however, was more than just a show of support. With the eight other Supreme Court justices present, Trump aimed to restore dignity to the judiciary, which has been tarnished by the mudslinging politics that characterized Kavanaugh's confirmation process. The president's concern that the character assassination attempt on Kavanaugh may be a seminal moment in American political and cultural history is well-founded.

The ideas that the court is just another political branch and that the presumption of innocence no longer applies if you are on the other team represent a seismic shift in how we view each other and the nation as a whole. If these ideas persist, we are in more trouble than we can imagine.

While Trump has at times contributed to the political rancor, he was commendable in his efforts to repair the damage inflicted by Senate Democrats and their media allies during the confirmation process. Hillary Clinton, in an interview with CNN, suggested that civility can return when Democrats regain power. Her comments are as reckless as bringing a can of gasoline to a bonfire, stoking trouble to gain a foothold in the 2020 race.

In a separate event, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio signed legislation allowing a third gender option on city birth certificates. The change, which takes effect on January 1, removes the requirement for a medical or mental health professional's affirmation of an individual's gender to change the certificate. While the change may be significant for some, questions have been raised about its impact on society and the city's priorities.

In conclusion, the events of the past two days have highlighted the polarization in American politics and society. The Kavanaugh confirmation process has revealed the Republican Party's ability to fight back and win, while the third gender option on city birth certificates has sparked debate about societal norms and priorities. As citizens, it is crucial to engage in open and respectful dialogue to navigate these challenging times.

Title: Undercover Footage Reveals Alleged Violent Tactics of Rose City Antifa Group in Portland

Article:

Investigative journalism group Project Veritas has released undercover footage of the secretive Rose City Antifa (RCA) group in Portland, Oregon, allegedly showing activists promoting violence and teaching combat techniques. The footage, released on Thursday, reportedly shows Project Veritas infiltrating RCA through an unnamed individual who took undercover footage of the group's ultra-secretive meetings.

The footage reveals a man identified as Nicholas Cifuni discussing the need to hide weapons from the police, stating, "Don't be that fucking guy with the goddamn spike brass knuckles getting photos taken of you." He also allegedly teaches combat techniques such as eye gouging, stating, "Practice things like an eye gouge. It takes very little pressure to injure someone's eyes."

The infiltrator, wearing a hoodie, ski mask, and sunglasses to protect his identity, described the process of becoming a member of Antifa, stating he was a "prospect" for the group. By his account, RCA enforced strict security measures, such as placing their phones in a neighboring bathroom with a fan that muffles sounds during meetings to prevent surveillance.

The source went on to show the vigorous security precautions deployed by the group upon their first meeting, remarking, "They were getting this tradecraft from someone else, someone with much more experience, someone who did this for a living."

Project Veritas identified the alleged founder of Rose City Antifa as Caroline Victorin, who previously lived in Sweden with her Swedish husband. Records uncovered by ███ indicate the couple moved in 2017 following a 2015 Gofundme fundraiser that attempted to procure funds for a green card for Caroline's husband.

Sweden has a large Antifa scene; a Swedish Defence Research Institute (FOI) report detailed the extent of the movement and tied the Swedish "anti-hate" group, the Expo Foundation, along with the UK anti-hate group Hope not Hate to the Antifa anarchist scene. Both groups have also received cash in the past from Hungarian-American left-wing billionaire George Soros through his Open Society Foundation.

Based in the city of Portland, RCA has become well-known as one of the most violent cells of Antifa in the United States and has been well-documented by journalist Andy Ngo. Ngo himself was brutally beaten by the group during a protest last year and suffered a brain bleed as a result.

President Donald Trump announced plans to designate the violent leftist group Antifa as a terrorist organization in May 2020. The group has been linked to several violent incidents during the ongoing riots that began in Minneapolis, and RCA has also been active in Portland in recent days. They are allegedly behind a May 30 attack on a man carrying an American flag during the anti-police brutality protest, shouting, "Black lives matter, faggot," as they beat him.

Title: Maryland Newspaper Staff Resilient After Deadly Shooting at Capital Gazette Office

Article:

In the aftermath of a tragic shooting incident at the Capital Gazette office in Annapolis, Maryland, the newspaper's staff demonstrated remarkable resilience, publishing a Friday edition from a makeshift location. The attack, which left five employees dead and two more injured, occurred on Thursday when a gunman entered the building with a shotgun and opened fire.

Chase Cook, a Capital Gazette reporter, tweeted, "We are putting out a damn paper tomorrow." Staff members worked in the parking lot to ensure the publication of the newspaper. The gunman was arrested shortly after the incident and has been charged with five counts of first-degree murder.

The suspect, identified as Jarrod Ramos, is reported to have unsuccessfully sued the newspaper group for defamation in 2012. The Capital Gazette published obituaries for their fallen colleagues and shared the front page of their Friday paper on social media.

The shooting, which occurred at 14:40 local time (18:40 GMT), sent shockwaves through the newsroom as journalists posted updates on social media as the gunman fired through the glass door of the office. Anthony Messenger, an intern at the paper, tweeted during the attack. Selene San Felice, a staff member, told CNN that her initial reaction was to lie down under her desk.

Phil Davis, a crime reporter who was also in the building, told The Baltimore Sun that he and his colleagues hid under their desks during the attack. "I don't know why he stopped [shooting]," he told the paper. He described the scene as "like a war zone" and shared his experiences as he waited to be interviewed by police.

County executive Steve Schuh told CNN that the suspect had been hiding under a desk in the building when police officers arrived "within 60 seconds" of receiving news of the incident. There was "no exchange of fire," he added.

William Krampf, deputy chief of Anne Arundel County Police, stated that the gunman had entered the building with a shotgun and "looked for his victims as he walked through the lower level." An item believed to be an explosive device was found at the premises and destroyed, but later turned out to be a smoke bomb.

Police safely evacuated 170 people from the building, which housed 30 other businesses. The Committee to Protect Journalists reported that before the Maryland shooting, seven journalists had been killed in the US in relation to their work since 1992.

The Capital Gazette reportedly wrote an article in 2011 about a woman who said Jarrod Ramos was stalking her, and he failed in his attempts to sue the paper for defamation the following year. Police did not ascribe any motive after arresting him following Thursday's attack.

Ramos is scheduled for a bail hearing on Friday morning in Annapolis. Federal agencies, including the FBI and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, were involved in the response to the attack.

Maryland governor Larry Hogan expressed his condolences on Twitter, stating he was "absolutely devastated" and in contact with authorities. President Donald Trump tweeted his "thoughts and prayers" were with the victims and their families. The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders, later condemned the attack on "innocent journalists doing their job."

The New York City Police Department (NYPD) deployed counterterrorism teams to media organizations in and around New York City as a precaution. Mayor of Annapolis Gavin Buckley told the Guardian he could not understand how the paper "could make someone that hostile."

"If this is an attack on journalism, it is a sad state of affairs," he said. "Because journalists, you don't get paid enough to put your life on the line, we're not in some war zone, we're not in some third-world country with a dictator."

Democratic senator Chris Van Hollen responded to a Gazette reporter on Twitter. Writer and alt-right figure Milo Yiannopoulos has faced criticism online for a controversial tweet about journalists. Mr. Yiannopoulos has since defended himself, stating the message was "a troll."

Title: Trump Delivers Unifying Address to Nation, Outlines Policy Priorities

Article:

WASHINGTON -- In a bid to unify a divided nation and inspire the future, President Donald Trump delivered a speech to Congress on Tuesday, outlining his policy priorities and reaffirming his commitment to keeping his campaign promises.

The president set the tone with a public commemoration of Black History Month while reflecting on the work that remains to be done. He addressed recent threats targeting the Jewish community, vandalism of Jewish cemeteries, and the shooting in Kansas City, stating, "We are a country that stands united in condemning hate and evil in all of its very ugly forms."

Education was highlighted as the "civil rights issue of our day," with the president suggesting that allowing school choice will help revitalize urban regions and failing minority youths. He also doubled down on his promise to get tough on illegal immigration, stating, "We are removing gang members, drug dealers, and criminals that threaten our communities and prey on our citizens."

In a moving moment, the president recognized Carryn Owens, the widow of Senior Chief William "Ryan" Owens, who was killed last month in a covert raid against al-Qaeda in Yemen. He also called on Congress to dream big and dare bold moves for the nation, stating, "This is our vision. This is our mission."

The Democratic response was delivered by former Kentucky Gov. Steve Beshear, who criticized the president for rolling back regulations, waging war on immigrants, and calling to repeal Obamacare.

Congressional members had a lot to say about President Trump's joint address, with many praising his unifying message and statesman-like demeanor. However, some expressed concerns about the lack of specifics in the president's speech, particularly regarding his budget and healthcare proposals.

Republican lawmakers feel encouraged and are ready to work on priorities like immigration reform and repealing and replacing Obamacare. Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell met with President Trump ahead of his speech and told the media they are on board with the president's bold agenda.

Title: Controversy Erupts Over Alleged Skinny-Dipping Incident by GOP Congressmen in Israel

Article:

A controversial report by Politico detailing a late-night skinny-dipping incident involving several Republican congressmen during a trip to Israel last year has sparked a series of clarifications and accusations between two primary opponents.

The report, which has since been met with denials and counter-accusations, claims the FBI investigated the incident, which took place during a visit by a group of GOP freshmen and leaders as guests of The American Israel Educational Foundation.

According to the report, Kansas Rep. Kevin Yoder was among those who stripped naked and jumped into the water that night, with several other lawmakers and staff members also participating, some of whom were clothed or partially clothed. Alcohol may have been a factor for some, the report suggests.

The congressmen named in the report include Florida Rep. Steve Southerland, New York Rep. Tom Reed, California Rep. Jeff Denham, and New York Rep. Michael Grimm. The report also named Arizona Rep. Ben Quayle as participating, but his office and his wife vehemently denied his involvement.

Jay Heiler, Quayle's spokesman, told Fox News that Politico's inclusion of the congressman in the beach scenes was inaccurate. He stated that people were leaving the dinner that night at different times, and Quayle did not go to the beach afterward.

Quayle's primary opponent, Rep. Dave Schweikert, has since accused Quayle of embarrassing "both the institution of Congress and Arizona with his completely inappropriate behavior that calls into question yet again his fitness to be in Congress."

In response, Quayle's wife, Tiffany, claimed the Quayle family did not partake in the water antics, despite the Politico report. "Ben and I and our daughter Evie were there together that evening in the Holy Land, although I was eight and a half months pregnant with her," she said. "We were neither party nor witness to any of the inappropriate behavior described in the article, nor were we a part of, or aware of any inquiry. We did return to Arizona with some water from the Sea of Galilee to baptize Evie after she was born."

The Sea of Galilee is where Jesus is said to have walked on water.

In a statement to the Kansas City Star, Yoder expressed remorse for any embarrassment caused. "I feel incredibly remorseful that I have caused embarrassment to my constituents and I have caused folks who believe in me to be disappointed," he said.

The incident has been rebuked by House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, the most senior Republican on the trip and the most senior Jewish lawmaker in Congress.

Title: FBI's Handling of YouTube Comment Raises Questions Amidst Ongoing Florida School Shooting Investigation

Article:

The recent mass shooting at a Florida high school has sparked renewed discussions about the FBI's role in identifying potential threats and preventing such tragedies. Last fall, a Mississippi bail bondsman and video blogger reported a comment on one of his YouTube videos that read, "I'm going to be a professional school shooter." The commenter's username was "Nikolas Cruz," the same name as the 19-year-old suspect in the shooting. However, the FBI has yet to conclusively link the account to the shooter.

On Thursday, FBI Special Agent in Charge of the Miami office, Robert Lasky, stated that the agency interviewed the man who reported the comment and searched public records databases, actions consistent with those taken during an FBI assessment, the lowest level and least intrusive stage of an FBI inquiry. Yet, they were unable to identify the poster.

The day before the shooting, Cruz, armed with an AR-15 rifle, entered his former high school in Florida and opened fire, killing 17 people. This incident follows a series of attacks in the last two years, including the Orlando nightclub massacre, the New York City bombings, and the Florida airport shooting, where the perpetrators had all been looked at by federal agents but were later deemed not to warrant continued law enforcement scrutiny.

FBI assessments are initiated following tips, which can be as simple as observing unusual activity in a neighbor's garage or a classmate's comments. Agents often face the challenge of sifting through the tens of thousands of tips received each year to identify potential threats. Had the FBI been able to confirm Cruz was the same person as the YouTube poster, they would have found numerous photos of rifles, ammunition, and targets filled with bullet holes, likely leading to a face-to-face interview. The FBI did not notify police in Florida about the post before the mass shooting.

Retired FBI Assistant Director Ron Hosko stated, "They owe us some more detail on what they did." The questions arise as the FBI is under scrutiny and facing criticism from President Donald Trump and some congressional Republicans, who have accused the agency of anti-Trump bias, particularly in relation to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe.

However, it is unclear whether the FBI dropped the ball in this case, according to Hosko. "With anything that the FBI receives, they are constrained to act based on what they have in front of them," said Hosko. "You have a random internet posting that suggests the person wants to do something, not that they are planning on doing something."

FBI guidelines balance national security with civil liberties protections, imposing restrictions on the steps agents may take during the assessment phase. Agents can analyze information from government databases and open-source internet searches, and conduct interviews during an assessment. However, they cannot request wiretaps or internet communications without higher levels of approval and a more solid basis to suspect a crime.

"It's a tricky situation because sometimes you get information regarding individuals and they may be just showing off, blustering," said Herbert Cousins Jr., a retired FBI special agent in charge. A vague, uncorroborated threat alone may not be enough to proceed to the next level of investigation, according to Jeffrey Ringel, a former FBI agent and Joint Terrorism Task force supervisor who now works for the Soufan Group, a private security firm.

Many assessments are closed within days or weeks when the FBI concludes there's no criminal or national security threat, or basis for continued scrutiny. The system is designed to ensure that a person who has not broken the law does not remain under perpetual scrutiny on a mere hunch—and that the FBI can reserve its scarce resources for true threats.

Tips like the one that came in about the Florida gunman are among countless complaints that come into the FBI daily with varying degrees of specificity. "How many of these do you expect the FBI to handle before it becomes the Federal Bureau of Complaints?" said retired FBI Assistant Director Ron Hosko. "They could spend their entire workforce tracking down internet exchanges that never going to go anywhere."

Title: Putin's Timely Intervention Saves Obama from Congressional Defeat, but at What Cost?

Article:

In the midst of the latest Syrian crisis, the return of Congress from their summer recess found the nation's future leaders immersed in the rigors of college life. The Class of '17, having been coached to impress college interviewers with tales of global adventures and intellectual pursuits, now find themselves on elite campuses with state-of-the-art facilities and sustainable dining options.

However, the question remains: what are they learning? With the liberal arts diminished in many institutions, students are less likely to be trained in the art of critical analysis and rhetoric, skills that are crucial in understanding history and literature, and in navigating the complexities of political discourse.

Recently, the Syrian crisis, which had put President Barack Obama in a tight spot, took an unexpected turn when Russian President Vladimir Putin intervened, effectively rescuing Obama from a potential defeat in Congress. The White House has since claimed that Obama's "toughness" was instrumental in the favorable turn of events, but the world knows that Putin was the true victor.

Secretary of State John F. Kerry's gaffe, inviting an improbable rescue, mirrors the ancient Greek dramatic device known as deus ex machina, a "god out of the machine" that is used to resolve a seemingly insoluble problem in a play. Aristotle warned against using this device, as it lacks credibility and undermines the believability of the story. Presidents, like playwrights, should avoid relying on such deus ex machina, and instead find a more credible solution to their problems.

The Putin rescue operation has been hailed as a "victory" for Obama by some, but Washington and the West cannot afford another such victory. Putin, as the improbable god in the machine, has effectively taken control of the Syrian conflict and the Middle East, delaying aid to the rebels who had hoped for support. The debate over the Syrian atrocity, which Obama had promised would be a national conversation, has been effectively silenced, decided by who best exploited and manipulated Kerry's gaffe.

Suzanne Fields, a columnist for The ███ and nationally syndicated, questions the value of such a resolution, and the loss of common cultural knowledge that results from the diminished study of the Greek and Roman classics. The ability to reason together, through the use of analogies and metaphors, is a lost skill, and one that is crucial in understanding and navigating the complexities of political discourse.

Putin's timely intervention has saved Obama from a potential defeat, but at what cost? The debate over Syria, and the future of the Middle East, has been effectively silenced, and the world is left to wonder what lessons have been learned, and what the future holds.

Title: Secret Service Director Julia Pierson Resigns Following White House Security Breach

Article:

In a sudden turn of events, United States Secret Service Director Julia Pierson resigned on Wednesday, following a series of high-profile security incidents that raised concerns about the safety of the President and his family. The resignation was announced by Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson in a written statement, and was later confirmed by the White House.

President Obama stated that new leadership was required for the agency, according to White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest. Johnson, in his statement, said, "Today, Julia Pierson, the Director of the United States Secret Service, offered her resignation, and I accepted it. I salute her 30 years of distinguished service to the Secret Service and the Nation."

A source familiar with the situation told Fox News that Johnson told Pierson the resignation would be effective immediately, after she offered it. The resignation comes just days after an intruder jumped the White House fence and made it to the East Room before being apprehended on September 19.

On Tuesday, despite Pierson's rocky performance during congressional testimony, the White House voiced support for her leadership. However, on Wednesday, Pierson was facing bipartisan calls to step down. Rep. Elijah Cummings, top Democrat on the committee that grilled Pierson, notably told NPR she is "not the person to lead that agency."

When asked about the reasons leading to her resignation, Earnest said Pierson had offered her resignation, and that recent and accumulating reports had raised "legitimate questions" about the agency. Johnson said that a "panel of independent experts" should review the September 19 incident, and that such a panel will submit its assessment and recommendations by December 15.

Johnson also appointed Joseph Clancy, a former special agent in charge of the Presidential Protective Division who retired in 2011, as interim director. The September 19 incident involving a Texas Army veteran who jumped the White House fence and was able to make it deep into the Executive Mansion before being stopped is now just one of several embarrassing disclosures about lapses in presidential security involving the Secret Service.

Title: U.S. Sanctions and Criticism Mount as Turkey Presses Ahead with Syria Offensive

Article:

Amidst growing international criticism, Turkey has vowed to continue its military operation in northern Syria, disregarding U.S. sanctions and calls for a halt. The decision has sparked controversy, with many questioning the strategic and moral implications of the move.

The U.S. withdrawal from Syria, initially advocated by President Donald Trump, has been met with criticism due to the potential consequences. Critics argue that the move could lead to the release of thousands of Islamic State fighters, ethnic cleansing, and the empowerment of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Some argue that the decision to withdraw stands apart from past instances of Washington abandoning allies, as the status quo was sustainable. American forces were not taking high numbers of casualties, and the region under the control of the Kurds was largely quiet. Islamic State fighters were penned up, and there was no major international pressure for the United States to withdraw.

If the Trump administration had wanted to accommodate Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's pleas for stronger actions, it could have done so in a more measured and coordinated manner, critics contend. The decision has been criticized as making little strategic sense and as a message to the world's rogues that a U.S. President has little interest in engaging on behalf of American allies or interests.

In response to the Turkish offensive, the U.S. has imposed sanctions, a move that has become the Trump administration's consistent response to complex global problems. However, critics argue that these sanctions may not be effective in stopping a military assault in real-time.

As the U.S. troops scramble to safely withdraw from the affected areas, and the Kurds have signed on to cooperate with Assad's Syrian army, the long-term consequences of the U.S.'s support for Turkey's invasion are becoming apparent. To mitigate the damage, some suggest that the U.S. should take responsibility for making the proposed buffer zone safe, as what is currently a military onslaught could quickly become a humanitarian crisis.

In conclusion, the U.S.'s decision to withdraw from Syria and Turkey's subsequent military operation in northern Syria has been met with criticism from both sides. The move has been criticized for its strategic and moral implications, and the effectiveness of the U.S.'s response, in the form of sanctions, has been questioned. The long-term consequences of the decision are becoming apparent, and the U.S. is now facing the challenge of mitigating the damage.

Title: Rand Paul Navigates Challenges in Advancing Libertarian Agenda on College Campuses

Article:

Rand Paul, the Kentucky Senator and potential 2016 presidential candidate, is visiting various college campuses to promote his libertarian agenda. However, the Republican faces a challenge in appealing to young people without alienating other Republicans.

During a recent appearance at the College of Charleston, Paul, who is known for his libertarian views, was confronted with questions on controversial topics such as abortion and drug policy.

A student asked Paul about his stance on Plan B, the emergency contraception commonly known as the morning-after pill. Paul, who sponsored an anti-abortion bill in 2013 that defines life as beginning at fertilization, initially appeared uncomfortable with the question. He clarified that he is not opposed to birth control, stating that Plan B is essentially a two-day course of birth control pills.

Another student questioned Paul on his views on drug policy, asking if he would support the legalization of marijuana, cocaine, and heroin. Paul stated that he is not in favor of drug use but believes that drug laws should be left up to the states. He cited Colorado and Washington's experimentation with legalized marijuana as an example of something that should be closely observed.

Paul has had success on the college circuit, with visits to universities such as Harvard and Howard garnering positive headlines and praise from Republicans seeking to modernize the party and broaden its national appeal. However, his visits also highlight the challenge he faces in balancing his libertarian ideals with the more conservative leanings of the Republican Party.

When asked about the legalization of hard drugs like cocaine or heroin, Paul hedged, stating that his position has not been for legalization but for less criminalization and more fair adjudication for those caught in the system. He also expressed support for giving young people a second chance.

On the topic of same-sex marriage, Paul favors traditional marriage but believes that states should determine their own marriage laws. When asked about the Republican Party's perceived disconnect with younger generations on this issue, Paul acknowledged the changing attitudes towards same-sex marriage but maintained his traditionalist views.

The interview revealed Paul's delicate dance as he navigates the Republican Party's conservative leanings while attempting to appeal to young voters with his libertarian views. When asked if he could reconsider his stance on same-sex marriage, Paul did not provide a definitive answer, instead expressing a nuanced view on the evolving issue.

Title: "Political Week in Review: Events, Elections, and Controversies Shape the Presidential Race"

Article:

In the aftermath of a series of violent incidents involving police and citizens, the political landscape in the United States has been significantly altered. Last week, two black men were shot dead by police officers in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and a suburb of St. Paul, Minnesota, leading to a violent response by a black extremist in Dallas, Texas, who killed five police officers.

The events have intruded into the presidential campaign, with cop shootings and violence against police becoming front and center issues for the foreseeable future. With additional attacks on police and protests against police shootings across the country, many Americans are deeply concerned that the country is coming apart.

Both candidates, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, have responded to the situation. Trump strongly defended the police, while calling the shootings of Alton Sterling and Philando Castile "senseless" and stating that "racial divisions have gotten worse." Clinton, on the other hand, appeared at a conference of black religious leaders to urge national guidelines for use of force by police.

As the country grapples with these issues, the candidates are not just politicians or office-seekers; they are being sought as healers for the nation. Both candidates have strengths in dealing with these issues, with Trump being viewed as a strong leader and a true supporter of law enforcement, and Clinton adopting a more unifying tone in her campaign and striving to be more emphatic with the African-American community.

The email controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton also continued last week, with FBI Director James Comey finding Clinton guilty of setting up an unauthorized private email server, being "extremely reckless" in handling classified material, and making false statements to the American people. However, Comey refused to indict Clinton, a decision that has not gone away.

Clinton and her surrogates have stated that the fact that she escaped indictment means this issue is now old news. However, she has been found guilty in the court of public opinion as dishonest and untrustworthy, and the "chance" meeting between Bill Clinton and Attorney General Loretta Lynch and the report in the New York Times that Clinton might keep Lynch as A.G. added to the perception that there is one set of rules for the Clintons and one for everyone else.

Trump, on the other hand, spent most of his Cincinnati speech on Wednesday defending his campaign's use of a Star of David in a weekend tweet, rather than focusing on Clinton's email scandal. Trump's failure to dwell on Clinton's email scandal meant the headlines were all about the Star of David, not the case against Hillary.

Looking ahead, Sanders is expected to endorse Clinton this week, but it remains to be seen if this will put an end to further challenges to the Democratic Party's rules or additional platform fights. The Republican rules and platform committees are also meeting this week in Cleveland, with potential fights over the rules and the platform. Trump is also expected to announce his running mate this week, with Newt Gingrich, former Defense Intelligence Agency Director Gen. Michael Flynn, and Indiana Gov. Mike Pence being the most likely contenders.

Overall, the political landscape in the United States is fraught with controversy and division, with the presidential race being shaped by events, elections, and controversies. The candidates' responses to these issues will be crucial in determining the direction the country takes in the coming months.

Title: White House and Republicans Begin Detailed Budget Negotiations, Fiscal Cliff Talks Remain Stalemated

Article:

In a significant development, President Obama's top aides presented a budget framework to Republicans on Thursday, proposing $1.6 trillion in tax increases coupled with future spending cuts to avoid the "fiscal cliff." However, GOP leaders swiftly rejected the offer, urging the White House to "get serious" about spending cuts.

The White House's overture signifies the commencement of real, detailed discussions after weeks of negotiating over principles. Republicans have already agreed to allow the government to raise revenue, and they are seeking Democratic agreement on the need to cut major entitlements such as Medicare. Democrats, on the other hand, argue that Republicans have yet to specify the taxes they will raise or propose their own spending cuts.
