At a news conference, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, called on Republicans to provide specifics on their proposals. "Now is the time for the Republicans to move past this happy talk about revenues—ill-defined, of course—and put specifics on the table," he said, surrounded by his leadership team.

The White House's wish list includes additional stimulus spending, a call to limit Congress' control over the federal debt limit, a rise in the estate tax, and an increase in taxes on dividends. These proposals would reverse parts of President Bush's 2001 and 2003 tax plans and are likely to be contentious among some Democrats, as well as with Republicans.

In exchange, President Obama reiterated his pledge to find up to $400 billion in entitlement spending cuts later, as well as to undertake a tax code overhaul.

Speaker of the House John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, stated after meeting with Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner that no substantive progress has been made in the talks between the White House and the House over the past two weeks.

The White House has shown some flexibility, with President Obama calling for tax rates on upper-income earners to rise from 35 percent to 39.6 percent but being willing to accept something less in negotiations. However, they have stated that rates will have to rise somewhat.

White House spokesman Jay Carney said Republican leaders must "accept the essential fact" that tax rates on the nation's top earners must increase as part of a deficit-reduction deal. "The president will not sign any legislation that extends the Bush-era tax cuts for the top earners in this country," he said.

Congressional Republicans have stated that increasing tax rates is out of the question. Instead, they want the additional government revenue to come from ending tax breaks and closing loopholes.

All sides are trying to avoid the "fiscal cliff"—the expiration of the Bush-era tax cuts on January 1, followed by $110 billion in automatic spending cuts. Going over the cliff and staying there could plunge the country into a short, sharp recession, though delaying the spending cuts and tax increases would mean deeper pain in the long run, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

The challenge for President Obama and Congress is to try to spread the pain while doing the least harm to the economy. The two parties have also staked out different positions on how best to increase the nation's $16.4 trillion debt limit, which the federal government could reach as early as next month.

Title: President Obama Pursues Executive Actions on Various Policy Issues Amidst Republican Opposition

Article:

In a move that is likely to spark controversy among Republican lawmakers, President Barack Obama is reportedly considering a series of wide-ranging executive actions, including new standards for private-sector cybersecurity, refinancing opportunities for homeowners, and energy-efficiency requirements for buildings.

The Washington Post reported that these actions, which also include new protections for homosexual government contractors and tougher regulations for coal-fired power plants, are part of Obama's efforts to advance his top priorities, despite the ongoing gridlock in Congress.

Last month, Obama issued 23 administrative actions on gun violence, and in the past, he has issued orders that delayed the deportations of young illegal immigrants and lowered student loan payments.

A White House official stated that the president is not using his executive powers to bypass Congress, but rather to move forward on issues where progress has stalled in Congress. However, Republicans view this as a power grab and a violation of the Constitution.

Sen. Charles E. Grassley (R-Iowa) recently stated, "It is a very dangerous road he’s going down, contrary to the spirit of the Constitution." Grassley added, "Just because Congress doesn’t act doesn’t mean the president has a right to act."

One of the more significant executive actions being considered by the president, according to the Post, would provide homeowners with a better chance to refinance their mortgages at today's low interest rates. Obama has already used his powers to make refinancing easier for people with loans backed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, but his new plan could extend opportunities to people running behind on the payments of their privately backed mortgages.

The president's decision to move forward with new executive actions is reportedly due to his conclusion that Republicans are unlikely to pass many of his major agenda items. The full extent of the executive actions and their impact remains to be seen, but they are sure to spark debate and controversy in the coming weeks.

Title: The 2016 Presidential Race: A Changing Landscape for the Republican Party

Article:

In the political landscape of 2016, the Republican Party is facing a significant shift in its once-touted "deep bench" of potential presidential candidates. The once-promising prospects of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell, who is currently fighting public corruption charges, and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, embroiled in the George Washington Bridge retribution scandal, have taken a turn for the worse.

McDonnell, a class of 2009 alumnus, is now focusing on avoiding prison time rather than campaigning for the 2016 election. Christie, on the other hand, is under investigation for his role in the Sandy aid controversy, making him vulnerable on multiple fronts.

The No. 2 contender, Senator Marco Rubio, has also faded from the spotlight after his attempt to court the center with immigration reform and his subsequent shift to the right. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, who was lucky to make it to the No. 7 spot, flamed out after his controversial comments about the Republican Party and his unpopularity among voters.

Texas Senator Ted Cruz, who was not on the initial list, has imploded due to his self-promoting and divisive political style. Senator Rand Paul, who made several lists, has been criticized for his plagiarism issues and politically risky foreign policy views.

Representative Paul Ryan, who was No. 5 on the list, has struggled to make a significant impact, with his only contribution to the 2012 ticket being a perceived negative influence on Mitt Romney. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, who is receiving renewed attention due to Christie's troubles, is facing ethical challenges within his own administration.

This leaves former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who is beloved by the GOP establishment but disliked by the Tea Party. His ties to Wall Street and his role in the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy could potentially be a liability in the current political climate.

South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, South Dakota Senator John Thune, and Indiana Representative Mike Pence round out the remaining contenders from the National Journal's initial list. The 2016 presidential race is shaping up to be a fascinating and unpredictable contest, with the Democratic side also facing its own challenges and intrigues.

Title: Michelle Williams Advocates for Reproductive Freedom at 2020 Golden Globes

Article:

Michelle Williams, the acclaimed actress who won the second Golden Globe of her career for her role on Fosse/Verdon, used her acceptance speech to emphasize the importance of reproductive freedom.

During her acceptance speech at the Golden Globes ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday night, Williams expressed gratitude for the choices she's made and for living in a society where choice exists. She stated, "I'm grateful for the acknowledgment of the choices I've made, and I'm also grateful to have lived in a moment in our society where choice exists."

According to a report by Anna North for ███, it is likely that the Supreme Court will dismantle Roe v. Wade in 2020. Already, multiple states have enacted laws that effectively ban abortions, and in March, the Court will hear arguments for June Medical Services v. Gee, a case centered on whether or not Louisiana can restrict abortions to treatment centers where at least one doctor has admitting privileges at an area hospital.

Williams, an active participant in Hollywood's Time's Up movement, declared that she could not have lived the life she's had without the guarantee of a woman's right to choose, and of knowing she would be able "to choose when to have my children, and with whom."

She continued, "I know my choices might look different than yours, but thank god or whomever you pray to that we live in a country founded on the principle that I am free to live by my faith, and you are free to live by yours." Williams concluded her speech by urging women to vote in their self-interest, stating, "Women, 18 to 118, when it is time to vote, please do so in your own self-interest. It's what men have been doing for years."

Tiffany Haddish, who presented the award, applauded Williams' speech vigorously, stating, "I'm about that women's right to choose."

Title: Top Risks to Watch Out for in 2020: A Comprehensive Analysis

Article:

As the new decade begins, the world is facing a multitude of challenges that could potentially disrupt global stability. Robert A. Manning, a senior fellow at the Atlantic Council's Scowcroft Center for Strategy and Security, has outlined a list of top risks to watch for in 2020.

1. 2020 Elections: The outcome of the U.S. elections, whether it's a Trump reelection or a Democratic victory, is expected to deepen political tribalism in the United States. A Trump victory could result in four more years of U.S. withdrawal from the multilateral world order, leading to a global leadership deficit. A narrow Trump loss could cause domestic political turmoil, while a Democratic victory and left-leaning economic policies could fuel uncertainty and market turmoil.

2. Brexit: The United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, scheduled for January 31, 2020, is certain. However, political and economic uncertainties abound. A U.K.-EU trade deal may drag out beyond 2020, leading to the breakup of the United Kingdom, as the Scottish Nationalist Party pursues another independence referendum and Irish nationalist MPs strong election performance in Northern Ireland positions them to ponder their future. London's global financial hub is also at risk.

3. North Korean Defiance: North Korea's nuclear ambitions pose the most immediate challenge of the new nuclear age. Whether there is another Trump-Kim summit or not, tensions are likely to rise in 2020 as Pyongyang continues developing strategic weapons. Kim Jong-un's New Year's Day speech offered a potential summit, but Kim has escalated his blackmail efforts, threatening a "new path" with powerful strategic weapons if the U.S. fails to make concessions.

4. The Great Unraveling: The World Trade Organization (WTO), the key enabler of 70 years of prosperity and a rules-based economic order, may become defunct. In the best-case scenario, after a lapse of six to 24 months, a new arbitration mechanism with a much-reduced mandate and a reformed, but also diminished in scope and authority, WTO may emerge. However, universal rules and enforcement will be less important in shaping the terms of trade than large countries using their market size to weaponize trade via tariffs.

5. A Bifurcated World: The decoupling of the world's two largest economies, the United States and China, amid growing techno-nationalism on both sides, is driving a new global economic dynamic. The main elements of Beijing's predatory mercantilism remain largely undiluted, while Washington is seeking to disrupt supply chains linking the United States and China, cutting off investment, scientific exchanges, and tech exports and imports from China.

6. Gray Swan: A China reckoning/world financial crisis: A perfect storm involving a simultaneous slowdown in the three economic centers (U.S., China, and EU) and the U.S.-China decoupling could catapult the global economy into another deep economic crisis. China's internal contradictions, including massive public, household, and corporate debt, aging demographics, and sagging growth, offer a preview of the costs to the U.S. of a bifurcated global economy.

This is by no means an exhaustive list, but an assessment of top risks to watch for. Other potential conflicts in the greater Middle East, such as Syria, Libya, Yemen, and Iran, are percolating, and proxy or real U.S. conflict with Iran is within the realm of the plausible. All things considered, 2020 promises to be a wild ride. The one risk you won't have to worry about is boredom.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder to Attend Paris Rally Against Terrorism, Declines to Label U.S. as at War with "Radical Islam"

Article:

Attorney General Eric Holder will represent the United States at Sunday's rally against terrorism in Paris, France, according to news reports. President Barack Obama has no public events scheduled, and Secretary of State John Kerry is on a trip to India.

The rally, which millions are expected to attend, will feature several European heads of state and dozens of high-level delegations from other countries. The demonstration is a response to last week's deadly attacks by radical Islamic terrorists on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper and a kosher supermarket, in which twelve and four people were killed, respectively.

In a previous testimony to Congress in May 2010, Holder refused to blame radical Islam in addressing the possible motives of terrorists who had recently launched attacks against the United States. "I don't want to say anything negative about a religion," he said.

Holder has been less careful around matters of race in the United States. He and President Barack Obama have been accused of creating an atmosphere of mistrust in the debate over the deaths of unarmed black suspects at the hands of police–an atmosphere that critics blame for attacks on police, including the assassination of two New York Police Department officers on patrol in an anti-terror exercise last month.

Holder has also sought to try terrorists in federal, civilian courts rather than at military tribunals in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. His department investigated the Central Intelligence Agency's use of "enhanced interrogation techniques" but declined to prosecute any agents. Instead of extended questioning, the U.S. now reads terror suspects their Miranda rights fairly soon after apprehension, under new Department of Justice policies.

In addition, Holder has shown lenience to terrorists in the past. During the administration of Bill Clinton, he reportedly pushed the Department of Justice to drop its objection to the commutations of sentences for members of a Puerto Rican terrorist group.

Fox News reports that Holder will also be participating in meetings in Paris with international counterparts about stopping terror attacks. Holder will also be the featured guest on five major Sunday morning news programs, except for Fox News Sunday.

President Obama is focused on his domestic agenda, and is preparing to continue a nationwide tour this week to preview his upcoming State of the Union address, which will be delivered to Congress the following week. It is possible that Obama has plans to attend the rally but has not announced them for security reasons. Typically, Obama plays golf on Sunday afternoons, declining to continue a personal golf moratorium that George W. Bush initiated in deference to the fact that U.S. troops are at war abroad. There are also two important NFL playoff games on television on Sunday.

Update: AFP's live feed from the rally shows heads of state and foreign dignitaries marching through Paris.

Update: Pressed by ABC News' George Stephanopoulos Sunday morning to answer whether the U.S. is at war with "radical Islam," Holder again declined. "I would say that we are at war with terrorists who commit these heinous acts and who use Islam. They use a corrupted version of Islam to justify their actions," he said on This Week with George Stephanopoulos.

Title: Opinion: The Left's Inconsistent Response to the Pandemic: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the political landscape in the United States has been marked by a significant divide in response strategies and public discourse. This article aims to provide a neutral analysis of the left's position on the nation's response to the pandemic, focusing on the inconsistencies and potential implications of their approach.

Since the onset of the pandemic, national Democratic leaders, left-leaning media, and some anti-Trump figures have been criticized for their focus on attacking President Donald Trump rather than addressing the myriad issues caused by the coronavirus. The left has been accused of adopting contradictory stances, criticizing Trump for both overreacting and underreacting to the virus.

Before the outbreak, numerous Democrats downplayed the virus and condemned Trump's China and Europe travel bans. However, as the virus spread, they shifted their criticism towards Trump, accusing him of not taking the virus seriously, despite the fact that they were initially taking a less serious approach themselves.

From the beginning, President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, and their medical team have been conducting daily press briefings to inform the public about the virus and the government's efforts to slow its spread. These briefings have been used by the media to criticize Trump rather than to inform the public. For instance, New York Magazine's Olivia Nuzzi asked Trump, "If an American President loses more Americans over the course of six weeks than died in the entirety of the Vietnam War, does he deserve to be reelected?"

Editorials have excoriated Trump for every imaginable sin and certainly every death, while exempting Democratic governors from any accountability for disproportionate cases and deaths in their states. They view the crisis through a partisan prism, exploiting it for political gain.

Trump has been accused of being solely interested in using the crisis to enhance his reelection efforts. He has been criticized for expressing hope to reopen the economy on Easter and for not listening to medical experts. However, Trump has been deferring to the medical experts, who have repeatedly denied that he is ignoring them.

The left's reduction of concerns for the financially devastated to class-warfare soundbites, such as Joe Biden's "No life is worth losing to add one more point to the Dow," has been criticized as shallow and insensitive. Similarly, the Lincoln Project's ad "Mourning in America," which blames Trump for both the deaths from the virus and the economic devastation, has been seen as a convenient and one-dimensional approach to the crisis.

It is crucial to recognize that the pandemic presents complex challenges that do not lend themselves to easy solutions. There is no perfect response, and there will be deaths and financial destruction. The focus should be on mitigating both, working together to reopen the economy while preventing new outbreaks. State governments should show faith in the American people and respect their prerogative to return to their lives, while exercising responsible behavior to protect themselves and their neighbors.

In conclusion, this article aims to provide a neutral analysis of the left's response to the pandemic, highlighting the inconsistencies and potential implications of their approach. It is essential to approach the crisis with a balanced perspective, recognizing the complexities and challenges it presents, and working together to find solutions that prioritize the health and well-being of all Americans.

Title: The Collapse of Confederate Nostalgia: A Shift in Political Landscape

Article:

In the aftermath of the racially-motivated shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, the removal of the Confederate flag from statehouses across the nation has become a significant political development. This shift, however, was not an expected outcome, as the flag has long been a symbol of Confederate nostalgia and a contentious issue in American politics.

The change can be attributed to a combination of generational replacement and increased political polarization. The last Civil War general died in the 1930s, and those with personal connections to the Civil War are now increasingly rare. This generational shift has relegated the Confederacy to history, even if its sympathizers persist.

Moreover, the most crucial factor in the removal of the flag is the rise of political polarization. In the past, lower-income rural whites, who were not a reliable part of the Republican coalition, held the key to winning in the South. However, in recent years, these voters have begun voting Republican from the top of the ticket to the bottom, and Democrats have either written off the region or formed coalitions of minorities, urban liberals, and suburbanites rather than of minorities, urban liberals, and poor whites.

With Democrats no longer seeing any electoral payoff in courting rural Southerners, they no longer have any incentive to make even weak gestures toward keeping the flag around. Progressives are now freed from their need to maintain a delicate dance with rural Southerners for the sake of maintaining some degree of power in the South. Polarization has forced them – and freed them – to explore new paths to power.

It is also essential to recognize that most prominent Southern Republican politicians have roots in either the suburban or old establishment Democrat wings of the party. With rural whites now largely polarized into the Republican column, Southern Republicans no longer have to go hard after their votes. If anything, they need to watch their flanks in the suburbs and in the business wing of the party, and so it is now more natural for them to move against the flag.

In conclusion, the removal of the Confederate flag from statehouses across the nation is a significant political development, reflecting a shift in the political landscape due to generational replacement and increased political polarization. This change may signal a broader movement away from symbols of racial oppression and toward a more inclusive and equitable society.

Title: Hillary Clinton to Highlight Depression-Era Upbringing in Mother's Footsteps at Campaign Rally

In a strategic move to emphasize her personal connection to the American middle class, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton is set to delve into the lesser-known story of her mother, Dorothy Rodham, at her first major campaign rally this Saturday.

Clinton's team has revealed that she will draw upon lessons learned from her mother's Depression-era upbringing, where she was abandoned by her parents and had to fend for herself. This narrative is intended to underscore Clinton's personal journey and her commitment to fighting for the middle class, a demographic she aims to represent in the White House.

Jennifer Palmieri, the campaign's communications director, commented, "She is a well-known figure, but when you're asking the American people to support you as president, even if it is for the second time, there is no skipping of steps. If you want to understand Hillary Clinton, and what has motivated her career of fighting for kids and families, her mother is a big part of the story."

A photograph from Clinton's 50th birthday in 1997, taken in front of her childhood home in Park Ridge, Illinois, with her late mother, Dorothy Rodham, serves as a poignant reminder of this personal connection.

The rally on Roosevelt Island in New York, steeped in symbolism of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt, offers Clinton an opportunity to redefine her candidacy and present a more comprehensive argument for her presidential bid. Some Democrats have expressed that Clinton and her campaign have yet to clearly articulate why she is the best candidate for the job.

This shift in focus was a topic of discussion at a dinner Clinton attended last week at the home of Sen. Dianne Feinstein in Washington. The intimate gathering, attended by several other Democratic women senators, provided a platform for candid conversations about Clinton's candidacy.

Title: Bloomberg's Controversial Presence in Selma's Civil Rights Commemoration

Article:

Michael Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor and current Democratic presidential candidate, found himself in the midst of controversy during a historic event in Selma, Alabama, on Sunday. The 55th anniversary of the 1965 civil rights march, known as "Bloody Sunday," saw Bloomberg attending the commemoration, an event that was initially met with resistance from some members of the community.

Bloomberg's decision to attend the event, which took place on the eve of Super Tuesday, was a departure from his initial response to an invitation from Rev. Leodis Strong. The former mayor had initially declined, citing his busy presidential campaign. However, a week later, he changed his mind and decided to participate in the commemoration, crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge with ailing congressman and civil rights icon John Lewis.

The presence of Bloomberg, who has been criticized for his legacy as the mayor responsible for stop-and-frisk policing, was met with a silent protest by a dozen or so churchgoers during his speech at Brown Chapel. Ryan P. Haygood, a former NAACP lawyer who directs the New Jersey Institute for Social Justice, explained, "Given what this sacred space means, I kept waiting for him to lean into it, to talk about what he presided over as mayor. When it became clear he wasn't going to atone, we decided to do something."

The protest, which was not planned, was a stark contrast to the boilerplate speech Bloomberg delivered. If Pete Buttigieg hadn't suspended his campaign hours later, the silent protest against Bloomberg would have been the biggest story out of Selma about any of the five candidates in attendance.

Notably absent from the event was Bernie Sanders, the only candidate with an arrest record related to civil rights protest. Sanders, who has attended multiple civil rights events in Alabama over the years, has nothing to prove on that front, but his campaign has always conceded the primary and never opened an office or hired a single staffer in Montgomery.

The Alabama primary, with its large African American voter base, is a crucial test for Bloomberg's unorthodox gambit. Whether the endorsement from the Alabama Democratic Council, which Bloomberg received last month, will dig into Joe Biden's large advantage with black voters in Southern states remains to be seen.

The council, which has not been a fearsome Southern machine for a long time, has been criticized for endorsing Bloomberg due to his financial support. Pam Foster, a Tuscaloosa Medical School professor, expressed her dissent, stating, "Reed and the ADC endorsed Bloomberg because he bought off a lot of people. [They want us] to forget that in New York, he ignored the African American community. I voted my conscience and voted Biden."

The Sanders campaign's decision to not open an office or hire staff in Montgomery, the state's capital, reflects the candidate's concession of the primary. In 2016, Alabama gave Hillary Clinton her second-highest margin of victory against Sanders, nearly 78 percent of the vote, mirroring her win in neighboring Mississippi. In 44 of Alabama's 67 counties, Sanders lost by 50 points or more.

The reasons for the candidate with the most credible and demonstrated commitment to addressing poverty being so roundly rejected by Deep South communities scarred by endemic hardcore poverty are not easily or neatly answered. However, the presence of Bloomberg in Selma, amidst the commemoration of a pivotal moment in the civil rights movement, has sparked a conversation about the role of money in politics and the expectations of candidates, particularly those with controversial pasts, in the African American community.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Constitutionality of U.S. Passport Policy for Jerusalem-Born Citizens

The United States Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Monday in a case that intertwines Middle Eastern politics with the shared foreign policy roles of the President and Congress. The case, which revolves around the birthplace notation on U.S. passports for citizens born in Jerusalem, has been a contentious issue since the establishment of Israel in 1948.

The U.S. has historically maintained that no country holds sovereignty over Jerusalem until its status is resolved through a Middle East peace agreement. However, supporters of Israel in Congress have attempted to institute a different policy, passing legislation that would move the U.S. embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and require the State Department to allow U.S. citizens born in Jerusalem to list Israel as their place of birth on their passports.

Both the Bush and Obama administrations declined to comply with this mandate, arguing that it unconstitutionally infringes on the President's foreign policy powers. The case in question, initially brought by Menachem Zivotofsky, a U.S. citizen born in Jerusalem to American parents who now maintain dual citizenship, seeks to force the State Department to list Israel as his place of birth on his passport.

In 2011, when the case first went to the Supreme Court, the justices did not issue a definitive ruling, instead remanding the case back to the lower court for further action. Now, the case is back before the Supreme Court, and a review of the 2011 argument offers insight into the justices' thinking.

During the 2011 argument, Nathan Lewin, the Zivotofskys' lawyer, argued that under the Constitution, foreign policy is a power shared by the President and Congress, but that Congress has the final say once it passes a statute, as it did in this case. However, Lewin faced a barrage of skeptical questions from the justices.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg questioned, "You say foreign relations is a shared power. So, if it is a shared power, why does Congress trump the executive?" Justice Anthony Kennedy described Lewin's view as a "narrow and crabbed interpretation of the president's foreign affairs power." Justice Sonia Sotomayor stated, "It seems to me you're not arguing for a co-equal congressional power, you're arguing for a superior congressional power. You’re saying whatever Congress says, the president has to comply with."

Chief Justice John Roberts noted that listing Israel as the place of birth for someone born in Jerusalem could potentially present foreign policy problems. However, Lewin rejected this premise, stating, "Congress has decided that saying Israel alone does not present a foreign policy issue."

Arguing for the President's exclusive authority in this area, Solicitor General Donald Verrilli told the justices that Congress cannot supersede the President's power. However, Justice Stephen Breyer questioned this proposition, stating, "There are very few cases I can ever think of where the court has said the president can act contrary to a statute."

Verrilli replied that, since President Washington, this has been one of those areas of presidential authority. The court, he argued, should give great deference to the President's judgment on a matter with such serious foreign policy implications. A passport, he observed, is not a communication by the passport holder; it's an official document communicating the position of the United States.

Justice Elena Kagan pressed Verrilli, who responded that the source for the President's power is the provision of the Constitution giving the chief executive the power to receive and recognize foreign diplomats, a power used since the founding to recognize foreign governments.

Justice Scalia did not find much merit in that provision as authority to rest the case on, musing, "I mean, if you've got to cast about for something, I suppose, I do not know what else you'd land upon." It is there, Scalia acknowledges, "but it does not say a whole lot."

The Supreme Court's decision in this case could have significant implications for the relationship between the President and Congress in matters of foreign policy and the interpretation of the U.S. Constitution. The justices' deliberations will be closely watched as they grapple with the complex interplay of constitutional powers and the political sensitivities surrounding Jerusalem.

Title: Bernie Sanders' Revolution: A Movement Beyond the Senator

Article:

As Bernie Sanders prepares to return to his role as a U.S. Senator, his political revolution lives on, with the first step unfolding at over 2,600 house parties across the country on Wednesday night. The gatherings served as a platform for Sanders to reiterate his call for fundamental change in the country, emphasizing the importance of grassroots activism and electing like-minded candidates at all levels of government.

In his address, Sanders reiterated his belief that real change does not come from the top but from the bottom, as millions of people demand change within the country. He emphasized that change will come through electing progressive candidates, from school boards to the U.S. Senate, as well as through ballot measures in the states. Additionally, he called for Democrats to hold the party accountable for implementing the most progressive platform in party history.

During the Democratic primaries, Sanders garnered over 12 million votes and held hundreds of enthusiastic rallies, serving as a counterpoint to Donald Trump's campaign. The question now is whether the Bernie revolution, enshrined in an organization called Our Revolution, can survive and thrive without Sanders himself.

Our Revolution, a 501(c)(4) social welfare organization, has faced challenges due to its tax status, which prevents Sanders from playing a role in running the group. The tax status also caused tension within the small staff, with several resigning over Sanders' decision to bring in his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, as president. The tax status allows for the acceptance of undisclosed and unlimited "dark money," potentially from billionaires, a stark contrast to Sanders' campaign, which prided itself on small-dollar donations.

Despite the organizational challenges, Sanders supporters remain hopeful. A group of 30 supporters gathered in a row house in Washington's Mount Pleasant neighborhood on Wednesday night, eager to hear from their leader once more. Michael Pattis, a student at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, working in Washington for the summer, expressed his support for Sanders' agenda, including health care for all, criminal justice reform, and a more equitable distribution of economic growth.

Maggie Ellinger-Locke, a lawyer in Arlington, Virginia, expressed her excitement for the "down ticket" races in November, emphasizing the importance of local politics in driving change. Both she and Pattis plan to vote for Hillary Clinton in November, but are prepared to "trade" their votes with third-party supporters in swing states to help prevent Donald Trump from winning crucial states.

The future of Our Revolution remains uncertain, but the group has already seen some successes. Jane Kleeb, visiting from Nebraska, recently won an upset victory in the race for chair of her state Democratic Party. Kleeb, an activist who originally opposed the Keystone XL pipeline, now aims to remake a party that has failed to win statewide office in deep red Nebraska.

"Our state party, for so many years, has not been progressive, and that has deflated the base," Kleeb said. "Candidates somehow think they have to be more conservative to win. I'm a progressive Democrat, and I was able to bring this coalition of conservative folks together to defeat the pipeline."

The tea party movement has faded, and the Occupy movement has channeled its energy into Sanders' candidacy. For now, Sanders supporters remain hopeful, and some have already made gains in local politics. The question remains whether the Bernie revolution will continue to thrive, or if it will follow the path of other political movements that have come before it.

Title: CBS News Poll Reveals Shift in American Opinion Regarding Mueller Investigation's Motivation

Article:

A new CBS News poll has shown a significant change in the American public's perception of the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into potential collusion between President Donald Trump and the Russian government. The poll, conducted between March 25 and March 26, found that 54% of respondents now believe the investigation was "politically motivated," compared to 37% who believe it was "justified."

In January, the same poll found 50% of respondents believed the investigation was "justified" and 45% said it was "politically motivated." This shift represents a growing skepticism towards the investigation's impartiality among the American public.

Interestingly, the poll's findings regarding the investigation's motivation were not the primary focus of CBS's report. The headline of the report, "Mueller report: Majorities across party lines want full report released," and the four tweets accompanying the article, only touched on the desire for the release of the Mueller report.

The poll also revealed that 34% of respondents feel the Mueller report, which found no collusion and not enough evidence to charge Trump with obstruction, "has cleared Trump," compared to 23% who think it "hasn't cleared Trump." Another 36% think it's "too soon to say" whether the report cleared the president.

Partisan differences were also evident in the poll. Sixty-six percent of Democrats want their party in Congress to continue investigating the matter, while 50% of Democrats were "disappointed" in Mueller's findings. In contrast, 69% of Republicans were "pleased" with the report.

Forty-four percent of respondents thought the investigation was conducted "fairly," while 10% thought it was "unfairly." Forty percent said it was "too soon to say."

The CBS News poll provides a snapshot of the American public's evolving perception of the Mueller investigation, revealing a growing belief that the investigation may have been politically motivated. However, it's important to note that this poll is just one of many and represents the opinions of a sample of the American public.

Title: Study Reveals Significant Life Expectancy Gap Between Americans and Peers in High-Income Countries Due to Injury Deaths

Article:

A new study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association has shed light on a concerning issue: the significant life expectancy gap between Americans and their peers in high-income countries. The study, which analyzed data from 2012, found that three major causes of injury deaths - guns, drugs, and cars - account for a substantial portion of this gap.

The study compared injury death rates in the US with those in other high-income countries, including the UK, Denmark, Sweden, Japan, and eight others. The results showed that, on average, men and women in these countries can expect to live about 2.2 years longer than their American counterparts.

Among men, gun deaths accounted for 21% of the life expectancy gap, drug overdoses for 14%, and car crashes for 13%. Among women, gun deaths accounted for 4% of the gap, drug overdoses for 9%, and car crashes for 6%.

The death rate for guns, drugs, and cars was much higher in the US than in its developed peers, as this chart shows:

``Although the reasons for the gap in life expectancy at birth between the United States and comparable countries are complex, a substantial portion of this gap reflects just three causes of injury,'' study authors Andrew Fenelon, Li-Hui Chen, and Susan Baker wrote.

The study's findings highlight the need for policy changes and cultural shifts to address these issues. With guns, the research shows that America's unusually high levels of gun ownership lead to more gun violence. Tightening existing gun control measures, such as gun licensing laws, could help reduce homicides and suicides, as studies in Connecticut and Missouri suggest.

With drugs, the US is currently grappling with a devastating opioid and heroin epidemic that is killing tens of thousands of people each year. Academic analyses of the crisis have concluded that the US was too slow to respond to misleading advertising campaigns from opioid producers, leading to widespread addiction and death.

With cars, European policies began encouraging walking, cycling, and public transportation in the 1960s, while the US continued to promote sprawl and driving. The result: Americans drive much more than their European peers, and are more likely to die in crashes as a result.

While cultural preferences may be difficult to change, better policies could help push the US in the right direction and save lives. The study's authors call for a comprehensive approach to addressing these issues, including improved access to healthcare, safer roads, and stricter gun control measures.

Title: Bill Clinton Advocates for Global Unity, Cautions Against Nationalism in Post-Election Speech

Article:

In his first major public appearance since the inauguration of Donald Trump, former President Bill Clinton delivered a keynote speech at a Brookings Institute event, cautioning against the rise of nationalism and its potential to further divide the world.

Clinton, in his address, warned against the "nation-state psychology" that he believes is gaining traction, stating that it is an "inevitable consequence of the economic and social changes that have occurred at an increasingly rapid pace." He argued that those who advocate for the nation-state are, in fact, promoting a "pan-national movement to institutionalize separatism and division within borders all over the world."

Though not explicitly referring to Trump or his chief counselor Stephen Bannon, Clinton's comments can be seen as a rebuke of the Trump-ian form of nationalist populism. Trump's overarching "America First" message is built on the primacy of domestic American interests over those of the world. Bannon, as the head of Breitbart, has been known for stoking resentment of immigrants and racial and religious minorities in the United States.

The Clinton family, following Hillary Clinton's defeat in the November election, has emerged as a set of reliable critics of the Trump administration. Daughter Chelsea Clinton has tweeted negatively about the administration, and Hillary herself has given a number of speeches since the election.

Clinton's speech also drew parallels to the assassination of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 by an extremist. Rabin, during his terms as Prime Minister, embraced the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, and his efforts for unity won him the Nobel Peace Prize in 1994. Citing this, Clinton said, "We have to find a way to bring simple, personal decency and trust back to our politics."

Clinton further emphasized the importance of negotiation and compromise, stating, "We should live by Rabin's model of negotiation and compromise. If you got that, in every age and time, the challenges we face can be resolved in a way to keep us going forward, instead of taking us to the edge of our destruction."

Closing his speech, Clinton reiterated the need for unity, stating, "This is a very old story. It's as old as the Holy Land, and much older. Ever since the first people stood up on the East African savanna, ever since the first families and clans, ever since people encountered the other. It is a very old story. And it always comes down to two things—are we going to live in an us-and-them world, or a world that we live in together?"

Title: "The Return of Big Brother: Tech Giants and the Pursuit of Conformity in the Digital Age"

Article:

In the year 1984, a commercial by Apple, titled "1984," depicted a dystopian future where a single company, Microsoft, held an iron grip on the computer world. Fast forward to the present, and it seems we are living in a reimagined version of that future. The tech giants, Apple, Google, YouTube, Facebook, and Twitter, are demanding conformity to their values, echoing the all-powerful leader from George Orwell's novel, 1984.

Recently, Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, addressed a civil rights group, stating, "We only have one message for those who seek to push hate, division, and violence: You have no place on our platforms." This statement, ironically delivered before a group advocating for civil rights, raises questions about the role these tech companies are playing in shaping public discourse.

If a user disagrees with the tech giants on political or moral grounds, they risk being silenced, as evidenced by the permanent ban of Canadian feminist Meghan Murphy from Twitter for refusing to use preferred pronouns and stating "women are not men." Similarly, Google, Facebook, and Twitter have all refused to carry political ads from conservative candidates, such as Tennessee Republican Marsha Blackburn.

Broad-based studies by the American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology and Northwestern University have confirmed the existence of bias against conservatives on these platforms. YouTube, for instance, has restricted over 100 videos by PragerU, a conservative educational organization, deeming them "inappropriate for children."

This bias, both overt and covert, is a cause for concern for those who value free speech. While the visible bias is troubling, the hidden, or "shadow banning," may be even more insidious. If one leans to the left, this may be acceptable, but for those not on the left, or for those who revere the First Amendment, this trend is a cause for alarm.

We are swiftly advancing towards an Orwellian, 1984 world of stifling, one-way-of-thinking conformity. This is not a fictional story; it is real. The solution lies in returning to the open market of ideas that served these tech companies so well for so long. Stop the censorship and let people make up their own minds. Otherwise, America, and the rest of what has been known as the Free World, will cease to be free.

I'm Brent Bozell, founder of the Media Research Center.

Title: Climate Crisis Takes a Backseat in Democratic Debate, Activists Call for Change

Article:

In the first Democratic presidential debate of 2020, the climate crisis was given less than 10 minutes of discussion, despite its potential to render large parts of the planet uninhabitable by the end of the century. This, according to journalist Kate Aronoff, is a shameful oversight that underscores the urgent need for a dedicated climate debate.

Aronoff, a writing fellow at In These Times, criticized NBC and Democratic National Committee (DNC) chairman Tom Perez for the limited time dedicated to the climate crisis. Protesters from the Sunrise Movement, who have been advocating for a Green New Deal, are currently occupying the DNC headquarters in Washington D.C., demanding a climate-focused debate.

The debate, which lasted nearly an hour and a half, saw New Jersey Senator Cory Booker emerge as the candidate with the most speaking time, close to 11 minutes. Booker, who has been described as progressive but not extreme, made a difference in the discourse by refusing to endorse Medicare for All and acknowledging the need to check corporate consolidation without appearing anti-business.

Elizabeth Warren, who was widely expected to dominate the debate, also performed well, particularly in the first half. She set a populist tone, arguing that the American economy benefits only those with wealth, and framed herself as a fighter who would take on big corporations. Warren also emphasized structural change, advocating for healthcare as a basic human right, supporting Medicare for All, and highlighting the prison-industrial complex that disproportionately affects black and Latino communities.

Julián Castro, who was polling at just 1% and was unknown to 56% of voters before the debate, had a significant impact on the debate. He demonstrated compassion and deep knowledge of immigration law, and displayed a fighting spirit as he called attention to policy differences with fellow Texan Beto O'Rourke. This early in the primary, name recognition is crucial, and Castro's performance should help his cause substantially.

The lack of focus on the climate crisis during the debate has been met with criticism from climate activists, who argue that the future of their generation and the entire civilization is at stake. Climate change is an existential threat and is intertwined with every issue discussed during the debate, including healthcare, immigration, and the presidency of Donald Trump.

As the debate progresses, it is crucial that the candidates and the media prioritize the climate crisis and address it with the urgency it deserves. A pleasing personality will not save the planet; what is needed is bold, decisive action to combat this existential threat.

Title: Supreme Court Declines ExxonMobil's Appeal in Massachusetts Climate Change Investigation

Article:

The Supreme Court declined to hear an appeal from ExxonMobil regarding Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey's climate change investigation on Monday, a move legal experts described as a "crushing blow" to the oil giant. The Court's decision could have implications beyond the state of Massachusetts as Exxon is forced to hand over documents detailing what it knew about climate change and when.

After the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled last April that the company must turn over documents requested by Healey, Exxon asked the Supreme Court to intervene, arguing Healey lacked jurisdiction to even bring the investigation.

"Today's decision means Exxon is out of options and out of time in its fight to keep these documents from public light," Carroll Muffett, president and chief executive of the Center for International Environmental Law, told ███.

The company is facing multiple climate lawsuits around the country. In the case of Massachusetts, like New York, the attorney general is investigating what Exxon knew about climate change and the effects of burning fossil fuels—and whether it lied to the public and its investors about the risks.

Reports published in 2015 by InsideClimate News and the Los Angeles Times revealed that the company was aware of the risks of burning fossil fuels as early as the 1970s, and yet continued to mislead investors.

"Courts have repeatedly rejected Exxon's attempts to stop the state attorneys general in New York and Massachusetts from investigating the company's historic knowledge about climate change and what it did with that information," Michael Burger, director of the Sabin Center for Climate Change Law at Columbia University, told ███.

The denial of Exxon's petition means Healey can proceed with her investigation, and that Exxon must respond to the attorney general's civil investigation demands—the subpoena-like request for documents, including transcripts of investor calls, internal scientific research, copies of public relations or media communication plans, and communication with organizations that have a history of promoting climate science denial.

"These internal documents—describing what the company knew and when it knew it—are critical to any fraud case that may result," Sharon Eubanks, a former U.S. Department of Justice attorney who prosecuted and won the massive racketeering case against Big Tobacco, said. "Without a doubt, ExxonMobil will bring further objections, but the [Court's] denial... is a crushing blow."

However, Eubanks, who now works for the firm Bordas & Bordas, added that the Supreme Court's denial of Exxon's request does not set a precedent; it doesn't give an indication as to where different justices sit on the issue, it simply allows the investigation to proceed.

The mere fact that the investigation can move forward "is a tremendous success," Alyssa Johl, legal counsel for the Center for Climate Integrity, said. "Where it goes from here is to be determined—it depends on what they [Exxon] disclose."

Legal experts told ███ that the Supreme Court's decision has wider implications beyond this particular case. In its efforts to fight the Massachusetts investigation, Exxon argued to the Supreme Court that it's an issue of jurisdiction. The company, which is headquartered in Texas, said that because it does not directly sell gasoline in Massachusetts, the attorney general does not have jurisdiction to investigate.

In essence, Exxon tried to argue that its service stations across the state are franchises, and not part of the company itself. And it was this argument that the Massachusetts court rejected earlier in 2018, "on the simple grounds that Exxon's standard franchise agreement gives the company significant control over how its products were marketed in the state," said Muffett.

Therefore, the Supreme Court's decision is "basically affirming, for now, the decision of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court that the AG has jurisdiction over ExxonMobil," explained Eubanks.

Upholding this decision not only means the case can proceed but hints that other states might be able to look to Massachusetts for inspiration down the road.

"The Massachusetts investigation poses an even bigger risk for the company because the pool of Exxon's potential victims includes not only the seven million citizens and consumers in Massachusetts but untold tens of millions more living in states with nearly identical consumer protection laws," Muffett said.

States with similar consumer protection laws to Massachusetts—ones that are based on the Federal Trade Commission Act—include California, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Maine, Ohio, Vermont, and Washington. There are additional states with laws modeled on the Unfair and Deceptive Trade Acts legislation but whose provisions share similar strengths to Massachusetts' law, Muffett explained, such as Illinois and New Jersey, as well as Washington, D.C.

And as the Massachusetts attorney general's office lays out online, the impact of Exxon's action on consumers is at the heart of its investigation: "Specifically, the investigation seeks information regarding whether Exxon may have misled consumers and/or investors with respect to the impact of fossil fuels on climate change, and climate change-driven risks to Exxon's business."

While each state is unique, many states do often draw on Massachusetts' extensive body of jurisprudence interpreting its consumer protection laws. This makes for "another aspect of the Massachusetts case that should be of serious concern for Exxon and its investors," Muffett said. "Since the court was interpreting Exxon's standard franchise agreement, it's very likely that its reasoning would be persuasive if Exxon tries the same defense in any other state where that same standard agreement is in use."

"This is another reason," he said, "why I think the significance of the Massachusetts AG's investigation has been grossly underestimated."

Title: New Hampshire Primary Results: Trump and Sanders Triumph Over Establishment Candidates

Article:

In a clear rejection of the political establishment, Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders emerged victorious in the New Hampshire Republican and Democratic primaries respectively.

On the Republican side, Trump secured a significant victory with 34 percent of the vote, leaving John Kasich in second place with 16 percent. Trump's campaign slogan, "Make America Great Again," has evidently resonated with voters, garnering him a substantial lead.

On the Democratic side, Sanders edged out Hillary Clinton by 20 percentage points, demonstrating a strong appeal among young voters. Sanders' platform, which includes promises of universal healthcare and free college tuition, has attracted a larger coalition of young voters than the one Barack Obama built in 2008.

The results of the primary elections suggest a growing disillusionment among American voters towards the political establishment. This disillusionment is not limited to one party, as evidenced by the 42 percent of Americans who now identify as independent, feeling that the two major parties do not represent their values and positions.

Trump and Sanders, two candidates who have been labeled as outsiders, have tapped into this disillusionment, promising to upend the status quo. Trump's controversial stance on illegal immigration and his proposal for a temporary ban on Muslims have been supported by a majority of Republican primary voters, despite causing national controversy.

Sanders, a self-proclaimed socialist, has also faced skepticism, but has managed to gain traction among voters who are seeking an honest and trustworthy politician. Sanders' long-standing advocacy for the average American, and his unwavering stance on issues, has resonated with voters who feel betrayed by the political establishment.

The results of the New Hampshire primary elections underscore a growing dissatisfaction among American voters. Honesty and trustworthiness appear to be more important to voters than experience or the ability to win in November. The American electorate is in revolt, seeking political leaders who can deliver on their desires for change.

While the path to the nomination for Trump and Sanders may not be clear-cut, one thing is certain: Americans have spoken, and they are done with business as usual.

Title: Fox Business Debate in Charleston: A Night of Political Pugilism

Article:

The Fox Business debate in Charleston, South Carolina, is not marketed as a boxing match, but by the end of the evening, it may be difficult to distinguish the two. The debate, set to take place on Thursday, promises a night of intense political exchanges, with each candidate vying for a chance to emerge victorious.

The stakes are high for the participating candidates, as they seek to establish themselves as the alternative to frontrunners Donald Trump and Ted Cruz. Marco Rubio, Chris Christie, and Jeb Bush are all eager to solidify their positions as the establishment choice, and a poor showing in the upcoming Iowa and New Hampshire primaries could prove detrimental to their campaigns.

In the last debate, moderators Neil Cavuto and Maria Bartiromo are expected to ask civil and substantive questions, as they aim to elicit important information from the candidates. Both anchors have emphasized that the debates are not about them, but about the candidates and the issues at hand.

However, the candidates themselves are likely to engage in a series of verbal sparring matches. Rubio, Christie, and Bush will undoubtedly take aim at each other, as they jockey for position in the race for the Republican nomination.

Texas Senator Ted Cruz, who previously tangled with Rubio over immigration and surveillance, will also be in the mix. Cruz has begun to question Trump's "New York values," and it is possible that he may take a jab or two at the real estate mogul. However, it is more likely that Cruz will focus his attacks on Rubio and the other candidates.

Donald Trump, if history is any guide, will likely hang back and engage in counterpunching. With Iowa polls showing him either slightly ahead of Cruz or running neck and neck, Trump may mention Canada once or twice.

For the middle-tier candidates, there is no room for holding back. Bush, Christie, and Rubio have a significant investment in a strong New Hampshire finish. The last Fox Business debate was unusually polite due to the fallout from the CNBC debate, where many candidates were outraged by the moderators' perceived condescension and opinionated questions.

However, the 2016 race is in a different phase now, and these debates have become winnowing events like never before. The debates dominate the media coverage for as much as a week, with key sound bites endlessly replayed and pundits offering their analyses of the winners and losers. Good debaters such as Rubio, Cruz, and Christie have benefited from this media attention, while poor performances have hurt candidates like Bush.

The Charleston debate, along with the upcoming debate in Des Moines later this month, looms large for some of the contenders. Some candidates could emerge badly bruised - or worse. Rand Paul is loudly denouncing the decision to knock him off the main stage and refusing to attend the undercard debate. Network criteria can deflate candidates by keeping them out of prime time, and time is running short. These debates have a magnified impact, as they dominate the media coverage and shape public opinion. The Charleston debate will be no exception.

Title: NFL Teams Show Solidarity with Protesting Players, Defy Trump's Call for Action

Article:

In a show of unity, NFL teams across the country and in London displayed a collective response to President Donald Trump's criticism of players who kneel during the U.S. national anthem, as a symbol of protest against perceived racial injustice.

On Sunday, coaches, support staff, and even some owners joined their team members in various displays of solidarity, such as kneeling, linking arms, or staying off the field during the anthem. This silent response was initiated last season by former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick, who has been a vocal critic of police treatment of African-Americans.

In Detroit, several members of the Lions knelt while singer Rico Lavelle dropped to one knee and pumped a fist in the air at the end of his performance of the "Star-Spangled Banner." In Philadelphia, city police officers joined with Eagles and New York Giants players and Eagles team owner Jeffrey Lurie to link arms during the anthem.

The controversy was rekindled by Trump on Friday at an Alabama political rally, where he denounced players who kneel during the anthem as unpatriotic and urged owners to dismiss them. This reprised his reality-show catchphrase, "You're fired."

While some Americans are sympathetic to the protesters, others see the refusal to stand as a sign of disrespect for the flag and for members of the military who have sacrificed or died in defending the country.

The theme could play well with Trump's conservative base at a time when the Republican president is grappling with North Korea's nuclear threats, an investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election, and a healthcare struggle in Congress.

However, Trump's stance appeared to galvanize players, teams, and the league to assert what they see as a right to express their political convictions freely. It also highlighted the deep political rift that Trump's election has exposed across many segments of American society.

New England Patriots Chairman and Chief Executive Robert Kraft, who has dined with Trump and whom the president considers a friend, criticized Trump on Sunday and defended players' right to protest.

"I am deeply disappointed by the tone of the comments made by the president on Friday," Kraft said in a statement. He said players had a "right to peacefully affect social change and raise awareness in a manner they feel is most impactful."

Despite a strong rebuke of his remarks by NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell and the players' union on Saturday, the president did not back down on Sunday, calling on fans to boycott the league if it would not discipline protesting players.

"If NFL fans refuse to go to games until players stop disrespecting our Flag & Country, you will see change take place fast," Trump wrote on Twitter. "Fire or suspend!"

In another tweet, Trump, who spent the weekend at his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey, said that the "league should back" fans who are upset about the protests.

In Chicago, Trump's feud was the main topic of conversation at the South Loop Club sports bar.

"This is a First Amendment issue and the president is supposed to uphold that right," said Sam Cunningham, 55, who was watching the Pittsburgh-Chicago game with his wife. "He should know better than anyone that to fire someone because of their opinion is not right."

One patron at a sports bar in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, Trump supporter Tim Kull, 67, said, "Do it on your time, not when you are wearing that uniform."

In Foxboro, Massachusetts, more than a dozen players and coaches on the Super Bowl champion Patriots knelt or linked arms, including quarterback Tom Brady, whom Trump name-dropped as a friend on the campaign trail. Brady placed one hand on his chest and used the other to link arms with his teammates.

Jacksonville Jaguars owner Shad Khan linked arms with team players in solidarity at the game against the Baltimore Ravens in London's Wembley Stadium. Khan donated $1 million to the Trump inauguration fund.

Robert McNair, chairman of the Houston Texans, said Trump's comments were "divisive and counterproductive to what our country needs right now." McNair also donated $1 million to Trump.

Other teams decided to stay off the field during the anthem. Before the Seattle Seahawks game against the Tennessee Titans in Nashville, neither team came out until after the pre-game ceremony.

Except for a single player, the Pittsburgh Steelers remained off the field in Chicago before their game against the Bears to avoid "playing politics," head coach Mike Tomlin said. The team was roundly booed by the home crowd when it finally emerged.

The demonstrations along the sidelines ahead of Sunday's early game triggered a fresh round of tweets by the president.

"Great solidarity for our National Anthem and for our Country. Standing with locked arms is good, kneeling is not acceptable. Bad ratings!" he wrote.

National Basketball Association players also struck back against comments by the president on Saturday after Trump clashed with one of the biggest stars in the league, Stephen Curry.

Then on Saturday evening, Oakland A's rookie Bruce Maxwell became the first Major League Baseball player to kneel for the national anthem in protest.

In a Twitter message, Trump rescinded a White House invitation to Curry, who had said he would "vote" against the planned visit by the NBA champion Golden State Warriors.

Curry told a news conference in Oakland, California: "It's beneath the leader of a country to go that route."

In a tweet on Sunday, Trump said the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey team, which won the Stanley Cup, accepted his invitation to the White House. "Great team!" he wrote.

Title: White House Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney Clarifies Remarks on Ukraine Aid and Quid Pro Quo

In a statement on Thursday, White House Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney sought to clarify his earlier remarks about the administration's dealings with Ukraine, following criticism that he admitted to a quid pro quo.

Mulvaney stated, "Let me be clear, there was absolutely no quid pro quo between Ukrainian military aid and any investigation into the 2016 election." He also emphasized that President Trump never instructed him to withhold any money until Ukraine conducted any actions related to the server.

In a press conference, Mulvaney had earlier stated that Trump told him Ukraine was a "corrupt place." He explained that the administration's decision to withhold aid from Ukraine was due to concerns about corruption and the lack of support from other European countries.

Mulvaney also addressed the allegation that his comments implied a quid pro quo, stating, "We do that all the time. We were holding up aid at the same time for, what was it, the Northern Triangle countries. We were holding up aid at the Northern Triangle countries so that they would change their policies on immigration."

He further clarified, "Elections have consequences, and foreign policy is going to change from the Obama administration to the Trump administration."

The statement from Mulvaney comes after a series of investigations into the administration's dealings with Ukraine, which has been a focus of impeachment inquiries in the House of Representatives.

Title: Federal Judiciary Faces Funding Crisis as Shutdown Drains Court Resources

Article:

The United States federal judiciary is facing a critical funding crisis as a result of the ongoing government shutdown and years of budget austerity measures. The situation has led to a surge of anger and frustration from federal judges, who are now directing their ire towards Congress for the chaos and hardships imposed on the judiciary.

Driving the judges' ire is the budget austerity and the chaos lawmakers have imposed on the judiciary. The judiciary has already been cut to the bone by sequestration, and the government shutdown has added to the problem, leaving the government's third branch running on fumes that may not last out the week.

In a blog post last week, Senior U.S. District Judge Richard Kopf, a George H.W. Bush appointee who sits in Lincoln, Nebraska, urged his fellow judges to designate all their staff as essential and exempt from furlough. He questioned why every remaining employee of every federal district court, including federal public defenders, should not be declared 'essential' to keep the judiciary functioning during the shutdown.

When lawyers for the House urged Judge Amy Berman Jackson to keep a case demanding Operation Fast and Furious-related records from Attorney General Eric Holder moving forward during the shutdown, the judge said lawmakers could cool their heels, just like others with claims pending against the government.

Even before the shutdown, the judiciary shed nearly 2,700 support staff positions over the past two years. Funding for drug testing and electronic monitoring of pre-trial detainees had also been slashed by 20 percent, and federal defenders were under orders to take about 15 days of unpaid furlough in the past year.

The cuts have caused delays in criminal and civil cases. Even the posting of judges' orders has slowed, with many federal court clerk's offices looking largely empty compared with a few years ago.

Sequestration cut $350 million, or about 5 percent, from the judiciary's budget in the past fiscal year, bringing it to about $6.6 billion annually. Judges themselves are effectively exempt from furlough because the Constitution says their salaries—currently $174,000 for district court judges—cannot be reduced.

For the past two weeks, the federal courts have essentially operated on fumes, using funds from filing fees and so-called no-year appropriations to pay salaries and keep the lights on. Court budget personnel now predict that money will run out on Thursday or Friday of this week. After that, work deemed essential will continue, but there will be no way to pay employees, contractors, or utilities until Congress passes legislation including temporary or year-long funding.

The chief judge of the U.S. District Court located just blocks from the Capitol building said that the shutdown's funding lapse, piled on top of two years of tight budgets and staff reductions, has prompted his colleagues' frustration level to rise.

"I have to say it's fairly high," Judge Richard Roberts said in an interview with ███ Friday. "Court budgets have essentially been slashed to the bone, with us losing nationwide thousands of judicial employees performing very important tasks...We're being told to furlough where we're already cut to the bone."

Back on Capitol Hill, earlier complaints had drawn some skepticism. At a Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing in July, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) suggested some of sequestration's impacts on the courts were being exaggerated.

"Congress voted and [the] American people seem quite comfortable with the idea that we can reduce spending for a little while around here instead of having steady growth and they're not panicked," Sessions said. "I know we have stories that there's not enough copy paper in a clerk's office somewhere. Well, I would say...you need a new clerk. It's like those school people that would require the students to bring in toilet paper because they can't find enough money to do that, or fix their roof. That's a mismanagement to me."

Sessions acknowledged that the sequester did force some cuts more abruptly than made sense, particularly to federal public defender services. Now, with the shutdown taking its own toll on the system, House Judiciary Committee Democrats staged a forum on Capitol Hill last week to draw attention to what they portrayed as a crisis in funding for the courts.

The Judiciary Committee's top Democrat, Rep. John Conyers of Michigan, called the impact of the cuts and the shutdown on the courts "grave and growing each day."

Title: "Cross-State Insurance Sales and Tort Reform: Add-Ons to Trumpcare Face Skepticism and Challenges"

Article:

In a bid to garner support for the American Health Care Act, also known as Trumpcare, House Speaker Paul Ryan is considering attaching a companion bill to the main legislation. This secondary bill aims to ease cross-state sales of health insurance and limit jury awards for pain and suffering in malpractice lawsuits.

The move is an attempt to soften the blow of the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) dismal score on the initial bill, which rolled back key parts of the Affordable Care Act and limited federal spending on Medicaid for low-income individuals. However, the CBO's inability to evaluate these additional prongs due to their lack of written documentation has led to skepticism, with some calling it "mythical legislation" and others suggesting "Easter basket" might be a more fitting description.

While the cross-state sale of insurance is theoretically possible, it is not a significant factor in improving healthcare markets. The decision to allow insurers to operate across state lines is left to individual states and their insurance regulators. The same applies to the second piece, tort reform, which has long been a Republican priority due to the belief that malpractice lawyers are predominantly Democrats. However, the impact of these reforms on insurance costs for the general public remains uncertain.

The primary challenge for Ryan lies in the fact that the sidecar bill, as it is known in Congress-speak, would require 60 votes to pass in the Senate, as it is not directly related to the budget and cannot be pushed through under budget reconciliation like the initial bill. Furthermore, it is unlikely to secure eight Democratic votes, given its association with the repeal of the Affordable Care Act.

Meanwhile, President Trump is reportedly courting conservatives with a "manager's amendment" to accompany the first prong, which could potentially end Medicaid sooner, making it more difficult to maintain the support of all Republican senators for the 51 votes needed.

Critics argue that TrumpCare, with its tax cuts for the wealthy, elimination of Medicaid expansion for the poor, and defunding of Planned Parenthood, is a significant step backward in healthcare policy. If you are concerned about these changes, you can contact your Senators by calling the Capitol Hill switchboard at (202) 224-3121.

Title: Senate's Bipartisan Deliberation Under Scrutiny as Partisanship Intensifies

The United States Senate, traditionally known for its cool and deliberative nature, is facing criticism for its increasingly partisan atmosphere, as demonstrated by the recent silencing of Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) during a debate on the confirmation of Attorney General nominee Jeff Sessions (R-AL).

On Tuesday, Warren was silenced after she read a 1986 letter by civil rights leader Coretta Scott King that expressed strong opposition to Sessions' nomination for a federal judgeship due to his record on civil rights issues. The incident, which has since gone viral on social media under the hashtags #LetLizSpeak and #ShePersisted, has sparked concerns about the Senate's character as a chamber of reasoned, civil deliberation.

Senate Rule 19, a rarely invoked rule, forbids a senator from impugning the motives of another senator or referring to them offensively. Warren was warned about breaking this rule, but continued to read the letter. She was later silenced by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who cited her quoting of Mrs. King's statement that "Sessions has used the awesome power of his office to chill the free exercise of the vote by black citizens."

Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-NY) vigorously defended Warren on the Senate floor on Wednesday, while Senator Tim Scott (R-SC), the Senate's only African-American Republican, gave an impassioned defense of Sessions.

Political scientists and historians have expressed concern about the deepening partisanship in the Senate, with some suggesting that it is being exacerbated by the tone of the Trump presidency. Amy Black, a political scientist at Wheaton College in Illinois, stated, "Given the tone of the Trump campaign and the Trump presidency so far, the Senate has the opportunity to take the political high road and model respectful partisan differences... But that opportunity is being missed."

Julian Zelizer, a political historian at Princeton University in New Jersey, noted that the deep partisanship incentivizes both parties to play hardball. "There is no cooling function left in the Senate," he said.

Senators Susan Collins (R-ME) and Bob Corker (R-TN) expressed concern about the level of political discourse in the country and the Senate, while others, such as Senator Corker, downplayed the Warren-Sessions flap as a "blip on the radar screen."

As the Senate continues to navigate contentious debates on health care, taxes, and the confirmation of cabinet nominees, the question remains whether the chamber can return to its traditional role as a place of cooler heads and bipartisan deals.

Title: House Select Committee on Benghazi Continues Investigation, Plans Public Hearings

Article:

The House Select Committee, established to investigate the 2012 terrorist attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, has recently held closed-door meetings with the State and Justice departments, with plans to conduct public hearings, according to Rep. Trey Gowdy, the committee's chairman.

In a statement, Gowdy revealed that the Department of State provided new information to the committee and addressed questions raised by its members. The committee is currently focusing on obtaining first-hand accounts from individuals who were present during the attack. Gowdy emphasized that this process will be ongoing and that some aspects of the investigation must remain classified.

The committee also met with the Justice Department regarding document production and potential witnesses, Gowdy added. Although the select committee has already held two public hearings, Gowdy indicated that more would be held, with most of the work being done in classified settings.

Last week, the GOP-controlled House reauthorized the committee, a move that was met with protest from Democrats on the panel, who expressed concern about the committee's purpose and the lack of clarity regarding new questions the committee aims to answer.

In a statement, the five Democrats on the committee called for rules that would ensure their full participation in the investigation. They stated, "Since our members were denied the ability to meaningfully debate or amend the resolution, we now look to the committee to quickly adopt rules that ensure that our Democratic members are able to participate fully in the investigation."

A report from the House Intelligence Committee released last year largely cleared the CIA of wrongdoing in the lead-up to the attack, which resulted in the loss of four American lives, including U.S. Ambassador to Libya J.
