From 2010 to 2013, all federal wages were frozen due to budgetary constraints, but CDC officials found a way to pay themselves through bonuses, overtime, within-grade increases, and promotion pay raises. Donald Shriber, deputy director of policy and communication at the CDC's Center for Global Health, received the highest bonus in the six years analyzed—$62,895 in 2011.

Kathleen Dunlap, deputy budget director at the CDC, was awarded an $8,000 bonus last year, the highest among her fellow employees. Ms. Dunlap didn't respond to a request for comment.

The CDC's handling of the Ebola outbreak has been criticized, and the agency has been accused of using budgetary constraints as an excuse for its response. National Institutes of Health Director Francis Collins told The Huffington Post last week that the CDC had been working on an Ebola vaccine for more than a decade but was hampered by shrinking budgets.

Two health care workers who treated an Ebola patient in Dallas have contracted the disease, raising serious questions about the hospital's procedures. Statistics from the United Nations World Health Organization place the death toll from the Ebola outbreak at 4,447, the vast majority in West Africa.

"Frankly, if we had not gone through our 10-year slide in research support, we probably would have had a vaccine in time for this that would've gone through clinical trials and would have been ready," Mr. Collins told the news site.

The CDC's budget has remained relatively flat since President Obama took office. In fiscal year 2010, the budget request for CDC funding was $6.31 billion. In Mr. Obama's latest budget request, funding is set at $5.39 billion, with additional contributions of $809 million expected from the Prevention and Public Health Fund—totalizing about $6.2 billion.

Amid stagnating funding, the CDC still handed out bonuses and added 1,888 positions from 2007 to 2013, data show. Employees at the CDC earn more than the federal average. According to figures kept by the Office of Personnel Management, the average salary for a full-time federal employee working on a permanent appointment was $79,030 as of September 2013, the most recent date for which the figure has been released. The average salary for a CDC employee was $95,015 last year, OpenTheBooks shows.

"Employees at the embattled CDC have been making millions in higher-than-average salaries and bonuses," said OpenTheBooks.com founder Adam Andrzejewski. "CDC executives 'gamed the system' to increase employee pay through bonuses during three years of the 'official federal wage freeze.' CDC officials should be focused on preventing diseases rather than pumping up their salaries."

Excluding Atlanta, where the CDC is based, CDC employees at the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Maryland, received the largest federal payout of $304 million in total wages from 2007 to 2013, as well as about $640,000 in bonuses. CDC sites in Cincinnati; Chamblee, Georgia; Bruceton, Pennsylvania; and Morgantown, West Virginia, all had CDC staff earning more than $100 million from 2007 to 2013. They also collectively paid out $1.8 million in bonuses.

It's too early to tell whether it was money well spent, Mr. Andrzejewski said. "The CDC's mission is to protect the health of the nation, but will these highly compensated executives be successful and earn their pay, not to mention bonuses?" he asked.

Title: Examining Potential Policy Changes for Transgender Service Members in the U.S. Military: A RAND Study Analysis

Article:

The RAND Corporation, a nonprofit research organization, has conducted a comprehensive study on the health care needs, costs, and potential implications of transition-related treatments for transgender service members in the U.S. military. The study, commissioned by the U.S. Department of Defense (DoD), aims to provide insights into the policies that may need to be adjusted if transgender personnel are allowed to serve openly.

The report identifies the health care needs of the transgender population, with a focus on transgender service members. It also examines the costs associated with transition-related treatments, assesses the potential impact on force readiness and deployability, and reviews the experiences of foreign militaries that permit transgender personnel to serve openly.

The study, part of the ███ research report series, underwent rigorous peer review to ensure high standards for research quality and objectivity. The report is not intended to reflect the opinions of the research clients and sponsors but rather to provide unbiased, factual, and informative findings.

The RAND Corporation is a federally funded research and development center sponsored by the Office of the Secretary of Defense, the Joint Staff, the Unified Combatant Commands, the Navy, the Marine Corps, the defense agencies, and the defense Intelligence Community. The report is available for personal use, but commercial use is prohibited. Unauthorized posting of the report's PDF to a non-RAND website is also prohibited.

This research could potentially inform policy decisions regarding the inclusion of transgender service members in the U.S. military, providing a valuable resource for understanding the associated health care needs, costs, and implications.

Title: Former State Department Official Explains Obama Administration's Avoidance of "Radical Islamic Extremism" Label

Article:

In a recent op-ed published in The New York Times, Richard Stengal, a former State Department official, has shed light on the reasons behind the Obama administration's reluctance to use the phrase "radical Islamic extremism" to describe the ideology.

Stengal, who served as the under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, explained that the practical reason for this avoidance was not due to timidity or political correctness, as critics often suggested. Instead, he argued, the Obama administration refrained from using the term to maintain relationships with key Islamic allies, including Jordan, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia.

According to Stengal, these allies believed that the term unfairly vilified an entire religion and did not consider the Islamic State to be Islamic. He added that the Islamic State's violent actions against Muslims proved their stance.

Stengal further argued that the Trump administration should continue with the previous administration's strategy, as ISIS as a military force is currently "on the ropes" in Iraq and Syria. He also suggested that Trump administration officials should reassure these Arab allies that references to "radical Islam" and "Islamic extremism" are directed only at the small percentage of the world's Muslim population that has embraced violence.

Despite this, Stengal expressed apprehension about the new direction the administration is taking. He emphasized that it is not up to the U.S. to define what is Islamic and what is not. Instead, he argued, the voices of mainstream Muslims and independent clerics in Muslim countries are crucial in refuting the Islamic State's narrative and offering a more positive alternative. This, he suggested, could potentially hinder the group's recruiting efforts.

Title: President Trump Warns of Long-Term Aid for Puerto Rico, Amidst Ongoing Recovery Efforts and Financial Crisis

Article:

In a series of early-morning tweets on Thursday, President Donald Trump issued a warning to Puerto Rico, stating that the U.S. territory's infrastructure was in a state of disrepair before the hurricanes and that federal aid cannot remain indefinitely on the island.

The president's comments come just one week after his visit to Puerto Rico, which is still grappling with the devastation left by Hurricane Maria, the strongest hurricane to hit the island in nearly a century. Trump's trip was met with criticism, particularly for his comments on the storm's death toll, which he compared to that of Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

"Sixteen people versus in the thousands," Trump said, referring to the number of deaths in Puerto Rico and those in New Orleans during Katrina. "You can be very proud of all your people."

The president has repeatedly called for more help "on a local level" from Puerto Rico and has had an intermittent feud with the San Juan mayor, who has also faced criticism for engaging in political combat while other officials on the island are not.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., responded to Trump's latest tweets, questioning, "Why do you continue to treat Puerto Ricans differently than other Americans when it comes to natural disasters?"

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), there were more than 10,000 federal officials on the ground on the island earlier this month. House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., is scheduled to lead a small bipartisan group, including the chairman and top Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, to visit Puerto Rico on Friday. Ryan plans to meet with local officials and emergency personnel.

The House is expected to vote this week on an emergency spending package, which includes billions of dollars more in relief for Puerto Rico, Texas, and Florida in the wake of the deadly storms Maria, Harvey, and Irma this hurricane season. The president has also requested a $4.9 billion loan to help Puerto Rico pay its bills from the storm. The island faced more than $70 billion in debt prior to the storm and declared bankruptcy in May.

Title: Former Senator Rick Santorum Ponders 2016 Presidential Run, Discusses Policy Ideas and Party Strategy

Article:

In an interview with The Associated Press, former Pennsylvania Senator Rick Santorum has expressed uncertainty about a potential 2016 presidential run, but has not ruled out the possibility. The former senator, who is currently serving as CEO of EchoLight Studios, a movie studio focused on faith and family-themed films, cites personal and professional commitments as reasons for not pursuing another White House bid.

Santorum, who ran an upstart campaign in 2012, surviving until Mitt Romney's last remaining rival, acknowledges the challenges he faced in the 2012 primary, including difficulty raising funds and securing support from establishment Republicans. However, his socially conservative profile did earn him victories in 11 states.

In his new book, "Blue Collar Conservatives: Recommitting to an America That Works," Santorum offers policy ideas on energy, education, the economy, and healthcare. The book, set to be released on Monday, is part think tank policy paper, part campaign playbook, and part communications advice on connecting with working-class voters.

Santorum argues that the Republican Party needs to shift its focus from business leaders and "job creators" to employees, as anxiety among working-class voters remains high. He believes that the party has for too long been speaking to the top earners while neglecting the workers.

"A rising tide lifts all boats—unless your boat has a hole in it. A lot of Americans, we've got holes in our boats," Santorum said. "Millions and millions of Americans (are) out there who want good lives but have holes in their boats."

Santorum also criticizes the libertarian streak within the Republican Party, stating that it distorts the definition of freedom and that politicians wrongly look to President Ronald Reagan's policies to address today's challenges. He also takes a swipe at Republicans who demonize social welfare programs, questioning whether they truly care less about the less fortunate than Democrats do.

The tough talk in Santorum's book raises questions about his viability in a potentially crowded 2016 primary field. Santorum is not rushing to campaign in early nominating states like Iowa or New Hampshire, stating that he would wait at least a year before deciding on a 2016 bid.

Santorum's personal life, particularly the health of his daughter Bella, who has a genetic disorder, also plays a role in his decision-making process. Bella, who has Trisomy 18, a condition that causes brain, heart, and internal organ developmental abnormalities, turns 6 in May. Santorum is currently working on a book about his daughter and has been kept awake by her difficult nights.

Family issues will be a key factor in Santorum's decision to run or not, and Bella's health will be a significant consideration. His other six children, Santorum said, are supportive of another run.

The Republican Party's direction in the 2014 elections is a focus of Santorum's latest book. He argues that the party is heading towards "No-ville," a place where they are against this, against that, without painting a positive vision for America.

After the 2012 campaign, Santorum joined EchoLight Studios as CEO, seeing an opportunity to produce movies with a faith message that are better than those that have been done. Santorum's daughter Bella keeps him busy at home.

Title: U.S. and Iran Nuclear Talks: A 50-50 Prospect as Key Issues Remain Unresolved

Article:

The ongoing Iran nuclear talks are progressing, but significant issues remain unresolved, creating a 50-50 chance of reaching a deal. This is according to top U.S. officials who are emerging from closed-door negotiations with their Iranian counterparts, aiming to broker a lasting deal that prevents Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.

The Obama administration is employing a strategic messaging approach to reassure key domestic constituencies, maintain the unity of the international coalition involved in the negotiations, and exert pressure on Iran. According to Suzanne Maloney, an Iran expert at the Washington-based Brookings Institution and a former State Department Iran policy adviser, this messaging strategy is crucial for setting the expectations of the negotiating parties and the political context at home.

Skeptics in Congress want to see a tough U.S. stance and the pursuit of the best possible deal. International partners want to ensure that the U.S. has not brought them to the negotiating table for nothing. Iran, on the other hand, needs to understand that the U.S. will not concede certain points and is willing to walk away if necessary.

Secretary of State John Kerry reiterated this message during a press conference on Thursday, stating that the U.S. is not prepared to sit at the negotiating table indefinitely. However, he also emphasized that the U.S. is not under time pressure and should not abandon negotiations simply because the deadline has passed.

Sen. Chris Coons of Delaware, a key Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, interpreted Kerry's words as a determination to send a message to Iran's Supreme Leader: "The deal that is on the table is the best deal you're going to get. You either need to accept it or we're going to walk away."

Maloney explained that Kerry and other officials' statements are a calculated attempt to influence Iranian decision-making from the outside. However, these statements also serve another purpose: addressing the concerns of restless members of Congress who fear that Iran is gaining the upper hand and sticking to its demands while the U.S. concedes.

By missing the July 9 deadline set by Congress and initiating a 60-day congressional review period instead of the initial 30 days, the administration now faces twice as much time for vocal opponents to scrutinize the deal's details and rally votes against it.

In recent weeks, the Obama administration has emphasized its willingness to walk away from negotiations if Iran does not relent on the final, crucial sticking points. President Barack Obama stated last week that he would walk away from the negotiations if the deal is not favorable, while Kerry reiterated on Thursday that the U.S. is prepared to end the process if the tough decisions are not made.

This tough stance gives some in Congress hope that the Obama administration is holding firm. However, it is unclear whether the more hardened skeptics are convinced by the administration's insistence that it is not flinching on key points.

"There's still frustration and an overwhelming skepticism toward the administration and its ability to hold a hard line with respect to Iran," said Maloney.

The messaging of walking away from a deal also reinforces the administration's argument that it has worked tirelessly to obtain a good deal and, therefore, has achieved the best possible one if a deal is reached. If no deal is reached, the messaging will help to manage expectations.

President Obama told Senate Democrats this week that it is more likely that there will be no deal. Sen. Dick Durbin of Illinois, the No. 2 Democrat in the Senate, reported that Obama said the chances are below 50-50.

Days later, Kerry expressed optimism, stating that some outstanding issues had been resolved and that progress had been made. However, the coalition of five world powers negotiating alongside the U.S. is already showing signs of strain, with Russia adopting a stance on relaxing sanctions more in line with Iran's. The new Iranian demand for the lifting of the arms embargo has caused frustration for the U.S. while winning support from Moscow.

Under no circumstances should the U.S. relieve pressure on Iran regarding ballistic missile capabilities and arms trafficking, stated Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey this week on Capitol Hill. The ongoing negotiations remain a delicate balance of pressure and diplomacy, with the U.S. and its partners working to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon while maintaining the unity of the international coalition and managing domestic expectations.

Title: David Hogg Outlines Political Ambitions, Calls for Older Democrats to Step Aside for Young Leaders

Article:

In a revealing interview with New York Magazine, Parkland shooting survivor and gun-control activist David Hogg has outlined his political ambitions, calling for older Democrats to make way for younger leaders if they want to be successful.

The article, published Sunday, provides an in-depth look at Hogg's life and aspirations, revealing a seven-year plan that includes working on a presidential campaign in 2020, attending college in 2019, and subsequently running for Congress.

Hogg, who is one of Time magazine's "100 Most Influential" people, expressed his belief that the reason Republicans are currently successful is due to their empowerment of young people. He criticized older Democrats for not relinquishing control, citing House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's age as an example.

In the interview, Hogg noted that U.S. House Speaker Paul D. Ryan was 45 when he took up the leadership role. He expressed his intention to spend the next several months meeting with other activists and canvasing in advance of the midterm elections.

If obstacles were non-existent, Hogg stated that he would attend college in the fall of 2019, followed by a year off in 2020 to work on a presidential campaign. He also mentioned that some candidates have already approached him for potential collaboration.

After college, Hogg plans to prepare for his congressional run, stating, "I think I’ve come to that conclusion. I want to be at least part of the change in Congress."

Hogg also expressed his admiration for Democratic Socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, predicting her success in the White House. However, he expressed dissatisfaction with the current state of the Democratic Party, stating, "Sen. Bernie Sanders is a great guy, terrible on guns. [Former President Obama] increased drone warfare and killed a lot of civilians.... Honestly, they all kind of suck."

Title: Hurricane Florence Approaches US East Coast, Threatening Millions with Extreme Weather Conditions

Article:

As Hurricane Florence, now a category three storm with maximum sustained winds of 120mph (195km/h), approaches the US East Coast, officials are urging millions of residents to evacuate before the storm makes landfall as early as Thursday evening. The National Weather Service has warned that the hurricane is "extremely dangerous" and could bring "unbelievable damage" from wind, storm surge, and inland flooding.

Up to 1.7 million people have been ordered to evacuate across South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. Four South Carolina motorways have been diverted one-way to speed the exodus. Georgia has declared a state of emergency, following the Carolinas, Virginia, Maryland, and Washington DC.

A National Weather Service forecaster said, "This will likely be the storm of a lifetime for portions of the Carolina coast." The forecaster went on to say, "I can't emphasize enough the potential for unbelievable damage from wind, storm surge, and inland flooding with this storm."

Jeff Byard, of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said, "This is going to be a Mike Tyson punch to the Carolina coast." North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper warned that "disaster is at the doorstep" and "tens of thousands" of buildings may be flooded.

Waves 83ft (25m) tall were recorded at sea on Wednesday morning. While many coastal residents have complied with mandatory evacuation orders, others are boarding up their homes and vowing to ride out the storm.

Florence could wreak more than $170bn (£130bn) of havoc and damage nearly 759,000 homes and businesses, says analytics firm CoreLogic. In 1999, Hurricane Floyd left hundreds of thousands of dead hogs and chickens floating in floodwaters in North Carolina.

Nearly 1,000 prisoners in South Carolina will not be moved from their cells, despite a mandatory evacuation order in the area. A state department of corrections spokesman said, "In the past, it's been safer to leave them there."

There are fears for wild horse herds in North Carolina's Outer Banks, but experts say these equines can sense bad weather coming and head to higher ground.

In a video posted to his Twitter account on Wednesday, US President Donald Trump warned residents in Florence's bullseye to heed official warnings. "Get out of its way, don't play games with it," said Mr. Trump. "It's a big one, maybe as big as they've seen, and tremendous amounts of water."

European astronaut Alexander Gerst shared images of Florence's eye wall from space, calling the storm a "no-kidding nightmare." Forecasters say the storm poses such a threat because it is expected to slow down and hover for nearly two days over the Carolina coast, before dipping south towards Georgia.

It is forecast to bring 20-40in (50-100cm) of rain and life-threatening storm surges of up to 13ft. As of Wednesday evening, officials say these surges are now "highly likely" as Florence churns closer. The National Weather Service also predicts "catastrophic flash flooding and prolonged significant river flooding" in parts of the Carolinas and Appalachians.

Hurricane force winds will emanate up to 70 miles from the centre of the storm, say meteorologists. National Hurricane Center Director Ken Graham warned that waterways up to 40 miles inland may flood. He added that half of fatalities during hurricanes are caused by storm surges, and another quarter of deaths are due to inland rains and flooding.

The relationship between climate change and hurricanes is a complex one. Warmer seas power hurricanes, so as the temperature of ocean water goes up, we might expect the intensity of hurricanes to increase in future. A hotter atmosphere can also hold more water, so this should allow hurricanes to dump more water on affected areas. However, there are so many factors that contribute to these rare events, it has been difficult to tease out clear trends from the data.

Title: Clinton Taps into Black Voter Anger over Supreme Court Vacancy, Accuses Republicans of Racial Insensitivity

Article:

In the wake of the passing of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, political tensions have escalated, with Democratic state representative Stacey Abrams of Georgia, and House minority leader, stating that the election on Nov. 8 can no longer be viewed as a mere theoretical exercise.

For Hillary Clinton, the court issue could be particularly significant, given her increasing reliance on nonwhite voters to secure her victory against Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Should she emerge victorious over Sanders, who has galvanized many liberals, she will need a compelling issue to motivate President Obama's loyalists to vote.

Clinton moved swiftly on Tuesday to capitalize on the anger of blacks over the Republican Senate's opposition to President Obama's nomination of a replacement for Justice Scalia. In a speech before a predominantly black audience in Harlem, Clinton criticized the Republican Senate's stance, stating, "Now the Republicans say they'll reject anyone President Obama nominates no matter how qualified. Some are even saying he doesn't have the right to nominate anyone! As if somehow he's not the real president."

Clinton further accused the Republicans of a longstanding pattern of mistreatment, stating, "They demonize President Obama and encourage the ugliest impulses of the paranoid fringe. This kind of hatred and bigotry has no place in our politics or our country."

Republicans have been sensitive about the notion that they are diminishing President Obama due to his race, and spokesmen for several Republican senators, including Mitch McConnell and Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, declined to comment or were unavailable for comment. The suggestion that racism is a factor has sparked anger among McConnell's allies, who point out his formative political experience working for a Republican senator who supported civil rights, his role in overriding President Ronald Reagan's veto of sanctions against the apartheid government in South Africa, and his marriage to an Asian-American woman.

Title: U.S. Court of Appeals Rulings Split on Affordable Care Act Subsidies

Article:

In a split decision, two U.S. appeals courts have issued conflicting rulings on the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) subsidies, with one court striking down subsidies in states that did not establish their own insurance exchanges, and the other upholding them.

The first decision, handed down by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, invalidated subsidies for the 36 states that did not set up their own insurance exchanges. The Obama administration has announced its intention to seek a review by the full 11-judge panel, with a spokeswoman for the Department of Justice stating, "We believe that this decision is incorrect, inconsistent with Congressional intent, different from previous rulings, and at odds with the goal of the law: to make health care affordable no matter where people live."

The potential impact of this decision could affect nearly 5 million Americans who signed up for Obamacare through federal exchanges, according to California Healthline. If subsidies were to be removed, millions of U.S. residents could become uninsured, as health plans sold through the exchange might become unaffordable without the assistance.

In a separate ruling, the three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit unanimously decided that the ambiguity in the ACA's language allows for subsidies to be given to both those who signed up using state exchanges and those who used federal exchanges on behalf of states.

The conflicting decisions stem from the interpretation of the ACA's language regarding subsidies for Americans who bought insurance through exchanges set up by states and the federal government. In his concurring opinion, Senior Circuit Judge Raymond Randolph of the D.C. Circuit court stated, "An Exchange established by the federal government can not possibly be 'an Exchange established by the State.' To hold otherwise would be to engage in distortion, not interpretation. Only further legislation could accomplish the expansion the government seeks."

The future of this dispute may ultimately be decided by the Supreme Court.

Title: Trump's Claim of 'Total Authority' Sparks Constitutional Concerns Amidst Pandemic

Article:

The United States is currently grappling with two significant crises: the coronavirus pandemic and the presidency of Donald Trump. The latter's connection to the administration's handling of the pandemic response is not merely political rhetoric. Unlike previous presidents who focused on meeting the challenges posed by crises, Trump prioritizes the pandemic only insofar as it serves to bolster his power and image.

During a recent press briefing, Trump asserted that as president, he holds "total authority." This claim, however, is unconstitutional and untrue. The Constitution divides federal authority among the three branches of government, and the 10th Amendment explicitly delegates power to the states.

Trump's assertion of "total authority" has raised concerns, as it contradicts the basic principles of the U.S. political system. If former President Obama had made such a claim, conservative protesters would have taken to the streets, supported by Fox News and GOP leaders. Yet, Trump's autocratic assertions are met with silence and assent.

The federal government, under President Trump, appears to be incapable of performing its duties during a national emergency. Trump wants all the power, all the credit, and none of the responsibility. This combination of authoritarianism and fecklessness poses a threat to American democracy and public health.

In the absence of federal leadership, the nation's governors are devising their own solutions. Governors such as Gavin Newsom (D-Calif.) are forming partnerships with neighboring states to plan for reopening their economies.

Voters should remember not just that Trump mismanaged this deadly pandemic, but that his behavior during the crisis constituted a crisis in its own right. The November election may provide a remedy for Trump's behavior.

Title: Open Carry Advocates' Public Presence Sparks Controversy and Fear in Daily Life

Article:

In a growing trend across the United States, open carry enthusiasts are increasingly making their presence felt in public places, sparking debates and causing unease among citizens. The recent Georgia law, which allows the open carrying of deadly weapons at all times and in all places, has further fueled this phenomenon.

A recent incident at a park where children were playing little league baseball saw an armed man waving his gun and shouting, creating a disturbing atmosphere for the parents. Despite the police finding no legal infringement, the incident left the parents feeling alarmed and forced to leave. This incident highlights the tension between the exercise of the Second Amendment right and the general public's sense of safety.

Following the Sandy Hook elementary school massacre, open carry advocates staged demonstrations at Starbucks stores nationwide, including in Newtown, Connecticut. These demonstrations caused no incidents, but the CEO of Starbucks politely requested that these gun proliferation supporters refrain from using Starbucks as a platform for their demonstrations, citing employee safety concerns.

Last week, open carry proponents staged a demonstration at a Jack in the Box, causing such fear among employees that they sought refuge in the walk-in freezer. The police, assuming an armed robbery was in progress, responded with a large presence.

One of the demonstrators, Haros, defended their actions, stating, "We're not breaking the laws, we're not here to hurt anybody. We're not trying to alarm anybody. We're doing this because it's our constitutional right." Haros believes that open carry demonstrations serve a safety purpose, as police cannot be everywhere at all times.

However, critics argue that these demonstrations infringe on the rights of others. In situations where open carry advocates are present, individuals may feel uncomfortable expressing their opinions, and employees may feel pressured to serve armed customers. In the real world, sane people do not confront armed individuals, and the general public is left questioning the line between exercising a constitutional right and causing unnecessary fear and discomfort.

As the open carry movement continues to gain momentum, the line between personal freedom and public safety becomes increasingly blurred, leaving many Americans questioning the true meaning of freedom in the presence of armed citizens.

Title: Romney's Overseas Trip: A Mixed Bag of Successes and Controversies

Article:

In the final leg of his three-country tour, Mitt Romney's overseas trip, aimed at showcasing his foreign policy expertise, has been marked by both substantive highlights and distractions. As the Republican candidate wrapped up his visit in Poland, a senior Romney adviser, Stuart Stevens, expressed confidence in the trip's success.

"I think it was a great success," Stevens said after Romney's foreign policy speech in Warsaw. "The idea is that, can people get a good sense of who he is? Can people listen and see that this is a person speaking from the heart about Israel and about Poland?" Stevens added.

Romney's speech at Poland's national library offered an emotional tribute to the country's journey from the Iron Curtain to the economic envy of Europe. "I, and my fellow Americans, are inspired by the path of freedom tread by the people of Poland," Romney said.

However, the trip has been marred by several controversies. The trouble began in Britain, where Romney publicly questioned whether London was ready to host the Summer Olympic Games. This led to a public rebuke from British Prime Minister David Cameron, who labeled Romney's comments as "not-so-subtle digs."

In Israel, Romney's policy advisers declined to comment on his comments, and the candidate himself took only three questions from the traveling press corps. Controversy also arose from Romney's remarks on Jerusalem and the economic disparity between Israelis and Palestinians, which inflamed already raw feelings in the region.

During the final hours in Poland, the Romney campaign spoke of its "great success" while facing criticism over perceived gaffes. A heated exchange between the campaign's traveling press secretary and reporters at the Polish Tomb of the Unknown Soldier made headlines, with the press secretary reportedly shouting, "Kiss my ass. This is a holy site."

Despite the controversies, the campaign has received positive reviews from supporters and U.S. television networks, according to Romney's senior adviser. As Romney returns to the U.S., he will be greeted by a slew of new ads and a mobile app about his VP selection process.

Conservative bloggers have protested that Romney's overseas trip has been unfairly judged in the media, with one blogger, John Hinderaker of Powerline, writing, "By any reasonable standard, Romney's trip has been successful. Yet press coverage has been unrelentingly negative." However, Fox News Channel anchor Greta Van Susteren, a frequent interviewee of Romney, had a different assessment of the coverage, writing, "There has been no press access to Governor Romney since we landed in Poland. We (press) are in a holding pattern."

Title: President Trump Calls for Tougher Travel Ban, Condemns London Attack; Criticism from Former Chief of Staff

In the aftermath of a terrorist attack in London that left at least 22 people injured, President Donald Trump called for a "larger, tougher" travel ban and criticized the perpetrator as a "loser."

The President took to Twitter early Friday morning, stating, "Another attack in London by a loser terrorist. These are sick and demented people who were in the sights of Scotland Yard. Must be proactive!" He followed up with another tweet, "Loser terrorists must be dealt with in a much tougher manner. The internet is their main recruitment tool which we must cut off & use better!"

The attack, which occurred at a London subway station, was declared a "terrorist incident" by London's Metropolitan Police, who reported that the incident was caused by the detonation of an improvised explosive device.

Following the attack, President Trump spoke with British Prime Minister Theresa May to express his sympathies and prayers for the injured. The White House released a statement, saying, "The President pledged to continue close collaboration with the United Kingdom to stop attacks worldwide targeting innocent civilians and to combat extremism."

In a series of early morning tweets, President Trump also criticized political correctness and reiterated his support for the travel ban, which is currently being contested in the courts. He tweeted, "The travel ban into the United States should be far larger, tougher and more specific-but stupidly, that would not be politically correct!"

Trump also claimed, "We have made more progress in the last nine months against ISIS than the Obama Administration has made in 8 years." He added, "We have to be very smart. We have to be very, very tough."

In response to President Trump's tweets, former chief of staff to Prime Minister May, Nick Timothy, criticized the President's use of the term "loser terrorist." Timothy tweeted, "True or not—and I’m sure he doesn’t know—this is so unhelpful from leader of our ally and intelligence partner."

Prime Minister May also released a statement, saying, "My thoughts are with those injured at Parsons Green and emergency services who are responding bravely to this incident."

Title: New Jersey Becomes 14th State to Allow Illegal Immigrants to Obtain Driver's Licenses

New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy signed a bill on Thursday, expanding access to driver's licenses for illegal immigrants, making the Garden State the 14th state in the country, along with the District of Columbia, to enact such a measure.

"Expanding access to driver's licenses is critical for the safety of New Jerseyans and a step toward building a stronger and fairer New Jersey for all," Murphy said.

The bill, which was approved by the Democratic majorities in both the state Assembly and Senate during their final legislative sessions of the year, allows individuals over the age of 16 who are illegal immigrants to obtain driver's licenses and learner's permits. Applicants can use foreign documents such as passports or their old driver's license from their home country to complete the process. A Social Security number is not required, according to The Associated Press.

The law reportedly establishes two types of licenses. One would conform to federal REAL ID requirements and would require proof of legal residency. The second license would only require six points of identification. The applicant would not have to provide proof of U.S. citizenship.

A similar measure known as "The Green Light Law" was signed by New York's Democratic Governor Andrew Cuomo earlier this year and went into effect this week. It also allows illegal immigrants to obtain a license without having to provide a Social Security number or proof of American citizenship.

Fox News' Danielle Wallace and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Title: The New York Times' Controversial Decision to Publish Senator Tom Cotton's Op-Ed: A Closer Look at the Criticisms and Implications

Article:

The publication of Senator Tom Cotton's Op-Ed in The New York Times has sparked a heated debate, with critics questioning the paper's editorial standards and the motives behind its decision to publish the controversial piece. The Op-Ed, which advocated for the use of military force to quell civil unrest, has been met with criticism on several fronts, including its tone, legal arguments, and potential impact on public safety, particularly for the black community.

One criticism leveled against the paper is that the Op-Ed did not meet The Times' editorial standards, with some arguing that the piece would have been more acceptable if Senator Cotton had presented a stronger case with more nuanced arguments and a less confrontational tone. Some critics suggest that the paper's supposed flaws in the Op-Ed may have been a pretext for achieving a politically desired outcome, following a staff revolt.

Another criticism is that the paper could have examined Senator Cotton's views without giving him an unmediated platform. Instead, his proposal should have been evaluated by the news department, not published uncritically in the Opinion pages. The argument is that his views are controversial and should have been presented in a more balanced and critical manner.

However, the value of the Op-Ed does not lie in its goodness or rightness, but rather in the fact that Senator Cotton is a leading spokesman for a significant segment of public opinion. Denying readers the opportunity to examine his opinions for themselves is seen as patronizing, and suggesting they should look up his opinions elsewhere is seen as a betrayal of the newspaper's responsibility as a newspaper of record.

The most serious criticism is that the publication of the piece puts black lives at risk, including members of The Times' staff. This is a valid concern, especially in the current climate of increased reports of hate crimes. However, it is not the duty of the paper to make people feel safe by refusing to publish dismaying Op-Eds. The knowledge of Senator Cotton's views, whether one agrees with them or not, can be a source of strength in understanding and countering his arguments.

In conclusion, the publication of Senator Tom Cotton's Op-Ed in The New York Times has sparked a heated debate, with critics questioning the paper's editorial standards and the motives behind its decision. While the piece has been met with criticism on several fronts, it is essential to consider the value of the Op-Ed as a reflection of a significant segment of public opinion and the importance of open and critical discourse in a democratic society.

Title: US Imposes New Sanctions on Russia Over Salisbury Poisoning Incident

Article:

The Russian rouble has plummeted to its lowest level since November 2016, following the announcement of new US sanctions in response to the poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter in the UK. The dollar-rouble rate reached 66.7 on the Moscow stock exchange, marking a significant drop from Tuesday's rate of 63.4.

The attack, which occurred in Salisbury in March, involved the use of the Russian nerve agent Novichok. Both Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia have since recovered, though their current whereabouts remain undisclosed. The US has determined that Russia "has used chemical or biological weapons in violation of international law," according to US State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert.

The new sanctions, which will take effect on or around August 22, cover exports of sensitive electronic components and other technologies that can have military applications. There will also be some further restrictions on Russian access to US financial services. If Russia fails to provide reliable assurances that it will no longer use chemical weapons and allow on-site inspections by the United Nations, more draconian sanctions, including a far-reaching trade embargo and a ban on Aeroflot flights to the US, may be imposed within 90 days.

The US and EU have previously imposed sanctions on dozens of Russian state officials and firms accused of involvement in the 2014 annexation of Crimea and support for separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine. These sanctions restrict travel and financial transactions.

The Russian embassy in the US has responded to the new sanctions, stating that it has become "accustomed to not hearing any facts or evidence" and reiterating its call for an open and transparent investigation of the Salisbury incident. The UK Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, thanked the US for its support and emphasized the importance of preventing chemical weapons from becoming a new norm.

The new sanctions come after pressure from Republican members of Congress, who have been pushing for a formal determination that Russia had broken international law by using a military-grade chemical weapon on the Skripals. The US expelled some five dozen diplomats shortly after the poisoning, but stopped short of making a formal determination until now.

The Salisbury incident and subsequent events have strained relations between Russia and the West, with more than 20 countries expelling Russian envoys in solidarity with the UK. The attack prompted the UK to blame Russia for the use of the nerve agent Novichok, and relations between the two nations have reached a new low. In addition to the Skripal case, two other individuals fell ill in Amesbury, eight miles from Salisbury, in June. One of them, Dawn Sturgess, later died, while her partner, Charlie Rowley, spent three weeks recovering in hospital. Tests conducted at the UK's military research lab, Porton Down, found that the couple had also been exposed to Novichok.

Title: U.S. Prisons and Jails Struggle to Contain COVID-19 Outbreaks

Article:

In a stark revelation, the New York Times has reported on the devastating impact of the coronavirus in federal prisons, with the Federal Correctional Complex in Oakdale, Louisiana, being one of the hardest hit. Patrick Jones, a 49-year-old inmate serving a 27-year sentence for possession of crack cocaine, became the first federal inmate to die of the virus on March 28. As of now, at least seven inmates have died, over 100 inmates and staff members have been infected, with more than 20 hospitalized.

The situation in Cook County Jail, the largest in the country, is equally dire. With four inmates dead and 215 testing positive, the jail is already one of the nation's largest sources of infections. The virus has also claimed the life of one employee. Sheriff Tom Dart, who has been open about the situation, has urged for more help due to the overwhelming nature of the crisis.

In Ohio, 2,300 prisoners in three prisons have tested positive, making it the largest reported source of coronavirus infection in the United States. Prisons and jails across the country are grappling with the virus, with inmates locked up for nonviolent crimes or awaiting trial, and older, vulnerable inmates near the end of their term, among others, living in fear of a potential death sentence.

Prisons and jails are proving to be virtual petri dishes for the virus, with social distancing impossible and basic hygiene facilities often inadequate. Correctional officers, who have no choice but to mix with inmates, are at risk, as are their families and the communities where they live.

In response, prisons and jails have begun to take measures such as reducing their population, isolating those with symptoms, providing soap and disinfectants, and increasing the frequency of facility cleaning. However, testing remains a significant issue, with too few being tested too seldom.

The situation has led to prison uprisings, with inmates demanding protection and more information, and corrections officers joining in lawsuits to secure adequate protective equipment, information, and testing.

Experts urge prison officials to speed the release of nonviolent offenders, the elderly, and the vulnerable. Universal testing is considered an imperative, and prisoners need more access to soap and water. Both prisoners and corrections officials need protective gear and information on how to protect themselves.

The pandemic has once again highlighted the moral outrage of the U.S.'s high incarceration rate, with prisoners disproportionately poor and people of color. Even without the virus, this is a disgrace. Now, the virus is turning incarceration into a potential death sentence. The time for aggressive action is long past, and prisons should be made a priority for supplies, tests, and early release of as many inmates as possible, particularly the elderly and the vulnerable.

Title: Rep. John Conyers Admits Settlement with Former Staffer Amid Sexual Harassment Allegations

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.), a powerful Democratic lawmaker and the longest-serving House member, admitted Tuesday that he settled a complaint with a former staffer who reportedly claimed she was fired for rejecting his sexual advances.

Initially, Conyers had denied any settlements related to sexual harassment allegations to the Associated Press on Tuesday. However, Conyers' office issued a detailed clarification Tuesday afternoon, acknowledging the complaint was real, though the lawmaker adamantly denied the underlying claims.

"The Associated Press made an unannounced visit to the home of Congressman Conyers this morning," a spokesperson for Conyers said Tuesday. "Congressman Conyers was under the impression the reporter was speaking of recent allegations of which he was unaware of and denied."

Conyers, who has served in the House for decades and is the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, stated that he has been a "fierce advocate for equality in the workplace" and supports the rights of his employees. However, he noted that the mere making of an allegation does not mean it is true.

"In this case, I expressly and vehemently denied the allegations made against me and continue to do so," Conyers said, adding that his office resolved the allegations. "That should not be lost in the narrative. The resolution was not for millions of dollars, but rather for an amount that equated to a reasonable severance payment."

Conyers also stated that he would "fully cooperate with an investigation" once the House determines the "extent" they will look at "these issues."

The allegations against Conyers, as reported by BuzzFeed News, include requests for sexual favors, inappropriate touching, and rubbing staff members' hands and legs and backs. The woman who complained about her firing reportedly claimed she was dismissed because she did not "succumb to [his] sexual advances."

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) called the report "extremely troubling" in a statement released Tuesday. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) said she was not aware of the reported settlement involving Conyers.

The report also stated that the Congressional Office of Compliance did not confirm or deny dealing with the case. The allegations against Conyers are the latest in a series of sexual harassment allegations shaking Capitol Hill in recent days. Similar allegations have been made against Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.) and Senate Republican candidate Roy Moore in Alabama.

Title: Veteran Senator John McCain Diagnosed with Glioblastoma, Vows to Return to Work

Article:

In a statement released by his office, veteran US Senator John McCain has been diagnosed with a brain cancer known as glioblastoma, following a surgery to remove a blood clot from above his left eye last week. The 80-year-old politician is currently reviewing treatment options, which may include chemotherapy and radiation, according to his doctors.

The senator, who is known for his tough and independent-minded demeanor, is recovering at home in good spirits. In a tweet, he expressed his gratitude for the outpouring of support and assured his colleagues in Congress that he would be back soon.

The tumor was discovered during the surgery at a clinic in Phoenix, Arizona, last Friday. Tissue analysis revealed that the clot was associated with a primary brain tumor. A statement from the Mayo Clinic confirmed the diagnosis.

Senior Republicans and Democrats have wished Senator McCain a speedy recovery, prompting him to tweet his thanks and a warning to his sparring partners in Congress.

John McCain, a Vietnam veteran and the chairman of the Senate Committee on Armed Services, is a decorated war hero who spent more than five years as a prisoner of war. He earned his reputation as a warrior, being shot down as a US Navy pilot over Vietnam and enduring more than five years of captivity, including two years in solitary confinement.

During the most recent presidential election campaign, Donald Trump belittled the senator as "not a war hero," saying "I like people who weren't captured." Mr. McCain may have annoyed many Republicans by arguing for reforms to campaign finance and immigration laws, and he may have irritated opponents of America's many wars with his forceful arguments in favor of the projection of US military might.

Glioblastoma is a particularly aggressive brain tumor, and its incidence increases with age, affecting more men than women. Senator McCain's family, including his 32-year-old daughter Meghan, has reacted with shock to the news. In a tweet, Meghan said, "Cancer may afflict him in many ways, but it will not make him surrender. Nothing ever has."

President Donald Trump, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and former President Barack Obama have all expressed their support for Senator McCain, wishing him a speedy recovery. The nation now waits with bated breath as the senator faces this new challenge with the same courage and determination that has defined his life.

Title: Army Warns of Potential Crippling Effects of Sequestration on Ground Forces

The United States Army is urging active and retired generals to advocate for relief from budget caps, known as sequestration, in Congress, as another round of automatic budget cuts could significantly impact the Army's ability to execute its strategic responsibilities, according to an internal memo obtained by The ███.

In the memo, Maj. Gen. Laura Richardson, the Army's chief of legislative affairs, stated that without relief from sequestration, the Army may soon be unable to meet the requirements outlined in the Defense Strategic Guidance, potentially leading to a "hollow Army." The budget caps, suspended under a bipartisan budget deal, could return in fiscal 2016, beginning on October 1, unless an agreement is reached.

Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, the Army's chief of staff and a former top commander in Iraq, has been one of the most vocal military leaders in warning about the potential consequences of another sequestration round. He has made several public statements emphasizing that another round of cuts could come close to breaking the Army.

The active-duty soldier force peaked at 570,000 during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars and is scheduled to shrink to approximately 450,000. However, sequestration poses a threat to further reduce the force to 420,000, a level that Gen. Odierno believes is the absolute minimum for the active force to carry out its strategic responsibilities.

Gen. Richardson wrote in the memo that caps on defense spending are having a detrimental impact on the Army, damaging readiness, reducing manpower, and weakening modernization programs. The memo also stated that Gen. Odierno wants all Army general officers to be aware of the impacts of sequestration so they can discuss these issues with members of Congress and their staff during their engagements.

Recent deployments demonstrate a busy U.S. Army, with forces sent to Europe for war games as a warning to Russian President Vladimir Putin, a deployment to Baghdad to advise the Iraqi Security Forces, soldiers inserted into West Africa to help combat the spread of the Ebola virus, and ground units maintained in Afghanistan.

Gen. Odierno recently told a group of defense reporters that the Army may reach a "breaking point" if more budget cuts are implemented. He stated that further cuts would force him to reduce purchases of weapons systems needed to modernize the war-weary force. "As I look at that," he said, "it's end strength, it's modernization, it's readiness. I can't go any faster on end strength, so that means you have to take further reductions in readiness and modernization."

Title: Gun-Violence Prevention Organizations Launch Voting Rights Campaign to Amplify Democracy and Combat Gun Violence

Article:

In a joint effort to highlight the connection between gun violence prevention and democracy, the gun-violence prevention organizations March For Our Lives, Brady, and Team Enough have launched a campaign focused on voting rights. The campaign, titled "Voting Access Saves Lives," aims to educate voters on their rights and provide resources to ensure equitable access to the ballot box.

The groups have released a report, "Accessing Democracy: A Gun Violence Issue," which focuses on four categories: voting by mail and absentee voting, voter registration, early voting, and restoration of voting rights. The report emphasizes that communities historically marginalized by gun violence are often deprived of the avenues of direct democracy and their right to vote.

The campaign will distribute the report and tool kits to hundreds of March For Our Lives, Brady, and Team Enough chapters, as well as the groups' network of other gun-violence prevention organizations. The tool kits will provide information on polling locations, voter registration, vote-by-mail and absentee voting laws, early voting options, and the status of voting rights for citizens with misdemeanor or felony records.

Each tool kit will also include "action plans" for the respective states, such as contacting state officials to expand equitable access to voting, extending in-person early voting, repealing voter ID laws, and supplying personal protective equipment to poll workers. For example, the Arizona tool kit provides citizens with the phone numbers of mayors and city council members in major cities, encouraging them to request personal protective equipment for poll workers.

Maxwell Frost, national organizing director for March For Our Lives, stated, "When we talk about actions and people getting involved, we're taking a very localized approach in this campaign. We're reaching out to folks who live in these states and asking them to advocate for their own states, for their own democracy reform in the place that they live in."

The Voting Access Saves Lives initiative comes amid protests and calls for racial justice following the death of George Floyd, a Black man who died in Minnesota after an officer knelt on his neck. The groups emphasize that while gun violence disproportionately affects Black communities, voting rights are often suppressed within those communities as well.

Crystal Cooper, director of communications at March For Our Lives, said, "If you're a young person who's been on the front lines and protesting and you clearly care about Black lives and racial justice and long-term outcomes, this work within the political system and fixing some of the historic inequities are also part of achieving that goal, and in fact play a major role in achieving that goal. It's the leaders as well, not just the policies, that we're advocating for. We need to make sure that we have the policies in place, the leaders in place."

The coalition believes there is a discrepancy between what Americans want and what they get when it comes to policy, in part because of a flawed electoral system and voter suppression. For example, a majority of people support background checks for private gun sales and sales at gun shows, according to the Pew Research Center. However, a bill that would require background checks for all firearms sales—passed in the House last year—has stalled in the Senate.

The Voting Access Saves Lives coalition is committed to ensuring that communities are able to vote for elected officials who represent them and their beliefs in free and fair elections. Kris Brown, president of Brady, stated, "The reality for our cause is that unless we ensure that we truly have free and fair elections, much of the work that we're trying to do will remain stalled in certain places."

Through calling for the restoration of voting rights, the coalition aims to make sure all citizens can participate in the electoral process. The campaign is particularly focused on the Black community, which has historically been disproportionately affected by gun violence and voter suppression.

Maxwell Frost, national organizing director for March For Our Lives, noted, "I'm really excited about this campaign personally because it's specific actions that are going to be helping different communities, you know, specifically the Black community, which is obviously the centerpiece of a national and international movement right now." Frost also highlighted the importance of restoring voting rights for formerly incarcerated individuals, citing his own experience working on a constitutional amendment that restored voting rights for most previously convicted felons in Florida.

Title: Analysis Shows Increasing Trend of High Safety Ratings in NHTSA Vehicle Assessments

Article:

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has been providing safety ratings for new vehicles since 1978, with the aim of informing consumers about a vehicle's crash protection and rollover safety. The agency awards up to five stars based on various safety measures, and a high rating can serve as a significant government endorsement for automakers.

An analysis by The Times, using data from car-shopping and research site Edmunds.com, reveals that almost every model has received high marks since 2001. From 2001 to 2010, 87% of all safety ratings were four or five stars.

John O' Dell, a senior editor and vehicle safety expert at Edmunds.com, attributes this trend to automakers' increasing understanding of NHTSA's requirements. They have learned to design their cars to excel in the ratings, with a focus on a vehicle's ability to withstand a rollover accident.

In 2011, the agency introduced new, stricter standards and added an overall safety rating. Despite these changes, the ratings have continued to improve. For models from 2011 to the present, 92% of the overall safety ratings were four or five-star ratings, according to the analysis. The percentage of four and five-star overall ratings increased each year, from 83% for 2011 models to 96% for 2015 models.

However, Jack Gillis, a former NHTSA official involved in early efforts to develop a ratings program at the agency and now a publisher of an independent rating, argues that the government is not making full use of this valuable resource. He suggests that presenting the information on a more relative basis could stimulate competition among automakers.

Title: President Obama Addresses National Security Agency Surveillance Concerns, Acknowledges Potential for Abuse

Article:

In a candid interview with CNN on Friday, President Barack Obama addressed the ongoing concerns regarding the National Security Agency's (NSA) surveillance programs. The President, during a two-day bus tour through upstate New York and Pennsylvania, acknowledged the potential for these programs to be abused if not properly checked.

"There are legitimate concerns that technology is moving so quickly that, at some point, does the technology outpace the laws that are in place and the protections that are in place?" Mr. Obama questioned, speaking with CNN's Chris Cuomo. "Do some of these [surveillance] systems end up being like a loaded gun out there that somebody at some future point could abuse?"

The President admitted that the American people are not reassured by his or congressional leaders' assurances that the federal government is not listening to citizens' phone calls or reading their emails. This skepticism has been fueled by recent disclosures that the NSA looked at as many as 56,000 communications of Americans over a three-year period, despite no connection to terrorism.

"This can only work if the American people trust what's going on," Mr. Obama stated. "People don't have enough information and aren't confident enough that between all of the safeguards and checks we put in place in the executive branch, and the federal court oversight, and the congressional oversight, people are still concerned that their emails are being read... We're going to have to continue to improve the safeguards."

While acknowledging Americans' fears and concerns, the President expressed confidence that the NSA surveillance programs are not being abused at the current moment. The NSA programs were first revealed by Edward Snowden, the former federal contractor who recently was granted asylum in Russia and is charged by the Justice Department with espionage and other offenses. Snowden is viewed by many civil liberties activists as a hero who exposed the extent of the government's spying on its own people.

Title: Obama Defends Bergdahl Rescue Mission, Addresses Congressional Criticism and National Security Concerns

Article:

In a press conference in Warsaw, Poland, President Barack Obama defended his administration's efforts to rescue Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from captivity, emphasizing the importance of bringing an American soldier home. The President stated, "We don't leave our men or women in uniform behind, and that dates back to the earliest days."

Obama argued that his administration had been consulting with Congress "for some time" regarding the possibility of a prisoner swap with the Taliban. However, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Mich.) disputed this claim, stating that Congress had not heard from the Obama administration since 2011 on the matter.

The White House did not inform lawmakers of the deal until after it had been executed, with formal notification coming on Monday, two days after the White House Rose Garden ceremony with Bergdahl's parents.

Obama maintained that his administration acted appropriately in seizing the opportunity to free Bergdahl, citing concerns for the soldier's health and the cooperation of Qatar in executing the exchange. Bergdahl has faced criticism for allegedly deserting his post in 2009, but Obama emphasized that the immediate focus is on helping him recover from the stresses of his captivity.

Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey stated on Facebook that any concerns about Bergdahl's conduct are separate from efforts to recover any U.S. service member in enemy captivity. Dempsey added that Bergdahl is innocent until proven guilty, and that the Army will not ignore misconduct if it occurred.

When asked about the possibility of Bergdahl facing a court martial for desertion, Obama stated that such discussions are premature, as the priority is ensuring a successful transition for Bergdahl after five years of captivity.

Obama also addressed concerns about the release of five Taliban members from Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, stating that their release was conditioned on Qatar's monitoring of their activities. He acknowledged the potential for recidivism but expressed confidence in the ability to respond if the released individuals engage in activities harmful to U.S. defenses.

Title: NSA Director Rogers Skeptical of U.S.-Russia Cyber Security Collaboration Amid Ongoing Concerns

In the picturesque town of ASPEN, Colorado, National Security Agency (NSA) Director Mike Rogers has expressed reservations about the prospect of a U.S.-Russia cyber security collaboration, a proposal that has sparked skepticism from several senior U.S. lawmakers.

The proposal, which initially seemed to have the support of President Donald Trump, has been met with criticism due to the ongoing investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. U.S. intelligence agencies have assessed that Russia meddled in the election by hacking Democratic emails and distributing online propaganda to help Trump win over his rival, Hillary Clinton.

Moscow has denied any interference, and Trump has maintained that his campaign did not collude with Russia. This week, a Russian presidential envoy suggested that discussions were underway between the two nations to create a joint cyber security working group.

When asked about the feasibility of setting up a cyber security cell with the Russians, Rogers, speaking at the annual Aspen Security Forum, responded, "I'm not a policy guy here... I would argue now is probably not the best time to be doing this."

Trump had earlier this month discussed the idea of creating such a group with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Group of 20 summit in Hamburg. However, the proposal has faced criticism from senior Republicans, who question Moscow's trustworthiness. Trump later seemed to back away from the idea, stating on Twitter, "The fact that President Putin and I discussed a Cyber Security unit doesn't mean I think it can happen. It can't."

The widespread concern and confusion about the possible cyber working group reflects the Trump administration's struggles to articulate a clear approach to international cyber security issues amid inconsistent statements by the president and ongoing personnel changes.

Rogers, however, suggested that such a unit could be a possibility "were we to see changes in [Russia's] behavior." The uncertainty surrounding the proposal underscores the complex and evolving nature of international cyber security relations, particularly between the United States and Russia.

Title: U.S. and Allies Seize Opportunity to Target Islamic State in Kobani, Acknowledge Long-Term Campaign Against ISIS

Article:

In a press conference on Friday, military and White House officials acknowledged that the ongoing fighting in the Syrian border town of Kobani has created an opportunity to take out large numbers of Islamic State (ISIS) fighters pouring into the battle. While the fighting has raised concerns that the vital town could still fall to ISIS, Army Gen. Lloyd Austin, head of U.S. Central Command, claimed that there is an upside for the U.S. and its allies.

Austin stated, "The enemy has made a decision to make Kobani his main effort," claiming "manpower" is streaming into the area. He further asserted, "Now, my goal is to defeat and ultimately destroy ISIL. And if [the enemy] continues to present us with major targets... then clearly, we'll service those targets, and we've done so very, very effectively here of late."

White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest echoed the point, stating that ISIS is amassing fighters and resources in Kobani. He explained, "That has created a rather target-rich environment around Kobani for American and coalition air strikes... it's easier to take them out."

However, military officials cautioned against expecting quick progress in the overall campaign against ISIS. Austin told a Pentagon news conference, "The campaign to destroy ISIL will take time, and there will be occasional setbacks along the way." He acknowledged "it's highly possible that Kobani may fall."

While the U.S. military is hammering the jihadists daily from the air, the U.S. military is talking of a years-long effort, one that will require more than aerial bombardment, will show results only gradually, and may eventually call for a more aggressive use of U.S. military advisers in Iraq.

Austin expressed optimism about the Iraqi government's ability to enlist the support of Sunni tribal leaders in Anbar province to turn the tide in that important region, where the militants have made recent gains. He also stated he sees no imminent threat to the international airport west of Baghdad, where U.S. Apache helicopters are monitoring Islamic State efforts to make inroads on the capital.

As an example of fresh progress, Austin said Iraqi soldiers on Friday attacked north from Baghdad to Beiji, home to Iraq's largest oil refinery. Yet, the militants are making gains in some parts, like the Sunni-dominated Anbar province, even as they stall or retrench in other areas. Baghdad is not believed to be in imminent danger of falling but it is "certainly in their sights," Pentagon spokesman Rear Adm. John Kirby said.

The Pentagon is preparing to set up a more formally organized command structure, known in military parlance as a joint task force, to lead and coordinate the campaign from a forward headquarters, perhaps in Kuwait. On Wednesday, it formally named the campaign "Operation Inherent Resolve."

As of Thursday, the U.S. had launched nearly 300 airstrikes in Iraq and nearly 200 in Syria, and allies had tallied fewer than 100, according to Central Command. Those figures do not capture the full scope of the effort because many airstrikes launch multiple bombs on multiple targets. Central Command said that as of Wednesday, U.S. and partner-nation air forces had dropped nearly 1,400 munitions.

Title: Russian An-148 Plane Crash Claims 71 Lives, Investigation Underway

Article:

A tragic incident occurred on Sunday as a Russian airliner, an An-148 regional jet belonging to Saratov Airlines, crashed minutes after takeoff from Domodedovo Airport in Moscow. The crash resulted in the death of all 65 passengers and six crew members on board, according to official statements.

The plane was en route to Orsk, approximately 1,000 miles southeast of Moscow, as reported by REN-TV. The Moscow Inter-Regional Transport Prosecutor's Office confirmed the fatalities, stating, "The plane was carrying 65 passengers and six crewmembers. All of them died."

Transport Minister Maxim Sokolov added, "Judging by everything, no one has survived this crash."

Authorities have recovered a black box from the crash site, and the area has been cordoned off. Sergei Poletykin, the regional head of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, reported, "One recorder was found at the crash site."

The crew of the doomed aircraft did not report any malfunctions, according to Svetlana Petrenko, an official representative of the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation. "At the moment it has been established that there have been no reports of aircraft failure from the crew," Petrenko said.

All passengers aboard the airliner are believed to have been residents of the Orenburg region, along the border with Kazakhstan, as per the Interfax news agency and Sergei Sheremetsinsky, a spokesman for the regional governor.

Russian President Vladimir Putin postponed a planned trip to Sochi to closely monitor the investigation and offered his condolences to the families of those killed. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stated, "The president expresses deep condolences to all those who lost their relatives and friends in this disaster."

Putin was to meet Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas on Monday in the Black Sea resort where the president has an official residence. Instead, Abbas will meet with Putin in Moscow in the latter part of Monday, as per Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov.

Fragments of the jet were found in the Ramenskoye area, about 25 miles from the airport, according to REN-TV. No ground casualties were reported. The flight took off from Moscow's Domodedovo Airport and spent about 5 minutes in the air before a signal was lost about 12 miles southeast of the airport, according to Flightradar24, a flight-tracking website.

The cause of the crash remains unclear, with weather conditions and pilot error being among the possible reasons. Russia's Investigative Committee is looking into all possible crash causes.

The plane, an Antonov An-148 jet, was manufactured in both Ukraine and Russia. While it remains to be seen what caused the crash on Sunday, shabby equipment and poor supervision had plagued Russian civil aviation for years after the 1991 collapse of the Soviet Union, but its safety record has improved markedly in recent years.

This tragic incident follows other significant crashes in Russia, such as the Tu-154 crash on Dec. 25, 2016, and the Boeing 737-800 crash in March 2016. The most recent large-scale crash occurred in October 2015, when a Russian Metrojet airliner was destroyed by an onboard bomb, killing 224 people.

Title: Democratic Recruitment Surges Amidst Fiscal Crises and GOP Troubles

Article:

In the wake of the ongoing fiscal crises that have plagued the U.S. Congress, the House Democrats are experiencing a significant boost in candidate recruitment efforts. The twin fiscal crises, which have taken a toll on the GOP's approval ratings nationwide, are providing a much-needed impetus for Democratic candidates who were previously hesitant or unwilling to run for office.

In Nebraska, Omaha city councilman Pete Festersen, who had previously declined to run against eight-term incumbent GOP Rep. Lee Terry, has reconsidered his decision following Terry's criticism during the government shutdown. National Democrats view Festersen as a pro-business moderate who could potentially challenge the Republican-friendly 2nd Congressional District.

Similarly, in New Jersey, attorney Bill Hughes Jr., the son of a popular former congressman, has expressed a likelihood of running against longtime GOP Rep. Frank LoBiondo. Indiana Democrat Joe Bock, a University of Notre Dame official, has also announced his intention to run after much deliberation.

Some of the Democratic recruits boast statewide or national profiles. Former FEMA director James Lee Witt is considering running for the seat being vacated by Republican Rep. Tom Cotton. In Florida, Alex Sink, the state's former chief financial officer, is contemplating a run for a seat in the St. Petersburg area.

The increased number of Democratic candidates offers a glimmer of hope for the party in an election year that has provided few opportunities for success. However, the combination of redistricting and demographics has limited the number of competitive seats in 2014, making it challenging for Democrats to chip away at the GOP's 17-seat majority.

Republicans are quick to point out that strong recruits are not a guarantee of success in red districts. Andrea Bozek, a National Republican Congressional Committee spokeswoman, stated, "It's going to be difficult for these second-tier Democrat candidates to run as outsiders in Republican districts when President Obama and Harry Reid are leading their party and running Washington."

Despite the challenges, the new recruits provide at least a glimmer of hope for the Democrats in an election year that has given them little reason for optimism. The fiscal crises have pushed many potential candidates, such as Festersen, Hughes, and Bock, to reconsider their decisions to run. The shutdown and debt standoff have also spurred other Democratic candidates, such as Aimee Belgard in New Jersey and Patrick Henry Hays in Arkansas, to contemplate challenging their respective GOP representatives.

The mess in Washington has made the sales pitches from the Democratic National Committee more compelling, with candidates such as Festersen and Witt being personally contacted by Vice President Joe Biden in an effort to secure their candidacy. The fiscal crises have crystallized the need for action, with candidates such as Hughes stating, "Whereas before it was, 'I don't know. Let's think about it.' Now it's, 'Let's do something.'"

Title: Attorney General Sessions' Alleged Misrepresentation of Russian Contacts Under Scrutiny

Article:

In a recent report by Adam Entous, Ellen Nakashima, and Greg Miller for the Washington Post, it has been alleged that Attorney General Jeff Sessions, under oath during his confirmation hearing, may have misrepresented his interactions with the Russian ambassador to the US, Sergey Kislyak.

According to the report, Sessions, in fact, spoke with Kislyak on two occasions, including, as reported by the Post, "at the height of what U.S. intelligence officials say was a Russian cyber campaign to upend the U.S. presidential race." This contradicts Sessions' statement to the Senate Judiciary Committee in January, where he stated that he was not aware of any such activities and had not communicated with Russians during the 2016 campaign.

During his confirmation hearing, Sen. Al Franken, a Minnesota Democrat, asked Sessions about any evidence of communication between individuals affiliated with the Trump campaign and the Russian government.
