Sessions responded, "I'm not aware of any of those activities," and added, "I have been called a surrogate at a time or two in that campaign and I did not have communications with the Russians."

The allegation that Sessions lied to Franken, if the Washington Post report is accurate, has sparked debate and controversy. Benjamin Wittes, editor in chief of the blog Lawfare, suggested on Twitter that there may not be enough evidence for a perjury charge. Wittes argued that there is ambiguity about whether Sessions, at his hearing, meant he had no communication with Russia as part of his work as a campaign surrogate versus his work as a senator. If he was speaking exclusively about his work on behalf of the campaign, Sessions could argue that his work as a US senator was a separate matter.

Sessions' spokesperson, Sarah Isgur Flores, and Sessions himself have denied any wrongdoing. In a statement, Sessions said, "I never met with any Russian officials to discuss issues of the campaign. I have no idea what this allegation is about. It is false." Sessions' spokesperson and his own statement only deny that he spoke with Russian officials as a campaign surrogate, but he still apparently communicated with a Russian official as a senator.

The Post report suggests that Sessions' contact with Kislyak, even as a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee at the time, was unusual. Among the 20 (of 26) members of the committee who responded to the Post, none of them met with Russia's ambassador last year.

The allegations against Sessions are the latest in a string of controversies surrounding the Trump administration's ties to Russia. Last month, former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn was forced to resign after it was revealed that he talked to Kislyak in December and may have suggested that Trump would lift sanctions against Russia—a potential violation of the Logan Act, which bans people outside the executive branch from making foreign policy on behalf of the U.S. administration. (Flynn and Trump were not in office at the time of the call.)

In response to the report, Democrats have called on Sessions to recuse himself from any investigation into Trump's ties to the Justice Department. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi called on Sessions to resign, stating, "After lying under oath to Congress about his own communications with the Russians, the attorney general must resign. Sessions is not fit to serve as the top law enforcement officer of our country and must resign. There must be an independent, bipartisan, outside commission to investigate the Trump political, personal, and financial connections to the Russians."

For more information on the growing Trump-Russia scandal, read ███'s explainer.

Title: Trump's Gun Control Proposals Face Skepticism as Washington Returns to Business as Usual

Article:

As the nation grapples with the aftermath of the Florida school shooting that left 17 dead, the push for gun law reform has gained momentum, with students who survived the tragedy leading the charge. However, as lawmakers returned to Washington this week, it appears that political realities on the Second Amendment remain as strong as ever.

President Donald Trump has promised to "turn our grief into action," pledging to outlaw bump fire stocks and to "harden" U.S. schools to protect them from shooters. He has also expressed support for "strong" background checks to prevent "sickos" from obtaining guns.

However, there is skepticism that any significant change in gun laws will be achieved in Congress, where pro-Second Amendment Republicans hold a majority. The White House is reportedly looking at expanding background checks to gun show sales and making them more efficient, as well as including private transactions.

Trump's call for raising the age that someone can buy a long gun from 18 to 21 has reportedly been put on hold, and there is little political support on Capitol Hill for the idea of returning mental institutions to address the issue of mass shootings.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has called for more action, but has given no indication that he is ready to expose senators up for re-election this year to tough votes on measures that would ban assault-style weapons. Some Republicans have signaled that hopes of raising the required age for purchasing long guns and even banning bump stocks are unlikely to be realized.

Senators Pat Toomey (R-PA) and Joe Manchin (D-WV) have attempted to forge a way forward for their bill on universal background checks, which failed to pass in 2013 after the Sandy Hook school massacre. Manchin expressed hope that the presence of a Republican in the White House could reassure some GOP lawmakers.

The White House has announced that Trump will meet with lawmakers on Wednesday to try to forge a way forward, and meetings of Republican caucus members on Tuesday will be closely watched to see whether there is any change in the political weather on guns. However, early evidence on Capitol Hill suggests it will be tough to pass anything much stronger than the Fix NICS bill, which would require states and agencies to do more to include records in the National Instant Criminal Background Check System.

Title: Hong Kong Government Fully Withdraws Extradition Bill, Protesters Call Move "Too Little, Too Late"

Article:

Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced on Wednesday that the government would fully withdraw the controversial extradition bill from the legislature, addressing one of the five demands protesters have been advocating for since June. The bill, which would have allowed the Communist Party of China to extradite individuals accused of violating communist "crimes" into the Chinese prison system, has sparked widespread fear among Hong Kong residents due to China's notorious human rights violations.

In a public address, Lam stated that the Legislative Council would fully withdraw the bill "in order to fully allay public concerns." She also acknowledged the violence that has engulfed the city, blaming both the peaceful protest movement and the police for the unrest.

"Our citizens, police, and reporters have been injured during violent incidents. There have been chaotic scenes at the airport and MTR stations; roads and tunnels have been suddenly blocked, causing delay and inconvenience to daily life," Lam said. "For many people, Hong Kong has become an unfamiliar place."

Lam also announced modifications to the membership of the Independent Police Complaints Commission, a move that addresses one of the remaining demands for an independent inquiry on police brutality. However, concerns remain that the police will exonerate themselves of human rights crimes if they conduct the investigation.

The Global Times, a Chinese regime propaganda outlet, warned that Lam's move should not be seen as a concession that could lead to a "slippery slope," and that radical forces should not have any illusion of winning ground on matters related to the "one country, two systems" principle that governs Hong Kong and China's sovereignty.

The protesters have made five demands on Hong Kong's government: a withdrawal of the extradition bill, an independent inquiry on police brutality, freedom for political prisoners, direct election of lawmakers, and an apology for labeling the June 12 protest a "riot."

Prior to Wednesday, Lam had adamantly refused to withdraw the extradition bill, stating that legislators had tabled it and declaring it "dead" in July. However, tabling a bill keeps it alive and allows lawmakers to revive it at any time.

Protest movement leaders have criticized Lam's previous statements, asserting that "dead" is not a legal term for a bill and that she gave no guarantees lawmakers would not bring it back to life.

The announcement follows the destruction of the Legislative Council floor and much of the building it uses as its headquarters. Protesters meticulously destroyed all the technology and every facility used to pass laws, but left historical documents, the building's cafeteria, and other irrelevant areas untouched.

Lam's concession comes after the publication of a bombshell report this week by Reuters, revealing audio of the chief executive saying she would like to resign from the post, but is not allowed. In the audio, Lam is heard saying, "For a chief executive to have caused this huge havoc to Hong Kong is unforgivable. It's just unforgivable."

Lam conceded on Tuesday that the audio is real, but claimed that her choice of words was taken out of context, and that she meant only that quitting was the easiest thing to do. Despite Lam admitting the audio was, indeed, of her voice, the Global Times called the Reuters report "fake," without elaborating.

Protest leaders have called Lam's withdrawal of the bill "too little and too late," insisting they will continue their struggle for freedom from China.

Title: South Korea, North Korea Agree to Dialogue and Summit Talks, as U.S. Remains Cautious Amidst North Korea's Denuclearization Pledge

Article:

In a significant development, North Korea has expressed a willingness to hold talks with the United States on denuclearization and has pledged not to use nuclear or conventional weapons against Seoul. This announcement was made by South Korea's presidential national security director, Chung Eui-yong, following his two-day visit to North Korea.

President Trump, in a tweet hours after Chung's statement, expressed cautious optimism, stating, "Possible progress being made in talks with North Korea. For the first time in many years, a serious effort is being made by all parties concerned. The World is watching and waiting!"

Chung's statement detailed that North Korea has committed to the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula and will not engage in strategic provocations such as nuclear and ballistic missile tests while dialogue continues. The two Koreas have agreed to hold summit talks in April at the border, and to establish a "hotline" communication channel to lower military tensions.

Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, however, called for countries to further isolate North Korea despite the regime's offer to discuss denuclearization. Tillerson emphasized that North Korea poses a threat to the global community through its unlawful nuclear and ballistic missile programs and proliferation activities.

The recent thaw in relations between North and South Korea can be traced back to last month's Pyeongchang Olympics, where the two Koreas held their first talks in years. North Korea sent a delegation to the Olympics, including Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, who met with South Korean President Moon Jae-in.

However, the phrase "unification" used by Kim Yo Jong in a guest book at South Korea's presidential office carries a far more sinister connotation for the Kim family and the regime. In Pyongyang's view, "unification" signifies the Kim dynasty's brutal dictatorship overcoming the South's government.

As North Korea's hard currency is expected to run dry by October, according to a South Korean lawmaker, the international community will continue to closely watch developments on the Korean Peninsula.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard and Hillary Clinton Exchange Heated Words on Social Media

Article:

In a series of tweets on Friday, Democratic presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard took aim at former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, following Clinton's suggestion that Gabbard is a "favorite of the Russians."

Clinton, the 2016 Democratic nominee, made the comment during an episode of the podcast "Campaign HQ," hosted by David Plouffe, who was the campaign manager for former President Obama's 2008 campaign. Clinton did not mention Gabbard by name, but it was clear that she was referring to the Hawaii congresswoman, who has repeatedly denied accusations of being a Russian asset.

Gabbard, a member of the Hawaii National Guard and an Iraq War veteran, responded with a series of tweets, calling Clinton the "embodiment of corruption" among the Democratic Party establishment.

"From the day I announced my candidacy, there has been a concerted campaign to destroy my reputation," Gabbard tweeted. "We wondered who was behind it and why. Now we know — it was always you."

Gabbard also challenged Clinton to "join the race directly" if she was going to attack her.

"It's now clear that this primary is between you and me. Don't cowardly hide behind your proxies. Join the race directly," Gabbard tweeted.

Gabbard's tweeted attack on Clinton left fellow Democratic 2020 candidate Sen. Cory Booker speechless. According to the RealClearPolitics polling average, Gabbard is polling at 1.2 percent nationally, making her one of the lower-tier candidates to make this week's primary debate in Ohio.

Gabbard's campaign has faced ongoing concern from political observers that her campaign is being amplified by Russian bots and online trolls. She has raised eyebrows with her anti-establishment foreign policy positions, especially her accusation that the U.S. engages in regime-change wars and her meeting with Syrian President Bashar Assad in 2017.

Title: Iran Denies Reports of Downing Civilian Plane, Invites International Investigation

Article:

In a press conference on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly in New York, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani and Iranian officials have denied reports from American and European intelligence agencies that Iran shot down Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752, which was en route from Tehran to Kyiv on January 8, 2020.

According to U.S. officials, the plane was reportedly brought down by an anti-aircraft missile battery. President Trump suggested on Thursday that the incident may have been an error, stating, "Somebody could have made a mistake on the other side."

However, Iran aviation department head Ali Abedzadeh stated at the press conference, "What is obvious for us, and what we can say with certainty, is that no missile hit the plane." Abedzadeh also invited officials from Boeing to join the investigation.

Hassan Rezaeifar, the head of the Iranian investigative team, stated that Iran would not share the aircraft's black box flight recorders until the country had completed a study of them. The team may reach out to international experts if it is unable to extract the recordings, but the investigation could take over a month to fully retrieve the black box data. After that, the investigation itself could continue for up to a year.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed that Canada intelligence believed the crash was caused by a missile strike. At least 63 Canadian citizens were on board the aircraft.

"The evidence indicates that the plane was shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile," Trudeau said on Thursday.

In total, 176 people died in the crash, mostly Iranian and Canadian citizens. While Ukraine International Airlines has yet to comment on the incident, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has said his country "will conduct a detailed and independent investigation" into the crash.

Title: Trump's Resilience in Republican Primary: A Force to Reckon With

Article:

In the ongoing race for the Republican presidential nomination, Donald Trump's rise and resilience is a unique phenomenon in modern American political history. Despite a few temporary setbacks, Trump maintains a dominant position in the Republican primary race, as demonstrated by his recent triumph in New York and his leads in the upcoming primary elections in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Rhode Island, and Connecticut.

With the New York primary results and the upcoming five states' votes, Trump is expected to secure an overwhelming share of the 267 delegates, bringing him less than 100 votes shy of the 1,237 delegates required to take the nomination outright.

Ted Cruz, despite his efforts, may struggle to catch up. Cruz could potentially win Pennsylvania, where 54 of the total 71 delegates are not bound, and where the senator is doing well in the delegate selection process. Alternatively, Cruz could win Indiana's 57 votes and Nebraska's 36. However, even with these victories and strong performances in the far West, Cruz may not be able to block Trump and win on the second ballot.

Trump's grip on the Republican primary voter is unparalleled. Despite a 75 percent negative rating among American women, there is little gender gap in his primary vote. He performs as well among Republican women as he does with Republican men.

The Republican Party's victory in the 2004 election was achieved by bringing 10 million more (largely white) voters out than in 2000. Barack Obama won in 2008 by bringing out 10 million more blacks, Latinos, and young people than in 2004. Mitt Romney lost, in part, because 10 million white voters stayed home in 2012. Trump's primary performances suggest he has the ability to get these voters back, driving Republican turnout to a level 75 percent higher than in 2012.

However, Trump faces a 10-point challenge in the general election. He runs 10 points worse among women against Hillary Clinton, is 10 points less favorable and 10 points more unfavorable than Clinton, and loses to her by 10 points in the RealClearPolitics average.

Despite these challenges, Trump's opposition to trade deals and his refusal to take super-PAC money could potentially rally voters, including those of Bernie Sanders, who have similar views on these issues. The impact of the FBI investigation into Clinton's State emails and the release of the Benghazi report remains to be seen.

In conclusion, Trump's ability to get his voters out and hold their support in the face of his terrible national general election numbers is a question mark. However, his resilience in the primary race and his vote-getting power suggest he could still emerge victorious in the general election.

Title: Reflecting on the 19-Year Anniversary of 9/11: A Nation Changed, a War Unending

Article:

September 11, 2001, remains a searing memory for many Americans, a day that marked a significant turning point in the nation's history. The images of the Twin Towers on fire, the Pentagon hit, and the horror of Flight 93 are indelible, serving as a stark reminder of the global jihad that continues to this day.

In the aftermath of the attacks, the nation was plunged into a state of shock and silence. The Houston suburbs, like many other communities, were left hushed, with roads empty and work coming to a standstill. The skies were devoid of planes, and citizens clung to their loved ones, wondering about the fate of those lost and if this was just the beginning of more attacks.

The events of 9/11 marked the beginning of a new and different kind of war, a war that Americans never asked for but answered to avoid further pain on home soil. Too much blood had been spilled in the homeland.

Since then, the landscape of America has changed. Petty insults have become a part of daily life, from the removal of shoes and travel-size toiletries to standing in line for pat-downs by security personnel who often miss obvious threats. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is a tangible reminder of the increased security measures, yet it has not stopped a single terrorist.

The threat of terrorism remains, with constant reminders in the form of attacks in cities like San Bernardino, Orlando, Nice, Paris, Ansbach, and Istanbul. Each instance, even with heightened security, elicits the same response: shock, disbelief, outrage, horror. Change social media avatars, go on living—the cycle continues.

Fifteen years later, it seems appropriate to reassess the trade-offs made in the intervening years. Questions about the effectiveness of mass surveillance, the balance between security and privacy, and the compatibility of Islamic beliefs with Western-style democracy arise. The war on terrorism, a long and ongoing conflict, has led to the creation of a vast bureaucracy, yet it seems cumbersome and inadequate in the face of continued terrorist attacks.

The question of what America should do moving forward is complex. Should the nation continue to engage in foreign conflicts, or should it withdraw and focus on securing its own borders? How do we handle massive immigration, and what happens if America withdraws or stays involved? What are the consequences of more subtle forms of terrorism, such as an Electromagnetic Pulse (EMP) attack or disruptions to the electric grid?

The war on terrorism, a war without battlefields or beachheads, has been long and difficult to sustain. Yet, the nation perseveres, fighting to protect its freedoms both within and without the Republic. The terrorists did not win on 9/11, but they have changed America, leaving the nation with a duality: attempting to retain freedom while protecting that freedom through means that infringe upon it.

In a Pentagon briefing on September 25, 2001, Douglas Waller of Time magazine reported that President George W. Bush acknowledged the challenges of sustaining a war. "Wars are easy to start," Bush said, "but they can be difficult to sustain." He has been managing expectations, pressing the case that this will be a long war against terrorism.

The war has been long, indeed. It has been a war without battlefields or beachheads. Fifteen years later, it still wages, and there are no signs of it ending. The monuments are built while the desire to forget is strong. We can't, though.

So, the country slogs forward, living with a duality: attempting to retain freedom while protecting that freedom through ways that infringe upon it. The terrorists did not win on 9/11. Yet, America is not the same. Her shiny innocence has been lost, and she faces a tireless enemy who continually tries her good nature.

Title: Ex-Boyfriend of Kavanaugh Accuser Julie Swetnick Alleges Threats and Exaggerations

Article:

In a significant development, the ex-boyfriend of Julie Swetnick, the woman who has made uncorroborated and salacious sexual assault allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, has claimed that Swetnick threatened to kill his unborn child and was known for exaggerating her stories.

Richard Vinneccy, who dated Swetnick on-and-off for seven years, made these allegations during an interview on Fox News' "The Ingraham Angle" on Monday. Vinneccy stated that Swetnick never mentioned her Kavanaugh claims to him and was known for wanting to be the center of attention.

"She was exaggerating everything. Everything that came out of her mouth was just exaggerations," Vinneccy said.

This is not the only controversy surrounding Swetnick. In a sworn statement last month, she claimed she had seen Kavanaugh "engage in abusive and physically aggressive behavior toward girls" and was a victim of a gang rape at a party where Kavanaugh and his friend Mark Judge were present. However, in an interview with NBC News, she appeared to walk back some of these claims, while standing by her claims of sexually aggressive behavior.

Swetnick's shifting and uncorroborated claims have led to questions about her credibility. NBC News has not been able to independently verify her claims, and she has struggled to provide corroborating witnesses. Swetnick provided four names to NBC News to back up her story, but one is dead, two did not respond to NBC requests, and one other said he didn't remember Swetnick and didn't think he had socialized with her.

Swetnick's ex-boyfriend's allegations add to the mounting questions about her credibility. The FBI is currently conducting a background investigation into sexual assault claims made against Kavanaugh. The agency is expected to wrap up its investigation by Friday.

Meanwhile, it was revealed this week that Swetnick was sued in 2000 by her former employer, Portland-based Webtrends, for allegedly falsifying her educational background and concocting false sexual harassment allegations. The suit, which was voluntarily dismissed by Webtrends shortly afterwards, has been called "bogus" by Swetnick's current lawyer, Michael Avenatti.

Swetnick's legal history is not limited to this case. The Associated Press reported on Sunday that Swetnick has been involved in at least six legal cases in the last 25 years. Avenatti told The Associated Press that court cases involving her have no bearing on the credibility of her claims about Kavanaugh.

The controversy surrounding Swetnick's allegations and her credibility continues to unfold as the Senate Judiciary Committee prepares to vote on Kavanaugh's nomination.

Title: Trump's Path to Republican Nomination: A Look at the Numbers

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) — The prospect of a contested Republican convention this summer may not be as likely as some political enthusiasts anticipate. While it is still possible for Donald Trump to secure the nomination before the July convention in Cleveland, his path is narrow and precarious.

Trump is the only candidate with a realistic chance of reaching the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination before the convention. His rivals, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich, can only hope to delay him.

If Cruz and Kasich are successful, political observers across the country will be treated to a convention with an uncertain outcome. However, Trump can put an end to such dreams, and he can do so without any of the 150 or so delegates who will go to the convention free to support the candidate of their choice.

Trump's path to the nomination outright on June 7 is not a prediction, but rather, a plausible scenario. To be sure, Trump will have to significantly improve his performance. He currently has 744 delegates.

New York, with 95 delegates at stake, is crucial for Trump. He starts Tuesday with a home-state advantage, and a big victory there could propel him closer to the nomination. If Trump wins a majority of the state's delegates, he could take 77 delegates on the night.

Five states hold primaries on April 26, with 172 delegates at stake: Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, and Rhode Island. Trump will need to perform well in these states to secure the remaining delegates he needs.

In all, it's a day on which Trump could claim 93 delegates. The remaining contests in May and June will determine whether Trump can clinch the nomination before the convention.

Title: NSA Director Denies Allegations of Massive Phone Data Collection in Europe, Addresses Ongoing Spying Controversy

Article:

In a heated congressional hearing on Tuesday, the head of the National Security Agency (NSA), Gen. Keith Alexander, adamantly denied recent reports that his agency is collecting millions of phone records across Europe. The hearing, which aimed to discuss proposed reforms to the NSA's bulk collection of communications under the Foreign Intelligence Security Act (FISA), was marked by allegations of spying on friendly countries' leaders and a heated exchange over the extent of such practices.

During the hearing, NSA Director Gen. Alexander stated that reports of the US gathering information on tens of millions of phone calls in France and Spain were "completely false." The comment was one of the highlights of the hearing, which took place amid an international uproar over reports last week that the NSA monitored the cellphone of German Chancellor Angela Merkel for a decade – part of a pattern of the agency eavesdropping on friendly countries' leaders.

Officials at the hearing did not deny that such spying takes place. Instead, their answers cast doubt on White House assertions that President Obama did not know the extent of the spying on Chancellor Merkel. When asked by Chairman Mike Rogers (R-MI) if the US would consider it important to get access to the communications of foreign leaders, Director of National Intelligence James Clapper responded that knowing "leadership intentions" was "one of the first things I learned in intelligence school in 1963."

When asked further if America's allies "conduct espionage on us," Mr. Clapper responded "absolutely" – before summarizing that the uproar over friends-on-friends spying reminded him of a scene from the movie "Casablanca."

"My God, there's gambling going on here," Clapper said, offering his own version of the famous line in which a policeman expresses "shock" at finding gambling in the movie's snazzy club and gambling den. "It's the same sort of thing."

As for the "false" reports of the NSA gathering millions of European phone records, General Alexander said that the data in question – part of documents divulged by Edward Snowden to European media – were actually collected by foreign intelligence agencies. Moreover, to a large extent, they were gathered outside of Europe, often in war zones of crucial security interest to the US and its European allies.

"This is not information we collected on European citizens," Alexander said, defining it instead as "information that we and our NATO allies have collected in defense of our countries and in support of military operations."

The documents Mr. Snowden provided European media were actually screenshots of data and were not the documents themselves, Alexander said. Some committee members asked why European leaders would offer such harsh judgments of US intelligence practices if their services are doing the same thing.

Some European parliamentarians and policymakers "may not have familiarity with exactly how their intelligence operations work," Clapper said, adding that officials are often unaware of "everything" their own intelligence agencies do.

The uproar over US intelligence practices overshadowed the purpose of Tuesday's hearing, which was to discuss proposed reforms to the NSA's program for bulk collection of communications under the FISA. One proposal from a bipartisan group of House and Senate members would effectively discontinue the program, while an opposing bipartisan collection of lawmakers would keep the program intact while focusing on strengthening its privacy protections.

The House Intelligence Committee's top Democrat, Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger of Maryland, said the program "allows the government to connect the dots" of brewing terrorist activities. "I shudder to think what would happen if the program were completely eliminated," he said.

But he added that "FISA must be reformed" to increase "transparency" and "privacy protections" if the government wants to "restore the public's confidence" in national intelligence activities.

NSA's Alexander said the record offers proof that the US intelligence community is getting things right. Contrasting a tally of more than 2,300 deaths overseas last year in terrorist attacks with the absence of any "mass casualty" attack in the US since 9/11, he said, "That's not by luck."

But Alexander also said the door was open to improving both the NSA's operations and its protections of civil liberties and privacy. "We're doing the right things," he said, "but that doesn't mean we shouldn't change."

Title: Ben Carson Endorses Donald Trump as Republican Presidential Nominee

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, retired neurosurgeon and former presidential candidate Ben Carson has officially endorsed Donald Trump as the Republican nominee for president. The announcement was made at Mar-a-Largo, Trump's luxury club in Palm Beach, on Friday.

Carson, who withdrew from the race last week, expressed his support for Trump during a press conference, stating, "I have found that, in talking with him, that there's a lot more alignment philosophically and spiritually than I ever thought there was."

When asked about his decision, Carson responded, "It's about 'we the people.' We need to empower the people." He further elaborated, "That is not going to be done through politics as usual, be that Republican politics as usual, or be that Democrat politics as usual."

Carson explained his endorsement of Trump as a need for an "iconoclast" who can listen and make wise decisions. He referred to Trump's ability to understand and implement policies that benefit everyone, not just specific groups.

Thursday night's GOP presidential debate saw Trump and Carson discussing education and improving schools. Reports from the Washington Post suggest that Carson and Trump met in Palm Beach earlier Thursday and reached an agreement.

Carson had reportedly been torn between Trump and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, but opted to support Trump due to a rumor circulated by the Cruz campaign ahead of the Iowa caucuses that Carson had dropped out of the race.

In a Thursday interview with Fox News Radio's "John Gibson Show," Carson was asked about joining the Trump campaign. He responded, "Let's put it this way, I'm certainly leaning [towards joining the campaign]." He added that there are "two Donald Trumps" - the one seen on television and the one he's gotten to know behind the scenes.

Carson concluded the interview by expressing his hope to bridge the gap and work towards policies that benefit all Americans, creating an equal playing field and equality of opportunity.

Title: Ross Perot, Self-made Billionaire and Former Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89

In a statement released by family spokesman James Fuller, Ross Perot, the self-made billionaire and former presidential candidate, has passed away at the age of 89 after a five-month battle with leukemia. Perot, who made his billions by founding Electronic Data Systems Corp., died early Tuesday at his home in Dallas surrounded by his family.

Perot, a native-born Texan, was seen by admirers as a patriot who served his country well before his two failed bids for the White House. In 1979, he financed a private commando raid to free two EDS employees being held in a prison in Iran. He was also a tireless advocate for Vietnam veterans.

In 1992, Perot spent more than $60 million of his own money to run against incumbent President George H.W. Bush and challenger Bill Clinton, promising to bring his business acumen to the nation's finances. He won 19 percent of the vote as a third-party candidate, pulling the largest percentage of votes for a third-party candidate since former President Theodore Roosevelt's 1912 bid.

Perot's second campaign four years later fizzled, as he gathered just 8 percent of the vote, and the Reform Party that he founded and hoped to build into a national political force began to fall apart. However, Perot's ideas on trade and deficit reduction remained part of the political landscape. He blamed both major parties for running up a huge federal budget deficit and letting American jobs to be sent to other countries. The movement of U.S. jobs to Mexico, he said, created a "giant sucking sound."

Perot continued to speak out about federal spending for many years. In 2008, he launched a website to highlight the nation's debt with a ticker that tracked the rising total, a blog, and a chart presentation.

Born in Texarkana on June 27, 1930, Perot's father was a cotton broker, and his mother was a secretary. Perot said his family survived the Depression relatively well through hard work and by managing their money carefully. Young Perot's first job was delivering papers in a poor, mostly black part of town from his pony, Miss Bee. Perot said when the newspaper tried to cut his commission, he complained to the publisher—and won. He said he learned to take problems straight to the top.

From Texarkana, Perot went to the U.S. Naval Academy even though he had never been on a ship or seen the ocean. After the Navy, Perot joined International Business Machines in 1955 and quickly became a top salesman. In his last year at IBM, he filled his sales quota for the year in January.

In 1962, with $1,000 from his wife, Margot, Perot founded Electronic Data Systems. Hardware accounted for about 80% of the computer business, Perot said, and IBM wasn't interested in the other 20%, including services. Many of the early hires at EDS were former military men, and they had to abide by Perot's strict dress code—white shirts, ties, no beards or mustaches—and long work days. Many had crew cuts, like Perot.

The company's big break came in the mid-1960s when the federal government created Medicare and Medicaid, the health programs for seniors, the disabled, and the poor. States needed help in running the programs, and EDS won contracts—starting in Texas—to handle the millions of claims. EDS first sold stock to the public in 1968, and overnight, Perot was worth $350 million. His fortune doubled and tripled as the stock price rose steadily.

In 1984, he sold control of the company to General Motors Corp. for $2.5 billion and received $700 million in a buyout. In 2008, EDS was sold to Hewlett-Packard Co. Perot went on to establish another computer-services company, Perot Systems Corp. He retired as CEO in 2000 and was succeeded by his son, Ross Perot Jr. In 2009, Dell Inc. bought Perot Systems.

In September 2011, Forbes magazine estimated Perot's wealth at $3.5 billion and ranked him No. 91 on its list of richest Americans. Perot's legacy will be remembered as a self-made billionaire who made a significant impact on American politics and business.

Title: Trump Threatens to Close Southern Border, Cut Aid, and Alter Trade Relations with Mexico Over Border Wall Funding

Article:

In a series of tweets on Friday, President Donald Trump threatened to close the southern border entirely if Congress does not agree to fund his proposed border wall. The tweets came as the ongoing government shutdown, now in its second week, continues to stalemate over funding for the wall.

Trump's tweets demanded $5 billion for the border wall, but Democrats have offered $1.3 billion for general border security. With both sides refusing to budge, there are no signs of the impasse ending anytime soon. One member of the House Republican leadership told reporters on Thursday that a resolution may not emerge until the new year.

In addition to renewing his demands for the wall, Trump threatened numerous consequences in the absence of the funding. He suggested pulling back on the recently renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which now goes by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA).

"The United States loses soooo much money on Trade with Mexico under NAFTA, over 75 Billion Dollars a year (not including Drug Money which would be many times that amount), that I would consider closing the Southern Border a 'profit making operation,'" Trump tweeted.

Trump also threatened to terminate aid to Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador, which he said are doing "nothing for the United States but taking our money." He referred to reports that another caravan of migrants hoping to reach the U.S. is planning to leave Honduras in January.

"Word is that a new Caravan is forming in Honduras and they are doing nothing about it. We will be cutting off all aid to these 3 countries - taking advantage of U.S. for years!" Trump said.

Trump has previously threatened to shut down the border and cut aid to countries that do not assist in stopping caravans. However, he took no action following those threats. Earlier this month, the U.S. pledged a total of $10.6 billion in aid and investment for Central America and southern Mexico as part of a push to promote better security and job opportunities to reduce emigration to the U.S.

A cut-off of trade relations with Mexico could also risk a new agreement that DHS Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen announced this month, which calls for immigrants claiming asylum in the U.S. to be returned to Mexico as their cases are processed.

Mick Mulvaney, Trump's incoming acting chief of staff, claimed on "Fox & Friends" on Friday that Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer is interested in a deal but Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi is preventing it. He alleged that Democrats are not negotiating because Pelosi is waiting until she secures the speakership.

However, Pelosi has denied claims that Democrats have not provided a counteroffer.

"Democrats have offered Republicans three options to re-open government that all include funding for strong, sensible, and effective border security - but not the President's immoral, ineffective, and expensive wall," said Drew Hammill, Pelosi's deputy chief of staff. "With the House Majority, Democrats will act swiftly to end the Trump Shutdown, and will fight for a strategic, robust national security policy, including strong and smart border security, and strong support for our servicemembers and veterans."

Title: House Oversight Committee Accuses President Trump of Obstruction as He Orders Federal Employees to Ignore Congressional Subpoenas

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Democratic chairman of the U.S. House Oversight Committee on Wednesday accused President Donald Trump of a "precedent-setting and growing pattern of obstruction" after he ordered federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations.

The Republican president has directed officials not to obey legal requests from the Democratic-led House of Representatives, which is carrying out multiple investigations of his administration, including his tax returns, White House security clearances, and the probe of Russian interference in U.S. politics.

Representative Elijah Cummings, who chairs the House Oversight Committee, said in a statement that Trump and Attorney General William Barr are "openly ordering federal employees to ignore congressional subpoenas and simply not show up - without any assertion of a valid legal privilege."

Cummings warned federal employees to "think very carefully about their own legal interests" in refusing to comply with the panel's requests. The president has vowed to resist every subpoena from House Democrats investigating his administration and to fight any effort by them to impeach him.

Trump filed a lawsuit earlier this week to prevent material from being turned over to lawmakers, and on Wednesday, the Justice Department rebuffed a House committee's request for an interview with an official involved in the administration's decision to put a citizenship question on the 2020 census.

The department said John Gore, a deputy assistant attorney general in the Civil Rights Division, would not participate in a deposition scheduled for Thursday if he could not have a Justice Department lawyer at his side. The committee had offered to allow a lawyer to sit in a different room.

Cummings said the committee would gather to hear Gore's deposition on Thursday and suggested he "should be well aware of his constitutional, legal, and ethical obligations to comply with a duly authorized subpoena from Congress."

A Department of Justice (DOJ) official said the committee had provided "no legitimate or constitutional basis for excluding a DOJ lawyer from assisting at the deposition."

"If a DOJ lawyer may appear to protect privileged subjects, then the Attorney General will allow the deposition to go forward," the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Trump has promised to fight all the way to the Supreme Court against any effort by congressional Democrats to impeach him, even though the U.S. Constitution gives Congress complete authority over the impeachment process. Under the Constitution, Congress is a co-equal branch of government alongside the executive branch and the judiciary.

But Trump has increasingly accused Democrats of conducting the Russia investigation for purely political purposes ahead of the 2020 election. He has stepped up those accusations since the release of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on his probe into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Democrats remain divided on whether to proceed with an impeachment of Trump after the Russia inquiry. Trump defiantly proclaimed on Twitter that the investigation "didn't lay a glove on me."

In an opinion piece in the Washington Post, Hillary Clinton, the Democrat whom Trump defeated in 2016, urged members of both parties to follow the facts, whether they lead to "the eventual filing of articles of impeachment, or not."

"Either way, the nation's interests will be best served by putting party and political considerations aside and being deliberate, fair, and fearless," Clinton wrote.

Mueller's findings, released in a redacted report last week, detailed how Trump often tried to impede the inquiry but it stopped short of concluding he had committed the crime of obstruction of justice. The report said Congress could address whether the president violated the law.

Mueller separately found insufficient evidence to conclude that Trump's campaign engaged in a criminal conspiracy with Russia in the 2016 presidential race.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democratic leaders have remained cautious over launching impeachment proceedings against Trump ahead of the 2020 election, although they have left the door open to such action. Others in the party's more liberal wing have demanded impeachment proceedings.

But Democrats have vowed to move ahead full steam with their investigations of Trump, which could produce more evidence that could be used in an impeachment proceeding.

The Constitution empowers Congress to remove a president from office for "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors." The House is given the power to impeach a president - bring formal charges - and the Senate then convenes a trial, with the senators as jurors. A two-thirds vote is needed to convict a president and remove him from office.

The Constitution gives no role to the Supreme Court in impeachment, though it does assign the chief justice the task of presiding over the Senate trial. Conservative John Roberts currently serves as chief justice.

That would not preclude Trump from proceeding with litigation to tie up the issue in the courts, despite Supreme Court precedent upholding congressional impeachment power. In 1993, the nation's top court ruled 9-0 in a case involving an impeached U.S. judge that the judiciary has no role in the impeachment process.

Laurence Tribe, a constitutional law professor at Harvard who has been critical of Trump, said the U.S. founding fathers had considered but ultimately scrapped the idea of allowing the Supreme Court to have any role in the impeachment process.

"Not even a SCOTUS filled with Trump appointees would get in the way of the House or Senate," Tribe said in a series of tweets on Wednesday.

Title: House Democrats Unveil Report Detailing Alleged Illegal Efforts to Sell Nuclear Technology to Saudi Arabia

Article:

In a new report released on Tuesday, the House Oversight and Reform Committee has revealed disturbing details about a secretive attempt by top Trump administration officials to sell sensitive nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia, potentially in violation of ethics statutes.

The report, accompanied by a tranche of internal White House emails, outlines a plan spearheaded by former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn to export technology for approximately 40 nuclear power plants to Saudi Arabia. The scheme, previously known through reporting by the Wall Street Journal and others, is now provided with more context and insight into the behind-the-scenes maneuvering to push the proposal forward.

The initiative was part of a broader Middle East economic development plan that Flynn began developing before President Trump's inauguration, while he was serving as an adviser to Trump's campaign and transition team. During this time, Flynn was also working as an adviser for a private company called IP3 International, a firm run by retired US military generals with a clear financial interest in exporting US nuclear energy technology to Saudi Arabia.

Once Trump was inaugurated, Flynn, along with longtime Trump associate Thomas Barrack, worked with other senior officials in the new Trump administration to make the plan a reality. On January 27, 2017, just seven days after the inauguration, several of the retired generals from IP3 visited the White House to discuss the nuclear plan for Saudi Arabia with Derek Harvey, a senior staffer on Trump's National Security Council at the time.

According to the House report, immediately after the meeting, Harvey directed the NSC staff to add information about IP3's "plan for 40 nuclear power plants" to the briefing package for President Trump's call with Saudi Arabia's King Salman.

As of now, it appears the proposal is still under consideration, but there is no indication one way or the other that the president will agree to it. At a minimum, the White House is still in discussions to sell nuclear equipment to Saudi Arabia despite fierce Democratic opposition.

The proposed nuclear deal, on the surface, seems beneficial: an American business stands to make significant profits—possibly billions of dollars—by selling nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia, while Riyadh would gain a new energy source to power its economy. However, the problem lies in the potential illegality of the scheme.

For the US to sell nuclear technology to a foreign country, it must sign what's known as a "123 agreement." This agreement, based on Section 123 of the 1954 US Atomic Energy Act, establishes the criteria for the US to sell nuclear materials to other countries. If a country wants to buy nuclear equipment from the US—for example, a nuclear reactor—it must meet nine conditions, including a guarantee that it will not use the technology to make nuclear weapons. Congress does not have to approve the sale.

However, according to the Democrats' report, Harvey, the senior National Security Council staffer (who is also a close Flynn ally), ignored these requirements and insisted that the decision to transfer nuclear technology to Saudi Arabia had already been made. If true, this means Harvey attempted to make the deal happen without arranging for Saudi Arabia to sign the 123 agreement, which could potentially allow Riyadh to pursue a nuclear weapon with US-sold equipment in the future.

Furthermore, there is the issue of Michael Flynn's personal involvement in the deal. Flynn, who previously consulted for IP3, may have skirted ethics rules, according to "whistleblowers" who spoke with House Democrats. White House ethics officials reportedly brought these concerns to light.

According to the report, one senior political official felt Harvey's proposal was "not a business plan," but rather "a scheme for these generals to make some money." This official then added, "Okay, you know we can not do this."

Clearly, their warnings were ignored—which may be why the whistleblowers spoke to congressional Democrats in the first place.

The main story here is Democrats stepping up their oversight of Trump's foreign policy. As I stated earlier, the broad outlines of this scheme have already been known for a while now, thanks to reporting from the Wall Street Journal and others.

Flynn's history of pushing specific policies while being on the payroll of the primary beneficiaries of said policies is also well-documented. Barrack, the longtime Trump associate who worked with Flynn to make the Saudi nuclear deal happen, has been vocal about his support for Saudi Arabia.

However, armed with insider information and internal documents from the whistleblowers, House Democrats were able to put together a report that fills in many of the gaps and sheds new light on how this Saudi nuclear deal went from being an idea cooked up by Flynn and a few retired generals to a serious policy being pursued at the highest levels of the White House.

This is exactly what Democrats promised to do when they took the House last November. Democratic Congress members and staffers told me they would oversee every aspect of Trump's foreign policy, from his use of the military to his foreign connections.

If the report didn't come out, it's entirely possible that the White House would have an easier time signing the nuclear deal with Saudi Arabia. That outcome is now in doubt, and any effort to make an agreement will likely be met with stiff resistance from Democrats in Congress.

That means Trump's ability to conduct global affairs as he wishes is now curtailed. Tuesday's report is at least a warning shot—but it could be a sign of bigger things to come.

Title: Florida Halts Publication of Real-Time Coronavirus Death Data Compiled by Medical Examiners

Article:

In a move that has raised concerns among transparency advocates, Florida health officials have ceased publishing real-time coronavirus death data reported by medical examiners. The decision comes after the data showed a higher number of fatalities than the official state total, as reported by The Tampa Bay Times.

The last nine days have seen the absence of lists compiled by the state Medical Examiners Commission. The halt in updates followed The Tampa Bay Times' report that the medical examiners' death count was approximately 10% higher than the number reported by the Florida Department of Health.

Dr. Stephen Nelson, who heads the commission, told the outlet that the change in policy was enacted after state health officials intervened. Nelson stated that the officials plan to redact causes of deaths and descriptions of cases from the data, rendering the lists "meaningless."

"This is no different than any other public record we deal with," Nelson added. "It's paid for by taxpayer dollars, and the taxpayers have a right to know."

The lists have been made public since medical examiners began compiling them in 1992. Paul Petrino, who runs the Palm Beach County medical examiner's office, told The Times that county lawyers instructed him to stop releasing the numbers last week.

"I was actually taken aback when they called us," Petrino said, adding that the data was important to make public so that individuals have accurate information about the health crisis. "I'd hate to see anything hinder that."

The health department told The Times that it "participated in conference calls" with law enforcement officials to express "privacy concerns for the individuals that passed away related to COVID-19."

The request came after the health department last month tried to convince the Miami-Dade County medical examiner's office to block access to death records, according to The Miami Herald. The county released the data, anyway.

The health department also refused to release information about infections in nursing homes until news outlets sued for the information.

"It's just shocking to me the level of interference," Barbara Petersen of the First Amendment Foundation told The Times.

A spokesperson for the health department in Hillsborough County argued that the discrepancies in the state's numbers could be due to a lag in reporting. Florida also excludes travelers and seasonal residents who died in the state, even though medical examiners do include them.

The efforts to keep public health information under wraps come as Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, moved to reopen parts of the state's economy after he delayed issuing a stay-at-home order earlier in the outbreak. DeSantis on Wednesday announced the plan to reopen, as the state saw its largest spike in coronavirus deaths since the pandemic began.

Florida's Democratic congressional delegation wrote a letter to DeSantis last week, questioning the "inconsistencies between COVID-19 death tracking methods used by the Florida Department of Health and county medical examiners." They called for a "detailed explanation of the public health justification" for excluding nonresidents from the state's death count.

Title: The Evolution of "Me Too" and the Current Controversy Surrounding Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh

Article:

In a stark contrast to its origins eight decades ago, the phrase "Me Too" has taken on a new meaning in today's society. Originally coined to describe a wave of Republican politicians aligning with the policies of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the term now stands as a symbol of a movement that aims to address sexual assault and harassment.

The movement, which has toppled television personalities, movie moguls, and politicians, has set its sights on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. The allegations against Kavanaugh by Christine Blasey Ford have sparked a heated debate, with some questioning the veracity of her claims and others insisting that the allegations must be believed.

Ford's story, which conflicts with that of the man she names as an eyewitness and the notes taken by her therapist, lacks specific details such as the approximate date and precise location of the alleged assault. Her history of supporting left-wing causes has led some to question her motives.

The call for belief, however, is strong. Senator Mazie Hirono declared, "Women like Dr. Ford, who bravely come forward, need to be heard, but they need to be believed." Hillary Clinton echoed this sentiment, stating, "You have the right to be believed."

The movement's fervor has not only affected those accused of misconduct but also those perceived as insufficiently supportive of the movement. Last week, The Tonight Show disinvited comedian Norm Macdonald from its studios, despite no accusations of misbehavior involving women. Macdonald's comments expressing support for the slowing of the #MeToo movement sparked backlash, validating his opinion while simultaneously contradicting it.

Similarly, editor Ian Buruma published an essay by Jian Ghomeshi, an Iranian-Canadian talk show host accused of sexual assault, in the New York Review of Books. Buruma's decision to publish the essay led to his resignation after university presses threatened a boycott.

The reluctance to come forward with allegations of sexual harassment and assault is understandable, given the often he said-she said nature of such claims. This warrants tolerance for the alleged victims, not the stripping of the accused of their rights. Due process, the presumption of innocence, and the right to confront one's accuser are principles that appear to be at odds with the #MeToo movement.

The movement, which has been credited with reorienting the behavior of powerful men, has entered a stage reminiscent of the Reign of Terror. As the movement continues to evolve, it remains to be seen whether it can correct the harm it was intended to address without also infringing on fundamental rights such as freedom of speech and due process.

Title: Global Powers Condemn Trump's Auto Tariff Investigation, Fear Trade Disruption

Article:

In a move that has sparked global concern, the Trump administration announced on Thursday its decision to launch an investigation into the potential imposition of tariffs on automotive imports, citing national security grounds. The move is seen as a negotiating tactic in the stalled talks with Canada and Mexico over the North American Free Trade Agreement.

The United States is the largest importer of passenger vehicles and light trucks, with Mexico being the top exporter, followed by Japan, Canada, Germany, and South Korea, according to the Department of Commerce. Japan, which accounts for about 40 percent of U.S. vehicle imports, has expressed its concern over the potential trade measures.

Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry, Hiroshige Seko, stated that such a measure would be "an extremely far-reaching trade sanction that would put the global market into turmoil." Germany's association of industry groups also voiced their opposition, describing auto tariffs as a "provocation" and "another nasty blow to our economic relations" with the United States. The European Union executive also stated that the move would be against the rules of global trade.

In Beijing, Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao Feng expressed similar concerns, stating that abusing national security provisions would "undermine the multilateral trade system and disrupt the order of international trade." China, a relatively minor player in the U.S. auto import market, has expressed its intention to closely monitor the progress of the U.S. investigation and to defend its legitimate rights and interests.

Japanese and European automakers have not issued individual comments, but some have referred to Global Automakers, an industry group of international automakers. The group's Chief Executive, John Bozzella, stated that the move would merely hurt American consumers, as it would lead to fewer choices and higher prices for cars and trucks in America.

Last week, Japan went to the World Trade Organization to warn of possible retaliation for tariffs on steel and aluminum, which Trump imposed in March. Japan is the only major U.S. ally that was not granted a temporary exemption from the tariffs. Japan estimates these tariffs will cost it about 50 billion yen (approximately $450 million) a year.

China, while a relatively minor player in the U.S. auto import market, is eager to expand its car industry abroad. In auto parts exports to the U.S., China was ranked second last year. A person familiar with the discussions has suggested that the president has proposed new tariffs of 20 to 25 percent on automobile imports.

Critics fear that other countries may retaliate with trade sanctions of their own and question the effectiveness of the move given the lengthy review required and the legal challenges ahead.

Title: Senate Rules Committee's Statement on Press Access Sparks Controversy Among Capitol Hill Journalists

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Senate Rules Committee has sparked controversy among Capitol Hill journalists after issuing a statement on Tuesday, stating that there have been no changes to the existing rules governing press coverage on the Senate side of the Capitol complex. The statement followed a brief outcry from television reporters who were informed that they could no longer conduct on-camera interviews with lawmakers without permission from the Senate Rules Committee.

The committee's statement, however, did acknowledge that they have been working with press galleries to "ensure compliance with existing rules" to maintain a "safe environment" for everyone. This "safety" justification has been a topic of discussion among Capitol Hill journalists, as the number of reporters on the Hill has reportedly doubled under the Trump administration.

Veteran reporters have estimated that there are about double the number of reporters on the Hill on average legislative days compared to previous administrations. The Senate subway cars, where reporters huddle upon arrival from the Russell, Hart, and Dirksen office buildings, serve as a crowded platform. As key senators emerge from the cars, they are met with 20 or 30 microphones jammed into their faces.

The moving press horde ascends a flight of stairs and proceeds another 50 feet or so until the senators can escape into the members-only elevator. Once the senators reach the second floor, where the Senate chamber is, they will meet the same scene from reporters stationed there, before escaping into the chamber or a private room.

Senators, who tend to be very old, are often surrounded by reporters due to their influential positions. For instance, Sen. Orrin Hatch, who is 83, is often surrounded by 3 to 4 million reporters since he runs the committee with health care and tax reform jurisdiction. The concern is that someone could trip, fall into Hatch, and potentially cause harm.

The increased number of reporters on the Hill is due to the significant amount of news that is being generated from the Hill. The government is currently unified under one party for the first time in several Congresses, and it is working to achieve long-standing ideological goals. The head of the unified government is President Donald Trump, who is known for his unconventional style and questionable grasp of facts.

The FBI and two select congressional committees are also conducting investigations into Russian interference in the election. The increased number of reporters on the Hill is a direct response to the increased amount of news coming from the Hill.

While the majority of these reporters are not asking questions that Republican lawmakers are thrilled to answer, they are posing questions that are relevant and important to the public. Questions such as, "Sen. Bob Corker, what do you think of Trump's tweets this morning?" or "Sen. Jeff Flake, will you support a bill that ends the Medicaid expansion in your state?" or "Do you think that it was appropriate for the president to issue a veiled threat to the FBI director and then fire him?"

If senators are truly concerned about the size of reporter mobs and their safety, they could be more forthcoming with information about their policies, perhaps through regular press conferences. This would reduce the need for reporters to be creative in their methods of obtaining information.

Until that day comes, let's be careful not to trip Sen. Orrin Hatch, or any other senator for that matter. The access that Capitol Hill journalists enjoy is a crucial check on power, and any restriction on press access would impede this check.

Title: Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal Urges GOP to "Stop Being the Stupid Party" in Call for Change

Article:

In a keynote address at the Republican National Committee's winter meeting on Thursday, Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal called on the Republican Party to "stop being the stupid party." The GOP, according to Jindal, does not need to change its values but may need to change "just about everything else we are doing."

Jindal, who is often mentioned as a potential 2016 presidential contender, emphasized the need for the GOP to shift its focus from Capitol Hill number crunching to "the place where conservatism thrives -- in the real world beyond the Washington Beltway."

The call for change comes as Republican leaders have promised to release a report in March, titled the "Growth and Opportunity Project," outlining recommendations on party rules and messaging designed to appeal to a rapidly changing American electorate. The report aims to address the GOP's struggles in reaching out to minority and women voters, who largely supported President Barack Obama in the November election.

Republican strategist Sally Bradshaw, who is part of a team appointed by RNC Chairman Reince Priebus to craft the report, stated, "I think you're going to see a very renewed, aggressive effort by this party to put on a different face." Bradshaw added, "We are going to go into areas that we do not go into and see folks that we do not see."

The 2012 presidential nominee, Mitt Romney, faced criticism for his stance on immigration and women's issues, which were seen as alienating to Hispanic voters and women, respectively. Romney's support for a border fence and "self-deportation" of illegal immigrants, as well as down-ticket candidates' backing of new abortion laws and Todd Akin's controversial comments about "legitimate rape," were among the factors that contributed to the GOP's losses.

GOP strategist Ari Fleischer suggested that the party could learn from Democrats on messaging, stating, "Republicans talk policy and Democrats talk people. Republicans can learn a little bit from Democrats on how to make those people connections with our policies."

When asked about his own presidential aspirations for 2016, Jindal declined to comment, stating, "Any Republican that's thinking about talking about running for president in 2016 needs to get his head examined. We've got a lot of work to do."

Jindal urged conservatives to focus on connecting with voters across the nation rather than fighting with Democrats on the size of government in Washington. He criticized the GOP's obsession with government bookkeeping, stating, "We seem to have an obsession with government bookkeeping. This is a rigged game, and it is the wrong game for us to play."

The call for change comes as the House of Representatives passed a bill on Wednesday to permit the government to borrow enough money to avoid a first-time default for at least four months. The bill was passed on a bipartisan basis, with majority Republicans backing away from their previous demand that any increase in the government's borrowing cap be paired with an equivalent level of spending cuts.

Jindal's blunt remarks follow criticism from another high-profile Republican, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who publicly blasted GOP leadership on Capitol Hill over their response to Superstorm Sandy relief efforts. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested that House Republicans could use hearings to expose waste and promote better ideas.

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Overturns Alabama Redistricting Plan, Deems District Court Ruling on Redistricting as Legally Erroneous

Article:

In a 5-4 decision, the U.S. Supreme Court has overturned a district court ruling that upheld Alabama's redistricting plan, which was accused of overloading some districts with black Democratic voters. The high court found the lower court's ruling to be legally erroneous.

Justice Stephen Breyer, who delivered the opinion, was joined by the court's other liberal justices, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Sonia Sotomayor, and Elena Kagan, as well as the swing vote, Justice Anthony Kennedy. The court's conservatives, including Chief Justice John Roberts, Antonin Scalia, Samuel Alito, and Clarence Thomas, dissented. Thomas wrote a separate dissent.

As reported by NPR's Nina Totenberg last November, the high court was asked to decide whether a 2010 state legislative redistricting in Alabama overloaded some districts with black Democrats on the basis of race or party.

In 2000, Democrats controlled the state Legislature and the redistricting process. They used their power to create districts with black majorities under the Voting Rights Act, while at the same time putting enough reliably Democratic black voters into majority white districts so that white Democratic candidates could build black-white coalitions and have a chance of winning. By 2010, Republicans controlled the Legislature, and they set about consolidating the black vote into existing majority-black districts. Under the plan, about one-sixth of all eligible black voters were moved from majority white state Senate districts to majority-black districts. The result was that in some of those districts, the black majority increased to over 70 percent. At the same time, the majority white districts got whiter, and more safely Republican.

The redistricting came after the 2010 census showed population shifts that made some existing districts way too big in population terms, and others too small. The Republicans tried to equalize the size of the districts. They also tried to maintain the same number of majority-black districts, contending that under the Voting Rights Act, a simple majority of black voters in those districts was not enough. Democrats disagree and contend that the GOP plan calls for unconstitutional racial quotas.

According to The Associated Press, Justice Breyer said the lower court should have reviewed claims of racial gerrymandering on a district-by-district level, not just statewide. He also said the court did not apply the right test when it found that race was not the primary motivating factor.

State officials say they had no choice but to concentrate black voters in some districts, making neighboring seats more white and apt to elect Republicans. The case is expected to be sent back to the lower court for further review.

Title: GOP Divide Threatens Bipartisan Efforts on Comprehensive Immigration Reform

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2016 election, there appears to be a shift in the Republican Party's stance on immigration, with a potential for a bipartisan deal. However, a significant hurdle looms: disagreement among Republicans on the approach to reform.

Some Republicans advocate for piecemeal reform, focusing on popular issues while deferring contentious matters, such as a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, for later consideration. Others, in alignment with Democrats, argue that a comprehensive deal is necessary to address the issue effectively.

The rifts that existed prior to the election persist, providing little evidence, at this early stage, that a deal will materialize as promising as it seemed on November 7.

"Doing a comprehensive bill is a big mistake," said Rep. Raul Labrador (R-Idaho). "What you end up having is a bill that nobody likes. Everybody hates one piece of it. It's a way to actually avoid doing what we need to do to solve the immigration problem."

Republicans favoring a piece-by-piece approach argue that starting with politically palatable issues could generate bipartisan momentum for a broader overhaul. They also point to the frustration generated by large legislative efforts such as the Affordable Care Act and the Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

"There's going to be a natural desire to try to pair things up [on immigration]," said Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas), the incoming Senate minority whip. "But at some point, the bill gets so big and cumbersome that I think by virtue of the size alone, that that makes it harder to pass."

The general outlines of a comprehensive package are clear. It would encompass provisions on border security and law enforcement, reforms to the legal immigration system, and a solution for the undocumented immigrants residing in the United States.

However, it is the last point that Democrats fear would be neglected if Congress dismantles immigration reform. A pathway to citizenship is the one thing Democrats and immigration advocates will insist on, but it is certain to encounter the strongest GOP resistance.

"That is probably the part of immigration reform that needs the greatest reform," said Rep. Charles Gonzalez (D-Texas), the outgoing chairman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. "That's why I've never really understood that people really believe that this piecemeal thing is going to get us anywhere."

"Why only half fix the problem?" added California Rep. Xavier Becerra, the incoming House Democratic Caucus chairman. "Let's go ahead and fix the whole thing. If you've got a machine that's not working well, you're not going to fix just half of it and have it still not work well, let's go ahead and fix it right."

Title: "Fiscal Slope: Turning the 'Cliff' into a 'Bunny Slope' for a Gradual Budget Adjustment"

Article:

In the ongoing debate surrounding the so-called "fiscal cliff," it is crucial to understand that the situation is not as dire as some may portray. Rather than a cliff, the fiscal challenges facing the U.S. economy can be more accurately described as a slope.

While the potential tax increases and spending cuts, with the exception of the payroll tax increase and extended unemployment benefits, are not expected to take effect on Jan. 1, 2013, or Feb. 1, 2013, if a budget deal isn't reached by those dates, the "dramatic impact" on the economy of a failure to reach a deal is largely exaggerated.

If President Barack Obama and Capitol Hill lawmakers remain rational and dispassionate, they can mitigate the impact of the fiscal slope by turning it into a smaller or "bunny slope," to borrow a skiing metaphor. Congressional leaders can lessen the impact of the budget deal by spreading the tax increases and spending cuts out over a longer period.

To achieve this, a four-part plan, or "bunny slope," is proposed:

1. Instead of letting all of the 2001-2003 Bush income tax cuts on families with income over $250,000 per year and individuals over $200,000 expire, have one-half the income tax cuts expire on Jan. 1, 2013, and the second half expire on Jan. 1, 2014.
2. Elongate sequestration, the roughly $100 billion in automatic spending cuts - half from the Department of Defense, half from non-defense programs – to three years. In 2013, cut $20 billion from DOD and $20 billion from non-defense programs, and cut the same amount in 2014 and 2015.
3. Increase the payroll tax that funds Social Security to its normal rate, 6.2 percent, from 4.2 percent, over two years: to 5.2 percent in 2013, and to 6.2 percent in 2014.
4. Let business expense tax write-offs, and other business tax provisions, expire over two years: half in 2013, and half in 2014.

These tax and spending changes would cut the budget deficit by an equal amount - about $148 billion - in both 2013 and 2014, which would decrease the projected budget deficit to $980 billion in 2013, and $832 billion in 2014.

Further, assuming tax or spending policies remain the same after 2014, and the U.S. economy grows at a 3.0 percent rate, the budget deficit should decline to about $652 billion in 2015, $452 billion in 2016, and $230 billion in 2017.

In 2017, the $230 billion budget deficit will occur in a roughly $3.9 trillion U.S. budget – one in which the net interest payment on the national debt will be about $350 billion to $380 billion.

In other words, by deploying merely the "bunny slope" plan of gradual tax increases and spending cuts, the non-debt-service portion of the U.S. budget will be balanced by the end of 2017.

Therefore, investors, and typical Americans, should not agonize over the current budget talks. The so-called fiscal cliff is really a fiscal slope, and the slope that exists can be converted into a bunny slope - further mitigating any GDP impact - so long as Obama and Congress remain rational and dispassionate. The two parties need to meet in a room and not return until a budget deal is reached. And when the budget deal is reached, the American people, and probably the late, great LBJ, as well, will be very proud.

Title: Trump's Proposed Tariffs on Mexican Goods: Implications for U.S. Economy and Immigration Policy

The United States is considering a new tariff on Mexican goods, which would add to the existing tariffs imposed by President Trump on aluminum and steel imports, as well as Chinese imports. The potential 25% tariff could result in an additional $87 billion annually to the current $19 billion in Trump tariffs collected so far.

If implemented, Mexico is expected to retaliate with counter-tariffs, which could significantly impact sectors such as American agriculture. Just two weeks ago, tariffs on Mexican aluminum and steel were lifted, and in return, Mexico removed tariffs on American farm goods. This brief respite may prove short-lived, as farmers may once again need to explore new markets.

The question remains whether the potential benefits of this tariff outweigh the economic pain for American consumers. President Trump is employing tariffs as a means to pressure Mexico into strengthening border control measures. While the cost of the tariff would be borne by Americans, the Mexican economy could also experience a loss in sales to the United States.

However, it is important to note that a significant portion of the immigrants attempting to cross the southern border are fleeing issues in Central America that are largely beyond the control of the Mexican government. Furthermore, while President Trump often refers to all immigrants as illegal, many are exercising a legal right to seek asylum.

Historically, past administrations have sought cooperation from Mexico on immigration matters without disrupting economic relations between the two countries. President Trump's decision to intertwine the two issues risks disrupting both economies, as the manufacturing sectors in Mexico and the United States are closely interconnected. According to Deutsche Bank, about two-thirds of trade between the countries is between factories owned by the same company.

Title: Sen. Amy Klobuchar Withdraws from Vice Presidential Consideration, Advocates for a Woman of Color
