In a surprising turn of events, Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) announced on Thursday that she is withdrawing her name from consideration as Joe Biden's running mate. In a statement, Klobuchar expressed her belief that a woman of color should be chosen as the vice-presidential nominee.

Klobuchar, who had been a strong contender for the position, had been a consistent performer in the Democratic primary debates and had garnered support from various demographics, particularly in the Midwest. However, her record as a prosecutor has been a point of contention among progressive activists, and her perceived lack of appeal among African-American voters has been a topic of discussion in political circles.

The decision by Klobuchar to step aside from the vice-presidential race comes at a time when the Democratic Party is grappling with the ongoing Black Lives Matter movement and the need for a more diverse ticket. Some political observers suggest that Klobuchar may have seen the writing on the wall, with graffiti from Black Lives Matter activists declaring "Don't pick Amy Klobuchar" in some cities.

If a Biden administration comes to pass, it is possible that Klobuchar could be offered a prestigious cabinet post or other high-level position. In the event of a Biden victory, Klobuchar would have played a significant role in the primary and in the running-mate selection process, putting her personal ambitions aside to support the party's nominee.

Regardless of the outcome of the November election, Klobuchar's decision to withdraw from the vice-presidential race will likely be seen as a strategic move that positions her for future opportunities within the Democratic Party.

Title: New Poll Shows Disapproval of President Trump's Job Performance at 60%, Highest in Washington Post-ABC News Polling

Article:

A new poll conducted by The Washington Post and ABC News has shown that 60% of Americans disapprove of President Donald Trump's job performance, marking a new high in polling conducted by the outlet. The poll, released on Friday, was conducted just days after special counsel Robert Mueller delivered a series of blows to the Trump administration in federal court.

The poll, which was conducted last week, found that only 36% of Americans approve of Trump's job performance. In the previous Washington Post-ABC News poll, conducted in April, Trump's approval rating was 40% and his disapproval rating was 56%.

The poll also found that most Americans would oppose Trump granting a pardon to former associate Paul Manafort, with 66% of respondents saying they were against a pardon. Only 18% said they would support a pardon.

Trump has recently focused negative attention on Attorney General Jeff Sessions, whom Trump has blamed for Mueller's investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 campaign. In an interview with Fox News' "Fox & Friends," the president criticized Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia probe and for failing to seize control of the Justice Department. However, a majority of Americans side with Sessions, with 62% saying they are on his side. A slightly larger portion, 64%, said Trump should not fire Sessions.

Special counsel Robert Mueller saw similar positive percentages, with 63% of those polled supporting Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, and 29% saying they oppose it. Further, 53% of respondents said they think Trump tried to interfere in Mueller's investigation in a way that "amounts to obstruction of justice," while 35% said he did not try to interfere.

A similar portion of survey respondents, 61%, said they believe it would be a crime if Trump directed Michael Cohen to make hush-money payments to two women who say they had affairs with Trump during the 2016 election. Cohen pleaded guilty to making payments of that nature, violating campaign-finance laws at the "direction of a candidate for federal office," meaning Trump.

However, when it comes to the economy, Americans were more favorable in their evaluations of the president. Forty-five percent of those polled said they approve of Trump's handling of the economy, while 47% said they disapprove.

The poll, which included a sample of 1,003 adults, was conducted from Aug. 26 to Aug. 29 via landlines and cellphones. The poll's margin of error was plus-or-minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Seven Potential Inflection Points That Could Tip the 2012 Presidential Election

Article:

As the 2012 presidential race between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney remains a tight one, with the Supreme Court's health care ruling no longer a significant factor, the campaign has entered a phase of relative stability. In a series of national polls, the race is a close 3-percentage-point contest, with Obama slightly ahead of Romney.

With both candidates running cautious campaigns, the race is unlikely to be significantly altered by any one event. Steve Murphy, a Democratic strategist, notes, "It didn't take long for the race to get locked in. There's no reason to think that it won't stay locked in."

The following are seven potential inflection points that could shift the narrative of the campaign:

1. Debate Performances: The upcoming debates between Obama and Romney could significantly impact the race, as both candidates have the opportunity to present their visions for the future and address key policy issues.

2. Unemployment Numbers: The state of the economy, particularly the unemployment rate, remains a significant concern for voters. Any significant changes in the unemployment rate could impact the race.

3. Credit Downgrading: The ongoing European debt crisis could have implications for the U.S. economy and, consequently, the presidential race.

4. Vice Presidential Candidates: The selection of vice presidential candidates could sway undecided voters and impact the race.

5. Health Care Ruling Fallout: The Supreme Court's health care ruling has not significantly shifted the race, but its impact could continue to be felt as the candidates address the issue in the coming months.

6. Foreign Policy Issues: The potential for Mideast or other foreign policy issues to flare up could impact voter perceptions of the candidates.

7. Global Events: Global events, such as a true financial calamity in debt-dogged Europe, could also impact the race.

Republican strategist Curt Anderson notes, "This race is going to be very close, and there's plenty of action left to come that can influence it." However, he adds, "There is a lot more peril than upside in all these things for President Obama."

As the race enters its final stretch, these inflection points will be closely watched by both campaigns and political observers alike. The outcome of the election could hinge on one or more of these factors.

Title: U.S. Economy Contracts for First Time Since 2008 Recession, GDP Decreases 0.1% in Q4 2012

The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) has reported a slight contraction in the American economy in the fourth quarter of 2012, with a 0.1% decrease in real gross domestic product (GDP). This marks the first time the U.S. economy has shrunk since the end of the 2008 recession.

The real GDP, which measures the output of goods and services produced by labor and property in the United States, decreased at an annual rate of 0.1% in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter. In the third quarter, real GDP increased by 3.1%. The downturn in real GDP in the fourth quarter was primarily due to decreases in private inventory investment, federal government spending, exports, and state and local government spending, which were partly offset by increases in nonresidential fixed investment, a larger decrease in imports, and an acceleration in personal consumption expenditures (PCE).

The 22% decline in federal military spending was the main factor contributing to the economic contraction. Nonmilitary spending by the federal government increased by 6%, but this was not enough to offset the decline in military spending cuts. One possible reason for the sharp decline in defense spending is the looming threat of the budget sequester brought on by the 2011 Budget Control Act. The Department of Defense may have made up for the prospect of budget cuts in Q3 2012 before paring back in Q4.

The March budget sequester is still scheduled to take place, and the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the defense spending cuts will result in a 0.4% drop in GDP. Members of Congress from both sides of the aisle will have to agree on some sort of package to delay the cuts to avoid a potential recession.

The GDP report was not all bad, though. Personal consumption spending and investment were growing, increasing by 2.2% and 8.4%, respectively. The boost in personal spending was driven mostly by durable goods, which suggests that consumers are replacing worn-out items. However, the lack of consumer confidence could spell trouble as well.

The BEA emphasized that the fourth-quarter advance estimate released today is based on incomplete or subject-to-revision source data. The "second" estimate for the fourth quarter, based on more complete data, will be released on February 28, 2013.

Title: Romney's Foreign Policy Strategy: A Balance of Tough Talk and Diplomacy

Article:

In his speech at the Virginia Military Institute (VMI) last week, Mitt Romney outlined his foreign policy vision, addressing key issues such as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Iran's nuclear program, and the Middle East in general. The speech, however, revealed a candidate who has left himself a significant amount of flexibility in terms of specific policy actions.

Romney emphasized his commitment to a democratic, prosperous Palestinian state living peacefully alongside Israel, criticizing President Obama for failing to achieve this goal. He also touched upon the theme of American "weakness" during the Obama era and the abandonment of allies, a message that has political appeal.

However, the specifics of what Romney would do, particularly on issues like Iran's nuclear program and dealing with difficult allies like Pakistan or Egypt, seem to align closely with Obama's approach in some instances. The speech appeared to gloss over positions Romney took more than a year ago, such as his opposition to expanding the intervention in Libya and his skepticism about a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Romney's foreign policy team, which has seen a shift in composition over the past few months, is reportedly still grappling with these issues. The candidate himself has not been deeply engaged in foreign policy matters during the campaign, particularly compared to his enthusiasm for economic issues.

The team, overseen by Kerry Healey, includes figures like Richard S. Williamson, Mitchell B. Reiss, and Jim Talent. Notable absentees include some well-known figures from the Republican foreign policy circles, such as John R. Bolton and Henry A. Kissinger.

The speech and Romney's foreign policy strategy, according to his advisers, reflect a candidate who resonates best with the concepts of "projecting strength" and "restoring global economic growth." However, the candidate's foreign policy positions seem to be a blend of different viewpoints within his own campaign, leading to some inconsistencies and confusion.

For instance, Romney's stance on Syria has been unclear, with advisers stating that he favors arming the Syrian rebels, but then correcting that he prefers Arab neighbors to arm them. Similarly, his position on Iran's nuclear capabilities has been inconsistent, with him initially stating he would prevent Iran from gaining a nuclear "capability," but later seeming to agree with Obama that he would prevent Iran from gaining a nuclear weapon.

In the VMI speech, Romney returned to his promise to "prevent them from acquiring a nuclear weapons capability," but focused primarily on new sanctions on Iran, a move that comes after Obama has imposed what experts agree are the most severe sanctions in history, combined with cyberattacks on Iran's nuclear infrastructure.

Overall, Romney's foreign policy strategy appears to be a balance of tough talk and diplomacy, with a focus on restoring American strength and global economic growth. However, the specifics of his policy actions remain somewhat unclear, and the candidate's foreign policy team is still in the process of defining his positions on various issues.

Title: Market Analysts Offer Cautious Outlook as U.S. Economy Gradually Reopens

Article:

As the U.S. economy begins to reopen, the stock market has shown signs of recovery, with stocks rising in volatile trading on Wednesday. However, the market's trajectory remains uncertain, as bank stocks climbed, but tech-focused "stay-at-home" plays fell.

David Lebovitz, global market strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management, expressed caution due to uncertainties surrounding the reopening process. He stated, "We have been surprised by the speed and the magnitude at which things have moved, but when you think about building a diversified portfolio, you have the 10-year Treasury yield at 70 basis points. Equities look attractive even if they're trading at north of 20 times. So, we have been encouraging folks to stay long equities despite some of the risks that exist."

Lebovitz's caution stems from the unknowns about reopening the economy, particularly the capacity requirements for businesses to operate profitably. He pointed out that for many businesses, especially service-oriented ones, reaching the break-even point might require 75% capacity, which could be challenging to achieve given the current circumstances.

Mike Mayo, managing director and head of U.S. large-cap bank research at Wells Fargo Securities, suggested that the Federal Reserve should let its policies from the previous recession work. He argued, "We've run over 200 earnings models. We've run different scenarios: a V recovery, a U recovery, an L recovery, and it's pretty tough, we think, for the government to conclude that large banks, well-capitalized banks, well-capitalized banks that earned their dividend twice over in the first quarter, in a quarter when they built reserves, we find it very tough for the Fed to conclude that banks should cut the dividends now."

Jason Furman, economic policy professor at Harvard University and former chair of the Council of Economic Advisers, warned investors against getting too eager too soon. He predicted a two-phase recovery, with a rapid partial bounce-back followed by a long and painful slog. Furman noted that the initial growth, observed from April 15 to May 15, is the low-hanging fruit of growth, but a significant number of people and businesses may not return to their pre-pandemic state.

In conclusion, while the U.S. economy is gradually reopening, market analysts and economists remain divided on the timeline for recovery. They urge caution and emphasize the importance of quality assets in building portfolios during this uncertain juncture. The Fed's role in supporting the recovery, particularly in relation to bank dividends, is also a topic of debate among experts.

Title: New York Attorney General Alleges $1 Billion in Hidden Assets by Sackler Family in Ongoing Opioid Crisis Case

Article:

In a significant development in the ongoing legal battle against Purdue Pharma and the Sackler family, the New York Attorney General's office has alleged that approximately $1 billion may have been concealed by the family as part of the opioid crisis litigation.

The allegations, made in court filings on Friday, are based on documents obtained from various financial institutions through subpoenas. According to the filings, these documents reveal about $1 billion in wire transfers between and among the defendants and their shell companies during the same timeframe that Purdue Pharma was allegedly draining its opioid-related proceeds.

New York Attorney General Letitia James, in a statement released on Friday, stated, "The Sacklers continue to lowball victims and skirt a responsible settlement. We refuse to allow the family to misuse the courts in an effort to shield their financial misconduct."

The Attorney General's office is investigating whether these transactions were a deliberate attempt by the Sackler family, who own Purdue Pharma, to conceal assets from litigants.

Purdue Pharma, the manufacturer of OxyContin, is facing thousands of lawsuits linked to the opioid crisis that has claimed tens of thousands of lives in the U.S. The company earlier this week announced a tentative settlement of $3 billion, with payments to be made from the sale of Mundipharma, a sister company also owned by the Sacklers.

However, the proposed settlement, which could see Purdue pay up to $12 billion and the Sackler family relinquish control of the company, has been met with criticism. Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey, in a statement, called it a "slap in the face" that allows the Sackler family to "walk away billionaires and admit no wrongdoing."

In response to the allegations, a spokesperson for Mortimer D.A. Sackler, formerly a Purdue board member, said in a statement to The New York Times, "This is a cynical attempt by a hostile A.G.'s office to generate defamatory headlines to try to torpedo a mutually beneficial settlement that is supported by so many other states and would result in billions of dollars going to communities and individuals across the country that need help."

The New York Attorney General's office is continuing its investigation into the matter.

Title: Obama's "Private Sector is Doing Fine" Comment Sparks Bipartisan Criticism

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Obama found himself at the receiving end of bipartisan criticism following an off-hand comment he made during a White House news conference on Friday. The comment, which suggested that the private sector was thriving, sparked a flurry of attacks from Republicans who accused the President of downplaying the economic struggles faced by the American people.

During the news conference, Obama stated, "As I've said, we created 4.3 million jobs over the last two years, 27 months, over 800,000 just this year alone. The private sector is doing fine." This statement, however, was met with immediate backlash, with many interpreting it as a dismissal of the economic struggles faced by the average American.

House Speaker John Boehner was one of the first to respond, stating, "Mr. President, I used to run a small business. And, Mr. President, take it from me, the private sector is not doing well." House Majority Leader Eric Cantor also weighed in, saying, "As the speaker said, we just listened to the president say the private sector is doing fine. I would say Mr. President, are you kidding? Did you see the jobs numbers last week? The private sector is not doing fine."

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, also joined in the criticism, stating, "He said the private sector is doing fine. Is he really that out of touch?" Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell also took to emailing journalists with the subject line "The private sector is doing fine?"

Twitter was alive with Republicans jumping on the bandwagon, with the #doingfine hashtag trending. The comment was reminiscent of the criticism leveled at then-Senator John McCain in 2008 when he stated, "The fundamentals of our economy are strong" during the height of the Great Recession.

John Dickerson, who writes for Slate and does political analysis for CBS News, made a relevant point in a tweet that seemed to suggest that Obama has some high-profile company when it comes to inducing winces in supporters and feeding frenzies among opponents. Dickerson tweeted, " 'private sector is doing fine' = 'not concerned about the very poor.' Discuss."

In an attempt to unring the bell he struck earlier with his remark about the private sector being "fine," Obama took the opportunity of a photo op with Philippine President Benigno Aquino to tell journalists that he is not unmoored from reality and indeed understands that the economy as a whole is not "fine." The President's full response to a reporter's question can be found in the article's conclusion.

Title: Republican Party Faces Internal Strife as Trump and Cruz Lead the Presidential Race

Article:

The Republican Party is grappling with deep-seated divisions following the ongoing presidential nomination race, with some party members expressing concern about the party's future direction. In a recent statement, former Republican National Committee Chairman Ed Gillespie, also known as Mr. Buchanan, expressed his apprehension about the party's potential shift towards protectionism, nationalism, and a more insular focus on border security.

These tensions within the Republican ranks have been brewing since the end of the George W. Bush administration, initially sparked by policy disagreements and later exacerbated by the party's response to the country's evolving demography. While some party leaders, such as Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, argue that the Republican Party must appeal to Hispanics and young people to survive, many voters view such appeals as a concession to the political establishment.

Instead, these voters crave an uncompromising brand of conservatism that confronts rather than accommodates the political establishment, a sentiment that has been reinforced by conservative talk radio hosts like Rush Limbaugh and commentators like Ann Coulter, whose influential commentary shapes the party's agenda.

Laura Ingraham, a talk-show host who played a significant role in the primary election defeat of Eric Cantor, the former House majority leader, in 2014, echoed this sentiment. "All the things the voters want have been shoved off to the sidelines by Republican leaders," Ingraham said. "And the voters finally have a couple of people here who are saying this table has to be turned over."

Regardless of the eventual nominee, the rifts within the party promise to be challenging to mend. If an establishment candidate secures the nomination, the highly engaged supporters of Trump and Cruz may rebel, with about two-thirds of Trump supporters indicating they would vote for him as a third-party candidate, according to a Suffolk University/USA Today poll last month. This scenario could potentially aid the Democratic nominee.

If Ted Cruz is nominated, he will need to win over party leaders without alienating his anti-establishment supporters. A Fox News poll released on Friday revealed that 66 percent of Cruz supporters in Iowa felt "betrayed" by politicians within their party.

In the event that party leaders support Donald Trump, they would find themselves campaigning in parallel universes, backing a candidate who has advocated for mass deportation of illegal immigrants and a temporary ban on Muslims entering the country, while simultaneously attempting to broaden their predominantly white male base. The party's internal discord underscores the significant challenges the Republican Party faces as it navigates the 2016 presidential election.

Title: Clinton Email Scandal: A Closer Look at the Alleged Mishandling of Classified Information

Article:

As the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server during her tenure as U.S. Secretary of State continues to unfold, the controversy surrounding the matter has intensified. While Clinton has attempted to downplay the issue, the revelation of deleted emails and the handling of classified information has raised questions about her handling of sensitive government information.

Clinton has admitted to deleting approximately 30,000 emails from her time in office, claiming they were personal in nature. However, federal law defines emails used during the course of one's work for the federal government as the property of the federal government. By deleting these emails, Clinton may have potentially violated federal law.

Furthermore, the 55,000 emails Clinton surrendered to the federal government were printed and not in their original digital format. This means that the metadata, which accompanies all digital emails and is crucial for tracing their origin and movement, was lost.

Clinton's decision to use a private email server for both personal and governmental emails has also come under scrutiny. Initially, Clinton stated that she believed using a single device for both types of emails would simplify her communications. However, it was later revealed that she carried four such devices.

The scandal took a more serious turn when it was discovered that Clinton's lawyers had the server that carried and stored the emails professionally wiped clean after she deleted the 30,000 emails and printed the 55,000 she surrendered to the feds.

Clinton has maintained that she did not send or receive any classified material on her email. However, an investigation by the State Department's and intelligence community's inspectors general found four classified emails among a random sample of 40. One of these emails was found to be top secret, containing satellite imagery of a foreign country and intercepts of communications among foreign agents.

When confronted with these facts, Clinton changed her explanation, stating that she never sent or received any email marked classified. However, emails are not marked "classified," but rather "top secret," "secret," or "confidential."

Last weekend, the State Department located 305 of Clinton's undeleted emails that likely fall into the top secret, secret, or classified categories. The potential consequences of Clinton's actions, if indicted for failure to secure classified information, remain to be seen.

The question of what should be the consequence of Clinton's behavior with the nation's most sensitive secrets is a matter of ongoing debate. If Clinton is indicted, she may argue that if an email was not marked with one of the above classifications, she did not know it was top secret. However, the nature of the information contained in the emails, such as satellite photos of foreign countries and intercepts of foreign agents, would likely be considered top secret.

The investigation into Clinton's email use is ongoing, and the outcome remains uncertain. However, the potential consequences of her actions, if found to have mishandled classified information, could have significant implications for her political future.

Title: U.S. Citizens Slaughtered in Mexico, International Issue Arises as Cartel Violence Escalates

Article:

MEXICO CITY (AP) - In a tragic turn of events, at least three women and six children, all apparently U.S. citizens, were killed by drug cartel gunmen in northern Mexico, officials confirmed Tuesday. Six children were found alive, one child had a bullet wound, and one child is still missing.

The incident occurred in a rural, mountainous area on the Sonora-Chihuahua border. Mexican Security Secretary Alfonso Durazo suggested that the group's large SUVs may have been mistaken for rival gangs. At least five children have been taken to Phoenix, Arizona for treatment.

The slaughter of U.S. citizens on Mexican soil has sparked an international issue, with U.S. President Donald Trump tweeting, "This is the time for Mexico, with the help of the United States, to wage WAR on the drug cartels and wipe them off the face of the earth."

Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, however, rejected this approach, stating at a Tuesday news conference, "The worst thing you can have is war." López Obrador said, "We declared war, and it did not work. That is not an option."

This incident marks the second failure in recent weeks for López Obrador's "hugs not bullets" anti-crime strategy. Two weeks ago, Mexican troops had to release a drug lord after his supporters mounted armed attacks in Culiacan, Sinaloa.

President Trump's tweet read, "The United States stands ready, willing & able to get involved and do the job quickly and effectively. The great new President of Mexico has made this a big issue, but the cartels have become so large and powerful that you sometimes need an army to defeat an army!"

The victims lived in the hamlet of La Mora in Sonora state, a decades-old settlement founded as part of an offshoot of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. La Mora is about 70 miles (110 kilometers) south of Douglas, Arizona. Many of the church's members were born in Mexico and thus have dual citizenship.

A relative, who wished to remain anonymous due to fear of reprisals, stated that the burned-out, bullet-ridden SUV containing the remains of his nephew's wife and her four children - twin 6-month-old babies and two other children aged 8 and 10 - were found.

"The mafia vehicles got her and four of her kids, and then set their vehicle on fire, burnt them to a crisp," said the relative.

Two women and two other children were later found dead.

Durazo stated that police, soldiers, and the National Guard were searching the area for the missing child. The relative speculated that it was a case of mistaken identity, as the cartel gunmen may have opened fire on the vehicle because it was an SUV.

Durazo also noted that the Sinaloa cartel has a significant presence in the Sonora region, but a rival cartel is attempting to invade the territory from the Chihuahua side.

Another relative, Julian LeBaron, stated on his Facebook page that one of the dead women was Rhonita Maria LeBaron. Jhon LeBaron, another relative, posted on his Facebook page that his aunt and another woman were dead, and six of his aunt's children had been left abandoned but alive on a roadside.

It would not be the first time that members of the break-away church had been attacked in northern Mexico, where their forebears settled - often in Chihuahua state - decades ago. In 2009, Benjamin LeBaron, an anti-crime activist who was related to those killed in Monday's attack, was murdered in neighboring Chihuahua state.

Title: Bipartisan U.S. Senators Introduce Tougher Sanctions on Russia, Combat Cyber Crime

WASHINGTON (AP) - A bipartisan group of U.S. senators from both the Republican and Democratic parties introduced legislation on Thursday aimed at imposing stricter sanctions on Russia and combating cybercrime. The bill, if passed, would be the latest response by lawmakers to punish Moscow for its interference in U.S. elections and activities in Syria and Ukraine.

The proposed legislation includes restrictions on new Russian sovereign debt transactions, energy and oil projects, and Russian uranium imports. It also imposes new sanctions on Russian political figures and oligarchs. The bill also expresses strong support for NATO and requires a two-thirds Senate vote in favor of any attempt to leave the alliance.

Russian markets reacted swiftly to the measure, with the rouble slumping towards two-week lows. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, one of the measure's lead sponsors, stated, "The current sanctions regime has failed to deter Russia from meddling in the upcoming 2018 midterm elections."

Congress passed a Russia sanctions bill last summer, but some lawmakers expressed dissatisfaction with what they perceived as President Donald Trump's reluctance to implement it. Trump eventually signed the bill after it passed with overwhelming majorities.

Several provisions of the measure introduced on Thursday aim to strengthen the previous law. Democratic Senator Bob Menendez stated that the administration had not fully complied with those sanctions. "This bill is the next step in tightening the screws on the Kremlin and will bring to bear the full condemnation of the United States Congress so that Putin finally understands that the U.S. will not tolerate his behavior any longer," Menendez said.

Republicans and Democrats united last month in repudiating Trump's failure to publicly condemn Russian President Vladimir Putin for interfering in the 2016 U.S. elections. However, Congress failed to pass any legislation before lawmakers went on their weeks-long summer recess.

The bill would need to pass both the Senate and House of Representatives and be signed by Trump to become law. Aides to the Senate's Republican majority leader, Mitch McConnell, referred questions about the bill to the Senate Banking Committee. A committee spokeswoman had no details on what measures the panel might consider. McConnell stated last month that Senate committees should hold hearings on legislation to stop Russia from future election meddling. Both the Banking and Foreign Relations Committees have since scheduled hearings relating to Russia.

Title: Russia's Constitutional Referendum: Putin Secures Future as President Until 2036

Article:

MOSCOW — Russian President Vladimir Putin appears to have secured his political future with a majority of votes in favor of a controversial national referendum that could see him remain in power until 2036. With 78 percent of votes counted, the referendum, which proposed more than 200 constitutional amendments, has shown strong support for the resetting of presidential term limits, allowing Putin to run for two more six-year terms in 2024 and 2030 if he chooses.

Official results, after 98 percent of ballots had been counted, showed that the former KGB officer, who has ruled Russia for more than two decades as president or prime minister, had easily won the right to run for two more terms. The Central Election Commission reported that 78 percent of votes counted across the world's largest country had supported changing the constitution, with just over 21 percent voting against.

The Russian leader, who has been president for 20 years, made the case for constitutional revisions, invoking patriotism and making a vague promise of securing Russia's future. The Kremlin had been keen to downplay the resetting of Putin's length of office, and more than 200 other issues were put to the public in the polls. However, these issues amounted to little more than fine print on the ballot papers.

The vote was irregular for a Russian election, beginning with online voting and a nearly week-long opportunity for citizens to stop by polling stations amid the coronavirus pandemic. The most novel aspect of Wednesday's election was that early results were announced by the Central Election Commission well before polls had closed in many parts of the country.

The result does not set Putin's future in stone. It does pave the way for him to possibly hold on to power until 2036, giving him the opportunity to be Russia's longest-serving ruler since Peter the Great. However, he will have to run two more presidential campaigns, and if he chooses to do so, the question then will be how many people turn out to vote.

Title: Florida High School Shooter's Alarming Behavior and Warnings Ignored Before Deadly Attack

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, where 17 people were killed and more than a dozen others were wounded, authorities, neighbors, and classmates have recounted a series of alarming behaviors exhibited by the shooter, Nikolas Cruz.

According to a complaint affidavit released on Thursday, Cruz admitted to being the gunman who entered the campus armed with an AR-15-style rifle and shot students he encountered in the hallways and on the school grounds. The 19-year-old former student, who had been expelled from the school, also may have stalked one of the girls he killed, a senior law-enforcement official said.

Neighbors called the police, classmates said he was obsessed with guns, and campus security considered him troubled. "Something was off with him," said Brody Speno, 19, who went to elementary and middle school with Cruz.

On Wednesday afternoon, Cruz took an Uber car to his former high school just before classes were dismissed, Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel said. He entered a school building with a legally purchased Smith & Wesson M & P 15 in a soft black bag. He readied his rifle and opened fire into five classrooms, the sheriff said.

Authorities can't arrest everyone they believe is dangerous, but "we can and we must do better," said Attorney General Jeff Sessions, speaking to a sheriffs association in Washington, D.C., on Thursday. President Donald Trump and Florida Gov. Rick Scott announced plans to redouble efforts to try to stop school violence, focusing more on mental health.

Cruz made his first appearance in court Thursday afternoon for a bond hearing, shuffling in shackles and wearing an orange outfit. He looked subdued and spoke only briefly, answering "Yes, ma'am" when asked to confirm his identity. Judge Kim Mollica informed Cruz that he faced 17 counts of premeditated murder and ordered him held without bond.

In a subsequent court proceeding, Gordon Weekes, chief assistant public defender in Broward County and part of Cruz's legal team, described the defendant as "deeply disturbed, emotionally broken," and said he is on suicide watch. The defense is gathering Cruz's mental-health history and will explore his brain development and the possibility he had autism, according to Weekes.

Meanwhile, Ben Bennight, a bail bondsman in Mississippi, said he contacted the FBI after seeing a comment from "nikolas cruz" on one of his YouTube posts. He also said he reported the comment as spam to YouTube, which took it down. The FBI visited Bennight at the time and returned Wednesday, he confirmed in an interview.

A white supremacist group, Republic of Florida, told the Anti-Defamation League that Cruz was affiliated with the group, according to an ADL spokesman. The Republic of Florida didn't return calls for comment.

Former Douglas high-school student Kyle Ramos, who knew Cruz from the Army Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps, said Cruz liked to get up early, around 6 a.m., and try to kill squirrels outside his house by shooting them with a pellet gun.

The shooting has sparked calls for a national conversation on gun control and mental health, with Broward County Public Schools Superintendent Robert Runcie putting the focus on weapons. "Now is the time for this country to have a real conversation on sensible gun-control laws," he said. "Our students are asking for that conversation."

Title: Jobs Report Shows Modest Growth, Leaves Economic Impact on Election Unchanged

Article:

The latest jobs report, released on Friday, showed a gain of 171,000 jobs in October, exceeding most mainstream forecasts. This economic data has once again brought the economy to the forefront of the presidential campaign, as both candidates, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, reengage in their economic debate.

The jobs report, released just days before the election, presents a mixed picture of the U.S. economy. The job growth is a positive sign, but the increase in the unemployment rate to 7.9 percent from 7.8 percent has denied President Obama a chance to tout a quickening recovery as he makes his final pitch to voters.

Both campaigns have used the report to reinforce their economic messages. Romney criticized Obama, stating that the unemployment rate is higher today than when Obama took office, while Obama highlighted the continuing trend of job growth as a reason to continue his economic policies.

The October jobs growth is in line with the recent trend and is unlikely to significantly impact the election. Economists such as Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics, have stated that the job numbers are not strong enough to help the president or weak enough to help Romney. John Silvia, chief economist at Wells Fargo, also noted that the report might be a modest benefit to Obama but does not change the overall picture of the economy.

With swing-state polls suggesting Obama is slightly ahead, he did not need a home run number on Friday. He just needed to avoid disaster and he certainly did that. Romney, on the other hand, arguably needed a much more dismal reading in order to crank up the heat on his closing argument that Obama has failed miserably on the economy and must be replaced.

Overall, the October jobs report shows a modest growth in the U.S. economy, but it is unlikely to significantly impact the outcome of the election. The economy will continue to be a key issue in the final days of the campaign, as both candidates seek to convince voters that they are the best candidate to lead the country.

Title: Chicago Police-ICE Agreement Sparks Concern Among Immigrant Rights Activists Ahead of City Council Vote on Sanctuary Law Amendments

Article:

As the Chicago City Council prepares to vote on amendments to the city's "sanctuary" law, a recently disclosed agreement between the Chicago Police Department (CPD) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has raised concerns among immigrant rights activists. The agreement, signed by former CPD Superintendent Eddie Johnson in April, designates certain CPD employees as "customs officers" with the authority to enforce federal offenses, but not administrative violations of immigration law.

CPD spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi stated that no department employees are currently deputized as "customs officers," but defended the agreement, arguing it allows police to investigate drug trafficking, human trafficking, gangs, and financial crimes through Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), a branch of ICE.

"Chicago, like many other major cities, has the authority to appoint officers to conduct joint state and federal investigations with Homeland Security Investigations," Guglielmi said. "This is not a partnership in immigration enforcement."

However, Guglielmi's assurances do not appease Rey Wences, a member of Organized Communities Against Deportations, who helped draft amendments to the Welcoming Cities ordinance that are set for a full City Council vote on Wednesday. The amendments prohibit CPD from assisting ICE, Customs and Border Protection, and Homeland Security Investigations in enforcing civil immigration operations and require the department to keep track of every request for assistance it receives.

Wences expressed concern about the agreement between CPD and ICE, stating, "Police-ICE collaboration is police-ICE collaboration, no matter how you paint it. The existence of this agreement... makes you wonder what other kinds of agreements the city has [with ICE]."

Ald. Carlos Ramirez-Rosa (35th) and Ald. Michael Rodriguez (22nd), who introduced the amendments in December with Mayor Lori Lightfoot, were also unaware of the agreement.

"The agreement goes against the spirit of the Welcoming Cities ordinance," Rodriguez said.

The mayor's office and ICE officials did not respond to requests for comments Tuesday.

The Homeland Security Investigations office was created in 2010 to handle a range of criminal investigations such as weapons smuggling and child sex tourism. ICE has routinely insisted Homeland Security Investigations is separate from its Enforcement and Removal Operations, which handles all deportations. However, under the Trump administration, the line between both branches of ICE has blurred.

In 2017, former ICE acting director Tom Homan instructed Homeland Security Investigations to increase time spent on worksite raids "by four to five times." Within two years, Homeland Security Investigations had conducted several high-profile raids across the country, including a raid of seven food processing plants in Mississippi that resulted in nearly 700 undocumented immigrant workers being detained (almost half of whom were released the next day).

A 2019 report by the Immigrant Legal Resource Center, the National Immigrant Justice Center, and the National Immigration Law Center criticized Homeland Security Investigations for engaging in racial profiling as it targets criminal gangs across the country.

"It is no longer a secret that HSI agents use the 'gang' label as a cover for engaging in widespread round-ups of immigrant youth of color," the report states.

Similar concerns have been raised in Boston, a fellow sanctuary city, where a similar agreement between the local police department and ICE led to widespread criticism after it was revealed that officials "regularly offer information back and forth between the agencies."

Guglielmi maintains that such incidents will not occur in Chicago and is confident that CPD officers will adhere to the Welcoming Cities ordinance.

"Our core focus of this department is to protect every resident of the city. We don't care where you were born," he said.

Freddy Martinez, a policy analyst at Open the Government who obtained a copy of the CPD-ICE agreement through an open records request, questioned the cooperation between immigration authorities and sanctuary cities.

"We know ICE uses deceptive practices to get CPD to cooperate with them on immigration enforcement, with or without their knowledge," Martinez said. "Significant questions remain about why [CPD] felt the need to enter into these types of agreements when there are no officers deputized to assist ICE."

Title: Iran's Economic Struggles Persist Despite President Rouhani's Promises of Relief

Iran's economy may be struggling, but the desire for change and improvement is palpable among its citizens. In the bustling city of Tehran, a downtown restaurant serves as a microcosm of the country's economic landscape. A well-dressed young man, identified as Ahmad, sits with a friend, discussing the economic climate under President Hassan Rouhani.

Ahmad, who is involved in the petrochemical business and independent trading, expresses a common sentiment that Rouhani has brought a more positive atmosphere to the country but has yet to deliver on economic changes. Ahmad's personal struggles, such as the high tariffs on imported cars, may not resonate with many Iranians grappling with more pressing economic issues.

Income inequality is one of the challenges Rouhani faces, but the Iranian president remains optimistic about his country's economic future. Iranians are pinning their hopes on a nuclear agreement and improved relations with the international community, which are seen as difficult to achieve.

Another significant hurdle for Rouhani is the opposition from entrenched interests that profit from Iran's isolation, such as the powerful Revolutionary Guard. In the poor neighborhoods of south Tehran, the economic struggles are more evident. Iran remains an economy of subsidies, with some direct cash payments replaced by food baskets for the poor.

In these areas, the economic hardships are more recognizable, but flashes of humor can still be found. An old man in a wool cap startles a reporter by shouting, "We chant 'Death to America' all the time! What are you doing here asking questions?" However, his comrades break into grins, and he smiles, acknowledging the reporter's presence.

Mehdi, a 77-year-old resident, makes it clear that they need help, but they do not appreciate food lines. "This is the fourth time I've come," Mehdi says. "They tell me to come back later, and then they say they've run out. It's not right."

Beyond a slight easing of sanctions last month, Iran has benefited from the widespread conviction that Rouhani's economic team is more competent than its predecessor's. Greater confidence, along with limited success in nuclear negotiations with six world powers, has helped reverse Iran's brutal inflation rate and stabilized the Iranian rial against the dollar.

However, achieving more will require the lifting of sanctions by further curtailing Iran's nuclear program, an effort that faces opposition both at home and abroad. Conservative Israeli and U.S. watchdogs such as United Against Nuclear Iran express concerns that "the architecture of the sanctions regime is crumbling," largely based on an increase in trade delegations visiting Iran and inflated Iranian predictions.

President Obama has stated that Washington will come down "like a ton of bricks" on those who violate sanctions. Inside Iran, people are not seeing improvements that would justify such concerns. Even the man in charge of making Iran's oil contracts more attractive to foreign companies is tempering expectations.

Oil ministry official Mehdi Hosseini states that Iran needs a massive $150 billion in foreign investment in the coming years, and so far, companies are not committing. "We still have sanctions now," Hosseini says. "There are companies coming and going, but we can't sign contracts while the sanctions remain, and contract talks will take time."

For now, Iranians say, there's nothing to do but struggle on, recognizing that better times ahead depend on factors beyond their control.

Title: White House Fires Top Aide of Former Secretary of State Tillerson Over Discrepancy in Firing Account

The White House has reportedly terminated Steve Goldstein, the Under Secretary of State, following a disagreement over the account of President Donald Trump's dismissal of former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. The Associated Press first reported the firing, citing officials.

The firing was allegedly prompted by a statement from Goldstein on Tuesday, in which he stated that Tillerson did not speak with Trump before his dismissal and was "unaware" of the reason behind his termination. This statement suggested that Tillerson may have found out about his firing through Twitter, though it contradicts published accounts of the decision that cited unnamed White House sources.

Goldstein's account differed from that of a White House official, who stated that White House Chief of Staff John Kelly informed Tillerson on Friday that Trump would fire him. President Trump, on the other hand, stated on Tuesday that he made the decision to oust Tillerson on his own and that Tillerson would be "much happier now."

Trump and Tillerson had reportedly clashed on several occasions, most notably after reports that Tillerson referred to Trump as a "moron" in private. The White House announced later on Tuesday that Heather Nauert, previously the State Department's spokesperson, had been named as Goldstein's replacement.

Title: Top 10 Standout Segments from "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" in 2013: A Year in Review of Satire and Parody

Article:

In the tumultuous year of 2013, America witnessed a plethora of controversial events, from the NSA's surveillance to the government shutdown, and the release of the questionable song "Accidental Racist." In the midst of these events, "The Daily Show" and "The Colbert Report" provided a much-needed dose of humor and satire. Here are ten of the best moments from the two shows:

1. Stephen Colbert and Alan Cumming's musical parody, "Oopsie Daisy Homophobe," took aim at the controversial song "Accidental Racist" by LL Cool J and Brad Paisley.

2. John Oliver's three-part series on gun control in Australia, which investigated the strict gun control measures implemented after mass shootings, and the U.S.'s failure to adopt similar measures.

3. Jessica Williams' segments on race in America, particularly her piece on food stamps and the hypocrisy of Mayor Michael Bloomberg's stop-and-frisk program.

4. Colbert's anger-fueled segment following Daft Punk's last-minute withdrawal from a "Colbert Report" performance, which turned out to be a hilarious critique of the band's VMA performance.

5. Aasif Mandvi's expose on North Carolina GOP leader Don Yelton, who made controversial comments about voter ID laws and racial minorities.

6. The "Daily Show's" annual skewering of Fox News' War on Christmas, with a particular focus on Megyn Kelly's outrage over a black Santa Claus.

7. The Best F#@king News Team Ever's parody of CNN's shoddy news coverage, which showcased the network's inaccuracies and sensationalism.

8. Jon Stewart's rage-filled verbal assaults on the GOP during the government shutdown, particularly his labeling of House Republicans as "self-righteous Orwellian zebra queefs."

9. The return of CNN's "Crossfire," parodied by Colbert in the program "Pointless Counter Pointless," featuring special guests Oscar the Grouch and Big Bird debating trivial topics.

10. A less humorous, but memorable moment, was former President Bill Clinton's admission of his insecurity with Twitter and his subsequent joining of the social media site under the handle "PrezBillyJeff."

Title: Republican Voters Support Gun Control Measures, but GOP Institution Remains Hostile to Gun Control Legislation

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, the Democratic Party has called on the GOP-controlled Senate to take action on gun control, particularly to pass a bill that would establish universal background checks. However, the Republican Party's stance on gun control remains a contentious issue, as polls show that while Republican voters prioritize gun rights, they are not universally opposed to restrictions on firearms.

According to polls, most Republicans support expanding background checks, "red flag" provisions allowing the police to take guns away from people deemed dangerous by a judge, and requiring a license to purchase a gun. Yet, the Republican Party as an institution remains hostile to gun control measures.

The political consequences of backing gun control measures are significant for Republican elected officials. If a Republican elected official votes for a gun control measure, they could potentially be labeled "anti-gun" and face electoral vulnerability. This is due, in part, to the fact that gun ownership is tied to the dominant political identity within the GOP, and views on guns are connected to broader conservative political beliefs.

Moreover, the Republican Party is aggressively working to expand gun rights at the state level, such as allowing people to carry concealed weapons without permits. The party also lacks a significant pro-gun control power, with no countervailing force promoting gun control within the GOP. The National Rifle Association (NRA) is a powerful force in GOP politics, exerting constant pressure and having a huge number of single-issue voters who could potentially walk away from a representative over the issue.

In conclusion, while a majority of voters overall and a sizable bloc of GOP voters would likely support gun control measures, a more comprehensive measure or group of measures faces significant barriers with a Republican-controlled Senate and a GOP president. The Republican Party's stance on gun control remains a contentious issue, and it is unlikely that the party will move too much anytime soon.

Title: Hydroxychloroquine, Malaria Drug, Shows Promise in Coronavirus Treatment, but More Data Needed for Firm Conclusion

A drug used to treat malaria is showing promise in lab and clinical studies for coronavirus, leading to reserved enthusiasm among some scientists. French researchers found that hydroxychloroquine lowered virus levels in most patients who took part in a clinical study this month. The results of a clinical trial in France and studies conducted in lab settings are building hope that a drug usually used to treat malaria and arthritis can treat and possibly cure coronavirus patients, though scientists say more data is needed before drawing a firm conclusion.

President Donald Trump asked the White House’s coronavirus task force about possibly using the drug during a briefing on Wednesday. Task force coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx said the drug is being studied "very carefully," as are several other potential therapeutics.

On Tuesday, a team of French scientists released the first results of a clinical study of the use of hydroxychloroquine on 24 coronavirus patients from southeast France. The research team, led by Didier Raoult, a renowned infectious disease expert from l’Institut Hospitalo-Universitaire in Marseille, administered the drug for 10 days along with azithromycin, a common antibiotic.

Researchers said the drugs cleared the virus in the nose and throat of most observed patients in three to six days. The study found that after six days of treatment, 70 percent of patients administered hydroxychloroquine were clear of the virus, compared to just 12.5 percent of patients who were not given drugs. Azithromycin boosted the effect of hydroxychloroquine, according to the study. After six days of treatment, all patients treated with the drug combination "were virologically cured," compared to 57.1 percent of patients treated with hydroxychloroquine by itself.

"We therefore recommend that COVID-19 patients be treated with hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin to cure their infection and to limit the transmission of the virus to other people in order to curb the spread of COVID-19 in the world," wrote researchers, who acknowledged the small sample size of the study.

Lab studies have shown that hydroxychloroquine, which was developed in the 1940s, inhibited coronavirus. A study published in Cell Discovery on Wednesday by three Chinese scientists found that hydroxychloroquine inhibited coronavirus in vitro, or in a lab culture.

Dr. Peter Hotez, the dean for the National School of Tropical Medicine at the Baylor School of Medicine, told ███ News Foundation he was "enthusiastic" about early results of studies involving hydroxychloroquine, though he said more data is needed to determine if the drug can effectively treat coronavirus.

"We urgently need to accelerate new antimicrobial therapies. If hydroxychloroquine could be approved in therapy it would be a game-changer," Hotez said. "The important next step is to show that it has an impact on reducing severity of symptoms in clinical disease."

Hotez said that an ideal study would be conducted in areas with high rates of transmission, such as the Lombardy region in Italy. More clinical trials are underway. A researcher at Asan Medical Center, a top research hospital in South Korea, is conducting a clinical trial of 150 patients with mild cases of coronavirus. The lead researcher, Sung-Han Kim, estimates that the trial will be completed in May.

According to NBC News, French drug maker Sanofi is working with health authorities to study whether hydroxychloroquine can help with coronavirus. The company is encouraged by preliminary findings, according to NBC News, but still does not have enough data to determine its efficacy.

Health officials in Belgium and South Korea have recommended the use of hydroxychloroquine for patients displaying either severe or mild symptoms from COVID-19, the disease caused by coronavirus. The United Kingdom appears to have some hope for the drug. On Sunday, government officials there banned the export and hoarding of hydroxychloroquine and two other drugs that could be useful as therapeutics, according to Pharmaceutical Technology.

Title: Former Benghazi Investigator Alleges Partisan Shift in Committee's Focus

Article:

In a recent interview with CNN's "State of the Union," a former investigator for the Select Committee on Benghazi, Air Force Reserve Maj. Bradley Podliska, has claimed that the investigation, initially non-partisan, shifted its focus towards former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Podliska, who was dismissed from his position, alleges that he was let go partially for not focusing his investigation heavily enough on Clinton, who was the U.S. Secretary of State during the 2012 Benghazi attack that resulted in the death of four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens.

However, on Sunday, the chairman of the House panel, Republican Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina, released a statement denying Podliska's allegations. Gowdy stated that the committee is seeking a "definitive accounting" of the attacks, and that Podliska was improperly focused on Clinton.

Podliska, a self-proclaimed conservative Republican who once interned for the conservative Media Research Center, maintains that his allegations are not partisan. He stated, "I would just like to state that I am going to vote for the Republican nominee in 2016. I do not support Hillary Clinton for president."

Podliska further asserted, "Hillary Clinton has a lot of explaining to do. We, however, did not need to shift resources to hyperfocus on Hillary Clinton. We did not need to de-emphasize, and in some cases drop, the investigation on different agencies, different organizations, and different individuals."

In response, the Benghazi committee issued a statement vigorously denying all of Podliska's allegations. The statement claimed that Podliska was terminated, in part, because he himself manifested improper partiality and animus in his investigative work. The committee also accused Podliska of imagining "a variety of new, outlandish, never previously mentioned allegations since his departure."

Podliska told CNN that the victims' families are not going to get the truth. He stated, "I know this because the nine months of research I had done is not lost. I have no idea where it is, and I know that I could give those victims' families... a pretty thorough explanation of why they were told that this attack was due to a video."

Title: The Government Shutdown: A Standoff Over DACA and the Fate of Dreamers

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, the recent government shutdown has been labeled as the "Dreamer shutdown" by some, as the fate of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and the Dreamers has become the central issue in the ongoing political standoff.

Illegal immigrant Dreamers, who have been advocating for citizenship rights, pressured Democrats to block funding for the government unless the bill granted them permanent protection. On Friday, Democrats heeded this call, mounting a filibuster of a four-week spending bill, denying the government the necessary funds to remain open.

Dreamers celebrated the shutdown, stating they were finally being taken seriously. Cata Santiago, a Dreamer, said in a statement, "We know that the public is on our side. We are calling for the immigrant community and our allies to take to the streets immediately to demand that Congress pass legislation guaranteeing permanent protection for immigrant youth NOW."

Dozens of Dreamers were present in the Senate's viewing galleries on Friday night, watching as the drama unfolded beneath them. Police were in force outside the galleries, prepared for potential protests and mass arrests, but there were no disturbances.

Senators seemed stunned by the turn of events, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell admitting, "Almost everybody on both sides doesn't understand how we ended up here." He laid blame squarely at the feet of the Dreamer debate, stating that Democrats held the entire process hostage to the immigration talks.

Democrats suggested there were other sticking points, but acknowledged immigration and the fate of the Dreamers was the chief hurdle. However, they said the hold-up was President Trump's demands for major changes in immigration policy, which the White House said had to be passed along with any action on Dreamers.

The Dreamers and their immigrant-rights allies now find themselves in a similar position as conservative and tea party groups, who pressured Republicans into an Obamacare-fueled shutdown in 2013. That shutdown lasted 16 days, and Republicans relented in the end, walking away with no substantive gains.

Dreamers are likely to emerge from this shutdown in better shape, with most lawmakers saying they do want to find a solution for them. Early Saturday morning, after the votes, Dreamers stood outside the Capitol in small groups, awaiting the outcome. For now, the Dreamers await along with the rest of the country to see the outcome, though they were emboldened by their show of political power.

Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice, a pro-immigration lobby group, said, "Our fight has never been about a government shutdown; it's about a policy breakthrough. It's not about political advantage; it's about people's lives."

Deemed the most sympathetic figures in the immigration debate, most Dreamers were brought to the U.S. by parents with little say in the decision, and many don't have substantive memories of their home countries. They began "coming out" as illegal immigrants in the last decade, and quickly became a political force, earning invitations to the State of the Union address, meeting at the White House with President Barack Obama, and addressing the Democratic National Convention.

They came close to a solution in 2010, when legislation known as the Dream Act—which they took their name from—cleared the House and came close to passing the Senate, falling in a GOP-led filibuster. Their power has grown in the years since, and they felt emboldened last year to demand a shutdown fight. Democrats balked the first few times, but finally agreed to a self-imposed Jan. 19 deadline for action.

However, the actual firm deadline for Dreamers is March 5, which is when President Trump's phaseout of the Obama-era DACA deportation amnesty, protecting some 690,000 Dreamers, begins to expire. More than 100 Dreamers are losing status each day right now, but those are ones who didn't manage to renew their status by Homeland Security's Oct. 5 deadline.

Sen. Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat who has led the fight on their behalf for years, said it was a travesty for Congress to have not solved their situation. "To say we're in no hurry—well, we may not be as senators and congressmen, but these young people are in a hurry to find out whether or not they have a life. That's what it comes down to," Mr. Durbin said.

Republicans countered that they, too, wanted to grant long-term certainty to Dreamers, but didn't want a new amnesty to invite another wave of illegal immigration. They demanded more border security and other policy changes be tied to any Dreamer legislation.

"We can not deal with the issue of individuals in our country illegally...and ignore how it happened in the first place," said Sen. James Lankford, Oklahoma Republican. The standoff continues, with the future of the Dreamers and the government hanging in the balance.

Title: Unemployment Rates Vary Widely Across U.S. States, With Some States Seeing Unprecedented Job Growth and Others Struggling

Article:

The disparity in the economic recovery across different U.S. states is evident in the stark contrast of unemployment rates, according to data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) for June. While five states have unemployment rates below 4%, several other states, particularly those with industrial backgrounds or poor populations, are still grappling with high unemployment rates.

Five states, including Vermont with an unemployment rate of 3.5% in June, have extraordinary jobless figures. These states are primarily located in the Great Plains, where an energy boom has contributed to the economy. North Dakota, with its rich shale resources, had a jobless rate of a mere 2.7% in June. Nebraska and Utah followed closely with unemployment rates of 3.5%, while South Dakota's rate was 3.8%. Wyoming, with a population of 578,759, was the only state with a 4% unemployment rate.

On the other end of the spectrum, employment remains high in several formerly industrial states and states with poor populations. Rhode Island, which has lost many factory workers and people from the financial services industry, had an unemployment rate of 7.9% in June. Mississippi, one of the poorest states in the country based on median household income, also had an unemployment rate of 7.9%. In another poor state, Kentucky, the jobless rate is 7.4%, and it is higher in the eastern counties that were once a center of coal production. Illinois, one of the most factory-rich northern states, had an unemployment rate of 7.1% in June. Michigan's was 7.5%, and Nevada, home to the greatest real estate collapse of the Great Recession, which gutted construction jobs, had a jobless rate of 7.7%.

It is evident that if the U.S. economy is to have a normal, fully recovered jobless rate of 5% or better, these most troubled states have a long way to go to contribute. There is nothing in their economic compositions that makes such a recovery likely.

24/7 Wall St. is a financial news and commentary partner offering content independently of ███.

Title: "The Debate Over Extended Unemployment Benefits: A Look at the Controversial $600 Weekly Boost and Its Impact on the Economy"

In the aftermath of the unprecedented $2 trillion stimulus package passed in March, one of the most contentious issues has emerged: the extension of unemployment benefits. With nearly 39 million Americans filing for unemployment in the past nine weeks, the enhanced benefits, which provide an additional $600 per week from the federal government, are set to expire on July 31 unless Congress votes to extend them.

The enhanced benefits, when combined with state-level payments, have created a situation where some workers are earning more on unemployment than they would if they returned to work. This has sparked a heated debate, with proponents arguing that the extra funds have helped stave off a more severe economic collapse, while opponents claim it will hinder the country's economic recovery by discouraging people from returning to work.

The issue is expected to be a key point of contention as Congress considers its next stimulus bill in the coming weeks. House Democrats have proposed a bill that would continue the $600 bonus through the end of January, while Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham stated that the GOP would oppose such an extension.

Opponents of extending the enhanced benefits argue that it will hold back the country's economic recovery by providing an incentive for people to stay home rather than return to work. They contend that this could lead to businesses suffering if employees refuse to accept what would effectively be a pay cut by going back to work when stay-at-home orders are lifted. The situation could also create resentment among essential workers who have remained on the job during the crisis for less pay than those who were laid off.

Proponents of continuing the enhanced payments argue that the extra money has helped many people make ends meet during these challenging times. They also point out that the larger checks mean people have money to spend, which helps businesses stay afloat. If the extra funds go away, the country could see a wave of evictions, foreclosures, and other secondary economic impacts that could lead to a prolonged and severe recession, some economists have warned.

Public health experts argue that the enhanced benefits are an important part of limiting the spread of coronavirus, which they see as the top priority. Not only would extending the enhanced benefits save lives, but lessening the severity of the outbreak would also ultimately benefit the economy more than a premature rush to push people back into the workplace, they say.

As of now, Republicans in the Senate have yet to release a plan for their next stimulus package. The earliest any legislation could move forward will be the first week of June, when senators return from a weeklong recess. The debate over the extended unemployment benefits is shaping up to be a significant point of contention in the ongoing economic recovery discussions.

Title: Obama's Healthcare Overhaul: A Test of Progressivism's Reputation and the Future of Liberalism

Article:

The rollout of President Barack Obama's signature healthcare overhaul, commonly known as Obamacare, has put the reputation of Big Government progressivism at risk for at least this generation. The success or failure of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) now rests on the president's ability to reverse the debacle and demonstrate that his approach to covering millions of uninsured Americans is not only an enlightened but workable policy.

In his 2006 best-selling book, "The Audacity of Hope," Obama dismissed the achievements of the most recent Democratic president, Bill Clinton. He criticized Clinton's policies as "recognizably progressive if modest in their goals." These words take on new significance in light of the ACA's success or failure.

The future of the Democratic Party's plausible agenda and of liberalism itself is at stake, as both emboldened conservatives and worried liberals agree. The challenge for Obama is to ensure that the cycle of progressivism he presumed to usher in and the period of renewed faith and confidence in the transformative powers of government does not die aborning.

William Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, who helped launch the centrist "New Democratic" agenda in the 1990s, said, "Unlike the Republican agenda, the Democratic agenda does not work unless people have a certain level of trust in the competence of the government to act on their behalf."

Conservative thinkers have seized on the rocky rollout of Obamacare as proof positive that the age-old argument over the proper role of state action in American life has reached a fresh danger point for the Democrats. The unraveling of Obamacare could catastrophically undermine the ideology of ever-expansive central government providing cradle-to-grave care for an ever-grateful citizenry.

Anxious congressional Democrats face a fight-or-flight dilemma of their own. For all their worries, abandoning Obamacare is no easy proposition. They supported its creation and understand that their constituents need health care reform—they cannot continue with the flawed old system that left so many shut out.

The White House, for its part, pooh-poohs such doomsday talk. "This is obviously a challenge, and we're facing the challenge, and we're up to the challenge," press secretary Jay Carney insisted on Friday.

However, more dispassionate analysts—even sympathetic ones—say it would be hard to overstate the danger of this moment for Obama and for Democrats more broadly. From the beginning, Obama sketched his agenda for the country as the sort that succeeds only once a generation, if then.

Title: Central American Migrant Caravan Arrives at U.S.-Mexico Border Despite Trump's Warnings

A group of Central American migrants, numbering around 600, traveling together in a caravan through Mexico, have arrived at the border city of Tijuana late on Tuesday, despite warnings from U.S. President Donald Trump that it would be futile to attempt crossing to claim asylum in the United States.

By evening, two busloads of men, women, and children, who have been on a month-long journey that began near Mexico's southern border with Guatemala, arrived in Tijuana, a city that borders southern California. The migrants, who have fled their homes in Guatemala, El Salvador, and Honduras due to lethal threats or political persecution, have held onto the hope of receiving asylum in the United States. However, their prospects have diminished after U.S. authorities released statements on Monday stating they would be turned back.

Rodrigo Abeja, a coordinator from immigrant rights group Pueblo Sin Fronteras, which has organized similar caravans for several years, said the caravan would regroup before making any decisions. "They will wait for all those seeking asylum to be together," Abeja said.

Another four busloads were making their way north from Hermosillo, a city 432 miles south of the border, where the migrants had been stalled for days. A third group, resigned to staying in Mexico, awaited processing for year-long visas by immigration authorities in Hermosillo.

The number of migrants traveling together has decreased from a peak of about 1,500 people, due to the twin pressures of waiting for transportation and attacks by President Trump, who began criticizing the caravan on Twitter in early April. After Trump's comments, Mexican authorities stalled the caravan in a southern town and began handing out temporary visas that gave them legal status to travel to the border.

Title: Hurricane Hermine Makes Landfall in Florida, Threatens East Coast

Article:

Hurricane Hermine, the first hurricane to hit Florida in over a decade, made landfall early Friday morning in the Big Bend area, where Florida's peninsula and panhandle meet. The storm caused power outages, damage from storm surges, and flooding in coastal communities.

As of Saturday, Hermine had weakened to a tropical storm, but the National Hurricane Center predicted it would regain hurricane strength over the weekend and potentially impact coastal areas as far north as Connecticut and Rhode Island through Labor Day. The storm's projected path prompted New Jersey Governor Chris Christie to declare a state of emergency for three counties on the Atlantic Ocean.

In Florida, the main impact of Hermine was power outages and damage from storm surges. A homeless man south of Gainesville died when a tree fell on him, Governor Rick Scott said. Scott later visited coastal communities like Cedar Key and Steinhatchee, which were hit hard by the storm.

In Cedar Key, numerous homes were damaged, storage buildings were destroyed, and a 100-yard fishing pier was damaged. In Steinhatchee, a storm surge crashed into Bobbi Pattison's home, leaving her living room filled with overturned furniture and an acrid smell. Tiny crabs darted around her floor.

In Keaton Beach, about two dozen people were stranded due to flooding, with police blocking the road. Dustin Beach, 31, rushed there from a hospital in Tallahassee where his wife gave birth to a girl Thursday night to see if his home still stood.

High winds knocked trees onto several houses in Tallahassee, injuring people inside. Alan Autry, 48, heard a large pine in his Tallahassee neighborhood start to crack and fall to the ground. The tree did not initially crash through the roof, and Autry and his wife went to a neighbor's house. Sometime before dawn, the corner of his house collapsed from the weight of the tree.

Tampa and St. Petersburg escaped major damage, with up to 17 inches of rain falling in the area over the last two days. The last hurricane to strike Florida was Wilma, a powerful Category 3 storm that arrived on Oct. 24, 2005. It caused five deaths in the state and an estimated $23 billion in damage.

As Hermine moves up the East Coast, it threatens a dangerous storm surge into Hampton Roads in southeast Virginia. The storm is expected to regain hurricane strength by Monday morning off the Maryland-Delaware coast before weakening again as it moves north. Tropical storm watches and warnings are posted up and down the coastline. Amtrak has cancelled or altered some service on the East Coast as the storm approaches.

Title: New Zealand Mosque Attack Suspect's Manifesto and Social Media Posts Reveal Far-Right Influence and White Nationalist Agenda

Article:

In the aftermath of the Christchurch mosque shootings in New Zealand, the gunman's actions, manifesto, and social media posts have been analyzed, revealing a deep connection to the far-right online community and a white nationalist agenda.

The gunman's actions, paired with the typical trolling tactics of the internet's most far-right instigators, were designed to provoke a response and create division. His manifesto, a chilling document, states that one of his objectives was to "agitate the political enemies of my people into action, to cause them to overextend their own hand and experience the eventual and inevitable backlash as a result."

The manifesto, filled with anti-Muslim sentiment, refers to nonwhites as "invaders" who threaten to "replace" white people. The author's choice of language and specific memes suggest a profound understanding of the far-right online community.
