The gunman's weapons bore the names of centuries-old military leaders who led battles against largely nonwhite forces, as well as the names of men who recently carried out mass shootings of Jews and Muslims. His manifesto, steeped in anti-Muslim sentiment, also references the gunman's interest in history, particularly events that fit into a white nationalist narrative.

The link to the livestreamed video was first posted to the /pol/ forum of 8chan, a notorious far-right space, where the gunman was hailed as a hero after the shooting. Some of his references were subtle, such as his choice to listen to a song associated with a 1995 Serbian nationalist video, which has recently been co-opted as a racist meme, during his drive to the mosque.

The investigation into the shootings continues, and the world grapples with the aftermath of this horrific event, seeking to understand the motivations behind it and to prevent such tragedies from happening again.

Title: Virginia's 7th District: A Tight Race Between Democrat Abigail Spanberger and Republican Incumbent Dave Brat

Article:

In the upcoming U.S. congressional midterm elections, the race between Democrat Abigail Spanberger and Republican incumbent Dave Brat in Virginia's 7th District is shaping up to be a tight contest. The district, which includes parts of suburban Virginia, has been experiencing a shift away from the Republican party, making it a potential target for Democrats.

Last week, at a campaign event in a martial arts studio, voters Meg Sneed and Cheryll Lesser, who had previously voted for Brat, listened to Spanberger. Their primary reason for attending was their disapproval of President Donald Trump, and they expressed their intention to vote against anyone who supports him, including Brat.

The discontent towards Trump is a significant factor in the Democrats' belief that they can win more than the 23 seats they need to seize control of the U.S. House of Representatives. Some predict that Democrats could take as many as 40 seats by flipping districts like Brat's in Virginia.

Earlier this year, Brat's seat was considered safe. However, if a "blue wave" materializes, it could roll through a district like his, given the increasing number of suburban voters turning away from the Republicans. Doug Heye, a former official at the Republican National Committee, noted that Republicans are playing defense in more and more places, while the Democrats' map continues to expand.

If Democrats do take the House, much of Trump's agenda would be stalled, and his administration would face greater scrutiny. Republicans, on the other hand, are favored to retain the Senate. While Democrats need a net total of just two seats to control that chamber, they must also defend seats in several conservative states.

Democrats have poured resources into Brat's district, as well as other battleground districts, such as Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Southern California, and other parts of Virginia, like the district currently represented by Republican Scott Taylor. They have been backed by deep-pocketed advocacy groups like House Majority PAC and NextGen, funded by California billionaire Tom Steyer, which launched efforts to turn out young voters in the district.

In response, the Congressional Leadership Fund, a Republican political action committee, is running ads attacking Spanberger, a sign that the party is genuinely worried about losing the seat.

Brat, who shocked the political order by beating then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in a Republican primary in 2014, has aligned himself with the ultra-conservative Freedom Caucus. Last year, as protesters disrupted his events during a House push to repeal former President Barack Obama's healthcare program, Brat remarked that "women are in my grille no matter where I go."

In September, Brat held his first town hall in a year, and he did so with a supportive audience of older veterans. Sarah Montgomery, a librarian for the U.S. Department of Defense who attended Spanberger's event in Spotsylvania, said that after Brat's district was redrawn in 2016 to include her home, she researched him, and the video of his "grille" remark was the first thing she found.

The firestorm over Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, who was accused of sexual assault while in high school, came at a perilous moment for Brat, given his already difficult reputation with some women voters. Trump has played a part in this, as both Sneed and Lesser were angry that he chose to attack Kavanaugh's accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, at a rally last week.

Kavanaugh was confirmed by the U.S. Senate on Saturday. Democratic activists hope discontent with his nomination will linger through November. Republicans, however, see the Kavanaugh fracas as galvanizing conservatives who have been looking for a reason to come out and vote in November's elections.

"It has mobilized and energized Republican voters in a way that only a Supreme Court nomination can," said Matt Gorman, communications director for the National Republican Congressional Committee, the arm of the party that supports House candidates like Brat.

Brat has been a solid supporter of Kavanaugh, even though the House served no role in his nomination. Last week, he reasserted that support in a Facebook post. His campaign rejected the notion that he is not supportive of women, pointing to his efforts to combat human trafficking and the opioid epidemic and the passage of tax reform last year.

A 39-year-old former officer for the Central Intelligence Agency, Spanberger presents herself as the face of the Resistance, the woman-driven protest movement against Trump. However, she has been careful to not alienate the independent and moderate voters she needs to win the district. At the Spotsylvania event, she didn't mention Trump, Brat, or Kavanaugh, focusing on domestic-policy issues such as healthcare and education.

Asked for her position on Kavanaugh's nomination, her campaign declined to comment. Instead, Spanberger touched on the thing that attracted voters such as Meg Sneed to her: turning down the volume in the civic discourse.

"We've reached a place where we need to restore a level of civility to our conversations," she told the crowd.

Tom Davis, a former Republican congressman from Virginia, said it remains Brat's race to win, and that Kavanaugh may be the issue that pulls him over the finish line. "It's still a southern district," Davis said. "There's nothing like a good fight to keep your base in line."

Title: The Impact of Economic Transition on Life Expectancy: A Comparative Analysis of Hong Kong and Central Europe

Article:

Last Friday, the Cato Institute hosted a forum on Neil Monnery's book, "Architect of Prosperity: Sir John Cowperthwaite and the Making of Hong Kong." Sir John Cowperthwaite, the financial secretary of Hong Kong from 1961 to 1971 and its financial under-secretary from 1951 to 1961, played a significant role in establishing policies that have been credited for transforming a poor British colony into one of the world's wealthiest regions.

During the discussion, Monnery highlighted that in the years following World War II, Hong Kong's per capita income was one-third of that in Britain. By the time of the British transfer of the territory to China in 1997, incomes in the two countries were equal. Today, the average inhabitant of Hong Kong is over 30% richer than the average Briton.

Economic growth, Monnery argued, is not only crucial for rising standards of living but also for health and life expectancy. In the 1960s, people in Hong Kong lived four years shorter than their British counterparts. Today, they live four years longer. This correlation between economic growth and life expectancy was a key point of discussion.

This got me thinking about the changes that Central Europe underwent since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the 28th anniversary of which we will commemorate on November 9. Following the end of the communist period, the region experienced an economic recession, as unproductive industries shut down, and millions of people lost their jobs. Life expectancy started to decline, which opponents of market reforms saw as proof positive of capitalism's deleterious consequences for people's welfare.

Revisiting life expectancy statistics some three decades later, a different picture emerges. Between 1960, the first year for which World Bank data is available, and 1989 (i.e., a period of 29 years), life expectancy in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia rose by 1.33, 1.46, 3.36, and 1.05 years, respectively. Between 1989 and 2015 (i.e., a period of 26 years), it increased by 7.1, 5.68, 6.44, and 5.24 years, respectively. The post-communist dip in life expectancy, such as it was, proved to be small and temporary.

Further afield, post-communist depression was much more pronounced in the Baltic countries, which is, in retrospect, unsurprising. These economies, being parts of the Soviet Union, were much more heavily distorted than their neighbors to the west. In other words, a deeper restructuring was necessary.

However, the relationship between economic growth and life expectancy still holds. In the 31 years between 1960 and 1991 (i.e., the year of the dissolution of the U.S.S.R.), life expectancy in Estonia and Lithuania rose by 1.47 and 0.52 years, respectively, while in Latvia it fell by.75 years. Between 1991 and 2015 (i.e., a period of 24 years), life expectancy rose by 7.33 years in Estonia, 2.97 years in Lithuania, and 5.02 years in Latvia.

In conclusion, a switch from socialism to capitalism appears to be good for the health and longevity of the citizenry. The correlation between economic growth and life expectancy, as demonstrated by the cases of Hong Kong and Central Europe, suggests that economic policies promoting growth and development can significantly impact the well-being and lifespan of a nation's population.

Title: Deadly Bombing Rocks Bangkok's Downtown Area, Killing 18 and Injuring Over 100

A devastating bomb blast rocked a popular shopping and tourism district in Bangkok during the evening rush hour on Monday, leaving at least 18 people dead and over 100 injured, according to authorities.

The explosion occurred near the Erawan Shrine, a Hindu religious site, with the blast's full force hitting people in the area. The BBC reported that body parts were scattered and a crater was present, indicating a bombing. Burned motorbikes were also seen on the road.

Initial reports suggested a second explosion was possible, but national police chief Somyot Poompummuang later confirmed that the suspicious object found near the blast site was harmless.

The exact cause of the explosion remains unclear, but the Bangkok Post reported that an improvised explosive device was placed inside the shrine complex and detonated at 6:55 p.m. local time. The blast set motorbikes and taxis ablaze near the Rajprasong intersection, a site of political protests in recent years.

Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Prawit Wongsuwan condemned the bombing and expressed condolences to the families of the deceased and injured. He stated that it was too soon to determine if the attack was politically motivated.

The White House also condemned the attack and extended condolences to those affected by the explosion. The U.S. will remain in close contact with Thai authorities investigating the blast.

While such attacks are rare in Bangkok, there have been smaller incidents in recent months, including a small homemade pipe bomb explosion near a shopping mall in February and grenade attacks in March and April.

It is not yet clear why the shrine was targeted. Thailand is predominantly Buddhist, with Hindus making up a small fraction of the population. Approximately 5% of the population is Islamic, and there has been some religious unrest involving Islamic separatists in southern Thailand in recent years.

Thailand experienced a military coup in May 2014, and the government was dissolved, replaced by a military-dominated national legislature. The current prime minister, Gen. Prayut Chan-o-cha, has cracked down on dissent and banned criticism of his government.

Witnesses described the chaos and panic that ensued after the explosion. Anna Mallika, a Thai-American auditor, was in an exercise class when the blast hit. "We heard the most almighty bang," Mallika said. "Most of us thought that something was wrong, but the instructor told us that it was probably just a car crash or something like that. Minutes later we saw people running and panicking outside the window."

Richard Sri-kureja told the BBC he was walking to a mall next to the shrine when he heard the blast. "There was total chaos," he said. "That area is usually very, very crowded as it's in the middle of the city and it's usually very packed. A local hotel is full of injured patients."

The investigation into the bombing is ongoing.

Title: Trump Administration's Border Wall Funding Case Rejected by Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals

Article:

In a significant development, the Trump administration's bid to secure funding for the construction of a border wall without congressional authorization has been rejected by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals. The court upheld a lower court's ruling that blocked the Defense Department from reallocating $2.5 billion from its budget for the border wall project.

The case began in May when a federal district judge in Oakland, Calif., Haywood Gilliam Jr., a former federal prosecutor appointed by President Obama, issued a preliminary ruling blocking the Defense Department from spending money that Congress had not appropriated for the border wall. The administration then sought a stay of Judge Gilliam's order, but the judge refused, and a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled 2-1 to uphold his refusal.

The administration claimed an emergency, stating that construction contracts had to be in place by the end of the current fiscal year on Sept. 30 for the project to proceed. However, the appeals court majority wrote that the Constitution assigns the power of the purse to Congress, and it is Congress that is to make decisions regarding how to spend taxpayer dollars.

This case marks the 28th time, according to Prof. Stephen Vladeck of the University of Texas School of Law, that the Trump administration has sought Supreme Court intervention of this sort, compared to six times for the administration of President George W. Bush and four times for the Obama administration in their respective eight-year terms.

The Trump administration's repeated attempts to bypass the appeals court and seek direct review from the Supreme Court have raised concerns about a historic change in the attitude and behavior of a presidential administration towards the Supreme Court. The skepticism stems from the administration's approach to the court, which may sometimes aim to lose cases and use the Supreme Court as a foil. The administration's actions are under close and critical scrutiny.

Title: President Obama Expresses Optimism on Immigration Bill, Sen. Schumer Reports 90% Progress in Gang of Eight Legislation

Article:

WASHINGTON — President Barack Obama expressed optimism on Wednesday that Congress will have a bill that overhauls the nation's immigration laws ready next month and that passage of the legislation can be completed by summer's end.

In an interview with the Spanish-language network Telemundo, Obama stated, "If we have a bill introduced at the beginning of next month as these senators indicate it will be, then I'm confident that we can get it done certainly before the end of the summer."

The president's comments come as four members of the Senate's so-called "Gang of Eight," including Arizona Republican John McCain and Democrat Charles Schumer, took a tour of the Arizona-Mexico border on Wednesday. Schumer told reporters after the tour that the lawmakers were 90% done with their work crafting the legislation.

Obama called on Congress this week to expedite the process and deliver an immigration bill as soon as possible. The president, who overwhelmingly won the Latino vote in his race against Mitt Romney, has been criticized by some Latinos for failing to reform immigration in his first term and for a record number of deportations being carried out under his watch.

In the Telemundo interview, Obama dismissed the suggestion that there could be potential political fallout for his party if the push on immigration falls short. "I'm not concerned about the Democratic Party," Obama said. "I'm concerned about the people whose actual lives are (going to) be impacted by it."

He emphasized the importance of the legislation, stating, "The most important thing is that we're seeing a strong commitment to finally solve this problem in a way that strengthens our border security, makes sure that there's a pathway to citizenship, an earned one, a tough one, but a pathway so that people can live out their dreams and make sure that they have a better life for themselves and their kids."

Obama also noted that he is prepared to introduce his own plan if necessary, stating, "I've got my own legislation I'm prepared to step in, but I don't think that's going to be necessary."

Title: Border Patrol Agents Warn of Increased Illegal Crossings as Immigration Reform Negotiations Progress

Article:

As the Gang of Eight in Washington prepares to announce a deal on immigration reform later this week, with a focus on border security before a path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, Border Patrol agents are expressing concerns about the potential impact of reduced agent work hours on border security.

According to an anonymous Border Patrol agent speaking to ███, illegal border crossings have nearly doubled since discussions about amnesty began. "We've seen the number of illegal aliens double, maybe even triple, since amnesty talk started happening," the agent said. "A lot of these people, although not the majority, are criminals or aggravated felons. This is a direct danger to our communities."

Data obtained by ███ and reported within Customs and Border Protection (CBP) from February 5 through March 1, 2013, shows 504 illegal aliens were spotted in the Tucson/Nogales area, with 189 being caught on CBP intelligence cameras. Of those 504, only 174 were apprehended, and 32 of the 189 on camera were carrying large drug loads for Mexican cartels. Some were armed with AK-47 style weapons.

Photos obtained by ███ from CBP intelligence cameras in Southern Arizona near the border with Mexico have been provided, with sensitive information redacted to protect the security and identity of the camera locations.

Last week, Fox News reported that sections of the border will soon become unpatrolled as hours for on-the-ground agents are cut. ███ has learned that Border Patrol agents working the border have been fully funded, yet internal political battles within CBP may be causing funds to be funneled to managers rather than those on the ground.

"Customs and Border Protection has been given enough money to fully staff the border, but has chosen to use the money elsewhere, we believe it is to fund the salaries of Supervisory CBP Officers," Vice President of the National Border Patrol Council Shawn Moran tells ███. "The money they are diverting was to go to Administratively Uncontrollable Overtime (AUO), which is actually straight pay and is used to pay Border Patrol Agents for anything past eight hours. Being that we have to maintain staffing 24/7, this is a huge part of border security. The criminals and drugs do not stop coming, so we have to make sure we have people out there."

Moran also stated that cutting AUO would result in a 30% pay cut for agents and a minimum 20% loss of staffing out in the field. "It is internal politics within CBP and also with immigration reform. There are still battles between legacy Customs, INS, and Border Patrol managers as to the direction CBP takes and how the funds are being used. Meanwhile, both parties claim no immigration reform until the border is secured, well, this surely will not secure the border."

As sequestration goes into full effect on April 7 and a deal in Washington on immigration reform gets locked in, illegal crossings are expected to worsen. "We have seen increased crossings and smuggling since word of staffing cuts began circulating," Moran says. "The border is safer but by no means secure."

Another agent expressed similar sentiments, stating that when apprehended, some illegal aliens ask where they can go to find amnesty.

Despite border security being put further at risk through bad policy, the push for immigration reform, well before full border security is ongoing. The AFL-CIO reached a deal with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on a guest worker program last Friday. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said the Gang of Eight has reached a deal on immigration reform on CNN's State of the Union over the weekend, but Republican Senator Marco Rubio has said reports of a deal are premature.

Title: Michael Cohen's Attorneys Expected to Cease Representation as Criminal Investigation Continues

Article:

In a significant development, the legal team representing Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's longtime personal lawyer, is expected to stop representing him in the ongoing criminal investigation into his business dealings. This information was shared by a source familiar with the matter.

The attorneys, including Stephen Ryan, Todd Harrison, and others from the law firm McDermott, Will & Emery LLP, have been representing Mr. Cohen since June 2017. They are currently reviewing over 3.7 million documents seized during an April raid of Mr. Cohen's home, office, and hotel room. This review aims to identify communications that are protected by attorney-client privilege, in accordance with a Friday deadline set by Judge Kimba Wood of the Southern District of New York.

Once the review is complete, the lawyers from McDermott, Will & Emery LLP are set to cease their representation of Mr. Cohen. At the moment, Mr. Cohen does not have a replacement law firm but is reportedly searching for a federal criminal lawyer in New York. Sources familiar with the matter suggest that Mr. Cohen is looking for a lawyer with close ties to the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office.

As of now, Mr. Cohen has not decided whether he will cooperate with prosecutors in the case. He has not been charged with any crime.

Judge Wood has appointed a special master to oversee the document review and decide whether communications designated as privileged by Mr. Cohen, Mr. Trump, or the Trump Organization can be viewed by government investigators.

The Manhattan U.S. attorney's office is investigating whether Mr. Cohen committed bank fraud, campaign-finance violations, and other potential crimes. A spokeswoman for the office declined to comment. Mr. Cohen has denied any wrongdoing.

This development was first reported by ABC News.

Title: FBI Agent Peter Strzok Faces Intense Scrutiny in 10-Hour Congressional Hearing

Article:

In a 10-hour joint hearing between the House Judiciary and Oversight Committees on Capitol Hill Thursday, senior FBI agent Peter Strzok faced intense questioning regarding his role in investigations into Hillary Clinton's private email server and potential coordination between Russia and the Trump campaign.

Strzok, at the center of suspicion due to a series of text messages he exchanged with his lover, former FBI attorney Lisa Page, defended his actions, stating, "I strongly believe that today's hearing is just another victory notch in Putin's belt."

During the hearing, Strzok maintained that he separated his political opinions from his investigations. However, his dismissal from the Russia investigation following the discovery of his text messages was a point of contention.

House Oversight Committee Chairman Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-SC) questioned Strzok, stating, "It was not the discovery of your texts, Mr. Strzok. It was the existence of your bias that got you kicked off."

In response, Strzok argued, "No, Mr. Gowdy, it was not. I do not have bias. My personal opinions in no way— "

"Well then why did you get kicked off?" Gowdy demanded.

"Mr. Gowdy, my understanding of why I was kicked off was that based on an understanding of those texts, and the perception that they might create— " Strzok said.

Gowdy countered, "Well, hang on a second, Agent Strzok! Hang on a second. Perception—you're saying it was the perception! There are 13 Democrats on the special counsel probe, including one who went to what he hoped was a victory party (for Hillary Clinton)!"

At one point, Strzok refused to answer questions, citing a directive by FBI attorneys, leading to a threat of contempt of Congress.

Throughout the hearing, Democrats defended Strzok, with Rep. Steve Cohen (D-TN) stating, "If I could give you a Purple Heart, I would."

Republicans, on the other hand, expressed outrage, with Rep. Trent Gohmert (R-TX) stating, "I do not appreciate having an FBI agent with an unprecedented level of animus working on two major investigations during 2016."

Lisa Page is scheduled to be questioned by members of Congress in a closed-door session, having had the benefit of watching Strzok's testimony on Thursday.

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry Challenges Syrian President Bashar Assad's Denial of Chemical Weapons Use

Article:

In a sharp rebuke of Syrian President Bashar Assad's claims that his regime did not use chemical weapons in the Aug. 21 attack, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry on Thursday urged the United Nations to take a firm stance when it convenes next week. Kerry's remarks came in response to Assad's assertions, as well as those of the Russian government, that the opposition was behind the deadly chemical attack.

During a surprise appearance at the daily State Department briefing, Kerry dismissed Assad's claims, stating, "Sarin was used. Sarin killed." He further questioned the plausibility of the opposition's involvement, stating, "Or whether the opposition secretly went unnoticed into territory they do not control to fire rockets they do not have, containing sarin that they do not possess, to kill their own people."

The U.S. diplomat's comments were made ahead of the U.N. meeting next week in New York, where U.S. diplomats will continue working on a U.N. resolution to enforce a newly struck agreement that would have the Assad regime turn over its chemical weapons to international control.

Assad's denial of his government's involvement in the chemical attack, which prompted the stand-off with the U.S., was reiterated in an interview with ███ that was aired Wednesday. In the interview, Assad admitted his country has chemical weapons but continued to push the theory that the opposition was behind the strike.

The Syrian president was confronted with the newly released findings of a United Nations report on the Aug. 21 attack. The report stated that there is conclusive evidence that the chemical attack occurred, but did not assign blame. It did, however, include findings about the type of rocket used, which the U.S. and its allies claim point to Syrian government culpability.

Kerry emphasized that nations cannot "have their own set of facts." He stated, "This fight about Syria's chemical weapons is not a game. Anybody who reads the facts (in the U.N. report) and puts the dots together... understands what those facts mean."

Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Offers Diplomatic Assistance to President Trump, Expresses Skepticism over Russian Interference in 2016 Election

Article:

In an interview with The New York Times, former President Jimmy Carter, a liberal Democrat, expressed support for President Donald Trump on several issues, including the media's treatment of the current president and his diplomatic efforts in the Middle East.

Carter, who admitted to voting for Sen. Bernie Sanders in the primary, criticized the media for their treatment of Trump, stating, "I think the media have been harder on Trump than any other president certainly that I've known about." He further added, "I think they feel free to claim that Trump is mentally deranged and everything else without hesitation."

The 39th president also praised Trump's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East, particularly his initiative reaching out to Saudi Arabia. Carter expressed a positive view of Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, stating, "I've seen in the Arab world, including the Palestinian world, the high esteem that they pay to a member of one's own family."

In a surprising turn, Carter was more critical of President Obama during the interview than he was of Trump. He also expressed interest in helping President Trump work on a diplomatic resolution to the conflict with North Korea, citing his past success in negotiating with the country during his presidency. Carter flew into Pyongyang in 1994, striking a deal with Kim Il-sung, the grandfather of the current leader, Kim Jung-un.

Carter offered his diplomatic services to the White House but, as of yet, has not been accepted. "I told him that I was available if they ever need me," he said, referring to H.R. McMaster.

Regarding the ongoing controversy over players kneeling during the national anthem in the NFL, Carter expressed a preference for players to stand for The Star-Spangled Banner. "I think they ought to find a different way to object, to demonstrate. I would rather see all the players stand during the American anthem," he explained.

In terms of the Russian interference in the 2016 election, Carter expressed skepticism, stating, "I don't think there's any evidence that what the Russians did changed enough votes, or any votes." This stance contrasts with the consensus of the U.S. intelligence community and the findings of the Mueller report.

Title: Obama's Delay of Employer Mandate Highlights Ongoing Changes to Affordable Care Act

Article:

President Obama's decision this week to delay the employer mandate to provide health insurance is the latest adjustment to his health care law, underscoring the ongoing changes to the legislation more than three years after it was signed into law. The courts have rewritten the Medicaid expansion, while Mr. Obama and Congress have repealed a long-term care program and onerous reporting requirements for businesses.

On Tuesday, Mr. Obama took unilateral action to postpone the employer mandate for a year, with his aides stating they are trying to demonstrate the flexibility all sides have requested as the massive bill moves toward full implementation. The fits and starts have left an ever-shifting platform that could become even more complex by the time the law's most controversial aspect—the individual mandate to have health insurance or pay a fine/tax—goes into effect on Jan. 1.

"There will certainly be opportunities here for further confusing people," said Timothy Jost, a professor at the Washington and Lee University School of Law.

All sides had predicted the law, officially known as the Affordable Care Act and widely nicknamed "Obamacare," would change over time, and even Mr. Obama and congressional Democrats had said they'd be open to tweaks that might make it work better.

However, observers were taken aback by the White House's sudden decision to delay the employer mandate by one year. The provision requires businesses with more than 50 workers to offer insurance to all full-time employees, or else pay a fine of $2,000 per worker.

Opponents of the law said the move exposed its fundamental flaws. "Implementation of the ACA has not lowered costs or increased access as promised," said Sen. Jerry Moran, Kansas Republican. "Individuals, families, and employers still face increasing health insurance costs, new taxes overseen by what we have recently learned is a politically-biased IRS, burdensome mandates, and massive uncertainty because of this flawed law."

Republicans have repeatedly tried to repeal the law or at least chip away at it, while Democrats say unfounded criticism and a lack of funding have undermined the administration's efforts after years of work.

"The problem all along has been that while the program was passed with great fanfare a few years ago, most of the policies that will really impact people won't take effect until 2014," said Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist and former spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid. "Which is a tough way to sell something to the American people, especially when the Republicans are doing everything they can to undermine a bill that is the law of the land."

Mr. Jost also said "widespread, vicious opposition to this law" has been the prime source of turbulence along the path to implementation. "It's like if you're trying to get your work done, and somebody's slapping you in the face all the time," he said.

The choices Congress made in writing the law have contributed to the complexity of getting it up and running. Congress did not employ a single-payer system that would have given the federal government complete control, and in an attempt to give states some flexibility, it offered them the chance to set up their own health insurance marketplaces, or exchanges. However, more than half of the states decided to let the federal government create one for them, creating a hodgepodge of state-run and federally facilitated marketplaces.

The Supreme Court added to the complexity last year when it upheld the core of the law but said states should be allowed to opt out of the Medicaid expansion. Some statehouses are still grappling with whether to accept the opt-out. Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, lawmakers have gone back and recaptured some of the money the law would have overpaid as tax credits for those using subsidies to buy insurance on the exchanges.

In 2011, all sides agreed to repeal a business expense reporting requirement that had been designed so the IRS could make sure employers were paying their full tax burdens.

This week's decision signaled that more tweaks and changes may be on the way. "These things have never been that easy," said Mr. Jost. "I just think it's so unfortunate that it's turned out this way."

Title: House Assures Vote on Sandy Aid Package by Jan. 15, Easing Tensions Among Lawmakers

Article:

Following bipartisan outrage over a decision to postpone a vote on a massive aid package for Superstorm Sandy victims, Speaker John Boehner has assured New York and New Jersey lawmakers that the House will vote on the package by Jan. 15. The announcement comes after a closed-door meeting that appeared to calm tensions in the party.

Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) reported after the meeting that the House will vote on a $9 billion flood insurance measure on Friday, followed by a vote on a $51 billion aid bill on Jan. 15. As far as King is concerned, he spoke for all members of the New York and New Jersey delegations, stating that the meeting was "extremely positive."

Boehner and House Republican Leader Eric Cantor affirmed the plan in a written statement, saying, "Getting critical aid to the victims of Hurricane Sandy should be the first priority in the new Congress, and that was reaffirmed today with members of the New York and New Jersey delegations."

Earlier in the day, King had lambasted party leaders for the move, calling it a "disgrace" and "immoral." He even urged constituents to stop donating to congressional Republicans. However, King's tone softened after the meeting, stating that the postponement was "in the past."

President Obama, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo also decried the "failure" to act, with the governors stating that the tradition of aiding American citizens in need was abandoned in the House.

At a press conference earlier in the afternoon, Christie placed the blame on House Republicans and Boehner himself. However, Boehner's toughest Republican critics on the Hill were walking things back late Wednesday.

The House Appropriations Committee produced a bill Tuesday that significantly pared back the Senate version, bringing it down to $27 billion. The initial plan was to put that bill for a vote, and then allow a separate vote on a $33 billion amendment. Now, it appears the House will move forward with a vote on the full $60 billion, in two installments.

A procession of lawmakers took to the House floor Wednesday to urge action on the bill and decry the decision to postpone it. House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer stated, "We can not and we should not wait. We must not walk away. I urge the speaker of this House to reconsider and act immediately." A spokesman for Boehner, Michael Steel, said, "The speaker is committed to getting this bill passed this month."

The storm was one of the worst ever to hit the Northeast, blamed for at least 120 deaths and damaging or destroying more than 72,000 homes and businesses in New Jersey and over 305,000 housing units in New York, with more than 265,000 businesses affected.

Title: Vice President Pence Warns North Korea of U.S. Response to Weapons Use, Promises Peaceful Diplomacy

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence, aboard the USS Ronald Reagan in Japan, issued a stern warning to North Korea on Wednesday, stating that any use of conventional or nuclear weapons would be met with an "overwhelming and effective" response from the U.S. military. Pence's remarks came amidst the ongoing tension over North Korea's nuclear weapons program and its recent failed missile launch.

Pence emphasized the U.S.'s commitment to working with allies such as Japan, China, and other global powers to apply economic and diplomatic pressure on Pyongyang. He also highlighted the importance of readiness, stating, "The United States of America will always seek peace but under President Trump, the shield stands guard and the sword stands ready."

Addressing a crowd of 2,500 sailors, Pence reiterated that any attack or provocation would be met with a robust American response. He also pledged to uphold the U.S.'s alliance with Pacific Rim nations and protect freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, a region where China has staked claims to disputed territory.

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, currently on a Middle East tour, also criticized North Korea's missile launch, describing it as a "reckless act of provocation." Mattis did not specify the type of missile, but stated it was not of intercontinental range, meaning it could not reach U.S. territory.

The Trump administration's stance on North Korea appears to be a continuation of the strategy employed by its predecessor, albeit with the added unpredictability of a new president who has shown a willingness to use force. Pence expressed hope that China would use its influence in the region to pressure North Korea to abandon its weapons program, but expressed impatience with North Korea's unwillingness to denuclearize.

Meanwhile, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov called for a peaceful resolution to the Korean Peninsula issue, expressing hope that the U.S. would refrain from unilateral actions and follow the line President Trump advocated during his election campaign. China has also called for a return to negotiations and has expressed concern over U.S. plans to deploy a missile defense system in South Korea, stating that these plans could damage Sino-U.S. relations.

The situation on the Korean Peninsula remains complex and uncertain, with both the U.S. and North Korea engaging in heated rhetoric. The Trump administration's strategy, while similar to that of the Obama administration, remains to be seen in terms of its effectiveness in resolving the ongoing crisis.

Title: Sen. Cory Booker Disagrees with Sen. Elizabeth Warren's Proposal to Break Up Tech Giants, Cites Presidential Responsibility

Article:

In an interview with ABC's Jonathan Karl on "This Week," Sen. Cory Booker (D-NJ) expressed his disagreement with Sen. Elizabeth Warren's (D-MA) proposal to break up major technology companies, stating that such a move would not be appropriate for a president.

Booker, a fellow 2020 presidential candidate, criticized Warren's plan to dismantle companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Google, which she has accused of unfair competition and stifling startups. He argued that a president should not single out companies for breakup without due process.

"I do not think that a president should be running around pointing at companies and saying breaking them up without any kind of process here," Booker said.

Comparing Warren's proposal to President Donald Trump's approach, Booker stated, "It's not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks. That sounds more like a Donald Trump thing to say, ‘ I'm going to break up you guys.’"

Despite this disagreement, Booker clarified that he considers Warren a friend. He added, "I'm telling you right now: We do not need a president that is going to use their own personal beliefs and tell you which companies we should break up."

Another Democratic presidential candidate, Sen. Kamala Harris (D-CA), also commented on the dominance of Silicon Valley's major tech titans, stating that Facebook has prioritized its growth over consumer interests, particularly in the area of privacy. When asked if Facebook should be broken up, Harris responded, "I think we have to seriously take a look at that."

The tech industry remains a significant topic in the ongoing 2020 presidential race, with candidates addressing issues such as antitrust, privacy, and the impact of corporate consolidation on American businesses.

Title: Chaotic Senate Confirmation Hearing for Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh

WASHINGTON ( ███ ) - The U.S. Senate confirmation hearing for Brett Kavanaugh, President Donald Trump's Supreme Court pick, was marked by disruption and partisan tension on Tuesday, as Democrats protested the withholding of documents related to Kavanaugh's past White House service and numerous protesters were arrested.

More than seven hours elapsed before Kavanaugh, a conservative federal appeals court judge, delivered his opening statement. Kavanaugh, nominated by a president who has often criticized the federal judiciary, emphasized the importance of an independent judiciary, stating, "A judge must be independent, not swayed by public pressure. Our independent judiciary is the crown jewel of our constitutional republic."

The session became chaotic due to repeated interruptions from Democratic senators and numerous protests from demonstrators, mostly women, who voiced concerns about Kavanaugh's potential impact on abortion rights, healthcare access, and gun control.

Democratic senators, including Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, criticized the withholding of documents by Republicans and the White House, arguing that it hindered their ability to properly vet Kavanaugh. Grassley deemed the Democrats' request to halt the hearing "out of order" and accused them of obstruction.

If confirmed, Kavanaugh, 53, is expected to shift the court's balance further to the right. Senate Democratic leaders have vowed a fierce fight to block his confirmation, and Democrats signaled they would press Kavanaugh on abortion, gun rights, and presidential power during questioning scheduled for Wednesday through Friday.

The Democrats' demands for documents relating to Kavanaugh's time as staff secretary to Republican former President George W. Bush from 2003 to 2006 have gone unfulfilled. Republicans have released some, but not all, documents concerning Kavanaugh's two prior years as a lawyer in Bush's White House Counsel's Office.

As the hearing paused for a lunch break, Fred Guttenberg, whose daughter was killed in the Parkland, Florida high school mass shooting in February, attempted to speak with Kavanaugh but was rebuffed. Video of the encounter was widely shared on social media.

The Democratic frustrations that boiled over on Tuesday had been simmering for more than two years. Democrats have accused Senate Republican leaders of stealing a Supreme Court seat by refusing to consider Democratic former President Barack Obama's nominee to the high court, Merrick Garland, in 2016, allowing Trump to fill a Supreme Court vacancy instead.

The Senate is likely to vote on confirmation by the end of September, with the court's next term beginning in October. The hearing provided Democrats a platform to make their case against Kavanaugh ahead of November's congressional elections in which they are seeking to seize control of Congress from Republicans.

Title: US-Iran Tensions Escalate as Trump and Rouhani Exchange Hostile Remarks

Article:

In a series of escalating exchanges, US President Donald Trump and Iranian President Hassan Rouhani have traded hostile warnings, as tensions between the two nations continue to rise.

Mr. Trump, in a tweet, warned Iran that it would "suffer consequences the likes of which few throughout history have ever suffered before" if it threatened the US. Mr. Rouhani earlier stated that a war with Iran would be "the mother of all wars."

The escalation comes amid the US's withdrawal from a nuclear deal in May, which had curbed Iran's nuclear activities in exchange for the lifting of international sanctions. The US is now re-imposing these sanctions, despite objections from the UK, France, China, Russia, and Germany, who all signed the 2015 agreement.

The US has expressed deep suspicion towards Iranian activity in the Middle East, and maintains close ties with Israel and Saudi Arabia, two of Iran's main adversaries. Mr. Rouhani's comments, made to Iranian diplomats, did leave open the possibility of future good relations with the US.

"America should know that peace with Iran is the mother of all peace, and war with Iran is the mother of all wars," he said, according to Iran's state news agency Irna. In response to Mr. Trump's broadside, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif tweeted, "Color us unimpressed."

Mr. Trump's aggressive rhetoric mirrors his Twitter barrages against North Korea's Kim Jong-un, whom he once branded a "madman." Despite their verbal hostilities, diplomacy eventually emerged between the two leaders.

On Monday, a senior commander in Iran's Revolutionary Guards suggested Mr. Trump's statements were part of a broader strategy. "The remarks Trump makes against Iran are psychological warfare, and he would be mistaken should he seek to take action against Iran," Gholamhossein Gheybparvar said, quoted by the Iranian Students News Agency.

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, in a speech to a group of Iranian Americans in California, said he wanted to try to stop countries importing Iranian oil by November as part of continued pressure on Tehran. He also accused the Iranian regime of resembling a mafia more than a government.

The Trump administration regards Iran as a destabilizing force in the Middle East, arguing that the nuclear deal enabled Iran to pursue a more assertive regional policy. Iran has sent hundreds of troops and thousands of volunteer militiamen to Syria, and has strengthened its military presence there.

Gulf states have accused Iran of backing Yemen's Houthi rebels with both money and weapons, though Iran has denied this. Saudi Arabia, a key US ally, is a major adversary of Iran and has repeatedly warned about Iran's intentions.

In May, Mr. Trump called the nuclear accord, or Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) as it is formally known, a "horrible, one-sided deal that should have never, ever been made." He alleged that the deal did not restrict Iran's "destabilizing activities" in the region enough, and could not detect or prevent any breaking of its terms.

Analysts also cited the influence of White House Iran hawks including Mr. Pompeo and US National Security Adviser John Bolton, and Mr. Trump's tendency to target major policies of his predecessor, President Obama.

Iran insists its nuclear program is entirely peaceful, and its compliance with the deal has been verified by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which has said Iran is honoring its commitments. The IAEA has said its inspectors were granted access to all locations they needed to visit in 2017, but that they did not seek to enter any military sites, which Iranian officials declared off-limits - a move the US said raised doubts over Tehran's compliance.

In May, Mr. Pompeo outlined 12 conditions for any "new deal" between the US and Iran, including the withdrawal of its forces from Syria and an end to its support for rebels in Yemen. Iran is one of the world's largest oil producers, with exports worth billions of dollars each year. It is already feeling economic pressures, and has seen large-scale protests over rising prices and a decline in the value of its currency, the rial.

Title: Analysis: The Future of the Affordable Care Act Amidst Ongoing Implementation Challenges

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, often referred to as Obamacare, has faced numerous challenges since its implementation, with the rollout being a significant point of contention. Despite the media's portrayal of a potential repeal, the reality is far from it. For a repeal to occur, a veto-proof majority would be required, a situation that is currently unlikely, according to Representative Steve Cohen, D-Tenn.

Cohen, in a recent interview, stated, "I can't see a veto-proof number coming up. I just don't see that happening. But you've got to remember, we just put off the budget, put off the sequester, we didn't cure that problem we put it off. So you've got some real problems coming up in January and in December with budget numbers and the sequester. But the bottom line is that Democrats are going to be vulnerable to Republican attacks on the Affordable Care Act regardless."

The Affordable Care Act, while bearing President Obama's name, is a creation of the Democratic Party. If Democrats were to help Republicans in obliterating it, it would be seen as an admission of governing incompetence, according to Cohen.

Two possible futures for the Affordable Care Act emerge: one in which it limps ahead, and another in which it undergoes a swift reversal of fortune. The nightmare scenario is not the repeal of Obamacare but the potential political, moral, and substantive challenges that could arise if the implementation process remains problematic.

If fixing Healthcare.gov takes significantly longer than the Obama administration is forecasting, or if enrollments never spike, political, moral, and substantive considerations could change. For instance, if fewer people enroll through the exchanges than see their policies canceled, it would be politically humiliating and raise questions about the fairness of imposing penalties on people for not entering a system they can't access or may not trust.

In this scenario, Democrats would face intense pressure to vote for a delay of the individual mandate. They might do so to stave off a full-scale rebellion, with the administration likely acting unilaterally, agreeing to provide hardship exemptions en masse, and hoping to hold the votes for a universal delay below a veto-proof threshold, to protect markets in states with functioning exchanges.

A more desirable scenario is one in which the website works well within a few weeks, enrollments shoot upward, quickly overtaking the number of people whose policies have been canceled. In this scenario, aggregates would matter more than anecdotes and hardships, as the media's bias towards anecdote and hardship would have to contend with raw numbers. If total enrollments, including new Medicaid beneficiaries, approach anywhere near the 16 million the Congressional Budget Office initially projected, the tale of the ACA's success would be impossible for the media to ignore.

Starting Dec. 1, opponents of the law will screen-grab and disseminate every website failure they encounter. However, if the law truly is working well "for the vast majority of users" as the administration likes to say, it will be reflected in swelling enrollment figures and regular updates on the law's improving progress. This will take the sting out of "you can keep it" attacks, and Democrats won't have anything to run from anymore. You can even imagine them repurposing the Upton bill, to put Republicans on the record against stripping new beneficiaries of their health plans.

A volte-face like that would likely stop the repeal campaign dead in its tracks.

Title: Impeachment of President Obama Unlikely Despite Republican Control of Congress

Article:

In the political landscape of Washington, the prospect of impeaching President Barack Obama, a long-held dream of some conservative factions, appears to be a distant reality. Despite the possibility of a Republican-controlled Senate and House in the November congressional elections, the numbers simply do not add up, making it impossible for the GOP to achieve the two-thirds Senate majority needed to convict the President.

According to a recent CNN/ORC International Poll, nearly two-thirds of respondents oppose impeaching the President. House Speaker John Boehner and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, who may have presidential ambitions in 2016, have also dismissed the possibility, stating that the actions of the President do not meet the high crimes and misdemeanors threshold for impeachment.

Republican leaders are attempting to manage the expectations of their conservative base, with Boehner stating that there are no plans to impeach the President. Ryan echoed this sentiment, saying that the issue does not rise to the level of high crimes and misdemeanors.

Meanwhile, Obama and Democrats are using the threat of impeachment to rally their supporters and raise funds. The President has criticized Republicans for their focus on lawsuits and impeachment, rather than addressing issues important to the middle class, such as jobs and infrastructure.

The impeachment issue resonates with Democratic supporters, with the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee raising $7.6 million online since House Republicans authorized Boehner to sue the President over executive actions.

The impeachment discussion reflects deeper political undercurrents within the Republican Party, particularly among diehard conservatives and more moderate Republicans. Wendy Schiller, a political scientist at Brown University, called impeachment a "farfetched" maneuver that could cause independent voters leaning Republican to instead vote Democratic in November.

Jonathan Chait, a writer who predicted four years ago that House Republicans would vote to impeach Obama before his presidency ended, now doubts that will happen. Missteps by Republicans, including primary defeats of viable candidates by conservative extremists and the government shutdown they forced last year, have convinced the establishment that they cannot indulge the base on all its flights of fancy.

Republican leaders are now seeking to steer their base away from impeachment, fearing a politically damaging vote. In dismissing an impeachment move, Boehner and Ryan have sought to shift the blame for any discussion about it onto Democrats and the White House.

The challenge for Boehner and other GOP leaders is to find a middle path between tea party demands to impeach Obama and less extreme options for action, such as the lawsuit. An impeachment effort after the November election would dominate Washington in the final two years of Obama's presidency, posing possible benefits and risks.

The impeachment proceedings against President Richard Nixon and his subsequent resignation still rankle many Republicans today, 40 years later. It was an event that made efforts to remove a sitting president part of routine political discussion in America. A GOP-led House voted to impeach President Bill Clinton on charges of perjury and obstruction in 1998. The Senate acquitted him on both charges, with none of the minority Democrats voting to convict, and he stayed in office.

Today, any Republican with presidential ambitions wants to avoid making impeachment a reflex response to dissatisfaction with the White House, Schiller noted. "If you want to be president some day," she said, "the last thing you want is for Congress to be able willy-nilly to impeach you."

Title: Edward Snowden's Asylum Status in Russia Remains Unclear as He Remains in Airport Transit Zone

Article:

Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, remains in the transit zone of Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, despite speculation earlier this week that he might be able to leave the facility. A Russian lawyer, reportedly planning to meet with Snowden at the airport, had sparked rumors that he would bring documents allowing Snowden to formally enter Russia.

However, it appears that even with new legal papers, Snowden's asylum request is still under consideration by Russian authorities. A spokeswoman for the Federal Migration Service told the Associated Press they had no information about the status of Snowden's application for asylum.

Snowden had applied for temporary asylum in Russia last week, following his attempts to leave the airport and fly out of the country being thwarted. He has been staying at the airport transit zone since June 23, when he arrived on a flight from Hong Kong.

U.S. prosecutors charged Snowden last month with espionage and theft of government property. On Monday, the U.S. Ambassador in Moscow, Michael McFaul, demanded Russia turn over Snowden, stating via Twitter, "Mr. Snowden ought to be returned to the United States to face the felony charges against him."

Russian state news agency RIA Novosti quoted an unnamed security official on Wednesday as saying that Snowden has been issued documents, allowing him to formally enter Russia. However, this information has not been confirmed, and Anna Zakharenkova, a spokeswoman for the airport, told The Associated Press that Anatoly Kucherena, a Russian lawyer advising Snowden, would meet with him.

President Vladimir Putin has stated that Snowden can be granted asylum in Russia only if he stops leaking secrets. Granting Snowden asylum would add new tensions to U.S.-Russian relations already strained by criticism of Russia's pressure on opposition groups, Moscow's suspicion of U.S. missile-defense plans, and Russia's resistance to sanctions against the regime of Syrian President Bashar Assad.

Title: U.S. Calls for Integration of Religious Freedom into Foreign Policy Amidst Middle East Crisis

Article:

The Middle East and North Africa are currently witnessing a surge in attacks against Christianity, with terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) systematically destroying ancient Christian communities and relics. The Obama Administration is under scrutiny for its lack of action in protecting religious freedom abroad, particularly in Syria and Iraq, where Christians are fleeing their homes in large numbers, creating a refugee crisis of grave consequences for the entire region.

The United States, Europe, and key allies have been criticized for their inaction against ISIS's efforts to drive out and eradicate religious communities from their historic and sacred homelands. The Obama Administration has been accused of ignoring the devastating cost of religious persecution on targeted communities. As a nation founded on the principles of religious freedom, America can and must do more to combat religious intolerance, a significant factor in the political instability and violence that plagues the region today.

To counter ISIS's strategy, the Obama Administration could build alliances with popular local and regional leaders who can expose radical ideologies' moral bankruptcy and champion pluralism and tolerance. The Administration should also combat terrorist propaganda about religious minorities and develop programs that promote tolerance and empower minorities to better advocate for their rights and interests. By reaffirming the importance of religious freedom and working closely with communities and their governments, the U.S. can strip away sympathy and support for ISIS and other extremist groups.

A foreign policy committed to religious freedom can advance national security interests, stabilize and consolidate the spread of democracy, help sustain economic growth, and promote the equality of men and women. It can also prevent religiously-motivated terrorism and undermine the conditions that have helped spur the rise of groups like ISIS, Boko Haram, and the Shuddhikaran Movement.

Moreover, higher levels of religious freedom are associated with higher levels of economic productivity and growth, as recent studies by groups such as the Religious Freedom and Business Foundation have found. Sustainable political and economic development is only possible when religious freedom and equal opportunity contribute to a secure environment in which citizens and businesses can operate freely.

Lastly, the U.S. must remain committed to religious freedom because of the special distinction religious freedom holds as a fundamental human right—a belief shared by democratic countries across the globe and protected by numerous international treaties and agreements. American support for religious liberty sends a powerful message to threatened communities worldwide: America is your friend. Such support builds enduring goodwill towards our country among those who could be leading their own nations in the years ahead. It also reminds all observers, whether friendly or hostile, that the U.S. remains committed to a world where justice and human dignity are central to legitimate governance.

Title: Kamala Harris Ends 2020 Presidential Bid, Marking Historic Exit from Democratic Race

SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) — Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) announced on Tuesday that she was ending her bid for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, marking a significant moment in a campaign that once held historic potential.

In a statement to supporters, Harris, the first woman and first black attorney general and U.S. senator in California's history, cited insufficient funds as the reason for her decision. "My campaign for president simply doesn't have the financial resources we need to continue," she said.

A senior campaign aide confirmed that Harris made the decision on Monday after discussing the path forward with family and other top officials over the Thanksgiving holiday.

Harris launched her campaign in front of 20,000 people on a chilly January day in Oakland, California. She was widely viewed as a candidate poised to excite the multiracial coalition of voters that sent Barack Obama to the White House. However, her fundraising remained flat as the field grew, and she was unable to attract the attention being showered on other candidates such as Pete Buttigieg and Elizabeth Warren.

In her note to supporters, Harris lamented the role of money in politics and took a shot at billionaire candidates Tom Steyer and Michael Bloomberg, who are funding their own presidential bids. "I'm not a billionaire. I can't fund my own campaign. And as the campaign has gone on, it's become harder and harder to raise the money we need to compete," she said.

Harris suffered from what allies and critics viewed as an inconsistent pitch to voters. Her slogan "For the people" referenced her career as a prosecutor, a record that was viewed skeptically by the party's most progressive voters. Through the summer, she focused on pocketbook issues and her "3 a.m. agenda," a message that never seemed to resonate with voters. By the fall, she had returned to her courtroom roots with the refrain that "justice is on the ballot," both a cry for economic and social justice as well as her call that she could "prosecute the case" against a "criminal" president.

At times, she was tripped up by confusing policy positions, particularly on health care. After suggesting she would eliminate private insurance in favor of a fully government-run system, Harris eventually rolled out a health care plan that preserves a role for private insurance.

Stumbles, often of the campaign's making, continued to dog Harris into the winter, stymieing her ability to capitalize on solid moments. Harris kicked off November with a well-received speech at a massive Iowa dinner, just a day after her campaign announced it would fire staff at its Baltimore headquarters and was moving some people from other early states to Iowa.

Her message was regularly overshadowed by campaign aides and allies sharing grievances with the news media. Several top aides decamped for other campaigns, one leaving a blistering resignation letter.

With Harris' exit, 15 Democrats remain in the race for the nomination. Several praised her on Tuesday. Former Vice President Joe Biden, who had a memorable debate stage tussle with Harris this summer, called the senator a "solid person, loaded with talent." Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders commended Harris for "running a spirited and issue-oriented campaign." New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, one of two black candidates still in the campaign, called Harris a "trailblazer."

Harris anchored her campaign in the powerful legacy of pioneering African Americans. Her campaign launch on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday included a nod to Shirley Chisholm, the New York congresswoman who sought the Democratic Party's presidential nomination 47 years ago earlier. One of her first stops as a candidate was to Howard University, the historically black college that she attended as an undergraduate. She spent much of her early campaign focusing on South Carolina, which hosts the first Southern primary and has a significant African American population.

However, Harris struggled to chip away at Biden's deep advantage with black voters who are critical to winning the Democratic nomination. Harris and her aides believe she faced an uphill battle—and unfair expectations for perfection—from the start as a woman of color. Her campaign speech included a line about what Harris called the "donkey in the room," a reference to the thought that Americans wouldn't elect a woman of color. Harris often suggested it was criticism she faced in her other campaigns—all of which she won.

Her departure from the presidential race marks her first defeat as a political candidate.

Title: Obama's Apology and Healthcare.gov Progress: A Political Dilemma Unfolds

Article:

In a rare moment of political vulnerability, President Obama apologized last week to those who were misled by his promise that everyone could keep their existing insurance policies. However, the apology was not the most newsworthy moment of the interview, as the President also provided an update on the progress of the administration's efforts to fix Healthcare.gov.

"I'm confident that it will be even better by November 30 and that the majority of people are going to be able to get on there," Obama said. "They're going to be able to enroll. They're going to be able to apply. And they're going to get a good deal -- a better deal than they've got right now when it comes to buying health insurance."

However, the administration's progress report on Thursday painted a different picture. A spokeswoman for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services told reporters on a conference call that as they fix certain pieces of functionality, new issues are being identified. This suggests a process akin to plumbers working a clogged pipe, with each blockage revealing another issue deeper in the system.

The administration maintains that it is confident Healthcare.gov will be working for the vast majority of users by the end of the month. However, its detailed assessments make this increasingly hard to believe. Insurance industry officials do not share the administration's confidence, and Republicans in Congress are already preparing to capitalize on the situation.

The political problem is almost as intractable, and in many ways could interfere with key policy imperatives. This week, Republicans will put legislation on the House floor that would require insurance companies to allow people to keep their recently canceled plans for another year. The bill has little policy merit, but it is on the right side of public opinion and is intended to fracture the pro-Obamacare coalition. If it ever clears the Senate, Obama would likely have to veto it.

A working website would limit the political consequences the canceled plans are causing, but it is in many ways a distinct problem. Republicans would continue to use the cancellations as impetus to undermine the law even if Healthcare.gov were functioning as well as Amazon. The administration is looking for an administrative remedy for cancellation letter recipients, but there is no obvious solution that would not require congressional action, and Republicans would block congressional action that addresses the problem without undermining the law.

In other words, Obama is facing a political nightmare, and we are not even at the point of contemplating the damage Republicans will inflict if the site is not working by the end of the month. Democrats in Congress will then face increasing pressure to agree to a GOP plan to delay the individual mandate penalty for a year. The administration may have the authority it needs to circumvent Congress here, but it would have to be prepared to admit failure first.

Title: Trump's Letter to Pelosi: A Scathing Rebuttal Against Impeachment as an "Illegal, Partisan Attempted Coup"

Article:

In a six-page personal letter sent to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday, President Donald Trump has lashed out against the impeachment process, labeling it an "illegal, partisan attempted coup." The letter, which serves as a historical record, is expected to have little impact on the anticipated Wednesday vote that could make Trump the third U.S. president to be impeached.

The letter, written in a tone that reflects Trump's grievances with the process and Pelosi's conduct, is a compilation of the president's criticisms. Trump accuses Pelosi of being inauthentic for claiming to pray for him, and he takes issue with her demeanor throughout the impeachment process.

The president contends that "more due process was afforded to those accused in the Salem Witch Trials," and accuses Pelosi of turning a "policy disagreement" into an impeachable offense. He also refers to the impeachment as a "policy disagreement" and suggests that Pelosi is trying to undo the results of the 2016 election due to her preferred candidate's loss.

Trump's letter, filled with exclamation points, accuses Pelosi of interfering in America's elections, subverting democracy, and obstructing justice. He also accuses her of causing pain and suffering to the republic for personal, political, and partisan gain.

Minutes after the letter's release, Trump adopted a more subdued tone during a meeting with the President of Guatemala, stating that he takes "zero" personal responsibility for the impeachment. Trump maintains that the phone call with the President of Ukraine, which is at the heart of the impeachment inquiry, was "perfect." He described the impeachment of a U.S. president over the call as a "disgrace" and a "mark on our country."

Title: Trump Threatens to Withhold Federal Funds for California Wildfire Response, Sparking Controversy

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a series of tweets on Wednesday, President Donald Trump threatened to cut off federal funds for California wildfire response, stating that the money is being wasted. The tweets read, "Billions of dollars are sent to the State of California for Forest fires that, with proper Forest Management, would never happen. Unless they get their act together, which is unlikely, I have ordered FEMA to send no more money. It is a disgraceful situation in lives & money!"

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., responded to Trump's threat, stating, "The President's threat insults the memory of scores of Americans who perished in wildfires last year & thousands more who lost their homes. House Republican leader Kevin McCarthy, another Californian,'must join me to condemn & call on POTUS to reassure millions in CA that our govt will be there for them in their time of need."

Trump has previously threatened to order the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to cut off funds for California wildfires, but the administration has not published an order. Critics on Twitter questioned whether Trump could legally withhold FEMA money that has been appropriated.

State officials accused Trump of playing politics with the California wildfires and said he does not understand the issues involved in fighting fires. They questioned whether Trump is going after California because it is a Democratic state.

Brian Rice, president of the California Professional Firefighters, cited the damage in and around Paradise, California, and said the people there "have only begun to be able to rebuild their lives.... Now, they find themselves being used as pawns in the president’s ill-informed chest-pounding at their expense."

Rice also stated that Trump is wrong to blame the fires on state forest management. "While forest health can be a contributing factor in large fires," he noted, "more than 60 percent of these forests are controlled by the federal government, not California."

California Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has criticized Trump over firefighting policy, tweeted after the president's shutdown speech Tuesday that "Trump's go-to is governing by fear and division."

Tuesday, the newly inaugurated Newsom proposed $105 million in new spending to prevent, fight, and escape wildfires in the wake of one of the state's worst fire seasons.

Trump has a history of declaring policy decisions only to change or modify them days later, as seen in the slowed-down withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria. The ongoing situation between the White House and California continues to unfold.

Title: Navigating Grocery Shopping in the Time of Coronavirus: A Guide for Safe and Efficient Shopping

Article:

In the current pandemic situation, a simple trip to the grocery store can become a daunting task. Here are some recommendations to help you prepare for a safe and efficient shopping experience.

1. Organize Your List: Before heading to the store, take a few extra moments to organize your list by department or aisle. This will help you move quickly through the store and avoid criss-crossing aisles.

2. Shop Alone: If possible, avoid taking children or partners to the store. Limiting the number of people in the store at one time will make it easier to maintain physical distancing.

3. Combine Shopping Trips: If you can, consider combining your shopping trips with others in your community to minimize their travel and your time in the store.

4. Expect Lines: Some stores may have lines outside the entrance due to staff limiting the number of shoppers. Plan your trip accordingly and expect to wait.

5. Wear Earphones: If the idea of making small talk in line makes you uncomfortable, consider wearing earphones.

6. Sanitize Cart and Items: Some stores are sanitizing carts between shoppers, while others are allowing customers to wipe down their own carts. Ask an employee if you're unsure about the store's policy.

7. Maintain Physical Distance: Be patient and avoid getting too close to others. Remember to be forgiving if someone invades your personal space—they may have been distracted by their own grocery list.

8. Expect Out-of-Stock Items: Many stores may be out of common items like eggs, toilet paper, and bread. Be prepared for empty shelves and have alternatives in mind.

9. Communicate with Household Members: If you're shopping for multiple households, ask them about their preferences for alternative items before you go shopping. This can help reduce your shopping time and set expectations for those who stayed home.

10. No Reusable Bags: Some stores may not accept reusable bags due to concerns about the virus. If you typically bag your own groceries, this may not impact you as much. The virus isn't known to survive long on soft items like tote bags, but some stores that usually have baggers have been offering paper or plastic bags only.

By following these recommendations, you can help ensure a safer and more efficient grocery shopping experience during the coronavirus pandemic.

Title: Timeline of Events Leading to the Death of 8-Year-Old Migrant Felipe Alonzo-Gomez in US Custody

An 8-year-old migrant, identified as Felipe Alonzo-Gomez, passed away in the custody of US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) on Christmas Eve. The child's death follows the death of a 7-year-old Guatemalan girl in CBP custody just weeks prior.

According to a timeline provided by CBP, Felipe was apprehended with his father near the Paso Del Norte port of entry in El Paso, Texas for illegal entry. The apprehension location is approximately 3 miles west of the port.

Felipe and his father were transferred to the Paso Del Norte processing center, where they were provided with food, snacks, juice, and water. Six welfare checks were logged during their detention. They were then transferred to the El Paso Border Patrol Station, where they received showers, food, juice, and water, and 17 welfare checks were logged over the next two days.

The father and son were subsequently transferred to the Alamogordo Border Patrol Station in Alamogordo, New Mexico due to capacity levels at the El Paso station. Upon arrival, they were provided with personal hygiene products and meals, and several welfare checks were conducted.

A processing agent noticed that Felipe was coughing and appeared to have glossy eyes. About 30 minutes later, based on the agents' observations, Felipe was transferred to Gerald Champion Regional Medical Center in Alamogordo with possible influenza symptoms. He was accompanied by his father.

At the hospital, Felipe was diagnosed with a common cold and given Tylenol. He was evaluated for release but was found to have a 103-degree fever and was held for continued observation. Felipe was released from the emergency room with a prescription for Ibuprofen and amoxicillin, a commonly prescribed antibiotic.

Felipe and his father were transported to temporary holding at the Highway 70 checkpoint. While at the checkpoint, Felipe and his father were offered and accepted a hot meal. Agents provided Felipe with a dose of the prescribed medication as ordered by the medical staff, and agents conducted several welfare checks that evening.

However, Felipe appeared to be nauseous and vomited. Agents were aware of this and helped clean up the vomit. His father declined further medical assistance as the child had been feeling better. Because no Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) was on duty, out of caution, agents made the decision to return Felipe and his father to Gerald Champion Regional Medical Center.

During transportation to the hospital, he began to vomit and lost consciousness. Hospital staff were unable to revive Felipe and pronounced him dead. The Guatemalan Consulate was contacted about the child's death. His father is currently detained at the Alamogordo Station pending transfer to ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations. He has spoken to his spouse in Guatemala and the Guatemalan Consulate.

The Guatemalan Foreign Ministry issued a statement that it was alerted to a minor's death in the US. Guatemala's Consul General in Phoenix, Oscar Padilla Lam, traveled to Alamogordo to meet with the boy's father to "hear his version of the facts," according to the statement.
