The Foreign Ministry said it will provide all assistance and consular protection to the boy's father and assume responsibility for the repatriation of the boy's remains.

Title: Former FBI Agent Peter Strzok Testifies: Hillary Clinton Not a Target in Email Investigation

Article:

In a series of transcripts released Thursday, former FBI Agent Peter Strzok told Congress that Hillary Clinton was not a target, witness, subject, or suspect during the investigation into her storage and sending of classified emails on her home server. The transcripts were inserted into the Congressional Record by Rep. Doug Collins (R-GA) during a floor speech, defying the Justice Department's slow pace in releasing the information for public consumption.

According to Strzok, Clinton was not considered a target by the Justice Department, but rather a "critical player" in the investigation. He emphasized that she was "not by any means the only person that we had an investigative interest in."

During his testimony to the House Judiciary Committee last year, Strzok also admitted to having an affair with FBI lawyer Lisa Page, despite knowing that, as a top counterintelligence officer, such a relationship made him vulnerable to being blackmailed by America's enemies. He also revealed that he knew of one instance where someone was recruited through such means.

The Strzok transcript is the third set released by Rep. Collins, following those from Justice Department official Bruce Ohr and Page herself. The transcript shows some surprising disconnects between Strzok and Page, particularly in their text messages.

For instance, in one text, Page told Strzok that he was fated to be investigating Donald Trump to save the country from a "menace." However, in her testimony, Page stated that the menace was Trump himself, while Strzok believed the menace referred to Russia.

Strzok also disputed the meaning of the now-infamous text exchange where Page expressed concern that Trump would become president and he replied, "No. No he won't. We'll stop it." In his June 27, 2018, closed-door appearance with the Judiciary Committee, Strzok clarified that he did not mean he would stop Trump from becoming president. Instead, he said he believed the "we" he was referring to was the country at large.

Strzok also defended his texts in March 2016, before Clinton had won the Democratic nomination and before Trump had the GOP nomination, where he said Clinton "should" win the White House 100 million to zero. Strzok maintained that his confidence in Clinton did not color his investigative efforts.

The transcripts provide insight into the ongoing investigation into Clinton's emails and the role of key figures like Strzok and Page during the 2016 election. The release of these transcripts comes as the Justice Department continues to face criticism for its handling of the investigation.

Title: Justice Scalia's Views on the Death Penalty and the McCollum-Brown Case

Article:

In a recent development, the case of Henry Lee McCollum and Leon Brown, two mentally disabled brothers who were wrongfully convicted and sentenced to death, has sparked a debate on the morality and effectiveness of the death penalty. The case, which has been in the spotlight due to DNA evidence exonerating the two men, has raised questions about the role of judges who support the death penalty, particularly Associate Justice Antonin Scalia, who has been vocal in his support for capital punishment.

The case against McCollum and Brown, who were 19 and 15 at the time of the murder, was based on coerced confessions. The conviction was later reduced to life in prison, but it was only after a state commission investigated the case that DNA from the crime scene was tested and other evidence implicated another convicted rapist, exonerating these two men.

In the past, Justice Scalia has cited this case in his decisions on the constitutionality of the death penalty. In the Collins v. Collins case in 1994, Scalia disagreed with Justice Harry Blackmun, who disavowed his former support for capital punishment and declared that he would no longer "tinker with the machinery of death." Scalia, in his characteristic sarcasm, wrote:

"Justice Blackmun begins his statement by describing with poignancy the death of a convicted murderer by lethal injection. He chooses, as the case in which to make that statement, one of the less brutal of the murders that regularly come before us, the murder of a man ripped by a bullet suddenly and unexpectedly, with no opportunity to prepare himself and his affairs, and left to bleed to death on the floor of a tavern. The death-by-injection which Justice Blackmun describes looks pretty desirable next to that."

The case of McCollum and Brown, with its brutal slaying and 30 years spent in prison, highlights the potential harm of false and coerced confessions and the power of DNA tests to exonerate the innocent. The legal system, it seems, obscured the truth at every level and every step along the way.

Justice Scalia, in his comments, suggests that the methods of punishment should be directly correlated to the luridness of the crime, a concept rejected by the Enlightenment-influenced writers of the Constitution he alleges to take so literally. Death penalty supporters often use cases like this to illustrate that "the system worked" and, by implication, always works. However, as the McCollum-Brown case demonstrates, the only reason it worked was because of an outside commission's investigation, which uncovered malfeasance, a coverup, and a corrupt indifference to justice.

Justice Scalia has stated that the Constitution does not forbid the execution of a convicted defendant who has had a full and fair trial but is later able to convince a habeas court that he is "actually" innocent. This stance has raised concerns about the potential execution of innocent people and the moral implications of such a mistake or criminal corruption.

In light of the McCollum-Brown case, the question arises: How can a person who claims that he could not be a judge if he thought his participation in the death penalty was immoral, yet does not believe it matters under the Constitution if the state executes innocent people, be on the Supreme Court of the United States? On what basis can our country lay claim to a superior system of justice and a civilized moral order when such people hold power?

Title: Younger Generations' Growing Affinity for Socialism and Misunderstanding of Capitalism

Article:

A new poll by YouGov/Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation reveals a significant shift in the political leanings of younger generations, with a majority of Millennials and Generation Z expressing a willingness to vote for a socialist candidate. The survey, which polled 2,100 individuals aged 16 and over, found that 70 percent of Millennials and 64 percent of Generation Z are somewhat or extremely likely to vote for a socialist.

The trend toward socialism appears to be accompanied by a dwindling support for capitalism, with 50 percent of Millennials and 51 percent of Generation Z holding a somewhat or very unfavorable view of capitalism. This shift in political ideology coincides with a seemingly foggy understanding of economic philosophies and recent history.

According to Pew Research, Millennials are better educated than earlier generations, with a higher percentage holding college and postgraduate degrees. However, when it comes to an economic education, younger Americans appear to be in the dark. Socialism, as defined by the Concise Encyclopedia of Economics, is a "centrally planned economy in which the government controls all means of production."

The appeal of socialism to young people, as described by Matt Kibbe of the libertarian organization Free the People, is rooted in values and personal experiences rather than empirical facts. Kibbe suggests that socialism, in the narrative of Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, is associated with community, cooperation, and dignity. However, these values are not historically part of socialist reality, as demonstrated by the failures of socialist systems in countries like Venezuela, Cuba, and North Korea.

Despite their apparent affinity for socialism, Millennials and Generation Z also embrace entrepreneurship and small business, hallmarks of capitalism. However, they do not connect these activities with capitalism and a free market.

The growing love affair with socialism among younger Americans is further evidenced by their lack of understanding of basic economic philosophies and recent history. A YouGov poll found that almost 20 percent of Millennials thought the Communist Manifesto "better guarantees freedom and equality for all" than the Declaration of Independence, compared to just two percent of Baby Boomers and five percent of Gen X.

Furthermore, a YouGov survey last year found that 87 percent of high school students flunked a five-question test of basic knowledge about American history, the worst of any age group. High school students were also least likely to know who is on Mount Rushmore and could not name the rights enumerated in the First Amendment.

A 2018 poll further revealed Millennial ignorance of history about the seminal event of the twentieth century, World War II, with two-thirds of American Millennials unable to identify the Nazi extermination camp of Auschwitz, and 22 percent saying they had not heard of the Holocaust or were not sure whether they had.

The oldest of the Millennials were small children when the Berlin Wall was knocked down, and they never felt the threat of the Cuban Missile Crisis or experienced nuclear war drills. They have not lived through the rantings of Comrade Khruschev or the slaughter of millions by socialist regimes.

Representative Ocasio-Cortez has stated that her generation has never known true prosperity. For a generation who views history only through its own experience, the idea of a college debt bailout may seem like the socialist dream come true. However, according to Kibbe, the misery AOC blames on capitalism is not reality.

"Those of us that crunch numbers… by any conceivable measure, we are living in the most prosperous, most opportunistic, most beautiful times in the history of the universe," Kibbe said, "but… there's a lot of reasons, from [Ocasio-Cortez's] perspective, that things could suck, even though things are the best they've ever been."

Title: Former Homeland Security Secretary Criticizes White House for Dismissing July 4 Terror Warning as "Standard Operating Procedure"

Article:

In a recent interview on Fox News Channel's "Your World with Neil Cavuto," former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge criticized the White House for dismissing the government's July 4 weekend terror warning as "standard operating procedure." The comment, made by White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest, was deemed inaccurate by Ridge.

Ridge, who served as the first Secretary of Homeland Security from 2001 to 2005, stated, "It's a real threat. I think it's a permanent threat. I think this is a scourge with which we're going to have to deal with... for the foreseeable future."

Former CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell echoed Ridge's sentiments, urging Americans to take the threat seriously. "I wouldn't be surprised if we're sitting here a week from today talking about an attack over the weekend in the United States. That's how serious this is," Morell said on Monday.

The heightened threat level comes amid a "confluence of events," as House Homeland Security Chairman Mike McCaul termed it on Sunday. The upcoming July 4 holiday, which celebrates America's founding, coincides with ISIS celebrating its one-year anniversary of major territorial wins this week. Additionally, Internet traffic has seen ISIS calling for the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, currently underway, to be changed from a month of peace to a month of calamities.

ISIS claimed responsibility for three terror attacks on Friday across three continents, which Ridge suggested were likely coordinated. "This is a global scourge, and, frankly, until the White House, until this president, western allies, and countries in that region, with the exception of Iran, get serious about destroying ISIL, we're going to be living with this threat on a fairly regular basis," Ridge said.

The warning was issued by the FBI, Homeland Security, and National Counterterrorism Center, and unless the United States takes a more aggressive stance against ISIS, the warning "may ultimately become a standard warning, i.e., we're at risk all the time," Ridge cautioned. "Not to be breathless, but that is the reality of the new world as long as we let ISIL expand its reach beyond Syria and Iraq," he warned.

Title: Federal Workers, Contractors File for Unemployment as Shutdown Reaches Record Length

Article:

In the nation's capital, federal workers and contractors are turning to unemployment offices as the partial government shutdown enters its record-breaking fourth week. Long-time federal contractor John Woodson, who would typically be receiving a paycheck, filed for unemployment benefits on Thursday morning.

"We should still be at work right now," said Woodson. "Politicians should handle this—don't put this on the citizens. You're hurting us."

Even if Woodson can secure unemployment benefits, which pay up to $425 a week in Washington D.C., he says it won't be enough to support his family. "I might have to wash some cars, go back detailing or wash some windows—whatever it takes to put some food on the table," said Woodson.

Federal workers and contractors are missing paychecks for the first time since the partial government shutdown began on December 22. This situation is causing some of these workers to do what once seemed unthinkable—apply for unemployment.

"The reason that I chose a public sector job was the stability of the whole thing," said Steve, a federal employee who also visited a D.C. unemployment office. He preferred to use a pseudonym due to potential repercussions. Steve left a higher-paying job in the private sector to work for the government. A significant factor in his decision was a shared sense of mission.

"The real benefit was a job that I felt appreciated at—a job that had stability," said Steve. "And right now, I feel unappreciated and unstable."

Officials in D.C. and Maryland report at least 7,000 unemployment claims have been filed by federal government workers and contractors since the shutdown began. This number is expected to rise significantly if the shutdown, now the longest in U.S. history, continues. In total, approximately 800,000 employees have been affected by the shutdown. An estimated 420,000 are working without pay, according to the Senate Appropriations Committee, while another 380,000 are on furlough.

At a rally for federal workers and their supporters in Silver Spring, Md., on Wednesday, some federal workers said they had no choice but to consider applying for unemployment benefits.

"This is the first time in my working life I am going to have to go to my creditors and say 'I don't know how to pay you.' And it's embarrassing," said Michelle, a long-time federal employee who preferred to remain anonymous due to potential repercussions.

Michelle fought back tears as she spoke with a group of women about how to apply for unemployment benefits. She never expected to be in this position.

"I show up to work. I do a good job. I'm doing everything a responsible adult is supposed to do," said Michelle. "All of a sudden, it's all blown up, and I don't know what else to do."

According to the federal government, the shutdown will cost at least $50 million a day in lost wages and productivity. However, there are hidden costs beyond money, said Randy Erwin, president of the National Federation of Federal Employees.

"Who in the world is going to want to work for the federal government when [workers] are disrespected...when people are not able to fill prescriptions, bouncing checks [and] ruining their credit?" said Erwin, whose union represents 100,000 federal workers.

The details surrounding who is—and isn't—eligible for unemployment can get complicated. Federal employees who've been furloughed can apply for unemployment benefits; workers who've been deemed "essential" and are working without pay are not eligible for unemployment.

Furthermore, federal employees who do receive unemployment benefits will have to reimburse the government if Congress votes to give employees backpay—which typically happens when the government re-opens. The U.S. Office of Personnel Management has issued guidance for furloughed workers on what to do during a shutdown—including how to write to creditors and mortgage companies.

On Friday, President Trump said he would sign a bill passed by both the House and the Senate to give back pay to federal workers affected by the shutdown.

Title: Historic Prisoner Exchange: American Contractor Alan Gross Returns Home After Five Years in Cuban Prison

Article:

In a significant development, American contractor Alan Gross has returned to the United States following his release from a Cuban prison after five years of imprisonment. The landmark humanitarian prisoner exchange was announced today by President Obama at the White House, marking a first step towards normalizing relations with the neighboring island nation just 90 miles off the Florida coast.

The prisoner exchange, the result of over a year of secret back-channel talks at the highest levels of both governments, represents a significant milestone in U.S.-Cuba relations. The U.S. and Cuba are now set to begin talks to restore diplomatic relations, with the U.S. planning to re-establish an embassy in Havana, as announced by the White House.

President Obama stated, "Today, the United States is taking historic steps to chart a new course in our relations with Cuba and to further engage and empower the Cuban people." He further added, "We are separated by 90 miles of water, but brought together through the relationships between the two million Cubans and Americans of Cuban descent that live in the United States, and the 11 million Cubans who share similar hopes for a more positive future for Cuba."

The announcement follows a phone conversation between Obama and Cuban President Raul Castro on Tuesday, a conversation described as a "summing up" of the work done over the past year leading up to these changes. The leaders discussed issues of importance in the hemisphere, while acknowledging that they will have differences to address in the future. According to a senior administration official, Obama made clear his intent to maintain U.S. advocacy for human rights in Cuba.

Gross was convicted of espionage by a Cuban court in 2011 and sentenced to 15 years for bringing telecommunication devices into Cuba while working as a subcontractor for the United States Agency for International Development. The Cuban government accused him of being party to a U.S.-led plot to overthrow the government through an "Arab spring."

In a statement released earlier this month to mark the anniversary of Gross' time in jail, Gross' wife Judy said, "Enough is enough. My husband has paid a terrible price for serving his country and community."

In return for Gross, the United States has agreed to the humanitarian release of three Cuban agents convicted of espionage in a controversial trial that found them guilty of spying on anti-Castro groups in Miami, but not the U.S. government. All three were most recently held in North Carolina at a federal medical facility for the U.S. Bureau of Prisons.

This humanitarian release marks the beginning of a promised new relationship with Cuba. The White House is indicating the beginning of new talks on everything from travel restrictions to eventual lifting of the Cuban embargo, which has been in place since John F. Kennedy was president.

In an interview last week with Jorge Ramos for Fusion, President Obama stated, "We've been in conversations about how we can get Alan Gross home for quite some time." He further added, "We continue to be concerned about him. We think that he shouldn't have been held in the first place."

Stay tuned for real-time updates as this story unfolds. To follow this story, simply "star" this article in the ███ phone app. Download ███ for iPhone here or ███ for Android here. To be notified about our live weekend digital reports, tap here.

Title: Prosecutor's Assessment Could Influence GOP Senators' Vote on Kavanaugh Confirmation

Article:

In a significant development, the sex-crimes prosecutor hired by Republicans to question Brett Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford during Thursday's hearing informed senators that the case would not hold up in a courtroom, according to sources speaking to Fox News. This guidance, provided by Rachel Mitchell, could potentially sway undecided senators ahead of a crucial Senate Judiciary Committee vote scheduled for Friday afternoon.

Mitchell, who spoke at an overnight meeting attended by all 51 Republican senators, reportedly told them that she would not charge Kavanaugh and would not even seek a search warrant. Her opinion could prove crucial as senators prepare to cast their votes.

The Republican Senators, including President Trump, have emphasized that the sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh lack first-hand corroboration. However, Ford testified that Kavanaugh and a friend allegedly trapped her in a room during a high school gathering in 1982, and Kavanaugh attempted to force himself on her before she escaped. Ford maintained that she is "100 percent" sure it was him, while Kavanaugh adamantly denied the allegations.

With 48 Republican senators pledging to vote for Kavanaugh at the scheduled full Senate vote on Tuesday, the outstanding Republicans are Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Mike Enzi of Wyoming. Enzi is expected to vote in support of Kavanaugh, but has not yet announced his position.

Collins, Murkowski, Flake, and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin could potentially vote as a bloc. The source told Fox News that Collins, Murkowski, and Flake met with Manchin on the sidelines Thursday evening to discuss the nomination. They spoke for approximately 30 minutes.

Republican Sen. Jeff Flake, who sits on the Judiciary Committee, said Thursday night that "it's a tough one." He added, "If you're making an allegation, you want there to be some corroboration. Where is the burden? It's like impeachment. You don't know."

Democratic Sens. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota and Joe Donnelly of Indiana have not yet revealed their voting intentions. Early Friday, Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., announced that he would vote "no."

Republicans hold a narrow 51-49 majority in the Senate, and can only afford one defection in their bid to confirm Kavanaugh, assuming they secure no Democratic votes. Other Republican senators, such as Sen. Bob Corker, have come out in support of Kavanaugh late Thursday.

Kavanaugh vehemently denied the allegations leveled against him, calling the process a "national disgrace" and a "circus." In his opening statement, Kavanaugh emphasized the Constitution's role in the confirmation process, stating, "But you have replaced advise and consent with search and destroy."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., announced a full Senate vote for Tuesday. "I think we're going to go ahead," Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said. "I worry about every one of these votes."

Title: Facebook's Privacy Agreement with Regulators: A Look at the Company's Data Sharing Practices and Internal Resistance

Article:

Facebook's agreement with regulators, finalized in 2011, stems from the social media giant's early experiments with data sharing. In late 2009, the company altered the privacy settings of its 400 million users, making some of their information accessible to all internet users. This information, including users' locations and religious and political leanings, was then shared with Microsoft and other partners.

This initiative, dubbed "instant personalization," was promoted as a step towards a more customized internet, where companies would use the information to enhance user experiences on sites like Bing. However, the feature drew criticism from privacy advocates and Facebook users, who felt their information was shared without their consent.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) investigated these practices and, in 2011, cited the privacy changes as a deceptive practice. Caught off guard, Facebook officials ceased mentioning instant personalization in public and entered into a consent agreement.

Under the decree, Facebook introduced a "comprehensive privacy program" designed to review new products and features. Initially overseen by two chief privacy officers, this program was intended to demonstrate Facebook's commitment to privacy. The company also hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to assess its privacy practices every two years.

However, according to four former Facebook employees with direct knowledge of the company's efforts, this privacy program faced internal resistance from the start. Some engineers and executives considered the privacy reviews an impediment to quick innovation and growth. The core team responsible for coordinating the reviews, numbering about a dozen people by 2016, was moved around within Facebook's organization, sending mixed signals about the company's commitment to privacy.

Critically, many of Facebook's special sharing partnerships were not subject to extensive privacy program reviews, according to two of the former employees. Executives believed that because these partnerships were governed by business contracts requiring them to follow Facebook's data policies, they did not require the same level of scrutiny. The privacy team had limited ability to review or suggest changes to some of these data-sharing agreements, which had been negotiated by more senior officials at the company.

Facebook officials contend that members of the privacy team were consulted on the sharing agreements, but the level of review "depended on the specific partnership and the time it was created." This revelation underscores the ongoing challenge of balancing innovation, growth, and privacy in the digital age.

Title: US Senate Confirms Gina Haspel as First Female CIA Director, Despite Controversial Past

Article:

The United States Senate has confirmed Gina Haspel as the first female director of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), despite her role in the agency's post-9/11 interrogation program. The confirmation came in a 54-45 vote, following a partisan debate among senators regarding the CIA's use of enhanced interrogation techniques during the Bush era.

Gina Haspel, a CIA veteran, once oversaw a covert detention site in Thailand following the September 11, 2001 attacks. Her confirmation as the CIA's director follows the departure of former CIA chief Mike Pompeo, who left to serve as the U.S. Secretary of State.

Senator John McCain, a Republican who was tortured during his more than five years in a Vietnamese prison, had previously announced his opposition to President Donald Trump's nominee. However, six Democrats crossed party lines to vote in her favor on Thursday.

Virginia Senator Mark Warner, one of the Democrats who voted for Haspel, said she had told him the agency should never have resorted to enhanced interrogation techniques. Warner also said Haspel had pledged never to use such methods if the president demanded it.

"I believe she is someone who can and will stand up to the president, who will speak truth to power if this president orders her to do something illegal or immoral, like a return to torture," Warner said in a speech before the vote.

Two Republicans, Jeff Flake and Rand Paul, voted against Haspel, meaning she would not have been confirmed without support from Democrats.

Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee Richard Burr said the confirmation of a woman as CIA head would send an important message. "Many others who have served, or are currently serving, have cracked the glass ceiling at the agency. Gina is poised to break it," he said.

"It may be impossible to measure the importance of that breakthrough, but I do know that it will send a signal to the current workforce and to the workforce of the future that a lifetime of commitment to the agency can and will be rewarded," Burr added.

A 33-year veteran of the agency, Haspel, 61, spent most of her career as an undercover operative. In 2002, she was selected by the agency to run a "black site" in Thailand where harsh interrogation techniques were used that a Senate report deemed to be torture. One suspect that was brought there, Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, was subjected to sleep deprivation, nudity, extreme temperatures, being held in a small box, and "walling" (being slammed repeatedly into a wall).

Three years later, Haspel ordered the destruction of 92 video tapes that documented the interrogation of al-Nashiri and Abu Zubaydah, who were also held at the Thai location. At least 119 men were tortured by the US in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center and Pentagon, according to a 2014 Senate report. Human rights groups say Haspel left Thailand to oversee further US torture, but it is unclear what role she played as her exact record has been classified by the CIA.

President Trump has previously called for the US to resume waterboarding terrorism suspects.

Title: U.S. Senate Reviews U.S.-Saudi Relations Amid Yemen Crisis, Highlights Iran's Role in Yemen Conflict

Article:

The U.S. Senate is currently reviewing U.S. relations with Saudi Arabia, focusing on the country's involvement in the Yemen conflict, following the brutal murder of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul in October. However, the humanitarian crisis in Yemen, caused by the ongoing conflict between the Saudi-supported government and the Iran-backed Houthi rebels, has received less attention.

The humanitarian crisis in Yemen is severe. The conflict, which has reportedly claimed over 57,000 lives, has driven half of Yemen's 28 million people to the brink of famine, and displaced 2.3 million Yemenis from their homes.

The U.S. has significant interests in ending Yemen's humanitarian crisis and preventing Iran and its Shi'a terrorist proxies, as well as Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and ISIS-Yemen, from establishing permanent footholds in the region. Iran is using arms transfers, training, and terrorist proxies to empower the Houthi rebels, terrorize Yemeni civilians, undermine the security of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, and challenge U.S. national security interests in the region.

Houthi rebels have used Iranian-supplied advanced arms in the Yemen conflict, indiscriminately launching over 100 ballistic missiles against Saudi cities, unleashing explosive unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) against Saudi civilian targets, and deploying explosive boats and anti-ship missiles against commercial ships in the Arabian Gulf.

Moreover, Iran-backed Houthi rebels have detained thousands of Yemenis and reportedly subjected many of them to "extreme torture," including being beaten with batons, hung from chains by their wrists or genitals for weeks at a time, and scorched with acid.

Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) and Iran-backed Lebanese Hezbollah terrorists have provided training and support that have greatly increased the lethality and combat effectiveness of Houthi rebels, and enhanced their ability to threaten Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, international shipping in the Gulf, and U.S. forces in the region. Even if Iranian weapons are somehow cut off, the Houthi rebels' combat-experience and training will persist for decades.

While the U.S. is right to hold Saudi Arabia accountable for Khashoggi's barbaric murder, it is also crucial to acknowledge Iran's central role in perpetuating Yemen's conflict. Failure to do so risks prolonging the conflict and causing more war, oppression, and misery in the region.

While the Saudis must answer for Khashoggi's murder, efforts to limit or end U.S. cooperation with the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen risks emboldening Iran and increasing the suffering of the Yemeni people. Engaging with partners and providing support shows that the U.S. takes the struggle against a real security threat seriously, thereby strengthening the argument that only a political solution will end the conflict.

The Saudis' lack of institutional accountability and lax military culture have contributed to civilian deaths in Yemen. The U.S. must do more to enforce the Saudis' understanding and application of the Laws of Armed Conflict. Targets must be more carefully vetted, and the Saudi military must do all that it can to avoid harming innocents and to allow for food and humanitarian aid to reach suffering civilians.

A political end to Yemen's conflict is necessary as soon as possible, but any negotiation that includes the Houthis in a future government would formalize an Iranian-Yemeni security relationship, harm U.S. long-term security interests, and provide a strong incentive for the Iranian regime to cause other conflicts in the region.

Even if a ceasefire is struck, terrorists from AQAP and ISIS-Yemen may seek to exploit a U.N.-brokered ceasefire between the Houthi rebels and the Saudi-led coalition and use terrorist attacks to advance their own agenda. U.S. forces, along with Yemeni and UAE counterparts, have worked hard for years to degrade extremist networks in Yemen and to keep America safe from terrorist attacks. The U.S. cannot cede ground in the counterterrorism fight.

Resolving Yemen's conflict requires not only ending Iranian and Saudi complicity in the country's humanitarian tragedy but also removing Iran's foothold in Yemen and its ability to destabilize the Arabian Peninsula.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address: Middle-Class Economics and Economic Fairness

Article:

In his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama, facing a Congress controlled by a party that has historically been uncooperative, chose to focus on economic fairness, highlighting the disparity between the prosperity of the wealthy and the stagnation of the middle and working classes. He proposed a strategy that involves redistributing wealth from the affluent to those less fortunate, while also implementing measures to boost wages and create jobs.

The President did not engage in a stark, economist-style debate on inequality, instead opting for the term "middle-class economics." However, his message was clear: the choice lies between an economy that benefits only a select few, or one that fosters rising incomes and opportunities for all who strive.

"It's now up to us to choose who we want to be over the next 15 years, and for decades to come," Obama said. "Will we accept an economy where only a few of us do spectacularly well? Or will we commit ourselves to an economy that generates rising incomes and chances for everyone who makes the effort?"

The President's proposals, such as raising the capital gains tax to 28 percent, a rate that was in effect during the Reagan era, and imposing ordinary income tax rates on dividends, are not radical, but rather a return to tax rates of the past. He also aims to end a provision in the tax code that shields hundreds of billions of dollars in appreciated wealth passed on to heirs, and impose a new fee on big banks.

These changes would finance a series of tax breaks for middle-income families, including credits for two-earner couples, increased child care and college tuition credits, as well as other programs, such as two years of tuition-free community college for some students. The proposals are designed to be revenue-neutral, with the tax increases covering the costs of the new programs, thereby avoiding the ongoing debates over deficits that have drained both political parties and the American public.

While the Republican party has already dismissed the President's ideas, his speech serves as a reminder of the issues of economic fairness that will be central to the 2016 presidential elections and beyond. The Democratic nominee, whether it be Hillary Rodham Clinton or another candidate, cannot ignore these issues. Even Republicans, traditionally reluctant to raise taxes on top-tier earners, may find appeal in the idea of supporting those in the middle class.

Title: "Unveiled: Email Alerts Detailing Real-Time Account of U.S. Consulate Attack in Benghazi"

Article:

In a significant development, emails detailing the real-time account of the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, have come to light. These emails, which are believed to be the earliest descriptions of the events that transpired on the night of the attack, were issued by the State Department as the incident unfolded.

Four Americans, including Ambassador Christopher Stevens, lost their lives in the attack. The emails, obtained by ███, provide a chronicle of the attack's progression, offering insights into the chaotic and dangerous situation that unfolded.

At 4:05 p.m. Eastern time on September 11, an alert from the State Department Operations Center was issued to various government and intelligence agencies, including the White House Situation Room, the office of the Director of National Intelligence, and the FBI. The alert read, "US Diplomatic Mission in Benghazi Under Attack." It continued, "Approximately 20 armed people fired shots; explosions have been heard as well. Ambassador Stevens, who is currently in Benghazi, and four COM (Chief of Mission/embassy) personnel are in the compound safe haven."

Less than an hour later, at 4:54 p.m., another alert was issued: "The firing... in Benghazi... has stopped... A response team is on site attempting to locate COM (embassy) personnel."

Then, at 6:07 p.m., State sent out another alert stating, "The embassy in Tripoli reported that the Islamic military group 'Ansar al-Sharia Claims Responsibility for Benghazi Attack'... 'on Facebook and Twitter and has called for an attack on Embassy Tripoli.'"

The emails are part of what is likely a large number of communications exchanged throughout the night. They are expected to become part of the ongoing political debate over whether the administration attempted to mislead by stating that the assault was an outgrowth of a protest, rather than a planned attack by terrorists.

Fourteen hours after the attack, President Obama sat down with Steve Kroft of "60 Minutes" for a previously scheduled interview and said he did not believe it was simply due to mob violence. "You're right that this is not a situation that was -- exactly the same as what happened in Egypt and my suspicion is that there are folks involved in this who were looking to target Americans from the start," Mr. Obama said.

The White House and State Department declined comment on the email alerts. The House Oversight Committee told ███ that the information in the emails will be part of their ongoing investigation into the Benghazi attack.

Title: Obama Promises Bipartisan Approach, Urges Political Reform at Chicago Fundraiser

Article:

In a bid to emphasize the need for a more unified political system, former President Barack Obama addressed a political fundraiser in Chicago on Wednesday, pledging to work towards convincing the American people that Democratic ideologies are the right ones. Simultaneously, he sought to foster a bipartisan tone, acknowledging the current state of Washington's political climate and expressing optimism for its potential for improvement.

Speaking at a reception for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC), Obama emphasized the need for a politics that aligns with the American people's decency, hard work, and creativity. He stated, "We've got everything that we need to succeed, but the one thing that's still missing is a politics that matches up with the decency and the hard work and determination and creativity of the American people. We've got a politics that's stuck right now."

The president expressed his willingness to collaborate with Republicans who view compromise as a positive aspect of politics. He stated, "I'm willing to work with any Republican who doesn't think compromise is a dirty word."

Obama's speech focused on several key issues, including gun control, education, U.S. infrastructure, and climate change. He emphasized the potential for energy independence and the impact it could have on geopolitics and the environment.

The event, held at the Chicago Hilton, was the first of two fundraisers Obama was attending during his one-night visit to his hometown. The audience included members of the Illinois congressional delegation, Democratic power players such as House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, DCCC Chairman Rep. Steve Israel, and Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

Following his speech at the Hilton, Obama visited the home of longtime supporters and Democratic activists Paul and Bettylu Saltzman. The pair hosted a dinner for roughly 70 people, with attendees paying either $10,000 per person or $32,400 per couple for the opportunity to dine with the president.

Obama highlighted the Saltzmans' significant role in his political career, stating, "It's true, [Bettylu Saltzman] had treated me like a son in Chicago, introducing me to many people who would eventually become political supporters." He expressed his gratitude, saying, "I love that woman."

This was the third fundraiser Obama has headlined for the DCCC this year, with three more scheduled. The events aim to raise funds for the DCCC's efforts to elect Democrats to the U.S. House of Representatives.

Title: Democrats Unveil Ambitious Agenda as House Majority Looms: Medicare for All, Green New Deal, and More

Article:

As the new year approaches, Democrats are gearing up to introduce a series of far-reaching legislative proposals, many of which were previously stalled under Republican leadership. With the party set to take control of the House in January, these measures, including "Medicare for all" and a host of other generous welfare programs, could potentially see a floor vote.

Rep. Bonnie Watson Coleman (D-N.J.) told Fox News that numerous measures have been languishing for years and are expected to come to the floor under Democratic leadership. The GOP's expanded majority in the Senate, however, makes it unlikely these measures would reach President Trump's desk.

The Democratic Party's agenda, likely to be spearheaded by Speaker-designate Nancy Pelosi, was outlined in their "A Better Deal" campaign platform. The set of proposals claims nearly every item could be paid for by rolling back the Trump tax cuts. The most liberal bills have emerged from the Congressional Progressive Caucus.

One of the most contentious proposals is "Medicare for all," which, according to one estimate, could cost nearly $33 trillion over 10 years. The "Medicare for all" proposal is just one component of the much broader "Green New Deal" platform being pushed by progressives like Rep.-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, which also calls for a tuition-free and federally funded education system, guaranteed jobs with an emphasis on "green" jobs, and more.

In addition to these high-profile proposals, individual bills sponsored by Democratic lawmakers during the last two years, such as "college for all," "debt-free college," "child care for all," and a "jobs guarantee," could now be voted on along with climate legislation, pro-labor union bills, and attempts to roll back the tax reform bill that passed in late 2017.

Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), likely the incoming chairman of the Education and Workforce Committee, also introduced a "Worker's Freedom to Negotiate Act" that bans state laws that allow employees to opt not to join a union and pay union dues. The Democratic campaign plan also calls for spending $40 billion on "universal high-speed Internet."

Other notable proposals include Rep. David Cicilline's (D-R.I.) Child Care for Working Families Act, which ensures that no family under 150 percent of a state's median income pays more than 7 percent of their income for child care, and Rep. Ro Khanna's (D-Calif.) Job Opportunities for All Act, which provides federal funding to put people to work immediately in both the public and the private sector.

Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.), who could play a prominent role in such legislative proposals, is a co-chairwoman of the Medicare For All Caucus and the Congressional Progressive Caucus. She was also the sponsor of the College for All Act in 2017, which would eliminate tuition and fees at public colleges and universities for families earning up to $125,000, and make community college free for everyone. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) introduced the Senate version, while Rep. Mark Pocan (D-Wis.), the other progressive caucus co-chairman, introduced a similar bill, the Debt-Free College Act.

As the new Congress convenes, Democrats are poised to introduce a wide range of ambitious legislative proposals, many of which could reshape the American social and economic landscape. The success of these measures remains to be seen, but their introduction is certain to spark lively debate and potentially significant changes in the coming years.

Title: White House Faces Challenges as Democratic Unity Cracks over Obamacare Website Issues

Article:

In the aftermath of the government shutdown, President Barack Obama's political capital has taken a hit due to the troubled rollout of the Obamacare healthcare website. The once-unified Democratic front, which held strong during the shutdown, has shown signs of cracking as the party grapples with the website's issues.

For weeks leading up to the shutdown, President Obama managed to keep every Democrat in the House and Senate united. However, the problems with the Obamacare website have transformed the president from a man with a seemingly renewed political capital to one who appears to be on the defensive. The man who was setting the agenda is now trying to beat back the latest frame Republicans have forced on him, inadvertently providing evidence to support the doubts they've been trying to sow from the beginning.

The White House has been dealing with a bizarre episode involving Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) over a supposed insult from a Republican, while also dealing with the growing impatience and dismay among Democrats over the botched rollout of the website.

Privately, certain Republicans have expressed concern with the party's decision to focus so much attention on the website, which could be fixed over the next few months, instead of calling attention to other potentially problematic aspects of the law. Polls show support for Republicans remains way down, while support for Obamacare is still ticking up.

However, instead of promoting all the aspects of the law that don't involve uninsured people spending hours trying to sign up, Democrats have had to confront undeniable problems that have even core liberals worried. A growing number of people on the Hill are pushing the White House to change its current position that it can fix the problems with the website without changing the deadlines or time frame.

Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) has been one of the most vocal critics, suggesting a delay in the individual mandate penalty for a year. Manchin, who has always been suspicious of an individual mandate, has yet to hear back from the White House regarding his announcement.

The good news, from the White House perspective, is that even Manchin—who has been a skeptic of the individual mandate—has only gone as far as suggesting a delay. The White House officials argue that any political fallout will be addressed as they overhaul the site, expressing confidence that most people outside of Washington are past looking at Obamacare as a political issue and want to see it preserved, if repaired.

Title: New York Attorney General Files Lawsuit Against Trump Foundation, Alleging Extensive Illegal Activities

Article:

New York Attorney General Barbara Underwood has filed a lawsuit against the Trump Foundation, President Donald Trump, and his three eldest children, alleging extensive and persistent lawbreaking. The lawsuit, filed in the New York Supreme Court in Manhattan, accuses the foundation of unlawful political coordination, repeated self-dealing transactions, and violations of laws governing non-profit organizations.

The lawsuit seeks to dissolve the foundation and $2.8 million in restitution. The president responded on Twitter, calling the lawsuit a politically motivated attack and vowing not to settle the case. The attorney general is also seeking to bar the president and his children from serving on the board of any New York-based charity.

The investigation into the Trump Foundation began in 2016 under the previous New York attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, who resigned last month following allegations of physical abuse by several of his former girlfriends. In October 2016, Schneiderman ordered the Trump Foundation to stop fundraising in New York after finding it had no proper registration.

The lawsuit alleges that the foundation was used to promote Trump's presidential campaign, with funds raised for the foundation being used to promote the campaign and pay for personal items, including a painting of Trump himself. The Trump Foundation issued a statement denying the charges and accusing the attorney general of holding its remaining funds "hostage for political gain."

The lawsuit adds to Trump's legal challenges, which include a wide-ranging special counsel investigation into alleged ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. The investigation has resulted in indictments of several of Trump's associates and a raid on the home and office of Trump's long-time lawyer and fixer, Michael Cohen.

The lawsuit marks a new front in the ongoing criminal investigations into Trump and his empire. While administration officials may attempt to brand the investigation as politically motivated, the New York Attorney General has significant investigatory and prosecutorial power, and if she starts looking into some of Trump's more questionable charitable activities, there's no telling what she might turn up.

The 41-page document filed with the NY Supreme Court spells out a range of alleged violations of laws concerning non-profit organizations, dating back more than a decade. The investigation apparently found that the foundation was "little more than an empty shell that functions with no oversight by its board of directors." The board had not met since 1999, despite being legally required to meet annually, and did not oversee the foundation's activities "in any way."

The lawsuit alleges that the foundation was used to promote Trump's presidential campaign, with more than $2.8 million being donated to the foundation at a charity fundraiser for veterans in Iowa in January 2016. The petition alleges that those funds raised from the public were used to promote Trump's campaign for the presidency, in particular in the Iowa nominating caucuses.

The lawsuit also claims that the foundation paid $100,000 to settle legal claims against Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort, $158,000 to settle claims against one of his golf clubs, and $10,000 to purchase a painting of Trump to hang at another of his golf clubs. The purchase of the painting was an example of one of "at least five self-dealing transactions" which violate tax regulations on non-profit charities, the statement said.

"As our investigation reveals, the Trump Foundation was little more than a checkbook for payments from Mr. Trump or his businesses to nonprofits, regardless of their purpose or legality," Ms. Underwood said. The investigation is ongoing, and it remains to be seen what further revelations may come to light.

Title: NSA Audit Reveals Thousands of Privacy Violations, Sparking Calls for More Oversight

Article:

In a report published by The Washington Post on Thursday, it was revealed that the National Security Agency (NSA) had broken privacy rules thousands of times each year since 2008. The audit, which was first reported by the Washington Post, has sparked heated discussions and criticism in Washington over the NSA's infringement on Americans' privacy.

Senator Patrick Leahy, D-Vermont, who chairs the Senate Judiciary Committee, expressed his concern about the NSA's wrongful impingement on privacy and stated that his committee will hold a hearing on the Post's revelations. Leahy noted that the committee will continue to demand "honest and forthright answers" from the intelligence community.

In a call with reporters on Friday, John DeLong, the NSA's director of compliance, acknowledged that "mistakes occur," even as he insisted that only a "tiny" amount of such problems were intentional. DeLong emphasized that "no one at NSA thinks a mistake is OK."

The May 2012 audit found 2,776 incidents of "unauthorized collection, storage, access to or distribution of legally protected communications" in the preceding 12 months, according to the Post's report by reporter Barton Gellman. Most of these incidents involved failures of due diligence or violations of standard operating procedure, with the most serious incidents including a violation of a court order and unauthorized use of data about more than 3,000 Americans and green-card holders.

Congressional leaders, including House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi and Senate Intelligence Committee chairwoman Sen. Dianne Feinstein, have called for "rigorous oversight" by Congress on the "incidents of non-compliance."

The Washington Post reported that most incidents involved unauthorized surveillance of Americans or foreign intelligence targets in the country. In one case, a programming error caused a "large number" of calls placed from Washington to be intercepted due to a programming error that confused the capitol's 202 area code for 20, the international dialing code for Egypt.

The NSA released a statement on Friday defending its programs, stating that "NSA's foreign intelligence collection activities are continually audited and overseen internally and externally." The agency also noted that it "reports the issue internally and to federal overseers -- and aggressively gets to the bottom of it" when it makes a mistake in carrying out its foreign intelligence mission.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest offered a similar statement, saying the NSA compliance office's review reflects its commitment to abiding by the law and protecting people's privacy. The man who leaked the audit to the Post, Edward Snowden, has been charged with three felony counts, including violations of the U.S. Espionage Act, for the leaks.

The NSA's compliance office stated that it "detects and corrects mistakes" as they occur and are identified, which stops them from being "propagated." The agency also noted that those who make repeated mistakes lose access to key databases.

Overall, the NSA insisted that it carefully adheres to privacy protections. The audit report has sparked calls for more oversight and hearings in Congress, with lawmakers expressing concern about the NSA's mistakes and the need for more transparency in the agency's operations.

Title: GOP Rep. Lou Barletta Wins Pennsylvania Republican Senate Primary, Advances to Face Democratic Incumbent Bob Casey Jr.

Article:

In a closely contested race, Republican Representative Lou Barletta has emerged victorious in the Pennsylvania Republican Senate primary, defeating state Representative Jim Christiana. The Associated Press called the race for Barletta after 52 percent of precincts had reported their numbers, showing he had 59 percent of the votes.

President Donald Trump endorsed Barletta in a February tweet, praising him as "a Great Republican" and highlighting his early support for the president. Trump also criticized Democratic incumbent Bob Casey Jr., stating that he listens to "Tax Hikers Pelosi and Schumer."

In a tweet on Tuesday, Trump congratulated Barletta on his victory, saying, "Lou is a friend of mine and a special guy, he will very much help MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!"

In a similar tweet on Wednesday morning, Trump expressed his confidence in Barletta, stating, "Congratulations to Lou Barletta of Pennsylvania. He will be a great Senator and will represent his people well – like they haven’t been represented in many years."

Barletta will now face Casey in the November general election for the U.S. Senate seat. The race is expected to be a high-stakes contest, with both candidates already having expressed their positions on various issues during the primary campaign.

Title: Trump's Defiance of Media and Political Criticism: A Look at the President's Unconventional Approach

Article:

In the political landscape, the intensity of criticism often mirrors a political figure's influence. The media, as a primary source of information, has traditionally offered unsolicited advice to the Republican Party. However, this advice has not always yielded favorable results for the GOP. Donald Trump's presidency, however, has been an exception, with his disregard for media counsel contributing to his electoral success.

In the current political climate, the media is urging Trump to refrain from criticizing Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Contrary to this advice, Trump should intensify his criticisms, highlighting Mueller's potential conflicts of interest and the partisan nature of his investigation. The media's fervor over the possibility of a fired Mueller seems unwarranted. If Trump were to dismiss Mueller, the uproar from the media and the ruling class would subside, and the American people would remain indifferent, as the Russian probe has become background noise. Trump's re-election would be ensured, and the only casualties would be the timid Republicans who align with the Democrats in calling for Trump's impeachment.

Beneath the surface of the media's guidance lies a questionable principle: a duly elected president is not permitted to manage his own executive branch. This principle, if applied consistently, would imply that Trump is not allowed to run his own Justice Department. Trump should counter this argument by asserting his right to govern according to the will of the American people, who elected him, and not according to the preferences of the D.C. ruling class, which includes Mueller, a close associate of former FBI Director James Comey, who is often seen as a symbol of this class.

Recently, former CIA Director John Brennan, who supported the Soviets during the Cold War and the Muslim Brotherhood in the present era, has resurfaced, calling for government officials to defy orders to fire Mueller. The media, which has long normalized left-wing radicalism, has portrayed Brennan's comments as evidence of high patriotism and statesmanlike wisdom. In reality, Brennan's remarks are akin to a call for a coup against a duly elected U.S. president.

The media's hostility towards the American people, as revealed by former New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis' admission that the country needs a "new people," has not abated. Those who voted Trump into office should not be concerned by the volume of criticism from these perpetual complainers and malcontents, who are determined to impose their willful liberalism on every aspect of the country. Instead, they should be alarmed if the criticism ceases.

Title: Obama Warns Syria on Chemical Weapons as Activity at Stockpile Sites Increases

Article:

In a significant development, President Barack Obama has issued a stern warning to the Syrian government over the movement of chemical weapons, stating that any use or threatening behavior could prompt direct American intervention. This statement was made during a news conference in August.

The activity at the chemical weapons sites has raised concerns, but American officials are yet to confirm whether this activity crosses the "red line" set by Mr. Obama. A senior American diplomat, deeply involved in the effort to dissuade Syrian forces from using chemical weapons, suggested that the activity could be a sign of desperation rather than a direct threat.

Israeli officials, too, have expressed caution, suggesting that the movement of chemical weapons and the apparent preparations to use them could be a bluff or a warning to the West. However, a senior Israeli official noted unusual activity that they have not seen before.

The White House has remained silent on the intelligence reports, but a senior administration official issued a warning to the Syrians, reiterating that the use of chemical weapons would cross a red line for the United States. The official also emphasized that the international community would hold the Syrian regime accountable if they use chemical weapons or fail to secure them.

Representative Mike Rogers, the head of the House Intelligence Committee, declined to comment on the new intelligence reports but expressed concern about the potential collapse of the Assad regime and the dangerous vacuum it could create. He also warned that the use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime would demand decisive action from the international community.

In response to the crisis, the United States military has sent a task force of over 150 planners and specialists to Jordan to help the armed forces prepare for the possibility of Syria losing control of its chemical weapons. Turkey has also requested two batteries of the Patriot antimissile system from NATO, citing the potential use of chemical weapons in warheads.

This is not the first time activity at stockpile sites has been detected. In September, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta reported some movement of Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles to more secure locations. However, the new activity appears to be of a different nature, and officials are no longer willing to confirm that all the sites remain secure.

The United States and its allies have increased electronic eavesdropping and other surveillance activities of the sites. A senior defense official confirmed that no U.S. troops have been put on heightened alert in response to the activity, although the Pentagon is prepared to do so if necessary.

Title: George Conway Discusses Trump Administration, Marriage, and Political Shifts in Interview

Article:

In an extensive interview with Yahoo News' podcast Skullduggery, George Conway, the husband of Kellyanne Conway, one of President Trump's closest advisers, shared his views on the Trump administration, their differing political views, and his withdrawal from a potential role in the Justice Department.

Conway, who has been a vocal critic of the Trump administration, discussed his consideration for the position of chief of the civil division, which would have involved defending the administration in lawsuits. He revealed that he withdrew from the role due to his disapproval of the administration's actions.

Conway also spoke about the impact of his public criticisms on his marriage, stating, "I don’t think she likes it," referring to his wife and his constant criticisms of the Trump administration. However, he added, "I’ve told her, I don’t like the administration, so it’s even."

Comparing their political disagreements to those common in Washington, D.C., Conway said, "If I had a nickel for everybody in Washington who disagrees with their spouse on something that happens in this town, I wouldn’t be on this podcast. I’d be probably on a beach somewhere."

Conway criticized the administration, citing events such as the firing of James Comey and the president's comments about Russia as reasons for his disapproval. He also expressed concern about the appointment of Robert Mueller as special counsel, fearing a potential war between the Justice Department and the administration.

Despite his criticisms, Conway acknowledged his wife's significant role in Trump's election and praised her work. He stated, "She basically got this guy elected. She steadied that boat." However, he also noted that Trump's presidency has significantly changed the country and the Republican party, which he described as a "personality cult."

Conway revealed that he had switched parties due to his discomfort with the current state of the Republican party and stated that he would rather move to Australia than vote for Trump again.

Title: Israel Warns of Iran's Nuclear Program and Holocaust Parallels as Peace Talks with Palestinians Stall

Article:

Tensions between Israel and the Palestinians have reached a new high as peace talks have once again stalled, with President Mahmoud Abbas' ongoing connection to the terror group Hamas raising concerns that he does not recognize Israel's right to exist. Simultaneously, as President Obama's foreign policy continues to face criticism, Israel is expressing new concerns and warnings about Iran's nuclear program.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued a stern warning during the country's annual memorial day for the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust, likening Iran's suspected nuclear ambitions to the Nazi genocide. Speaking at the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, Netanyahu drew parallels between the Nazi genocide and Iran's leaders' repeated references to the destruction of Israel and their denial of the Holocaust.

Netanyahu questioned why, in the years leading up to the Holocaust, most of the world's leaders did not see the danger ahead of time. "In hindsight, all the signs were there," he said.

The Obama administration's approach to preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons has been criticized for being insufficient, and Secretary of State John Kerry has been accused of painting Israel as the villain in the peace talks. In a closed-door meeting last week, Kerry reportedly warned that if Israel does not make peace soon, it could become "an apartheid state," a comparison that has sparked outrage among Jewish leaders in America and Israel.

The use of the term "apartheid" is rare among American officials, and President Obama has previously rejected the idea that it should apply to Israel. Kerry's use of the loaded term has already caused controversy and could attract unwanted attention in Israel.

Meanwhile, Russia has threatened to pull out of sanction agreements on Iran, adding to Israel's concerns about Iran's nuclear program. The Obama administration's foreign policy has been criticized for isolating allies and promoting enemies, raising questions about the future of U.S.-Israel relations and the stability of the Middle East.

Title: U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm Faces Criminal Charges, Attorney Maintains Innocence

A statement from the attorney representing U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm (R-NY) on Friday confirmed that federal prosecutors have disclosed their intent to file criminal charges against the congressman. The charges stem from an ongoing investigation into possible campaign finance violations.

Grimm's attorney, William McGinley, stated in the release that the two-year investigation, which has been marked by leaks, violations of grand jury secrecy, and strong-arm tactics, will ultimately result in Grimm's vindication.

The U.S. Attorney's Office in Brooklyn and the FBI's New York office declined to comment on the case. A spokesman for the U.S. Attorney's Office said he couldn't confirm, deny, or comment on the case.

The House Ethics Committee announced in November that Grimm was under investigation for possible campaign finance violations. The panel deferred its inquiry due to a separate Department of Justice investigation.

Grimm made headlines in January after confronting a New York City cable news station reporter who tried to question him about a long-running FBI investigation into campaign finance. Grimm was recorded saying he would throw the reporter off a balcony if the reporter asked him about the investigation again.

During Grimm's first campaign, he acknowledged receiving contributions from followers of an Israeli rabbi, Yoshiyahu Yosef Pinto. Some members of Pinto's congregation subsequently said they made tens of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions, including gifts passed through straw donors. Grimm has denied knowledge of any improprieties, and the FBI hasn't accused him of any wrongdoing.

In August, Ofer Biton, the Israeli businessman who had served as Grimm's liaison to Pinto's followers, pleaded guilty to an immigration fraud charge. Three days later, the FBI filed a sealed criminal complaint accusing a Houston woman named Diana Durand, who had been romantically involved with Grimm, of using straw donors to make illegal campaign contributions.

On Friday, Durand was indicted in Brooklyn on those charges. She was also charged with making false statements to the FBI when she said she didn't reimburse straw donors for their contributions to Grimm's campaign. Attorney Stuart Kaplan said Durand would plead not guilty to the charges.

A spokesman in Grimm's Washington office did not immediately return emails or a telephone message seeking comment.

Under federal law and the chamber's rules, an indicted House member does not lose any rights or privileges. However, rules used by the two major political parties require indicted committee or subcommittee chairmen, or members of a party's leadership, to temporarily step aside. Grimm is not a chairman or a member of the leadership.

Associated Press writers Tom Hays, Michael Sisak, and Alan Fram contributed to this report from New York and Washington, D.C.

Title: "2016 Presidential Election: Sanders Leads in Ad Spending, but Trump Outperforms in Ad Efficiency"

Article:

The 2016 Presidential Election is shaping up to be the most expensive in history, with a significant increase in the number of TV ads aired compared to the 2012 election. According to a new report from the Wesleyan Media Project, 480,000 ads have aired thus far in the 2016 election cycle, a 112 percent increase over the same period in 2012.

In the Democratic race, Bernie Sanders has spent more on TV ads than any other candidate, totaling nearly 125,000 ads as of May 8. Sanders, who has relied heavily on small donors, has spent approximately $8 per vote, while Hillary Clinton has spent about $5 per vote, despite spending about $11 million less on ads.

On the Republican side, the race has been marked by a high number of candidates, many of whom have dropped out after only a few votes were cast. Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal, who had a superPAC behind him and dropped out before any contests took place, spent approximately $17,000 per vote. Excluding Jindal's astronomical figure, the candidates spent significantly less per vote, with Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, Lindsey Graham, and John Kasich all spending millions but amassing few votes.

Donald Trump, who has spent about $2 on TV ads per vote, stands out as the most efficient spender of ads. Trump, who was already a household name in the U.S., has been able to secure significant free media coverage, estimated at $2 billion as of March. This estimated $2 billion may be a key factor in Trump's ability to maintain high levels of support despite anti-Trump ads spending nearly $6 million more than the candidate himself.

The Wesleyan Media Project's data suggests that the superPAC has changed the campaign fundraising game, but money does not necessarily buy votes. The effectiveness of ads may be waning as Americans spend more time online and cut the cord on traditional television. Gregg Phillips, who ran Newt Gingrich's 2012 superPAC, Winning Our Future, told NPR last year that "more and more people are sort of turning off those [TV] ads." Phillips suggested that younger generations are more likely to be moved by online ads or grassroots campaigns.

In conclusion, the 2016 Presidential Election is on track to be the most expensive in history, with significant differences in ad spending and efficiency between candidates. Bernie Sanders has spent the most on ads, but Donald Trump has spent his ads most effectively, with approximately $2 per vote. The superPAC has changed the campaign fundraising game, but the effectiveness of ads may be waning as Americans spend more time online.

Title: Pentagon Clarifies Number of Troops Diagnosed with Brain Injuries Following Iran Strike, Provides Update on Their Status

Article:

In a recent update, the Pentagon has clarified the number of troops who were diagnosed with brain injuries following the U.S. strike on an Iranian-backed militia in Iraq. According to the latest information, 11 troops were pulled out of Iraq for brain injury treatment.

On Friday, Defense Secretary Mark Esper provided an update on the status of these troops. He stated that out of the 34 troops diagnosed with brain injuries, 17 have returned to duty, including one service member who was transferred to Kuwait for treatment.

Esper also revealed that eight service members have been transferred to the U.S. for treatment after initially being sent to Germany. Nine are still undergoing treatment and evaluation in Germany.

Esper attributed the change in numbers to symptoms that "are late-developing" and "manifest over a period of time." He explained that while some troops initially screened for concussion-like symptoms saw their conditions improve rapidly, others did not. Some of these troops had their conditions worsen, and some had severe enough symptoms that they were transported for further treatment.

President Donald Trump had previously played down the initial reports of injuries, stating on Wednesday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that the injuries were not "very serious." However, Esper, during his speech on Friday at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, defended the Pentagon's reporting of injuries around the globe, emphasizing the importance of accuracy and proper categorization of such incidents.

Esper also clarified that the Pentagon does not normally report such injuries, stating that "This is mostly outpatient stuff. So we can track that if—if you're really interested in it." He also noted that he did not know the exact number of injured troops at the time of his previous comments. "I'm not a doctor and I'm not the ones evaluating them," he said.

The Pentagon's commitment to transparency and accurate reporting of such incidents, as stated by Esper, extends to troops engaged in operations worldwide.

Title: Facebook's Trending Topics Allegations: A Call for Informed Consumer Choice in the Digital Age

Article:

In the digital age, technology has democratized information, making it easier for individuals to access and share news from various sources. However, the human impulse for control and power remains prevalent, as evidenced by recent allegations against Facebook's Trending Topics feature. A Gizmodo investigation has revealed that the social media giant may have suppressed conservative news and opinion sites from its Trending Topics index.

Facebook's Trending Topics function provides users with a headline feed that indicates the top stories generating discussion on the platform. The site claims that the feed results from organic conversations among users, offering a measure of social penetration of issues, activists, and news sites. However, some former Facebook curators have admitted that they excluded results from conservative news and opinion sites, including The Drudge Report, Breitbart News, The Washington Examiner, and RedState (a site owned by Townhall Media Group, which also owns Hot Air, where the author is employed as senior editor).

The suppressed topics ranged from conservative political events such as the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) to discussions about Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker (R) and Mitt Romney. Some curators reportedly received instructions to "inject" topics into the index to artificially produce discussion, with some injections appearing to promote certain agendas, such as the Black Lives Matter movement.

Facebook has denied these allegations, stating that it does not allow or advise its reviewers to systematically discriminate against sources of any ideological origin. However, the Gizmodo investigation has raised questions about the transparency and objectivity of Facebook's Trending Topics feature.

In light of these allegations, conservatives are grappling with what to do next. Some have suggested abandoning Facebook altogether, arguing that it is not worth engaging with a platform that may suppress conservative viewpoints. However, others argue that pulling out would only make conservatism more insular and would play into the hands of liberal Facebook curators who may want to banish conservatives from the platform or make them as irrelevant as possible.

Instead, conservatives should use the open platform of Facebook and other social media networks to engage people, make connections, and use those networks to expand the reach and relevance of the conservative agenda. However, they should also treat Facebook more skeptically than they once did, exercising their own choices and calling out those gatekeepers when their biases become so obvious as to be insulting.

Informed consumer choice is not just an antidote to editorial bias; it is a freedom worth liking on any and all social networks. As consumers, we must remain vigilant and critical, ensuring that we are accessing a diverse range of perspectives and making informed decisions about the news we consume. In this way, we can ensure that technology truly democratizes information and empowers us all.

Title: White House Clarifies IRS Investigation Involvement, Consultations with Treasury Department

Article:

The White House has revised its account of its involvement in the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) investigation into conservative political groups, revealing that it had consulted with the Treasury Department on the timing and content of the information's release.

On Tuesday, Press Secretary Jay Carney disclosed that the discussions, led by Deputy Chief of Staff Mark Childress, focused on the timing of the release of the information and the findings of the actual audit. Carney stated that these conversations did not involve the president, who was not informed of the forthcoming inspector general report on the issue.

Carney named only two senior White House staffers who were aware of the IRS probe: White House counsel Kathy Ruemmler, who made the decision not to inform the president, and himself, who learned about it from news reports. He clarified that he had not been among the senior staff informed of the IRS actions earlier.

In response to questions about who else knew of the report's existence before the first news stories about it emerged on May 10, Carney was evasive, stating that Ruemmler may have had conversations about the matter but could not confirm the existence of an email regarding the issue.

The briefing grew testy when Carney was asked whether he was among the senior staff who were told of the IRS investigation before news reports emerged. He was not, he said, echoing his response from the previous day.

The White House continues to defend its decision not to loop in President Obama about the inspector general's report before the news became public. This clarification comes after the White House initially stated that Chief of Staff Denis McDonough and other senior White House staff learned of the situation nearly a month ago.

Title: The Impact of Obamacare's Medicaid Payment Reduction on Primary Care Doctors in 2015

Article:
