As the clock ticks down to January 1, 2015, thousands of primary care doctors who treat Medicaid patients are bracing for a significant pay cut of 42 percent. The Affordable Care Act temporarily boosted payment rates for these doctors in 2013 and 2014 to encourage their participation in Medicaid as the program expanded to cover millions more Americans.

The temporary pay raise, which averaged out to a 73 percent increase for primary care doctors across the country, is set to expire on December 31. This means that, beginning January 1, 2015, Medicaid doctors will earn less each time they see a patient, or they could decide to pull out of the program altogether.

Here's a quick guide to why the raise happened, why it's running out, and what it means for the future of Obamacare:

1. Obamacare raised Medicaid's primary care payments in 2013 and 2014

Before the Affordable Care Act, Medicare (the federal insurance program that covers the elderly) paid doctors more than Medicaid (the state-federal insurance program that covers the poor). On average, Medicaid paid doctors about two-thirds of what Medicare paid, although there was lots of variation across the country.

Even though Medicaid paid less, it has usually done a pretty good job making sure patients can get in to see primary care doctors. However, there was a worry that, after Obamacare, that might not be the case. Medicaid is one of the two big programs the law relies on to expand health insurance coverage (the other is the marketplaces). Forecasters had estimated that 13 million additional people would join the program in Obamacare's first decade, and 7 million of those people would sign up in the first year.

Research has found that doctors are more likely to accept new Medicaid patients when their payment rates are higher. And the Affordable Care Act included a provision that aimed to entice doctors to sticking with—or perhaps joining—the program as it expanded to cover millions more Americans.

Beginning in 2013, the law bumped Medicaid primary care doctors' reimbursement rates up to match those of Medicare (specialists did not get any increase). The law funded the increased payments through the end of 2014, setting up a looming cliff that we're now approaching.

2. Doctors will see a 42 percent pay cut in 2015

That's an estimate from the Urban Institute, which ran the numbers on how payment rates will change in 2015. The decline will vary a lot from state to state. That's because each state sets its own payment rates for primary care doctors. In a state like California, for example, which tended to pay Medicaid doctors very low rates, Obamacare has doubled their fees. But in North Carolina, where the two programs' fees were more similar, the pay rate increase was much smaller.

3. The federal government will not extend the pay cut

Mostly because it's expensive: the two years of the pay-bump cost the federal government $11 billion.

Medicaid advocacy groups have lobbied Congress a bit to extend the pay cut for at least two years now. And Sens. Patty Murray (D-WA) and Sherrod Brown (D-OH) did introduce legislation that would extend the pay bump until 2016.

"We’re ready to lobby for what’s right to improve the situation," Roland Goertz, chair of the Academy of Family Physicians, had said in 2012 about extending the pay cut. "We’re ready to go to the mat for what works, and we need to be going in this direction."

But the issue has not gotten traction; the Murray-Brown bill has languished in committee since its introduction this past summer. And that means, barring any last-minute miracle, Medicaid payment rates will decline in many states—but not all—on Thursday.

4. Fifteen states are stepping in to extend the payment raise

Medicaid is a joint federal-state program, with the two governments splitting the bill for patients' coverage. And, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation, 15 states will step in and provide funding to either fully or partially continue the payment increase.

What's notable about this map, however, is that the states stepping in tend to be those that were already paying Medicaid doctors pretty well in the first place. They are places like New Mexico that, before Obamacare, paid primary doctors 85 percent of the Medicare rate, or Mississippi, which paid 90 percent.

The states that have a much bigger gap between Medicaid and Medicare payments, like California, are not generally not stepping in to avert the payment cut. This is probably due to the fact that fixing the bigger gaps is so much more expensive.

5. Nobody knows what this will mean for Medicaid patients' access to care

The worry among Medicaid advocates is that lower payment rates will translate into fewer doctors being willing to see patients. This is articulated in a recent New York Times article, citing data from Ohio:

A survey by the Ohio State Medical Association found that some Ohio doctors began accepting Medicaid patients because of the rate increase in 2013. Ohio doctors who were already participating in the program said they had accepted more Medicaid patients after the rate increase. And almost 40 percent of Ohio doctors indicated that they planned to accept fewer Medicaid patients when the extra payments lapsed.

Previous studies have shown that states that pay more for primary care in Medicaid do have more doctors accepting new patients. This chart from Health Affairs shows the correlation:

Those are the reasons for concern—but there are also reasons to think things might go okay, too. Medicaid patients tend to have just as good access to primary care as patients in private coverage. One 2012 study commissioned by the federal government found that Medicaid patients are equally as likely to have had a routine check-up in the past year as those with private insurance. The real challenges in access tend to happen when patients seek specialty care.

And it's worth keeping in mind that there were thousands of doctors who saw Medicaid patients prior to the Affordable Care Act's pay bump. These are people who, even before they got a big raise, thought it made sense to see these patients at lower rates. That gives decent reason to think that these doctors will stick around after the pay increase disappears, too.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Kelly Outlines Immigration Enforcement Changes in Line with Trump's Executive Actions

Article:

Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly, on Tuesday, unveiled a series of immigration enforcement changes in accordance with President Trump's executive actions, aiming to strengthen border security and expand the categories of illegal immigrants targeted for deportation.

In two memos released by the department, Kelly outlined measures to hire thousands more officers, end "catch-and-release" policies, and initiate work on the U.S.-Mexico border wall as promised by the President. The changes prioritize criminal illegal immigrants and others convicted or charged with any criminal offense, or who have abused public welfare programs.

The directives will not affect the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, also known as "dreamers," as a DHS official emphasized during a conference call with reporters. However, the memos aim to broaden enforcement by no longer exempting classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement.

The memos also call for expanding the 287(g) program, which allows participating local officers to act as immigration agents, and had been rolled back under the Obama administration. Furthermore, they initiate the planning, design, and construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall, aiming to end "catch-and-release" policies under which illegal immigrants subject to deportation potentially are allowed to "abscond" and fail to appear at removal hearings.

The timelines for these objectives and the budgetary and other constraints the department and its agencies will face remain unclear. In an effort to address the potential increase in cases due to the end of "catch-and-release," a plan with the Justice Department is being developed to "surge" immigration judges and asylum officers.

While congressional Republicans have pledged to work with Trump to fund the front-end costs associated with the border wall, the memos also hint at future efforts to potentially use money otherwise meant for Mexico, following Trump's repeated campaign vow to make Mexico pay for the wall. The memos, however, do not specify how that information might be used.

Mexican officials have consistently stated they will not pay for a border barrier. DHS has identified initial locations to build a wall where current fencing is not effective, near El Paso, Texas; Tucson, Arizona; and El Centro, California.

The DHS directives come as the Trump White House continues to work on rewriting its controversial executive order suspending the U.S. refugee program as well as travel from seven mostly Muslim countries. The order was put on hold by a federal court, and Trump's team is said to be working on a new measure.

The directives also come as the Trump administration faces criticism from Democratic lawmakers and immigration advocacy groups for recent ICE raids of illegal immigrants. DHS officials on Tuesday's conference call stressed that they are operating under existing law and reiterated that National Guard troops will not be utilized to round up illegal immigrants, contradicting an apparently erroneous news report from last week.

"We're going to treat everyone humanely and with dignity, but we are going to execute the laws of the United States," a DHS official said on the conference call.

Title: FEMA Terminates Contract with Tribute Contracting LLC Over Underdelivery of Hurricane Maria Meals in Puerto Rico

A New York Times investigation has revealed that Tiffany Brown, an Atlanta entrepreneur and self-described government contractor who owns Tribute Contracting LLC, drastically underdelivered on a $156 million contract awarded by FEMA to provide 30 million self-heating meals to Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria.

According to the Times, Brown, the sole employee of her company, only followed through on 50,000 meals, despite being awarded the contract on Oct. 3. In response to Brown's failure to meet a deadline of providing the first 18.5 million meals, her contract was terminated by email on Oct. 19.

Brown hired an 11-person wedding catering company and a Texas nonprofit that had shipped food to a Houston food bank during Hurricane Harvey to provide the meals. However, the operation was reportedly a "logistical nightmare," according to an email from Carolyn Ward, a FEMA official who handled the contract with Brown's company.

A FEMA spokesman told the Times that other suppliers provided "ample" food and water for Puerto Ricans, and that Tribute's contract did not result in any missed meals. This is at least the sixth government contract awarded to Tribute that has been canceled, according to the Times.

At the time the FEMA contract was awarded, the Government Publishing Office had a ban on awarding contracts of more than $35,000 to Tribute until January 2019 due to a mishandled project. Brown is now fighting the FEMA contract termination and seeking a $70 million settlement.

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee is investigating the Tribute contract. Committee Democrats criticized FEMA in a letter to committee chairman Trey Gowdy, stating that FEMA should have considered Tribute's history and lack of large-scale disaster relief experience before awarding the contract.

In the letter, Democrats highlighted the Tribute contract as the latest example of how FEMA was unprepared to handle the hurricane aftermath in Puerto Rico by not preparing contractors in advance. They also compared the Trump administration's response to the hurricanes in Puerto Rico in 2017 to the Bush Administration's response to Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

FEMA and the Puerto Rican government reached an agreement earlier this month to continue providing food and water to affected communities, after the agency faced major backlash following a report that it would stop the distribution.

Title: FBI Indictments Confirm Russian Meddling in 2016 U.S. Elections, but No Evidence of Outcome Alteration

Article:

In a significant development, the national security adviser to President Donald Trump, H.R. McMaster, stated at the Munich Security Conference in Germany that the recently unveiled FBI indictments provide incontrovertible evidence of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential elections. McMaster's remarks come in response to the indictment of 13 Russian nationals and three Russian companies by a federal grand jury for allegedly interfering in the 2016 presidential elections.

The indictment, led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, details a sophisticated plot to wage "information warfare" against the U.S. The Russian nationals are accused of setting a strategic goal to sow discord in the U.S. political system, including the 2016 presidential election.

Tech giant executives, including those from Facebook and Twitter, testified recently on Capitol Hill that Russia indeed used social media to disrupt the 2016 White House race and sow discord among voters. This is the first indictment against Russian nationals as part of Mueller's probe into whether Trump associates colluded with Russian officials during the 2016 elections.

However, the Justice Department made it clear in its case that the indictment does not allege that any of the interference changed the outcome of the presidential race. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversees the special counsel probe, stated at a Friday press conference that "there is no allegation in this indictment that any American was a knowing participant in this illegal activity. There is no allegation in the indictment that the charged conduct altered the outcome of the 2016 election."

Russia's foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, dismissed the indictment, calling it "just blabber." When asked about the indictments, Lavrov replied, "I have no response. You can publish anything, and we see those indictments multiplying, the statements multiplying." He argued that U.S. officials also have said no country influenced the U.S. election results.

The 37-page indictment, signed by Mueller, states that the actions detailed by prosecutors date back to 2014. The defendants are accused of spreading derogatory information about Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, denigrating Republican candidates Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, and ultimately supporting Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders and then-Republican candidate Donald Trump.

President Trump asserted on Friday that the indictment proved there was "no collusion" between his campaign and the Russians. "Russia started their anti-US campaign in 2014, long before I announced that I would run for President," Trump tweeted after the indictment was unveiled. "The results of the election were not impacted. The Trump campaign did nothing wrong — no collusion."

The three entities charged in the indictment are Internet Research Agency LLC, Concord Management and Consulting LLC, and Concord Catering. The 13 Russians charged are Yevgeniy Viktorovich Prigozhin, Mikhail Ivanovich Bystrov, Mikhail Leonidovich Burchik, Aleksandra Yuryevna Krylova, Anna Vladislavovna Bogacheva, Sergey Pavlovich Polozov, Maria Anatolyrvna Bovda, Robert Sergetevich Bovda, Dzheykhun Nasimi Ogly, Vadim Vladimirovich Podkopaev, Gleb Igorevich Vasilchenko, Irina Viktorovna Kaverzina, and Vladimir Venkov.

Title: Romney's Remarks on Obama Supporters Spark Controversy, Stirring Debate on Government Dependency and Entitlement

Article:

In a video released Monday, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney made controversial remarks about President Barack Obama's supporters, describing them as dependent on government and unwilling to take responsibility for their lives. The video, posted on the website of Mother Jones, showed Romney speaking at a private fundraiser earlier this year.

In the video, Romney stated, "There are 47% of the people who will vote for the president, no matter what. All right, there are 47% who are with him, who are dependent upon government, who believe that they are victims, who believe the government has a responsibility to care for them, who believe that they are entitled to health care, to food, to housing, to you-name-it. That's an entitlement. And the government should give it to them. And they will vote for this president no matter what."

Romney also said, "My job is not to worry about those people. I'll never convince them they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives."

In a hastily scheduled news conference in Costa Mesa Monday night, Romney did not back away from his remarks. "It's not elegantly stated, let me put it that way," Romney said. "I'm speaking off the cuff in response to a question."

The comments could be read as unflattering to Obama supporters broadly and to millions of people who hold jobs and in many cases pay payroll taxes, but who do not earn enough to pay the income tax. Some of those people receive tax benefits that have been championed by both parties, such as credits for children, which wipe out their tax burdens.

The incident was reminiscent of Obama's remarks this summer, made famous by his awkward "you didn't build that" comment, that were interpreted by Republicans as a disparagement of entrepreneurialism. Democrats said the president meant only that government spending on infrastructure and other programs is important to business owners.

In other contexts, the candidates have said these competing ideas go to the heart of the election, with Obama arguing for a government role in the economy and Romney saying government is too intrusive.

The Romney campaign arranged for top Romney adviser Ed Gillespie to speak to reporters Monday amid a set of news stories about the campaign's weakening position in public opinion surveys and after the website Politico posted an article about infighting inside the Romney campaign.

Democrats and some Republicans have said Romney should lay out more policy specifics, such as which tax breaks he would scrap in order to pay for a 20% cut to tax rates he has proposed for all income brackets.

"We do think the timing is right, at this moment, to reinforce the specifics—more specifics—about the Romney plan," Gillespie said.

Romney did not offer new policy specifics in a speech Monday to small-business owners at the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. He said he would overhaul the legal immigration system. His comments dovetail with House Republicans' effort to pass legislation that would increase the number of visas for workers in fields like engineering and science. A vote is expected this week.

Title: Contact Tracing: A Potential Solution or a Privacy Concern?

Article:

As the world grapples with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, a new challenge has emerged: contact tracing. Contact tracers are individuals tasked with identifying and questioning people who test positive for the novel coronavirus, tracing their contacts, and advising self-quarantine and self-monitoring for symptoms. While this tactic has proven effective in other countries, the prospect of an army of government interrogators has raised concerns about privacy and potential abuse.

The National Association of County and City Health Officials estimates that at least 100,000 contact tracers will be needed to keep the virus at bay as communities reopen. New York state, ground zero for America's pandemic crisis, plans to put between 6,400 and 17,000 contact tracers in place. New York City's "Test and Trace Corps" will launch with 1,000 contact tracers, according to Mayor Bill de Blasio.

While the Johns Hopkins University, a go-to trainer for many contact tracing programs, offers a free, online, certificate-granting course in contact tracing, ethical considerations, including privacy, are a significant concern. The university's course delves into the biology of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the process of gathering information, and ethical considerations, but it is state, city, and local government agencies that are managing the deployment of the contact tracers they train.

In Washington state, Gov. Jay Inslee's reopening plan, including an initial 1,371 contact tracers, is raising questions about privacy rights. The state requires restaurants to create a daily log of all customers and maintain that log for 30 days, including telephone/email contact information and time in. This has raised concerns about the collection and storage of personal information.

In California, Robert Levin, the director of Ventura County Public Health, had to apologize after a contact tracing program announcement during which he gave the impression that isolated individuals would be taken out of their homes and placed in hotels or motels. This type of "impression" has contributed to people's reluctance to share details of their shopping trips and social interactions with government-employed strangers.

Cooperation with contact tracers is voluntary, but winning people over is critical, as there is no way to make unwilling people cooperate. If public officials can convince the public of the wisdom of their tactics and the innocence of their intentions, maybe we can work together to resolve our health concerns. However, the potential for lying and mistrust remains a significant challenge.

Bioethicist Jacob Appel argues that countries with authoritarian governments or high levels of social cohesion have successfully used contact tracing, but the United States does not possess either. The burden is on public officials to demonstrate to our satisfaction that they are deploying an army of helpful contact tracers and not a plague of intrusive cootie cops.

Title: Federal Reserve Lowers Economic Outlook, Hints at Delay in Interest Rate Hike

Article:

In a two-day meeting on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve lowered its economic outlook, citing a slowdown in growth during the winter months due to temporary factors such as harsh weather conditions. The Fed's statement did not provide a clear signal for an initial interest rate hike at its June meeting, but policymakers indicated they expect to act this year.

Following the announcement, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.3%, the S&P 500 index fell 0.3%, and the Nasdaq composite declined 0.3%. Yields on 10-year government bonds rose above 2%.

The Fed stated that economic growth slowed during the winter months, in part due to unusual cold weather. However, it expects the economy to rebound and grow at a moderate pace in the coming months. The Fed's optimistic view did not rule out a June rate increase, but it suggested a delay in raising the target range for the federal funds rate, which has been near zero since the 2008 financial crisis.

Job growth moderated, household spending declined, and inflation-adjusted incomes rose strongly, partly due to earlier declines in energy prices. Business investment softened, and exports declined, according to the Fed's statement. Inflation continued to run below the Fed's target, and the government reported that the Fed's preferred measure of inflation rose 0.9% last quarter, the smallest increase since 2010.

Employers added just 126,000 jobs in March, compared to average monthly gains of 269,000 in the prior 12 months. The government reported that the economy grew at a 0.2% annual rate in the first quarter, down from 2.2% in the October-December period and below the modest 1% pace expected by economists.

The Fed reiterated that it will raise the federal funds rate when it has seen further improvement in the labor market and is reasonably confident that inflation will move back to its 2% target over the medium-term. Many economists predict the Fed is unlikely to act until September at the earliest, allowing time to assess the economy's momentum. This timetable is consistent with the Fed policymakers' median forecast in March and recent speeches by Fed policymakers, including Fed Chair Janet Yellen.

Title: Investigations Mount Against Secretary of State Mike Pompeo: A Closer Look at the Allegations

Article:

In a series of revelations that have dominated headlines, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo finds himself at the center of a growing scandal that has raised questions about the use of taxpayer funds, potential abuse of power, and disregard for accepted procedures. The allegations, which have been corroborated by several news organizations, paint a picture of a Secretary of State who has treated his position as a personal fiefdom, with little regard for common decency or the taxpayers' money.

The scandal began with reports of about two dozen luxurious dinners hosted by Pompeo and his wife Susan at the State Department's Diplomatic Reception Rooms, all paid for by taxpayers. The guest lists, according to NBC News, were made up more of Republican donors and activists than foreign diplomats and policy experts. In fact, nearly 40% of the nearly 500 invitees were from Fox News, NBC reported.

The scandal deepened last Friday when President Donald Trump announced his intention to fire the State Department's Inspector General, Steve Linick. Inspectors general are Senate-confirmed government officials charged with auditing and investigating potential instances of fraud and abuse in the government. Pompeo acknowledged on Wednesday that he asked Trump to fire Linick, but offered scant explanation for the reason, other than that it should have happened sooner. He called claims that the firing was retribution for probes into his activities "patently false."

However, moments after the announcement, Democratic Rep. Eliot Engel, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, dropped a bombshell, revealing that Linick was investigating Pompeo. Engel, with Sen. Bob Menendez, ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, opened a probe into the ouster, decrying "the politically-motivated firing of inspectors general and the President's gutting of these critical positions."

Later, NBC reported that Linick was investigating Pompeo's use of a State Department political appointee to conduct personal errands, such as walking his dog and picking up his laundry. Within hours, the accusations grew more disturbing. Engel told CNN of another possible reason for Linick's firing. The inspector general, it turns out, was investigating the declaration of an "emergency" that Pompeo had cited one year ago as reason for bypassing the requirement that Congress approve an $8 billion sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia.

The NBC investigation identified the dog-walking staffer, whose name appeared in the emails NBC reviewed in connection with the so-called Madison Dinners. The staffer was the principal liaison between Pompeo's office and the protocol office that organized the dinners. "Two administration officials told NBC News that Linick made some type of inquiry to the protocol office last week, before he was fired," NBC reported. "One of the officials said Pompeo's office was then notified." Whether Linick was also investigating Pompeo's dinners remains unclear.

The details of the dinners, with their own logo embossed on State Department invitations, brought hundreds of people to the center of US diplomacy more than 20 times since Pompeo became Secretary of State. The events, with their guest lists, suggest an opportunity to further a political career within the Republican establishment rather than an opportunity to discuss complex foreign policy matters.

The majority of the guests came from the corporate world and conservative media and entertainment, along with Republican members of Congress. Among those wined and dined were Fox News' Laura Ingraham, Marjorie Dannenfelser, head of a prominent anti-abortion lobbying group, Bill Miller, head of a leading casino lobbying group, former Major League Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, Chick-fil-A Chairman Dan Cathy, a leading conservative donor, and others.

Sources told NBC that the State Department collected information about each guest, and that information was all forwarded to the private Gmail account of Susan Pompeo, the Secretary of State's wife. Whatever reason she had for receiving the data, it amounts to a treasure trove, should the Secretary of State decide to run for a Kansas Senate seat--or for President. If that is the purpose of the dinners and the emailing, it is a violation of the Hatch Act, which bans most federal employees from using their position for partisan political activities.

The allegations against Pompeo are still unfolding, and it remains to be seen what the full extent of the Secretary's actions will be. However, the initial revelations are more than enough to raise serious questions about the use of taxpayer funds, the politicization of the State Department, and the Secretary's disregard for accepted procedures and common decency. The American public deserves a full and transparent investigation into these matters, and a thorough accounting of the Secretary's actions.

Title: Unprecedented Victory for Hong Kong's Pro-Democracy Movement in District Council Elections

Article:

Hong Kong's pro-democracy movement has achieved a significant victory in the Chinese territory's district council elections, with early results showing that 17 out of 18 councils are now controlled by pro-democracy councillors. The election, which was seen as a test of support for the government after months of unrest, protests, and clashes, did not materialize the expected show of support from the so-called "silent majority."

Despite fears the vote could be disrupted or cancelled, it proceeded peacefully. The election allowed residents to express their opinion on the handling of the crisis by embattled Chief Executive Carrie Lam, who came to power amidst a now-withdrawn extradition law controversy.

A record 4.1 million people had registered to vote, more than half the population, and more than 2.9 million people cast their votes, resulting in a turnout of over 71%. The weekend was also the first in months without any clashes between protesters and police.

In many districts, young, first-time candidates, many who had explicitly aligned themselves with the protesters, unseated established politicians backing the government. The hope from activists is that the overwhelming victory of anti-establishment parties will force the government to take protesters' demands more seriously.

One of the biggest losses for the pro-Beijing camp was lawmaker Junius Ho, who suffered a shock defeat. He has openly voiced his support for Hong Kong's police force on multiple occasions and was filmed shaking hands with a group of men suspected of being triad gangsters who later assaulted pro-democracy protesters.

Jimmy Sham, a political activist who has recently risen to prominence as the leader of the Civil Human Rights Front, won a seat after running for the first time. Mr. Sham has also been attacked twice, once apparently with hammers.

Pro-democracy activist Joshua Wong was barred from running in the elections, a move he referred to as "political screening," but the pro-democracy candidate who replaced him has won. In a tweet, Mr. Wong said the "historic" results showed that public opinion had not turned against the pro-democracy movement.

Reflecting on her reported defeat, pro-Beijing lawmaker Alice Mak suggested Ms. Lam's administration was partly to blame. "In the election campaign, pro-government candidates have been unfairly treated. This is a very important reason," she said.

Starry Lee Wai-king, chairwoman of the city's largest pro-Beijing party, was among the few establishment candidates to secure her seat. "I think [Lee] is the only one who can survive the de facto referendum," said Leung Kwok-hung, her pro-democracy opponent in the poll.

Title: GOP Shifts Focus to Legislative Achievements as Midterm Elections Approach

Article:

As the midterm elections loom, Republicans are working on a backup plan in case the GOP tax law does not prove to be a strong selling point for their party. While the booming economy is expected to be a core pillar of the GOP's midterm messaging, it remains unclear whether the party will receive credit for the tax law, which has lagged in polls.

In response, GOP leaders on both sides of the Capitol are emphasizing a breadth of legislative achievements as they seek to convince voters to keep them in charge and not deliver majorities to Democrats. To bolster their case, Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) point to a flurry of wide-ranging bills sent to President Trump's desk last month.

In an interview with a major news outlet last month, McConnell highlighted last year's $1.5 trillion tax-cut package, but also pointed to increased spending for the military, 15 repealed regulations, and the confirmation of a conservative Supreme Court justice and 21 conservative circuit court judges. Ryan and his top lieutenants have made a similar pitch.

"We're doing more things this week to continue to establish our priorities," Majority Whip Steve Scalise (R-La.) told reporters Wednesday. "It's not just lowering taxes for families, but it's taking care of our military and taking care of our veterans."

In another move meant to paint the portrait of Republicans hard at work, McConnell announced Tuesday he would cancel most of the August recess so that senators could work through spending bills and Trump's nominations before a Sept. 30 funding deadline. The decision has the added benefit of keeping dozens of Democratic senators off the campaign trail in August.

"We think we have a good chance of passing a number of appropriations bills," McConnell told reporters during his weekly news conference on Tuesday. "In order to do that, and deal with this nominations backlog, we need to be here in August."

It remains unclear whether the GOP's messaging strategy will work, especially when accomplishments on Capitol Hill can be easily overshadowed by more dramatic developments coming out of the White House. The same week that Congress sent a trio of bills to Trump's desk, for example, the president dominated the news cycle by canceling a planned historic summit with North Korea.

The GOP Congress also has come up short on some of Trump's chief priorities, disappointing the president and his most fervent supporters. Despite majorities in both chambers and control of the White House, Republicans failed to repeal and replace Obamacare or fund Trump's signature border wall. Trump has bashed Congress over the failure on the wall in particular, to the chagrin of Republicans, who think it shortchanges the accomplishments that have been secured.

"I'd like the president to talk about it more often and I believe he will going into the fall campaign," McConnell said of the GOP's successes. The effort to push a more aggressive Republican agenda could please some conservatives, who have said tax reform alone is not enough to run on in the midterms.

"You can't just rest on your laurels," Rep. Mark Walker (R-N.C.), chairman of the Republican Study Committee, told a major news outlet on Wednesday. "You've got to keep fulfilling your promises to the American people."

While the tax law's poll numbers have improved, GOP strategists point out that some voters may not see the benefits until next year. There are also concerns that the economic gains from the tax law could be wiped out after Trump slapped tariffs on steel and aluminum imports worldwide, including from the European Union, Canada, and Mexico. Trump has threatened to follow up with additional tariffs on foreign cars and has also talked about imposing new tariffs on imports from China.

It can be difficult to accomplish major policy items in election years, with less time on the legislative calendar and vulnerable members reluctant to take any tough votes. But in recent months, Congress has seen an uptick in activity, with Trump signing legislation to ease financial regulations, improve how veterans access health care, and allow terminally ill patients to try experimental drugs. The House, which also passed a bipartisan prison reform bill last month, plans to take up legislation next week to combat the nation's deadly opioid crisis—an issue that resonates strongly in many communities around the country.

Congressional leaders want to avoid passing another short-term funding patch this year and are hoping to move spending legislation through both chambers before the end of September. Since it is the last train leaving the station, lawmakers will surely push to attach a number of priorities to the legislation. But if there are poison pill amendments—or if Trump refuses to sign any spending measure that doesn't contain money for his border wall—it could bring Congress to the brink of another shutdown just weeks before the midterms. That could chip away at the GOP's argument that they are effective legislators.

"It could be a real mess if it leads to a shutdown," said Matt Mackowiak, a GOP strategist and opinion contributor for a major news outlet. "So there's still some political risk out there for Republicans."

Title: President Obama Pursues 19 Separate Steps on Gun Control Without Congressional Approval

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, President Barack Obama is reportedly considering 19 separate steps on gun control that do not require congressional action. These measures, which include stricter gun trafficking laws, increased federal research on gun control, and school safety grants, are part of a broader plan to be unveiled this week.

The President's proposals will reportedly consist of a mix of measures that require congressional approval and steps he can implement independently. On Monday, during a press conference, Obama stated that he will present his proposals this week, with a focus on measures that are effective and practical rather than politically feasible.

Vice President Joe Biden, who is leading a task force on the issue, met with Democratic lawmakers on Monday to discuss potential measures. The specific proposals Obama will present this week remain undisclosed.

One contentious measure, a potential ban on military-style "assault weapons," is expected to face strong opposition in Congress. Figures such as National Rifle Association President David Keene and U.S. Senator John McCain (Arizona Republican) have predicted that such a ban would not pass through Congress.

In addition to the assault weapons ban, Congress may also consider limiting high-capacity ammunition clips and implementing universal background checks for gun buyers. President Obama acknowledged on Monday the challenges of passing some of these items through Congress.

"Will all of them get through this Congress? I don't know," Obama said. "My starting point is not to worry about the politics. My starting point is to focus on what makes sense, what works."

Title: Justice Department Declines Appeal, Paving Way for Potential Indictment of Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe

Article:

In a significant development, former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, a frequent subject of President Donald Trump's criticism, faces the possibility of an indictment after his legal team failed to convince senior Justice Department officials to forego charges related to allegations of lying to internal investigators. Two anonymous sources familiar with the matter revealed this information on Thursday.

The Deputy Attorney General declined an appeal from McCabe's lawyers aimed at preventing a prosecution. The sources, who were not authorized to discuss the issue publicly, spoke on the condition of anonymity. However, it remains unclear when or if the United States Attorney's Office in Washington, which has been spearheading the investigation, will announce charges.

McCabe's legal team has contended that he should not face charges based on accusations of lying to internal investigators about authorizing a media leak in the fall of 2016. McCabe has maintained that he did not intentionally mislead anyone.

An indictment of McCabe could reignite public attention on the turbulent months of 2016 when the FBI found itself embroiled in presidential politics, with investigations involving both major candidates—Democrat Hillary Clinton and Trump, her Republican opponent.

While prosecutors are expected to concentrate on whether McCabe lied to investigators on specific dates, McCabe's legal team is likely to argue that the prosecution is a result of a political vendetta driven by the president. They are expected to emphasize the personal animosity between the two men, with Trump criticizing McCabe even before he took office and McCabe describing the president as a "deliberate liar."

McCabe's lawyers have stated that any false statements made to investigators were due to a faulty memory, and that the interviews took place during a tumultuous time for the bureau as it investigated potential ties between Russia and the Trump campaign.

McCabe assumed the role of acting director of the FBI after Trump fired former Director James Comey on May 9, 2017. McCabe has said his 2018 firing—for what the Justice Department called "lack of candor"—was politically motivated. He sued the Justice Department in August, alleging that officials had used the inspector general's conclusions as a pretext to remove FBI leaders perceived as biased against Trump.

The investigation followed an October 2016 story in The Wall Street Journal that described internal debates within the FBI and the Department of Justice about the aggressiveness of the Clinton Foundation investigation weeks before the presidential election. The article recounted a particularly tense phone call between McCabe and a senior Justice Department official about the investigation.

The inspector general's report stated that McCabe told internal investigators that he had not authorized anyone at the FBI to speak with the reporter, and he did not know who did. The report also noted that McCabe ultimately corrected that account, and confirmed that he had encouraged the conversation with the reporter to counter a narrative that he thought was false—namely, that he had been trying to stymie investigations into Clinton and the foundation.

Title: Trump Secures Third Consecutive Victory in Nevada Republican Caucuses

Article:

In a significant development, Donald Trump has emerged victorious in the Nevada Republican Presidential caucuses on Tuesday, marking his third consecutive win in the primary race. Trump's victory, with 45.9% of the votes, surpasses his two closest rivals, Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, combined.

The latest victory for Trump, who has been a controversial figure in the political landscape, has shattered the supposed "ceiling" on his support, as predicted by political analysts. Trump's support was stronger among every demographic group, including evangelical Christians, Hispanics, and both genders. He also won among Republicans and independents, and among voters from various ideological, educational, and racial backgrounds.

Florida Senator Marco Rubio and Texas Senator Ted Cruz finished in second and third place, respectively. This result may not significantly boost either candidate's momentum, but it ensures that both remain in the race, which could potentially benefit Trump, as he attacks Cruz as a liar and dismisses Rubio as a lightweight.

The upcoming Super Tuesday contests, featuring a dozen states, including several in the South, the GOP's traditional stronghold, are set for next week. Texas Senator Ted Cruz, in an uncharacteristically subdued tone, warned supporters that it would be "the most important night of this campaign."

The theme that runs through Trump's supporters is a sense of concern and dissatisfaction with the current state of the nation. Nearly 94% of caucusgoers expressed a negative view of the government, and six in ten described themselves as "angry." An equal number said they wanted the next president to come from "outside politics."

At his victory rally in a Las Vegas hotel, Trump highlighted his success with various demographic groups, including Hispanics, young voters, and the "poorly educated." He predicted a "amazing two months" ahead, as the primary race moves forward.

Trump's victories in New Hampshire, South Carolina, and now Nevada, over a record-sized field, have expanded the Republican electorate and forged the broadest-based coalition of any of his opponents. The upcoming primaries and caucuses will test this coalition, as the race moves to states like Massachusetts, Vermont, Georgia, and Texas, where nearly a third of Republican convention delegates will be chosen. Two weeks later, with primaries in Florida, Ohio, and elsewhere, nearly two-thirds of the delegates will have been chosen.

The upcoming contests will provide insights into questions such as whether a single rival can defeat Trump in a head-to-head showdown, and the likelihood of a contested convention for the first time in four decades.

Title: Romney's Campaign Strategy: Distancing from Bush Policies in the Presidential Debate

Article:

DENVER — The upcoming presidential debate on Wednesday night is expected to see President Barack Obama taking a jab at Mitt Romney, likening his policies to a third term for George W. Bush. The attack is a strategic move by the Obama campaign, aiming to portray Romney as a continuation of Bush's hands-off approach to taxes, spending, and regulation, which, according to Obama, led to the economic crisis.

The strategy is reminiscent of Obama's successful attack on John McCain four years ago, where he attempted to associate McCain with the recent Republican unpleasantness. Although not as direct, the tactic serves to remind voters of the Republican administration's past and leave conservatives perplexed as to why their nominee has not rebutted the charge or attempted to turn the tables on both recent presidents.

Polling suggests that such a strategy, known as "triangulation," is not an option but a necessity. A CNN poll last month showed that 62 percent of self-described moderates blamed Bush and the Republicans for the country's economic troubles, while only 30 percent faulted Obama and the Democrats. By indicting both parties for America's fiscal problems, Romney could detach himself from Bush and gain credibility with voters tired of Washington's politics.

Michael Tanner, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, stated, "Making twin villains of Bush and Obama would blunt Obama's attacks on Romney wanting to return to the Bush policy. And it would help rally those tea party folks who don't think much of Bush or the Republican establishment."

Anti-tax crusader Grover Norquist added, "The speech writes itself." The debate is set to take place in Denver, Colorado, and will be the first of three face-to-face meetings between the two candidates before the November election.

Title: Wisconsin's Proposed $100 Million Tax Incentive Package for Kimberly-Clark Sparks Debate on Crony Capitalism

Article:

A proposed $100 million tax incentive package for Kimberly-Clark, a global paper products manufacturer, has sparked a heated debate in Wisconsin, with critics labeling it as an example of crony capitalism. The plan, aimed at keeping Kimberly-Clark's operations in the state, has been met with criticism from those who argue it undermines free market principles and fiscal responsibility.

In January, Kimberly-Clark announced plans to cut 13 percent of its global workforce, potentially resulting in the loss of up to 5,500 jobs nationally and the closing of ten of its 91 manufacturing facilities. Two of these facilities are in Neenah and Fox Crossing, Wisconsin, supporting 600 jobs.

The timing of Kimberly-Clark's announcement is significant, as Wisconsin recently finalized a $3 billion incentive package for technology company FoxConn, which plans to build an enormous $10 billion facility in the state that could employ up to 13,000. The cost of the FoxConn package is substantial, with estimates suggesting it amounts to between $219,000 and $587,000 per job.

Supporters argue that the FoxConn deal offers a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, and Governor Scott Walker has made it a centerpiece of his campaign for a third term. The hope is that it will spur the development of a new Silicon Valley along the western shore of Lake Michigan.

However, critics argue that this is a form of central planning, leading to market distortion, an inefficient use of resources, and a narrative of economic development built on myths and hubris. Rick Esenberg, president and general counsel of the Wisconsin Institute for Law & Liberty (WILL), and Collin Roth, director of public engagement and a policy analyst at WILL, have expressed their concerns, stating that such incentives serve neither business nor workers.

The proposed tax incentive package for Kimberly-Clark would offer a 17 percent tax credit for existing jobs paying between $30,000 and $100,000 annually (Wisconsin law currently allows for a 7 percent credit) and a 15 percent capital-investment credit.

Critics argue that the state's economy is already booming, with unemployment below 3 percent, wages rising, and business optimism up. Paying Kimberly-Clark $100 million to "save" 600 jobs, they contend, is unnecessary and could retard growth, as workers who stay at Kimberly-Clark are denied the opportunity to fill open jobs at Wisconsin businesses with better long-term prospects.

The debate highlights the ongoing tension between the desire for economic growth and the principles of free market economics. As the business cycle inevitably turns, the long-term implications of such incentive packages will become increasingly important.

Title: Trump and Clinton Clash in Contentious Second Presidential Debate

Article:

The second presidential debate at Washington University in St. Louis on Sunday night was a heated exchange between Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and Republican nominee Donald Trump, with both candidates attacking each other's character and policies.

The debate, moderated by Anderson Cooper and Martha Raddatz, took place just days after a leaked recording revealed Trump making lewd comments about women. Clinton, who had initially declined to shake hands with Trump, accused him of being unfit for the presidency and of lying throughout the debate. Trump, in response, suggested that if he were elected, Clinton would go to jail.

Trump, however, managed to regain some ground by putting Clinton on the defensive and reminding voters of what they do not like about her. He cited Clinton's destruction of emails that had been subpoenaed by Congress, her handling of the Benghazi attack, her stance on Syrian refugees, and her wavering support of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

One of the most contentious moments of the debate came when Trump was asked about his treatment of women, and he invited four women who had accused Bill Clinton of sexual assault or rape to participate in a press conference before the debate. Trump also brought up the dirty tricks campaign waged against Bernie Sanders by Clinton in cahoots with the Democratic National Committee.

Clinton, for her part, defended her record and her policies, touting her background in fighting terrorism and her commitment to children and families. She also discussed her plans for the Supreme Court, saying she would look for a justice who would support Roe vs. Wade and marriage equality, and would also appoint someone who would overturn Citizens United, and get dark money out of politics.

The debate in St. Louis was not a confrontation that made either candidate look noble or appealing. Trump, however, proved he is still in the race to win, and managed to cite Clinton's weaknesses and remind voters of the controversies surrounding her campaign. The election, it seems, will be a choice between two candidates with significant baggage, and the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: Iowa's Des Moines Register Endorses Clinton and Rubio Ahead of Presidential Caucuses, but Impact on Voters Unclear

Article:

In a move that has become a tradition since 1988, The Des Moines Register, the most prominent daily newspaper in Iowa, has endorsed Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Marco Rubio ahead of the presidential caucuses on February 1. The endorsements, however, may not significantly influence voters, as both candidates' rivals are expected to use the endorsements to their advantage.

In its dual editorials, The Des Moines Register praised Clinton's "depth" of "knowledge and experience" and her ability to work across party lines. The paper also commended Rubio for his potential to "chart a new direction" for the Republican Party. Despite acknowledging Clinton's email controversy and her changing stances on gay marriage and immigration, the paper argued that she is a more qualified candidate than Bernie Sanders and Martin O'Malley. Regarding Rubio, the paper noted that he still faces questions over his experience and ability to unite the party, but he could offer an "uplifting message" of a new American century.

Both campaigns quickly shared the respective editorials with their supporters. However, strategists and observers have raised questions about the endorsement's impact on voters, with some suggesting it could even be counterproductive. The Register has endorsed candidates in Iowa's presidential caucuses since 1988, but this cycle's endorsements were given in a politically charged atmosphere where traditional practices have become unwelcome reminders of insiderdom.

The two Republican candidates most likely to win the caucuses, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, did not seek the paper's endorsement. It remains unclear whether they would have accepted it, as Republican strategists and political observers predict that a Register endorsement could be used as a talking point by rivals, highlighting the winners' alignment with a mainstream media outlet's moderate-to-liberal lean.

David Yepsen, who covered politics for The Des Moines Register for 34 years, predicted that the Republican endorsement could backfire. "I think it will become a point to needle," said Yepsen. "See, we told you he was too liberal."

The Democratic endorsement may be more influential, as The Des Moines Register's left-leaning editorial board tends to connect better with Democrats. The Register would have been hard-pressed to abandon Clinton, whom it backed over then-Senator Barack Obama in late 2007. The paper described her as "ready" to lead the country in 2007, and it wrote, "We believe as president she'll do what she's always done in her life: Throw herself into the job and work hard."

Clinton won the endorsement despite the paper's editorial board almost entirely turning over since her last campaign. The Register's Saturday endorsements were its 10th and 11th since it first backed Democrat Paul Simon in 1988.

In a year marked by hostility towards mainstream media institutions, Cruz has warred with the Wall Street Journal editorial board, while Trump has fought with The Des Moines Register itself. The paper wrote an editorial last year slamming Trump for sexist comments, prompting Trump's campaign to deny press credentials to The Register for covering local events.

Candidates can now afford to do battle with prominent outlets, as they have 24/7 exposure. In previous caucus years, endorsements were more meaningful because candidates did not have constant media exposure, and a trusted editorial board was an important liaison to voters. Today, they are only good for a positive news cycle or two, according to Ari Fleischer, a former press secretary to President George W. Bush.

In the meantime, recipients' rivals will be working to spin the endorsement as a negative, especially on the Republican side, "with the dislike of all things establishment this cycle," said Kevin Madden, a spokesman for Mitt Romney's 2012 presidential campaign.

Over the years, The Des Moines Register has had mediocre luck at picking winners, and former New York Times data expert Nate Silver noted in 2011 that there is little evidence that candidates even received a statistical benefit from the endorsement. That year, the paper endorsed Romney, who lost the Republican caucuses narrowly to Rick Santorum but ultimately became the party's nominee.

In general, "I just think newspaper endorsements are kind of an antiquity," said Yepsen. "What it's worth is a little media buzz. The media writes about itself, and the race kind of moves on."

Title: Puerto Rico Governor Calls for Cancellation of Whitefish Energy Contract for Power Grid Restoration

Article:

In a significant development, Puerto Rico's Governor Ricardo Rosselló has called for the cancellation of a contract given to the Montana-based firm, Whitefish Energy, to aid in the rebuilding of the island's power grid. The head of the US-controlled island's power authority, the Puerto Rican Electric Power Authority (Prepa), has accepted the governor's recommendation and intends to terminate the deal.

The contract, awarded without a public bid process, was given to Whitefish Energy, a company with limited experience in projects of such scale. As of Sunday morning, more than 70% of people on Puerto Rico were without power, over five weeks after Hurricane Maria devastated the power grid.

Governor Rosselló has instructed Prepa to cancel the Whitefish contract and coordinate with the states of Florida and New York to reinforce the brigades currently rebuilding the grid on the island. Concerns have been raised about why Puerto Rican authorities did not request "mutual aid" from other public power authorities, as is typical during disasters in the US.

In response to the news, Whitefish Energy expressed disappointment in the decision, stating that it would delay the restoration of power to the people of Puerto Rico. The company maintains that it secured the $300 million deal in a legitimate manner.

The White House and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) distanced themselves from the deal last week. The company's headquarters is in the town of Whitefish, the hometown of US Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, who has denied any involvement or wrongdoing.

Earlier this week, Fema denied allegations by Prepa that it had reviewed the deal. The contract states that "Prepa hereby represents and warrants that Fema has reviewed and approved of this Contract." In a statement on Thursday, Fema stated, "Any language in any contract between Prepa and Whitefish that states Fema approved that contract is inaccurate."

Fema also expressed "significant concerns" with how Prepa procured the contract and had "not confirmed whether the contract prices [were] reasonable." It is unclear what will happen to any outstanding costs.

Puerto Rican authorities initially said Fema would pay for the deal. They later stated there was "nothing illegal" about the contract. Prepa and the Puerto Rican government are burdened with massive debts, with the power authority declaring bankruptcy in July.

The US House of Representatives Natural Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Caribbean island, is also scrutinizing the contract. On Friday, top Democrats from that panel and the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee sent a letter asking the Department of Homeland Security's inspector general to launch an investigation. The correspondence follows similar requests from other members of Congress to the interior department's inspector general.

The future of the power grid restoration in Puerto Rico remains uncertain as the investigation unfolds.

Title: Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer to Deliver Democratic Response to President Trump's State of the Union Address

Article:

In the aftermath of President Donald Trump's State of the Union address scheduled for Tuesday night, the focus will shift to Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer, who will deliver the Democratic response to the president's speech.

Governor Whitmer, a 48-year-old former prosecutor, made history in Michigan as the first female leader of the Democratic caucus in the state Senate before becoming the Wolverine state's governor in 2018, defeating GOP nominee Bill Schuette in the midterm elections. The victory came two years after Michigan, a battleground state, helped secure Donald Trump's election victory over Hillary Clinton in 2016.

During the January primary debate, Democratic presidential hopeful Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) highlighted Whitmer as a female candidate who had proven her ability to win against male competitors in various races across the country. In her election campaign, Whitmer emphasized expanding healthcare and focused on "dinner-table issues," which she stated are central to the party's strength.

Whitmer has maintained a strategy of avoiding divisive, partisan fights by minimizing mentions of President Trump. In an interview with the Associated Press following her selection for the response, Whitmer stated that voters in her state are more concerned with "fundamentals," such as addressing deteriorating roads and offering job training for better-paying positions.

Upon announcing Whitmer as the Democrats' choice for the rebuttal, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) praised the Michigan governor, stating, "Whether it's pledging to 'Fix the Damn Roads' or investing in climate solutions, Governor Whitmer's vision for the future is exactly what this country needs, and I'm thrilled she is giving the Democratic response."

Whitmer echoed Schumer's sentiments, stating, "These are the fundamentals that people in America are concerned about." She added that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi believed her message would resonate with the public.

Governor Whitmer's response to President Trump's State of the Union address will follow immediately after the president's speech, which is scheduled for 9 p.m. ET on Feb. 4.

Title: "The Enduring Threat of Mass Surveillance: A Look at the Patriot Act and the Fourth Amendment"

Article:

In the history of the United States, the Fourth Amendment, a cornerstone of individual liberties, was enacted to prevent the government from engaging in the same practices that sparked the American Revolution. However, in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, the Patriot Act was introduced, which, critics argue, has eroded the very principles it was designed to uphold.

The Patriot Act, enacted in 2001, was passed in haste and with minimal debate, with members of Congress given mere minutes to review its 300-plus pages. Section 505 of the Act allows federal agents to issue their own search warrants, bypassing the requirements of the Fourth Amendment. These agent-written warrants, known as National Security Letters, are not based on probable cause of crime but rather on a representation by one agent to another of governmental needs.

Since 2001, federal agents have issued over 300,000 of these search warrants to custodians of financial records, telecom providers, computer service providers, supermarkets, credit card issuers, health care insurers and providers, legal service providers, local and state governments, and even the Post Office. The concept of one federal agent authorizing another to seize records is antithetical to the Fourth Amendment and repugnant to the American Revolution.

Section 215, which is set to expire on March 15, is equally contentious. It permits designated federal judges to issue general warrants based on the old writs of assistance standard of governmental need. In 2013, a judge signed a search warrant for the telephone records of all Verizon customers in the U.S., at the time numbering 115 million.

Both Sections 215 and 505 are seen as weapons of mass surveillance and should be repealed. They are instruments of a totalitarian government, not of free people. They defy the Constitution. They presume that our rights are not natural but come from a government that can take them back. Mass surveillance produces a state that knows more about us than we do about it—one that will slowly consume our freedoms in the name of governmental needs. It already has.

Judge Andrew P. Napolitano, Fox News' senior judicial analyst, has been published in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and numerous other publications. He is the author of the best-seller, "Lies the Government Told You: Myth, Power, and Deception in American History." For more of Judge Napolitano's reports, visit his website.

Title: Court Filing Reveals FBI's Attempt to Arrest Mysterious Professor Joseph Mifsud, Whose Interactions with George Papadopoulos Hindered Russia Probe

Article:

In a recent court filing by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, it has been revealed that FBI agents had considered arresting the mysterious Maltese professor, Joseph Mifsud, during the Russia probe, but he left the United States before they had gathered sufficient evidence.

According to the filing, the FBI located Mifsud in Washington D.C., but lacked enough information to detain him due to the misleading information provided by George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign volunteer who pleaded guilty to lying about Mifsud during the initial FBI interview in January 2017. Papadopoulos is set to be sentenced on Sept. 7, with the special counsel recommending a prison sentence of zero to six months.

Papadopoulos and Mifsud had met in London in the spring of 2016, while Papadopoulos was working at a think tank and officially serving as a Trump adviser. Mifsud, a professor who teaches in Malta and circulates among think tanks in Europe, including Russia, is a somewhat enigmatic figure.

At that time, the public was unaware that Russia had hacked and stolen thousands of emails from the Democratic Party, which would later be published by Wikileaks. The public was, however, aware of the controversy surrounding Hillary Clinton's deletion of 30,000 emails that could have been relevant to the investigation into her mishandling of classified information during her tenure as secretary of state.

Mifsud informed Papadopoulos that the Kremlin possessed "thousands" of Clinton emails, a statement whose exact meaning remains unclear.

Papadopoulos lied, the court filing stated, by saying the meeting occurred in February before he joined the campaign instead of the actual April date. "Rather than acknowledging these contacts and communications," the filing said, "the defendant concealed them from the FBI. He lied about their timing, extent, and nature."

The lies, Mueller added, "impeded the FBI's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election." The defendant's lies, the filing continued, "substantially hindered investigators' ability to effectively question the Professor when the FBI located him in Washington, D.C., approximately two weeks after the defendant's January 27, 2017, interview. The defendant's lies undermined investigators' ability to challenge the Professor or potentially detain or arrest him while he was still in the United States. The government understands that the Professor left the United States on February 11, 2017, and he has not returned since then."

Papadopoulos' self-appointed mission in London was to set up a meeting between candidate Trump and the Kremlin. He asked Mifsud for contacts and spoke to a Russian woman with ties to the Foreign Ministry. However, no such meeting ever transpired, and Papadopoulos has not been charged with any collusion.

Title: Twitter Introduces New Policy for Handling Rule-Violating Tweets from Politicians and Government Leaders

Article:

Twitter, the popular social media platform, has announced a new policy for handling tweets from politicians and government leaders that violate its rules but are still in the public interest. The new policy will place a notice over such tweets, requiring users to click or tap on the warning to view the content.

In a tweet, Twitter's safety team stated, "Sometimes, we decide that it may be in the public's interest for certain Tweets to remain on Twitter, even if they would otherwise break our rules." The team further added, "We're going to start using a new notice to make it clear when we make these decisions."

The new policy will apply to verified government officials, political candidates, and people being considered for a government position who have more than 100,000 followers. Before viewing the tweet, users will see a notice that says, "The Twitter Rules about abusive behavior apply to this Tweet. However, Twitter has determined it may be in the public's interest for the Tweet to remain available."

This change is part of Twitter's recent efforts to combat harassment and abuse on its site. In the past, the company has argued against removing problematic tweets from world leaders, including President Donald Trump, due to their public interest.

President Trump, a prolific Twitter user, has on multiple occasions accused social media companies of being biased against conservatives. Social media companies, for their part, have apologized for how they've handled some conservative content, but deny any bias and say they do not censor political views. As of yet, Trump has not tweeted about Twitter's latest move.

In addition to placing the notice over tweets that break its rules, Twitter said those tweets will appear less prominently on the site and will not show up in places like safe search or the Explore tab. The notice will not be applied to any tweets sent before Thursday.

A team including regional members will decide when to use the notice and will consider factors such as the potential harm from the rule violation, whether preserving the tweet will allow people to hold politicians accountable, and other factors.

The White House did not respond to a request for comment.

This development comes as senators grill Twitter and Facebook over alleged political bias, with the latest hearing taking place recently.

Updates:
- June 28: Added more details on Twitter's notice.
- Added more background.

Title: President Trump Stands Firm on Border Wall Funding as Government Shutdown Looms

Article:

As the deadline for a government funding bill approaches, President Donald Trump has reiterated his commitment to securing funding for the U.S.-Mexico border wall, potentially leading to a partial government shutdown if a deal cannot be reached by December 21. The Democrats, who have previously rejected similar funding proposals, are insisting on limiting funding to $1.6 billion for border security.

In March, President Trump declared that he would never sign another bloated spending bill like the $1.3 trillion Omnibus bill that did not include funding for the border wall. He has since pledged to fix the country's immigration system, even if it requires a government shutdown.

During the last budget impasse, President Trump offered a generous deal to congressional Democrats, agreeing to grant legal status to nearly a million DACA recipients in exchange for border wall funding. However, the Democrats rejected the proposal, despite the $5 billion requested for the wall accounting for less than 0.004 percent of the total amount Congress appropriated.

If a partial government shutdown occurs, it would primarily affect the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), which includes Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). However, even in the event of a temporary funding lapse for DHS, Border Patrol and ICE agents would still be required to report for duty. Previous shutdowns have resulted in back pay for affected employees.

The Democrats are portraying a potential shutdown as a national catastrophe, but the reality is that two-thirds of the federal government is already funded, and a shutdown would not significantly impact most federal employees, including those in the armed forces.

Harlan Hill, a political advisor, media commentator, and an advisory board member of the Donald J. Trump for President, Inc., believes that President Trump is not going to abandon his priority of securing the border in the interest of political expediency. The Democrats, according to Hill, are using fearmongering tactics to manipulate public and press opinion.

Title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls Face Backlash Over Controversial Remarks on America's Past

Article:

In a series of recent statements, several potential 2020 Democratic presidential candidates have faced criticism for comments perceived as critical of America's past, sparking a national debate on the party's stance towards the nation's history.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, a name often floated in discussions about the 2020 Democratic presidential race, found himself in the midst of a controversy this week after he said America "was never that great." The remark, made during a bill signing, has been interpreted as a critique of President Donald Trump's campaign slogan, "Make America Great Again."

Cuomo's office has since released a statement clarifying that he believes America is great, but that it has yet to reach its full potential. In a call with reporters, he described the remark as "inartful."

The comment is the latest in a series of bolder statements from Democrats, who have been calling out what they see as injustices or inequalities in America. The Republican National Committee (RNC) has seized on these remarks, with an email blast this week stating that "the only thing that seems to unite prominent Democrats these days is their collective bashing of America."

President Trump, in a series of tweets, criticized Cuomo's statement, calling it a "career-threatening" remark and predicting that "his political career is over."

Other potential 2020 candidates have also made remarks that some perceive as critical of America or large segments of its population.

Senator Cory Booker (D-N.J.) said in a speech in New Orleans that there is "a normalcy of injustice" in America. Senator Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) said that America's economic inequality is "fundamentally immoral." Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) described America's criminal justice system as "racist, front to back."

The RNC has pointed to these remarks as evidence that Democrats are out of touch with the public, with a 2016 Washington Post poll finding that only seven percent of those polled said that America has never been great.

The controversy surrounding these remarks highlights the delicate balance that potential 2020 Democratic candidates must navigate when discussing America's past, as they seek to appeal to both the progressive wing of the party and the broader electorate.

Title: Grassroots Movement Gains Momentum in Iowa for Elizabeth Warren Presidential Bid

Article:

Des Moines, Iowa (CNN) - A small office park in Des Moines serves as the hub for a grassroots effort to persuade Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) to run for the Democratic presidential nomination. The only indication of the activity within is a yard sign taped to a door.

On a recent weekday afternoon, about 20 volunteers gathered to strategize on how to convince their friends, neighbors, and, most importantly, the Massachusetts senator, to join the race.

"Who's Warren?" asked retiree Gordon Rowe, describing the reaction he receives when he talks up the Massachusetts senator. "They don't know who Elizabeth Warren is. I tell them they need to get involved; they're middle class too, and they need representation."

The term "middle class" is repeatedly used when discussing Warren supporters. They believe she understands, represents, and will help rebuild the middle class. The conviction that Warren is fighting for them on issues such as income inequality and regulating Wall Street is the driving force behind their effort to draft her into the race, despite her repeated dismissals.

Blair Lawton, Iowa Field Director for the Run Warren Run campaign, acknowledged their current position. "We totally take Senator Warren at her word right now," he said. "We know that right now she's not running, and if she was, we wouldn't have a reason for a draft campaign like this. Really, me and my staff's goal every day is to show her that she has got support all across the state and a path to victory."

Their strategies include holding meetings to teach volunteers grassroots political techniques, setting up phone banks to call Iowa Democrats, and having Run Warren Run representatives attend small Democratic meetings across the state.

Beth Farvour, a Run Warren Run regional field director, attended a meeting in Tipton, where she explained her reasons for supporting Warren to the 40 or so Cedar County Democrats. Farvour, who spoke before Martin O'Malley, was politely received, as were representatives making similar cases for Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Clinton remains the frontrunner at this early stage in Iowa.

The Run Warren Run campaign is being funded by MoveOn.org, which has pledged to spend $1 million on the effort, and Democracy for America, which has contributed an additional $250,000. In Iowa, the campaign has eight staff members who travel the state promoting her candidacy. Run Warren Run also has staffers in New Hampshire.

Warren's supporters, almost to a person, are hesitant to entertain the possibility that the Massachusetts senator will not run for the White House.

"I think we can get her in the race," said Katie Freerksen, a veterinarian technician who started volunteering three months ago. "I think we are capable of it, because this has grown so much since I have gotten involved."

Toria Pinter, a law student on medical leave, was drawn to Warren because of the senator's vocal call to lower the interest rates on student loans. Pinter emphasized that this campaign is not an anti-Clinton effort but a pro-Warren movement.

"The campaign is not about Clinton," she said. "That's not what we are here to talk about. We are here to talk about Warren and how important she is to us because she embodies the ideals and issues that are important to us at the end of the day."

Lawton acknowledged the long-term benefits from this campaign, including "putting a big investment into the progressive community."

"I am confident every day if we do our job we get her to enter this race," he said. "But also, you know, other goals, as well, on top of getting her to run: I want to make sure every time a campaign comes in we are leaving the community in a better place. So really what we are doing right now, by getting volunteers involved and training them, we are really helping to build the progressive movement across the state of Iowa."

Title: Obama Administration and Iran Nuclear Deal: A "Political Agreement" Instead of a Written Accord

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Obama administration's pursuit of a nuclear deal with Iran may result in a "political agreement" rather than a written accord, as reported by Western diplomats involved in the negotiations. This development comes as the deadline for a preliminary agreement approaches in the next seven days.

The lack of a written accord, signed by the Iranians, is a departure from traditional diplomatic practice. Iran has reportedly resisted a formal "framework" agreement at this stage, preferring a more general "understanding" followed by a final accord in June.

This development is not entirely unexpected, given the history of the negotiations between the Obama administration and the Ayatollah Khamenei regime.
