White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest has consistently downplayed the significance of the March deadline. In response to a question last Friday about the consequences of a deal not being reached by the end of March, Earnest stated:

"What we would anticipate at the end of this year is essentially — or at the end of this month, pardon me — at the end of this month, we would anticipate a political agreement. What that means is it means some very specific commitments from the Iranians about their nuclear program and about how some of their nuclear facilities are run. It would also include very serious commitments by the Iranians to agree to a set of historically intrusive inspections."

However, Earnest also noted that the technical experts would require time to discuss the implementation of these political agreements, with the technical negotiations and discussions expected to be resolved by the end of June.

The New York Times reports that the Khamenei regime does not acknowledge the existence of the March deadline. A senior administration official who was in Lausanne for the talks last week stated that the United States still hoped to agree on specific limits by the end of March, defining the parameters of a more detailed, comprehensive agreement to be completed by the end of June.

This two-step process, initially envisioned by Secretary of State John Kerry in November, was intended to demonstrate concrete progress to Congress and keep the process with the Iranians moving. However, Ayatollah Khamenei's unexpected statement in early February that there would be only one agreement left the United States and its allies in a precarious position. The March deadline, it seems, was primarily a tool for President Obama to declare victory in "ending" Iran's nuclear program before any actual deal is made.

This development could have significant implications for the Obama administration's legacy and the political landscape of the United States. By securing a "political agreement" before the June deadline, Obama may be able to claim a significant foreign policy achievement, potentially influencing the narrative surrounding his legacy and the 2016 presidential election.

Title: GOP's Focus on Healthcare Reform and Midterm Elections Strategy Under Scrutiny

Article:

In a recent development, the Republican party's agenda appears to be shifting towards a focus on the upcoming midterm elections, with immigration reform and other significant legislative initiatives seemingly taking a back seat. This change in strategy has been confirmed by conservative reporters, including The Washington Post's Robert Costa, who suggests that comprehensive immigration reform, tax reform, and tweaks to the federal health-care law are unlikely to progress in the current Congress.

Costa reports that Republican representatives, such as Rep. Devin Nunes (Calif.) and pollster Frank Luntz, have acknowledged the difficulty in passing major legislation in a divided government. Nunes stated, "We can do a few things on immigration and work on our principles, but in terms of real legislating, we’re unable to get in a good negotiating position." Luntz added, "It is an acknowledgment of where they stand, where nothing can happen in divided government so we may essentially have the status quo."

While it is not unusual for legislative activity to slow down ahead of an election, the timing of this shift in strategy is noteworthy. February is typically early in the election cycle for one party to transition from policymaking to politicking, especially when the opposing party is actively advancing a positive and popular agenda.

The Senate has already passed comprehensive, bipartisan immigration reform and the Employment Non-Discrimination Act. If Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid uses the Senate to pass (or to force Republicans to filibuster) additional bills, such as renewing emergency unemployment compensation, a Voting Rights Act patch, an equal pay bill, a minimum wage bill, and so on, it will look awkward if the House has little to offer in return.

Healthcare might be the exception, as House Majority Leader Eric Cantor has practically committed to passing an Affordable Care Act alternative this year. However, history suggests that this intention may fizzle, leaving Republicans with full repeal – a political loser – as their official health care reform platform going into the midterms.

If the GOP's strategy is to focus solely on the Affordable Care Act, it raises questions about their ability to offer a comprehensive and popular agenda to the public. The electoral map may also contribute to inertia by making the GOP's strategy unfalsifiable. With Senate Democrats defending seats won in 2008 and the House in a midterm three years after they gerrymandered themselves a durable majority, even a bad GOP strategy will likely yield significant gains in the Senate and retention of the House.

This focus on the Affordable Care Act also raises questions about the GOP's long-term strategy, as winning in 2014 might not require them to offer a broader agenda. However, it may leave them without much to show the public if they watch Democrats actively advancing legislation and begin to wonder what the GOP has to offer other than a single-minded opposition to the Affordable Care Act.

This shift in strategy is a departure from the past, as Congressional Democrats in 2006 outlined a broad and thorough agenda and vowed to advance it through the House if they won. When they did win, they let the Bush administration be the story for the next two years but also moved items that lacked GOP support through the House to establish a Democratic agenda. This year's Republicans, however, seem incapable of replicating this approach. Winning in 2014 might not require them to be, but it may leave them without much to show the public if they watch Democrats actually doing things and begin to wonder what the GOP has to offer other than a single-minded opposition to the Affordable Care Act.

Title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Trump Administration's Contraceptive Mandate Accommodation vs. Obama Administration's Policy

Article:

In a significant development, the Supreme Court heard arguments this week on the Trump administration's accommodation for the contraceptive mandate, which is in contrast to the Obama administration's policy. The Obama administration's policy, which was aimed at pushing the cost of contraceptive care onto insurers and plan administrators, allowed employers who objected to the coverage to avoid paying for it, while their employees would still be covered automatically.

The heart of the case is whether the contraceptive mandate and the Obama administration's workaround impose a substantial burden on the religious beliefs of employers. However, if employers are not providing the contraceptive coverage, there is no burden on them.

The Obama administration's compromise required objecting organizations to simply inform the federal government that they indeed object. From there, the government would have worked with the objectors' health insurers to offer costless contraception directly to their employees. Beyond giving notice, the objectors would have suffered no further involvement and paid nothing for any contraceptive care their employees received.

The mandate's critics argue that the mere act of giving notice would be intolerable, and that nothing short of offering full exemptions to practically any employer that wants one will do. Federal law demands special care for the concerns of the faithful in striking a balance between religious liberty and governmental interests. It does not insist that there be no balance at all. The Obama administration accommodated all sides in good faith. The court should respect the principled balance that the Obama administration struck.

Every member of the Supreme Court's conservative majority has, in the past, expressed sympathy for religious objectors seeking exemptions from a generally applicable law. However, each has also expressed a desire to limit federal agencies' discretion to make policy. And on Wednesday, several of those conservative justices appeared to realize that these two goals are in tension—at least in the two Pennsylvania cases.

The cases primarily ask whether the Trump administration has the power to give religious objectors a sweeping exemption, regardless of whether such an exemption is required by law. At least three of the Court's conservatives, Justices Clarence Thomas, Neil Gorsuch, and Brett Kavanaugh, expressed concerns that the Trump administration may not have this power. In a 2019 opinion, Gorsuch proposed revising the largely defunct 'nondelegation doctrine,' a constitutional doctrine briefly used in the 1930s to restrict Congress's power to delegate authority to the Roosevelt administration. While Gorsuch's opinion in that 2019 case, Gundy v. United States, is vague, it suggests the possibility of a cross-partisan coalition to strike down the broad exemption.

Title: Fact-Checking President Trump's NATO Defense Spending Claims: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

In a fact-check of President Donald Trump's claims about NATO defense spending, NPR national security correspondent David Welna reports that the U.S. has not been stiffed for unpaid bills by NATO allies, contrary to Trump's assertions.

Welna notes that Trump reiterated his claims about NATO's European allies during a breakfast meeting in Brussels, stating that many countries owe the U.S. a significant amount of money from past years due to the U.S. having to pay for them. However, former Obama administration National Security Council official Aaron O'Connell explains that NATO is not like a club with annual membership fees, and there is no ledger that maintains accounts of what countries pay and owe.

Trump also highlighted Germany's defense spending, stating that the country is only paying 1.25 percent of its GDP, while the U.S. is spending 4.2 percent. However, Germany indeed devotes only about 1.25 percent of its GDP to defense, and while it has increased defense spending the past two years, it does not plan to reach the 2 percent mark by 2024, as agreed upon by NATO members four years ago.

Trump also called on NATO member states to spend 4 percent of their GDP on defense, a figure that is at odds with the Pentagon's estimate of the U.S. defense spending at 3.3 percent of GDP. American University NATO scholar Garret Martin notes that the U.S. defense needs vastly surpass those of its European allies, as the U.S. is a global military power with global military commitments.

Last week at a rally in Montana, Trump made another claim about NATO funding, stating that the U.S. is paying for 70 to 90 percent to protect Europe. However, former NSC staffer O'Connell explains that the U.S. pays 22 percent of a common budget that all NATO allies pay into, not 90 percent.

Trump also sought to take credit for NATO allies spending more, stating that commitments have been made for over $40 billion dollars since the last meeting. However, NATO reported yesterday that spending by European members has increased by $35 billion, not $40 billion. American University's Martin notes that the higher spending continues a trend that predates Trump.

NATO General Secretary Jens Stoltenberg pointed out that despite Trump's complaints about the U.S. spending too much, it is actually spending more than before. Stoltenberg also noted that U.S. funding for military presence in Europe, the European Deterrence Initiative, has been increased by 40 percent, a spending increase that was approved by Congress.

The Senate last night and the House today overwhelmingly approved resolutions backing NATO, demonstrating bipartisan support for the military alliance.

Title: Trump and Pence Celebrate Carrier Deal as a Victory for U.S. Job Preservation

Article:

In a move hailed as a successful negotiation, President-elect Donald Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence will take a victory lap in Indianapolis on Thursday to highlight the preservation of nearly 1,000 U.S. jobs at Carrier, a manufacturing company based in Indianapolis. The deal, which has been characterized as a demonstration of Trump's commitment to protect U.S. jobs and workers, has been met with praise from both political parties.

Kellyanne Conway, Trump's former campaign manager and top adviser, described the Carrier deal as a winning negotiation that could be replicated once Trump takes office. Few details have been revealed about the specifics of the agreement, but it is believed that Carrier will keep about 850 jobs in Indiana and has been offered tax incentives by the state government.

Carrier, which is owned by United Technologies, a larger company based in Connecticut with contracts with the U.S. government, issued a statement on Wednesday, stating that incentives offered by Indiana were "an important consideration" in its decision, but offering no further details. The White House downplayed the news, stating that President Obama's policies had created more than 800,000 manufacturing jobs.

Trump's team argues that the Carrier deal shows Trump can build a positive climate for business, behind an overhaul of the tax code and reduction of regulations, that will grow the economy at a faster pace than what has been seen during the Obama years. John Feehery, a Trump supporter and Republican strategist, deemed Trump's use of the bully pulpit to keep American jobs here "great politics."

However, fiscally conservative groups are staying quiet about the deal for the time being. If it turns out that Trump and Pence have offered any special concessions to Carrier, either at the federal level or the state level, given that the vice president-elect is still the governor of Indiana, then those free-market groups are likely to cry foul.

The particulars of this agreement have not been released, but our position on corporate welfare is well-known, and that has not changed, said Brent Gardner, chief government affairs officer at Americans for Prosperity, a major grassroots organization within the network of conservative mega-donors Charles and David Koch.

The Carrier deal could set a precedent for Trump's approach to job preservation, and it remains to be seen how this will impact U.S. companies and the economy as a whole. House Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) stated that he had no issues with Trump personally getting involved to prevent the outsourcing of jobs, as long as it is in the best interest of the country.

In two speeches toward the end of the presidential campaign, Trump argued against using incentives like low-interest loans and tax cuts to entice U.S. firms to stay put. It remains to be seen how Trump's willingness to negotiate one-on-one with a company will impact the free-market orthodoxy of the Republican Party.

Title: Marco Rubio: The Seabiscuit of the 2016 Republican Race

Article:

In the current political landscape, the 2016 Republican primary race bears a striking resemblance to the presidential race of eight years ago. A young, first-term U.S. senator, Marco Rubio, is making his bid for the presidency, much like Barack Obama did in 2008. Despite a stumble in the New Hampshire debate, Rubio remains in a comfortable position, ready to make his move when the opportunity arises.

America, like eight years ago, is seeking renewed hope and a sense of identity, yearning for a leader who will represent the dignity, decorum, and exceptional qualities of the United States. The current campaign trail is marked by a current of anger, as seen in the campaigns of Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, and Bernie Sanders. However, beneath this veneer, there is an undercurrent of optimism for a better future and a leader who embodies the American spirit.

Marco Rubio, in many ways, is reminiscent of the thoroughbred racehorse Seabiscuit. Currently in third place, Rubio is keeping a steady pace, with Cruz and Trump well within his sights. The winner of this race is not the candidate who takes the lead early on, but the one who finishes first at the national convention.

For Rubio, winning the Republican nomination could be as simple as 3-2-1: finishing third in Iowa, second in New Hampshire, and first in South Carolina, then maintaining a swift pace all the way to Cleveland. If his performance in the New Hampshire debate lands him lower than second, he has more than enough time to regain his stride and overtake the leaders.

As the race heats up, Rubio and his team need to emphasize several key points. America is not the country of 200 years ago; it is a melting pot of immigrants from all over the world. Rubio, as the son of Cuban-Americans, should highlight his parents' struggle and his rags-to-riches story as an inspiration for all ethnic groups, not just Latinos.

Rubio should also address the equality of all ethnic groups and religions in our country, demonstrating his commitment to unity and inclusivity. Investing in big data and data-crunching capabilities, similar to what Ted Cruz did in Iowa, will be crucial in giving Rubio the direction needed to win the race.

Rubio finished third in Iowa, but closer to Trump than expected. Now, he hopes to finish second in New Hampshire, behind Trump, and ahead of Cruz. This could give him the momentum to come in first on Feb. 23 in Nevada, where he's been endorsed by Sheldon Adelson's powerful Las Vegas-Review, and then on Feb. 27 in South Carolina, where several key members of his team have strong roots. By Super Tuesday, when voters in 14 states go to the polls, Rubio could already be in the lead.

Rubio has been articulate in outlining his plans for issues like immigration, healthcare, and national security, and he has provided more substantive details on his website than any of his opponents. Cruz has criticized Rubio for his involvement with the "Gang of Eight," but seeking bipartisan support to solve problems is a commendable approach, and Rubio should use that to his advantage.

Marco Rubio is a compassionate, brilliant, articulate, focused leader who can rally America to a new era. Now is his time to sharpen his focus, take the lead at the end of the first turn, pace himself in the backstretch, and leave the others in his dust as he sprints to the finish line.

Title: U.S. and Iran Agree on Extension of Nuclear Talks, Amidst Congressional Criticism and Ongoing Negotiations

Article:

In a last-ditch diplomatic effort, the U.S. and its allies have agreed to extend the nuclear talks with Iran by seven months, aiming to limit Tehran's ability to produce nuclear weapons. The extension was announced on Monday, following a week of tough negotiations in Vienna.

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and other Western foreign ministers, who gathered in Vienna for the talks, described the extension as the best way forward. Kerry stated, "We would be fools to walk away." However, it appears that little progress was made in the negotiations, with the parties now aiming to agree on specific terms by March 1, with a final agreement to follow four months later.

Criticism from Congress was swift, with powerful Republicans expressing concern that Iran is merely buying time. Members of the new Republican-controlled Congress, set to be sworn in early next year, have already threatened to impose additional sanctions on Iran and may have enough votes to overturn an expected veto by President Barack Obama.

Sen. Mark Kirk, an Illinois Republican, lamented, "The one thing the Iranians did not have was time, and now they have 219 days." Kirk and Sen. Bob Menendez of New Jersey, who have worked together on oil sanctions, pledged to come forward with a new bipartisan sanctions package after the Republican takeover of the Senate. Menendez stated, "I'll work to ensure that Iran comprehends that we will not ever permit it to become a threshold nuclear state."

The U.S. administration strongly opposes additional sanctions, fearing it will push Tehran away from the negotiating table. Kerry called for patience, stating, "I hope congressional skeptics will 'come to see the wisdom' of giving talks an extra 'few months to be able to proceed without sending messages that might be misinterpreted.'"

In Tehran, hard-liners may increase pressure on Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to break off talks. However, the latest extension appears to have the approval of Khamenei, the ultimate arbiter in Iran. Positive comments by Iranian President Hassan Rouhani reflected Khamenei's backing.

Rouhani stated, "Many gaps have been eliminated," though he added that the sides were "still some distance" from a deal. U.S.-Iran relations have warmed since Rouhani took office last year, and the thaw has extended to the nuclear negotiations.

Monday's decision benefits Iran, as its nuclear program remains frozen but intact, without any of the cuts sought by the U.S. The negotiations will continue, and monthly dole-outs of $700 million in frozen funds will continue. British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond stated, "We are giving ourselves until March to agree on a text 'that sets out in layman's language what we have agreed to do.'" Experts will then have four months to "translate that into precise definitions of what will happen on the ground."

Among the issues the two sides are haggling over are the number and type of centrifuges Iran should be allowed to have, as well as the length of constraints on Tehran's nuclear program. The U.S. and Iran have different views on these matters, with the U.S. pushing for deeper and more lasting cuts in the program than Tehran is willing to give, and Iran insisting on no more than 10 years of constraints.

Past talks have often ended on an acrimonious note, with each side blaming the other for lack of a deal. However, Kerry focused on praise, in an apparent attempt to maintain a relatively cordial atmosphere at the negotiating table. Kerry stated, "We have made real and substantial progress and we have seen new ideas surface." The foreign ministers of the six powers also sought to put a good face on what was achieved.

Title: Gantz and Lieberman Agree to Collaborate, Threatening Netanyahu's Chances of Forming a New Government

Article:

Israeli opposition leader Benny Gantz, head of the Blue and White Party, announced on Monday that he had agreed to work with Avigdor Lieberman, leader of the small Yisrael Beiteinu party, in an effort to form a new government following the national elections last week. This development poses a significant setback for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is currently facing corruption charges and is struggling to maintain his grip on power.

In a statement, Gantz reported that he had held a productive meeting with Lieberman, during which they discussed matters of fundamental principle and determined their intention to assemble a government that would end Israel's political deadlock and avoid a fourth round of elections.

Last week's election, Israel's third in less than a year, saw Netanyahu's Likud party emerge as the largest party. However, with his smaller religious and nationalist allies, Netanyahu secured only 58 seats in parliament, three short of the required 61-seat majority needed to form a new government. Netanyahu's opponents, led by Gantz, control a majority of seats. Yet, beyond their shared animosity towards Netanyahu, there are deep divisions between these parties, including Lieberman's secular, ultra-nationalist party and the Arab-led Joint List.

Gantz's announcement with Lieberman represents a step towards unifying the anti-Netanyahu forces, although it remains uncertain whether they can reach a final agreement, let alone a deal with Arab politicians. In the past, Lieberman has branded Arab political leaders as "terrorist" sympathizers.

"We'll continue to discuss the details, formulate our common objectives, and move forward," Gantz said.

Netanyahu is determined to remain as prime minister as he prepares to go on trial on March 17. He has been charged with fraud, breach of trust, and accepting bribes in connection to a series of scandals that include accepting expensive gifts from wealthy friends and offering to exchange favors with powerful media moguls. Netanyahu's lawyers have requested a delay in the start of the trial, citing the need for more time to review evidence. Prosecutors on Monday opposed any delays.

Israel's president, Reuven Rivlin, must decide by next week who to choose as the prime minister-designate. The president typically chooses the candidate he deems has the best chance of forming a governing coalition. Netanyahu has defiantly insisted he won last week's election and accused his opponents of trying to "steal the elections" by aligning with Arab-led parties he claimed were hostile to the state. "I promise you, I am not going anywhere," Netanyahu said over the weekend.

Title: President Obama Defends U.S. Airstrikes in Somalia, Cites Improved Procedures and Potential Death of Senior Al-Shabab Commander

Article:

WASHINGTON — In a press conference on Friday, President Obama defended the regular use of drone strikes and other airstrikes by his administration to target terror leaders and training camps in Somalia, Libya, and Yemen. The President acknowledged that in the past, such strikes have inadvertently resulted in civilian casualties, but he emphasized that the procedures for approving such strikes have improved.

"There has been legitimate criticism that the legal architecture around the use of drone strikes or other kinetic strikes wasn't as precise as it should have been, and there's no doubt that civilians were killed that shouldn't have been," Obama said at the end of the Nuclear Security Summit in Washington. "What I can say with great confidence is that our operating procedures are as rigorous as they have ever been, and that there is a constant evaluation of precisely what we do," he added, without offering specifics.

Obama's remarks came after the U.S. military announced on Friday that it had conducted an airstrike the previous day targeting a senior terrorist leader in Somalia, Hassan Ali Dhoore, an operational commander of al-Shabab, an al-Qaeda-linked terror group. The Pentagon stated that Dhoore was involved in planning a number of attacks, including some that resulted in the deaths of three Americans.

"In addition to being part of al-Qaeda, Hassan Ali Dhoore was a member of al-Shabab's Amniyat (security and intelligence) wing and was heavily involved in high-profile attack planning in Mogadishu," the Pentagon said in a statement.

The Pentagon stated that officials were still assessing the results of the operation to determine if Dhoore was killed in the strike, but said his death would be a "significant blow" to the terror group's operations and ability to conduct attacks. Dhoore is believed to have played a role in the December 25, 2014, attack on Mogadishu International Airport that killed several African Union personnel and a U.S. citizen, as well as the March 27, 2015, attack on the Maka al-Mukarram Hotel in Mogadishu that killed 15 people.

Last month, the Pentagon launched a strike that killed up to 150 militants at a terrorist training camp in Somalia.

Title: The Pursuit of Heroism: A Look into the Fabricated War Stories of Public Figures

Article:

In the realm of public figures, the truth is often a fluid concept, with many individuals embellishing their pasts to fit the mold of a hero. This trend has been evident in recent years, with numerous politicians, actors, and journalists found to have fabricated or exaggerated their military service records. The latest addition to this dishonor roll is NBC News anchor Brian Williams, who has admitted to peddling a fabricated war story about himself during the 2003 invasion of Iraq.

Williams, a trusted figure in the media, has been a target of public scrutiny after it was revealed that he has told a shifting story about the day he flew aboard a U.S. Army helicopter during the invasion. In later versions, he has said his helicopter was hit and forced down by enemy fire, a version he told last Friday. However, Williams' helicopter was not the one that was hit, as he admitted in a statement to Stars and Stripes.

This trend of fabricating war stories is not unique to Williams. In 1983, President Ronald Reagan told the prime minister of Israel that he had filmed the Nazi death camp as a U.S. Army photographer. Reagan also shared a version of his death camp story with Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal. However, as Lou Cannon's March 5, 1984, Washington Post article demonstrated, Reagan could not have possibly filmed the death camp because, by his own admission, he never left the country during World War II.

Other politicians called out for military-service fudging include Sen. Richard Blumenthal, President George W. Bush, and Sen. Tom Harkin, who bragged about flying non-existent combat air missions in Vietnam. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton also dispensed her own combat blarney during the 2008 campaign, asserting that during the Bosnia war she and her group landed "under sniper fire" at an airstrip in Tuzla and "we just ran with our heads down to get into the vehicles to get to our base."

This dishonor roll of politicians disturbs few of us because taking liberties with the truth is their default setting. However, we expect higher truth standards from members of the press, right? Brian Williams might not be working as a shoe-leather reporter, but he is as much a journalist as any newspaper rewrite-man. Journalists are paid to be more vigilant than civilians about the stories they tell. Millions listen to Williams because he has sold himself as a truth-teller, not a fabulist. We expect the truth from him, whether he is reading a human-interest piece into NBC's cameras or recounting personal war stories on Dave Letterman's show.

Alas, the human tendency to juice our stories is universal, and it is a temptation that some journalists find impossible to resist. When we tell our personal stories, we tend to add dramatic pauses that will build suspense. In each retelling, we tend to incorporate into it the reactions of the last audience, escalating the drama that got a good reaction, tamping down the events that dragged, and making up stuff to further engage our audiences. We supplement and reshape our stories both subconsciously and deliberately, because there is no public shame like the public shame that follows the telling of a boring tale. If you don't think you don't do the same with your favorite stories, ask your spouse or siblings. They'll happily regale you with your entertaining exaggerations.

Journalists adhere to the same traditional story forms that other, more fanciful tellers use, but with the proviso that they don't embellish. This is the journalistic commandment that Williams broke, and you can see it happening in the timeline of his changing stories compiled by CNN. Williams' early tellings are accurate but boring. After a few years and a few tellings, Williams begins to conform to the "juice" model, adding details about the "dangers" he faced as his helicopter was hit. Perhaps Williams thought it was okay for him to embellish because he was off the clock. Sorry, Brian, a journalist is never off the clock, especially when speaking to thousands or millions at a time.

Americans lie about their military records to themselves with such regularity that a couple of years ago Congress passed a law prohibiting such acts of "stolen valor." (Wisely, the Supreme Court struck the law down as injurious to the First Amendment.) For reasons any evolutionary psychology professor can explain to you, everybody wants to be the hero and nobody wants to be the coward. Not to get too psychoanalytic on Williams, but maybe he stretched his mundane helicopter story into an exhilarating but false one because he feels guilty about having gone to war the easiest way possible—in the company of well-protected generals.

"The allure of a hero's status can be irresistible," says scholar W. Joseph Campbell, who has written extensively on media myths. "It's a warping, cinematic effect." You'd think that Brian Williams, a mega-successful, handsome, funny, high-status multimillionaire journalist wouldn't need laurels beyond the ones he's already collected. You'd be wrong.

Title: Indiana Governor Mike Pence Endorses Ted Cruz, Praises Donald Trump Ahead of Indiana Primary

Article:

Indiana Governor Mike Pence has announced his endorsement of Republican candidate Ted Cruz for the upcoming Indiana primary on Tuesday. In an interview on WIBC radio in Indianapolis, Pence praised Cruz as a "principled conservative" who has "stood up for taxpayers" in Washington and has shown "strong, unwavering stand" against abortion rights.

However, Pence seemed to go out of his way to praise Republican front-runner Donald Trump as well. He commended Trump for giving voice to people's frustrations and for taking a stand for Hoosier jobs. Pence also expressed gratitude towards Trump for his voice in the national debate.

Despite his endorsement, Pence emphasized that his decision was not intended to sway the votes of Indiana Republicans. "I respect the right of every Hoosier in making their determination," Pence said, adding, "I encourage everyone to make up their own mind."

Pence's endorsement is significant as he is running for re-election this fall and has been seen as a possible Republican presidential candidate in the past. Cruz is hoping that Pence's endorsement will give him a boost in the Hoosier State, where he is currently trailing Trump in recent surveys.

Cruz was also helped by Scott Walker's endorsement in Wisconsin, which gave Cruz his only big-state primary victory so far in this campaign. However, Cruz's endorsement by Pence was far less forceful than Cruz would probably have liked.

There are 57 delegates at stake in Indiana on Tuesday. If Trump sweeps those delegates, his path to the nomination not only becomes clear, but likely. Currently, he needs 42 percent of remaining delegates to win, which is very doable. If he wins all of Indiana's 57 delegates, that drops to 36 percent.

Title: GOP Candidates Engage in Policy Discussion at Kemp Forum, Stepping Away from Campaign Trail's Heated Rhetoric

Article:

In a departure from the heated rhetoric and controversial statements that have characterized much of the 2016 Republican primary race, several GOP candidates gathered at the Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity in Columbia, South Carolina, for a five-hour discussion focused on policy proposals and ideas to alleviate poverty. The event, which took place on Saturday, was a stark contrast to the rallies of front-runners Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, who were not in attendance.

The forum, moderated by Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and South Carolina Republican Sen. Tim Scott, provided a platform for candidates such as former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson to discuss vital, if mundane, policy proposals. Ohio Gov. John Kasich also participated, highlighting his legislative background and his role in the first set of welfare reform legislation.

The event was a breath of fresh air, according to Ryan, who noted that it offered candidates more than 30 seconds to discuss issues and engage in substantive conversations. The change in tone was welcomed by many, with candidates praising the forum's focus on policy and ideas.

In contrast, the night before the GOP poverty event, Trump held a boisterous rally in Rock Hill, South Carolina, where he praised the capture of Mexican drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, had a Muslim woman who silently protested during the event kicked out, and rallied the crowd with exclamations about his plans to "knock the sh-- out of ISIS." Meanwhile, Cruz made headlines in Iowa with a comparison of spanking his daughter to the spanking Hillary Clinton could receive from voters.

Participants at the Kemp Forum, including Kasich and Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, praised the event's focus on substantive conversation, with Graham noting that the primary chatter had taken a welcome break. Graham, who sparred with Trump before dropping out of the race last month, commented on the difference in tone between the event and Trump's rallies, stating, "If you are real loud here, you are a jerk."

After the forum, Kasich expressed his long-held desire for a more substantive conversation to be integral to the presidential campaign process. "In the debate, you get six minutes in two hours," Kasich said. "People can't see your personality. They can't see what you are made of. They can't see your heart. It's extremely difficult."

The candidates appeared to revel in the nonconfrontational environment, with Bush, who has struggled to break through, discussing his policy positions on block grants, the need to focus on marriage, and creating a work-based competency system. Christie also spent several minutes discussing the details of the earned income tax credit and how increasing the refundable tax credit incentivized poor people to seek employment.

While the candidates largely agreed on the issues discussed, the afternoon session with Kasich and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) was interrupted multiple times by young immigration protesters. The protesters, who were quickly escorted out by police, targeted Rubio's position on the country's immigration laws. However, even this interruption did not cause a break in the comity.

"We're going to enforce our immigration laws, guys," Rubio responded to raucous applause. Kasich quickly added some backup to defuse the situation, stating, "We heard it. Thank you very much." The Kemp Forum on Expanding Opportunity provided a rare moment of substantive policy discussion in the 2016 campaign, offering a glimpse into the candidates' policy positions and ideas for addressing poverty.

Title: What Happens to Campaign Contributions When a Presidential Candidate Drops Out? A Guide for Donors

Article:

In the recent shake-up of the 2020 presidential race, Washington Governor Jay Inslee and former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper have both dropped out of the race, with Hickenlooper announcing his Senate bid. As of June, both former candidates raised nearly $8.5 million in campaign contributions from individual donors and Political Action Committees (PACs). With the third round of debates in Houston approaching, more candidates may follow suit, leaving millions in campaign donations in their wake. But what happens to these contributions when a presidential candidate drops out of the race?

According to rules set forth by the Federal Election Committee (FEC), any excess campaign funds are not allowed for personal use. However, the world of campaign finance is needlessly complicated.

If you've donated $25 to a candidate, part of your donation might be used to pay off any outstanding debt or expenses. This could mean paying salaries for campaign staff or even moving expenses. If a campaign hasn't accrued any debt, it's likely part of your $25 might be used for that candidate's future campaigns.

Candidates also have the ability to use your donation to purchase "gifts," so long as they are not given to the candidate's family. What constitutes a "gift," however, seems pretty open-ended.

Less likely alternatives include a candidate using your $25 to support a political action committee they support or another candidate in a race (though they'd probably prefer to keep it). Your contribution could also be donated to charities at your candidate's choosing.

The FEC's rules are vague, and candidates adhere to them in whatever way they see fit. This brings us to a big, glaring question—how can you be sure your donation has been used appropriately?

While you can never be 100% sure how your individual donation is spent, you can research a campaign's spending throughout and after a presidential bid is over. "Once a campaign has ended, a candidate's committee must continue to file FEC reports until the committee is terminated," a spokesperson for the FEC said in an email. "So it's possible to track how the campaigns spend any residual funds they maintain."

To view these reports, visit the FEC database, search by a candidate's campaign name—which typically consists of their last name, followed by "For America" or "2020"—and scroll to the bottom of the page to find their expenses. To find Inslee's campaign, search for "Inslee for America." To find Hickenlooper's campaign, search for "Hickenlooper 2020." You can search for any former presidential candidate's campaign from any other election, as well.

There are limits to these filings. For one, they're generally updated quarterly; if you donated to Inslee or Hickenlooper, you won't know how they're spending excess funds until September. Also, you'll have to do a lot of digging into candidates' expenses, and even then, you can't fully interpret a simple line item.

None of this should dissuade you from donating to a candidate of your choosing. In fact, it should provide incentive to vote for a candidate who promotes campaign finance reform, so that your future contributions are spent wisely.

Title: Republican Anxiety Over Romney's Campaign Strategy Spreads Across Battleground States

Article:

As the presidential race between Mitt Romney and Barack Obama heats up, a sense of anxiety among Republicans about the Republican candidate's campaign strategy and his own miscues has spread beyond Washington. Republican strategists across the country have expressed concern about being asked about Romney's remarks, creating an unwelcome potential trap for those in tight races.

Romney has attempted to turn the issue against Obama, labeling the president as an advocate of redistributing wealth and emphasizing, "My campaign is about the 100 percent of America." However, during a Univision forum in Coral Gables, Florida, Obama focused on Romney's "47 percent" comments.

"My thinking is maybe you haven't gotten around a lot," Obama said about Romney.

There is a growing sense of frustration among Republicans that Romney has yet to take a commanding lead in any of the major battleground states, particularly North Carolina, which has the nation's fifth-worst unemployment rate, or Nevada, which has the nation's highest jobless rate, 12 percent.

In Ohio, Florida, and Colorado, Republicans who support Romney's efforts have expressed concern that he is not campaigning enough in their states and that resources are not trickling into vital counties. A.J. Matthews, a Republican State Committee member from Hillsborough County, Florida, said, "Could we use yard signs? Could we use information data? What would we most like from Governor Romney and Congressman Ryan? Visit us more."

In Ohio, some Republicans have expressed concern that Romney is not spending more money and appearing more frequently in rural counties where he needs a strong turnout to win the state—and where his "47 percent" comments threaten to undercut support among working-class voters otherwise inclined to vote for him. A bus trip by Romney next week may address some of these worries.

In Colorado, Dick Wadhams, a longtime Republican strategist and a former state party chairman, said he hoped to see Romney campaign harder for swing voters in suburban Denver, and he was pleased the candidate was planning to visit the state on Sunday, the first time in seven weeks.

Speaking of those swing voters, Wadhams said, "They want to vote against Obama, but they haven't quite come to the point where they're going to vote for Romney."

Wadhams and other party leaders said, however, that they were heartened by Romney's get-out-the-vote operations. Republicans say Romney's on-the-ground efforts are far superior to those of Senator John McCain in 2008.

Officials at the Romney campaign said they believed some of the concern in the tossup states was being created by what they described as hyped news media reporting on Romney's latest missteps. The campaign has been meticulously thought out, they said, and its supporters have yet to see activity that, by design, was not scheduled to begin until near the end of the race.

"We're making some very strategic decisions," said Rich Beeson, the political director. "And when we're coming down to the end, you'll see the governor everywhere he needs to be."

Romney has yet to take command of any battleground states, according to polls, many of which show Obama with an edge. The Romney campaign has been focusing on Iowa as one of its more promising states, but an NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist College poll released Thursday evening showed Obama with an 8-point advantage there.

In a stop near Des Moines, Ann Romney said it was time for Republicans to stop second-guessing her husband. "Stop it. This is hard," she told Radio Iowa. "You want to try it? Get in the ring."

The president and his aides are aware that everything could change in an instant, particularly with three presidential debates looming, and said Democrats could not be complacent.

But for the first time in many months, Mr. Obama's job approval rating has reached 50 percent in several recent polls. He has taken the edge away from Romney on questions of who voters believe will be a better steward of the economy, which coincides with the release of modestly positive economic signals.

Construction of new houses and home sales have reached their highest levels in more than two years, new reports show, and the Census Bureau reported that the number of young adults living at home with their parents—a vivid indicator of the personal effect of the recession on young people—is dropping.

Yet the president must still contend with his campaign promises made four years ago, including his pledge to change Washington. When asked about that Thursday during the Univision forum, he said change must come from the "outside."

Speaking to supporters in Sarasota, Florida, Romney seized on the remark as an admission of failure, saying, "The president today threw in the white flag of surrender. He went from the president of change to the president who can't get change."

For all of the open fretting among Republicans, several party leaders say Romney still has an opportunity to win over voters who are ready to reject Obama.

"Romney has not made the sale yet with the 5 or 10 percent that are undecided, and he very well could," said Mike DeWine, Ohio's attorney general. "It's a very doable thing for Romney to win Ohio and very doable for him to win the race."

As Romney headed to an evening fund-raiser in West Palm Beach, Florida, a reporter asked if he would be campaigning more extensively.

"Ha, ha. We're in the stretch, aren't we?" Romney said before promptly changing the subject and pointing to the sky. "Look at those clouds. It's beautiful. Look at those things."

Title: North Korea Renews Tensions with Missile Launch Over Japan, World Powers Respond

Article:

In a sudden escalation of tensions in the Asia-Pacific region, North Korea launched a midrange ballistic missile over Japan on Tuesday, a move that has been met with strong condemnation from the international community. The missile, capable of carrying a nuclear payload, flew over Japanese territory and landed in the northern Pacific Ocean.

President Trump, in a statement released by the White House, called the launch a "grave" threat and a "dangerous precedent." He stated, "The world has received North Korea’s latest message loud and clear: this regime has signaled its contempt for its neighbors, for all members of the United Nations, and for minimum standards of acceptable international behavior."

The President continued, "Threatening and destabilizing actions only increase the North Korean regime’s isolation in the region and among all nations of the world. All options are on the table."

The launch, which reportedly did not pose a threat to North America, has been met with a strong response from the United States and its allies. The Pentagon is currently investigating the launch, and the North American Aerospace Defense Command (NORAD) has determined that the missile launch did not pose a threat to North America.

In response to the launch, South Korea conducted a live-fire drill involving powerful bombs, with four F-15 fighters dropping eight MK-84 bombs that accurately hit targets at a military field near South Korea's eastern coast. Each bomb has an explosive yield of a ton, according to South Korea's air force.

The latest launch comes days after North Korea fired what was assessed as three short-range ballistic missiles into the sea and a month after its second test of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM). The ICBM test, analysts say, could reach deep into the U.S. mainland when perfected.

The U.S. and its allies are particularly concerned about the latest test, as it puts North Korea a step closer to its goal of an arsenal of nuclear missiles that can reliably target the United States. The situation has been further complicated by escalating rhetoric between North Korea and the U.S., with President Trump earlier this month threatening Kim Jong Un's regime with "fire and fury."

In response to the latest round of provocations, the U.S. and Japan have committed to increasing pressure on North Korea and convincing the international community to do the same. The U.S. and Japan have also pledged to work together to counter North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

The situation remains fluid, and it is unclear what the next move will be from North Korea or the international community. However, it is clear that the latest missile launch has renewed tensions in the region and raised concerns about the potential for further escalation.

Title: White House Refuses to Comment on President's Involvement in Ongoing National Security Leaks Investigation

Article:

As the U.S. Justice Department investigates recent high-level national security leaks from the White House, a top adviser to President Obama, David Plouffe, declined to confirm whether the president will answer investigators' questions during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday."

The White House has announced an investigation into the leaking of classified national security information to a New York Times reporter, which led to a series of recent stories. The leaks included details of a top-secret "kill list," a list of targets for drone strikes assembled by the president's national security team, as well as information on a U.S. cyberattack on Iranian infrastructure and confirmation of a mole inside al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

Some congressional Republicans and political pundits have speculated that the leaks were authorized by the White House to boost President Obama's re-election campaign by bringing his national security record back into the spotlight. However, the truth of this theory remains unclear.

Sen. Joe Lieberman, Connecticut independent, expressed concern over the leaks, stating that the disclosure of cyberwarfare against Iran could lead to a retaliatory strike. He also suggested that the administration should appoint independent prosecutors to investigate the matter, rather than relying on investigators who report directly to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.

The White House has so far rejected calls for independent prosecutors, with David Plouffe stating that the appointment of two U.S. attorneys is a "smart move." Despite being pressed on the question, Plouffe would not confirm whether the president would agree to one-on-one interviews with the investigators, as former President George W. Bush did during the probe into the public disclosure of former CIA operative Valerie Plame's identity.

Sen. Lieberman and others are now urging the administration to follow the Bush administration's playbook by cooperating fully with the investigation and eliminating any appearance that people in the administration leaked the highly classified information for political or personal purposes.

Title: "Political Polarization in the United States: A Deep Dive into the Divide"

Article:

In a recent correspondence with a long-time friend, a stark reminder of the deep political divide in the United States was brought to light. The friend, a Republican, stands out as one of the few in an extended family predominantly made up of Democrats. This observation, while anecdotal, seems to reflect a broader trend of political polarization in the country.

To substantiate this claim, one needs to look no further than the Pew Research Center's findings from 2014, based on interviews with 10,000 adults. The report revealed that the number of Americans expressing consistently conservative or consistently liberal opinions has doubled over the past two decades, from 10 percent to 21 percent. The report also showed that ideological overlap has diminished, with 92 percent of Republicans being to the right of the median Democrat, and 94 percent of Democrats being to the left of the median Republican.

The report further highlighted that many in the political center stay on the edges of the political process, while the most ideological make their voices heard. Two-thirds of consistent conservatives and half of liberals say most of their close friends share their political views, a statistic that might come as a shock.

The divide between the two major political parties is not just limited to ideology but extends to perceptions of the opposition. Two-thirds of conservative Republicans think the Democratic policies threaten the nation's well-being, while the corresponding number for Democrats is 50 percent. Since 1994, highly negative views of the opposition party have doubled, with 43 percent of Republicans and 38 percent of Democrats holding such views.

National Journal's Ron Brownstein suggests that this divide is not going to go away anytime soon. Essentially, the U.S. is witnessing a durable standoff between a diverse, younger, urbanized, more secular Democratic coalition and a predominantly white, older, non-urban, and more religious Republican coalition.

The cause of this political polarization is a topic of ongoing debate. Some suggest that partisan news media and the internet have played a significant role in shaping and reinforcing political views. However, finding a solution to this problem remains elusive.

In conclusion, the political landscape of the United States is marked by a deep divide that extends beyond the two major political parties. This divide, while complex and multifaceted, is a reality that cannot be ignored. Understanding and addressing this issue is crucial for the health and stability of American democracy.

Title: U.S. and China Announce Higher Tariffs as Trade War Escalates, Global Markets React

Article:

In a move that has sent shockwaves through global markets, the United States and China have announced higher tariffs on each other's goods, intensifying the ongoing trade war between the world's two largest economies.

On Monday, the U.S. President Donald Trump announced plans to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping next month at the G20 summit in Japan. This announcement came after China announced earlier that it would impose higher tariffs on a range of U.S. goods, including frozen vegetables and liquefied natural gas.

The U.S. Trade Representative's office later announced plans to hold a public hearing next month on the possibility of imposing duties of up to 25% on a further $300 billion worth of imports from China. Cellphones and laptops would be included in that list, but pharmaceuticals would be excluded, the office said.

The prospect of a no-holds-barred dispute between the U.S. and China that could derail the global economy has rattled investors, leading to a sharp selloff on equities markets in the past week. A gauge of global stocks shed a further 1.9% on Monday, its biggest one-day drop in more than five months. China's yuan currency fell to its lowest level since December, and oil futures slumped.

Trump said he would talk to Xi at the G20 summit and expressed optimism about the meeting, saying, "Maybe something will happen. We're going to be meeting, as you know, at the G20 in Japan and that'll be, I think, probably a very fruitful meeting."

Speaking at a White House dinner gathering later, Trump said it should be clear in "three or four weeks" if a U.S. trade delegation's trip to Beijing two weeks ago was successful. "I have a feeling it's going to be very successful," Trump said.

China's top diplomat, State Councilor Wang Yi, said during a trip to Russia that China-U.S. talks were not a "one-way street" and needed to be conducted on the basis of equality. "Both countries' negotiating teams have the ability and wisdom to resolve each other's reasonable demands, and in the end, reach a mutually beneficial, win-win agreement," he said.

U.S. farmers are among those most affected by the trade war, with soybean sales to China plummeting, and U.S. soybean futures hitting their lowest level in a decade. Trump said on Monday his administration was planning to provide about $15 billion to help farmers whose products might be targeted.

China also announced plans to set import tariffs ranging from 5% to 25% on 5,140 U.S. products on a $60 billion target list. It said the tariffs would take effect on June 1. China's finance ministry said the tariffs were a response to U.S. unilateralism and protectionism, and it hoped the U.S. would get back to the right track of bilateral trade and economic consultations and meet with China halfway.

Economists and industry consultants maintain that it is U.S. businesses that will pay the costs of the tariffs and likely pass them on to consumers. Goldman Sachs economists said in a research note that the costs of Washington's tariffs on China last year had fallen entirely on U.S. businesses and households, with no clear reduction in prices charged by Chinese exporters. They said the effects of the tariffs had spilled over noticeably to the prices charged by U.S. producers competing with goods affected by the levies.

Title: Sen. Doug Jones Announces Support for Trump Impeachment Conviction on Both Articles

Article:

In a statement released on Wednesday, Sen. Doug Jones (D-Ala.) announced his decision to vote for the conviction of President Donald Trump on both articles of impeachment. The Senate is set to vote on the two House-passed articles later in the day.

Jones, who is considered one of the most vulnerable Senate Democrats running in November, stated, "After many sleepless nights, I have reluctantly concluded that the evidence is sufficient to convict the President for both abuse of power and obstruction of Congress."

The Alabama senator's announcement comes hours before the Senate votes on the two articles: abuse of power over the delayed Ukraine aid and obstructing Congress's investigations into those actions. Jones, who has been undecided on his vote for weeks, told reporters on Monday that he was "getting there" but still wanted to review notes and consult with colleagues.

Jones sparked speculation last month that he could split his votes, expressing concerns about the House manager's second article of impeachment, which deals with alleged obstruction of Congress. However, on Wednesday, Jones acknowledged that the second article "gave me even more pause," adding that he "struggled to understand" the House's strategy.

"However, after careful consideration of the evidence developed in the hearings, the public disclosures, the legal precedents, and the trial, I believe the President deliberately and unconstitutionally obstructed Congress by refusing to cooperate with the investigation in any way," Jones said.

Jones added that Trump's actions "demonstrate a belief that he is above the law" and, if left unchecked, would risk guaranteeing that no future whistleblower or witness would ever come forward and no future President would be subject to Congressional oversight.

On the first article, abuse of power, Jones said he was "deeply troubled" by the arguments from Trump's legal team. "The President’s actions placed his personal interests well above the national interests and threatened the security of the United States, our allies in Europe, and our ally Ukraine. His actions were more than simply inappropriate. They were an abuse of power," Jones said.

Title: Fact-Checking Biden's Claim on Lack of Oversight in Coronavirus Relief Effort

Article:

In the aftermath of a virtual rally in Wisconsin, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden asserted that President Trump was implementing the coronavirus relief effort with "no oversight, no IGs [Inspectors General], no accountability." However, this statement appears to be inaccurate, as the CARES Act, the legislation that established the relief program, has outlined several methods of oversight for the coronavirus relief effort.

The most significant oversight body is the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee, established by Section 15010 of the CARES Act. The committee's responsibilities include auditing the economic relief funds to prevent waste and abuse and ensuring the money is efficiently distributed. The CARES Act outlines the membership of the committee, which includes the inspectors general of various departments, such as Defense, Education, Health and Human Services, and the Treasury, among others.

The CARES Act also created a special inspector general for pandemic recovery, whose duties include conducting audits and investigations of the loans, loan guarantees, and other investments made by the Secretary of the Treasury under any program established by the Secretary under the Act. The position is currently vacant, with President Trump having nominated his senior associate counsel, Brian Miller.

Furthermore, the CARES Act established the Congressional Oversight Commission, tasked with overseeing the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve's lending practices to create transparency about how the money is being used and determine the economic impact of the loans. The commission is made up of five members, with each party leader in the House and Senate appointing one member, and the leaders of each chamber picking a fifth member with consultation from the minority party leaders.

President Trump's actions regarding the inspectors general on the Pandemic Response Accountability Committee and his choice for a special inspector general have earned him criticism. Trump has also stated he disagrees with certain elements of the CARES Act oversight provisions and has said he won't abide by the Act in allowing the special inspector general to issue reports to Congress without "presidential supervision."

In light of the above, it is inaccurate to claim, as Biden did, that there is "no oversight, no IGs [Inspectors General], no accountability" in the coronavirus economic relief effort. Biden's campaign did not respond to a request for comment.

Title: Bipartisan Immigration Bill Dismissed by White House as Non-Starter Ahead of Senate Introduction

A bipartisan immigration bill, brokered by Senators John McCain (R-AZ) and Chris Coons (D-DE), is set to be introduced in the Senate on Monday. The bill aims to grant eventual citizenship to undocumented immigrants who have been in the U.S. since 2013 and arrived as children, but it does not address all of President Trump's stated immigration priorities, such as ending family-based immigration categories or the diversity visa program.

The bill does not immediately authorize the $30 billion for the border wall that Trump is seeking, instead greenlighting a study of border security needs. The bill also seeks to address the number of undocumented immigrants staying in the U.S. by increasing the number of resources for the immigration courts, where cases can take years to finish.

The bill is a companion to a House legislation that has 54 co-sponsors split evenly by party. However, the White House has dismissed the effort, with a White House official telling CNN that the bill is worse than the Graham-Durbin immigration bill. President Trump also tweeted about the latest immigration efforts, stating that any deal on DACA that does not include strong border security and the desperately needed wall is a waste of time.

Senator Coons defended the bill in a conference call with reporters on Monday, calling it a "strong starting place" and a "fresh start" if other talks about immigration do not result in a compromise. The White House has been aware of the legislation for weeks, with officials being informed while it was being drafted and with Chief of Staff John Kelly and Legislative Director Marc Short being briefed on the bill in meetings with members of Congress.

The bill would create a "smart wall" where the Department of Homeland Security would gain "operational control" of the border by the end of 2020 through "technology, physical barriers, levees, tools, and other devices." On family-based migration, the bill does not make explicit reference to sponsoring relatives, but the bill authors say that existing law would prohibit parents of these individuals who came to the U.S. illegally to apply for a visa to come back without returning to their home country for at least 10 years before applying, and the bill does nothing to erase that requirement.

Coons said that McCain approached him about being a co-sponsor, stating that McCain is deeply concerned about the lack of future certainty for the military because of a budget impasse and the lack of a broader deal on immigration issues, and wanted to find a partner to introduce the Hurd-Aguilar bill in the Senate as part of that effort. Coons also had some harsh words for the President, saying that despite the White House saying his proposal is the only one that can move forward, "I'm sorry, that's not how the Senate works." He rejected White House criticism of his proposal and said the "worst" thing would be failing to act or only doing a one-year stopgap.

The Senate is expected to turn to a floor debate on immigration soon, and Coons has been part of a group of bipartisan lawmakers that have been meeting for weeks to try to find a compromise that could pass the vote with more than the 60 votes needed to advance legislation, which would require members of both parties. McCain has been recuperating from cancer treatments but is a veteran of efforts to pass immigration reform.

Title: "2016 Presidential Election: A Closer Look at the Electoral College and Tipping Points"

Article:

As the 2016 Presidential Election approaches, the race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump is heating up. Here's a breakdown of the latest forecasts, focusing on the Electoral College and the states that could potentially tip the balance.

# How the forecast has changed
We will be updating our forecasts daily, right up until Nov. 8, to reflect the latest data. Our current win probabilities are based on simulating the election 20,000 times, which provides a distribution of possible outcomes for each state. Here are the expected margins of victory, with the closer the dot is to the center line indicating a tighter race, and the wider bar indicating less certainty about the outcome.

Here's a map of the country, with each state sized by its number of electoral votes and shaded by the leading candidate's chance of winning it.

A candidate needs at least 270 electoral votes to clinch the White House. Title: Supreme Court to Review Same-Sex Marriage Cases: A Milestone in the Legal Battle for LGBT Equality

Article:

In a significant development for the ongoing legal battle over same-sex marriage, the United States Supreme Court has agreed to review two landmark cases: Windsor v. United States and Hollingsworth v. Perry. The cases, which challenge the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and California's Proposition 8, respectively, were granted review on Friday, signaling a potential turning point in the fight for LGBT equality.

The Supreme Court's decision to take up these cases comes as same-sex couples in Washington state began exchanging wedding vows following the state's legalization of same-sex marriage last month. The federal law and Proposition 8 both define marriage as the union between one man and one woman, and four justices had to agree for a case to be heard.

Gay rights activists, such as James Esseks, litigation director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender & AIDS Project, expressed cautious optimism. "This is it—the Supreme Court marriage moment that the ACLU has been working towards for years," Esseks said. "These cases are poised not just to take down DOMA and Prop 8, but to be the next building blocks for LGBT equality more broadly."

Traditional-values groups, however, remain concerned that gay marriages are still not recognized in more than 80 percent of the states. John Eastman, chairman of the National Organization for Marriage, which opposes gay marriage, noted that the Supreme Court's decision to accept the cases sends "a strong signal that the justices are concerned with the rogue rulings that have come out of San Francisco."

Oral arguments for the cases are expected to be held in late winter or early spring, with decisions issued by summer. The high court proceedings are likely to take on new urgency given the activity in states such as Washington, where same-sex couples have been able to marry since Thursday.

The federal case was brought by the ACLU and other lawyers on behalf of Edith Windsor, a New York woman who married her longtime companion, Thea Spyer, in Canada in 2007. When Ms. Spyer died a few years later, their marriage was not recognized by the federal government because of DOMA, and Ms. Windsor, now 83, was forced to pay nearly $370,000 in federal estate taxes.

The Proposition 8 case asks whether the U.S. Constitution prohibits the people of California from defining marriage as the union of one man and one woman in their state. The American Foundation for Equal Rights (AFER) sued to overturn Proposition 8 on behalf of two same-sex couples.

"This case is about the fundamental constitutional right of all Americans to marry the person they love," said Theodore B. Olson, AFER's lead co-counsel with David Boies. The Supreme Court's decision to grant review in this case "illustrates the national significance of marriage equality, and brings us closer to the day when every American will be able to equally enjoy the fundamental freedom to marry."

Andy Pugno, general counsel for ProtectMarriage.com, the organization that put Proposition 8 on the ballot, said, "Arguing this case before the Supreme Court finally gives us a chance at a fair hearing, something that hasn't been afforded to the people since we began this fight."

This story is based in part on wire service reports.

Title: Republican Governors Shift Focus Away from Tax Cuts and Towards Infrastructure and Healthcare

Article:

In the wake of the 2010 elections, Republican governors across the nation, led by Wisconsin's Scott Walker, made significant strides in implementing conservative policies, including limiting public-employee collective bargaining and enacting tax cuts. However, as the 2016 election approaches, a different narrative is emerging.

Currently, it appears that no Republican governor is poised to replicate Scott Walker's 2010 success. Walker himself has distanced himself from the idea of a right-to-work bill, viewing it as a potential distraction amidst Wisconsin's $2.2 billion budget gap over two years.

In Ohio, Governor John Kasich, another potential presidential candidate, is advocating for increased taxes on energy drilling companies to fund an income tax cut, despite opposition from a Tea Party faction in the General Assembly. Michigan's Governor Rick Snyder, who overcame conservative objections to financial aid for Detroit, is proposing higher gasoline taxes to improve roads, an idea that is unpopular on his right.

The prospect of sweeping new tax cuts, a cornerstone of Republican orthodoxy, seems to have diminished. This shift is partly due to incumbents who have already enacted cuts, but it also appears to be a response to the cautionary example of Kansas.

In Kansas, Governor Sam Brownback implemented large business and income tax cuts in 2012 and 2013, promising that the loss of revenue would be compensated by a business boom. Instead, revenues plummeted, the state faces a significant budget shortfall, and Brownback, a Republican, nearly lost re-election due to a backlash.

In Florida, Governor Rick Scott, who was sworn in on Tuesday, has outlined an agenda that includes increased spending on schools, the environment, and transportation - a stark contrast to the $3.3 billion in education cuts during his first term, as well as his rejection of billions in federal aid for high-speed rail.

In Arizona, the newly elected Republican governor, Doug Ducey, pledged in his inauguration speech not to raise taxes but omitted mention of his campaign promises to cut income taxes annually. This omission was not surprising, given that the state faces a substantial and growing budget deficit.

Several Republican governors, including Tennessee's Bill Haslam and those in Wyoming and North Carolina, have expressed support for some form of Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act, arguing that accepting the billions of dollars in federal aid is a fiscally smart move.

This shift in focus from tax cuts to infrastructure and healthcare suggests a more pragmatic approach from Republican governors, as they navigate the complexities of their states' budgets and the lessons learned from the experiences of their colleagues in Kansas and other states.

Title: Hillary Clinton Affirms No Contact from FBI in Email Investigation, Remains Confident About Debate with Bernie Sanders

Article:

WASHINGTON — In an interview on NBC's Meet the Press on Sunday, Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton stated that she has not received contact from the FBI in the ongoing investigation regarding her use of a private email server during her tenure as Secretary of State.

When asked if FBI agents had reached out to her, Clinton responded, "No, no, they haven't." She added, "Back in August, we made clear that I'm happy to answer any questions that anybody might have. And I stand by that."

Clinton expressed no concern that the investigation may not be concluded by the time the Democratic National Convention takes place in July. "No, I'm not," she told moderator Chuck Todd. "Because I do not think anything inappropriate was done. And so I have to let them decide how to resolve their security inquiry, but I'm not at all worried about it."

Clinton reiterated that sending emails from a private server while serving as Secretary of State was a mistake. "So let me just say again, I sent emails to government employees on their government accounts," Clinton said. "I had every reason to believe they were in the government system. It was a matter of convenience. I've said repeatedly, it was not the best choice. It was a mistake. But I think that anybody who's actually looked at this has concluded that I have now put out all of my emails. Go and ask others for their emails. Ask everybody else who's in public office. I'm the one who's done it, and I did it because I thought it was the right thing to do."

In addition, Clinton expressed confidence that she will debate her Democratic rival, Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, before the New York primary on April 19, but would not commit to a specific date. "I'm not the one negotiating it, that's going on between our campaigns," Clinton said.

Sanders has been pushing for a debate with Clinton. Sanders, a native of Brooklyn, believes he has a chance to win New York, while Clinton, a New York resident and former U.S. senator from the state, expects to carry the Empire State.

Sanders also expressed confidence that there will be a debate before the primary, stating on ABC's This Week on Sunday that he is "looking forward to debating Secretary Clinton."

Title: "St. Paul Police Incident: Charges Dropped Against Christopher Lollie Following Alleged Misconduct"

Article:

In a recent turn of events, a video surfaced this week capturing an alleged instance of police misconduct in downtown St. Paul, Minnesota. The video, which has since gone viral, depicts a confrontation between a police officer and 28-year-old Christopher Lollie, who was waiting to pick up his children from New Horizon Academy.

The video begins with a female officer approaching Lollie, asking him to identify himself. Lollie, who was sitting in a public area for approximately 10 minutes, expresses his confusion and refusal to comply, stating that he had not broken any laws.

"The problem is I'm black," Lollie interjects. "It really is, because I'm not sitting there with a group of people. I'm sitting there by myself, not causing a problem."

A second officer then approaches the pair, and an attempt is made to touch Lollie. Lollie, growing increasingly upset, states, "I've got to go get my kids. Please don't touch me." The second officer responds, "You're going to go to jail then."

The situation escalates, with Lollie being cuffed, a taser being charged, and Lollie's subsequent screams heard in the video. The police report, obtained by local media, states that two officers, Michael Johnson and Bruce Schmidt, were called to the First National Bank Building "on a report of an uncooperative male refusing to leave." The female officer involved in the incident has not yet been identified.

Lollie, who had been attending New Horizon for about 9 months at the time, said his children were not present during the incident. However, his children's classmates and teacher witnessed the event. The teacher provided a witness statement, stating that Lollie was calm, not causing a problem, and was speaking with them before the officers allegedly assaulted him.

Since the incident, Lollie has fought the charges, and all charges against him were dropped as of July 31, according to Lollie. He stated that he chose not to release the video until the charges were dropped.

"It hurts," Lollie said. "Because no matter what—I could be the nicest guy in the world, talk with respect, I can be working, taking care of my kids, doing everything the model citizen is supposed to do—and I still get that type of treatment."

The St. Paul Police Department has not yet released a statement regarding the incident or the actions of the officers involved. Lollie's attorney, Nate Madden, has stated that they are considering a lawsuit against the police department.

Title: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver Defends Employee's Freedom of Speech Amidst Cancellation of Preseason Games in China

TOKYO (AP) — NBA Commissioner Adam Silver defended Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey's freedom of speech, despite China's state broadcaster canceling plans to show two preseason games later this week, following Morey's tweet supporting anti-government protesters in Hong Kong.

Speaking Tuesday at a news conference in Tokyo before a preseason game between the Rockets and NBA champion Toronto Raptors, Silver stated, "Daryl Morey, as general manager of the Houston Rockets, enjoys that right as one of our employees."

Silver further explained, "What I also tried to suggest is that I understand there are consequences from his freedom of speech and we will have to live with those consequences."
