The cancellation of the games between the Los Angeles Lakers and Brooklyn Nets, which were scheduled to take place in Shanghai and Shenzhen, was one of the consequences. Basketball is popular in China, and the two teams, particularly the Lakers due to LeBron James' stardom and the Nets due to Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba's co-founder Joe Tsai's ownership, would have likely drawn a significant television audience.

CCTV, China's state broadcaster, issued a statement saying, "We are strongly dissatisfied and oppose Adam Silver's claim to support Morey's right to freedom of expression." The broadcaster also stated it is reviewing all its cooperation and exchanges involving the NBA.

The NBA is not the first major corporation to face criticism from China over political differences. Other companies, such as Mercedes-Benz, Delta Air Lines, hotel operator Marriott, fashion brand Zara, and others, have also encountered conflicts with China in recent years.

Silver is scheduled to visit Shanghai on Wednesday and hopes to meet with officials and some of the league's business partners there in an effort to find common ground. He expressed hope that Chinese officials and fans would consider the long-standing relationship between the league and China and understand his response while acknowledging political differences between the countries.

Silver stated, "I'm sympathetic to our interests here and our partners that are upset. I don't think it's inconsistent on one hand to be sympathetic to them and at the same time stand by our principles."

The rift between China and the NBA began last week when Morey tweeted a now-deleted image that read, "Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong," in reference to months of pro-democracy demonstrations in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.

Efforts to defuse the situation were made, with Rockets owner Tilman Fertitta stating Morey does not speak for the Rockets, and Morey returning to Twitter on Monday to clarify his statement. However, the damage was already done, with at least one Chinese sporting goods company ending cooperation with the Rockets, NBA streaming partner Tencent stating it would not show Rockets games, and a sports news website in China stating it was no longer covering the team.

Further complicating the matter is the fact that China's best-known basketball player, Hall of Famer Yao Ming, spent his NBA career with the Rockets. Yao is now the president of the Chinese Basketball Association, which has suspended its relationship with the Rockets in response to Morey's tweet. The CBA also canceled plans for Houston and Dallas G League affiliates to play preseason games in China later this month.

Silver expressed hope for reconciliation, stating, "I'm hoping that together Yao Ming and I can find an accommodation. But he is extremely hot at the moment, and I understand it."

An NBA Cares event for a Shanghai educational center with the Nets was canceled Tuesday, though the Nets participated in other events as scheduled. The Lakers were due to arrive in Shanghai Tuesday. NBA Cares will still honor its larger mission surrounding the event, including providing a gift of new computers.

Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Geng Shuang stated Tuesday, "NBA's cooperation with China has been going on for quite a long time, so for what should be said and what should be done, they know best."

Silver also released a statement before his news conference, stating, "Those who question our motivation should know that the NBA's stance is about more than business." Many U.S. lawmakers have called for the league to take action, with some suggesting the games in China should be canceled by the NBA.

Silver concluded, "We are not apologizing for Daryl exercising his freedom of expression. I regret—again, having communicated directly with many friends in China—that so many people are upset, including millions and millions of our fans. At the end of the day, we come with basketball as an opportunity to sell dreams, sell hopes... that we are causing disruption in people's lives and that we are causing disharmony, that's something I regret."

Title: Controversial Remarks by Obamacare Architect Jonathan Gruber Raise Questions for Democrats Ahead of Supreme Court Review

Article:

In the wake of controversial remarks made by Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor Jonathan Gruber, who was a key architect of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), Democrats are facing questions about his role in their defense strategy as they prepare for another Supreme Court review of the health care law.

Gruber's comments, which surfaced recently, have caused a stir as he admitted to manipulating the language of the bill to avoid the Congressional Budget Office scoring the individual mandate as a tax, even though the U.S. Supreme Court ultimately upheld the mandate as constitutional under Congress' taxing power.

In his comments, Gruber stated, "Lack of transparency is a huge political advantage... That was really, really critical to get the thing to pass." He also referred to American voters as "stupid" and suggested that their lack of understanding was crucial to the bill's passage.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who had previously cited Gruber in a 2009 "myth buster" post, distanced herself from him this week, stating, "I don't know who he is. He didn't help write our bill." However, she added that Gruber's comments were a year old and he had recanted them.

Gruber has since expressed regret for his remarks, but House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, stated that American voters are "anything but stupid" and oppose the health care system's overhaul for valid reasons.

Gruber's explanation in 2012 of how Obamacare's subsidies should be paid has also caused problems for the Obama administration. In legal briefs submitted last year to a federal district court in Virginia, administration attorneys cited Gruber in a case defending their ability to pay subsidies to enrollees regardless of whether they are part of state-run or federally run health care exchanges.

The Supreme Court decided this month to take up the case, King v. Burwell, after the challengers lost to the administration in the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Neither the Justice Department nor the White House responded to questions about Gruber and his role in their legal strategy.

Sam Kazman, general counsel for the Competitive Enterprise Institute, which is funding the administration's opponents in the King case, stated that Gruber's 2012 remarks about subsidies bolster their own arguments. Gruber at the time said subsidies would flow only to states that set up their own exchanges, which would mean consumers in most states wouldn't be eligible for subsidies, potentially puncturing a big hole in Obamacare.

In a parallel case before the D.C. Circuit, the administration tried to downplay Gruber in its latest court filings. On Nov. 3, the Justice Department stated in a footnote that "post-enactment statements by a non-legislator are entitled to no weight."

In the King case, Obama administration attorneys who cited Gruber in briefs at the lower court dropped him from their arguments to the Supreme Court, said Michael A. Carvin, an attorney for the health care law's opponents.

Gruber has made hundreds of thousands of dollars off Obamacare, serving as a consultant to the Department of Health and Human Services and to states that used health care grant money to pay him for his services.

Timothy Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee University who closely tracks the health care law, stated that the controversy has been overblown. "He wasn't a legislator. He didn't write the bill. He didn't vote on the bill," Jost said.

Title: Trump Administration's Proposed Rule on Short-Term Health Insurance Plans: Urban Institute Report Highlights Gains and Reduced Costs for Taxpayers

Article:

The Trump administration's proposed rule to ease the availability of short-term, limited duration (STLD) health insurance plans could lead to an increase of 1.7 million Americans being insured while reducing costs to taxpayers, according to a new report from the Urban Institute.

On February 20, the Trump administration released a proposed rule that aims to make it easier for Americans to access affordable health insurance options outside of the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) health-insurance exchanges. The rule would repeal an October 2016 regulation that restricted the availability of STLD plans, which can be purchased for around $124 per month, compared to $393 on the exchanges.

The report, titled "The Impact of Short-Term Limited Duration Insurance and the Individual Mandate on Health Insurance Markets and the ACA's Subsidy Program," provides a clear picture of the potential benefits of the policy. The report's executive summary highlights several statistics, but it is the findings in the report's Table 1 that offer the most insight.

According to Table 1, 7.4 million on the exchanges eligible for tax credits would see no change in premiums. Furthermore, 4.2 million would enroll in STLD plans, whose premiums would be far below those for plans currently available (STLD premiums in the fourth quarter of 2016 were 68.4 percent lower than those on the exchanges).

Additionally, 4.5 million on the exchanges without tax credits would see premiums rise somewhat (by an average of 18.2 percent, compared with 8.3 percent in states prohibiting STLD plans, according to Table 4 on page 16).

While there are roughly similar numbers of winners and losers, the scale of benefits far exceeds the costs. The modest premium increases would be felt only by unsubsidized high-income enrollees, but the savings would be enjoyed across the income distribution—including by large numbers of low- and moderate-income households.

The Urban Institute also estimates that Trump's proposal would reduce the number of uninsured Americans by 1.7 million—a finding the report buries by grouping those enrolled in STLD plans together with the truly uninsured. In other words, restricting the sale of attractive, affordably priced health insurance isn't necessary to forestall the collapse of the exchanges, but it has needlessly concentrated enormous costs on millions seeking health insurance and forced many to go entirely without.

The Urban Institute's study is also enlightening with respect to the net fiscal impact of STLD deregulation. As a cheaper alternative to the exchanges becomes available, low-risk subsidized individuals may disenroll, and hence the government may save money. However, as the risk pool on the exchanges becomes sicker, subsidies expand, costing the government money. The net impact of these effects has as yet been unclear.

The Urban Institute finds that the number of people on unsubsidized ACA-compliant plans would fall by 1.5 million, while the number on subsidized plans would fall by 600,000. As a result, the reform would slightly reduce federal spending on health care for the nonelderly—by $686 million, or 0.2 percent—and should allay whatever federal budgetary concerns may have impeded the proposal's more thorough implementation.

These empirical findings (from authors who had expressed opposition to STLD insurance) suggest that the deregulation of STLD plans overall substantially reduces the cost of health insurance, covers more people, and slightly reduces the burden on taxpayers. States should embrace it—and give their residents a real chance to purchase affordable insurance coverage for themselves and their families.

Title: Trump Administration Lifts Ban on Lawsuits Against Foreign Companies Over Confiscated Cuban Properties

WASHINGTON/HAVANA - The Trump administration will allow lawsuits in U.S. courts for the first time against foreign companies that use properties confiscated by the Cuban government since Fidel Castro's revolution six decades ago, a senior U.S. official announced on Tuesday. The policy shift, to be announced on Wednesday, could expose U.S., European, and Canadian companies to legal action and potentially harm Cuba's efforts to attract foreign investment.

The decision, which will be explained in a speech by President Donald Trump's national security adviser, John Bolton, on Wednesday, also signals Washington's efforts to punish Havana over its support for Venezuela's socialist president, Nicolas Maduro. The administration will also announce new sanctions on Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua, countries Bolton has branded a "troika of tyranny."

It remains unclear whether such property claims will be accepted in U.S. courts, with the European Union already warning it could lodge a challenge with the World Trade Organization. EU ambassador to Cuba, Alberto Navarro, stated in Havana that the extraterritorial application of the U.S. embargo is illegal, contrary to international law, and immoral.

President Trump had previously threatened in January to allow a law that has been suspended since its creation in 1996, permitting Cuban-Americans and other U.S. citizens to sue foreign companies doing business in Cuba over property seized in decades past by the Cuban government. Title III of the Helms-Burton Act had been fully waived by every president over the past 23 years due to opposition from the international community and fears it could create chaos in the U.S. court system with a flood of lawsuits.

The complete lifting of the ban could allow billions of dollars in legal claims to move forward in U.S. courts and likely antagonize Canada and Europe, whose companies have significant business holdings in Cuba. It could also affect some U.S. companies that began investing in the island since former President Barack Obama began a process of normalizing relations between the two countries from the end of 2014.

The Cuban government did not immediately respond to a request for comment. However, the country's National Assembly, meeting over the weekend, declared the Helms-Burton Act "illegitimate, unenforceable, and without legal effect." Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel stated in a speech on Saturday that the United States "has pushed the precarious relations with our country back to the worst level... trying to activate the hateful Helms-Burton Law, which aims to return us in principle to... when we were a slave nation of another empire."

U.S.-Cuban relations have deteriorated since Trump became president in early 2017. A six-decade U.S. economic embargo on Cuba has also remained officially intact. Trump is going ahead despite protests by Canadian and European leaders to U.S. counterparts.

The U.S. official dismissed the EU's warning of a possible WTO challenge and a cycle of counterclaims in European courts as doomed to fail. Among the foreign companies heavily invested in Cuba are Canadian mining firm Sherritt International Corp and Spain's Melia Hotels International SA. U.S. companies, including airlines and cruise companies, have forged business deals in Cuba since the easing of restrictions under Obama.

Defending the decision, the U.S. official said allowing lawsuits would cause only a "bump" in the business world but send a message of U.S. resolve against Havana. In addition to halting any further waivers of Title III, the administration will begin full enforcement of Helms-Burton's Title IV, which requires the denial of U.S. visas to those involved in "trafficking" confiscated properties in Cuba.

Trump's decision followed threats by his top aides in recent weeks to take actions against Cuba to force it to abandon Maduro, something Havana has insisted it will not do. Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido invoked the constitution in January to assume the interim presidency. The United States and most Western countries have backed Guaido as head of state. Maduro has denounced Guaido as a U.S. puppet who is seeking to foment a coup, and Maduro is backed by Cuba, Russia, China, and the Venezuela military.

Trump's toughened stance on Cuba, as well as Venezuela, has been well-received in the large Cuban-American community in south Florida, an important voting bloc in a political swing state as he looks toward his re-election campaign in 2020. In Bolton's speech on Wednesday, he is expected to announce further measures against Cuba. The administration is considering a range of options, including sanctions against senior Cuban military and intelligence officials over their role in Venezuela and the tightening of limits on U.S. trade with the island, according to two people familiar with the matter. Navarro stated that EU companies had the obligation not to collaborate with U.S. judgments under Title III and the possibility to make counterclaims.

James Williams, president of Engage Cuba, a Washington-based lobbying group working to normalize relations with Cuba, stated that the policy decision has not been tested legally. Some 5,913 claims held by U.S. companies and individuals have been certified by the U.S. Justice Department and are estimated to be worth roughly $8 billion. Cuban law ties settlement of any claims to U.S. reparations for damages from Washington's embargo and what it considers other acts of U.S. aggression. Cuban estimates of that damage range from $121 billion to more than $300 billion.

Title: Conservative Groups and Fiscal Hawks Criticize Bipartisan Budget Agreement, Speaker Boehner Defends Deal

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the bipartisan budget agreement negotiated between House Republicans and Senate Democrats has faced strong criticism from conservative groups and fiscal hawks, with House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, facing an unusually harsh response. The deal, struck a day earlier by House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican, and Senate Budget Committee Chairwoman Patty Murray, Washington Democrat, has been met with mixed reactions, with some sectors of the economy set to benefit while others face potential losses.

The agreement, which could be voted on in the House as early as Thursday, has been criticized for its perceived failure to address long-term spending on entitlement programs and for permitting new spending in the short term in exchange for vague promises of long-term cuts.

Rep. Jim Jordan, Ohio Republican, expressed his opposition, stating, "I am against [the deal] from just a basic point that we embarked on a position at the beginning of the year that said, 'We will keep the sequester in place unless we get to make changes on mandatory spending that will save those programs and put the budget on a path to balance within the next 10 years.'"

Chris Chocola, president of the fiscally hawkish Club for Growth, added, "Apparently, there are some Republicans who don't have the stomach for even relatively small spending reductions that are devoid of budgetary smoke and mirrors. If Republicans work with Democrats to pass this deal, it should surprise no one when Republican voters seek alternatives who actually believe in less spending when they go to the ballot box."

Despite the conservative backlash and tepid reviews from many House Democrats, Speaker Boehner defended the agreement, using strong language to counter the criticism. "They're using our members and the American people to their own purposes," an angry Mr. Boehner said. "This is ridiculous."

The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the bulk of the plan's deficit reduction would come in the final three years of the deal, while the new spending would occur over the next two years. The estimate followed news that the U.S. government ran a $135.2 billion budget deficit through the first two months of the year, a significant decrease from the $226.8 billion deficit of the same period last year.

The Ryan-Murray agreement increases spending in 2014 to $1.012 trillion and in 2015 to $1.014 trillion, restoring more than $60 billion in sequester spending cuts. The new spending is offset in part by lowering the cost-of-living adjustment for military retirees, requiring higher pension contributions from recently hired federal employees, and raising fees on travelers collected by the Transportation Security Administration.

Industries and interests that emerged as losers in the final deal, such as the airline industry and federal employees, have already expressed their displeasure. The National Treasury Employees Union and National Nurses United have voiced concerns about the impact on federal workers and military retirees, respectively.

Many liberal lawmakers have also criticized the agreement, arguing that it unfairly burdens federal workers and may face difficulties passing if it does not extend unemployment insurance for the 1.3 million Americans set to be kicked off the rolls before the end of the year.

As the debate continues, it remains to be seen whether the bipartisan budget agreement will pass, and if so, with what amendments or concessions.

Title: "Ahmad Khan Rahami Captured in Shootout with Police, Charged with Attempted Murder of Officers"

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Ahmad Khan Rahami, the primary suspect in the bombings in New Jersey and New York over the weekend, was captured Monday following a gun battle with police in Linden, New Jersey. The 28-year-old naturalized U.S. citizen was identified as the main person of interest in the Saturday night blast in New York's Chelsea neighborhood, an explosion in New Jersey's Seaside Park on Saturday morning, and a foiled bomb attack Sunday night near a train station in Elizabeth, NJ.

The manhunt for Rahami began Monday morning after a bar owner in Linden spotted him sleeping in his doorway. A police officer confronted Rahami around 10:45 a.m., and a gun battle ensued. The officer, identified as Angel Padilla, was shot in the abdomen, but was wearing a bulletproof vest. A second officer, Investigator Pete Hammer, was grazed by a bullet. Both officers are expected to recover.

Rahami was shot at least once in the leg and was eventually subdued and taken into custody. He was charged with five counts of attempted murder of a police officer and was being held on $5.2 million bail. Rahami underwent surgery at University Hospital in Newark and remained at the hospital. It was not known if Rahami had an attorney as of Monday evening.

Federal charges in the bombings have yet to be filed. Rahami was last known to have lived in Elizabeth, where the FBI conducted a raid on his apartment Monday morning. The city is also where investigators discovered five suspicious devices, one of which exploded while a bomb squad robot tried to disarm it, near a train station on Sunday night.

Governor Andrew Cuomo suggested during a Monday interview that the bomb plot may have been influenced by foreign sources. Two U.S. officials told Reuters on Monday that the bomb plot likely involved several individuals. Federal authorities conducted a traffic stop in Brooklyn of a "vehicle of interest" in the bombings on Sunday night. The individuals in the vehicle were no longer in custody, the FBI said Monday.

The Chelsea bombing, which injured 29 people, occurred on West 23rd Street at 8:30 p.m. on Saturday. Police found a second, unexploded device four blocks away. The device was described as a pressure cooker with wires and a phone attached. The contraption bore a resemblance to the bomb used in the 2013 Boston Marathon attack and was placed in a plastic bag.

Authorities found Rahami's fingerprint on the unexploded bomb discovered on West 27th Street. Police are still searching for two individuals who allegedly removed the bomb from a duffle bag after it had been placed on the street by Rahami. The pair placed the device in a plastic bag and then walked off with the duffel bag. Police consider the individuals witnesses.

The pipe bomb explosion in Seaside Park occurred about 80 miles south of the Chelsea bombing site. No one was injured in that blast. Runners were slated to be near the location of the explosion when it went off, but the race was delayed after an unattended backpack was discovered.

Local and federal officials said Rahami had not been on law enforcement's radar before the explosions, and the FBI said they had no knowledge of Rahami receiving any weapons or explosives training overseas.

Title: Bernie Sanders and Michael Bloomberg Face Off in CNN Town Hall, Sanders Criticizes Bloomberg's Wealth but Declines to Address Accepting Potential Funding

In a heated exchange during a CNN town hall on Tuesday night, Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders criticized fellow candidate Michael Bloomberg's wealth, stating that it was "offensive" for a candidate to "buy the presidency." Sanders, however, declined to indicate whether he would accept financial help from Bloomberg to beat President Donald Trump.

During the town hall, Anderson Cooper asked Sanders if he considered Bloomberg his closest competition for the Democratic nomination. Sanders responded, "I don't think he has the right to buy this election... I think it's a bit obscene that we have somebody who... I'll buy the presidency."

Later in the event, an audience member asked Sanders if he would accept help from billionaires like Bloomberg if he were nominated. Sanders dodged the question three times about whether he would accept Michael Bloomberg's money in the general election.

Sanders emphasized his grassroots campaign, stating that he has received more campaign contributions from more Americans than any candidate in the history of the United States. He also reiterated his commitment to defeating President Trump.

Cooper pressed Sanders on the issue, asking if Sanders would accept money from Bloomberg if he did not win the nomination. Sanders responded that he would support the Democratic nominee, but declined to answer directly whether he would accept Bloomberg's money if he did not win the nomination.

The exchange between Sanders and Bloomberg is the latest in a series of heated exchanges between the two candidates. The primary season is heating up, and the race to take on President Trump in the general election is intensifying.

Title: House Republicans Propose Transitional Plan to Address Potential Obamacare Subsidy Crisis

Article:

In a bid to address the potential fallout from a forthcoming Supreme Court ruling on the Affordable Care Act (ACA), House Republicans have outlined a plan to maintain subsidies for Obamacare beneficiaries while allowing states to opt out of the program. The plan, described as a "work in progress," would continue to provide full subsidies under the ACA to all beneficiaries regardless of their state of residence, but starting in 2016, states could begin to opt out, receiving block grants to manage their residents' health insurance as they see fit.

The block grants and subsidies, including those for states that remain in the ACA, would expire in 2017, leaving the next president and Congress with the task of replacing the law entirely. Representative Charles W. Boustany Jr. (R-LA) praised the plan, stating, "I think it's a good plan. It's a good start."

The Supreme Court is currently considering a part of the law that stipulates subsidies can be paid to residents in states with their own exchanges. The administration argues this was intended to cover everyone, while opponents claim it was meant to exclude the 34 states that did not establish their own exchanges and instead rely on the federal HealthCare.gov program. More than 6 million Americans could lose subsidies if the court rules against the administration.

Senate Republicans are also discussing their own plans, including extending subsidies through 2017 and allowing states to opt out of the ACA. Senate Republicans have co-sponsored a bill by Senator Ron Johnson (R-WI) that would lock in the subsidies through August 2017.

President Obama and his Democratic allies argue the law is fine as it stands, and that all Americans should receive subsidies. They contend that if the court rules against the administration, Congress should pass a one-sentence change to clarify that subsidies should be available to everyone. However, the GOP-led Congress is unlikely to support this approach.

The House proposal, which is still in development, would repeal the ACA's insurance mandates for individuals and employers, a move that is likely to draw criticism from ACA supporters who argue these mandates are necessary to balance risk pools and keep premiums in check. The plan would be passed using a budget process known as "reconciliation," which can pass the Senate with a majority vote, but could still be vetoed by President Obama.

Some lawmakers are hesitant to extend Obamacare subsidies beyond 2015 and 2016, fearing it sends the wrong message to voters after the GOP has spent years trying to repeal the entire law. The House plan is still in development, and the fractious House GOP caucus has struggled to agree on many issues in the past.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry Cautions on Iran Nuclear Deal Amid Allegations of Secret Uranium Enrichment Facility

Article:

In a significant development, U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry has expressed concerns about a potential derailment of the ongoing nuclear deal negotiations with Iran, following allegations from an Iranian dissident group that Iran is operating a secret uranium enrichment facility near Tehran.

During a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing on Wednesday, Kerry stated that U.S. officials were aware of the site prior to this week, but it has not been identified as a nuclear facility. He emphasized, "It is a facility that we are well aware of, which is on a list of facilities we have. I’m not going to go into greater detail."

The alleged facility, known as "Lavizan-3," is said to have been used for clandestine nuclear research since 2008 and for uranium enrichment with advanced IR-2m and IR-4 centrifuge machines, according to the National Coalition of Resistance of Iran (NCRI), a dissident group that claims the site has never before been revealed to international officials.

The NCRI's claim is not yet verifiable, and the group has a controversial history in Washington. However, the group is known for having deep sources inside Iran's nuclear community and is credited with having made game-changing revelations about Tehran's activities in the past.

Notably, during the early 2000s, similar NCRI claims exposed the existence of Iran's Natanz uranium enrichment facility and the Arak heavy-water plutonium facility—two operations that have been at the center of international scrutiny and distrust of Tehran since then.

Rep. Brad Sherman (D-California) noted to Kerry during the hearing that "the MEK sometimes gives us accurate information." Sherman added, "They are the ones that told the world about the Iranian nuclear program. They now say that there’s a secret facility at Lavazza 3."

The development comes as the U.S. and Iran are in the final stages of negotiations to reach a comprehensive nuclear deal, with a deadline of November 24, 2014. The allegations of a secret uranium enrichment facility could potentially complicate the ongoing negotiations and raise further concerns about Iran's nuclear ambitions.

Title: Comparative Analysis: South Korea's Response to COVID-19 vs. China's Approach

Article:

In the global fight against the COVID-19 pandemic, two contrasting approaches have emerged, with South Korea and China representing opposite ends of the spectrum. While China's Communist Party has claimed its response as a testament to its political prowess, a closer look at the situation reveals a more complex reality.

South Korea, a democracy, has demonstrated a more open and transparent approach, focusing on education, transparency, and mobilizing civil society. This strategy, devoid of China's tactics such as forced home detention, use of minorities as slave labor, or silencing critics, has resulted in a more manageable outbreak.

South Korea's most effective weapon against the virus has been its rapid expansion of testing. The country is currently testing 15,000 people daily, according to government figures, with 210,000 South Koreans tested since January 3, compared to approximately 6,500 tests completed in the United States by Tuesday morning. Despite the spike in confirmed cases, South Korea's mortality rate stands at 0.71 percent, with only 54 deaths reported as of Tuesday.

The number of daily confirmed cases has been steadily declining, from 686 on March 2 to just 131 on Tuesday, according to government figures. The government has deployed 53 drive-through sample collection stations, ensuring physical distancing during testing.

President Moon Jae-in acknowledged the gravity of the situation on March 1, raising the crisis alert to the highest level. South Korea's civil society has also played a significant role, with major events canceled, church services moved online, and citizens voluntarily avoiding areas with high infection rates, such as Daegu, without resorting to lockdowns.

Controversial measures, such as tracking confirmed cases via GPS, have been implemented, but they pale in comparison to the surveillance tactics used in some parts of China, such as drones taking people's temperatures and spraying disinfectant.

To prevent the export of the virus, South Korea has implemented a three-step detection system at Incheon International Airport, with additional screening measures for passengers bound for the United States. This approach emphasizes transparency and openness, rather than China's pattern of distortion and distraction.

While China deserves credit for its scientific attention to the problem, as acknowledged in a World Health Organization (WHO) report, the report also highlights the deep commitment of the Chinese people to collective action in the face of the common threat. If Beijing had practiced openness, transparency, and public education earlier, the epidemic might not have reached such devastating proportions.

In conclusion, South Korea's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, characterized by openness, transparency, and the active participation of its citizens, offers a stark contrast to China's more authoritarian approach. This approach not only appears to be more effective in managing the outbreak but also aligns with democratic values, ensuring dignity, and entrusting citizens with truth. The success of South Korea's response, both in terms of public health and politics, serves as a reminder of the strength of democratic values in times of crisis.

Title: FBI Interview Summaries Suggest Alleged Email Classification Deal Between State Department and Clinton Aides

Article:

In a series of interviews with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), it has been suggested that there was an attempt at a deal between Patrick Kennedy, a high-ranking official at the State Department, and the FBI, where classified emails on Hillary Clinton's unsecured bathroom server would have their status altered in exchange for more favorable treatment of FBI officials in overseas postings at embassies.

According to documents made public by the FBI as part of interview summaries surrounding the Clinton emails case, the negotiations took place in the spring of 2015. The Weekly Standard's Stephen Hayes first broke the story on Friday.

The FBI interviews reveal that a senior FBI official in the international operations division described conversations with Kennedy about the classification of emails. In his interview, this official stated that his section of the FBI had attempted to contact Kennedy repeatedly over several months but received no response. In the late spring or early summer of 2015, the FBI official reported to work to find a note indicating that Kennedy had called. According to the summary, Kennedy wanted help.

The FBI official spoke with Kennedy, and Kennedy raised the possibility of keeping at least one Clinton email from public disclosure by obtaining a "B9" exemption under the Freedom of Information Act, a rarely used exemption that refers to "geological and geophysical information and data." One email in particular concerned Kennedy, and according to the FBI summary, providing a B9 exemption "would allow him to archive the document in the basement of the department of state never to be seen again." The FBI official told Kennedy that he would look into the email if Kennedy would authorize a pending request for additional FBI personnel in Iraq.

Further evidence of Kennedy's attempts to have the classification of some sensitive emails changed comes from a summary of an interview with the section chief of the FBI records management division. The FBI records official, whose job includes making determinations on classification, told investigators that he was approached by his colleague in international operations after the initial discussion with Kennedy. The FBI records official says that his colleague "pressured" him to declassify an email "in exchange for a quid pro quo," according to the interview summary. "In exchange for making the email unclassified, State would reciprocate by allowing the FBI to place more agents in countries where they are presently forbidden." The request was denied.

The FBI has "explained" these events by saying that the bargained-for exchange never took place, and the FBI agent with whom Kennedy was communicating has since retired. State Department spokesman Mark Toner made the absurd claim that these conversations were a "normal part of the classification process" — as though it's "normal" to reclassify documents that are part of an investigation into criminal misuse of state secrets in favor of the governing party's presidential nominee.

This communication took place amid Hillary Clinton's denials that any classified material was sent or received on her email, which her former employees still working at State — including Kennedy — knew to be a lie. And rather than give the public the truth, which wouldn't come out until much later, after she had won the Democrat nomination, Kennedy was working to remedy her false denials by making a lie true.

Furthermore, he was offering essentially a bribe to the FBI in order to procure more favorable field on which the Clinton email investigation would play out. This isn't some ho-hum bureaucratic deal-making at work — or if it is, it illuminates precisely how like the Third World the corruption in Washington has become.

Consider what would happen if the middle manager or legal counsel at XYZ Corporation, whose CEO is under FBI investigation, were to offer perks and valuables to FBI agents individually or collectively as a quid pro quo for a reframing of the investigation. We all know how that would go — the charges would pile up, the offender in question would be quickly dismissed, the corporation would be dragged through the mud, and the CEO would be accused of directing the attempted bribe.

In this case, there is no evidence Hillary Clinton was behind Kennedy's offers — but we also don't know how hard investigators have looked. After all, this horse-trading didn't happen when Hillary was wrapping up her affairs at State in 2012; it happened last year when the FBI investigation was ramping up. One assumes Kennedy understood the stakes at hand, and one assumes he's smart enough to know how best to butter his own bread as a Clintonite.

And given Kennedy's role as the Clintons' fixer at State, you would expect that he would be the primary individual put to the squeeze in any investigation of the email scandal. Kennedy, after all, was involved in the questionable political hiring of Clinton IT tech Bryan Pagliano to a nonpolitical State Department job; Pagliano was the man who set up Hillary's private server and ended up getting immunity in the investigation.

But yes, Toner and the rest of the Democrat stooges disguised as federal bureaucrats are correct. For those of us rubes in the hinterlands, this might seem a flagrant example of an out-of-control government, but for our betters inside the Beltway, it's a Tuesday. And they wonder why we increasingly recoil from consent to be governed by them.

Title: Raheem Kassam, Donald Trump Jr., and the Ongoing Debate on Social Media Censorship

Article:

In an interview at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), Raheem Kassam, a former editor for Breitbart and a fellow at the Claremont Institute, expressed his belief that the Left is attempting to silence conservative voices on social media. Kassam's recent suspension from Facebook, which was later restored, has sparked a conversation about online censorship and the suppression of free speech.

Kassam, who is the author of "No Go Zones: How Sharia Law Is Coming to a Neighborhood Near You," sees the social-media crackdown on conservatives as evidence of the Left's fear. "If the other side wasn't afraid, they wouldn't be coming down so heavy-handed on people," Kassam said. He also predicted that if President Trump is re-elected in 2021, there will be a push for a Digital Bill of Rights to address the issue of online free speech.

The suppression of online free speech has been a topic of concern for many conservatives, with instances of censorship becoming increasingly common on platforms like Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube. In February, Instagram (owned by Facebook) deleted a post by Donald Trump Jr., which led to a backlash from the president's son. Trump Jr. was livid in his reaction, stating, "You're part of the problem. Maybe allow for discourse rather than force feed everyone your leftist bulls**t."

The issue of online censorship has been a contentious one, with many conservatives feeling that their voices are being silenced while the Left's narrative is being amplified. In 2016, the suspension of Stacy McCain's Twitter account, which had tens of thousands of followers, was met with outrage. Twitter offered no details of what McCain had allegedly done to deserve the banishment.

At CPAC, Laura Loomer, a Trump supporter who was banned from Twitter in November after criticizing newly elected Democrat Rep. Ilhan Omar, discussed her role in a recent investigation of Omar. Loomer asserted that pressure from the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), which has connections to Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood, was responsible for Twitter's banning her.

Loomer also had a brief video interview with Donald Trump Jr. at CPAC, during which she gave him one of her red #StopTheBias hats and asked about taking action against social-media censorship. Trump Jr. responded, "It's time."

If Kassam's analysis is correct, the ongoing campaign of online censorship could have significant consequences for the tech giants, as they may be forced to pay a high price for attempting to deprive Americans of their freedom of speech. The issue of online censorship is a complex and contentious one, and it remains to be seen how it will be addressed in the future.

Title: Kentucky Senate Race: Candidates Dodge Questions in Debate, Raising Questions About Political Calculus

Article:

In the highly anticipated debate for the Kentucky US Senate race, incumbent Republican Mitch McConnell and Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes each evaded a significant question from the moderator, leading to speculation about the political strategy behind their evasions and the potential impact on their campaigns.

The focus of this article is on the evasive tactics employed by both candidates during the debate, particularly in response to questions about their political leanings and policy positions.

First, let's discuss Ms. Grimes, the Kentucky Secretary of State. A viral video from Friday showed her refusing to answer a question about whether she voted for President Obama during an interview with The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Kentucky. In the debate, she explained her evasion by stating that, as the chief election official, she felt it was her duty to uphold the right to a secret ballot.

Grimes's evasion was met with criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. Some argued that her refusal to answer a seemingly straightforward question was evasive and damaging to her credibility. On the other hand, some argue that the question was unnecessary, as her support for President Obama is already well-known.

Senator McConnell, too, evaded a question about climate change, a topic of relevance in a state heavily reliant on the coal industry. In the past, McConnell has stated, "I'm not a scientist," implying that he is not qualified to discuss the causes of climate change. When asked about his stance on climate change during the debate, McConnell brushed past the question, focusing instead on his efforts to protect coal jobs in Kentucky.

Political analysts suggest that both candidates' evasions are part of a calculated political strategy. By not answering questions that could potentially harm their campaigns, they are able to avoid alienating key constituencies or taking positions that could be used against them in campaign advertisements.

However, some observers argue that the candidates' evasions may not matter much, as both candidates are pro-coal and the question of climate change is not a significant voting issue in Kentucky.

In conclusion, the first debate in the Kentucky US Senate race saw both candidates evade questions about their political leanings and policy positions. While some argue that this evasion is part of a calculated political strategy, others believe that the candidates' positions on these issues are already well-known and that the questions were unnecessary. Regardless, the debate raised questions about the political calculus behind the candidates' evasions and the potential impact on their campaigns.

Title: President Obama's Visit to Israel: A Trust-Building Mission

Article:

President Barack Obama landed in Israel this morning, marking his first visit to the country as president. Speaking at a welcoming ceremony at Tel Aviv airport, Obama said, "I see this visit as an opportunity to reaffirm the unbreakable bond between our nations, to restate America's unwavering commitment to Israel's security, and to speak directly to the people of Israel and to your neighbors."

NPR's Larry Abramson, who is at the airport, reported that Obama was welcomed by Israeli President Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The leaders reaffirmed the "unbreakable alliance" between the countries, according to Larry.

Obama is now on his way to tour Israel's Iron Dome, the country's missile defense system, which the United States has helped fund. Later today, he will head to Jerusalem, and tomorrow, he will cross into Ramallah in the West Bank.

The New York Times reports that Obama does not arrive in the region with grand plans to revive stalled peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. Instead, the president is seeking to make a connection with the Israeli people, many of whom view him with a jaundiced eye after four years in which he sparred with Mr. Netanyahu over issues like Iran and the Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

The highlight of the trip will be a speech Obama will deliver to students at the Jerusalem International Convention Center on Thursday. The Washington Post reports the president is expected to reassure Israel of the United States' commitment to its security as Israel "seeks to counter threats from Iran and protect its people in the midst of civil war in neighboring Syria."

Larry called this a "trust-building visit." He says that even though both sides insist there are no problems between the two countries, the fact is there has been some tension. "There have been questions about whether or not the Israelis are a little too eager to possibly attack Iran in order to keep it from getting a nuclear bomb. And there are also questions about whether or not Israel is serious about resuming peace talks with the Palestinians, but nobody is really expecting any big initiatives by the United States or the Israelis on those two fronts at this point," Larry told our Newscast unit.

President Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu just wrapped up a 45-minute press conference in which they addressed the peace process, Iran, and Syria. During the press conference, President Obama was asked by NBC's Chuck Todd why peace talks stalled during his first term. Obama said that going into his presidency, he did not promise to bring peace to the Middle East, instead, he said, he would start on the process immediately.

However, the bottom line, he said, is that "this is not easy." Netanyahu was asked directly whether Israel and the United States believed that Iran was a year away from producing a nuclear weapon. Netanyahu said the countries "share information and we share the same assessment on the schedule."

President Obama said that "each country has to make its own decision" when it comes to war. But he believed that on the question of Iran, there was "still time to solve this diplomatically." On Syria, President Obama defended the United States, saying it has done a lot to try to bring the conflict to a resolution. "I have made clear the use of chemical weapons is a game changer," Obama said. His team, he added, is currently trying to assess whether the Syrian government has used those weapons.

"Israel will have no greater friend than the United States," President Obama said during an appearance with Israeli President Shimon Peres. Peres, for his part, told Obama that his vision of peace for the region can be accomplished. He said he believed Obama when he said, "peace is not only a wish but a possibility."

Obama and Peres opened their meeting with a planting ceremony. Obama brought Peres a magnolia tree from the White House garden. "This is the work of generations," Obama said about peace. He framed that quote with a story from the Talmud about Honi and the carob tree. The tree yields carobs 70 years after it's planted. So what's the point of planting one, if you may never eat its fruits, Honi asks a man. The man tells him that when he came into the world, his father and grandfathers had planted carob trees for him to enjoy. The man said he was planting carob trees for his children and grandchildren.

Title: Senate Foreign Relations Committee Approves Mike Pompeo's Nomination for Secretary of State

Article:

Mike Pompeo, the current CIA director, secured a favorable vote on Monday from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, thanks to a last-minute endorsement from Sen. Rand Paul. This unexpected endorsement has smoothed the path for Pompeo's confirmation as secretary of state, potentially as early as this week.

Initially, Pompeo seemed likely to receive an unfavorable recommendation from the committee, with Paul firmly opposed. However, the Kentucky Republican changed his stance after personal appeals from President Donald Trump. Had Paul not changed his vote, Pompeo would have been the third nominee in two decades to receive a negative report in committee, and likely the first in that time to win a vote in the full Senate.

Paul's change of heart on Pompeo came after several conversations with Trump and assurances that the hawkish nominee views the Iraq War as a mistake and seeks to wind down the U.S. presence in Afghanistan.

"President Trump believes that Iraq was a mistake, that regime change has destabilized the region, and that we must end our involvement with Afghanistan," Paul said in a statement. "Having received assurances from President Trump and Director Pompeo that he agrees with the president on these important issues, I have decided to support his nomination to be our next Secretary of State."

Trump praised Paul after the libertarian's change of heart on Pompeo, according to a pool report.

The final vote count on Pompeo's nomination sparked temporary intrigue in the committee, as Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.) agreed to vote "present" despite his opposition. This allowed Foreign Relations Chairman Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) to steer the nominee to the floor without waiting for the delayed Sen. Johnny Isakson (R-Ga.) to vote. The final roll call was 11-9.

Pompeo is expected to win confirmation from the full Senate later this week with unified GOP support and backing from a handful of vulnerable Democrats. After Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota became the first Democrat to announce her support on Thursday, Sens. Joe Donnelly (D-Ind.) and Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) followed suit on Monday.

Among the Democrats who remain undecided on Pompeo are Sens. Mark Warner of Virginia, Doug Jones of Alabama, and Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire. Sen. Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire became the latest Democrat to come out in opposition to Pompeo on Monday.

Activists on the left who have pushed Democrats to oppose Pompeo, citing his past suggestion that Islamic leaders might be "potentially complicit" in terrorism as well as other politically volatile stances, lauded the committee's minority for staying united in opposition.

"We were glad to see Democrats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hold firm and say that an Islamophobic, anti-woman, climate change-denying, pro-torture war hawk is an unacceptable choice to serve as our country’s secretary of state," Elizabeth Beavers, foreign policy manager at the liberal group Indivisible, said in a statement.

Title: U.S. Military Bases Increase Security Levels Due to Terror Threats

Article:

Washington ( CNN ) - The U.S. Department of Defense has increased security conditions at military bases across the country due to growing concerns about terror threats, officials confirmed on Friday. The security level has been raised to "Force Protection Bravo," the third-highest threat level on a five-tier scale.

The decision was not prompted by a specific threat but rather due to several recent incidents that have raised concerns, according to U.S. military officials. One such incident involved a jihadist linked to the Garland attack tweeting the name and address of a U.S. military officer connected to the military's Syrian rebel training program.

The tweet, published on an account connected to British-born jihadist Junaid Hussain, appeared to encourage an attack on the address and was sent out a few days before the attack on a cartoon exhibit featuring drawings of the Prophet Mohammed. Hussain is also believed to have been messaging with Elton Simpson, one of the two attackers of the Texas event, and had been urging Simpson to take action.

This followed the publishing of the names and addresses of about 100 military members on ISIS-connected accounts several weeks ago. FBI Director James Comey told reporters on Thursday that there are thousands of ISIS followers online in the U.S.

"We have a general concern, obviously, that ISIL is focusing on the uniformed military and law enforcement," Comey told reporters.

The order to upgrade the threat level was signed by Admiral William Gortney, head of the U.S. Northern Command, which oversees all U.S. military installations in the continental U.S. The security order affects 3,200 sites, including bases, National Guard facilities, recruiting stations, and health clinics, a Pentagon official said.

Captain Jeff Davis, spokesman for the U.S. Northern Command, or NORTHCOM, said, "We have the same concern about the potential threat posed by violent homegrown extremists."

The change in threat level status could mean more checks of vehicles entering bases and more thorough identity checks of all personnel. Davis emphasized that "this is the new normal, that we are going to have increased vigilance and force protection. We seek to be unpredictable."

The order to raise the force protection level to Bravo also applies to all National Guard installations, recruiting stations, and ROTC detachments. However, a U.S. military official acknowledged that it will be difficult for ROTC detachments to do much more than security awareness.

In addition, security was recently raised at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, in response to a perceived threat to the base security. The threat was never deemed credible, but it came after another security concern at a base in Delaware used by Vice President Joe Biden when he flies home.

On Friday, Wright-Patterson announced that the Air Force museum, which is part of the base, was canceling a planned Friday night concert and was stopping tours that were regularly offered until further notice. The base said this was "due to elevated security measures."

Since NORTHCOM was established in October 2002, the threat level has reached Bravo on four occasions: Feb. 9, 2003, amid concerns al Qaeda was planning attacks on American targets; Dec. 21, 2003, when officials were concerned about attacks during the holiday season; May 1, 2011, in the aftermath of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden; and the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. It reached "Delta," its highest level, on Sept. 11, 2001, Pentagon officials told CNN at the time.

Title: Altered Historical Record: National Archives Removes and Apologizes for Edited Photograph from Women's March

Article:

Last week, the National Archives removed and apologized for an altered photograph from the 2017 Women's March on Washington, following public outcry and media scrutiny. The photograph, which was part of a display at the National Archives Research Center, had the word "Trump" blurred on a sign that originally read "God Hates Trump." Other signs in the same picture, which originally contained the words "vagina" and "pussy," were also edited.

The National Archives offered two arguments and one excuse for the alterations. The excuse was that the altered photograph was not part of a current exhibition at the Archives, tracing a hundred years of the suffragist movement, but merely a display that advertised the show. The arguments were that the words referring to female anatomy may strike visitors as "inappropriate" and that the Archives are a "non-partisan, non-political federal agency."

The altered photograph, taken by photographer Ellen Shub, is a stark reminder of her lifelong work documenting social protests. Shub, who died last month at the age of seventy-three, was known for her text-centric photographs, which served as a historical record of social movements and protests. Many of her photographs were published in alternative and movement media, including gay and lesbian newspapers, feminist newspapers, and city weeklies.

The incident at the National Archives has sparked comparisons to the Soviet system for excising people, objects, and facts from photographs. The analogy suggests that the head and staff of the National Archives may not have given themselves a moment to consider their actions, perhaps because their actions seemed so logical and right to them. The swift media reaction and public outcry may have been instrumental in correcting the record, but as philosopher Hannah Arendt warns, history lost, even if only temporarily, is still memory lost.

The incident at the National Archives raises questions about the role of historical institutions in preserving and presenting the truth, and the potential dangers of political bias in shaping historical narratives. The incident also highlights the importance of media scrutiny and public engagement in holding institutions accountable for their actions and ensuring the accuracy of historical records.

Title: Ecuador Delays Decision on Edward Snowden's Asylum Request for Up to Two Months

Article:

In a developing story, former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden remains in transit at a Moscow airport, as Ecuador announced that it could take up to two months to approve his political asylum bid. The delay in decision-making comes as Ecuador faces international scrutiny and potential consequences for offering asylum to Snowden, who is wanted by the US government for leaking top-secret information on US surveillance programs.

Ecuador's foreign minister, Ricardo Patino, stated yesterday that if Snowden were to seek asylum at the Ecuadorean embassy, a decision would be made. He acknowledged the parallel with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, who has been holed up in the South American country's embassy in London for over a year.

Snowden is wanted by the US government after leaking top-secret information to The Guardian, The Washington Post, and a Hong Kong-based newspaper, where he first sought refuge. The US revoked his passport, but he managed to flee Hong Kong on Sunday. Reuters reports that Ecuador denies granting Snowden special travel documents.

Initially, Snowden was expected to leave Russia on Monday on a flight to Cuba, but he did not board the plane. Some speculate that Snowden has already left the Moscow airport and is making his way toward Ecuador's embassy there.

Ecuador has come under fire for offering Snowden asylum, with calls in the US Congress to cut off aid to the country. National security analyst Aaron Cohen told Fox News that the US is giving millions of dollars to Ecuador, which may potentially be harboring someone responsible for one of the most massive intelligence leaks in history.

Ecuador has received $144.4 million in US aid over the past five years, according to Fox. Some speculate that Ecuador is taking its time considering the asylum application in order to come across as seriously weighing the legal implications of Snowden's asylum request, while others point to the media attention Ecuador garners while the decision is pending.

Ecuador's embassy official, Efraín Baus, stated that Snowden's application will be reviewed responsibly, as are the many other asylum applications that Ecuador receives each year. Ecuador does have an extradition agreement with the United States, but makes exceptions for political crimes, reports The ███.

Steve Striffler, a Latin America specialist at the University of New Orleans, wrote on CNN that Ecuador's President Rafael Correa isn't considering Snowden's asylum request just to gain political points at home. He notes that after offering Mr. Assange asylum in 2012, President Correa actually fueled opposition party criticism.

Politicians are always looking to score political points, and Correa has certainly had his moments. However, Correa's stance is best seen as a principled one, according to Striffler. In broad terms, Correa's openness to Assange and Snowden, as well as his decision to close a US military base in Ecuador, is part of an effort to deepen Ecuadorian sovereignty while strengthening Latin America's ability to limit the influence of the United States in the region.

Many have criticized Ecuador for the apparent irony in its support of freedom of information when it comes to individuals like Assange and Snowden sharing top-secret information, but deterring expression at home. The country recently passed a media law that contains "questionable or dangerous provisions" to clamp down on criticism by the press, according to Reporters without Borders.

There could be some immediate political and economic consequences for Ecuador if it does indeed grant Snowden asylum, as well. The renewal of preferential treatment for trading certain products, including roses and tuna, is on the table, reports The New York Times.

Michael Shifter of the Inter-American Dialogue told the Times, "The risks are enormous… It would bring the United States down very hard on him." Others, however, say preferential treatment was already at risk of not being renewed.

"The US doesn't have too many measures it can utilize, other than to criticize," says Jonas Wolff, a senior research fellow at the Frankfurt-based Peace Research Institute. The Guardian's Stephen Kinzer says Ecuador is a good choice for Snowden because even if Ecuador's government drastically changes in coming years, the region as a whole has moved away from falling in line behind US policy.

Title: ABC News Under Fire for Alleged Cover-Up of Jeffrey Epstein Story

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, a video has emerged this week that appears to show ABC News spiking a story about billionaire Jeffrey Epstein, a story that could have exposed the disgraced financier as a sex offender. This comes on the heels of allegations by journalist Ronan Farrow that NBC News suppressed his reporting on alleged rapist Harvey Weinstein to protect their own in-house sexual abuser, morning anchor Matt Lauer.

The video, featuring anchor Amy Robach, was recorded off-air and shows her expressing frustration over ABC executives' decision to kill her story about Epstein, which she had been sitting on for three years. Robach said she had an interview with Virginia Roberts, who made allegations of sexual abuse against Epstein.

"I've had this interview with Virginia Roberts... We would not put it on the air... I was told, 'Who's Jeffrey Epstein? No one knows who that is. This is a stupid story.' Then the palace found out we had her whole allegations about Prince Andrew and threatened us a million different ways... And then Alan Dershowitz was also implicated in it because of the planes," Robach said in the video.

Epstein, a wealthy money manager with close ties to many top establishment figures, including Bill and Hillary Clinton, was indicted for sexually abusing scores of underage girls in 2007. However, with the help of high-profile lawyers such as Ken Starr, Jay Lefkowitz, and Alan Dershowitz, Epstein negotiated a 13-month sentence with former U.S. Attorney and later Trump Labor Secretary Alex Acosta.

The Epstein case serves as a stark reminder of the growing chasm between our society's elites and the rest of us. If the super-wealthy and super-connected can get away with raping young girls with almost no punishment, our system is clearly broken.

After the video was released, Robach issued a statement, saying her comments were a "private moment of frustration." ABC claimed they didn't run the interview because they "could not obtain sufficient corroborating evidence to meet ABC's editorial standards about her allegations."

However, ABC's claims that the story didn't run because of a lack of "corroborating evidence" are hard to accept, given that the same network ran outlandish and uncorroborated reports about Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, peddled at the time by now-disgraced Democratic activist and lawyer Michael Avenatti. There's no explanation for such disparate treatment besides pure bias.

There is one further explanation: politically partisan bias. Avenatti's claims were made against Kavanaugh, a Republican. The claims against Epstein potentially implicated former President Bill Clinton. ABC's lead news anchor is George Stephanopoulos, Bill Clinton's former staffer.

CBS News, MSNBC, and CNN have largely ignored the Robach video. ABC, in addition to their clearly bogus statement, responded by searching for the whistleblower who released the video. Reports indicate that ABC found the whistleblower was working at CBS, and CBS followed up by firing the whistleblower.

Taken together, we have all three major U.S. television broadcast networks implicated to some degree in covering for rapists. NBC, in Farrow's new book, is accused of killing his report on alleged rapist Weinstein, another Clinton confidant. ABC anchor Robach is claiming that ABC News killed her report on alleged child rapist Epstein. And CBS News has now fired the woman who released the Robach video.

A recent Gallup poll found that 69% of Americans have lost trust in the news media over the past decade. Based on these sordid events of the past couple of months, that number may now be closer to 100%.

Title: President Trump Expresses Optimism Over North Korea's Nuclear Disarmament Following Historic Summit with Kim Jong Un

Article:

In the aftermath of his groundbreaking summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, President Donald Trump expressed optimism that the North Korean leader will initiate the process of dismantling his country's nuclear program "virtually immediately." The historic agreement, signed in Singapore, outlines Pyongyang's commitment to work toward the "complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula."

During an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity, Trump stated, "We are now going to start the process of denuclearization of North Korea, and I believe that he's [Kim Jong Un] going to start it virtually immediately – and he's already indicated that, and you look at what he's done."

The agreement was the culmination of several meetings between the two leaders throughout the day. When asked by a reporter if Kim had agreed to denuclearize, Trump responded, "We are starting that process very quickly."

At a press conference, Trump announced that he will be ending joint military exercises between the United States and South Korea. He also stated that Kim had agreed to destroy a "major" missile testing site, although specific details were not provided.

The joint declaration states that the U.S. has committed to providing "security guarantees" to Pyongyang. The extent of these guarantees remains unclear, but Trump sounded optimistic as he left the summit, stating that the two leaders "got along from the beginning" and Kim understood the need to dismantle his nuclear program.

The summit, which almost did not occur, marked a significant shift from the tension between Washington and Pyongyang last summer, when Trump and Kim exchanged a war of words, with the American president warning the dictator of "fire and fury." However, Trump told Fox News that "without the rhetoric, we wouldn't have been here."

As for the future, Trump insisted, "I think he's [Kim] gone back to get this done. He wants to get it done." During a gaggle with reporters on Air Force One later in the day, Trump said he trusts Kim but emphasized that the U.S. would have to "check" to ensure denuclearization occurs. "We're going to have to check him. And we will check him very strongly," Trump said. "He has a plan total and complete, he's got a total plan. It will get done."

When asked whether he had any concerns about Kim, the president insisted Kim "wants to get it done." He added, "And we should all want that to happen."

Title: GOP Presidential Candidate Ben Carson Defends Flat Tax Plan, Discusses Foreign Policy and Controversial Remarks

In a recent interview on Fox News Sunday, Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson defended his proposed flat tax plan, stating that it is "condescending" to suggest that poor people cannot pay taxes. The 63-year-old Carson, who grew up poor in Detroit before becoming a renowned pediatric neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins University, argued that his plan, which he refers to as a "proportional tax," is fair and based on the biblical concept of tithing.

Under Carson's plan, individuals making $10 billion a year would pay $1 billion in taxes, while those making as little as $100 would pay $1. He argued that this would make it more difficult for politicians to raise taxes since they would be raised on everyone. However, host Chris Wallace countered that experts suggest a flat tax rate of 20% would be necessary to match current revenue, which would result in low- and middle-income families facing a tax hike while the wealthy would see a tax cut. Carson disputed these numbers, stating that his numbers are closer to 10-15%.

Carson also discussed his foreign policy, particularly his stance on Russia. When asked if "all options" should remain open for dealing with Russia, Carson replied, "All options includes all options." He clarified that this does not mean war would be his first option, but that he would deal with Ukraine differently than President Barack Obama has. Carson pointed out that Ukraine gave up its nuclear weapons on the promise of defense from the United States and other Western powers, and he suggested that a military option may be necessary if Russia invades again.

Carson also addressed two controversial statements he has made in the past. In a 2014 interview with Breitbart.com, Carson stated that Americans feel intimidated by their own government and compared modern America to Nazi Germany. In a 2013 speech, Carson compared Obamacare to slavery. Carson defended these statements on Sunday, arguing that Obamacare fundamentally changes the relationship between the people and the government and that Americans feel intimidated by the government due to the threat of IRS audits and other repercussions.

Finally, Carson was asked about his statement last week that, as president, he would not have to enforce "judicial law." Carson clarified on Sunday that the president or the executive branch is obligated to carry out the laws of the land, according to the Constitution. He pointed to the Supreme Court's Dred Scott decision, which disallowed slaves to sue for their freedom, as an example of a judicial decision with which he disagreed. Carson stated that the laws of the land, according to the Constitution, are provided by the legislative branch.

Title: Bipartisan Dispute Erupts Over Trump Administration's Decision to End ObamaCare Subsidies

Article:

A legal battle has ensued between the Democratic attorneys general from 18 states and the District of Columbia, and the Trump administration, following the White House's decision to end payments to health insurers under the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare). The lawsuit, filed in federal court in California, alleges that the president's move to halt the payments is an attempt to undermine the health and well-being of the nation.

The states involved in the lawsuit include California, Connecticut, Delaware, Kentucky, Illinois, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, Virginia, and Washington. They are seeking the court's intervention to compel the Trump administration to make the next payment to insurers, scheduled for October 18.

In a separate court case, the Justice Department notified a federal appeals court in Washington on Friday that the payment "would not occur." A federal judge has previously found that Congress never properly approved the payments, which have continued under Obama and Trump until now, despite prior threats by the president to block them.

The subsidies, amounting to approximately $7 billion this year, are used by companies to lower out-of-pocket costs like co-payments and deductibles for low- and middle-income customers. Congressional Democrats have vowed to push for a bipartisan deal to restore the money by the end of the year.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi denounced Trump's move to end the payments as a "spiteful act of vast, pointless sabotage leveled at working families and the middle class in every corner of America."

President Trump, speaking at the Values Voter Summit, defended his decision, stating, "Congress, they forgot what their pledges were." He added, "So we're going a little different route. But you know what? In the end, it's going to be just as effective, and maybe it will even be better."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., has expressed openness to continuing the payments, provided they are accompanied by significant changes. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, R-Texas, has also supported the continuation of the payments, citing their impact on premiums.

The decision is part of Trump's broader effort to "repeal and replace" ObamaCare, and is expected to cause instability in already-unsteady insurance marketplaces. The legal and political battle over the payments is likely to continue, with both parties seeking a resolution that addresses the needs of their constituents.

Title: Senate Leaders Negotiate Government Reopening and Debt Ceiling Deal, but Hurdles Remain

Article:

In a significant development, Senate leaders have outlined a potential deal to end the two-week-old government shutdown and provide the Treasury Department with enough borrowing room to avoid a potential default this month. However, the specifics of the agreement are still under negotiation, and all sides have cautioned that the deal is far from finalized.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) and his Republican counterpart, Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY), have agreed on the broad strokes of the deal. The government would be funded for several months, and President Obama would be given room to raise the debt ceiling into next year. The House and Senate would appoint negotiators to try to reach a broader budget deal in the meantime.

However, the exact dates of the debt and spending extensions, and the add-ons, such as delays or restrictions on Obamacare, are still under negotiation, aides said. The length of the stopgap funding bill, the amount of borrowing authority to give the Treasury Department, and the specific changes to Obamacare are all points of contention.

Even if Mr. Reid and Mr. McConnell are able to strike a deal, it's unclear whether it could pass the GOP-controlled House, where conservatives have expressed skepticism. "When you're giving 98, 99 percent of Obamacare, I don't see how that would ever pass over here, if indeed it passes the Senate," said Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R-KS).

The mere prospects of a deal that would give the government more room to expand its $16.7 trillion debt sent the stock markets higher on Monday. President Obama had asked the top party leaders to come to the White House for talks on Monday afternoon but canceled the meeting, saying it made more sense to give Mr. Reid and Mr. McConnell space to work.

For his part, the president visited a local food bank, Martha's Table, where some furloughed federal workers were helping out. Mr. Obama said "some progress" had been made, but he cautioned that "we'll see if the progress is real."

The Treasury Department has said it will run out of borrowing room on Thursday, leaving it with only cash on hand to pay bills. That could last a couple of weeks, or it could be exhausted almost immediately, analysts said. If a deal is not reached, the consequences could be severe, with the potential for a devastating effect on the economy.

The White House has been insistent that the government reopen and the debt be raised without any conditions, repeatedly comparing Republican demands on Obamacare to hostage-taking and terrorism. House Republicans remain a major hurdle, and conservatives have expressed concern about the lack of Obamacare-related concessions in the deal.

As the negotiations continue, both party leaders are discussing strategy, such as which chamber should go first and how many House Democrats would be needed to pass the deal there. The fate of the deal remains uncertain, but all sides are working towards a resolution to end the shutdown and avoid a default.

Title: A Reflection on National Unity and Identity Politics in the 21st Century

Article:

In the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, the United States witnessed a surge of national unity and camaraderie that was unprecedented. However, as the years have passed, the question remains: Where has the spirit of unity gone, and what has replaced it?

In an article by William Murchison, he suggests that in 2001, under the threat of a global enemy, Americans found and asserted their American identity. The events of 9/11 brought people together, and the nation came together in the interest of punishing the perpetrators. The unity, however, did not last, and the country has since become a series of subdivisions, with group identity taking precedence over national identity.

Murchison argues that identity politics has become the new brand of politics, with each group asserting its demands over the needs and rights of others.
