He notes that while the United States has always had its share of divisions, the indisposition to cut slack for anyone besides ourselves is the main and most frightening feature of today's politics.

Murchison also points out that the American ideal of freedom to pursue legitimate interests is being challenged by those who view themselves as uniquely deserving or put-upon. The president's war on free trade, the elimination of Confederate monuments, and the secularist's airbrushing of Christianity from the American canvas are all examples of this trend.

Murchison is currently writing a book about moral restoration in the 21st century, and his article serves as a call to reevaluate the state of national unity and identity politics in the United States. He urges readers to remember the spirit of unity that marked the aftermath of 9/11 and to work towards a more accommodating and inclusive society, where the needs and rights of all constituencies are considered.

Title: Post-Republican National Convention: Analyzing Mitt Romney's Poll Bounce and Image Improvement

Article:

Following the conclusion of the Republican National Convention, there appears to be a slight poll bounce for Mitt Romney, but the overall race remains tight. The convention seems to have improved Romney's image, particularly his likeability, according to various polls.

According to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday, Romney's overall favorability improved, but there was no significant change in the number of voters who would cast their ballot for him. The poll showed Romney steadily improving in likeability and other positive-image features.

Rasmussen Reports' data showed a six-point swing in Romney's favor following the Republican National Convention. Prior to the convention, Romney trailed President Barack Obama by two points, but now holds a four-point lead. This poll also showed Romney surging ahead by two points in 11 key swing states.

Gallup's data, published prior to the Tampa convention, indicated that the GOP had slightly bolstered its image compared to 2008, while Democrats' favorability has dropped significantly over the same period.

The information is relevant as it informs the composition of the 2012 electorate and predicts the election's outcome. The Rasmussen Report's 37.6 percent GOP self-identification number should be kept in mind when interpreting polls that peg the Republican segment of the electorate in the mid-twenties.

An update on a snap poll of Florida voters also bodes well for Romney, suggesting a potential advantage in a crucial swing state. However, it is important to note that holiday weekend polling is notoriously unreliable.

Overall, while the polls show a slight improvement for Romney, the race remains tight, and both candidates have work to do to secure the support of undecided voters.

Title: Evolution of Abortion Stances: A Comparative Analysis of Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg's Responses

Article:

In the ongoing debate on abortion rights, two Democratic presidential candidates, Bernie Sanders and Pete Buttigieg, have recently offered their perspectives on the issue during town hall events.

During an MSNBC town hall on February 4, 2020, in Manchester, N.H., Senator Bernie Sanders was asked, "Is there such a thing as a pro-life Democrat in your vision of the party?" Sanders responded, "I think being pro-choice is an absolutely essential part of being a Democrat... When we talk about what a Democrat is, I think being pro-choice is an essential part of that."

This stance represents a shift from Sanders' position in 2017, when he campaigned for Heath Mello, an Omaha, Neb., mayoral candidate who was labeled "anti-abortion" for supporting a bill that required doctors to inform women of their ultrasound rights. However, it's essential to note that the bill did not mandate women to undergo an ultrasound.

In contrast, during a Fox News town hall, Pete Buttigieg was asked, "Do you want the support of... pro-life Democratic voters?... If so, would you support more-moderate platform language in the Democratic party to ensure that the party of diversity, of inclusion really does include everybody?" Buttigieg responded evasively, stating, "The best I can offer is that if we can't agree on where to draw the line, the next best thing we can do is agree on who should draw the line. And in my view, it's the woman who's faced with that decision in her own life."

The abortion debate is complex, and both candidates' responses highlight different approaches to the issue. Sanders' stance is clear, emphasizing the importance of choice, while Buttigieg's response was more equivocal, focusing on personal autonomy and the role of the individual in drawing the line.

It is noteworthy that both candidates have been questioned about their stance on pro-life Democrats, and their responses have been met with varying degrees of directness. Sanders' response can be seen as a step towards transparency, while Buttigieg's response, though evasive, may reflect a more nuanced understanding of the issue.

As the primary race continues, the abortion debate will likely remain a contentious issue, and the candidates' responses will continue to shape the discourse surrounding reproductive rights.

Title: Obama Campaign Outspends Romney in June, but Faces Challenges in Polls and Favorability Ratings

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Barack Obama's re-election campaign outspent Mitt Romney's in June, despite Romney's fundraising advantage, according to campaign reports filed with the Federal Election Commission. The Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee spent $70.8 million in June, while Romney and the Republican National Committee spent $38.8 million.

The Obama campaign reported more than $46 million in direct contributions in June and total spending of $58 million, leaving them with significantly less cash on hand than Romney and the Republicans. The Obama campaign spent about $38 million on television advertising in June, while Romney and the Republican National Committee spent about $11 million.

However, the spending advantage may not translate into electoral success, as recent polls show a tight race between the two candidates. In the head-to-head race, Romney holds a statistically-insignificant 47 to 46 percent lead in the new New York Times/CBS poll, and Obama is stuck at 47 percent in recent polls by Fox News and NPR.

More troubling for the Obama campaign is the worsening economic news and the public's perception of the president's handling of the economy. In the CBS/NYT poll, Obama's job approval dropped to 44 percent, with only 39 percent approving of his economic performance -- down five points from April. For the first time since January, more voters now think the economy is getting worse.

Another red flag for Team Obama is the president's crumbling favorability ratings, a troubling departure from his previous strength. In the CBS/NYT poll, Obama is underwater on the favorability question by double digits, with more Americans developing a poor overall perception of Obama the man, independent from their misgivings about his leadership. Obama's favorability with independents is 28/52, with Romney actually above water at 32/31.

The media should be asking whether Obama's Bain attacks are hurting Obama rather than focusing on the impact on Romney. I'll leave you with this related nugget, reported by the Weekly Standard over the weekend. Remember The One's big May re-elect kickoff event in Columbus? His campaign spent nearly $93,000 to rent a large arena -- and ended up with thousands of empty seats. Hyped expectations, disappointing results, huge expenditures, and resulting deficits. Sound familiar?

Title: International Sanctions on Iran Lifted as IAEA Verifies Compliance with Nuclear Deal

Article:

Following the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) confirmation that Iran has complied with the terms of the nuclear deal, international sanctions on Iran have been lifted. The move, which was announced by EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini, is expected to contribute to improved regional and international peace and security.

The landmark deal, agreed upon last July, aims to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons. The lifting of sanctions will unfreeze billions of dollars of assets and allow Iran's oil to be sold internationally. The IAEA confirmed that Iran had taken the necessary steps, including reducing its number of centrifuges and dismantling a heavy-water reactor near the town of Arak, both of which could be used in creating nuclear weapons.

Iran has maintained that its nuclear program is peaceful, but some, such as US Republicans, argue that the deal does not do enough to ensure Iran cannot develop a nuclear bomb. US Secretary of State John Kerry has ordered that US nuclear-related economic sanctions against Iran be lifted.

In a statement, US Republican House Speaker Paul Ryan expressed concern, stating, "Today, the Obama administration will begin lifting economic sanctions on the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other opponents of the deal have also expressed skepticism.

In a significant development, Iran has released Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian and three other Iranian-American prisoners in an apparent prisoner swap with the United States. Rezaian, 39, was jailed on charges including espionage last November. The US is offering clemency to seven Iranians being held in the US for sanctions violation.

The IAEA has installed a device at the Natanz plant to monitor Iran's uranium enrichment activities in real time, in order to verify that uranium enrichment levels are kept at up to 3.67% as agreed in the deal with world powers. The organization's head, Yukiya Amano, is to visit Tehran on Sunday for meetings with President Rouhani and other officials.

The deal, which was agreed upon in July 2015, limits Iran's sensitive nuclear activities for more than a decade in return for the lifting of crippling sanctions. The US is confident the agreement will prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. Iran asserts it has the right to nuclear energy and stresses that its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes only. The sanctions have cost Iran more than $160bn in oil revenue since 2012 alone. Once they are lifted, the country will be able to resume selling oil on international markets and using the global financial system for trade. Iran has the fourth-largest oil reserves in the world, and the energy industry is braced for lower prices. Iran will also be able to access more than $100bn in assets frozen overseas.

Title: Biden Challenges Perception of Democratic Party Shift, Critiques Progressive Wing in Interview

Article:

In an interview with Axios, set to air this weekend on HBO, former Vice President Joe Biden has taken aim at the progressive wing of the Democratic Party, particularly Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) and other newly elected progressive Democrats. Biden suggested that these politicians do not represent the future of the Democratic Party as much as they represent a new party, distinct from the traditional Democratic apparatus.

During the interview, Biden disputed the notion that the rise of progressive Democrats and "Democratic socialists" was a response to Hillary Clinton's loss to President Donald Trump in 2016. Biden claimed that the media's portrayal of the Democratic electorate as more liberal and left-leaning is inaccurate, according to Axios.

"You guys got it all wrong about what happened," Biden said, implying that the media has misrepresented the Democratic voter base. "It's just bad judgment... AOC was a new party, she's a bright, wonderful person. But where's the party? Come on, man."

Biden told "Axios on HBO" that he believes his rivals for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination are misinterpreting the party, and that Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) and Bernie Sanders (I-VT) appeal to a narrow segment of voters who are more vocal but do not represent the Democratic electorate as a whole.

"The party's not there. The party's not there at all," Biden said, referring to where Warren and Sanders fall on the political spectrum. He reportedly added that he believes both Warren and Sanders have misread Democratic voters and are appealing to the wrong segment of primary voters.

Biden's comments are not a departure from his long-held belief that he is a more moderate choice for the Democratic nominee. However, this is a significant development in that Biden has directly called out the progressive left wing of the party, including Ocasio-Cortez and the "Squad," and suggested that they are a small segment of a larger Democratic party and not the future of the party as Ocasio-Cortez and her Justice Democrats claim.

While Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez seem to represent a static element of the Democratic Party, both Sanders and Warren are vying for the same group of potential primary voters - mostly young, white, highly educated voters in urban centers. However, until now, most of the candidates targeting the middle, such as Biden and South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg, have resisted the urge to suggest the progressive left is not part of the party.

The good news for Biden is that his newfound opposition to a leftward moving party may play well with voters in early primary states like Iowa, South Carolina, and Nevada, where progressive ideas, like Medicare for All, do not seem to be resonating with voters.

Title: Obama Urges House to Approve Comprehensive Immigration Reform, Citing Unfairness of Current System

Article:

In an effort to advance his second-term agenda, President Barack Obama has called on House lawmakers to approve comprehensive immigration reform, stating that the current system is "not fair."

Addressing supporters of immigration reform in the East Room of the White House on Thursday, the President said, "We have kicked this particular can down the road for too long." He emphasized, "This is the moment when we should be able to finally get the job done. Let's go get it done."

House Republican leaders have indicated they plan to hold an immigration debate this year, but they are unlikely to support the comprehensive reform bill passed by the Senate. With a short legislative calendar following a 16-day government shutdown, President Obama faces challenges in getting his priorities acted upon this year.

The President endorsed the Senate bill, which provides a pathway to citizenship for an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants, arguing that it would benefit the economy and the country. He urged Republican leaders to disregard the political implications of the issue.

"I'm not running for office again; I just believe this is the right thing to do," Mr. Obama said. "What we can't do is just sweep the problem under the rug one more time. Let's not delay, and let's do it in a bipartisan fashion."

Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, has expressed opposition to the President's wishes, according to his spokesman, Brendan Buck. Buck stated, "The speaker agrees that America has a broken immigration system and we need reform that would boost our economy. He's also been clear that the House will not consider any massive, Obamacare-style legislation that no one understands."

Instead, the House is committed to a step-by-step approach to immigration reform, according to Buck. He added, "We hope that the president will work with us — not against us — as we pursue this deliberate approach."

Title: MIT Media Lab Director Resigns Amid Epstein Donation Scandal

In a significant development, the director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's (MIT) Media Lab, Joi Ito, has resigned effective immediately, following the revelation of the lab's attempts to conceal its relationship with the late financier Jeffrey Epstein. The resignation came less than a day after an article in The New Yorker detailed the Media Lab's handling of donations from Epstein, including a $2 million gift from Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates.

According to internal emails obtained by The New York Times, in October 2014, six years after Epstein pleaded guilty to a sex charge involving a minor in Florida, Ito wrote that the gift from Gates had been "directed by Jeffrey Epstein." A development official at the Media Lab, Peter Cohen, subsequently wrote, "For gift recording purposes, we will not be mentioning Jeffrey’s name as the impetus for this gift."

In a statement, a spokesperson for Gates said Epstein had been introduced to Gates as a person interested in increasing philanthropy. The statement also clarified that Epstein had not directed any programmatic or personal grant-making for Gates, and any claim to the contrary was false.

The resignation of Ito is part of a growing list of powerful individuals facing scrutiny for their connections to Epstein. This list includes President Donald Trump, former President Bill Clinton, Britain's Prince Andrew, high-profile scientists, business executives, and former U.S. Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta, who resigned after his role in the 2008 plea agreement with Epstein was heavily criticized.

The Media Lab, a research institution that focuses on science, technology, and art, has been under fire for its association with Epstein, who donated millions to the lab over the years. The lab's relationship with Epstein has raised questions about the ethical standards of the institution and its leadership. The resignation of Ito marks a significant step towards addressing these concerns and restoring public trust in the Media Lab.

Title: COVID-19 Patients Face Mental Health Challenges Amid Hospital Isolation

Article:

The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has brought about a new challenge for some survivors: mental health issues stemming from hospital isolation. With many hospitals requiring adult patients to enter without family, the stress, loneliness, and fear experienced by patients, often magnified by invasive treatment procedures, place them at a high risk for disorders such as PTSD, according to some medical experts.

Loneliness, a combination of thinking, feeling, and behaving, can have a significant impact on psychological and physical health, says Ami Rokach, a clinical psychologist and psychology teacher at York University in Toronto. While there are indications that people's resilience and increased use of communication technology may be helping lessen the broader impact of the pandemic on loneliness, the situation is different for COVID-19 patients.

Not only is it stressful to be diagnosed with a new disease with minimal treatment options, but the virus itself can affect the brain, including psychiatric and neurological complications. Being alone through the prolonged treatment process can be "heart-wrenching" to watch, says Martha A.Q. Curley, a professor of pediatric nursing at the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing.

"You have people who've lived 50, 60, 70 years together and they can't be with them when they're ill, they can't transition through the illness with them, and they can't be there when they die. [It] is just excruciatingly painful," Curley says.

Some COVID-19 survivors may experience PTSD, which can last for years without treatment. Most people feel anxiety with the uncertainty of COVID-19, but some experience PTSD due to trauma and a "threat to life or threat to physical integrity," says Anthony King, a professor of psychiatry and psychology at the University of Michigan.

"Clearly, the coronavirus disease is a threat to life," and the chance someone may experience PTSD may be exacerbated by patient isolation while fighting the disease, King says while cautioning further research is needed into anecdotal evidence. Long-term studies of past serious outbreaks found PTSD is much higher in patients than in the general population.

In one study, one-fourth of 90 SARS patients had PTSD 30 months after the outbreak, and 15.6% had a depressive disorder. Research has shown many ICU survivors experience trauma, particularly with procedures like intubation. Reports of post-intensive care syndrome are growing after patients with COVID-19 are discharged, which can be further complicated by the fact that family members do not know what the patient went through.

Four doctors argue in a New England Journal of Medicine perspective piece that new guidelines should enable more regular telecommunication between isolated patients and their families. Curley, who is also a pediatric nurse at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, goes one step further and suggests steps can be taken to safely allow a family member into the ICU with a COVID-19 patient. Family facilitators can help with the careful screening, preparation, and support needed to undertake this goal, she says.

"We need to think of ways to make this happen. It will be different within each system, it will be different with each patient, but we ought to not just create a rule that families are not allowed," Curley adds.

Isolated and faced with uncertainty and fear, some COVID-19 patients are at risk for trauma that experts say should be screened for and addressed at all stages of healthcare.

Title: Democratic Primary Results Declare Hillary Clinton as Nominee, While Bernie Sanders Pushes for Change in Party's Stance on Israel

Article:

In a decisive move, the news media has declared Hillary Clinton the winner of Tuesday's Democratic presidential primaries, with the former secretary of state reaching the 2,383 delegates needed to secure her party's nomination. The announcement comes before the primaries in the six states set to vote Tuesday, including California, the largest.

Clinton, in a speech to her supporters, expressed her gratitude and emphasized the importance of voter participation, stating, "We're going to come out of the primary even stronger to take on Donald Trump."

Meanwhile, Bernie Sanders' campaign has accused the media of rushing to judgment, with spokesperson Michael Briggs stating, "It is wrong to count the votes of superdelegates before they actually vote at the convention this summer. Secretary Clinton does not have and will not have the requisite number of pledged delegates to secure the nomination."

The superdelegates will not vote until July 25, and Sanders has vowed to spend the time until then convincing them that he is the stronger candidate. Although Sanders' campaign may be winding down, he has left a significant impact on the Democratic Party, pushing it to the left on economic issues and attempting to change the party's platform on Israel.

Sanders has already named pro-Palestinian representatives to the platform committee, including those who support the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement. The movement aims to delegitimize the Jewish state. Pro-Israel Democrats argue that changes in the party's platform regarding Israel would be met with resistance.

However, recent data from the Pew Research Center suggests a shift in the sympathies of liberal Democrats. For the first time in a decade, the percentage of liberal Democrats sympathizing with Palestinians is greater than those aligning with Israel. This division could potentially lead to a contentious fight at the Democratic National Convention over the party's support.

Even without a fight at the convention, the split could indicate a future shift in Democratic support, potentially moving the party towards more support for Palestinians and less for Israel. This development underscores the ongoing complexities and evolving dynamics within the Democratic Party.

Title: Seaside Town Trapped in Apocalyptic Conditions as Australia Wildfires Rage On

PERTH, Australia (AP) — Wildfires burning across Australia's two most populous states trapped residents of the seaside town of Mallacoota in Victoria state in apocalyptic conditions on Tuesday, with at least two people confirmed dead and numerous homes destroyed.

About 4,000 residents in the southeastern town fled toward the water Tuesday morning as winds pushed an emergency-level wildfire toward their homes. The smoke-filled sky shrouded the town in darkness before turning an unnerving shade of bright red.

Australia's annual wildfire season, which peaks during the Southern Hemisphere summer, started early after an unusually warm and dry winter. Record-breaking heat and windy conditions triggered devastating wildfires in New South Wales and Queensland states in September.

Over the past few months, about 5 million hectares (12.35 million acres) of land have burned nationwide, with 12 people confirmed dead and more than 1,000 homes destroyed. Nearly 100 fires were burning across the state of New South Wales, which is home to Sydney.

New South Wales state Rural Fire Services Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons described this wildfire season as the worst on record and painted a bleak long-term picture.

"We've seen extraordinary fire behavior," he said Tuesday. "What we really need is meaningful rain, and we haven't got anything in the forecast at the moment that says we're going to get drought-breaking or fire-quenching rainfall."

The wildfire crisis has reignited debate about whether Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative government has taken enough action on climate change. Australia is the world's largest exporter of coal and liquefied natural gas.

Morrison, whom critics have deemed a climate change skeptic, conceded earlier this month that "climate change along with many other factors" has contributed to the wildfires.

The prime minister faced criticism for going on a family vacation to Hawaii in December during the crisis. He eventually cut his trip short and publicly apologized.

Late Tuesday, Mallacoota was saved by changes in wind direction, but authorities said "numerous" homes were lost. Residents returning home were urged to boil tap water before drinking it. Forest Fire Management Victoria said the wildfires had put heavy demands on tap water that is affecting the supply of water.

Stranded residents and vacationers were reported to be sleeping in cars on New Year's Eve, while gas stations and surf clubs transformed into evacuation areas.

Victoria state Premier Daniel Andrews had earlier announced plans to evacuate the trapped people by sea. There were grave fears for four missing people. "We can't confirm their whereabouts," Andrews told reporters Tuesday.

Andrews has requested assistance from 70 firefighters from the United States and Canada, while Australia's military sent air and sea reinforcements.

Victoria Emergency Services Commissioner Andrew Crisp confirmed "significant" property losses across the region. More than 115 communities across Victoria remained under emergency warnings Tuesday night.

Some communities canceled New Year's fireworks celebrations, but Sydney's popular display over its iconic harbor controversially went ahead in front of more than a million revelers. The city was granted an exemption to a total fireworks ban in place there and elsewhere to prevent new wildfires.

Fire conditions in Victoria and New South Wales worsened after oppressive heat Monday mixed with strong winds and lightning.

Police in New South Wales said Tuesday that two men — a 63-year-old father and 29-year-old son — died in a house in the wildfire-ravaged southeast town of Cobargo, and a 72-year-old man remained missing.

"They were obviously trying to do their best with the fire as it came through in the early hours of the morning," New South Wales Police Deputy Commissioner Gary Worboys said. "The other person that we are trying to get to, we think that person was trying to defend their property in the early hours of the morning."

On Monday, a firefighter was killed when extreme winds flipped his truck. Samuel McPaul, 28, was the third volunteer firefighter in New South Wales to have died in the past two weeks. He was an expectant father.

More than 130 fires remain burning across New South Wales, with five at an emergency level. Authorities warned that power would be out for 24 hours along the fire-ravaged south coast of the state.

Title: Anticipation Builds as Biden and Ryan Prepare for High-Stakes Vice Presidential Debate

Article:

As the clock ticks down to the vice presidential debate tonight in Danville, Kentucky, both parties are gearing up for a showdown that promises to be a significant event in the 2012 presidential race. The debate, which will pit Vice President Joe Biden against Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan, is expected to draw widespread attention and serve as a crucial precursor to the second presidential debate on Tuesday in New York.

The stakes are particularly high for Vice President Biden, following President Barack Obama's perceived lackluster performance in the first presidential debate, which saw Mitt Romney take a lead in national polls. Republicans have been eagerly anticipating this confrontation for months, believing that Ryan, the intellectual powerhouse of the GOP ticket, can expose any potential gaffes from the gaffe-prone Biden.

"It's the man with the 200-pound brain vs. Crazy Uncle Joe," says Ed Goeas, a Republican pollster. Democrats, on the other hand, believe Biden will come well-prepared and use the debate to expose what they see as the duplicity of the Romney-Ryan ticket, which has appeared to shift positions on issues such as abortion, education, and tax policy in recent days.

Vice presidential debates are often quickly forgotten, but this one is expected to be different. "It will be very substantive, with probably two of the most substantive vice presidential candidates we've ever had," says David Carney, a Republican consultant. "I think Biden's performance, in an ironic way, will put more pressure on [President] Obama for the next debate."

Four years ago, the vice presidential debate between Biden and Republican Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska drew higher TV ratings than any of that year's presidential debates. This debate is also expected to draw considerable attention.

Biden's task tonight is different from what it was four years ago. Then, he essentially ignored Palin in favor of attacking Arizona Sen. John McCain, the GOP nominee. This time, he'll still want to concentrate most of his fire on the other party's presidential candidate, but he will doubtless also use Ryan as a target. As the House Budget Committee chairman, Ryan is the architect of a spending plan that Democrats warn would gut domestic programs and threaten entitlements such as Medicare.

"Where Gov. Romney muddied the water, I think the vice president will try to clarify it," says Jared Bernstein, who served as an economic adviser to Biden in the White House. "He's going to link the political agendas and the policy agendas so the electorate has a much better understanding than they did from the first debate."

Since his selection as running mate, Ryan has served as the loyal soldier, shying away from some of the implications of his own budget and declaring that Romney sets the policy for the ticket. But if Democrats accuse the Republicans of duplicity, Republicans counter that Democrats have mismanaged the economy and do not have a record worth running on and so are relying on scare tactics.

Goeas, the GOP pollster, predicts Ryan will drive home the point that, counter to Democratic claims, the Republican plan would not alter Medicare for those ages 55 and older. Republicans also hope that, under pressure, Biden could once again uncork a comment that takes on a life of its own. As Joel Goldstein, a law professor at Saint Louis University and expert on the vice presidency, points out, one gaffe can undo all the other successful messaging a vice presidential candidate might pull off during a debate.

Last week, Biden attacked the GOP tax plan, but in so doing offered what sounded like a criticism of his own administration by saying the middle class has "been buried the last four years." "He's had a bad run of foot-in-mouth disease," says David Yepsen, director of a public policy institute at Southern Illinois University Carbondale. "He really needs to avoid any of that. Part of getting Democrats back on track is having Joe Biden not make gaffes."

But Biden's gaffes tend to come "from unregulated exuberance on the campaign trail," says Gary Bauer, president of American Values, a conservative group concerned with social issues. He'll presumably be more disciplined on stage during his key moment in the entire campaign.

And Republicans who have anticipated Ryan outmatching the vice president are likely to be disappointed. Biden spent 36 years in the Senate, chairing important committees in charge of both domestic and foreign issues. "Paul Ryan is a wonk at heart—he's the brains of this particular Congress," says Tara McGuinness, executive director of the Center for American Progress Action Fund, the progressive think tank's advocacy wing. "Joe Biden, though very experienced in politics, is a storyteller at heart."

Ryan, who was born two years before Biden was first elected to the Senate, needs to show he has some "gravitas," Yepsen says. Republicans from Romney on down have tried to downplay expectations for Ryan's performance in recent days, pointing out that he has not engaged in a campaign debate since he first ran for Congress 14 years ago.

Ted Kaufman, a longtime Biden aide who succeeded him in the Senate after his ascension to the vice presidency, says Ryan will be ready. "Ryan will do a good job," Kaufman says. "Anyone who has been a member of Congress for 14 years knows how to present their positions well and how to challenge the positions of the other side."

Title: Escalation in Eastern Ukraine: New Offensive and Alleged Russian Military Involvement

Article:

In a significant development, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko convened an emergency security meeting today as pro-Russia rebels launched a new offensive in eastern Ukraine. The escalation comes amid mounting evidence suggesting direct Russian military involvement in the conflict.

The previously unaffected town of Novoazovsk, situated between Russia and the annexed Crimea Peninsula, experienced shelling just hours after a landmark meeting between the Russian and Ukrainian presidents on Tuesday. Pro-Russian rebels reportedly took control of the town on Wednesday, with some Ukrainian forces in retreat. Access to Novoazovsk was denied to Associated Press reporters today by separatists.

The new southeastern front raises concerns that the separatists may be attempting to establish a land link between Russia and Crimea. If successful, this could provide them or Russia control over the entire Sea of Azov and the gas and mineral riches believed to be contained within. Ukraine has already lost approximately half its coastline, several major ports, and significant Black Sea mineral rights following Russia's annexation of Crimea in March.

In Mariupol, a city of 450,000 residents approximately 30 kilometers (20 miles) to the west, a Ukrainian forces brigade arrived at the airport Wednesday afternoon, while deep trenches were dug on the city's edge the previous day.

The BBC reports that the incursion could serve as a means to divert Ukrainian troops from Luhansk and Donetsk, where they have made progress against pro-Russian separatists in recent months.

Ukraine accused Russia this week of supplying heavy weaponry to aid pro-Russian rebels in southern Ukraine. National security spokesman Col. Andriy Lysenko stated that Russian soldiers crossed as far as 30 miles beyond the border in armored personnel carriers and a truck this week.

The prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic admitted today that there are Russian servicemen fighting alongside pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. Alexander Zakharchenko claimed there are between 3,000 and 4,000 Russian volunteers fighting with the rebels. Some of these individuals are reportedly retired Russian military personnel.

Accusations of direct Russian involvement in Ukraine have prompted Western governments to impose sanctions on Russia, despite Moscow's repeated denials. Russia refers to the crisis in Ukraine as a domestic issue that must be resolved internally.

The Obama administration this week accused Russia of moving artillery and air defenses to aid pro-Russia separatists in Ukraine. "These incursions indicate a Russian-directed counteroffensive is likely underway," said Jen Psaki, the State Department spokeswoman. Psaki criticized Russia's "unwillingness to tell the truth" about its military's role in Ukrainian territory.

International leaders, including those from France, Germany, and NATO, have expressed concern. "I think there's a shift here that we may be witnessing, very recently, from largely covert, ambiguous, deniable support to what appears increasingly to be flat-out, overt and obvious [support]," a NATO diplomat told reporters in Brussels on the condition of anonymity.

NATO officials are expected to provide a briefing today on the situation in Ukraine. French President François Hollande stated this week that if Russian soldiers are in Ukraine, "it would be intolerable and unacceptable." German Chancellor Angela Merkel called Russian President Vladimir Putin for clarification on the Kremlin's involvement.

A UN report found that the death toll in eastern Ukraine over the past month reached at least 36 people per day. An estimated 2,200 people have died since the conflict began in April, according to the UN.

Title: "The Tight Presidential Race: A Closer Look at the Obama-Romney Deadlock"

Article:

As the back-to-school season kicks off, the political landscape is heating up with the upcoming presidential election. In a recent poll, 57 percent of likely voters believe America is in decline, yet the race between President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, remains a dead heat. This article delves into the factors contributing to this unexpected tight race.

According to the latest polls, President Obama faces significant challenges in areas such as overall job approval, handling of the economy, and government intervention. By an almost 20-point margin, respondents expressed a preference for the federal government to leave them alone rather than lend a hand. When asked whether it was fair to say Obama wants to make Americans more dependent on the government, 53 percent said yes, while only 44 percent said no.

These numbers paint a grim picture for any incumbent Democrat, particularly one whose major liabilities revolve around spending too much and intervening too much while struggling to revive the economy. However, the race remains close, and the effort to define Romney has been equally successful.

The undecided or those rejecting the major party choices reveal a group of voters who find little to like in either candidate. While Obama suffers a 12-point deficit on personal favorability among these voters, Romney's rating stands at a staggering negative 28 points.

Every re-election campaign is about answering two questions: Do we want to keep the incumbent, and is the challenger a plausible alternative? As we approach the two-week convention kick-off for the fall campaign, it is clear that Obama has failed the first question. With 74 days until the election, there is no way for the president to turn public sentiment in favor of his administration.

The Obama campaign has focused on personal attacks on Romney for nearly five months, with Vice President Joe Biden often saying, "Don't compare us to the almighty, compare us to the alternative." The central emphasis of the Obama campaign has been to make Romney an unacceptable alternative. Yet, despite the relentless attacks, Romney remains competitive.

Respondents in the poll were 6 points less inclined to believe Romney wanted to make the rich richer at the expense of everyone else, a charge that is the ethos of the Obama campaign, than they were the Republican charge that Obama is seeking greater government dependency. The other significant criticism of Romney is that he is more interested in political expedience than principle.

This creates a scenario in which fed-up moderates and independents might declare a pox on both houses and sit out the election. Obama has been seeking a base-versus-base election and his long, negative campaign has helped push people into their respective camps earlier than usual. The president's team believes that the power of incumbency combined with a superior turnout operation will allow them to win a narrow victory.

However, the alarming sign for the blue team is this: The president has failed to close the voter intensity gap for month after month. Romney supporters lead Obama supporters 64 percent to 54 percent on the question of whether it is "extremely important" for their candidate to win. In a tie race, that would mean victory for Romney.

The next week is crucial for both candidates. For Obama, the focus is on energizing his base and getting his voters marching. For Romney, the first step came with his selection of Paul Ryan as his running mate, helping cast Romney as a serious man and a serious fiscal conservative. The effort continues today and through the next week, with Romney aiming to reintroduce himself to a crabby and skeptical electorate. The message will be one of competency, accomplishment, and steadiness. It's not sexy, but it's certainly a plausible presidential pedigree.

Title: Philippines Impounds North Korean Freighter in Response to Global Sanctions Over Nuclear Test and Missile Launch

Article:

In a move that underscores the global community's response to North Korea's recent nuclear test and missile launch, the Philippine government has impounded a North Korean freighter, the Jin Teng, in Subic Bay. The Philippine News Agency reported that the ship's crew will be deported, according to presidential spokesman Manuel Quezon III in a radio interview.

The United Nations Security Council, in a unanimous vote this week, imposed new sanctions on North Korea in response to what it called "violation and flagrant disregard" of previous resolutions. The sanctions mandate that other countries should inspect cargo within or transiting through their territory, including airports, sea ports, and free trade zones, that was destined for or originating from the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

The Jin Teng, operated by Ocean Maritime Management, is one of 31 vessels named in the U.N. resolution as being "subject to the asset freeze." Documents show that all 21 of the Sierra Leone-flagged ship's crew are North Korean nationals.

The freighter arrived in Subic Bay on Thursday from Indonesia with a load of palm kernels, according to state news. Coast guardsmen found minor safety violations during an inspection, such as faulty emergency light bulbs, a lack of fire hoses, corroded air vents, and inadequate accommodations for crew.

A team from the United Nations may also inspect the Jin Teng, according to Quezon. The Philippine government will report its findings to the world body.

Despite these actions, North Korea has continued to escalate its threats, with leader Kim Jong Un stating on Friday that his country's "nuclear warheads need to be ready for use at any time." The rhetoric comes after reports of North Korea testing a new multiple-launch rocket system and "short-range projectiles."

North Korea's nuclear ambitions and missile capabilities have long been a concern for neighboring countries and the international community. There are strong doubts that North Korea currently has the technology to mate a nuclear warhead to a missile that could travel 5,000 miles and hit the U.S. West Coast, but much is still unknown about Pyongyang's military potential.

One anti-nuclear advocate, Philip Yun, executive director of the Ploughshares Fund, believes that much of the talk is intended for internal consumption, to help Kim consolidate power, and is not proof of his military's abilities. "For them to deliver on a threat, they have to have intent and they have to have capability. And quite frankly, I do not think they have both," Yun said.

Title: Former President Obama's Speaking Fee for Milan Climate Change Address Remains Unknown Amidst Speculation

Article:

The speaking fee for former President Barack Obama's upcoming climate change address in Milan remains a mystery, with neither his team nor the hosting organization, Seeds & Chips, disclosing the amount. This secrecy has sparked speculation, with one publication estimating that Obama could potentially receive $3.2 million for the event.

The event, which is a summit on food innovation aimed at addressing climate change, is scheduled for May 8-11. Tickets for the event, priced at 850 euros ($925), have been sold for 3,500 tickets in total. However, this leaves open the question of how much Obama is being paid.

Following the event, The Express updated its initial story, omitting any mention of a speaking fee. Representatives for Obama did not respond to Fox News' request for comment, while Michela Gelati, a spokesperson for Seeds & Chips, stated they did not have the information.

The speculation surrounding Obama's potential payday comes after he drew criticism for two lucrative speaking engagements that seemed to contradict his image as a champion of the 99%. In late April, it was reported that Obama would receive $400,000 for a talk on healthcare at a Wall Street conference run by Cantor Fitzgerald, a major Wall Street firm.

Eric Schultz, a spokesman for Obama, defended the former president, stating, "With regard to this or any speech involving Wall Street sponsors, I'd just point out that in 2008 Barack Obama raised more money from Wall Street than any candidate in history -- and still went on to successfully pass and implement the toughest reforms on Wall Street since FDR."

Obama also reportedly received $400,000 for his appearance at the A&E Networks advertising upfront at The Pierre Hotel in New York City in early April.

While Obama's speaking fees may be common for former presidents, he has faced criticism for allegedly using his tax-exempt Obama Foundation as a money generator. The foundation is in place to raise money for his presidential library, but critics warn that the operation is starting to resemble the controversial Clinton Foundation, which took in tens of millions of dollars and sparked "pay-to-play" accusations.

In an effort to avoid such comparisons, Obama stated in January that he would not accept contributions from for-profit entities, federal lobbyists, foreign nationals or agents while in office.

Despite the criticism, it is not uncommon for former presidents to earn substantial speaking fees after leaving the Oval Office. Harry Truman refused to give speeches for money and called the practice exploitative, but Gerald Ford, the first president known to take advantage of the speaking circuit after leaving office, earned as much as $40,000 per speech after leaving office in 1977. Bill Clinton, who normally charges between $250,000 and $500,000 per engagement, was paid a whopping $750,000 to give a talk in Hong Kong in 2011, while George W. Bush has reportedly made between $20 million and $35 million in speaking fees since leaving office in 2009. Shortly after leaving office in 1989, Ronald Reagan was paid around $2 million to go on a speaking tour of Japan.

Title: Harry Reid Plots 2016 Reelection Bid Amidst Republican Eagerness for 2016 Elections

Article:

In an interview last week, the 73-year-old Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, declared his intention to run for reelection in 2016. The Nevada Senator, who has been a target of Republican ire for his inflammatory rhetoric and hardball tactics during the government shutdown, is reportedly ramping up his campaign organization and preparing for the anticipated GOP onslaught.

Reid's plans for the 2016 elections are more than three years away, but he is already seeking commitments from aides to stay with him through that year. He is spending more time fundraising, from New York to Southern California, and has issued a warning to potential GOP opponent, Governor Brian Sandoval of Nevada, who may run midterm if reelected next year.

Reid's polarizing stance during the shutdown fight has kept Democrats together, a challenging feat. Removing him from his position as the powerful majority leader has become a leading Republican campaign pitch in the run-up to the 2014 midterms. However, whether Reid is simply posturing to avoid being viewed as a lame duck remains to be seen. He could ultimately change his mind and decide not to run for a sixth term, or his calculus could change if Republicans regain control of the Senate in 2014 and he loses the majority leader title, which he has held for more than six years.

Reid is optimistic about Democrats' prospects in 2014, even believing the party may gain seats next year. He attributes the Republicans' handling of the government shutdown as weakening the GOP. When asked if he was bluffing about running in 2016, Reid responded, "I guarantee you that I haven't spent all that money [just] to show strength during the shutdown. To have a campaign operation that I have is not easy."

Reid's fundraising efforts have been successful, with his campaign and political action committee account raising over $600,000 in the third quarter, more than the $407,000 it pulled in during a similar period in 2010. At a similar point in the last cycle, Reid had raised $5.5 million, compared to the $5.6 million he had raised at the same time in 2010.

Reid's reputation as a polarizing figure has grown due to his constant derision of the Republican party, using words like "extreme" and "anarchists" to describe conservative Republicans in the House and Senate. He has been criticized for his tactics during the shutdown fight, which have further solidified his status as the GOP's scourge.

Reid's refusal to negotiate with Republicans until they agree to pass a Senate bill to keep the government open until mid-November, and his refusal to schedule votes on House GOP bills to fund popular agencies and programs one at a time, have been met with frustration from the GOP.

Representative Tom Rooney (R-Fla.) described Reid as "the most uncompromising politician I've encountered in the past five years. He's the guy more than anybody that thwarts progress." When asked about his rhetoric, Reid seemed to acknowledge his reputation for gaffes but was unapologetic about his tough talk.

Title: U.S. Job Market Shows Strongest Growth in Two Years, Yet Unemployment Rate Decreases Due to Labor Force Exit

Article:

The U.S. job market demonstrated its strongest growth in two years in April, with the addition of 288,000 jobs, according to the Department of Labor's report released on Friday. This figure surpassed economists' predictions, causing stocks to rise, albeit temporarily, before falling back. The unemployment rate decreased to 6.3%, down from 6.7% in March.

The severe winter weather had previously impeded various economic indicators, including the housing market, retail sales, and manufacturing. However, the jobs numbers for February and March were revised higher, indicating that the economy has moved past the winter slump.

Despite the lower unemployment rate, the labor force participation rate tells a more discouraging story. The rate, derived from a survey of households, shows a decrease in the number of Americans joining the labor force and a decrease in the number reporting employment. This decrease in participation is not due to discouraged workers leaving the labor force, according to a Department of Labor spokesperson, but rather to fewer young people entering the job market for the first time and more seniors retiring and staying retired.

This trend could indicate a decrease in the number of young people entering the job market and an increase in the number of seniors retiring. Additionally, participation also fell among the prime working-age population, which is a concerning sign, according to Diane Swonk, chief economist for Mesirow Financial.

Economists caution against reading too much into a single month's data. The overall picture remains the same. As Jason Furman, top economic adviser to President Obama, wrote in a White House blog post, "The employment data can fluctuate from month to month, and while this month's report happens to be above expectations, it is still broadly consistent with the recent trends we have been seeing in the labor market."

Given the millions of jobs lost during the financial crisis, even solid hiring is not enough to quickly re-employ the vast number of unemployed Americans. The jobs recovery has been ongoing for four years, and long-term unemployment remains elevated, with 3.5 million people out of work for six months or more. Economists estimate that it could take at least another two years until the job market returns to its pre-recession health, when the unemployment rate was around 4% to 5%.

The positive aspect of the recovery is that it is now broad-based across many industries. For example, professional and business services, which added 75,000 jobs in April, have seen over 660,000 jobs added over the past 12 months. Many of these jobs are likely to be office jobs paying mid- to high-level wages. Retail, restaurants and bars, traditionally low-wage industries, have also seen strong job growth, and blue-collar industries like manufacturing and construction are on the upswing.

The only major sector that continues to cut jobs is the federal government, which has reduced its workforce by 83,000 positions over the past 12 months.

Title: Sen. Dianne Feinstein Defends Hillary Clinton's Cognitive Abilities and Endorses Her Foreign Policy Expertise

In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat, expressed support for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, should she decide to run for president in 2016. While not issuing a formal endorsement, Feinstein praised Clinton as a top foreign policy expert and a strong leader.

When asked about recent comments by Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, regarding Clinton's cognitive abilities, Feinstein called Rove's remarks a "pathetic" attempt to sway voters. When pressed on the legitimacy of Rove's questions about Clinton's health, Feinstein stated, "That she has sustained brain damage? That's legitimate?... In my view, she's in the prime of her political life. She has all the elements of a good leader, plus the fact—and this is not to be underestimated—she is enormously attractive to people. She carries the torch for women, who are the majority of votes in this country, very strongly and holds it very high. I think people respond to her."

Feinstein also referenced Clinton's upcoming book as evidence of her foreign policy background. "I think the book will likely carry a good bit of her thinking on various big issues, certainly foreign policy, certainly the Secretary of State, and we would have someone in the White House who would have a real background in foreign policy," Feinstein said. She added, "I think that's critical at this point in the world with Russia expanding, with Africa becoming real problems from a terror point of view, and on and on and on."

Title: Testimonies Reveal Turbulent Times at the White House and the Ukrainian Embassy in 2019

Article:

In a series of testimonies, several key figures have shed light on the tumultuous events that unfolded at the White House and the Ukrainian embassy in March 2019. The situation, initially focused on security, economy, justice, and support for Ukrainian democratic resistance, was overshadowed by a political agenda promoted by former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani and a group of officials with direct access to the White House.

During the testimonies, it was stated that some members of the committee seemed to believe that Russia and its security services did not conduct a campaign against the United States in 2016, with the suggestion that Ukraine may have been responsible instead. This narrative was described as a fictional one, perpetuated and propagated by the Russian security services. It was emphasized that Russia was the foreign power that systematically attacked democratic institutions in 2016.

The hold on security assistance was lifted, but concerns persisted about unfulfilled requests, such as a meeting with the president in the Oval Office. It was suggested that this desire for such meetings continues to the present day.

The testimonies also revealed a strained relationship between Ambassador Sondland and some of his colleagues. Ambassador Sondland was reportedly involved in a domestic political errand, while the National Security Council was tasked with national security foreign policy. This divergence was a source of frustration for some, including the speaker, who expressed his concerns to Ambassador Sondland.

The testimonies also addressed the accusations against Colonel Vindman, suggesting he has dual loyalties. In response, the speaker, as an immigrant himself, expressed his belief that such accusations are deeply unfair.

Regarding Giuliani's role, it was stated that he was compared to a hand grenade by Ambassador Bolton, indicating that his actions and statements could backfire.

The testimonies concluded with a call for unity and truth, emphasizing the importance of the testimonies in ensuring the American people can make informed choices in the 2020 presidential election without fear.

Title: YouTube Investing in The Young Turks' TYT Academy for Digital-First Local News Creation

Article:

In a significant move towards fostering digital-first local news, Google-owned YouTube has announced an investment in The Young Turks (TYT) to launch the TYT Academy. The investment, reported to be in the mid-six-figures range, is part of YouTube's $25 million commitment to news efforts, which is a part of the $300 million Google News Initiative announced in 2018.

The TYT Academy, a two-track online course, aims to engage everyday people in digital media, empowering them to report on their local communities. The course features a two-track video series, with each track containing eight videos. Users will take short quizzes along the way, and must pass a final exam after completing each track to earn a TYT Academy certificate.

The first track focuses on journalism tactics and responsibilities, while the second track delves into best practices for online video production across various online platforms, not just YouTube. The course is currently in a trial period, with plans to expand it more broadly after testing it with 10-15 individuals.

Steven Oh, TYT’s Chief Business Officer and the creator of TYT Academy, clarified in a phone call with ███ that TYT is "not interested in cranking out journalists who share our political viewpoint whatsoever."

This investment comes as Facebook has also invested in online news courses from publishers. In December, ███ reported that Facebook would be funding an online deepfakes course for newsrooms by Reuters. The videos for this course, which have been online for about two months, appear to be nonpartisan. However, it's notable that YouTube is investing in a course from TYT, which has a progressive bent.

Facebook has stated that it will include partisan publishers like Breitbart in its news tab, but it won't necessarily pay Breitbart. The company has not released a list of all the publishers who are being paid.

Meanwhile, Young Turks' founder Cenk Uygur is running to fill the seat vacated by former Rep. Katie Hill. This move by TYT underscores the platform's commitment to engaging in local politics and news, in addition to its digital media courses.

Title: Idaho Wedding Chapel Owners Face Legal Action for Refusing to Perform Same-sex Weddings

Article:

In a turn of events that has sparked controversy and raised concerns about religious freedom, two Christian ministers in Idaho are facing potential legal action for refusing to perform same-sex weddings at their wedding chapel. The Hitching Post Wedding Chapel in Coeur d’Alene, owned by Donald and Evelyn Knapp, is at the center of a lawsuit filed in federal court on Friday.

The lawsuit, filed by the Alliance Defending Freedom, claims that the city is requiring the Knapps to either perform same-sex weddings or face jail time and fines of up to $1,000. The wedding chapel is registered as a religious corporation limited to performing "one-man-one-woman marriages as defined by the Holy Bible." However, it is also registered as a for-profit business, not as a church or place of worship, and city officials argue that this means the owners must comply with a local nondiscrimination ordinance.

The ordinance, passed last year, prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation and applies to housing, employment, and public accommodation. City Attorney Warren Wilson reportedly told local news outlets that the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel would likely be subject to the ordinance. If the Knapps refused to perform same-sex weddings, they could face fines of up to $1,000 and jail time of up to 180 days.

The lawsuit states that Wilson confirmed the ministers would not be exempt from the ordinance because the Hitching Post is a business and not a church. The city has not responded to requests for an interview regarding the matter.

The controversy came to a head last week when the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit allowed same-sex marriages to commence in Idaho on Oct. 15. Two days later, the Hitching Post received a call inquiring about a same-sex wedding ceremony, which they declined, putting them in violation of the law.

The lawsuit seeks to protect the Knapps' freedom to adhere to their faith as pastors, as guaranteed by the First Amendment. The Alliance Defending Freedom also filed a temporary restraining order to stop the city from enforcing the ordinance.

The incident in Coeur d'Alene comes on the heels of a similar controversy in Houston, where five Christian pastors were issued subpoenas demanding sermons dealing with homosexuality and gender identity.

Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council, called it "open season on Americans who refuse to bow to the government's redefinition of marriage." He added, "Americans are witnesses to the reality that redefining marriage is less about the marriage altar and more about fundamentally altering the freedoms of the other 98 percent of Americans."

The incidents in Houston and Coeur d'Alene are the latest examples of a disturbing trend in the culture war, with direct attacks on clergy. "Government officials are making clear they will use their government power to punish those who oppose the advances of homosexual activists," Perkins said.

The Knapps' lawsuit comes as the latest example of the ongoing debate over religious freedom and same-sex marriage in the United States. The incidents in Houston and Coeur d'Alene raise questions about the balance between religious freedom and nondiscrimination, and the role of government in regulating religious practices.

Title: Nation Mourns the Passing of Former First Lady Nancy Reagan

Article:

Nancy Reagan, the wife of the 40th President of the United States, Ronald Reagan, has passed away at the age of 94, according to TMZ. Known as Mrs. Ronald Reagan, she was a close confidant and played a significant role in her husband's career and presidency.

In a statement, Senator Marco Rubio wrote, "Today our nation mourns the loss of Nancy Reagan, a true example of integrity and grace." The world may have never seen the man who won the Cold War if it wasn't for the driving force of Nancy in his life.

Nancy Reagan and Ronald Reagan met in 1949 when Ronald was the head of the Screen Actors Guild. They married three years later, and their bond was deep, serving as a driving force behind Ronald Reagan's relentless and successful political career.

When Ronald Reagan was diagnosed with Alzheimer's in 1994, Nancy became his primary caretaker until his death in 2004. Throughout that time, she remained a guardian of his legacy.

Nancy Reagan's impact on the nation was profound, and she was admired by many. Former Presidential candidates, Senators, and political figures took to Twitter to express their condolences and memories of the former First Lady.

Former Presidential candidate and Senator Ted Cruz wrote, "Nancy Reagan, the wife of a truly great President, was an amazing woman. She will be sorely missed." Former Governor of California, Arnold Schwarzenegger, tweeted, "Nancy Reagan was a trailblazer for women in politics and a true partner to her husband, President Reagan. She will be deeply missed."

Nancy Reagan's legacy will continue to inspire future generations, and her impact on American politics and culture will be felt for years to come. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Reagan family during this difficult time.

Title: Democrats Face Criticism Over Pay Equity as They Promote Equal Pay Day

Article:

In a show of solidarity for equal pay for women, Democrats have marked Tuesday as National Equal Pay Day, symbolizing the number of days a woman needs to work in a given year to earn what men earned in the previous year. However, the move has sparked criticism as data reveals that both President Obama and leading Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton have not consistently practiced pay equity within their own administrations.

President Obama, in a proclamation, highlighted the wage gap, stating that on average, full-time working women earn 78 cents for every dollar earned by men. He emphasized that this disparity puts women at a career-long disadvantage and negatively impacts families, communities, and the economy as a whole.

However, an analysis of White House salaries from last July revealed a 13% pay gap between male and female staffers, with women earning less on average. In 2009, women at the White House were paid an average of $72,700, while male staffers earned $82,000. By 2014, the gap had narrowed slightly, with women staffers earning $78,400 compared to the average male salaries of $88,600.

Similarly, during her time in the U.S. Senate, Hillary Clinton's office paid women 72 cents for each dollar paid to men. The Washington Free Beacon's analysis found the median annual salary for female staffers was $15,708.38 less than the median salary for men between 2002 and 2008, a gender gap of 28%.

While Clinton's supporters argue that she has been a consistent advocate for equal-pay legislation, her critics point to her own record in this regard. The Democratic National Committee (DNC) has attacked GOP presidential candidates on their pay-equity policies, but the party itself faces scrutiny over its own practices.

In response to the criticism, Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz stated, "Democrats are proud to fight for equal pay every single day." The DNC has also criticized Republican presidential candidates for their perceived lack of commitment to pay equity or for enacting policies deemed unfavorable to female workers.

In Congress, Democrats are proposing the Paycheck Fairness Act, which aims to allow employees to share information about their pay and file lawsuits against employers. On the Republican side, a coalition of senators, led by Sen. Deb Fischer of Nebraska, has offered an amendment to the bill that would prohibit retaliation against employees for discussing salaries and provide grants to states to create industry-led partnerships to address pay disparities.

The debate over pay equity continues to be a contentious issue, with both parties emphasizing their commitment to addressing the wage gap while facing criticism for their own records on the matter.

Title: House Approves Syrian and Iraqi Refugee Bill: Bipartisan Support, Veto-Proof Majority

The House of Representatives passed a bill on Thursday that aims to block Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the United States unless they undergo stringent background checks. The bill, which saw near unanimous support from Republicans and broad support from Democrats, could potentially collide with President Barack Obama and Senate Democrats.

The bill, known as the American Security Against Foreign Enemies Act, requires the FBI, Department of Homeland Security, and the Director of National Intelligence to certify that any refugee from Syria or Iraq is not a threat to the security of the United States before being allowed to settle in the country.

The bill's passage marks a significant loss for the White House, with the House Democratic Caucus voting against Obama on a similar scale as the trade bill in mid-June. The measure faces an uncertain future in the Senate, with Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) stating that the Syria bill will not reach Obama's desk.

The bill's supporters argue that the current vetting system is insufficient, while opponents contend that the new bill is unnecessary and burdensome. The final vote was 289-137, with many House Democrats signaling early Thursday that there was not broad support in their caucus to take a tough vote on national security.

In response to the bill's passage, the White House dispatched Chief of Staff Denis McDonough and Secretary of Homeland Security Jeh Johnson to Capitol Hill to speak with Democrats. However, their efforts to persuade Democrats to oppose the Republican-authored bill were not successful.

Representative Sean Patrick Maloney (D-NY) stated, "It is offensive to me that we would stigmatize refugees...but if you read the bill what you find is that you have a pretty simple certification process sitting on top of an existing and extensive screening process that most of us believe works pretty well."

The bill's passage is a rebuke of President Obama by House Democrats who felt that the administration failed to make a compelling case as to why they should vote against the Republican-authored bill when it was bad politics to do so. The vote, coupled with the Iranian nuclear agreement bill from September, also shows that Republicans plan to make national security a key issue in the 2016 elections.

Title: John Kasich's 2016 Presidential Campaign: A Closer Look

Article:

In the 2016 Republican primary race, Ohio Governor John Kasich's campaign, while not particularly successful, bore some resemblance to former Utah Governor Jon Huntsman's unsuccessful 2012 bid. Both candidates shared the same campaign strategist, John Weaver, and followed a similar playbook, albeit with varying results.

Kasich's strategy seemed promising at the onset, particularly in the early primary state of New Hampshire, where he placed second to Donald Trump. However, his heavy focus on New Hampshire left him with limited infrastructure for the rest of the campaign, resulting in a non-existent presence in the South Carolina primary. By the time the campaign reached his home state, Kasich was effectively out of the running, winning only Ohio. He ended the campaign with fewer delegates than Senator Marco Rubio, who dropped out on March 15.

Kasich's campaign platform revolved around his image as a traditional conservative who could also win swing states like Ohio. His policy focus, however, was largely centered on his advocacy for a balanced-budget amendment, a promise tied to his work on balancing the national budget during his tenure in the U.S. House in the 1990s. The extent of his involvement in this work is a subject of debate.

Kasich's policy stances on other issues, such as his acceptance of Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act in his capacity as governor, were met with criticism from conservatives. His justification for this decision, rooted in faith, further alienated him from the Republican base.

Kasich's image as a friendly, approachable politician was not universally accepted by his former colleagues, who recalled a more irritable, angry Kasich. The disconnect between this image and the candidate that Republican primary voters wanted in 2016, a more volatile, unpredictable nominee, ultimately proved to be Kasich's undoing.

Title: Obama Administration Faces Challenges in Meeting 2016 Obamacare Enrollment Target

Article:

As the third round of enrollment for the Affordable Care Act's (Obamacare) health insurance marketplaces approaches, President Obama faces a significant challenge in meeting the 21 million enrollee target set in budget projections for 2016. As of June, the Department of Health and Human Services reported 9.9 million customers who have purchased plans through the federal HealthCare.gov portal and state-run exchanges, which is less than half of the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) 2016 projection.

Industry analysts have described the CBO's estimate for next year as "overly optimistic" and a "stretch," suggesting that it will take more time for the law to attract the necessary number of people onto the web-based marketplaces. Elizabeth Carpenter, a vice president at Avalere Health, a D.C.-based consultancy, stated, "Given where things stand, the ramp-up of enrollment may be slower than initially anticipated."

Open enrollment for the third round of Obamacare's exchanges begins on November 1. The administration is counting on winning over millions of customers who did not sign up during the first two years but may be pressured by the increasing penalties associated with the "individual mandate" tax, which assesses a penalty on those who forgo health insurance. Rachel Klein, director of organizational strategy at Families USA, a nonprofit that advocates for affordable health care, noted, "It is definitely something that people pay attention to."

The tax during the first year was $95 or 1% of income above the filing threshold, a relatively minor penalty. This year, the penalty will be $325 or 2% of income, and by 2016 it will be $695 or 2.5% of income. Larry Levitt, a senior vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, stated, "The substantial increase in penalties under the individual mandate next year is a big wild card. We're in uncharted territory here about how effective these bigger penalties will be in nudging people to get insured."

The individual mandate was included in the Affordable Care Act of 2010 to ensure that enough healthy Americans signed up, spreading out the costs for higher-risk customers. The Supreme Court upheld the mandate in 2012 as an appropriate use of Congress' taxing power. However, congressional Republicans are still intent on scrapping the health care law, and may use a fast-track budget procedure known as "reconciliation" to take a swing at it. GOP leaders say they may not be able to eviscerate the law through the budget, but repealing the individual mandate is "definitely on the table."

Even as it struggles to meet the 2016 enrollment projection, the Obama administration is on track on other measures, including a CBO estimate that 17 million fewer people lack insurance this year because of the health care law. However, the administration has begun to set more modest goals for exchange enrollment, ignoring the CBO's guess of 12 million for 2015 and setting the mark at 9.1 million enrollees. The agency says it is doing its own evaluation of the marketplace and will likely announce its enrollment targets for 2016 before signups begin in November.

In conclusion, the Obama administration faces a significant challenge in meeting the 2016 enrollment target for Obamacare. The CBO's estimate for next year's enrollment is "overly optimistic," and industry analysts suggest that it will take more time for the law to attract the necessary number of people onto the web-based marketplaces. The administration is counting on winning over millions of customers who did not sign up during the first two years but may be pressured by the increasing penalties associated with the individual mandate tax. The future of the health care law remains uncertain, as congressional Republicans continue to push for its repeal.

Title: Republican Opposition to Obama's Cuba Policy: A New Roadblock in U.S.-Cuba Relations

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Barack Obama's plan to normalize relations with Cuba has faced a familiar hurdle as Republicans on Capitol Hill have begun exploring ways to impede any changes to the U.S.-Cuba relationship.

Just hours after Obama announced a prisoner swap with the Cuban government for two Americans as the start of a new relationship with the communist country, Republicans started informally discussing strategies to obstruct any alterations to the U.S.-Cuba relationship. Proposed measures include denying Obama funds to reopen an embassy in Havana, stalling the nomination of a potential ambassador, voting down a bill to open up travel more widely, and ignoring requests from the White House to lift a decades-old embargo.

With Republicans set to control the Senate next year, they would be in a strong position to implement some of their plans. However, even if they cannot fully halt Obama's initiatives, as the president has some authority to act without Congress, the dispute will provide another opportunity for the president's Hill rivals, including 2016 likely contenders Sens. Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, to continue questioning his use of executive action – a theme Republicans had already planned to take on next year regarding Obama's moves on immigration and Obamacare.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) expressed his opposition on Twitter Wednesday, stating, "I will do all in my power to block the use of funds to open an embassy in Cuba. Normalizing relations with Cuba is a bad idea at a bad time."

In a White House address on Wednesday, Obama announced that he would direct Secretary of State John Kerry to review Cuba's place on a list of state sponsors of terrorism, reestablish an embassy in Havana, and ease travel restrictions. Obama also stated that the U.S. would increase remittance levels, expand commercial sales, and exports.

"We will end an outdated approach that for decades has failed to advance our interests," Obama said. "Neither the American nor the Cuban people are well-served by a rigid policy that is rooted in events that took place before most of us were born."

Republicans will control the Senate starting in January, meaning they will have the power to block presidential nominations. Already, a number of influential Republicans vocal on foreign affairs, including Graham, Sens. John McCain (R-Ariz.), Rubio (R-Fla.), and Cruz have stated their staunch opposition to Obama's plans.

Obama also called on Congress to pursue legislation that would lift the 50-year embargo against goods and travel to Cuba. The embargo, launched by President John F. Kennedy, is not solidified by decades of congressional legislation – a fact Obama alluded to in his remarks.

"The embargo that has been imposed for decades is now codified in legislation. As these changes unfold, I look forward to engaging Congress in an honest and serious debate about lifting the embargo," he said.

However, Speaker John Boehner stated he would not allow any Cuban-U.S. relations to be revisited in the House.

"Relations with the Castro regime should not be revisited, let alone normalized, until the Cuban people enjoy freedom – and not one second sooner. There is no'new course' here, only another in a long line of mindless concessions to a dictatorship that brutalizes its people and schemes with our enemies," the Ohio Republican said.
