Incoming Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said he would defer the upper chamber's response to Cuba policy changes to Rubio, who criticized Obama for threatening U.S. national security concerns.

Already, some Republicans are casting doubt on if the Obama administration has the legal authority to roll back some travel restrictions and allow increased numbers of Cuban cigars to be brought into the U.S. Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) said action by Obama "may be in direct violation of Helms-Burton that specifically states that all political prisoners must be released and free and fair elections must be held before establishing a diplomatic relationship."

The incoming chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Tennessee Republican Bob Corker, gave few details on Wednesday on what his panel would do to halt any of Obama's proposals.

"The new U.S. policy announced by the administration is no doubt sweeping, and as of now, there is no real understanding as to what changes the Cuban government is prepared to make. We will be closely examining the implications of these major policy changes in the next Congress," he said.

Meanwhile, Democrats were mixed on their response to Obama's plans. Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.), the current chair of the Foreign Relations Committee, was highly critical of Obama's proposals. However, House Minority Nancy Pelosi hailed Obama's "new chapter."

"It is clear that policy of isolating Cuba is serving neither the interests of the American people nor the democratic aspirations of the Cubans. We must acknowledge our policy towards Cuba is a relic of a bygone era that weakens our leadership in the Americas and has not advanced freedom and prosperity in Cuba," Pelosi said.

Title: Analyzing the Impact of Obamacare on Federal Budget: A Long-term Perspective

Article:

The Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, has been a subject of intense political debate since its inception in 2010, with claims ranging from it being a significant contributor to deficit reduction to a potential budgetary burden. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) initially estimated that the ACA would reduce deficits by over $100 billion in the first decade and by half a percent of economic growth in the second decade, potentially reducing deficits by more than $1 trillion.

However, the CBO's estimate is contingent on the law being implemented exactly as written, which may not be the case. The ACA's implementation has already seen several changes, and more are being proposed, which could impact its deficit-reduction potential. For instance, there is a push to repeal the ACA's tax on medical devices, a move that could result in a loss of $30 billion over the next decade.

Moreover, adhering to various cost-containment provisions in the law could prove challenging, according to Joshua Gordon, policy director of the Concord Coalition, a deficit watchdog group. If lawmakers continue to make changes to the law, there is a risk of adding to deficits rather than reducing them.

A long-range simulation by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) suggests that if key provisions intended to restrain spending growth in Medicare and health insurance subsidies are phased out, deficits could increase by 0.7% of GDP over the next 75 years. This increase would primarily be due to increased spending on Medicaid, the Children's Health Insurance Program, and subsidies offered on the health insurance exchanges.

The impact of Obamacare on the federal budget remains uncertain, as it is a complex law with various provisions that phase in and out over time. The growth in national health spending, of which federal spending is a significant part, has fallen to a record low rate. While part of this slowing is attributed to the ACA, the exact extent is unclear. The growth rate is expected to rise in the next few years as more people become insured under Obamacare.

The success of the new health insurance exchanges in attracting a diverse pool of enrollees and generating enough competition to provide affordable health care for most Americans remains to be seen. What is encouraging, according to Gordon, are the changes that hospitals, doctors, and insurance companies are making to slow cost growth. These changes reflect a shift towards a value-based health care system.

However, Gordon's pessimism stems from the potential for Congress to interfere with these positive changes. The long-term fiscal impact of Obamacare will depend on how lawmakers choose to implement and adjust the law.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell Calls for Roy Moore to Step Aside Amid Sexual Misconduct Allegations

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) on Monday urged GOP Senate candidate Roy Moore to withdraw from the Alabama Senate race following a series of sexual misconduct allegations against him.

"I think he should step aside," McConnell said during a tax reform press conference in Louisville, Ky., when asked about the calls from his Senate colleagues for Moore to leave the race.

The Washington Post published a story last week detailing allegations that Moore pursued relationships with teenage girls, including an account from Leigh Corfman, now 53, who said she had a sexual encounter with Moore in 1979, when she was 14 years old and he was 32. The report also included accounts from three other women who said Moore attempted to court them around that time, when they were between 16 and 18 years old.

Moore, in a tweet early Monday afternoon, responded to McConnell's remarks by saying, "He has failed conservatives and must be replaced."

Even if Moore withdraws from the Senate race — something he has said he will not do — Republicans are stuck with his name remaining on the ballot. The deadline for the party to remove Moore's name from the ballot passed in October, though Republicans could mount a write-in challenge. Republicans have also floated trying to move back the December special election date.

McConnell said Monday that the party is exploring a write-in bid, though he declined to say specifically who would be the candidate. "That's an option we're looking at, whether or not there is someone who could mount a write-in successfully," he said.

When asked if Sen. Luther Strange (R-Ala.), who Moore defeated in the GOP primary runoff, would be the write-in candidate, McConnell added, "We'll see."

Moore has denied wrongdoing and threatened to sue The Washington Post, arguing the story is politically motivated and aimed at damaging him ahead of the December special election.

Senate Republicans, including Orrin Hatch (Utah) and Susan Collins (Maine), have called on Moore to step aside if the allegations are true. Sen. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.), who leads the Senate GOP campaign arm, later called on the Senate to expel Moore if he wins the special election.

Alabama Republicans have publicly defended Moore and warned that if he left the race it would hand the Senate seat to Democratic candidate Doug Jones. Alabama Republican Party Chairwoman Terry Lathan also pushed back against a write-in campaign, saying it would be a "serious error" for any current elected GOP official or candidate to endorse another party's candidate, an independent, a third party, or a write-in candidate in a general election.

Moore is using the blowback from Republican lawmakers in his fundraising appeals, saying that "establishment Republicans are colluding with the Obama-Clinton Machine."

Republicans have a slim 52-seat majority in the Senate, and losing the Alabama seat to a Democrat would likely make it harder for McConnell to get major legislation through the chamber.

Title: Political Divide on Foreign Policy: A Closer Look at the 2016 Presidential Debate and ISIS

Article:

In the aftermath of the Paris terror attacks, the political landscape in the United States has been marked by a stark contrast in foreign policy perspectives between the Democratic and Republican parties. The debate, particularly on the issue of ISIS, has been a focal point of the 2016 presidential race.

During the Paris attacks, then-President Barack Obama described ISIS as "contained," a statement that was met with criticism. In the following days, some liberals argued that the attacks in Paris demonstrated the success of Obama's strategy, as ISIS was forced to lash out to gain attention. This perspective, however, was not widely shared.

Earlier this year, while still in office, President Obama described global warming as the greatest threat to humanity. This view was echoed by Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders during Saturday night's Democratic debate, where he reaffirmed his belief that global warming is the root cause of terrorism in the Middle East. Meanwhile, Martin O'Malley expressed his intention to bring 60,000 Syrian refugees into the country, despite the fact that some of these refugees have been linked to the Paris attacks.

The White House Deputy National Security Advisor has confirmed that the refugee importation will proceed as planned. The Republican Party, on the other hand, has been criticizing this decision, with the American people seemingly favoring a more aggressive stance against ISIS.

The Republican Party has traditionally struggled in domestic policy elections, but in foreign policy, they have found a stronghold. The American public appears to want a leader who is willing to take decisive action against terrorists, without being overly idealistic. The Democrats, in contrast, have been criticized for their perceived naivety and delusional approach to foreign policy.

Hillary Clinton, a Democratic candidate, has faced criticism for her foreign policy proposals. As John Podhoretz noted, her policy solutions seem to be a jumble of contradictory platitudes. She has stated that ISIS must be "rooted out," implicitly criticizing Obama's strategy of containment. Yet, she also argued that ISIS cannot be an American fight, American leadership is essential, but the United States does not bear the bulk of the responsibility.

In a surprising turn, Clinton places the responsibility for the Syrian crisis on Syria's dictator, Bashar al-Assad, and the Iraqis, rather than on ISIS itself. This stance has been met with criticism, as Assad has been responsible for the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of his own people and is a key player in the refugee crisis.

The political divide on foreign policy between the two major parties is stark, with the Republican Party advocating for a more aggressive stance against ISIS, and the Democrats focusing on global warming and refugee resettlement. The American public will have to decide which approach they believe is best for the country in the upcoming elections.

Title: A Milestone Reached: 100 Women in Congress, Yet Inequality Persists

Article:

Tuesday's midterm elections marked a significant milestone in American politics, as the number of women in Congress will reach 100 for the first time in the nation's history. However, this milestone is somewhat overshadowed by the fact that more than 80% of the country's federal legislators are still men.

The increase in female representation will be approximately 1%, a figure that falls short of the celebration that one might expect. The low number of women in political power in Washington should be a cause for concern, as it is far lower than in most advanced democracies.

According to Debbie Walsh, director of the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University, women tend to enter politics because they want to solve a problem or address a policy issue, while men often run for political careers. This difference in motivation could be a factor in the underrepresentation of women in Congress.

The article highlights the challenges women face in politics, including the need to raise vast sums of money, the later entry into politics, and the difficulty in building power and recruiting other women into the field. Incumbents almost always win, preserving the status quo and, consequently, the gender imbalance.

It is important to note that when women do run, they win in similar numbers as men. Once in office, women tend to function more as consensus builders than men do, and there is growing evidence that women are more effective at building bipartisan support for legislation.

The article also highlights the firsts achieved by women in Tuesday's elections, such as Joni Ernst, the first female combat veteran to serve in the Senate, and Mia Love, the first black woman ever elected to Congress as a member of the Republican Party.

The story of women in American politics is one of persistent and very-slowly-eroding inequality. To break this pattern, more women need to run on both parties. Each victory is a sign to other women that politics is a field where they can succeed, and, as it happens, success for women would give the entire country, Democrats and Republicans, a real reason to celebrate.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Book "What Happened" Draws Controversy and Comparisons to Past Political Moments

Article:

In her new book, "What Happened," former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recounts her experience in the 2016 presidential election, including a controversial moment during a debate with Donald Trump. Clinton describes an uncomfortable encounter with Trump, where he allegedly followed her closely, invading her personal space.

The book, which spans 512 pages, offers insights into Clinton's perspective on the election, but not without controversy. One of the most debated sections of the book is Clinton's recollection of a debate moment where she and Trump shared a small stage. Clinton describes the moment as "incredibly uncomfortable," with Trump "literally breathing down [her] neck."

The book has sparked discussions about Clinton's response to the situation, with some criticizing her for not standing up to Trump more assertively. Clinton, however, defends her decision to remain calm and composed, citing a "lifetime of dealing with difficult men trying to throw [her] off."

The book has also drawn comparisons to a similar moment in presidential debate history, when Al Gore approached George W. Bush during a debate in 2000. Gore's approach was met with laughter from the audience, while Clinton's moment with Trump has been met with criticism and debate.

In addition to the debate moment, Clinton's book has been criticized for its focus on personal anecdotes and self-reflection, rather than offering a more in-depth analysis of the election and its aftermath. The book has also been criticized for its tone, with some describing it as self-pitying and self-aggrandizing.

Despite the criticism, Clinton's book has been a bestseller and has sparked conversations about gender, politics, and the role of the media in shaping public opinion. The book has also drawn attention to the challenges faced by women in politics, with Clinton discussing the sexism and misogyny she experienced during the campaign.

In a chapter entitled "On Being a Woman in Politics," Clinton references a speech by David Foster Wallace, in which he discusses human nature and the challenges of recognizing reality. Clinton uses Wallace's speech to discuss the challenges of recognizing sexism in politics, but some have criticized her use of the speech as a way to deflect blame from her own actions and decisions during the campaign.

Overall, Clinton's book has been a polarizing and controversial addition to the political discourse, with some praising it for its honesty and insight, while others criticize it for its tone and focus on personal anecdotes. The book has sparked conversations about gender, politics, and the role of the media in shaping public opinion, but has also raised questions about Clinton's leadership and her ability to move past the 2016 election.

Title: Unbiased Analysis: Quijano's Moderation of Vice Presidential Debate Sparks Controversy

Article:

The vice presidential debate on Tuesday night at Longwood University was marked by a noticeable bias in the moderation, according to conservative critics. CBS anchor Elaine Quijano, who presided over the debate, was accused of favoring Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Kaine and interrupting Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence more frequently.

Quijano's moderation style was criticized for being heavily weighted towards Kaine, with Pence receiving tough questions only 8 times compared to Kaine's single question in the entire debate. The New York Times acknowledged this bias, stating, "Elaine Quijano, the moderator, helped Mr. Kaine along, opening one question with a recitation of Mr. Pence's statements."

The debate began with Quijano asking Kaine about the trustworthiness of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, a question that was not posed to Pence. However, the rest of the debate was dominated by Kaine's interruptions and Quijano's attempts to control the conversation.

Conservatives on social media praised Pence's performance, with The Washington Post's Chris Cillizza listing Pence among the debate's "winners." Even MSNBC's Chris Matthews, known for his pro-Democratic leanings, admitted that Pence was "eloquent," "excellent," and "looked like a grown-up."

Despite the praise for Pence's performance, the mainstream media's post-debate coverage was expected to focus on Kaine's allegations against Pence and his running mate Donald Trump. CNN's Jake Tapper, for instance, suggested that the night went to Pence but questioned whether the week would belong to Kaine.

The debate's moderation sparked a wave of criticism on social media, with many conservatives accusing Quijano of bias. The debate's interruptions and the moderator's questions were also a topic of discussion, with some commentators pointing out that Quijano's questions to Kaine were more conversational and less confrontational than those posed to Pence.

The third and final debate between the two vice presidential candidates will take place on October 9, with CNN's Anderson Cooper joining Quijano as a moderator. With Cooper's known liberal leanings, some conservatives are already expressing concerns about the moderation of the final debate.

Title: Minimum Wage Increase: A Contentious yet Persistent Policy Debate

Article:

The debate over increasing the minimum wage has long been a contentious issue in American politics, with both sides presenting compelling arguments for and against the policy. The latest development in this ongoing debate comes from a report released by the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) on Wednesday, which projects that a phased-in $10.10 minimum wage, as proposed by President Obama, could result in a modest but real disemployment effect.

According to the CBO, a $10.10 minimum wage could reduce employment by as many as 1 million jobs by the end of 2016, with the best estimate being a loss of 500,000 jobs relative to what would happen without any increase at all. This finding has been met with enthusiasm by conservatives, who have long opposed minimum wage increases and are now using the report to bolster their argument that a $10.10 minimum wage is a job killer.

However, supporters of the minimum wage increase argue that the policy has significant benefits that outweigh the potential job losses. The CBO also found that a $10.10 minimum wage would lift about 900,000 people out of poverty and increase wages for nearly 16.5 million people. This means that for every job potentially lost, nearly 33 people would see a wage increase.

Furthermore, a higher minimum wage could help mitigate some of the consequences of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) that conservatives have been critical of. People who earn higher wages are less likely to quit their jobs, and when wages increase, they slide up the ACA's means-tested benefit scale. This could result in a reduction in the number of uninsured individuals, particularly in states that have refused to expand Medicaid or have not implemented the ACA effectively.

It is important to note that both sides acknowledge that it is possible to increase the minimum wage beyond the point at which the costs outstrip the benefits. However, the CBO's report suggests that $10.10 is not that point.

The debate over the minimum wage is a complex one, with both sides presenting valid arguments. The CBO's report provides valuable insight into the potential effects of a $10.10 minimum wage, but it does not necessarily determine the policy's overall merit. Ultimately, the decision will be made by lawmakers, who will need to weigh the potential job losses against the benefits of lifting millions of people out of poverty and increasing wages for millions more.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address: Emphasis on Education, Diplomacy, and Cybersecurity

In his State of the Union address, President Barack Obama proposed a series of initiatives aimed at education, diplomacy, and cybersecurity. The proposals, which would cost approximately $60 billion over a decade, include a community college initiative, new tax credits for the middle class, and an expansion of existing tax breaks for higher education.

The community college initiative, a key part of the president's plan, aims to make community college free for many students. The proposals also include a new $500 tax credit for families with two working spouses, a subsidy of up to $2,500 annually to pay for college, and the tripling, up to $3,000, of an existing tax break to pay for college.

President Obama emphasized the importance of treating child care as a national economic priority, stating, "It’s time we stop treating child care as a side issue, or as a women’s issue, and treat it like the national economic priority that it is for all of us."

In terms of foreign policy, the president argued for a more diplomatic approach towards Cuba, stating that the current strategy of isolation has been ineffective. He also expressed his opposition to new sanctions against Iran, preferring to engage in diplomatic talks to prevent Iran's development of a nuclear weapon.

The president also addressed the issue of cybersecurity, calling for legislation to bolster protections against cyberattacks. He cited several high-profile cyberattacks, including one against Sony Pictures, as reasons for the need for stronger protections. "No foreign nation, no hacker should be able to shut down our networks, steal our trade secrets or invade the privacy of American families, especially our kids," Obama said.

Overall, the president's State of the Union address focused on a combination of military power, strong diplomacy, coalition building, and the importance of leveraging technology for the benefit of all.

Title: U.S. Reaffirms Justification for Syria Strikes, Calls for Global Action and Accountability

Article:

In a strong statement at the United Nations on Friday, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley reiterated the Trump administration's stance on the U.S.'s missile strikes on a Syrian airbase earlier this week, following a chemical weapons attack that resulted in the deaths of numerous civilians, including children.

Haley emphasized the U.S.'s readiness to take further action, but expressed hope that it would not be necessary. She echoed President Trump's call for all civilized nations to unite in ending the atrocities in Syria and to advocate for a political solution.

Haley also pointed the finger at Syria's president, Bashar Assad, as well as his allies, Iran and Russia, for the use of chemical weapons in the war-torn country. She suggested that Russia, entrusted with ensuring the removal of such weapons from Syria, may be either knowingly allowing the weapons to remain, being incompetent in their efforts, or being deceived by the Assad regime, which allegedly claims to have no chemical weapons.

Russia, in response, has denounced the U.S. missile strikes and has vowed to strengthen Syria's anti-aircraft defenses.

Haley reminded the U.N. Security Council of her earlier warning this week about the possibility of a unilateral U.S. strike against Syria, stating that when the international community fails to act collectively, individual states may be compelled to take independent action. She underscored that the indiscriminate use of chemical weapons against innocent civilians is a situation that warrants such action.

Title: Traditional Conservative Newspaper Endorsements of Clinton Spark Backlash, Risking Subscriptions and Facing Criticism

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, traditionally conservative newspaper editorial boards across the United States have endorsed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, sparking backlash and losing subscribers. The Cincinnati Enquirer, which hadn't endorsed a Democrat in nearly a century, and The Arizona Republic, which had only backed Republican presidential candidates in its 126-year history, have faced criticism and even death threats following their endorsements.

The Arizona Republic, in a scathing editorial this week, portrayed Donald Trump as unqualified and not a true conservative. The Enquirer, which made the decision to endorse Clinton last week, has received over a hundred angry letters and subscription cancellations, according to Peter Bhatia, the Enquirer's editor.

The backlash, presumably from ardent Trump supporters, is not surprising, analysts say. Trump has made anti-media sentiment a central theme of his campaign, and the billionaire businessman is likely to dismiss Clinton endorsements as evidence of the establishment's opposition to him.

The Enquirer was aware that its Clinton endorsement could backfire, strengthening Trump's support. "I've certainly thought about that," said Bhatia. "But at the end of the day, we felt we had an obligation to our community to make a statement about the presidential race."

At least a dozen major American newspapers have endorsed Clinton, but none has backed Trump. Libertarian Gary Johnson has secured at least four major endorsements, including those of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and the New Hampshire Union Leader.

In addition to The Arizona Republic and the Cincinnati Enquirer, the Dallas Morning News and USA Today have also broken decades of precedent in their presidential endorsement decisions. USA Today, which had never endorsed any presidential candidate, still technically didn't in Thursday's editorial, calling Trump "unfit for the presidency." The Morning News, which hasn't endorsed a Democrat since World War II, was more explicit, urging readers to back Clinton.

Since the Sept. 7 editorial, the paper has reported a drop in subscriptions. In Arizona, Republic editors have lost subscribers and received at least one death threat, though this hasn't caused them to reconsider their decision. "We know we're doing the right thing," said Phil Boas, director of the paper's editorial page.

While endorsements may have an impact on newspaper subscriptions, there are questions about how much they affect the presidential race itself. Analysts suggest that endorsements may influence voters considering third-party options, encouraging them to vote for a candidate with a chance of winning rather than casting a protest vote.

Title: Democrats Push for Gun Purchases Ban by Terror Suspects, Face Opposition from Republicans and NRA

Article:

In a bid to capitalize on the prevailing public concerns about security, Congressional Democrats are attempting to garner support for a proposal that would bar gun purchases by terror suspects. This move comes in the wake of the Republican's House victory, which was largely driven by the same security anxieties.

The initiative, spearheaded by Senator Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., aims to prevent federally licensed gun dealers from selling firearms to individuals on a list of known and suspected terrorists. The list would be compiled by the attorney general, likely drawing from existing government databases.

Currently, gun dealers are prohibited from selling to 10 categories of people, including convicted criminals or those with severe mental illness. However, individuals on the government's terror watch lists, including those barred from air travel, are not automatically disqualified from buying weapons from gun dealers.

The bill, if passed, would require the FBI to be notified when a background check for the purchase of firearms or explosives generates a match with the watch list, and agents would often use this information to intensify surveillance on suspects. People can attempt to remove their names from terror lists or file lawsuits challenging their inclusion. The lists are predominantly composed of foreigners.

Between 2004 and 2014, individuals on one terror watch list underwent background checks to buy guns 2,233 times and were allowed to make the purchase 91 percent of the time, according to a report by the Government Accountability Office.

National Rifle Association (NRA) spokeswoman Jennifer Baker has criticized the move, citing instances of innocent people being mistakenly added to terror lists and accusing Democrats of exploiting the Paris terrorist attacks to push their gun-control agenda.

Senator Feinstein's measure mirrors legislation proposed by the late Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., and Rep. Peter King, R-N.Y., over the last decade. None of these measures have ever received a vote.

The bill was introduced by Feinstein in February, but the recent mass killings in Paris have reinvigorated the debate on terrorism and public safety as top-tier political issues. Last week, Republicans capitalized on voter's security concerns and passed legislation in the House preventing Syrian and Iraqi refugees from entering the U.S. until the administration tightens restrictions on their entry.

House Speaker Paul Ryan, R-Wis., and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., have not yet publicly stated their stance on Feinstein's bill. Opposition from Republicans and some Democrats to curbing firearms is deep, and such legislation would require support from 60 of the 100 senators, a hurdle that Democrats have not been able to overcome, even when they had a Senate majority in the aftermath of the 2012 Newtown, Connecticut, massacre.

In addition to Feinstein's bill, Democrats may also pursue a measure by Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., that would bar gun sales to foreigners in the U.S. from the 38 countries from which visitors need not have visas.

Title: Sen. McCain Accuses Media of Cover-up in Benghazi Investigation, Challenges David Gregory on Four Americans' Deaths

Article:

In a heated interview on NBC's Meet the Press, Senator John McCain (R-AZ) accused the media of downplaying the ongoing investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack and questioned the sincerity of the media's concern for the four Americans who lost their lives during the incident.

During the interview with David Gregory, McCain expressed his belief that there are still unanswered questions regarding the attack and suggested a cover-up of the information concerning the deaths of the four brave Americans. When Gregory asked for clarification on the nature of the cover-up, McCain responded by stating that the information regarding the Benghazi attack has not been forthcoming.

The interview took a dramatic turn when McCain questioned Gregory's empathy towards the four Americans who died, asking whether he cared that they had died. Gregory responded by asking what McCain meant by a cover-up, to which McCain replied that the cover-up was of the information concerning the deaths of the four Americans.

McCain then provided a list of questions that have not been answered, including what the president did and who he spoke to on the night of the attack, why those who were evacuated from the consulate the next day were not interviewed, and why the president continued to claim for two weeks that he did not know whether it was a terrorist attack or not.

McCain concluded by stating that the answers to these questions are necessary to reach conclusions and that the lack of answers is a fact. The interview ended with McCain's statement, "But hey, what difference at this point does it make, right?"

The interview has sparked debate and discussion among political pundits and the public, with some agreeing with McCain's assessment and others criticizing his approach and tone. The investigation into the Benghazi attack remains ongoing.

Title: James Comey's Book Stirs Controversy as Key Witness in Russia Investigation

Article:

WASHINGTON – In the aftermath of his dismissal by President Donald Trump last year, former FBI Director James Comey has emerged as a crucial witness for Special Counsel Robert Mueller in the ongoing investigation into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election. Comey's written accounts of his interactions with Trump, including the president's requests for loyalty and for the FBI to drop its investigation of former national security adviser Michael Flynn, form the core of Mueller's inquiry into potential obstruction of justice.

However, the release of Comey's book, "A Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership," has sparked a new crisis for the White House and raised questions about Comey's credibility as a key witness. The book, in which Comey compares Trump to the Mafia bosses he once prosecuted, has been met with criticism from the Republican National Committee, which launched an offensive against the book, challenging Comey's credibility.

The Republican National Committee's website features a section titled "Lyin' Comey," which includes critical tweets from Trump and comments from lawmakers questioning Comey's handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server when she was Secretary of State. Former FBI Assistant Director Ron Hosko suggested that the book may open the door to criticism that Comey wrote the dramatic account merely to enrich himself.

In an interview with ███, Comey characterized the book project as "an obligation to try to drive a healthy conversation" about leadership and ethics. He explained that the loss of a young son to a preventable infection inspired him to offer a vision of ethical leadership to people, especially young people.

Comey defended the timing of the book's publication amid the Russia inquiry and before the release of a Justice Department inspector general's examination into the FBI's handling of the Clinton email investigation, which Comey oversaw. He told ███ he did not consult Mueller about the timing of the book's publication.

In the book, Comey wrote, "It is wrong to stand idly by, or worse, to stay silent when you know better, while a president brazenly seeks to undermine public confidence in law enforcement institutions that were established to keep our leaders in check."

Patrick Cotter, a former federal prosecutor, suggested that there is less risk in limiting a witness's public statement about an ongoing case, but Comey's story has been the subject of a full, public Senate Intelligence Committee hearing. Cotter stated, "Unless there are glaring inconsistencies in his testimony and what he told the special counsel and in his book, I don't see a problem. It appears to me that what I know about the book is that he is sharing his inner monologue about his interactions with the president that he already has testified about. He's not changing the facts."

Cotter added that any argument related to a financial incentive could fall flat. "As far as I know, everybody does what they do for money. I thought the Republicans were in favor of capitalism," Cotter said. "In a perfect world, you would put witnesses in a cryogenic chamber and only let them out when it's time to testify. That's not the world we live in."

Title: Gina Haspel Confirmed as First Female Director of CIA, Despite Controversy Over Past Role in Interrogation Program

Article:

WASHINGTON (AP) - Gina Haspel, a veteran intelligence officer with a 33-year career at the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), has been confirmed as the first female director of the agency following a close Senate vote that saw six Democrats join Republicans. The 54-45 vote was the closest for a CIA nominee in the nearly seven decades that a Senate nod has been required.

Haspel, 61, is a native of Kentucky but grew up around the world as the daughter of an Air Force serviceman. She has worked in Africa, Europe, and classified locations globally and was tapped as deputy director of the CIA last year. Haspel worked under former CIA director Mike Pompeo until President Donald Trump moved him to secretary of state.

Haspel's confirmation was backed by many in the CIA rank-and-file and was robustly supported by senior intelligence officials, including six former CIA directors and three former national intelligence directors. National Intelligence Director Dan Coats said Haspel has integrity and both frontline and executive intelligence expertise.

However, Haspel's opponents argued that it was not right to promote someone who supervised a covert detention site in Thailand where terror suspects were waterboarded, an interrogation technique that simulates drowning. They said the U.S. needed to slam closed what was one of the CIA's darkest chapters that tainted America's image with allies abroad.

Several senators said Haspel was not forthcoming in answering questions about her role in the torture program or the CIA's decision to destroy video-taped evidence of the sessions. They also had questions about her rejection of the now-banned techniques.

Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said in a floor speech that Haspel "offered up almost the classic Washington non-apology." He asked how the Senate could take seriously Haspel's "conversion on torture?"

Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said the world was watching the confirmation vote, which he called a "referendum on torture." He said the so-called "enhanced interrogation techniques" the CIA used at black sites, including slamming detainees against walls and confining them in coffin-shaped boxes, amounted to "government-sanctioned torture."

Haspel has vowed never to restart such a program and says her "strong moral compass" would prevent her from carrying out any presidential order she found objectionable. That was enough to coax some senators into the "yes" column. However, Leahy said he still questioned her judgment and lamented that she has never publicly condemned torture as "immoral."

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., said the nomination was not just about Haspel, but the U.S. grappling with its past mistakes.

"The bottom line is this: No one has ever been held accountable for the torture program and I do not believe those who were intimately involved in it deserve to lead the agency," Feinstein said before casting her vote against Haspel.

Since Trump nominated Haspel, her confirmation has been clouded by debate over the CIA's former interrogation program. A protester in the Senate visitor gallery briefly disrupted speeches ahead of the vote with shouts against the CIA.

Three Republicans opposed her: Sen. John McCain of Arizona, who is battling cancer and did not vote; Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky; and Sen. Jeff Flake of Arizona. Six Democrats, however, were heartened by her pledge to never restart harsh interrogation programs, even if Trump requested. They said they voted for Haspel because they thought her experience was essential in confronting today's threats from U.S. adversaries like Russia, North Korea, China, and Iran.

Among Democrats supporting Haspel were several up for re-election this fall in states where Trump is popular, including Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Sen. Joe Donnelly of Indiana, and Sen. Bill Nelson in Florida. Also voting yes were Sen. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Sen. Mark Warner of Virginia, the ranking member of the intelligence committee.

"This has not been an easy decision," Warner said, adding that he'd met and talked with Haspel many times in the past several weeks. He said he's convinced that Haspel could and would stand up to Trump, who has voiced support for waterboarding and has said "torture works."

After the vote, human rights groups quickly issued statements denouncing the confirmation and the now-defunct program.

"The Senate has now rewarded that atrocious conduct by promoting someone that reportedly administered it to lead one of the government's most powerful agencies," said Daphne Eviatar at Amnesty International USA.

Title: U.S. Job Creation Falls Short in May, Significantly Impacting June Fed Rate Hike Prospects

Article:

NEW YORK -- The U.S. job market took a significant hit in May, with the creation of only 38,000 jobs, far below the expected 160,000 new positions. This marked the worst month for job creation since September 2010.

The Federal Reserve, led by Chairwoman Janet Yellen, had been signaling a potential interest rate hike in the coming months, with June as a possible candidate. However, the disappointing jobs report has led to a reevaluation of these plans.

Steven Ricchiuto, chief economist at MSUSA, described the jobs report as "horrible." Chris Gaffney, president of world markets at EverBank, called it "very weak." Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, referred to the jobs number as a "bombshell."

The weak job creation in May has led to a near-zero chance of a Fed rate hike at the June meeting, which concludes on June 15. "This is the weakest number of workers added in almost six years," Gaffney said via email.

Before the jobs report was released, the odds of a June hike stood at 19%. After the data, these odds plummeted to about 4%, according to CME Group's futures markets.

While the chances of a July hike have also decreased, from close to 60% to 34%, professional investors are not yet ruling out a hike in July. The market reaction was swift, with stocks dipping, bond yields falling, and the U.S. dollar weakening as the Fed's rate-hike timetable gets pushed back.

The unemployment rate did decrease to 4.7%, but this was primarily due to "another big drop in the labor force," according to Paul Ashworth, chief U.S. economist at Capital Economics. Yellen is scheduled to speak on Monday, and Wall Street will be closely listening for insights into the Fed's thinking.

"Yellen should provide more insight on the Fed's thinking Monday," Ashworth said via email.

Title: Facebook's Removal of Pages Sparks Controversy, Raises Concerns Over Foreign Meddling in U.S. Politics

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and raised concerns, Facebook has removed 32 pages from its platform, citing "coordinated inauthentic behavior" that may be linked to Russia. Among the pages taken down was an event page for a counter-protest to a white nationalist march in Washington D.C., organized by Black Lives Matter DC.

The counter-protest event, titled "No Unite the Right 2 - DC," was being organized before the first page was set up. However, the removal of the page has caused organizers to fear a potential backlash, with organizer April Goggans stating, "Our participation may take a hit because people are trying to find out what's legit and what's not. We've had to prove we exist."

Facebook's statement suggests that administrators of a page called "Resisters" were connected with those from other legitimate pages, who helped drum up support for the protest. However, Andrew Batcher, an organizer for the Shut It Down DC coalition, stated that the event page created by "Resisters" was taken over and controlled by "a lot of real people doing real work." Batcher also noted that he has not seen any evidence that any administrator for the "Resisters" page was a "bad actor."

While Facebook did not directly link the 32 pages in question to Russia, lawmakers on Capitol Hill have done so. A spokesman for Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley stated that Facebook had informed his office "that a limited group of Russian actors has attempted to spread disinformation using its platform, and that the affected groups are affiliated with the political left."

The issue highlights a broader difficulty social media sites now face in identifying Russian actors. While the intelligence community has concluded that Russia meddled in the 2016 election through online activities, Russia's meddling has not been limited to pro-Trump activities, especially this election cycle.

The New York Times reported that Facebook also detected coordinated activity around the #AbolishICE campaign, a left-wing movement advocating for the abolition of Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The issue underscores a potential threat to the integrity of political discourse on social media platforms, with both sides of the political aisle potentially being influenced by foreign actors.

The controversy comes as the Trump administration continues to grapple with allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 election. In February, President Trump approvingly retweeted a statement by Facebook's Vice President of Ads, Rob Goldman, who had written that the majority of Russian spending on ads occurred after the 2016 election, and that swaying the election was not the main goal of those ads. However, Goldman later clarified that "the Russian campaign was certainly in favor of Trump."

The New York Times also reported that Russia used Facebook groups for a wide range of causes, including groups such as United Muslims of America, Blacktivist, and Secured Borders. The use of such groups raises concerns about the potential for foreign actors to manipulate public opinion and sow discord in the United States.

With the president still playing clean-up after appearing to initially accept Vladimir Putin's denial of election meddling during their summit last month, the administration is making clear they accept the prior U.S. intelligence findings and take the threat seriously. At a White House press briefing last Thursday, officials warned that a disinformation campaign from Moscow is ongoing. The administration's stance underscores the need for social media platforms to be vigilant in identifying and combating foreign meddling in U.S. politics.

Title: Republican Representative Cole Advocates for Bipartisan Approach to Tax Rates, Urges Early Agreement on Bush Tax Cuts

Article:

In a private meeting on Tuesday, Republican Representative ███ called on his colleagues to vote to extend the Bush tax rates for all but the highest earners before the end of the year, suggesting a bipartisan approach to avoid the fiscal cliff.

Cole, a Republican from Oklahoma, told POLITICO in an interview that he believes such a vote would not violate the anti-tax pledge by Grover Norquist and that he is not alone in his stance within Republican circles. During a meeting of the House GOP whip team earlier in the day, he argued that Republicans would strengthen their position by joining hands with President Barack Obama to give most taxpayers a "early Christmas present" by ensuring their taxes don't increase on January 1.

Cole's position is notable given his reputation as a staunch Republican and adherent to party orthodoxy. He has served as chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee and held other official posts within the party. Cole's proposal might also provide cover for other Republicans looking to make an agreement to avoid the fiscal cliff.

"I think we ought to take the 98 percent deal right now," Cole said, referring to freezing income tax rates for all but the top 2 percent of earners. "It doesn't mean I agree with raising the top 2. I don't."

Instead, Cole suggested that Republicans should fight the president over tax rates for the top earners after everyone else is taken care of. This approach, he said, would remove the president's argument that Republicans are holding up tax cuts for all but the top earners.

"Some people think that's our leverage in the debate. It's the Democrats' leverage in the debate," Cole said.

Cole indicated that he is likely to support his leadership when a package is put on the floor, but he also noted that there are other lawmakers in his camp, as well as others who have been willing to listen. He was adamant that his approach would not violate the Norquist pledge, which binds signatories not to join any effort to raise income tax rates. Rather than raising taxes, he said, Republicans would be voting to lower them for most people and do nothing—which would result in an increase—for the rest.

"I don't see that as a violation of my pledge," he said.

Title: Supreme Court's Conservative Majority Leans on Textualism in Key Decisions

Article:

WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court's conservative justices have been controlling most of the closely divided cases this term by adhering to the words written by Congress, as they meticulously define terms such as "for," "shall," "any," and "other," among others. This approach, known as textualism, has resulted in a series of 5-4 decisions written by Justices Neil Gorsuch, Clarence Thomas, and Samuel Alito.

The justices have settled challenges involving the rights of workers, immigrants, prisoners, and patent owners by interpreting the statutes under review literally. This has led to a series of decisions that rely on "textualism" – letting the statutes speak for themselves.

Paul Clement, former U.S. solicitor general who has argued more than 90 cases at the Supreme Court, notes that this is a shift in the terms of the debate. "You don't want to walk into the court without a textualist argument," Clement says.

Justice Gorsuch, the newest justice now entering his second year on the court, had promised during his Senate confirmation in 2017 to "try to understand what the words on the page mean, not import words that come from us."

Last week, Gorsuch refused to read into the National Labor Relations Act any rules for handling legal disputes under the Federal Arbitration Act. Gorsuch's opinion for the court held that employers can insist that workers settle labor disputes individually through arbitration.

In another 5-4 decision written by Gorsuch last month, the court said an administrative board created to review patents can not pick and choose which parts of a patent to review.

In February, Gorsuch's 5-4 opinion for the court held that under federal law, prisoners who win civil rights suits must pay up to 25% of their award "to satisfy" attorneys' fees. Lower court judges can not limit a prisoner's contribution, the court said.

In dissent, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said the law lets judges limit the amount prisoners must pay. The phrase "to satisfy" does not necessarily mean in full, she said, citing other contexts ranging from credit card payments to college course credits.

Supreme Court experts say Gorsuch's addition has merely returned the court to Scalia's brand of textualism. "The court is no more textualist than it was when Scalia was on the court," says Irving Gornstein, executive director of the Supreme Court Institute at Georgetown University Law Center. "The only thing that has changed is that one textualist has been replaced by another."

However, Jeffrey Fisher, co-director of the Stanford Law School Supreme Court Litigation Clinic, says Gorsuch "seems to be trying to put some fresh wind in the sails of textualism. And it seems he’s having some success."

Justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas also stuck to the letter of the law in recent 5-4 rulings. Alito ruled that illegal immigrants can be detained indefinitely while their cases are reviewed, rather than given intermittent bail hearings.

In a second case involving workers' rights, Thomas's 5-4 ruling found that service advisers at car dealerships can be excluded from the Fair Labor Standards Act's wage and hour protections because their duties are akin to salesmen and partsmen, who are specifically excluded.

Elizabeth Wydra, president of the liberal Constitutional Accountability Center, says conservatives often accuse liberals of reading into statutes what they want them to say. The court's conservatives, she says, also are guilty of that.

"There’s going to be a battle about what is actual textualism," Wydra says. "And the liberals aren’t giving up that fight."

Title: President Trump Signs Executive Order to Address Social Media Regulation and Liability Protections

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and debate, President Donald Trump has announced his intention to sign an executive order on Thursday, aiming to regulate social media and technology companies. The decision follows a fact-check by Twitter on one of the president's tweets regarding mail-in voting.

The order is based on section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, a provision that aims to protect free speech by shielding providers from liability for the content they host. The section states, "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider."

The president's executive order seeks to add regulations to section 230, aiming to limit the liability protections for companies that editorialize or censor content or speech. The president also plans to instruct the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to act as a check on reported political bias.

President Trump's tweet about mail-in voting was fact-checked by Twitter, while the president has noted that the platform has left propaganda from the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) unchecked until recently.

The White House tweeted, "Today, I am signing an executive order to protect and uphold the free speech and rights of the American people." Bloomberg QuickTake reported that Trump described social media companies as currently receiving "an unprecedented liability shield."

The executive order is expected to face legal challenges in court regarding its constitutionality. The president has partnered with Attorney General Bill Barr in this effort. AG Barr contends that the new order does not repeal section 230, but rather an accountability measure to ensure that the law is interpreted correctly.

Section 230 has been a subject of criticism from both Republicans and Democrats, who argue that the law allows social media companies to avoid the responsibility to ensure truth is present online. The executive order is expected to be a significant development in the ongoing debate about the role and responsibility of social media companies in the digital age.

Title: Immigration Overhaul: A Long and Contentious Road Ahead Amidst Cautious Optimism

Article:

The ongoing debate over an immigration law overhaul remains a complex and challenging issue, with bipartisan supporters expressing cautious optimism but facing significant hurdles in the Republican-controlled House of Representatives. In June, a comprehensive immigration bill, which included a 13-year path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country and stricter border security measures, passed the Senate with bipartisan support. However, this legislation has largely stalled in the House, where Speaker John Boehner has rejected negotiations with the Senate over its comprehensive bill.

Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, a key negotiator of the Senate bill, acknowledged the challenging road ahead, stating, "This is obviously a long, hard road, but I think since August, the number on the other side vehemently opposed has stayed the same, the number who think it should go forward has grown, and numbers in the wide middle are less opposed than they used to be. But that doesn't guarantee an outcome one way or another."

Republican Party leaders, backed by business groups, have emphasized the necessity of an overhaul to repair their political position with Latino and other immigrant voters. Former Chief of Staff to Speaker Boehner, Barry Jackson, is now consulting for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which supports an overhaul that expands high-technology visas and guest worker programs.

Despite the importance of the issue, immigration is less of a concern during midterm elections, when immigrants are less likely to vote, and House members in safe districts are somewhat insulated from the influence of more moderate swing voters. The biggest threats to Republicans often come from primary challenges from more conservative candidates who argue that changing the immigration status of undocumented immigrants amounts to amnesty for lawbreakers.

Representative John Carter, Republican of Texas and one of the Gang of Eight House members who attempted to forge a bipartisan overhaul, told Capitol Hill newspaper Roll Call that an election year is not the time to press forward. "Immigration is a very, very contentious issue," he said. The future of the immigration overhaul remains uncertain, with both supporters and opponents maintaining their positions, and the political landscape potentially influencing the outcome.

Title: President Obama's Hawaiian Vacation: A Luxurious Retreat Amidst Official Duties

Article:

During his 16-day Hawaiian vacation, President Barack Obama took a brief moment from his leisurely activities to tweet about Obamacare, marking one of the few visible acts of official business during his winter retreat. The president's winter recess, filled with golf, fine dining, snorkeling, and a private zoo visit, has been akin to a dream getaway for many.

Despite the idyllic setting, the president's aides confirm that he remains diligent, receiving daily presidential briefings, including the "threat matrix" from intelligence agencies, and engaging in conference calls about global hotspots. The president also signed a few bills, participated in discussions about contentious legislation, and received updates on terrorist attacks in Russia.

The Obamas' luxurious living in a $3,500-per-day beach house in Kailua, Oahu, is being paid for privately, although taxpayers cover the cost of the first family's travel on Air Force One. The rental home costs $56,000, while the flights on Air Force One, which cost over $180,000 per hour, amount to a couple of million dollars.

The vacation has been an expensive affair for taxpayers, with hundreds of federal workers joining in, including White House staffers and the Secret Service security detail. According to watchdog.org, the government rented at least seven homes in the area, costing taxpayers over $183,750, with the overall cost estimated to reach $4 million.

In comparison to the 2012 vacation, which cost taxpayers at least $7.2 million due to a "fiscal cliff" negotiation, this year's Hawaiian vacation has been more tranquil. The president has engaged in various activities, such as golf, gym workouts, family hikes, beach trips, and snorkeling. The Obamas also had the Honolulu Zoo all to themselves for a visit on Thursday.

The first couple has met with U.S. troops once but have not attended church services, even for Christmas. Reporters and photographers, who have spent tens of thousands of dollars to cover the president's vacation, have been kept at a distance, but were allowed to observe the president during his New Year's Eve shopping center outing and his golf outing with New Zealand Prime Minister John Key.

As President Obama returns to Washington next week, he will once again face the challenges of his office, with the decisions likely to get tougher. The president, who is known for his wit, quipped during a golf outing, "I guess I should have chipped it, after all."

Title: Washington D.C. Braces for Second Unite the Right Rally as Businesses Prepare to Refuse Service to Participants

Article:

As the second Unite the Right rally approaches in Washington D.C., white supremacists and white nationalists may face challenges in finding transportation and dining options due to the stance taken by various businesses and ride-sharing services. The rally, scheduled for Sunday, coincides with the one-year anniversary of the violent white supremacist events in Charlottesville, Virginia.

In Charlottesville, police have taken precautions, blocking off streets and mobilizing hundreds of officers downtown. A group of Antifa protestors marched through the city Saturday afternoon, carrying a flag that read "Antifascist action."

In preparation for the rally near the White House, Uber and Lyft have informed drivers that they have the right to refuse service to passengers who harass or threaten them. The Restaurant Association of Metropolitan Washington has also sent out a toolkit to inform restaurateurs of their legal rights to refuse service to white nationalists and other political fringe groups.

Airbnb has previously threatened to ban users who participate in the rally. In a statement shared with Fox News, the company confirmed that it would take appropriate action against users who behave in a manner that is antithetical to the Airbnb Community Commitment, which may include removal from the platform.

Rally organizer, Jason Kessler, has obtained a permit for Lafayette Park across from the White House, expecting 400 supporters to attend. The first "Unite The Right" rally in Charlottesville on Aug. 12, 2017, resulted in violent clashes between white supremacists and counter-protesters, with one person being killed when a white supremacist drove into a crowd of counter-protesters.

Several restaurant owners in Washington D.C. have stated that they are prepared to refuse service to those participating in the rally or to close their establishments altogether. Dan Simons, owner of Founding Farmers, told The Washingtonian, "Our mentality is we’re going to protect each other. This is our city. Our house. Our people."

Ellen Kassoff Gray, owner of Equinox restaurant near the White House, also expressed her intention to refuse service to those who espouse hate. "I’ll proudly stay open and serve those who are respectful and kind. But being a Jewish restaurant owner and having a pro-Nazi group come to town, would I refuse service? Yes, I would," she told The Washingtonian.

As for the Proud Boys, verified accounts belonging to the group and its founder, Gavin McInnes, were suspended by Twitter for violating the platform's policy against "violent extremist groups," according to The Guardian. A number of non-verified accounts for various Proud Boys chapters were also suspended, the paper reported.

Title: President Trump Hosts "Celebration of America" as Eagles Disinvitation Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, President Donald Trump has opted to host a "Celebration of America" event on Tuesday, following his decision to disinvite the Philadelphia Eagles, the Super Bowl champions, from a White House event. The move comes amid the ongoing controversy surrounding national anthem protests.

The White House event will feature the United States Marine Band and the United States Army Chorus, with the National Anthem and other patriotic music set to be played at 3 P.M. Trump announced the event on Twitter, stating, "We will proudly be playing the National Anthem and other wonderful music celebrating our Country today at 3 P.M. The White House, with the United States Marine Band and the United States Army Chorus. Honoring America! NFL, no escaping to Locker Rooms!"

The White House's decision to disinvite the entire team marks the end of speculation over whether the Eagles would visit the White House in some capacity. The team reportedly wanted to send a small group of players. Trump's decision to rescind the invitation followed his tweet late Monday, stating, "The Philadelphia Eagles Football Team was invited to the White House. Unfortunately, only a small number of players decided to come, and we canceled the event. Staying in the Locker Room for the playing of our National Anthem is as disrespectful to our country as kneeling. Sorry!"

Philadelphia Mayor Jim Kenney responded to Trump's move, stating, "Disinviting them from the White House only proves that our president is not a true patriot, but a fragile egomaniac obsessed with crowd size and afraid of the embarrassment of throwing a party to which no one wants to attend."

Last month, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell announced the league would fine teams and league personnel who do not "stand and show respect for the flag and the anthem." Goodell said the league unanimously agreed to the vote, though San Francisco 49ers owner Jed York abstained. The new overhaul does allow players to remain in the locker room for the anthem.

Trump's Eagles decision and his Tuesday tweet reflect ongoing tension between his White House and players protesting police violence by sitting out the national anthem. The President also used his Twitter account Tuesday to note past events the White House has held with other championship teams. Trump tweeted, "We have had many Championship teams recently at the White House including the Chicago Cubs, Houston Astros, Pittsburgh Penguins, New England Patriots, Alabama and Clemson National Champions, and many others. National Anthem & more great music today at 3:00 P.M."

Title: House of Representatives Prepares to Sue Justice Department over Fast and Furious Documents

Article:

The United States House of Representatives is preparing to file a lawsuit against the Justice Department in an attempt to compel the release of additional documents related to the controversial Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation. Speaker of the House, John Boehner (R-Ohio), announced the impending legal action on CBS's "Face the Nation" on Sunday.

The decision to sue comes after the House approved two resolutions last Thursday, which found Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress for failing to provide further documents to congressional investigators. The criminal contempt resolution opens the possibility for the House to call on the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia to bring the case before a grand jury. However, Deputy Attorney General James Cole informed Boehner in a letter on Friday that the agency would not prosecute, stating that Holder's failure to release the documents does not constitute a crime.

The civil contempt resolution, on the other hand, grants the House the ability to ask a court to compel the Justice Department to hand over the documents. President Obama has already asserted executive privilege over the documents in question.

The investigation into the Fast and Furious operation, led by GOP Rep. Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, has been ongoing for 16 months. The non-defunct Operation Fast and Furious was run out of an Arizona field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), which is under the Justice Department.

The operation involved putting roughly 2,000 assault guns into the hands of arms dealers, then allowing the guns to cross the U.S.-Mexico border with the expectation they would resurface at crime scenes and lead agents to organizers of Mexican drug cartels. Two of the weapons were found at the site of the 2010 shooting death of U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

White House Chief of Staff Jack Lew stated on "Fox News Sunday" that the Justice Department's decision not to prosecute Holder was based on a Reagan administration memo and that the House's continued efforts are "political" and a "fishing expedition."

Title: James Clapper Criticizes President Trump's Openness to Foreign Opposition Research, Cites Double Standard in Dossier Case

Article:

In the aftermath of George Stephanopoulos' exclusive interview with President Donald Trump, former Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, appeared on Anderson Cooper 360 to discuss the president's comments regarding his willingness to listen to foreign opposition research. During the interview, Clapper and Cooper focused on Trump's statement about considering information provided by a foreign country, particularly a foreign adversary, disregarding the potential for disinformation.

"It's certainly interesting. I've run out of adjectives to describe my reaction to this. Incredible, amazing, stunning, and disturbing that the president would advocate for this use of accepting information provided by a foreign country, notably a foreign adversary, while completely overlooking the fact that this could, will be, probably would be, disinformation," Clapper told Cooper. "In other words, completely phony. And to endorse that, and in doing so endorse, undercut the FBI, and its director, it's just incredible. I can't get over the duplicity of it."

Clapper's comments come as a response to Trump's statement that he would be open to receiving opposition research from foreign entities. Clapper argued that this stance could potentially undermine the FBI and its director, especially considering the potential for disinformation.

However, Clapper also pointed out a perceived double standard in the handling of opposition research. "Wait a second. We have a double standard here. It's okay for the FBI to run with the Steele dossier, despite it being compiled by a former British spy, someone who could arguably be a 'foreign influencer,' but it's not okay for a campaign to even think about hearing out the information another country has?" Clapper asked.

Clapper argued that the criticism of the infamous dossier, compiled by former MI6 officer Christopher Steele, is due to the FBI's acceptance of the document as fact. "Here's all this criticism about the infamous dossier, and you can't use it because it's not valid. You can't accept it. That's, and in this case, okay. And we're looking in the future here. We're not talking about the past," Clapper added.

Clapper also addressed the issue of political motivations in the handling of the dossier. "The problem conservatives have with the dossier is that the FBI didn't vet what was in the dossier. They accepted it as fact. Opposition research is the norm. It happens in every campaign during every election. Did Hillary Clinton have a right to do oppo research on Trump? Absolutely. The government, however, has an obligation to independently verify what was in the document, especially when we're talking about obtaining FISA warrants based on said information," Clapper stated.

Clapper also criticized the media for not independently verifying the information in the dossier, stating that they accepted it as fact because it was damning evidence against Trump. "Don't be fooled. There were political motives in not vetting Steele's information," Clapper said.

According to Cooper, this is Trump's "clarion call" for information from foreign countries, particularly Russia, in the upcoming 2020 election. "They're [Russia] going to repeat what they did in 2016. They're going to repeat it in 2020," Clapper said. "And now, what President Trump has done, is encourage them to do so. Again, it's just, it's just stunning."

Title: Planned Parenthood Affiliates Face Repayment of $80 Million in PPP Loans Due to Ineligibility

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, thirty-seven Planned Parenthood affiliates have been notified by the Small Business Administration (SBA) that they must return a total of $80 million in loans received from the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), as they were ineligible for the coronavirus stimulus payouts. The SBA has stated that affiliates of larger organizations with more than 500 employees, such as the Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PFFA), which has over 600 employees, are not eligible for PPP distributions.

One such affiliate, Planned Parenthood of Metropolitan Washington (PPMW), will receive a letter stating that although it self-certified that it was eligible for a $1,328,000 PPP loan in accordance with the SBA’s affiliation rules, it will need to return the money. This request for funds came just months after PPMW’s president and CEO, Laura Meyers, promised to turn down federal funds in response to the Trump administration's ban on Planned Parenthood clinics making abortion referrals if they wanted to continue receiving federal funds.

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), who serves as chairman of the Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship, has called for an immediate investigation into the matter. Rubio stated, "There is no ambiguity in the legislation that passed or public record around its passage that organizations such as Planned Parenthood, whose parent organization has close to half a billion dollars in assets, is not eligible for the Paycheck Protection Program."

In 2018-2019, Planned Parenthood reported a record-high number of abortions and government funding. At the same time, Planned Parenthood claimed that abortion constituted just a small percentage – 4 percent in 2018-2019 – of its services, and that federal funds did not go directly to abortions.

The SBA warned of "severe penalties" for incorrect or false eligibility certifications by PPP recipients, including criminal or civil sanctions if the SBA determined borrowers made knowingly false statements. The SBA letter explained that PPFA affiliates were clearly covered by the PPP affiliate rules, as PPFA's bylaws require a certification by the PPFA board and govern each affiliate by written bylaws that conform to PPFA policies.

The largest single government loan was a $7.5 million allotment to the Planned Parenthood of Orange and San Bernardino Counties in California. One Planned Parenthood affiliate received a loan but declined it. Canceled or returned funds can be used during future PPP rounds.

Republicans have strongly resisted reported efforts from some Democrats to push abortion-related spending amid the pandemic. In March, The Daily Caller reported House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) tried to include federal funding for abortion in the coronavirus stimulus bill. Multiple senior White House officials told the outlet that speaking to Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, Pelosi sought a provision for up to $1 billion to "reimburse laboratory claims." This might set a precedent for health-related spending without the protections of the Hyde Amendment, a compromise restricting federal funds for abortion in most cases.

Title: Alabama Senate Passes Controversial Abortion Ban Bill, Sending Measure to Governor's Desk

The Alabama Senate on Tuesday evening approved a bill that imposes stringent restrictions on abortions, with the measure now heading to Governor Kay Ivey's (R) desk for potential signing into law. The legislation, which passed by a 25-6 vote, would effectively ban abortions in almost all instances, including for victims of rape and incest, and would only allow the procedure if necessary to save a mother's life.

The bill's proponents hope the legislation, along with similar restrictions in other states, will instigate a Supreme Court challenge that could potentially overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. State Rep. Terri Collins (R), who sponsored the bill, told The Washington Post that the exceptions were intentionally left out to create a strong enough law to trigger a federal court battle.

The legislation was temporarily tabled last week due to a heated argument on the Senate floor after the exception for cases of rape and incest was removed from the bill. If signed into law, anyone performing an abortion could face 10 to 99 years in prison, but no criminal charges would be brought against a person undergoing the procedure.

The bill is the most restrictive abortion law in the country, with 16 states having passed or considering abortion bans once a fetal heartbeat is detected, about six weeks into pregnancy. Four states have approved so-called heartbeat abortion laws.

The pro-abortion rights group NARAL Pro-Choice America swiftly condemned Tuesday's vote, expressing concern that the current Supreme Court composition puts Roe v. Wade at risk following the confirmation of President Trump's two nominees.

"Alabama just passed a law that is a total ban on abortion, criminalizing the act and punishing women and doctors," NARAL Pro-Choice America President Ilyse Hogue said in a statement. "Anti-choice Republicans no longer even pretend to respect the law or the women that it protects."

State Sen. Vivian Figures (D) told The Washington Post before the bill was considered, "If I were them, I would be making plans to leave Alabama. Who is going to stay in a state like this?"

The passage of the bill has sparked heated debates and concerns about the future of reproductive rights in the United States.

Title: Inside Syria's Capital: A Visit to the Controversial Sayida Zeinab Shrine Amid Ongoing Conflict

Article:

In the heart of Damascus, the capital city of Syria, a visit to the Sayida Zeinab shrine offers a unique perspective on the country's ongoing conflict. The shrine, a significant religious site for all Muslims, is particularly revered by the Shiite sect and is surrounded by guards due to fears of potential destruction by Sunni extremist rebels.

Accompanied by a local doctor, who requested anonymity, we navigated through the city, passing bombed-out buildings and military checkpoints. The doctor, a longtime resident and worker at a nearby hospital, expressed his concern for the shrine, citing the potential threat from Sunni extremist rebels who, he believes, do not respect religious sites and follow Wahhabi ideologies.

Upon reaching the shrine, we were greeted by a series of military checkpoints and a bustling street leading to the golden-domed shrine, adorned with elaborate blue tiles. Inside, we found a courtyard filled with words echoing the support for Assad's government, marking the deaths of three men who were martyrs in the war.

The guards of the shrine include Lebanese allies of Assad, longtime veterans of the Lebanese Shiite group Hezbollah, and local men, such as a former sheep dealer who joined a volunteer defense force. The doctor, our guide, took us through the golden dome and into a room of brilliant light, covered with mirrored tiles. Pilgrims touched the tomb of Sayida Zeinab, and we spoke with a young mother who expressed her support for Assad's government.

Leaving the shrine, we walked down the battle-scarred street behind it and arrived at a local hospital. There, we met again with the doctor who shared his thoughts on the Syrian people's sentiments towards President Assad. He stated that while a significant portion of the population either strongly supports or vehemently opposes Assad, the majority, comprising 60%, loves their country and does not want it to be destroyed.

The doctor, while not expressing undying loyalty to Assad, expressed disapproval of the rebels. He stated that he supports any revolution that aims to improve the country and establish democracy but disapproves of those that would destroy the country. In Syria's elections, Assad has always been the only candidate, making it a yes-no referendum on his rule. The challenge for Syria's rebels is to present a plausible alternative—a new system of government in which terrified Syrians might believe.

Title: Afghan Immigrant Ahmad Khan Rahami Arrested in Connection with New York and New Jersey Bombings

Article:

In a significant development, Ahmad Khan Rahami, a 28-year-old Afghan immigrant, was apprehended on Monday following a shootout with police in Linden, New Jersey. Rahami, a naturalized U.S. citizen, is suspected of being involved in a series of bombings that occurred in New York City and a New Jersey shore town over the weekend.

Rahami, who underwent surgery for a gunshot wound to his leg, was discovered sleeping in a bar doorway and was wounded in a subsequent gun battle with police.
