Two officers were also injured but are not in critical condition. The arrest came hours after authorities issued a bulletin and photo of Rahami, who lived with his family in an apartment in Elizabeth, New Jersey, above a fried-chicken restaurant owned by his father.

U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara, the chief federal prosecutor in New York, stated that New Jersey officials will likely bring charges against Rahami for the police officers' shooting, while federal authorities consider their own charges. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio described the incident as an "act of terror."

The bombings began on Saturday night when a shrapnel-packed pressure-cooker bomb exploded in New York's Chelsea section, wounding 29 people, none seriously. An unexploded pressure-cooker bomb was found blocks away. Earlier that day, a pipe bomb exploded in Seaside Park, New Jersey, before a charity race to benefit Marines. No one was injured. On Sunday night, five explosive devices were discovered in a trash can at an Elizabeth train station. Investigators have not publicly tied Rahami to these bombs, and they are still gathering evidence.

With Rahami's arrest, officials stated that there are no indications of more bombs or suspects to find, though they cautioned that they are still working to understand Rahami's connections. His motive remains unclear, according to New York Police Commissioner James O'Neill.

William Sweeney Jr., the FBI's assistant director in New York, stated that there are no indications Rahami was on law enforcement's radar at the time of the bombings. As for how investigators zeroed in on him as a suspect, three law enforcement officials said the clues included a fingerprint lifted from one of the New York sites and "clear as day" surveillance video from the bombing scene that helped identify Rahami. The officials spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the case.

Five people were pulled over on Sunday night in a vehicle associated with Rahami, but were questioned and released. At least one of Rahami's relatives was in the car, which appeared headed toward Kennedy Airport in New York after coming from New Jersey.

Linden Mayor Derek Armstead stated that the break in the case came late Monday morning, when the owner of a bar reported someone asleep in his doorway. A police officer went to investigate and recognized the man as Rahami. Rahami pulled a gun and shot the officer, who was wearing a bulletproof vest, in the torso, and more officers joined in a gun battle that spilled into the street.

The Council on American-Islamic Relations, a national Muslim advocacy group, welcomed Rahami's arrest. The organization and the Afghan Embassy in Washington condemned the bombings. The arrest came as President Barack Obama was in New York on a previously scheduled visit for a meeting of the U.N. General Assembly. He called on Americans to "show the world we will never give in to fear."

Rahami lived with his family on a busy street a few miles from the Newark airport. The building that houses the family's restaurant and home was cordoned off when an Associated Press reporter visited. Rahami's father, Mohammad, and two of Rahami's brothers sued the city of Elizabeth in 2011 after it passed an ordinance requiring their restaurant, First American Fried Chicken, to close early because of complaints from neighbors that it was a late-night nuisance. The lawsuit was terminated in 2012 after Mohammad Rahami pleaded guilty to blocking police from enforcing the restrictions on the restaurant.

Ryan McCann, of Elizabeth, said that he often ate at the restaurant and recently began seeing the younger Rahami working there more. "He's always in there. He's a very friendly guy, that's what's so scary. It's hard when it's home," McCann said.

On Sunday, a federal law enforcement official stated that the Chelsea bomb contained a residue of Tannerite, an explosive often used for target practice that can be picked up in many sporting goods stores. One of the five devices found at the Elizabeth train station exploded while a bomb squad robot tried to disarm it. No one was hurt.

Two homeless men grabbed a backpack left on a trash can near the Elizabeth train station, only to discover it contained several apparent pipe bombs. They quickly reported the find to police, said Elizabeth Mayor Christian Bollwage. On Saturday, two men walking down a street in New York saw a suitcase on a sidewalk, opened it, discarded the pressure cooker they found inside, and walked off with the bag. Later that evening, after the blast in Chelsea, state troopers found the unexploded device.

Title: "West Virginia Governor Invites Virginia Counties to Secede Amidst Political Divide"

Article:

In a move that has been dubbed "Vexit" by the Richmond Times-Dispatch, West Virginia's Republican Governor Jim Justice has extended an invitation to Virginia counties discontent with their liberal state government in Richmond to secede and join West Virginia. The proposal was made at a press conference held with Liberty University President Jerry Falwell, Jr. at a community college in Martinsburg, West Virginia on Tuesday.

"If you're not happy where you're at, come on down," Justice said. "If you're not truly happy where you are, we stand with open arms to take you from Virginia or anywhere you may be. We stand strongly behind the Second Amendment, and we stand strongly for the unborn."

The invitation comes amidst growing discontent in Virginia, particularly among conservatives, following the Democratic takeover of the state government last fall. Since taking office this month, the new Democratic administration has moved to dismantle laws protecting gun rights and abortion restrictions, as reported by ███ News and The Wall Street Journal. The administration is also proposing to repeal the state's 70-year old right-to-work law, a move that would force workers to join a union, pay dues, and deny them the freedom to choose whether to be part of a union or not.

Thousands of gun owners concerned about their freedoms gathered for a rally on the Capitol grounds in Richmond on January 20th, lobbying against the proposed legislation. Fearing the loss of their freedoms, citizens have flooded city council meetings all over the Old Dominion, resulting in 91 of Virginia's 95 counties declaring themselves Second Amendment Sanctuaries.

The idea of Virginia counties seceding to another state is not a new one. In 1863, West Virginia became a state formed from western counties of Virginia that opposed Virginia's decision to secede from the United States. West Virginia is the only state created by seceding from a Confederate state.

When asked for a reaction to West Virginia's proposal that Virginia counties join their state, Virginia Democrat Governor Ralph Northam's office responded, "It sounds like it's an election year in West Virginia." Virginia Senate Majority Leader Dick Saslaw (D) described the secession proposal as "preposterous," suggesting West Virginia should focus on fixing its high poverty rate.

Minority leader in the House of Delegates, Todd Gilbert, told ███ News many Virginians across the state are not happy with the Democrat agenda, but Republicans are not retreating from the political fray in Richmond. Despite this, he seemed to appreciate West Virginia's offer.

"We're nowhere near done fighting for our values here in the Commonwealth," Gilbert said. "Democrats have been in power for less than two months and they're already raising taxes, working to let violent felons out of jail early, and punishing law-abiding gun owners. We think Virginians will have a significant case of buyer's remorse very soon. That being said, it's always nice to have options."

However, concern by Virginia conservatives over the leftist tilt of their state government is not going away. Jerry Falwell, Jr., President of Liberty University, described the situation in Virginia as "a tragedy in the making." He accused Democratic leaders in Richmond of elitism and radicalism, stripping away the God-given rights of Virginia citizens despite their due protections under the US Constitution.

Whether what is now part of Virginia could become a new part of West Virginia remains uncertain. According to Fox News, lawyers consulted by Falwell suggested that, if Virginians wanted to, secession would be a difficult process. Virginia counties would need to conduct petition drives, followed by a referendum. If successful, the proposal would then go before the Virginia General Assembly. University of Virginia law professor Richard Schragger told the Times-Dispatch the move was "certainly a long shot," and would require the consent of Congress and both states.

For their part, lawmakers in West Virginia have already introduced formal resolutions inviting parts of Virginia to join their state. The future of this unusual political proposal remains to be seen.

Title: Seismic Activity in North Korea Determined as Natural Event, Not Nuclear Test

Article:

Following several hours of analysis, Chinese and South Korean monitors have concluded that the seismic activity in North Korea on Saturday was a natural event and not a nuclear test. The South Korean Meteorological Administration reported a magnitude 3.0 earthquake in North Hamgyeong Province, an area where North Korea conducted its sixth and most powerful nuclear test on Sept. 3.

The Korea Meteorological Administration stated that the activity occurred in Kilju, a site near where the nuclear test took place. The seismic service in China also confirmed that the quake was a natural event, as reported by Xinhua, China's official news agency. The Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization also indicated that their initial analysis suggests the quake was unlikely to be man-made.

The seismic activity comes amidst growing tension over North Korea's nuclear and missile intentions. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has vowed to take the "highest-level" action in response to President Trump's threat to "totally destroy" North Korea over its nuclear and missile programs. North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho recently stated that Pyongyang may consider its most powerful test of a hydrogen bomb over the Pacific Ocean.

In response to escalating tensions, China announced on Saturday that it will limit exports of petroleum products to North Korea starting in October under the terms of the latest U.N. sanctions passed in response to North Korea's sixth nuclear test. The future of the North Korea-U.S. standoff remains uncertain, with both parties maintaining firm stances on their respective positions.

Title: Senate Democrats Distance Themselves from Obama as Midterm Elections Approach

Article:

As the midterm elections of 2014 approach, Senate Democrats running in competitive states are distancing themselves from President Barack Obama, who remains unpopular in many of these regions. The White House and Senate Democrats are devising a campaign strategy that aims to keep Obama's presence minimal to avoid potential complications for Democratic candidates.

According to a report by ███, the White House and Senate Democrats have been in discussions with nearly every incumbent and aspiring Democratic Senate candidate across the country. However, only a handful of candidates have expressed a desire for Obama to campaign with them.

Alaska Sen. Mark Begich, for instance, stated, "I don't care to have him campaign for me. I'd rather he come up to see where his policies aren't working. He's wrong on ANWR, we've had struggles to try to get our permits done down in the southeast for our timber industry. I want to show him how important the military is in Fairbanks."

The president's unpopularity could potentially cost Democrats the Senate, but vulnerable incumbents need the full support of the White House to maintain their majority. The White House and party leadership are exploring ways to deploy Obama and his team in a manner that minimizes complications for Democrats in states like Colorado, Georgia, or Kentucky, where his polls are unfavorable.

The White House has committed to half a dozen Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee fundraisers for 2014, with the first two expected in the coming weeks in New York and the Washington suburbs. Obama is also planning to attend fundraisers for the Senate Majority PAC.

Vice President Joe Biden, first lady Michelle Obama, and former President Bill Clinton will take the lead for Democrats, while Obama stays away. Democrats hope Hillary Clinton—whose office declined comment—will campaign as well.

The White House is also working closely with the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee on a full email and direct mail fundraising effort. This effort, sources familiar with the planning say, is part of a "comprehensive effort" for the 2014 midterm effort that will include House and governors' races.

At a meeting at Nationals Park last week, Obama told Senate Democrats that his health care law would be the "No. 1 attack tool" on Democrats by the Koch Brothers. He acknowledged his unpopularity in some states and offered to help where he could.

Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), the Senate majority whip, said, "He said, 'I understand in some of your states I'm not the most popular politician.' So if you're going to break from the White House on an issue or a position, understood. But I can help many of you, even in states where I'm not popular with everyone. I can still help, and I'm willing to do everything I can."

Sen. Mark Pryor of Arkansas, who is trying to defend his seat, downplayed the role any surrogate would play in his campaign, even though Clinton has already helped with fundraising. "I don't get people to come and campaign for me very often," Pryor said. "To me, in Arkansas, people don't vote for you because somebody else says vote for you."

Biden was a previously unreported attendee in an Oval Office meeting last week with Obama, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.), DSCC Chairman Michael Bennet (D-Colo.), and DSCC Executive Director Guy Cecil. The White House is reportedly debating how and where to deploy the first lady. In 2012, many of her events on behalf of the president's reelection were focused on voter registration, and she could help promote turnout and energize the Democratic base without endangering candidates by a close connection to the president—particularly in places like New Orleans, where local turnout could make the difference for Sen. Mary Landrieu.

Sen. Michael Bennet (D-Colo.) said, "They will help us a lot—in lots of different ways. I think they're both committed to doing everything they can to help us." When asked if Michelle Obama would campaign for Senate Democrats, Bennet said, "I certainly would hope so. I certainly would love it if she did, but she has other responsibilities, too."

The president is still likely to hit the trail at some point later this year, although decisions have yet to be made. He has a busy travel schedule in February and March focused on international affairs, including a California summit with the king of Jordan and trips to Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and Vatican City, where he'll meet Pope Francis.

Title: US Officials Believe Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 Likely Downed by Iranian Missile, According to Multiple Reports

Article:

Multiple reports on Thursday suggest that US officials believe Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 was likely shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile. The incident, which occurred early Wednesday, resulted in the death of all 176 people on board.

According to The Associated Press, US officials stated that it was "highly likely" that Iran was responsible for the crash, which took place outside the Iranian capital of Tehran. Defense officials told Newsweek and other outlets that the plane was probably shot down by accident, as Iran's surface-to-air missile systems were likely active at the time of the crash.

CBS News reported that US intelligence detected anti-aircraft radars turning on before the crash and that satellites detected two infrared blips, thought to be SA-15 missiles, that were quickly followed by another blip, the suspected aircraft explosion. CNN confirmed CBS and Newsweek's reporting, and US officials told The Associated Press that it was "highly likely" that the aircraft was downed by an Iranian anti-aircraft missile.

President Donald Trump said on Thursday that he did not believe that the passenger jet went down as a result of a mechanical error. "It was flying in a pretty rough neighborhood," the president said. "Someone could have made a mistake." Trump added, "I have a feeling that — it's just some very terrible, something very terrible happened, very devastating."

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday afternoon that Canada also had intelligence and evidence from multiple sources indicating "that the plane was shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile." He added that "this may well have been unintentional" and expressed a desire for a full investigation.

Images appearing to show Tor missile fragments, said to have been found outside Tehran, have been circulating on social media. A video making the rounds appears to show the moment a missile struck the Ukrainian aircraft. Iran has denied responsibility, with Iranian media, citing state officials, arguing that the missile theory is "scientifically impossible" and "illogical" because several domestic and foreign flights were in Iran at the same altitude of 8,000 feet.

Ukrainian investigators are considering several possibilities, including the plane being shot down, an engine explosion due to a technical malfunction, a terrorist attack on the flight, or even a collision with an unmanned aerial vehicle. Oleksiy Danylov, the secretary of Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council, wrote on Facebook earlier Thursday that Ukrainian investigators were considering several possibilities.

Title: "Church Security: A Growing Concern in the Wake of Charleston Massacre"

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, the issue of church security has come to the forefront of national discussions. The attack, considered the worst on an assembled congregation in American history, has prompted concerns about the increasing number of violent attacks on houses of worship.

Since 1999, Carl Chinn, a statistician who documents violent attacks on churches and synagogues, has recorded over 1,000 such incidents, with more than 150 this year alone. The Charleston massacre, according to Chinn, is a calculated attack that underscores the growing trend of violence directed against churches.

Tim Miller, a renowned expert in church security and the president of LionHeart International Services Group, shares Chinn's concerns. Miller, a retired Marine and former Secret Service agent, police officer, and counter-intelligence officer, has spent nearly 30 years protecting others. He and his team, which includes former Homeland Security agents, FBI agents, and special-ops personnel, have pivoted their efforts to help churches and non-profits deal with the same threats that were once confined to overseas territories.

Churches, Miller notes, are soft targets, and the Charleston massacre should serve as a wake-up call. "My first thought was to pray," he said, "having been in situations where that kind of carnage exists – the suffering is unimaginable. My second thought – was this is a realization of what we've been talking about and what we help churches prepare for."

The challenge lies in creating a welcoming environment for those in need, while simultaneously preparing for potential acts of violence. "We welcome you on the one hand – while on the other hand, if a gunman comes in, we have the resources to handle it," Miller explained.

The Book of Nehemiah, an Old Testament text, seems to address this issue, stating, "We prayed to our God and posted a guard." As the nation grapples with the aftermath of the Charleston massacre, the need for church security is becoming increasingly apparent.

Title: U.S. Navy to Proceed with Review of SEAL Eddie Gallagher's Status Despite Presidential Support

The U.S. Navy has announced that it will move forward with an administrative review board hearing on December 2nd to consider the potential expulsion of Special Operations Chief Eddie Gallagher from the Navy SEALs, despite President Donald Trump's recent tweet expressing support for the SEAL.

Gallagher and three supervising officers were informed of the hearing on Wednesday. The Navy will not be taking away Gallagher's Trident Pin, a symbol of membership in the SEALs, according to Trump's tweet on Thursday.

In July, Gallagher was acquitted of murdering a wounded Islamic State militant in Iraq in 2017, but was convicted on the single charge of posing with the body of the dead prisoner. Last week, Trump restored Gallagher's rank after he had been demoted to petty officer first class. However, the president did not pardon Gallagher for his offense.

In a statement issued late Thursday, Rear Adm. Charlie Brown, Chief of Information, said:

"The Navy follows the lawful orders of the President. We will do so in case of an order to stop the administrative review of SOC Gallagher's professional qualification. We are aware of the President's tweet and are awaiting further guidance."

The White House did not respond to an NPR request for comment on the tweet.

Gallagher's lawyers claim that Navy brass is seeking to expel him from the SEALs in retaliation for Trump's reversal of his demotion. They have filed a complaint with the Navy Inspector General, alleging that Naval Special Warfare Commander Rear Adm. Collin Green is defying the president.

"How can Admiral Green credibly preach about preserving good order and discipline while publicly flouting the orders of the commander in chief?" Gallagher's attorney Timothy Parlatore said, as quoted by the Associated Press.

If a review board decision goes against Gallagher, he can then appeal to the Navy's Personnel Command.

Title: Vatican Concludes Doctrinal Assessment of Leadership Conference of Women Religious, Marking an End to Five-Year Overhaul

The Vatican has announced the conclusion of a five-year doctrinal overhaul of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious (LCWR), the main umbrella group for nuns in the United States. The decision, announced on Thursday, marks the end of a process that began in 2012.

The Vatican's statement indicates that the Doctrinal Assessment of the LCWR has been accepted, signifying the conclusion of the overhaul. NPR's Sylvia Poggioli reports this as a sign of Pope Francis' focus on a more merciful church.

During their annual visit to Rome, LCWR leaders met with Pope Francis, a meeting that David Gibson of Religion News Service describes as another indicator of the thaw in relations. Both parties have agreed to maintain silence on the matter for the next month, and the joint statement and final report issued Thursday seem to represent a quiet and merciful end to the contentious period between the Vatican and the nuns.

The Rev. James Martin, SJ, editor at large of the Jesuit magazine America, stated in a Facebook post that the LCWR agreed to implement some changes, mainly regarding speakers and liturgies at its annual conventions. However, overall, the operations of the LCWR remain intact.

Joshua J. McElwee, writing in the National Catholic Reporter, suggests that the news brings to an end what had been an especially contentious period between the women religious and the Vatican. The investigation of the LCWR, which began in 2012 under Cardinal William Levada, the previous head of the Vatican's theological watchdog, had declared that the umbrella group representing most American nuns had strayed from church doctrine and adopted "radical feminist" views. Rome ordered Seattle's archbishop to begin monitoring all operations of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious. The investigation called for a five-year doctrinal overhaul of the group.

Sister Simone Campbell, head of the Catholic social justice lobby Network, had described the investigation as coming "like a sock in the stomach" at the time. A separate Vatican investigation into U.S. nuns ended last December with the Vatican expressing appreciation for the dedicated work of nuns in education, health, and among the poor.

Title: Democrats' Criticism of Trump's Asylum Policies Echoes Obama's 2014 Stance

Article:

In a recent development, Democrats have criticized President Donald Trump over new asylum regulations, which require migrants to claim asylum in the first safe country they arrive in, not their preferred country. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) described the regulations as "illegal" and "cruel."

However, a revisit of former President Barack Obama's statements from five years ago shows a striking similarity in the Democrats' stance on asylum issues. In 2014, Obama stated that poverty and crime are not sufficient legal reasons for granting asylum. He explained that under U.S. law, refugees are admitted based on narrow criteria, and typically, refugees' status is not granted just based on economic need or living in a dangerous neighborhood.

Obama further clarified that the American asylum-request pipeline is not designed to handle a large-scale humanitarian asylum crisis. He emphasized, "I think it's important to recognize that would not necessarily accommodate a large number of additional migrants."

These comments were made following a meeting at the White House with Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez, Guatemalan President Otto Perez Molina, and El Salvadorian President Salvador Sanchez Ceren, to discuss a migrant crisis that was impacting Central America, Mexico, and the U.S. The crisis was marked by a surge of unaccompanied migrant children that overwhelmed U.S. immigration resources.

This revelation underscores the evolving nature of political discourse and the shifting goalposts in the debate over asylum policies, as both Democratic and Republican administrations grapple with the complexities of managing a large-scale humanitarian asylum crisis.

Title: Center for Reproductive Rights Releases Controversial Video on 40th Anniversary of Roe v. Wade, Featuring Actor Mehcad Brooks

The Center for Reproductive Rights, an organization dedicated to advancing reproductive rights, has released a video to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the landmark Supreme Court case Roe v. Wade. The video features actor Mehcad Brooks, known for his roles in USA Network's "Necessary Roughness" and HBO's "True Blood."

The video has sparked controversy, with some critics arguing that it trivializes the issue of abortion and undermines the role of men in the debate. Critics contend that the video sends a message that men can abandon their responsibilities as fathers by resorting to abortion as a solution.

One point of contention is the choice of Mehcad Brooks for the video, given the historical context of abortion rights advocacy. Margaret Sanger, the founder of Planned Parenthood, has been criticized for her views on race and abortion. Some argue that her beliefs, which included a desire to limit the growth of the black population, are reflected in the high abortion rate within the black community. According to data from the Guttmacher Institute and Census data, black women make up 13 percent of the female population in the United States, yet they account for 30 percent of the abortions performed.

The video has been met with criticism for its tone, which some find inappropriate and disrespectful. Critics argue that abortion is a serious medical procedure with potential psychological consequences, and the video's lighthearted and celebratory approach is not in line with the gravity of the issue.

The Center for Reproductive Rights and Mehcad Brooks have not responded to these criticisms. The video can be found on the Center for Reproductive Rights' website and social media platforms. The organization's stance on abortion remains unchanged, emphasizing the importance of access to safe and legal abortion as a fundamental human right.

The video has sparked a heated debate, with proponents and critics of abortion rights voicing their opinions on social media and news outlets. The issue is expected to be discussed further on Fox News' "Hannity" tonight at 9:40 pm EST.

Title: U.S. Small Business Administration Warns of Imminent Exhaustion of Paycheck Protection Program Funds

The United States Small Business Administration (SBA) has warned lawmakers that the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), a relief initiative designed to support small businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, may run out of funds as early as Wednesday. According to reports, the program, which has approved over 1.3 million loans worth nearly $300 billion, is nearing its $349 billion allocation.

The SBA's announcement comes as the Senate originally legislated $350 billion for the program, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell advocating for additional funding since last week. However, Senate Democrats have blocked this effort, while Senate Republicans have proposed a clean bill to legislate an additional $250 billion to the program.

In a tweet on April 13, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer emphasized the need for small businesses in rural areas to have access to funds, regardless of their relationship with larger banks. He also criticized the delay in funding, stating, "Small biz in rural areas should have access to funds even if they're not customers of larger banks."

Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Schumer have accused the Republican party of delaying the funding, while the GOP has countered these allegations. Pelosi, in a tweet on April 15, stated, "The Paycheck Protection Program is a crucial tool for protecting workers across the country – yet serious flaws are keeping far too many small businesses from receiving the resources they need."

The ongoing partisan disagreements could potentially lead to further economic distress for small businesses if additional funding is not legislated promptly. It is crucial for both parties to put aside their political differences and focus on providing the necessary support to small businesses during these challenging times.

Title: Fact-Checking President Obama's Healthcare Reform Promise: A Closer Look at the "You Can Keep Your Insurance" Pledge

Article:

In the wake of recent media coverage, President Obama's pledge that individuals could keep their insurance under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has come under scrutiny. However, a closer examination reveals that the situation is more complex than it seems.

First, it is crucial to understand that the ACA grandfathered all individual policies that were in place at the time the law was enacted. This means that plans that were active during the bill's passage could still be offered, even if they did not meet all the ACA's standards.

The plans being terminated due to non-compliance with the ACA's minimal standards were all plans introduced after the law's passage. Insurers may not have informed their clients at the time these plans were sold that they would not be available after 2014 because the plans did not comply with the ACA.

If insurers did not inform their clients that the new plans would only be available for a short period, the blame would seem to rest with the insurance companies, not the ACA. President Obama did not promise people that he would keep insurers from developing new plans that do not comply with the ACA's provisions.

Furthermore, there have been complaints that the grandfathering was too strict. For example, insurers can only raise their premiums or deductibles by a small amount above the rate of medical inflation. As a result, many plans in existence at the time of the ACA are losing their grandfathered status.

In this case, it is wrong to view insurers as passive actors who are being forced to stop offering plans because of the ACA. The price increases charged by insurers are not events outside of the insurers' control. If an insurer offers a plan with many committed buyers, it would be able to structure its changes in ways that are consistent with the ACA. If it decides not to do so, this is presumably because the insurer has decided that it is not interested in continuing to offer the plan.

As a practical matter, there are many plans that insurers will opt to drop for market reasons that may or may not have anything to do with the ACA. It's hard to see how this could be viewed as a violation of President Obama's pledge. After all, insurers change and drop plans all the time. Did people who heard Obama's pledge understand it to mean that insurers would no longer have this option once the ACA passed?

If Obama's pledge was understood as ensuring that every plan that was in existence in 2010 would remain in existence, then it would imply a complete federal takeover of the insurance industry. This would require the government to tell insurers that they must continue to offer plans even if they are losing money on them and even if the plans had lost most of their customers. This would at the least be a strange policy. It would be surprising if many people thought this was the meaning of President Obama's pledge.

Finally, there will be many plans that insurers will stop offering in large part because of the changed market conditions created by the ACA. For example, last week the Washington Post highlighted a plan for the "hardest to insure" that was being cancelled by Pathmark Blue Cross of Pennsylvania. This plan is likely being cancelled because it is unable to compete with the insurance being offered through the exchanges. The exchanges charge everyone the same rate regardless of their pre-existing health conditions. A plan that is especially designed for people who have serious health conditions would almost certainly charge a far higher rate. If these high-priced plans no longer exist because they can not compete with the exchanges, would this mean that President Obama had broken his pledge?

On closer inspection, the claim that President Obama lied in saying that people could keep their insurance looks like another Fox News special. In the only way that the pledge could be interpreted as being meaningful, the pledge is true. The ACA does not eliminate plans that were in existence at the time the bill was approved.

If we want to play Fox News, President Obama also promised people they could keep their doctor. Since 2010, tens of thousands of doctors have retired or even died. Guess the pledge that people could keep their doctor was yet another lie from the Obama administration.

Title: Vice President Pence to Meet with Mexican Officials Amidst Tariff Tensions and Economic Concerns

Article:

Vice President Mike Pence is set to meet with top Mexican officials on Wednesday, as the Trump administration and Mexico engage in a diplomatic standoff over proposed tariffs that could significantly impact the North American economy. The tariffs, which President Trump announced last week, would impose a 5 percent tariff on all Mexican goods beginning on Monday, with the potential to rise to 25 percent by October if Mexico fails to address increasing levels of illegal migration.

Trump's announcement has been met with criticism from Republican senators, who warn that the tariffs could slow the U.S. economy and hinder progress on ratifying the revised North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with Canada and Mexico. Some GOP senators have even threatened to withhold their support for the tariffs, contrasting their stance on the issue with their earlier support for Trump's national emergency declaration to secure funding for his long-promised border wall.

Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard is leading the Mexican delegation to the White House, accompanied by U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Ebrard has stated that the delegation has spent the past few days preparing for the meeting, which was quickly convened over the weekend.

Ebrard emphasized that Mexico is taking steps to address the issue of illegal migration, including increased detention of migrants and other measures designed to prevent them from crossing into the U.S. However, the specific steps Mexico would need to take to prevent the tariffs from taking effect remain unclear, adding to the confusion surrounding the situation.

Acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan has stated that the administration wants to see Mexico take action to create a "vast reduction" in illegal crossings by tightening security on its border with Guatemala, expanding intelligence sharing with U.S. law enforcement agencies, and cracking down on migrants crossing its northern border with the U.S.

The economic impact of the proposed tariffs is already being felt, with the private sector adding just 27,000 jobs in May, according to a key study. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated that the central bank is closely monitoring the situation and may respond by slashing interest rates to prevent widespread damage.

The diplomatic and economic tensions could slow or stop progress toward the president's NAFTA revision, which Pence has previously vowed would be approved by this summer. The trade pact was signed by the leaders of all three countries last year but must still be ratified by their legislatures. The U.S. and Mexican governments have both started the formal legislative process, but consideration could be delayed with the tariffs in place.

Mexico recently became the U.S.'s largest trading partner, with the U.S. importing $346.5 billion in goods from Mexico last year, according to the U.S. trade representative. Automakers, agricultural companies, and retailers are expected to be hit hardest by the duties, which will be paid for by U.S. importers and often passed along to consumers.

The meeting between Pence and the Mexican officials is set to take place on Wednesday at the White House. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain, but the stakes are high, as both sides seek to find a solution that addresses the issue of illegal migration while minimizing the potential economic damage of the proposed tariffs.

Title: Boehner Criticizes Obama's Budget Proposal, Accusing It of Lacking Bipartisan Efforts and Failing to Address Spending Issues

Article:

In a press release on Friday, House Speaker John Boehner criticized the budget proposal President Barack Obama is set to unveil, stating that it takes no steps towards finding common ground with Republicans, despite the president's offer to cut federal entitlement spending.

Boehner argued that the president's proposal, which reportedly includes changes to Social Security and Medicare, similar to an offer Obama made to Boehner during the fiscal cliff negotiations in December, would not be a viable solution. The president's proposal, as described to CNN and other news outlets by senior Obama administration officials, includes a $400 billion cut to Medicare over a decade.

Boehner stated, "If the president believes these modest entitlement savings are needed to help shore up these programs, there's no reason they should be held hostage for more tax hikes. That's no way to lead and move the country forward."

The speaker also criticized the president's last offer during the fiscal cliff negotiations, stating that it was significantly skewed in favor of higher taxes and included only modest entitlement savings. Boehner further argued that the reported entitlement program changes have also received fire from left-leaning groups who argue the changes would hurt vulnerable individuals.

Obama's budget also includes tax increases, which Republicans say is a non-starter since taxes were increased on wealthy individuals as part of the final fiscal cliff deal. Boehner wrote, "In the end, the president got his tax hikes on the wealthy with no corresponding spending cuts. At some point, we need to solve our spending problem, and what the president has offered would leave us with a budget that never balances."

Boehner also suggested that Obama's so-called charm offensive was to little avail on budget matters. "When the president visited the Capitol last month, House Republicans stated a desire to find common ground and urged him not to make savings we agree upon conditional on another round of tax increases. If reports are accurate, the president has not heeded that call," Boehner said.

Republicans have roundly criticized Obama for missing the February deadline for submitting his budget proposal. The proposal could be released next week, White House officials have said. The Republican-led House has previously passed a proposal drafted by Budget Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wisconsin. It was a budget not warmly received by the Democratic Senate or the White House.

Title: Trump-Erdogan Meeting Fails to Resolve NATO Ally Dispute Over Air Defense Systems

WASHINGTON (AP) — In a meeting Wednesday at the White House, President Donald Trump and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan failed to reach an agreement on Turkey's decision to accept delivery of a Russian air defense system, a move that has strained relations between the two NATO allies.

The U.S. suspended Turkish participation in the multinational F-35 fighter jet program due to the threat posed by the Russian S-400 system. Despite the disagreement, Trump and Erdogan agreed to continue discussions on the issue.

"The acquisition of the S-400 creates some very serious challenges for us," Trump said. "Hopefully we'll be able to resolve that situation."

Trade between the two countries, which amounted to about $24 billion in 2017, was another topic of discussion. Trump expressed optimism about increasing trade to about $100 billion between the two countries.

The dispute over the competing air defense systems is a major component of the tension between the two countries. Turkey has also faced criticism for its incursion into Syria last month to attack Kurdish forces that fought with the U.S. against the Islamic State, and for repression of political opponents, journalists, and others.

Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) acknowledged Turkey's concerns regarding certain Kurdish elements of the Syrian Democratic Forces, but said they should be addressed by creating a safe zone and not with a "disruptive" incursion that "must end."

Turkey, meanwhile, is angered at the U.S. for supporting the Kurdish forces it views as a threat and for refusing to extradite a Muslim cleric it accuses of fomenting a 2016 coup attempt against Erdogan.

Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said lawmakers have significant concerns about both the S-400 and the attack on the Kurds, who "have risked a lot to stand with America" and battle the Islamic State.

The leaders' meeting came amid the ongoing House impeachment inquiry, with Trump saying he was too busy to watch the televised hearings, which he called a "hoax."

Congressional Democrats criticized Trump for meeting with Erdogan after the invasion of Syria, with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) calling it "mindboggling" and "appalling."

In the Senate, two Democrats have introduced legislation denouncing Turkey's targeting of journalists, political opponents, dissidents, minorities, and others. They said the Turkish government had imprisoned more than 80,000 Turkish citizens, closed more than 1,500 non-governmental organizations on terrorism-related grounds, and dismissed or suspended more than 130,000 civil servants from their jobs.

During the news conference, Trump joked that Erdogan should only call on a friendly Turkish reporter. When Erdogan called on a female Turkish reporter, according to several people in the room, Graham leaned over and quietly told someone seated next to him, "She's the only reporter left over there" in Turkey.

Title: New York Financial Regulator Proposes Enhanced Cybersecurity Measures to Protect Against Potential "Armageddon-Type" Cyber Attacks

In a speech at Columbia Law School on Wednesday, Ben Lawsky, head of New York's Department of Financial Services (DFS), expressed concerns about the potential for a large-scale cyber attack on Wall Street firms that could have far-reaching implications for the broader economy. Lawsky likened such an event to the mortgage meltdown of 2008 and stated that he is considering new rules to protect against this potential threat.

Lawsky's proposed measures include forcing banks and insurance companies regulated by DFS to improve their cybersecurity defenses. DFS has regulatory oversight over dozens of New York-licensed banks and insurance companies, including Goldman Sachs, MetLife, and Barclays. As head of DFS, Lawsky has the power to impose penalties for bad behavior and to set new standards for the operations of these financial institutions.

To prevent a devastating cyber attack, Lawsky wants to incorporate cybersecurity into the grades DFS gives the banks and insurance companies it regulates. Financial firms "care deeply" about their grades because they can impact their ability to pay dividends or acquire other companies, Lawsky said.

Lawsky is also considering mandating multifactor authentication systems for employees of DFS-regulated financial firms. He believes that single-step passwords are outdated and should no longer be used.

In addition, Lawsky may require banks and insurance companies licensed by DFS to obtain guarantees from third-party vendors that their security meets certain standards. These vendors can often serve as a "backdoor entrance" for hackers, Lawsky said.

Lawsky's call for enhanced cybersecurity measures follows a report last week by Moscow-based security firm Kaspersky Lab, which warned of a group of international cybercriminals who have stolen up to $1 billion from 100 banks across 30 countries by infiltrating their internal systems.

In his speech, Lawsky also touched on new rules he is considering to combat money laundering. These rules include random audits for DFS-licensed banks to assess how well they flag suspicious transactions, as well as requiring bank executives to certify that their money transaction monitoring is up to par to better protect against terrorism and other crimes.

Lawsky's office has discovered that some banks do not take monitoring of financial transactions seriously. Indeed, British bank Standard Chartered found itself in hot water recently after Lawsky accused it of turning a blind eye to money laundering. In August, the bank agreed to settle its dispute with DFS by paying $300 million and cutting off dealings with certain customers that were flagged for their suspicious transactions.

Lawsky stated that DFS caught Standard Chartered by comparing the company's flagging of suspicious transactions with its own system for finding suspicious activity. "We basically ran the company's transactions through our own filtering system and compared the results," Lawsky said, noting that regulators typically rely on self-reporting from the firms they oversee.

"What regulators have not done is actively tested the effectiveness of the filtering systems banks are using. That needs to change," Lawsky said.

Title: Democrats and Republicans Gear Up for 2018 Midterm Elections: A Tight Race for Senate Seats and House Control

The 2018 midterm elections are rapidly approaching, and the political landscape is shaping up to be a tight race, with the balance of power in both the Senate and the House of Representatives hanging in the balance. The question of whether the Republicans will maintain their hold on power or if the political pendulum is swinging in the Democrats' favor remains unanswered, as tight polling in many states means the outcome won't be settled until Election Day in November.

One aspect that is certain is that Democrats will be on the defensive, as they hold 22 of the 33 Senate seats up for grabs, while Republicans hold just eight. Independents hold the remaining two seats. In an effort to bolster their chances, Democrats are reportedly calling in high-profile reinforcements, including former President Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, and her husband, former President Bill Clinton.

Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, admitted last week that Democratic candidates running for Senate are welcoming the support of Obama and the Clintons. "We welcome support from everybody who wants to help, including Secretary Clinton and President Obama," he said, according to the Washington Examiner. "As the head of the DSCC, we welcome those individuals and everybody that wants to help."

Clinton has already been reaching out to campaigns, according to Hollen. The twice-failed presidential candidate started "Onward Together" last year, an organization focused on electing Democrats nationwide. "I think she's going to continue to reach out to candidates and let them know that she's ready to help in any way that she can," Van Hollen said. "These are really conversations that go on between Secretary Clinton or President Obama and the particular campaign."

In the House of Representatives, every seat is up for grabs each election cycle, and if Democrats want to re-take control, they have some work to do. Currently, Republicans have a 42-seat majority. However, in California, at least, the national party is facing a potential self-inflicted disaster, as the New York Times reports. The mushrooming political chaos across Southern California has led national Democrats to pour millions of dollars into congressional races to avert a loss of seats or a lack of competitiveness against the more organized Republicans.

In summary, the 2018 midterm elections are shaping up to be a critical contest for both parties, with Democrats on the defensive in the Senate and facing potential self-inflicted wounds in California's House races. The outcome of these elections will determine the balance of power in Congress for the next several election cycles.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and the Republican Strategy on Healthcare: A Delicate Balance

Article:

In a move that signals a potential shift in the political landscape, President Trump has assigned three Republican senators the task of devising a replacement for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) if the courts rule against it. This contingency plan, while prudent, has sparked debate within the Republican party, with some senators expressing reluctance to take up the assignment.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, in a recent press conference, hinted at a wait-and-see approach, suggesting that the Senate would only engage in health care reform once the White House and the Democrats reach a deal. This strategy, according to Republican strategists, is a calculated move to avoid presenting a Republican health-care plan open to attack, and instead focus on criticizing Democratic proposals.

However, this strategy may not be as effective as intended. The reluctance to propose a health-care plan could provide Democrats with ammunition to accuse Republicans of abandoning a crucial issue and seeking to eliminate a health law relied upon by millions. The choice for Republicans, then, is whether to counter this attack with their own plan or to let Democrats create a caricatured conservative plan to associate with them.

The passage of a conservative health-care plan through a Democratic House seems unlikely, and a bipartisan compromise may be challenging to achieve. Yet, the lack of a Republican health-care plan during the Obama administration, when they had the power to enact legislation, is a point of criticism. The absence of a consensus among Republican politicians and voters left them unprepared when they regained power.

The key innovation of Obamacare was not the subsidization of health-insurance purchases, but the centralization of health-insurance regulation in Washington, D.C. This centralization, and the accompanying curtailment of choice and increase in costs, is what Republicans tasked with replacing Obamacare should now work to undo.

A possible solution could involve the federal government removing many of Obamacare's regulations and redirecting the money currently flowing to Obamacare's exchanges and Medicaid expansions to state governments. These state governments would then determine how to spend the funds to meet their residents' health-care needs.

This approach would allow states to allocate funds to different groups, such as disabled Medicaid recipients, or to let Medicaid recipients use a share of the Obamacare money to buy insurance on the private market. States could also attempt to increase coverage rates among the young by allowing insurers to offer them discounts.

Republican officeholders are encouraged to contribute their ideas to this basic template or propose wholly different ideas. The goal is to ensure that Republicans do not simply hold off the next Democrat-led lurch to the left for a few years, and that conservatives do not let them. President Trump's challenge to his party, despite its reception, is a welcome one.

Title: Senate to Vote on Federal Reserve Audit Legislation in 2015

Article:

In a significant shift, the Senate is set to vote on legislation next year that would force a comprehensive audit of the Federal Reserve's decision-making process. The bill, championed by former Rep. Ron Paul and now backed by his son, Sen. Rand Paul, and other lawmakers, has the support of the new Republican majority leader, Sen. Mitch McConnell.

The legislation, which has already passed twice in the House, is not guaranteed success in the Senate, despite its bipartisan support. The Federal Reserve itself is pushing back against the proposed audit, with Chairwoman Janet L. Yellen stating earlier this month that the Fed remains opposed to stricter oversight of its monetary policy decisions.

Yellen argued that the Fed's monetary policy decision-making should remain exempt from GAO audits, citing a 1978 law that explicitly prohibits such audits. However, supporters of the audit argue that the Federal Reserve's role in the 2009 Recovery Act, which totaled $800 billion, pales in comparison to the trillions of dollars in stimulus the Federal Reserve oversaw.

The bill has garnered significant support in the House, passing twice, including most recently in September on a 333-92 vote. All but one Republican, and more than half of the Democrats in the chamber, voted for the legislation. However, the bill was blocked by former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid in 2012 and 2014, a move that has been criticized by supporters of the audit.

With the change in Senate leadership, the bill now has a better chance of reaching the floor for a vote. Norm Singleton, vice president of policy at Campaign for Liberty, a political organization founded by Ron Paul, said, "His refusal to bring popular legislation like 'Audit the Fed' to the floor is a major reason why he's being demoted to minority leader."

However, Singleton cautioned that the bill's success is not guaranteed, especially in light of reports that Fed officials are lobbying against the audit push. "This is popular with 75 percent of the American people, but it's not popular among Wall Street; it's not popular among banks; it's not popular among foreign central banks," he said. "These hold a fair amount of sway among both parties, so just to say that a change in party necessarily means we'll be able to move Audit the Fed, it's better odds now than we've had before, but it's not a slam dunk."

Sen. Paul's office has confirmed that the bill will be among the first pieces of legislation introduced when the new Congress convenes in January. Transparency at the Federal Reserve remains a top priority for Sen. Rand Paul. The Federal Reserve, established nearly a century ago, acts as the lender of last resort to the country's banking system and is charged with fighting inflation and promoting economic growth and employment. The interest rates it sets have a direct impact on the rates that banks charge consumers. However, some of the board's decision-making has been shielded from view to give the agency independence.

The audit legislation would grant the Government Accountability Office the power to retroactively review the Fed's decision-making, particularly on monetary policy. Ms. Yellen and her defenders argue that giving the GAO audit powers could amount to having their decisions scrutinized almost in real time, which they say could influence the closed-door deliberations by the Fed. Critics of the Fed's actions argue that increased transparency is necessary to ensure accountability and prevent future financial crises.

Title: Trump and Schiff Engage in Twitter Spat as Democrats Push for Release of Memo Countering GOP's Allegations

Article:

In a series of tweets on Monday, President Donald Trump took aim at Representative Adam Schiff, a California Democrat, accusing him of being a liar and leaker. The tweet comes as Democrats push to release a memo that is expected to counter a Republican document alleging FBI surveillance abuses.

Trump tweeted, "Little Adam Schiff, who is desperate to run for higher office, is one of the biggest liars and leakers in Washington, right up there with Comey, Warner, Brennan and Clapper! Adam leaves closed committee hearings to illegally leak confidential information. Must be stopped!"

In response, Schiff tweeted, "Mr. President, I see you've had a busy morning of 'Executive Time.' Instead of tweeting false smears, the American people would appreciate it if you turned off the TV and helped solve the funding crisis, protected Dreamers or... really anything else."

Trump did not provide evidence that Schiff has illegally leaked confidential information. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment Monday morning.

According to a source with direct knowledge of the matter, Democrats plan to offer a motion at a Monday business meeting to release their memo. If approved, the matter would be sent to Trump, who would have five days to object to its release.

The four-page GOP memo, spearheaded by Chairman Devin Nunes of California, alleges that the FBI improperly used information paid for in part by Hillary Clinton's campaign to obtain a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act warrant for then-Trump campaign foreign policy adviser Carter Page. Trump has said the memo "totally vindicates" him in the Russia probe.

At last week's meeting, Republicans blocked a Democratic attempt to release their memo at the same time as the Nunes memo. Republicans argued they had just been presented with a copy of the Democrats' document.

Republicans have since said they would vote to release the Democratic memo, drafted by Schiff, a sign that the committee is likely to approve its release.

In a separate tweet, Trump praised Nunes, saying, "Representative Devin Nunes, a man of tremendous courage and grit, may someday be recognized as a Great American Hero for what he has exposed and what he has had to endure!"

The back-and-forth between Trump and Schiff marks the latest development in the ongoing political battle between the two parties over the Russia investigation and the handling of the FBI and Department of Justice.

Title: Trump Defends Steel Tariffs Amidst Global Outcry and Potential Trade War Escalation

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his decision to impose tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, stating that "trade wars are good and easy to win." The announcement, which has been met with criticism from manufacturers and trade partners in China and Europe, will see tariffs of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminum for an extended period.

In a tweet on Friday, Trump asserted, "When a country (USA) is losing many billions of dollars on trade with virtually every country it does business with, trade wars are good, and easy to win." The formal order is expected to be signed next week, but details, including any product or country exemptions, have yet to be disclosed.

The planned tariffs, justified on the grounds of cut-price metal imports harming both American producers and national security, have raised the prospect of reciprocal restrictions on American exports and increased prices for domestic users. While the practical impact may be limited, the political environment for global trade has taken a turn for the worse.

The response in China, the world's largest steel producer, has been muted, with Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying merely urging the U.S. to follow trade rules. Industry insiders, however, have been less restrained. Wen Xianjun, vice chairman of the China Nonferrous Metals Industry Association, stated that the U.S. measures "overturn the international trade order."

U.S. allies, seeing their industries threatened, have responded with bafflement and dismay. Some also question the idea that metal imports pose a threat to national security. Japan's Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko stated, "Steel and aluminum imports from Japan, which is an ally, do not affect U.S. national security at all."

The European Union has vowed to "react firmly" with World Trade Organization-compliant countermeasures, while Canada, the biggest foreign supplier of steel to the U.S., has called the measures unacceptable. Australian Trade Minister Steve Ciobo called the move "disappointing" and seeks an exemption.

Trump maintains that the tariffs will level the unfair playing field and make it easier for American companies to expand and hire workers. However, U.S. companies that use aluminum for manufacturing and packaging, such as MillerCoors and Hershey Co., have expressed concerns that operations will be negatively impacted by the tariffs.

The potential for retaliation, particularly from China, is a concern. China has already launched a probe into U.S. imports of sorghum and is studying whether to restrict shipments of U.S. soybeans, targets that could hurt Trump's support in some farming states. While China accounts for just a fraction of U.S. imports of the metals, it is accused of flooding the global market and dragging down prices.

The extent of the impact hinges on which nations will be affected, according to Alex Wolf, senior emerging markets economist at Aberdeen Standard Investments in Hong Kong who previously worked at the U.S. State Department. "It's not much ado about nothing, but until we see the final scope of the tariffs and the response from global trading partners, it's hard to say it's the start of a tit-for-tat trade war," he said.

Title: Senators Rubio and Feinstein Warn of ISIS Expansionist Threat to U.S. Homeland

Article:

In a chilling assessment, Senators Marco Rubio (R-FL) and Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) have issued warnings about the potential expansionist threat posed by the jihadist ISIS group, suggesting that their ideology could lead to attacks on the United States.

Rubio, a member of the Senate's Foreign Relations and Select Intelligence Committees, has stated that President Barack Obama was right to use military force to protect America's diplomats and military personnel in Iraq. However, he argues that this should not be the only goal. In a piece published on Friday, Rubio warns that if decisive action against ISIS is not taken now, it will not only be Iraqis or Syrians who suffer, but Americans as well, due to a potential terrorist attack on U.S. soil or on U.S. personnel overseas.

Rubio's warning mirrors that of Senate Intelligence Committee chairwoman Dianne Feinstein, who has also expressed concern about the recruitment of fighters in Western countries by ISIS. In a statement backing Obama's airstrike authorization, Feinstein stated, "It has become clear that ISIL is recruiting fighters in Western countries, training them to fight its battles in the Middle East and possibly returning them to European and American cities to attack us in our backyard."

Both senators call for an increase in military and humanitarian assistance to the Iraqi government and the Kurdistan Regional Government. They argue that inaction is no longer an option, and that a broader military campaign against ISIS is necessary to prevent the group from establishing safe havens and launching attacks on the United States and its allies.

ISIS, which emerged from al Qaeda, has already established a presence in Iraq, even as they seize Iraqi towns and communities. Rubio asserts that ISIS, with thousands of foreign fighters, many of them from the West, will not rest after taking the Kurdish capital of Irbil or Baghdad. He warns that their expansionist ideology will lead them to attack U.S. allies in the region and eventually Europe and the United States.

In conclusion, the warnings issued by Senators Rubio and Feinstein highlight the urgent need for the United States to take decisive action against ISIS to prevent potential attacks on U.S. soil and protect its allies in the region. The senators' calls for increased military and humanitarian assistance to Iraq and the Kurdistan Regional Government underscore the importance of a coordinated international response to the threat posed by ISIS.

Title: Clinton Accuses Trump of Ties to Alt-Right Movement, Stirring Controversy Ahead of Presidential Debate

Article:

In a heated exchange this week, the two presidential candidates have been trading accusations of racism and bigotry, with Hillary Clinton arguing that Donald Trump's rhetoric and policies are an invitation to the "alt-right" movement.

During a speech in Reno, Nevada on Thursday, Clinton stated, "This is not conservatism as we have known it. This is not Republicanism as we have known it. These are racist ideas. These are race-baiting ideas. Anti-Muslim, anti-immigrant, anti-women ideas – all key tenets making up an emerging racist ideology known as the 'alt-right.'"

The views of the alt-right are widely seen as anti-Semitic and white supremacist. This mostly online movement uses websites, chat boards, social media, and memes to spread its message. The infamous Star of David image that Trump received criticism for retweeting was reportedly first seen on an alt-right message board.

Most of its members are young white men who see themselves first and foremost as champions of their own demographic. Their greatest points of unity lie in what they are against: multiculturalism, immigration, feminism, and, above all, political correctness.

"They see political correctness really as the greatest threat to their liberty," Nicole Hemmer, University of Virginia professor and author of a forthcoming book Messengers of the Right, explained on Morning Edition. "So, they believe saying racist or anti-Semitic things — it's not an act of hate, but an act of freedom."

The alt-right movement differs from what we think of as traditional conservatism. The movement's origins are traced to many conservatives' opposition to the policies of President George W. Bush, especially the U.S. invasion of Iraq (alt-righters are strictly isolationist). They are also suspicious of free markets, a key tenet of conservatism, as they believe that business interests can often be in conflict with what they view as higher ideals — those of cultural preservation and homogeneity.

Two self-proclaimed leaders of the alt-right movement — Breitbart's Allum Bokhari and Milo Yiannopoulos — recently outlined a manifesto of sorts for what the group believes and who their allies are and are not. It claimed that "beltway conservatives" hate alt-right adherents even more "than Democrats or loopy progressives."

They see themselves, rather, as "natural conservatives," with an "instinctive wariness of the foreign and the unfamiliar," Bokhari and Yiannopoulos wrote.

Last week, the GOP presidential nominee announced that Stephen Bannon, chairman of Breitbart News Network, which Bannon has called "the platform for the alt-right," would be his campaign's new chief executive.

"By putting Breitbart front and center in his campaign," said Hemmer, "Trump has elevated the alt-right."

However, Hemmer suspects that Trump — and all but a small fraction of his supporters — do not pledge allegiance to the alt-right movement. "I think they are attracted to Trump [and] see him as a vessel for getting their ideas out there," Hemmer said.

Clinton is likely to continue drawing a link between Trump and the alt-right in the minds of voters. "She's reminding those undecided voters that whatever the new moderate face of Donald Trump might be," Hemmer said, "there are the things he has said and here are the implications of the things he said and the people who he's brought into his campaign."

The controversy surrounding the alt-right movement and its ties to the Trump campaign is likely to continue as the presidential race heats up, with both candidates seeking to appeal to their respective bases and win over undecided voters.

Title: "Federal Health Care Exchange: Initial Enrollment Figures Revealed Amidst Rollout Challenges"

Article:

In a significant development, the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has disclosed that a total of 6 individuals had successfully enrolled in the federal health care exchange by October 2, according to documents obtained by the committee. The documents, which include notes from a "war room" meeting at the Center for Consumer Information and Insurance, underscore the initial challenges faced by the online marketplace, HealthCare.gov.

The documents indicate that the six enrolled individuals were issued policies from five different insurance companies. Healthcare Service Corporation, one of the insurers, reported two enrollments. By the next meeting, held that afternoon, approximately 100 enrollments had taken place since the launch of the federal exchange.

However, the documents do not represent an official enrollment tally, according to Joanne Peters, a Health and Human Services spokeswoman. The department has declined to release the number of Americans who have successfully enrolled in the exchange.

Peters stated, "We will release enrollment statistics on a monthly basis after coordinating information from different sources such as paper, online, and call centers, verifying with insurers and collecting data from states."

Peters reiterated that a slow start does not mean that the exchange will not attract a significant number of enrollees by the deadline. "We have always anticipated that the pace of enrollment will increase throughout the enrollment period," she said.

Citing the quiet pace at which Massachusetts residents registered for that state's health program, the spokeswoman remained confident that enrollment totals would increase as more people learn about the exchange.

The Center for Consumer Information and Insurance is part of the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services. Despite the initial challenges, HHS remains focused on providing accurate enrollment totals and cannot yet give those figures due to collection issues.

"We have had more than 20 million visitors to the Marketplace, showing an overwhelming interest in Americans learning more about their options for affordable health care," Peters concluded.

Title: Republican Presidential Aspirants Take Aim at Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire GOP Summit

Article:

In the heart of New Hampshire, the Republican presidential hopefuls gathered for the state GOP's two-day summit, with Hillary Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner, being the central focus of their speeches. The event, held in Nashua, attracted nearly the entire field, with each candidate taking turns to criticize Clinton's tenure as Secretary of State, her email server controversy, and her handling of foreign policy, particularly the 2012 attack on the U.S. Embassy in Benghazi.

Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul delivered the strongest attack on Clinton, accusing her of dereliction of duty and suggesting that her actions should disqualify her from holding high office. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker questioned Clinton's understanding of everyday life, stating that she may not have ever been to a store like Kohl's.

Hillary Clinton is scheduled to visit New Hampshire on Monday and Tuesday, but for the weekend, the political world's attention was on the Republicans in Nashua. The Clinton surrogate at the event was former Hewlett-Packard executive Carly Fiorina, whose speech was light on substance but managed to grab attention with her allusion to the Monica Lewinsky scandal and a jab at the idea that only men should be elected President.

Policy differences were also a topic of discussion, with Paul taking on his own party over Libya, stating that the U.S. should never have waded into the conflict in the first place. South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham and Texas Sen. Ted Cruz advocated for a more muscular role in the Middle East.

Florida Sen. Marco Rubio managed to weave a compelling narrative, tying his Cuban immigrant parents' pursuit of the American dream to his efforts to save it for his daughters. Rubio positioned 2016 as a "referendum on our national identity," stating that his children and their generation would be "the first to inherit a diminished country from their parents."

Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush attempted to assuage primary voters' concerns about a potential Clinton vs. Bush general election, stating, "I don't see any coronation coming my way, trust me." He also showcased his policy chops, distancing himself from Common Core standards, expressing support for "traditional marriage," and highlighting his eight years as a conservative Florida governor as an advantage over his rivals.

The event also featured a charm offensive from Sen. Lindsey Graham, whose quick wit and South Carolina drawl were on full display. Real estate mogul Donald Trump managed to both insult and win the audience's applause with his candid remarks about running for president. Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, despite a compelling personal story and policy chops, was largely forgettable, lacking a standout quality.

Title: Justice Department Declines to Investigate Trump-Zelensky Call, Citing Insufficient Evidence for Quid Pro Quo Scheme

Article:

WASHINGTON, D.C. - The Department of Justice (DOJ) has announced that it will not be launching an investigation into the July phone call between President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, which sparked a formal impeachment inquiry over allegations of a quid pro quo arrangement.

In a statement released on Wednesday, DOJ spokesperson Kerri Kupec stated, "Relying on established procedures set forth in the Justice Manual, the Department's Criminal Division reviewed the official record of the call and determined, based on the facts and applicable law, that there was no campaign finance violation and that no further action was warranted."

The statement continued, "All relevant components of the Department agreed with this legal conclusion, and the Department has concluded the matter."

During the July 25 phone call, Trump reportedly asked Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden, over allegations that the former vice president used his position to help a Ukrainian energy company avoid a corruption probe soon after Hunter was appointed to its board of directors.

On Tuesday, Trump admitted to temporarily withholding military aid from Ukraine, which was intended to help the country counter Russian aggression. This admission has fueled suspicions of a quid pro quo scheme, as a foreign national, Zelensky, would have been providing Trump's campaign assistance in the form of opposition research on his chief political rival, Joe Biden.

The White House released a partial transcript of the call on Wednesday, revealing that Trump did indeed ask Zelensky to help Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani investigate Biden's influence in firing a Ukrainian prosecutor.

The whistleblower complaint, submitted by an anonymous member of the intelligence community to the Director of National Intelligence's inspector general in August, was based on the July call. The DOJ's Office of Legal Counsel released an opinion on Wednesday stating that the whistleblower complaint was not an "urgent concern" and challenged the idea that the complaint must be sent to the congressional intelligence committees.

However, on Tuesday, Senate Republicans unanimously approved a non-binding measure proposed by Democrats calling on the Trump administration to turn the complaint over to Congress. The ongoing impeachment inquiry into President Trump is being led by the House of Representatives.

Title: Trump Steps Down from Business Empire to Focus on Presidential Duties

Article:

In a series of tweets before dawn on Wednesday, President-elect Donald Trump announced his decision to step down from his multi-million dollar business empire to focus solely on his role as the nation's new commander-in-chief.

"I will be leaving my great business in total in order to fully focus on running the country in order to make America great again," Trump tweeted.

The president-elect explained that he felt it was important, as president, to avoid any potential conflict of interest with his various businesses. He is not legally mandated to do so, but he believes this move will help maintain transparency and integrity in his presidency.

The news comes as the Trump transition continues, with more cabinet picks, a flurry of activity on Twitter, and a significant victory on job creation. This week, Trump Tower has seen a steady stream of visitors, hinting at high-powered auditions for cabinet posts.

Among the latest selections are Steven Mnuchin for treasury secretary, who, if confirmed by the Senate, will play a key role in shaping Trump's tax policy. Wilbur Ross, a Wall Street financier, was chosen to lead the Commerce Department. Elaine Chao, who served as labor secretary under George W. Bush and is the wife of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky), was announced as the secretary of transportation.

Robert Johnson, the founder of BET, was offered a post but declined, citing his preference to remain an entrepreneur rather than enter government bureaucracy. Johnson also stated that he does not believe Trump is a racist or anti-African-American.

The question on everyone's mind is who will be chosen for the position of secretary of state. Trump has been meeting with potential candidates, and Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn) commented that the secretary of state's role is crucial to a president, and he needs to choose someone he is very comfortable with.

Trump also had dinner with Mitt Romney on Tuesday, despite Romney's criticism during the campaign. Romney has since praised Trump for his election victory and his "message of inclusion."

Other potential candidates for the top diplomat position include Gen. David Petraeus, former CIA director.

Trump stirred up a Twitter storm on Tuesday with a tweet suggesting that anyone who burns the American flag should face consequences, such as loss of citizenship or a year in jail. The Supreme Court has ruled that flag burning is constitutionally protected speech.

Meanwhile, Trump is already making good on a campaign promise to keep jobs in America. The air conditioning company Carrier Corp. announced that it has reached a deal with the president-elect to keep nearly 1,000 jobs in Indiana, rather than moving to Mexico as previously planned.
