This move is a sign that Trump intends to deliver quickly on his key campaign promises, which include repealing the Affordable Care Act, fixing the immigration system, strengthening the economy by cutting taxes and government regulations, and bringing back jobs.

Title: Federal Court Unseals Fusion GPS Bank Records, Revealing Details of Payments and Journalist Connections

A federal court in Washington, D.C., unsealed documents in a lawsuit over Fusion GPS's bank records on Tuesday, providing new details of payments made last year to the opposition research firm that commissioned the infamous Trump dossier. The documents also shed light on requests made by the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence about payments that Fusion GPS made to journalists.

The records, unsealed in response to a ruling made last week by Richard Leon, a federal judge in the district court in Washington, D.C., reveal transactions between two law firms that Fusion GPS worked with last year on two Russia-related projects.

Perkins Coie, the law firm that represented the Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee, paid Fusion GPS a total of $1,024,408 between May 24, 2016, and Dec. 28, 2016. The largest payment was made just before the election, with Perkins Coie making a $365,275 payment to Fusion GPS on Oct. 28, 2016. A payment made to Fusion in late-December is later than previously thought.

The transaction list does not show payments that Fusion made to Christopher Steele, the former British spy who wrote the dossier. Fusion reportedly paid Steele a total of $168,000 for his work, which lasted from June 2016 until the election.

The records show that Fusion was also paid $523,651 by the law firm BakerHostetler between March 7, 2016, and Oct. 31, 2016. Fusion worked for BakerHostetler to investigate Bill Browder, a London-based banker who helped push through the Magnitsky Act, a sanctions law vehemently opposed by the Kremlin.

BakerHostetler represented Prevezon Holdings and its owner, a Russian businessman named Denis Katsyv. Katsyv and Prevezon sought to limit the impact of the Magnitsky sanctions.

Glenn Simpson, a former Wall Street Journal reporter and Fusion GPS founding partner, compiled the research for the anti-Browder project. He worked closely with Natalia Veselnitskaya, the Russian lawyer who also showed up at the infamous Trump Tower meeting held on June 9, 2016. Simpson's research ended up in the Trump Tower meeting in the form of a four-page memo carried by Veselnitskaya. She also shared Simpson's work with Yuri Chaika, the prosecutor general of Russia.

Simpson testified this week that he did not know that Veselnitskaya provided the Browder information to Chaika or to Donald Trump Jr., the Trump campaign's point-man in the Trump Tower meeting. Simpson also stated that he did not know that Veselnitskaya had visited Trump Tower until it was reported in the press earlier this year.

The unsealed documents also reveal details of the House committee's requests for records related to Fusion's payments to journalists. The document shows that the committee sought records related to "five Fusion payments to research and Russia expert [name redacted]" and the production of three additional payments. The committee also seeks records "related to Fusion's payments to journalists who have reported on Russia issues relevant to its investigation."

In a memo filed Tuesday, lawyers for the House panel stated that they are seeking transactions related to nine payments made to "three individual journalists...each of whom have reported on and/or been quoted in articles regarding topics related to the Committee's investigation, some of which were published as recently as October 2017." The names of the journalists are redacted in the filing.

It is not clear from the requests whether Fusion GPS paid active journalists for their work. The firm is known to employ a stable of former reporters. Simpson and his two founding partners, Peter Fritsch and Thomas Catan, worked together at The Wall Street Journal.

The unsealed filings show that Fusion argued against releasing records related to payments to journalists. In a Nov. 3 declaration, Fritsch argued that "transactions between Fusion GPS and certain journalists...are not pertinent to work related to Russia or Donald Trump." And in a Nov. 2 email to the Intel committee's legal team, Levy argued that "records related to payments to the journalists and 'individuals' are protected by the First Amendment and confidentiality, and they are not pertinent."

Title: Justice Department Drops Charges Against John Edwards, Ending High-Profile Corruption Trial

Article:

In a significant development, the Justice Department announced on Wednesday that it will not be retrying former Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards, following a federal judge's declaration of a mistrial in his corruption case two weeks ago. The department's decision was formalized with an "order for dismissal" filed in the U.S. District Court in North Carolina, dismissing the remaining five counts against Edwards on which the jury had been deadlocked.

Assistant Attorney General Lanny Breuer, in a statement, explained that the government has decided not to retry Edwards "in the interest of justice." Breuer defended the department's decision to prosecute the case, stating, "We knew that this case -- like all campaign finance cases -- would be challenging. But it is our duty to bring hard cases when we believe that the facts and the law support charging a candidate for high office with a crime."

Breuer further noted, "Last month, the government put forward its best case against Mr. Edwards, and I am proud of the skilled and professional way in which our prosecutors conducted this trial. The jurors could not reach a unanimous verdict on five of the six counts of the indictment, however, and we respect their judgment."

Edwards' attorneys, Abbe Lowell, Allison Van Laningham, and Alan Duncan, welcomed the decision in a joint written statement. They stated, "While John has repeatedly admitted to his sins, he has also consistently asserted, as we demonstrated at the trial, that he did not violate any campaign law nor even imagined that any campaign laws could apply."

The attorneys further added, "We are confident that the outcome of any new trial would have been the same. We are very glad that, after living under this cloud for over three years, John and his family can have their lives back and enjoy the peace they deserve."

Judge Catherine Eagles had declared a mistrial two weeks ago when the jury was unable to reach a verdict on most of the counts alleging Edwards accepted illegal campaign contributions. Prosecutors had tried to prove that hush money sent to his mistress by wealthy donors during the 2008 presidential campaign constituted illegal donations.

However, Edwards' lawyers maintained throughout the trial that the money was intended to hide his affair from his wife Elizabeth, who has since passed away from cancer, and not from voters. Edwards himself, after the trial, stated, "I do not believe I did anything illegal, but 'I did an awful, awful lot that was wrong.'"

Title: Republican Senator Jeff Sessions Accuses Obama Administration of Failing to Enforce Century-Old Immigration Law on Public Charge

Article:

In a recent statement, Republican Sen. Jeff Sessions, top Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, has accused the Obama administration of failing to enforce a century-old law meant to prevent immigrants from taking root in the U.S. and relying on government welfare. The administration reported that no one was cited for this violation last year.

Sessions argued that "virtually no one" is being examined before they enter the country to determine if they will immediately begin to depend on government welfare. He stated that any immigration reform package "has got to end that."

Last week, Sessions presented new statistics from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) that he described as a startling trend. DHS reported that relatively few immigrants are being turned away on the grounds that they are likely to become a "public charge" – individuals who depend on welfare programs – despite a 100-year-old law that is supposed to prevent this.

The department, citing "data entry quality," reported that it did not have complete information on how many immigrants became public charges. However, the department did conduct a case-by-case review for the bulk of fiscal 2012, and found just one case where this claim was leveled at an immigrant. "However, the charge was later withdrawn," DHS reported.

Further, the department reported that just a tiny fraction of people are rejected on these grounds when seeking entry under a program that allows admission for 90 days for travelers from certain countries. Between fiscal 2005 and most of fiscal 2012, a total of 9,796 were denied – a fraction of a percent of those admitted. State Department figures for visa applications showed a similar trend, with just.068 percent of visa applications denied on those grounds in fiscal 2011.

Sessions has been vocal about this issue for months. He and other Republican senators earlier wrote to the departments of Homeland Security and State arguing that a bedrock principle of immigration law is that "those who seek citizenship in this country ought to be financially self-sufficient."

The senator suggests the immigration system has produced a lopsided result in which high-skill immigrants are turned away while those who end up absorbing more taxpayer dollars than they contribute stay. Recent studies show welfare spending on immigrant-headed households is relatively high. A Center for Immigration Studies report found that 36 percent of these households were using "at least one major welfare program" in 2010 – compared with 23 percent of other households.

Sessions' office states that the number of non-citizens on food stamps has skyrocketed in recent years. The conservative Heritage Foundation claims low-skill immigrant households take in roughly $20,000 more in government benefits every year than they pay in taxes.

Sessions suggests the government is fueling this trend. He earlier made a fuss over long-running U.S. Department of Agriculture radio "novelas" that depicted people being pressured into going on food stamps. The ads were later discontinued. The senator also is drawing attention to the WelcomeToUSA.gov site that provides information on a host of taxpayer assistance programs for immigrants, including Medicare, food stamps, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, and others.

Title: U.S. Lifts Sanctions on Three Russian Companies, Oligarch Oleg Deripaska Remains Under Restrictions

Article:

The U.S. Treasury Department announced on Wednesday that it will remove sanctions on three Russian companies, including aluminum giant United Co. Rusal PLC, EN+ Group PLC, and JSC EuroSibEnergo, which were previously on the U.S. sanctions list due to their ownership or control by Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska.

The Treasury Department stated that the companies agreed to a comprehensive deal that will result in their removal from the blacklist in 30 days. The deal is based on a change in factual circumstances, in line with longstanding U.S. sanctions precedent, and is not intended to significantly alter U.S. foreign policy.

The U.S. also imposed fresh sanctions on 15 Russian agents, including a former Russian intelligence officer who is reported to work for Mr. Deripaska and lead business negotiations on his behalf. The Treasury had issued licenses at least six times since April, allowing the companies to continue operating while they worked with the U.S. government to reach a satisfactory divestment plan.

The agreement requires Mr. Deripaska to reduce his ownership stake in EN+ from 70% to 44.95%, and he is prohibited from increasing his stake. Mr. Deripaska will not receive cash for his shares nor future dividends issued by the companies. EN+ is the linchpin underlying the sanctions designations on all three companies, as Mr. Deripaska has virtually no direct ownership in Rusal and none at all in EuroSibEnergo.

The agreement also mandates sweeping governance changes. Mr. Deripaska's voting rights in EN+ will be limited, and EN+ will create a 12-person board mostly independent of him. He will be bound to commitments severing his ability to control the company. In addition, EN+ and Rusal agreed to a number of transparency measures, including the provision of quarterly earnings reports, board minutes, and notifications of any change in board composition.

EN+ will continue to control Rusal through a 56.88% stake, and it will retain the right to nominate the chief executive. EN+ also will use that majority control to create a 14-person board, most of whom will have no ties to Mr. Deripaska. Rusal's current chairman will step down, and the new chair will be held by one of the new directors. EuroSibEnergo, which is wholly owned by EN+, will provide the Treasury with monthly certifications that they are not acting on behalf of Mr. Deripaska.

The companies will face severe consequences if they fail to comply with the agreement, including being put back on the sanctions list. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that "OFAC maintains the ability under the terms of the agreement to have unprecedented levels of transparency into operations."

David Murray, a vice president at consulting firm Financial Integrity Network who previously served as the director of Treasury's illicit finance office, commented that "What we have is an outline of expectations that OFAC may have for other companies targeted solely because they're owned or controlled by someone on the sanctions list."

Aluminum prices, which fell to a 16-month low before the sanctions announcement, could head lower once the sanctions are lifted. Some analysts had predicted aluminum prices would rise again in 2019, based in part on the sanctions against Rusal, the world's second-largest aluminum producer. "If (the sanctions) had not been solved, at least half of Rusal's production would have had to shut down," said Lloyd O' Carroll, an independent analyst for the metals industry. "That's not happening now."

Title: Town Hall Debate: A Balancing Act for Obama and Romney as They Emulate Clinton's 1992 Performance

Article:

The town hall-style debate, popularized by Bill Clinton in 1992, is set to return on Tuesday, with President Obama and former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney taking the stage. However, the format presents a unique challenge for President Obama, who is expected to display more passion and engage more directly with the audience, according to political analysts.

Chris Arterton, a professor of political management at George Washington University, notes that Democratic partisans are eager to see a more passionate performance from President Obama, but the town hall format may not be the ideal platform for him to display this passion while also taking on Romney in a more confrontational manner.

"Unfortunately, Obama, given his performance in the first debate, has to do two things simultaneously — take on Romney in a more confrontational way and at the same time, be responsive to the person asking the question," Arterton says. "That's not easy."

Alan Schroeder, a journalism professor at Northeastern University, agrees that the town hall format will require a balancing act from the president. "The town hall format is more conversational. There's more of a dialogue with people asking the questions," Schroeder says.

Candidates at debates are known for dodging questions and delivering rehearsed political soliloquies. However, in a town hall, ignoring a question from a working mother of two from Red Hook, for example, would not be an option.

"In a town hall, I think one of the measurements is whether the candidate is responsive to the question," Schroeder says. "There are also some physical things. Being able to maneuver the space, understanding that it's a different-looking debate than the ones where you either sit at a table or stand at lecterns."

Bill Clinton's performance in the 1992 town hall debate is often cited as a model for how to engage with the audience. "He got off his chair; he engaged more than President Bush did. He walked around more freely, was more responsive, more natural," Arterton says.

However, the town hall debate format has become more controlled in recent years, with campaigns placing more restrictions on the questions asked. "Now, you have to get there early, write up your question on a piece of paper, the moderator chooses the question, the questioner is not allowed to depart from what they have written, they are not allowed to follow up," Schroeder says.

The result? The 2008 town hall debate between Obama and GOP nominee Sen. John McCain was "one of the dullest presidential debates in history," Schroeder says. "The campaigns don't like spontaneity," he says. "They want to be able to predict the questions, and if they are vetted by the moderator first, there's a better chance of doing so."

The tussle over control of the format is ongoing, with CNN anchor Candy Crowley, who will moderate the debate, raising hackles on both sides for suggesting that she may take a more active role in the questioning. As strange as it sounds after his lackluster performance in Denver, one last hurdle for President Obama might be changing his tactics while still giving off an aura of consistency. In 2000, Vice President Al Gore changed his style from debate to debate, Arterton notes. "First he was Attila the Hun, then Mr. Nice Guy and in the last debate, he was the geeky policy wonk," he says. "People just couldn't get a fix on who he was."

Title: Tucker Carlson Addresses Growing Political Tensions in New Book: "Ship of Fools"

In a recent interview, Fox News host Tucker Carlson discussed the increasing political polarization in the United States, citing instances of confrontational protests and the role of the mainstream media in shaping public opinion.

The latest example of such confrontations occurred last Friday, when a protester confronted Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and his wife, Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, at a restaurant in Kentucky. The protester reportedly told them to "get out of here" and "leave the entire country." The protesters followed McConnell to his car and threw his to-go box out the door.

Carlson, in an interview with ███ News, accused the mainstream media of being "water carriers for the Democratic Party." He argued that the media's presentation of news is a reflection of the Democratic Party's political objectives for the day.

President Donald Trump's latest tagline, "jobs not mobs," suggests that the Democratic Party has become the party of mob rule, an idea that Carlson agrees with. He stated, "The Democratic Party obviously is not in control of its crazy people on the street, okay. Those people are committing acts of violence. They do not want to admit that because they know it scares normal people."

When asked about the alleged violence on the political Right, Carlson responded, "That's not true." He acknowledged the existence of extremists on all sides but argued that there are currently no groups of conservatives engaging in the same level of disruptive behavior as some on the Left, such as shouting at lawmakers in restaurants, on airplanes, or in airports, or damaging property.

Carlson's views on the country's heated politics are further explored in his new book, "Ship of Fools: How a Selfish Ruling Class is Bringing America to the Brink of Revolution." The book is set to provide insights into the current state of American politics and the potential consequences of the country's polarization.

Title: GOP Unveils Detailed Draft of Obamacare Replacement Plan: A Comprehensive Look at the Proposed Legislation

Article:

In a significant development, the Republican party has released a detailed draft proposal for the long-awaited Obamacare replacement plan. The document, while not a finalized piece of legislation, offers a comprehensive and specific glimpse at the Republicans' approach to overhaul the Affordable Care Act (ACA).

The proposed bill, according to analysts, eliminates most of the onerous, market-distorting provisions contained within the ACA. It abolishes many of the subsidies that reduce the incentives for those outside the labor force to remain there, and it eliminates the individual mandate to purchase insurance.

Based on age, not income, the plan would establish tax credits to help uninsured patients afford private insurance plans. The plan scales back or eliminates some of ObamaCare’s most burdensome tax provisions, including the Medicare surtax on wages and self-employment income. It eliminates federal Medicaid expansion by 2020, but preserves capped payments to states based on the number of enrollees in states that expanded Medicaid already.

Most encouragingly, the plan includes grants to states that would allow them to experiment with programs designed to increase coverage rates or reduce premiums.

However, the plan also includes elements that appear to partially mimic or tweak Obamacare's existing provisions. Conservative healthcare wonk Avik Roy offers a mixed verdict on the roadmap laid out in the leaked document. He notes that Republicans have abandoned the flawed "repeal and delay" strategy, which would have rolled back large swathes of Obamacare via reconciliation, then punted the replacement piece to an undetermined later date.

The new law would still prohibit insurers from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions, so long as those people have maintained continuous coverage. This strongly incentivizes consumers to obtain coverage without imposing an individual mandate tax (which is repealed under this plan) and while disincentivizing people to wait until they develop a health problem or injury before finally enrolling (by permitting insurers to charge substantially more to people who seek to sign up after a coverage gap).

The proposal also entails critical reforms to Medicaid (through a form of flexible block-granting) and Health Savings Accounts (roughly doubling the amount of money individuals and families can save for medical expenses tax-free). It also pumps billions into a modernized version of high-risk pools, under which states can innovate and invest to help cover the medical expenses of their most vulnerable citizens.

Overall, there are disputes and details that will undoubtedly still need to be ironed out. That's what debates, negotiations, and legislative mark-ups are for. I'd be quite surprised if the eventual legislative language were identical to the draft document, which is a useful and important starting point.

Meanwhile, knee-jerk accusations from some conservatives that the plan amounts to "Obamacare lite" are unfair; the core of the troubled law is removed, and replaced with a system that massively curtails burdensome federal mandates and taxes, and offers much more flexibility and discretion to the states. These changes, if adopted, would represent a welcome paradigm shift.

That said, it's not as if federal spending, mandates, and revenue-raisers will all magically disappear. Helping tens of millions of people have access to affordable coverage is a complex policy challenge. Republicans' draft proposal seeks to end the current law, then provide needed solutions in a less intrusive and market-distorting way than the current sputtering reality under Democrats' failed scheme.

Finally, with media chatter about town hall meetings on healthcare all the rage these days (with appalling displays like this receiving scant attention), I'll leave you with a few points: (1) Conservatives should go out of their way to attend these events and make phone calls to their members' offices in order to help stiffen GOP spines in the face of intense, and sometimes coordinated, liberal opposition. (2) Republicans ought to be prepared to defend their positions with compassion and confidence, as quite a few have been doing. (3) Beware of fake news stories about members "skipping" or "fleeing" town hall meetings that they'd never organized or committed to in the first place. (4) How's this for a narrative disruptor?

NEWS: From MT to WV, the nation's most vulnerable Senate Dems are avoiding town hall meetings - ABC News - via @ ABC.

Title: Young People Favor Same-sex Marriage, but the Future of Marriage Remains a Question: David Frum

Article:

In a significant shift in societal attitudes, young people overwhelmingly support same-sex marriage, according to political commentator David Frum. However, Frum poses a more pressing question: the future of marriage in general. Frum, a renowned author and senior editor at The Atlantic, points out that children born to single parents face much longer odds in life, and this issue may be more critical than the ongoing debate about same-sex marriage.

This week, the Supreme Court will hear arguments in two same-sex marriage cases. Regardless of the court's decision, the outcome seems predetermined, Frum suggests, given that 80% of Americans under 30 support same-sex marriage. However, while young straight Americans support marriage for gays, they are increasingly opting against marriage for themselves.

The trend is alarming, with nearly half of American children, 48%, now born to unmarried women. Among women without college degrees, and of all races, unwed motherhood has become the norm. This, Frum argues, is the crisis of the American family.

The consequences of single parenthood are far-reaching. Children born to married mothers and fathers are more likely to finish college, avoid prison, and form marriages themselves than children born to single parents. The harms of single parenthood tend to be self-replicating, threatening to create a caste divide, with some families launched into cycles of downward mobility due to the unstable relationships of parents, grandparents, or great-grandparents.

The debate over same-sex marriage has dominated headlines for the past two decades, while the issue of single parenthood has been largely overlooked. One reason for this, Frum suggests, is the lack of good ideas about how to address the problem. The core of the problem seems to be the decline of male wages relative to female wages.

In a recent New York Times article, MIT economist Michael Greenstone stated, "I think the greatest, most astonishing fact that I am aware of in social science right now is that women have been able to hear the labor market screaming out 'You need more education' and have been able to respond to that, and men have not. And it's very, very scary for economists because people should be responding to price signals. And men are not."

The decline of mass-production industries has put pressure on the roles and incomes of working-class and middle-class men. The expansion of government and service industries has opened new opportunities for women, of which working-class and middle-class men seem less able to avail themselves.

It's crucial to note that men in full-time work continue to earn more than women in full-time work. However, the bottom-line number conceals a widening divergence between the family patterns of the college-educated top one-third and those of the non-college-educated bottom two-thirds. The family life of the bottom two-thirds is the family policy challenge of the 21st century, Frum asserts. The debate over same-sex marriage is yesterday's issue; it's settled, whether the Supreme Court knows it or not. But how to ensure that the next generation of American children enjoys the more equal chance and the wider opportunities from a more universal commitment to marriage—that debate needs to begin.

Title: Romney's Wife Hints at Consideration of Female Vice Presidential Candidate, Discusses Campaign Strategy

Article:

In a rare joint interview with CBS News, Ann Romney, wife of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney, revealed that her husband is considering a female running mate for the upcoming election. The interview, conducted at the Romney family's lakeside estate in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire, also provided insights into the Romneys' strategy and the ongoing vice presidential search.

During the interview, Ann Romney stated, "We've been looking at that, and I love that option as well." She added, "There's a lot of people that Mitt is considering right now." When asked about President Obama's strategy, Ann Romney said, "Early on, we heard what their strategy was. It was 'kill Romney.' Not when I'm next to him, you better not."

Mitt Romney himself did not comment on his wife's characterization of President Obama's strategy during the joint interview. He also declined to discuss the status of the vice presidential search, stating, "That's something I'm keeping close with my team."

Speculation about the potential vice presidential candidate has been high, with names such as Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty, Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte, South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley, and former eBay CEO Meg Whitman being mentioned.

Ann Romney also outlined her requirements for a running mate, stating, "Someone that obviously can do the job but will be able to carry through with some of the other responsibilities." She added, "Competent, capable, and willing to serve this country. I think there's lots of good people out there that fill that bill right now."

The last time a woman was on a Republican presidential ticket was in 2008 when Sen. John McCain selected then-Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, a move that was criticized for her lack of readiness to be president. This year, Mitt Romney has emphasized preparedness to be president as his top requirement for a vice president.

The Romneys' interview comes at a crucial time in the campaign, with the Republican National Convention scheduled for late August. The Romneys are taking a week-long break at their New Hampshire estate, a chance for the candidate to contemplate strategy and adjust as necessary in a contest that polls show is close.

Several potential candidates, including Sen. Rob Portman, former Gov. Tim Pawlenty, and Gov. Bobby Jindal, were campaigning in Ohio this week, essentially auditioning for the vice presidential spot. Mitt Romney's vacation ends on Sunday, and he is scheduled to resume his campaign schedule full time after fundraising events in New York.

Title: Understanding the Causes of Mass Incarceration in America: A Look at the National Research Council Report

Article:

The United States is witnessing a growing movement towards reducing mass incarceration, with both the federal government and state governments scrutinizing the number of individuals they are sending to prison and the lengths of their sentences. However, the question remains: how did the U.S. prison population grow so significantly over the past 40 years?

A National Research Council report from 2014 debunked two common misconceptions about the causes of the increase, offering two primary reasons: increased efficiency in prosecution and lengthened prison sentences.

The report found that the rise in incarceration could not be attributed to crime rates increasing. Crime rates have varied over the past forty years, and do not seem to have a substantial impact on the prison population, regardless of the direction of crime rates. The report also found no evidence that harsher prison sentences deter crime.

It was not because of better policing leading to more arrests
Policing has evolved significantly since the beginning of the mass-incarceration era, and most of these changes have been designed to make policing more effective. This implies that police are better at apprehending criminals today than they were thirty years ago.

However, the NRC report showed that since 1980, the ratio of arrests per crime—in other words, the proportion of crimes that police were able to find and arrest suspects for—stayed relatively constant. Based on the arrest-to-crime ratio, the authors wrote, "no increase in policing effectiveness occurred from 1980 to 2010 that might explain higher rates of incarceration."

It was because people who got arrested were more likely to go to jail
While the arrest-to-crime ratio is a rough measure of police effectiveness, the prison-to-arrest ratio is a rough measure of the efficiency of the prosecution and court process. The NRC report found that prosecution has become more efficient, and this was a significant reason for the explosion of the incarcerated population.

Why are people who get arrested more likely to end up in prison now than they were thirty years ago? Part of it is that more crimes now require a prison sentence than required one in 1980, so more of the people who are found guilty of crimes end up having to go to prison for them (rather than getting probation or a fine).

Part of it is also that most people who get convicted of crimes these days never even go to trial—they just plead guilty in exchange for a shorter prison sentence. This makes it much easier for prosecutors to move cases through the courts. Of course, efficiency is not necessarily the same as effectiveness—in theory, the point of prosecution should be to determine whether the person committed a crime or not, not to convict and sentence as many people as possible.

But whatever the merits of the way prosecution works, the authors concluded it was definitely a big reason for the rise of mass incarceration. In fact, during the 1980s, it was the biggest reason, before being overtaken by the last and most important factor.

It was because people who went to prison served more time
The biggest reason the prison population exploded, especially after 1990: more people were in prison for longer periods of time. This is also largely due to changes in sentencing policy. States and the federal government added lots of new mandatory minimum sentences in the 1980s and 1990s, which forced people convicted of a given crime to serve a certain number of years in jail.

One particularly harsh kind of mandatory minimum sentence was imposed as "three-strikes" laws, which forced a criminal convicted of his third felony to serve a long prison sentence (between 25 years and a life sentence). States and the federal government also passed "truth-in-sentencing" laws, particularly in the late 1980s and early 1990s, which forced inmates to serve a large amount of their prison sentences (typically 85 percent) before being eligible for parole.

Ultimately, the NRC report's authors said, the common denominator in both of the big causes of mass incarceration—more prisoners per arrest, and longer sentences per prisoner—is the harsher sentencing policies of the 1980s and 1990s. That means that sentencing reform policies that some state governments have been pursuing, and that members of Congress in both parties have proposed, are a good place to start when it comes to reducing mass incarceration—even if they are not a panacea.

Title: Politicians Distance Themselves from Controversial Remarks Made by Cliven Bundy, Ted Nugent, and Phil Robertson

Article:

In the wake of Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy's racially charged comments about the welfare of African Americans under slavery, several prominent politicians have distanced themselves from the controversy. Bundy's remarks, which have been widely criticized as offensive and insensitive, are the latest in a series of incendiary racial comments from a new crop of folk heroes embraced in some conservative circles.

Bundy, 67, a rancher whose much-publicized land dispute with the federal government endeared him to conservatives, defended his comments as idle thoughts. "In my mind I'm wondering, are they better off being slaves, in that sense, or better off being slaves to the United States government, in the sense of the subsidies? I'm wondering. That's what. And the statement was right. I am wondering," he said Thursday on "The Peter Schiff Show."

However, Bundy stood by those comments in interviews with CNN on Thursday and Friday. In a tense exchange with "New Day" anchor Chris Cuomo on Friday morning, Bundy said, "Maybe I sinned... If I say Negro or black or slave... if those people can not take those kind of words and not be (offended), then Martin Luther King has not got his job done yet... We need to get over this prejudice stuff."

Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a potential 2016 presidential GOP contender, Republican Sen. Dean Heller of Nevada, and other conservatives have scrambled to distance themselves from the controversy. "His remarks on race are offensive and I wholeheartedly disagree with him," Paul said in a statement. Heller "completely disagrees with Mr. Bundy's appalling and racist statements, and condemns them in the most strenuous way," according to his spokesman, Chandler Smith.

The Republican National Committee said Bundy's comments were "completely beyond the pale. Both highly offensive and 100% wrong on race."

Experts on race and politics say the comments, much like those of rocker Ted Nugent, who created a firestorm when he called President Barack Obama a "subhuman mongrel," also speak to complicated and deeply fraught cultural tensions running beneath the surface in some segments of America.

"We are looking at some of the 'last white men standing,'" said Mark Anthony Neal, an African-American studies professor at Duke University, referring to demographic shifts that show minorities now represent more than half of the nation's population born in 2010 and 2011, according to the most recent census data.

"His comments represent that, and people rally around him because of this idea that white men are under siege. They are calling out the political establishment to stand by them," Neal said.

Over the next several generations, political experts say minority voters will become more of a power base in the Deep South, the Southwest, and in California. During the 2012 presidential election, Republicans faced huge losses among minorities and women, prompting the GOP to re-examine outreach to those groups.

Bundy's comments, much like those of Nugent and "Duck Dynasty" star Phil Robertson, who shared during an interview with GQ last year pastoral recollections of blacks "singing and happy" as he and his family worked alongside them in Louisiana cotton fields, speak to a certain politically active fringe element, political experts say.

"What this reflects is that there are groups of people who have not been accepted by politically correct circles and have never learned to frame their comments in a palatable fashion. They take pride in that," said Andra Gillespie, an associate professor of political science at Emory University. "The articulation of their views is somewhat fringe, but the underlying attitude is not. They are a minority viewpoint, but they are a large minority."

Politicians who have previously embraced men such as Bundy, Nugent, and Robertson as cause célèbres are now finding themselves in an awkward position. For instance, Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott, his state's Republican nominee for governor, took heat from some quarters when Nugent appeared at a campaign event for him this year. Abbott's campaign said it did not endorse Nugent's comments.

Other Republicans viewed as potential presidential candidates, including Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and the state's governor, Rick Perry, also distanced themselves from Nugent's remarks. Paul said an apology was in order, which Nugent eventually offered for using the term.

Conservative radio host Sean Hannity said on his show that he worries Democrats will now use Bundy's "repugnant" and "despicable" comments to paint everyone on the far right as racists. "If you ever want to be taken seriously for your outreach efforts, you might want to start by not defending racists," DNC spokesman Mo Elleithee said in a statement.

Title: White House Invokes Executive Privilege in Fast and Furious Documents Controversy

Article:

The ongoing dispute between the Obama administration and the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee over the Fast and Furious operation has escalated, with reports indicating that the White House is invoking executive privilege over documents that the committee's Republican majority has subpoenaed. This development comes just before a committee hearing, where lawmakers are expected to vote on whether to cite Attorney General Eric Holder for contempt of Congress for failing to comply with the subpoena.

The hearing, which is to be webcast, is set to take place amidst the news of the executive privilege assertion. According to NPR's Carrie Johnson and others, the committee is expected to proceed with the majority's plan to cite Holder for contempt.

Fast and Furious gained public attention following the December 2010 death of a U.S. Border Patrol agent, Brian Terry. Two guns linked to the flawed gun-trafficking operation were found near Terry's body, sparking two congressional probes and an ongoing investigation by the Justice Department's inspector general.

During a hearing on June 7, Holder faced tough questioning from Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) and other Republican lawmakers. Issa asked Holder if his department was aware of the tactics used in the gunrunning operation, and Republicans accused him of not being forthcoming and not complying with subpoenas.

As of now, the committee has not yet voted on the contempt citation. Members are still arguing along partisan lines, with Republicans advocating for and Democrats opposing the contempt citation of Holder.

If the committee does vote to hold Holder in contempt, the contempt citation would then go to the full House. The Associated Press reports that if the matter progresses, there could be a federal case against Holder, but past examples suggest the matter may not reach that point.

The lawmakers are still deliberating, and no vote has been cast as of yet. Committee members are still giving their opening statements, with arguments along party lines—Republicans stating that the Obama administration has been resisting efforts to obtain information about Fast and Furious, while Democrats argue that the administration has cooperated fully.

At the start of the hearing, Issa stated that the committee did not aim to hold Holder in contempt, but rather to "get the information the committee needs to complete its work." He described the assertion of executive privilege as "untimely" and "not spoken of last night" during negotiations between committee staffers and Justice Department officials.

Title: Montana Special Election: Republican Greg Gianforte Wins Amid Assault Allegation

Article:

In a closely-watched race, Republican Greg Gianforte has emerged victorious in the Montana special congressional election, defeating Democrat Rob Quist despite an election-eve altercation with a journalist that led to a misdemeanor assault charge.

According to the Associated Press, with 83 percent of precincts counted, Mr. Gianforte led Mr. Quist by a margin of 50.3 percent to 43.9 percent. Libertarian Mark Wicks secured 5.8 percent of the vote.

The race was called in Mr. Gianforte's favor more than 2½ hours after polls closed at 8 p.m. MDT. The victory comes less than 24 hours after Mr. Gianforte was charged with misdemeanor assault following an incident involving a reporter from Britain's Guardian newspaper.

In his election night speech, Mr. Gianforte expressed gratitude to Montana voters, stating, "Tonight, Montanans are sending a wake-up call to the Washington DC establishment." He also addressed the incident with reporter Ben Jacobs, saying, "I made a mistake and I took an action that I can't take back."

The outcome of the election means that Republicans will now hold a 239-193 majority in the House. The victory, however, could potentially cause headaches for GOP lawmakers, who have faced questions over their stance on Mr. Gianforte's behavior and his potential inclusion in the GOP conference.

House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have both expressed disapproval of Mr. Gianforte's actions, while House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi described him as a "wannabe Trump" and called for a "higher standard of behavior."

Despite the controversy, Mr. Gianforte's victory marks the continued success of Republicans in special congressional races following the election of President Trump. The Democrats, on the other hand, are now 0 for 2 in special election races, having also lost the April special election in the 5th Congressional District in Kansas.

Looking ahead, both parties will now focus on the June 20 special election in Georgia's 6th Congressional District, where Democrat Jon Ossoff and Republican Karen Handel are in a tight race.

Title: The Importance of Political Dialogue at the Thanksgiving Table: A Call for Conservative Families to Engage with Progressive Relatives

Article:

As the holiday season approaches, many Americans are reminded of the unspoken rule to avoid political discussions during family gatherings, especially during Thanksgiving. However, this year, some conservative media outlets are urging families to seize the opportunity to engage in political dialogue with their progressive relatives, particularly those who have moved to coastal cities or are attending college.

For conservative families, Thanksgiving may be the only time to speak to their progressive relatives with a home-field advantage, outside of their liberal bubble. This term, "bubble," is not used in hyperbole but represents the closed-off mindset of American progressivism in coastal cities and on college campuses.

In cities like New York, where the labor movement is seen as too centrist, and avowed Socialists are now a "political force," do conservative family members ever get to hear both sides? Of course not. On the coasts, far-flung progressive interest groups are now directing policy, and rational thought and political balance are principles relegated to the occasional op-ed.

On campus, conservative relatives may be in much more dire straits, having their minds shaped in the midst of the unparalleled and unmitigated rage of the American left, where "cancel culture" and groupthink overshadows academic debate. That's a $41,000 bill for a degree in close-minded wokeness you're paying for, mom and dad.

Fellow conservative, if you are concerned by this, and by the broader rise of the radical left, then by-God you must use this holiday for more than just gorging on Karen's apple cobbler. You have your son, daughter, niece, or nephew on your home turf, where they can't be blinded: the family table. Make use of it!

Do not hesitate to retell the story of why you live where you live, especially if you're one of millions of American families who have fled the high-taxed states for other parts of the country. Explain how this has bettered their lives.

Remind them about religion, and how religious institutions have been a positive force for change in our country since its inception. Perhaps they enjoyed playing for the St. Ignatius basketball team, or how mom relied on the J.C.C. afterschool program so she could work. Has their family benefitted from a religious organization?

Let them wow you with their talk of Socialism. Then confront them with the stark reality of why it scares you. Has a family member ever experienced it firsthand, or at least seen on television the devolution and poverty of the Soviet Union and other countries over the years?

Be open about your family's past. Whether it immigrated like mine 100 years ago from the sulfur mines of Sicily to the subway tunnels of New York, or whether yours came like so many just years ago with nothing but the hope and promise of hard work, explain how your family made sacrifices and took risks.

Perhaps even recall how your household was once Democratic, and how membership in a union played a role in their success. But unmask the modern party and how they have abandoned the middle class for the fringe-left.

Talk about the law enforcement. Do they feel the same anti-police anger as many in their generation? Do they not recall the family members who wore a badge, or the friends they grew up with who became cops? Are those people really racists, or fascists, or whatever they tend to call them?

Do not hesitate to bring up Trump. Sure, they may hate him, but explain why your family may be better off. Explain what more money in the family bank account does for them, personally. Explain what the booming economy and job market has done for the hometown and the neighbors they once loved. Remind them how the retirement fund looks, and how there will be more for them some day in the future.

Prepare for some hurt feelings and rolling-eyes by the time the pumpkin pie is served. But on balance, we all must realize that these opportunities to confront those in our family who form the vanguard of the American left are few and far in between. If we don't want to end up eating meatless turkey at some Thanksgiving in the future, now may be the time to serve up a hot plate of reality.

Title: Newsrooms Adapt to Trump Presidency: A New Era of Unpredictability and Excitement

Article:

As the reality of a Donald Trump presidency sets in, the media landscape is undergoing a significant shift. The unpredictable and controversial nature of the president-elect has revitalized newsrooms, offering a plethora of storylines and changes that were not anticipated.

"This changes everything," says Phil Griffin, president of MSNBC. "We left the studio at 4 a.m., and we knew there was a whole other world of storylines and changes that are going to happen."

Major TV news operations were bracing for a ratings decline as the historic and contentious election wound down. CNN had its highest online traffic ever on Election Day, and the election was a distinct revenue driver for its parent company, Time Warner, this year. However, the company was warning as early as summer that its ratings would drop next year.

But Tuesday happened. Trump defied most polls and emerged victorious, leaving TV networks to quickly reconsider coverage plans and story ideas. "There are so many different threads that we'll pursue that we didn't imagine three days ago," Griffin says. "It's an amazing story about what's going on in this country."

The first 100 days of any presidency are exciting, particularly when a new party takes over in Washington, D.C. The transition, with politicians jockeying for key Cabinet positions, is a horse race of its own kind. But, Trump, the inexperienced politician suddenly leading the federal government, adds multiple and substantive layers to the story.

"You've got a more dynamic transition in place," says Chris Isham, CBS News' Washington bureau chief. "He's not a predictable Republican, not in the way of previous administrations."

Gauging Trump's comfort level with the press, already underway, has been as challenging as pinning down his stance on issues. Reporters who have known him for years speak of his accessibility and willingness to banter. Yet he's also sought political advantage in bashing the mainstream media.

"Let's see how much access he grants," Ariens said. "He's not the candidate anymore. He's not going to be calling into Fox and Friends."

One of the first major interviews Trump granted after the election was to 60 Minutes, which will air Sunday. Jeff Fager, executive producer of 60 Minutes, said the show had planned on pursuing an interview with the president-elect regardless of the election outcome, but because so much of Trump's governing philosophy and policy specifics are unknown, it heightens the urgency.

"It's not about good TV. It's about how we can help people better understand," Fager says. "There's a lot to talk about. Hopefully, we'll get some details."

In an interview clip released early by CBS, Trump says he's willing to retain some key provisions of the Affordable Care Act, including prohibiting insurers from denying coverage to patients with pre-existing conditions.

There has already been plenty of hand-wringing in American newsrooms about the failure to properly assess the impact of Trump's voters and the issues that drove them so eagerly to the voting booths. Coverage planning for Trump's presidency must entail deep-diving into these issues to hold him accountable for some of his outlandish proposals, Fager says.

"There are so many layers that make this interesting," he says. "He's tapped into the dissatisfied voters. That's an important part of this. How is he going to address the issues they care about? How is he going to build a wall?"

Beyond issues, scrutinizing Trump's governing styles and tendencies—not as a career politician, but honed on the fly based on his experience as a real estate developer and TV personality—will also be a rich source of stories.

"He's a businessman who's a negotiator," Fager says. "There's a lot of stories that could be generated in (covering) someone who's got a totally different perspective on how to get things done."

While no news executives may admit it publicly, the possibility of Trump's gaffes and unfiltered diatribes, frequently evident during his campaign, remains an intriguing variable, says Mark Feldstein, a broadcast journalism professor at the University of Maryland, College Park, and a former journalist at NBC.

"Media critics are always attacking TV for ideological bias," he says. "But the real bias is toward conflict, controversy, and excitement because that's what increases revenue. Whether you love or hate him, he is going to bring controversy."

Title: Trump Softens Stance on Immigration, Courts Non-White Vote Amidst Controversial Remarks

Article:

In a significant shift in his campaign strategy, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has softened his stance on the contentious issue of immigration, as he seeks to appeal to non-white voters. This move comes amidst a series of controversial statements made by the candidate this week, which have sparked debate and criticism.

The week began with Trump's interview with Fox News host Sean Hannity, where he stated, "They'll pay back taxes, they have to pay taxes. There's no amnesty, as such, there's no amnesty, but we will work with them." This statement appears to indicate a departure from his previous hardline stance on immigration, which included the proposal for a "great, great wall" along the US-Mexico border and the suggestion of a "deportation force" to remove undocumented migrants.

However, the following day, after meeting with his Hispanic advisory council, reports emerged that Trump was softening his stance. His campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, seemed to waffle on whether Trump was still committed to deportation. In response, Trump denied that he was "flip-flopping" and postponed a speech he was due to give on Thursday to fine-tune his immigration policy.

On Wednesday, Trump clarified that immigrants not in the US legally would not be granted citizenship but seemed to offer a path forward, contradicting his previous promises of deportation. This apparent moderation on immigration comes as Trump tries to aggressively court Hispanic and African American voters, trailing behind Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in polls.

In a speech in Akron, Ohio, on August 22, Trump made a series of statements about crime in American cities, particularly those run by the Democrats. He claimed that crime is at "levels that nobody's seen" and that crime-ridden American streets are more dangerous than parts of the world where the US is engaged in military action. However, this statement contradicts a trend of declining crime that has persisted for over a quarter of a century.

Trump also claimed to employ "so many, so many" African Americans in his various businesses. However, a June analysis by the Associated Press found "few if any" black executives in the upper echelon of Trump's organization. Trump has recently increased his outreach to African American voters, but he delivers his speeches before largely white audiences. A recent NBC/Wall Street Journal poll showed Trump receiving the support of only 1% of African American voters.

In a speech in Dimondale, Michigan, on August 19, Trump repeated the eye-popping statistic that more than half of young black men and women are unemployed. However, the latest figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics put the unemployment rate among 16- to 19-year-old black Americans at 25.7%. The campaign's economic adviser, David Malpass, explained that the 58% figure was calculated by including labor force participants and those outside the labor force, such as students and retirees, in the calculation. Economists have criticized this method as statistically misleading.

In conclusion, Donald Trump's recent statements and actions suggest a softening of his stance on immigration and a renewed effort to court non-white voters. However, his statements on crime and employment among African Americans have been met with criticism and controversy, raising questions about the accuracy and tact of his approach.

Title: Biden's Third Presidential Bid: A Unity Candidate in Question

Article:

As the 2020 presidential race heats up, former Vice President Joe Biden is gearing up for his third run for the highest office in the land, having previously contested in 1988 and 2008. Currently, Biden leads in 36 out of 37 polls compiled by RealClearPolitics, and is ahead in Iowa and even in Kamala Harris' home state of California.

However, Biden's campaign is facing a significant challenge: the question of his ability to unite the Democratic Party, a role he was once seen as a frontrunner for due to his long party service and his association with the popular Barack Obama administration. Recent months have seen a resurgence of criticism over Biden's past political and policy associations, particularly those that are not well-regarded by the party's minority and feminist constituencies.

Despite this, Biden's standing among Democratic voters remains strong. Morning Consult's tracking poll of Democrats shows him with a high approval rating of 75/15. He is also the top second-choice candidate for those who favor Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, or Bernie Sanders.

However, as the primary season approaches, it remains to be seen whether Biden can maintain his "unity candidate" persona, particularly if his rivals begin to attack him more forcefully. Some political analysts have raised concerns that Biden's past record could become a significant issue for actual voters, and that he may struggle to balance his moderate past with the party's more progressive leanings.

One potential solution for Biden is to establish himself as the most, or even the only, electable candidate against President Donald Trump. Some argue that Biden has a unique ability to appeal to white working-class swing voters in the Rust Belt states that were crucial to both Obama's and Hillary Clinton's victories. However, it is still early in the election cycle, and it remains to be seen whether this will prove to be a significant factor in the general election.

Title: Volker Testimony Undercuts Biden Allegations in Trump Impeachment Inquiry

Article:

In the ongoing impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, Republican lawmakers are increasingly relying on the closed-door testimony of senior diplomat Kurt Volker to defend Trump against allegations of improper dealings. Volker, a close ally of Trump, has provided a version of events that suggests Trump did not engage in a "quid pro quo" when he pressured Ukraine's new president to investigate allegations against Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.

Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) stated on Wednesday that "The definitive account on all of this is the one from Ambassador Volker." Around the same time, Trump tweeted a "thank you" to Volker for his testimony. A transcript of Volker's testimony, released by the House Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, has been a topic of discussion.

However, Volker's account contradicts the specific allegations against Biden that Trump and his allies have been promoting for months. In his testimony, Volker stated that no evidence was presented to support the allegations, and he considered them "very self-serving and not credible."

Biden has publicly admitted to pressuring Ukraine's leadership to fire prosecutor general Viktor Shokin in 2016, even threatening to withhold nearly $1 billion in U.S. aid if Shokin was not removed. Volker testified that Biden's actions were in line with U.S. policy at the time and were widely understood as the right policy.

Republicans have questioned Biden's son Hunter's involvement with Burisma, a major gas company in Ukraine, where he served on the board for two years. They have suggested that Burisma may have hired Biden's son to curry favor with the Obama administration or to protect themselves. Volker testified that it is "quite possible" that Burisma executives believed they were "buying influence" through Biden's son, but he did not believe Biden would take any improper action on his son's behalf.

Volker's testimony also sheds light on Shokin's reputation, with Volker stating that Shokin was not pursuing corruption cases and had a "notorious reputation" for not doing his job. This contradicts the allegations made by Shokin's successor, Yuriy Lutsenko, who claimed that Biden pushed for Shokin's firing to protect his son and derail the Ukrainian investigation of Burisma.

Volker testified that Lutsenko's allegations were self-serving and made up to save his job and prevent investigations into his own actions. Lutsenko's initial claims seemed to back away after Zelenskiy was elected as Ukraine's new president and after the allegations against Biden began to attract more media attention.

In conclusion, Volker's testimony undercuts the specific allegations against Biden that Trump and his allies have been promoting. The allegations against Biden have not been directly or fully debunked, according to Volker, as they have never been investigated. The impeachment inquiry against Trump continues, with the House Intelligence Committee expected to release more transcripts of closed-door testimony in the coming days.

Title: House Judiciary Committee Releases 658-Page Impeachment Report on President Trump

The House Judiciary Committee has released a comprehensive 658-page report detailing the impeachment case against President Donald Trump, early Monday morning. The report alleges two impeachable offenses: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress during its investigation.

The report states, "President Trump has placed his personal, political interests above our national security, our free and fair elections, and our systems of checks and balances." The Judiciary Committee argues that the President's actions constitute a pattern of misconduct that, if left unchecked, will continue. The report concludes, "Accordingly, President Trump should be impeached and removed from office."

The Democrats also assert that Trump has committed crimes, although these are not explicitly outlined in the articles of impeachment. The report states, "While there is no need for a crime to be proven in order for impeachment to be warranted, here, President Trump's scheme or course of conduct also encompassed other offenses, both constitutional and criminal in character."

The report alleges that Trump's abuse of power constituted the constitutional offense of "Bribery" and multiple federal crimes. The Democrats argue that Trump has betrayed the national interest, the people of the nation, and should not be allowed to be above the law.

Republicans, led by Ranking Member Doug Collins (R-GA), have criticized the Democrats for what they perceive as a biased impeachment process. Collins stated, "The facts are contested, and, in many areas, the majority's claims are directly contradicted by the evidence." The Republicans argue that the Democrats have based their impeachment case on hearsay and assumptions, and that the articles of impeachment do not include any of the criminal accusations leveled against the President over the past year.

The Republicans also claim that the Democrats' impeachment process is "unprecedented, unjustifiable, and will only dilute the significance of the dire recourse that is impeachment." The full House is expected to vote on the articles of impeachment this week.

Title: Missing Wisconsin Girl Jayme Closs Found After 88 Days; Suspect Arrested for Kidnapping and Murder

In a significant development, 13-year-old Jayme Closs, who had been missing since her parents were found dead in their home three months ago, has been located. The girl was found on Thursday, having escaped from a remote house and was subsequently found by a woman walking her dog.

Jayme was taken into police custody after the woman, upon noticing her, stopped at a nearby home to call the authorities. The teenager was reunited with her family on Friday following discussions with investigators.

The suspect in this case has been identified as Jake Thomas Patterson, a 21-year-old resident of the area. On Friday, investigators announced charges of kidnapping and murder against Patterson. Police stated that Patterson had meticulously planned his actions and taken steps to avoid detection.

Patterson was apprehended near the house from which Jayme had escaped, and his arrest was facilitated by a description of his vehicle that Jayme had provided. Authorities believe Patterson was searching for the girl when he was taken into custody.

Barron County Sheriff Chris Fitzgerald expressed his emotions after spending 88 days searching for Jayme, stating, "The will of a kid to survive – it's unthinkable." Fitzgerald also mentioned that, as of Friday morning, there was no evidence of a relationship between Patterson and the Closs family, nor any social media contact between Patterson and Jayme.

Patterson had a connection to Jayme's hometown, Barron, but the sheriff declined to elaborate on the nature of the connection. He also revealed that Patterson had altered his appearance before the attack and abduction in October, shaving his head to avoid leaving hair behind.

Investigators are still working to determine the details of Jayme's ordeal and the motives behind Patterson's actions. The search of the house where Jayme had most recently been held is ongoing, and it remains unclear if Jayme had been in the same house for the entire duration of her disappearance or if she was moved to other locations.

The local district attorney's office plans to issue a criminal complaint next week. Jayme's aunt, Sue Allard, expressed her joy upon learning of Jayme's return, stating, "Praise the Lord."

Police have stated that they are not searching for any additional suspects, and no one else was found in the house from which Jayme escaped. The FBI special agent in charge of Milwaukee, Justin Tolomeo, described the case as difficult due to the steps the suspect took to evade law enforcement, but commended Jayme for her resilience in escaping.

Patterson is scheduled to make his first court appearance on Monday.

Title: U.S. Withdraws from Arms Trade Treaty, Citing Sovereignty and Domestic Gun Rights

Article:

In a move that has been anticipated by gun rights advocates, President Donald Trump announced on Friday that the United States would withdraw as a signatory to the Arms Trade Treaty, a global agreement aimed at regulating the international sale of conventional weapons. The treaty, which was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 2013 but never ratified by the U.S. Congress, has been a point of contention between the gun lobby and the Obama administration.

Speaking at the National Rifle Association (NRA) annual convention in Indianapolis, President Trump declared, "We will never surrender American sovereignty to anyone." The NRA, a key backer of Trump's 2016 campaign, was a leading opponent of the treaty, arguing it could impinge on the rights of American gun owners.

The Arms Trade Treaty has been ratified by 101 countries, including member states of the European Union, but not by the United States. A senior administration official noted that China and Russia are not parties to the treaty. While some U.S. conservatives argue the treaty could open the door to stricter gun regulations at home, some experts say it has no effect on domestic arms sales or gun rights.

Thomas Countryman, a former assistant secretary of state who was the lead U.S. negotiator for the treaty, stated, "The treaty has no impact whatsoever on Second Amendment rights of U.S. citizens." Countryman, who was given explicit instructions by the Obama administration to negotiate the treaty's language in a way that would ensure U.S. compliance without changing any domestic laws, added that the U.S. has for decades had strict arms-export laws.

Rachel Stohl, managing director of the conventional defense program at the Stimson Center, a Washington think tank, described the decision as part of a U.S. retreat from global leadership. "Un-signing the Arms Trade Treaty will undermine international peace and security, increase irresponsible and illegal sales of conventional weapons, and harm the American economy," she said in a statement.

Ted Bromund, a senior research fellow at the Heritage Foundation's Margaret Thatcher Center for Freedom, praised the president for withdrawing from a treaty that "has achieved nothing." Bromund cited low levels of compliance with the treaty as evidence of its failure and said nations are free to impose their own legal controls on arms exports.

The decision comes amidst a series of moves by the Trump administration to distance the U.S. from international agreements, including the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which the U.S. announced in February it would withdraw from, citing alleged Russian violations.

During his third visit as president to an NRA annual convention, Trump pledged his support for gun rights, touted the strength of the U.S. economy, and criticized the recently completed Mueller investigation. Trump also warned the crowd that "far-left radicals in Congress" want to take their guns, saying "that will never happen as long as I'm president, not even close."

The president received a rousing reception from NRA members, despite criticism from some hard-line gun-rights advocates of his record on guns. The only major action Trump had taken on guns since being elected was to ban bump stocks, devices used in the September 2017 Las Vegas massacre that make semiautomatic rifles fire like machine guns. Meanwhile, Trump hasn't signed into law any major pro-gun legislation.

Title: Media Bias Allegations as NBC, CBS, and ABC Ignore Death Threats Against Senator Tim Scott and Pelosi's Controversial Remark

Article:

In a stark contrast to their coverage of political figures' controversial statements and book releases, the liberal broadcast networks, ABC, CBS, and NBC, have been accused of ignoring a New York Times report detailing death threats and racial slurs against Republican Senator Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the Senate.

On Tuesday, The New York Times published a report by Catie Edmondson, detailing the shocking death threats Senator Scott and his aides have received in recent days. The report mentioned two audio recordings shared by Scott, filled with profanity and racist slurs, including one call where a person discussed putting the senator "in his crosshairs."

Senator Scott, in an interview with The Times, blamed the media for how his police reform legislation was being portrayed. He stated, "It's interesting that we are on the right side of the police reform conversation, yet we're on the wrong side according to the people, based on the way that we are characterized in the national press."

The broadcast networks' lack of coverage of Senator Scott's ordeal and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's controversial remarks has raised questions about media bias. As reported last week, ABC and NBC skipped the official rollout of Scott's Justice Act, while CBS downplayed it in a 22-second mention.

Pelosi's comments, made on CBS News Radio, generated outrage when she said, "But so far, they were trying to get away with murder, actually, the murder of George Floyd." Despite the incendiary, divisive, and blatantly false comment, CBS Evening News had time to promote John Bolton's book, but refused to cover Pelosi's comments made to their own West Coast correspondent, Steve Futterman.

The lack of coverage and the apparent bias in reporting have sparked a debate about the role of media in shaping public opinion and the need for unbiased, factual, and informative news.

Title: "Bipartisan Dialogue on Immigration: A Personal Journey and a Surprising Discovery"

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Rremida Shkoza, an Albanian-born US citizen and real estate broker, found herself in a bipartisan conversation on immigration, hosted by her friend Tracy Hollister. The conversation, which took place in New York, brought together three Democrats and three Republicans, including a Chinese-American Republican co-host.

Shkoza, a refugee who fled communist Albania in 1991, shared her personal experiences of xenophobia and the struggles she faced as a young immigrant. To her surprise, her Republican counterparts, including a Brazilian immigrant and a North Carolina-based conservative, empathized with her story and emphasized the importance of humanizing immigrants and providing humane treatment for migrants and refugees.

The conversation, which focused on the need for comprehensive immigration reform, revealed a shared desire among participants to balance democratic values with the need to help others. While they acknowledged the challenges posed by immigration, they also agreed on the need to protect American values and provide a beacon for democratic values.

The conversation also touched on policy differences, with Shkoza raising concerns about the impact of Trump's tax cuts and the need to invest more in working-class Americans. The Republicans, in turn, discussed the importance of learning more about the root causes of immigration and reconsidering foreign aid distribution.

Shkoza left the conversation with a newfound hope for bipartisan cooperation, believing that personal connections across party lines are crucial for bridging the empathy gap. She concluded that the lack of empathy is not a deficit, but a lack of personal connection with those across the political spectrum.

This experience serves as a reminder that dialogue, understanding, and empathy are essential for finding common ground and moving forward in a polarized political climate. As Shkoza puts it, "We might not have all the answers, but we can start by engaging in conversations with those who may not share our political views, and by humanizing the immigrants and refugees who are seeking a better life in America."

Title: Federal Law Enforcement Tactics in Portland Spark Concerns Over Civil Liberties

Article:

In the heart of Portland, Oregon, federal law enforcement officers have been using unmarked vehicles to detain protesters since July 14, according to reports from Oregon Public Broadcasting (OPB). The tactic, which involves detaining individuals without explanation and driving off, has raised concerns over civil liberties and the escalation of federal force on Portland city streets.

Federal officers have charged at least 13 people with crimes related to the protests so far, while others have been arrested and released. Some demonstrators, like Pettibone and O' Shea, claim they were targeted by federal officers for simply wearing black clothing in the area of the demonstration. They attend protests regularly but say they are not "instigators." They don't spray paint buildings, shine laser pointers at officers, or do anything else other than attend protests, which law enforcement has regularly deemed "unlawful assemblies."

Pettibone and O' Shea's accounts, along with multiple videos posted online, show officers driving up to people, detaining individuals without explanation, and driving off. The tactic appears to be another escalation in federal force deployed on Portland city streets, as federal officials and President Donald Trump have said they plan to "quell" nightly protests outside the federal courthouse and Multnomah County Justice Center that have lasted for more than six weeks.

The use of unmarked vehicles and unidentified officers has sparked controversy, with some comparing the situation to police tactics in countries like Chile or Argentina, where people have been "disappeared" by authorities. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) of Oregon has called for an investigation into the federal government's actions in Portland.

Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf visited Portland on Thursday, where he reiterated the department's commitment to protecting federal facilities and those within them. Mayor Ted Wheeler and other local officials have said they did not ask for help from federal law enforcement and have asked them to leave. Governor Kate Brown called Wolf's visit "political theater from President Trump" and said he "is looking for a confrontation in Oregon in the hopes of winning political points in Ohio or Iowa."

The situation in Portland has raised concerns over the use of federal force in response to protests and the potential for similar tactics to be used in other cities. Critics argue that the federal government's actions in Portland are a violation of the principles of democracy and the rule of law.

As the situation in Portland continues to unfold, it remains to be seen whether the federal government will continue to use these tactics in other cities and whether there will be a broader investigation into the actions of federal law enforcement in Portland.

Title: Romney Affirms Individual Mandate in Health Care Law as a Tax Following Supreme Court Ruling

Article:

In a recent interview with CBS News, former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney confirmed that the individual mandate in President Obama's health care law is, in fact, a tax. This statement comes just days after Romney's campaign had previously rejected this characterization.

During the interview with Jan Crawford, Romney stated, "While I agreed with the dissent, that's taken over by the fact that the majority of the court said it's a tax. They have spoken."

He further added, "They concluded it was a tax. That's what it is, and the American people know that President Obama has broken the pledge he made. He said he wouldn't raise taxes on middle-income Americans. Not only did he raise the $500 billion that was already in the bill, it's now clear that his mandate, as described by the Supreme Court, is a tax."

On Monday, Romney's presidential campaign stated that the health care mandate should be considered a penalty and not a tax. This statement by Eric Fehrnstrom, the campaign's spokesman, contradicted the general stance of leading Republicans in Congress and elsewhere, who have been quick to accuse the president of imposing a new tax.

"The governor disagreed with the ruling of the court," Fehrnstrom said Monday on MSNBC's "The Daily Rundown." "He agreed with the dissent written by Justice Scalia, which very clearly stated that the mandate was not a tax."
