The characterization of the mandate is a delicate issue for the Romney campaign, given Romney's past support for universal health care in Massachusetts when he was governor there. While Romney has pledged to repeal what conservatives call Obamacare, he had previously avoided labeling the mandate as a tax, possibly due to his Massachusetts plan including a similar mandate.

Romney made his comments while vacationing in New Hampshire.

Title: Unforced Errors in Politics: A Look at Recent Blunders by Clinton and GOP Senators

Article:

In the world of sports, an unforced error is a mistake made by a player that costs them or their team. Similarly, in politics, unforced errors can be just as damaging, especially when the stakes are high, such as the pursuit of power. Recently, two significant unforced errors have been committed by both sides of the political aisle.

Hillary Clinton's presumptive nomination as the Democratic candidate for the 2016 presidential election faced a setback due to her use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State. While it may have seemed like a smart move in light of the Whitewater investigation that led to her husband's impeachment proceedings, the decision to bypass standard e-mail services for government business has raised questions about transparency and accountability.

For someone who has served in high office, it is questionable why one would not have an official government account to handle business emails while maintaining a separate account for personal correspondence. Clinton's explanation, reminiscent of her husband's defense during the Monica Lewinsky scandal, has been met with skepticism. "It depends upon what the meaning of the word 'is' is," she said, a statement that defies the common sense test for most observers.

For average voters, the focus on this issue may seem trivial, while partisan players will react along party lines. Democrats argue, "What's the big deal?" while Republicans view it as a constitutional controversy that requires further scrutiny.

Meanwhile, the Republican Party has also committed an unforced error with the open letter signed by 47 GOP Senators to the Iranian leadership. The letter, which was seen by some as a lesson in constitutional government, was perceived as arrogant and an attempt to sabotage any deal reached between the U.S. and Iran. The signatories, including U.S. Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, were criticized for meddling in foreign policy and appearing spiteful.

While senators have the constitutional power to approve a treaty and can outlast a president with their six-year terms, the tone and tactics used in the open letter were seen as inappropriate and potentially damaging to U.S. foreign relations.

In this age of political polarization, these unforced errors are a reminder of the partisan nature of the players and the potential consequences of their actions. Blind arrogance of power, whether in the handling of emails or the flaunting of senatorial power and prestige to a foreign nation, often backfires on those wielding the power.

As the political landscape continues to evolve, it remains to be seen how these unforced errors will impact the upcoming elections and the future of American politics. However, one thing is clear: the game of politics suffers when unforced errors are made.

Title: Attorney General Establishes Task Force to Combat Violent Anti-Government Extremism

Article:

In a move aimed at curbing violent activities by anti-government extremists, Attorney General William Barr has announced the formation of a task force within the Department of Justice (DOJ). The task force, as outlined in a June 26 memo to all heads of department components and U.S. attorneys, is designed to investigate, prosecute, and ultimately eliminate extremist violence that threatens public safety and the rule of law.

In the memo, Barr expressed concern over the escalating threats to the rule of law, citing instances of violence during recent protests, attacks on law enforcement officers, destruction of public and private property, and threats to innocent bystanders. The memo specifically references the unrest in Minneapolis following the death of George Floyd and the subsequent establishment of an "autonomous zone" in Seattle, which has been the site of acts of violence, including a recent shooting.

Barr's memo emphasizes that these extremist groups seek to deny constitutional rights to others and resort to illegal methods. The DOJ, according to Barr, has obtained information suggesting that some extremists intend to continue causing chaos. The task force will provide training and resources to local law enforcement to arrest perpetrators of violence and will collaborate closely with the FBI to gather detailed information about violent anti-government extremists, networks, and movements.

The task force will also share this information with federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies, particularly in areas where these extremists pose a threat. The announcement coincided with President Donald Trump's signing of an executive order aimed at protecting American monuments, memorials, and statues from destruction.

The task force's establishment comes amidst ongoing protests, largely peaceful, sparked by the police-custody death of George Floyd. While the protests have seen instances of violence, Barr's memo underscores the DOJ's commitment to upholding the rule of law and protecting constitutional rights.

Title: Former Texas Governor Rick Perry Suspends 2016 Presidential Campaign

Article:

In a speech at the Eagle Forum in St. Louis on Friday, former Texas Governor Rick Perry announced the suspension of his campaign for the 2016 GOP presidential nomination. Perry, who served as governor for 14 years, struggled to gain traction in a crowded and experienced field.

Perry, who attributed his decision to divine intervention, said, "That is why today I am suspending my campaign for the presidency of the United States." He acknowledged the strength of the current Republican field, stating, "Our party will be in good hands, as long as we listen to the grassroots, listen to that cause of conservatism."

Suspending a campaign, in political terms, is equivalent to dropping out of the race. Candidates typically cite technical fundraising issues as the reason for such a move. Perry's decision comes less than a week before the second debate of the primary season.

This marks the second presidential campaign Perry has ended prematurely, following his 2012 bid, which was labeled one of the biggest campaign failures in modern political history. In his 2016 bid, Perry had pledged to be more prepared and to learn from his mistakes, but he failed to find a niche in the crowded field.

Reports emerged last week that Perry had stopped paying his staff, and some of his team had defected to other political campaigns. Michael Dennehy, a Perry supporter and strategist in New Hampshire, expressed his support for Perry's decision, stating, "It is a shame that a man with the most successful executive experience and the one who can best relate to middle-class America will not be on the ballot as we choose the Republican nominee."

Perry was relegated to the second tier in last month's first presidential debate in Ohio, and was set to be in the second tier in next week's debate at the Reagan Presidential Library. Matt Schlapp, chairman of the American Conservative Union, noted that Perry's demotion in Cleveland was a significant setback.

"I knew that his demotion in Cleveland was punishing for him," Mr. Schlapp said. "It was really a body blow." Perry's departure leaves four candidates in the second-tier debate: Former Sen. Rick Santorum, former New York Gov. George Pataki, Sen. Lindsey Graham, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal.

The main stage, featuring 11 candidates, includes businessman Donald Trump, retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, Govs. Chris Christie of New Jersey, John Kasich of Ohio, and Scott Walker of Wisconsin, former Govs. Jeb Bush of Florida and Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, and Sens. Rand Paul, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio.

Perry concluded his speech by expressing gratitude for his life and family, stating, "As I approach the next chapter in life, I do so with the love of my life by my side, Anita Perry. We have our house in the country, we have two beautiful children and two adorable grandchildren, four dogs, and the best sunset from our front porch that you could ever imagine."

Title: ZOA Defends Stephen Bannon Against ADL's Allegations of Anti-Semitism

Article:

In a recent statement, President of the Zionist Organization of America (ZOA), Morton A. Klein, has criticized the Anti-Defamation League (ADL) for character assassination against President-elect Donald Trump's appointee, Stephen Bannon, and his media company, Breitbart. The ADL, through its president Jonathan Greenblatt, accused Bannon and Breitbart of "anti-Semitism" and Israel hatred.

However, the ZOA, in its statement, has defended Bannon, stating that he is an "American patriot who defends Israel & has deep empathy for the Jewish people." The ZOA's own analysis of Breitbart articles confirms this, citing several instances where Bannon and Breitbart have taken a stand against anti-Semitism.

For instance, Bannon, along with his Breitbart team, took action against anti-Semitic rallies at CUNY by urging officials to address the issue. Breitbart has also reported on the Palestinian Authority's dissemination of false information about Israel, such as the baseless claim that Israel poisoned former PA President Yasser Arafat.

Moreover, Breitbart has reported on the human cost of anti-Semitic incidents, such as a swastika being found on a Jewish student's dorm room door, and the rise of anti-Semitic incidents on US college campuses due to the anti-Israel Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) movement.

The ZOA has also highlighted Breitbart's coverage of Iran's violations of the Iran deal, which poses an existential threat to Israel, and its sympathetic reporting on the scourge of anti-Semitic anti-Israel boycotts.

In light of these actions, the ZOA has expressed its support for Bannon's appointment as chief strategist in the incoming Trump/Pence administration and has called on the ADL to withdraw and apologize for its character assassination of Bannon and Breitbart Media.

The statement also raises questions about the silence of the ADL and other Bannon critics regarding the inclusion of anti-Israel individuals in Hillary Clinton's advisory team, particularly George Soros, a major donor to Hillary Clinton. The ZOA questions why these critics did not voice similar concerns then.

Title: Attorney General Sessions Calls for Tougher Prosecution Policies, Reversing Obama-Era Policies

Article:

In a significant shift from Obama-era policies, Attorney General Jeff Sessions has directed federal prosecutors to pursue the most serious charges possible against the majority of suspects, a move that is expected to result in more people being sent to prison for longer terms.

In a memo sent Thursday night to US attorneys and made public early on Friday, Sessions wrote that the policy affirms the responsibility of the justice department to enforce the law, stating that it is "moral and just, and produces consistency."

The new policy is a clear departure from Obama administration criminal justice policies that aimed to ease overcrowding in federal prisons and contributed to a national rethinking of how drug criminals were prosecuted and sentenced. Critics argue that the change will subject more lower-level offenders to unfairly harsh mandatory minimum sentences.

Sessions contends that a spike in violence in some big cities and the nation's opioid epidemic show the need for a return to tougher tactics. "The opioid and heroin epidemic is a contributor to the recent surge of violent crime in America," Sessions said in remarks prepared for a Thursday speech in Charleston, West Virginia. "Drug trafficking is an inherently violent business."

The policy memo states that prosecutors should "charge and pursue the most serious, readily provable offense" - something more likely to trigger mandatory minimum sentences. The memo concedes that there will be cases in which "good judgment" will warrant a prosecutor to veer from that rule, but any exceptions will need to be approved by top supervisors, and the reasons must be documented.

The directive rescinds guidance by Sessions' Democratic predecessor, Eric Holder, who told prosecutors they could in some cases leave drug quantities out of charging documents to avoid triggering long sentences. Holder's 2013 initiative, known as Smart on Crime, was aimed at encouraging shorter sentences for nonviolent drug offenders and preserving justice department resources for more serious and violent criminals.

The Obama policy shift coincided with US Sentencing Commission changes that made tens of thousands of federal drug prisoners eligible for early release, and an Obama administration clemency initiative that freed convicts deemed deserving of a second chance. Combined, those changes led to a steep decline in a federal prison population that now stands at just under 190,000, down from nearly 220,000 in 2013. Nearly half of those inmates are in custody for drug crimes, records show.

Obama administration officials cited that decline and a drop in the overall number of drug prosecutions as evidence that policies were working as intended. They argued prosecutors were getting pickier about the cases they were bringing and were seeking mandatory minimum sentences less often.

However, some prosecutors felt constrained by the Holder directive and expressed concern that they'd lose plea bargaining leverage – and a key inducement for cooperation – without the ability to more freely pursue harsher punishments. Sessions and other justice department officials argue Holder's approach sidestepped federal laws that impose such sentences and created inconsistency across the country in the way defendants are punished. Even while in the Senate, Sessions repeatedly asserted that eliminating mandatory minimums weakened the ability of law enforcement to protect the public.

Advocates for the previous policy argue that the change will revive the worst aspects of the drug war. "It looks like we're going to fill the prisons back up after finally getting the federal prison population down," said Kevin Ring, president of Families Against Mandatory Minimums. "But the social and human costs will be much higher."

Title: NSA Headquarters in Ft. Meade Experiences Second Incident in a Month; Two Dead, Two Injured in Vehicle Attack

Article:

A vehicle attempted to breach the security gates at the National Security Agency (NSA) headquarters in Ft. Meade, Maryland, on Monday morning, leading to a confrontation with security forces that ended in shots being fired. At least one uniformed guard was injured and transported to an ambulance, with reports suggesting that the individual is not in life-threatening condition.

According to BBC News, helicopter footage showed two cars, one a police vehicle and the other a black vehicle with no insignia, in a junction near the security gates. The cars appear to have collided, and debris is scattered across the intersection. A white cloth is visible beside the black vehicle.

Local emergency responders are reportedly assisting the NSA police force in handling the incident. The BBC reports that they were unable to obtain an official comment from the NSA.

Initial reports from the UK Mirror and CBS News suggest that two people were injured during the incident, with one fatality and one injured individual being transported to a hospital. The BBC, however, reports only one fatality and one injured individual. CBS News claims that the fatality was one of the two women who attempted to ram the NSA gates, with the other woman being taken to Shock Trauma for treatment.

The gender of the individuals attacking the NSA headquarters is disputed in various reports. NBC News is claiming that the two people in the car were "men disguised as women," not women. The NBC report does note that drugs were found in the vehicle, coinciding with CBS's claims. CNN is also reporting that the attackers were two men.

Further updates note that the car was stolen, and there is not yet any indication of an organized terrorist attempt. Instead, the incident is being described as a "local criminal matter" by an anonymous official to NBC.

This is not the first recent report of trouble at NSA headquarters. Earlier this month, the FBI arrested a man for firing shots at the building, as part of a shooting spree that lasted several weeks, including shots fired at a service truck which injured one of the passengers with shattered glass.

Update 12:30PM EST: ABC News reports that one of the perpetrators was shot dead on the scene, while the other is "severely injured" and is likely not to survive. The injuries of the security officer are said to be non-life-threatening. Some reports have suggested the officer was struck by one of the vehicles involved in the crash, rather than being hit by gunfire.

CBS News in Baltimore reports that the FBI will take over investigation of the incident from the NSA's security force. There are still said to be no links to organized terrorism.

Update 4:45PM EST: The Associated Press reports that the vehicle used to ram the NSA gates was stolen from a hotel.

Title: American Photojournalist Luke Somers and South African Hostage Pierre Korkie Killed in Failed Rescue Mission in Yemen

Article:

In a tragic turn of events, American photojournalist Luke Somers and South African hostage Pierre Korkie were killed during a failed rescue mission in Yemen, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel confirmed on Saturday.

Somers, who was held by al-Qaeda militants since his abduction in the Yemeni capital of Sanaa in September 2013, was the subject of a joint U.S. and Yemeni special forces operation that ended in tragedy.

Hagel, speaking from Kabul, stated that compelling reasons indicated Somers' life was in imminent danger. He described Somers' death as a murder at the hands of terrorists. Lucy Somers, Luke's sister, learned of her brother's death from the FBI.

Pierre Korkie, a teacher abducted in Yemen in May 2013 with his wife, also perished during the failed raid. Yolande Korkie, Pierre's wife, had previously been released by al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula militants.

According to a senior Defense Department official, speaking anonymously due to not being authorized to speak publicly, helicopters dropped U.S. commandos about a mile from the village where Somers was being held. U.S. warplanes flew overhead for protection but did not engage in combat. The commandos, from teams based in the Middle East, killed all of the al-Qaeda-linked terrorists. No U.S. forces were wounded during the operation.

President Obama authorized the rescue attempt due to information indicating Somers' life was in immediate danger, including a video released by his terrorist captors this week announcing the journalist would be killed within 72 hours.

U.S. officials believe the militants shot both hostages during a firefight, and that both were alive when American forces pulled them from a building on the group's compound and got them aboard aircraft. Korkie is believed to have died during the flight, while American Somers died on the USS Makin Island, a Navy ship in the region.

Those who knew Somers, who was born in Britain but spent much of his life in America, remembered him as a person drawn to new experiences. Shawn Gillen, an English professor and chairman of Beloit College's journalism program, described Somers as someone who "really wanted to understand the world."

Tamarack Song, director of The Teaching Drum Outdoors School in Three Lakes, Wis., met Somers in 2007 when he was hired to edit a book for the school. Song recalled Somers as someone with "an undying curiosity for human dynamics and for the way people worked."

At a news conference in Bahrain on Saturday, Yemen's national security chief, Maj. Gen. Ali al-Ahmadi, stated that the militants had planned to kill Somers on Saturday. Al-Qaeda had promised to conduct the execution, but unfortunately, they shot the hostage before or during the attack, according to al-Ahmadi.

Pierre Korkie was set to be released on Sunday, according to Gift of Givers, the aid group that negotiated his wife's freedom. The psychological and emotional devastation to Yolande and her family will be compounded by the knowledge that Pierre was to be released by al-Qaeda, the aid group stated.

In a YouTube video released Wednesday, Somers, 33, said his "life is in danger." The video featured an al-Qaeda official and a brief message from Somers—dressed in a purple shirt and with a shaved head—at the end.

Pentagon press secretary Rear Adm. John Kirby stated on Thursday that a U.S. raid last month attempted to free Somers, but he was not present at the site. Before her brother's death, Lucy Somers released an online video describing him as a romantic who "always believes the best in people." She ended with the plea: "Please let him live."

Title: Nine Members of Mormon Community Killed in Drug Cartel Attack in Northern Mexico

Article:

A tragic incident occurred in the border state of Sonora, Mexico, on Monday, where nine members of a Mormon community of dual U.S.-Mexican citizens were killed in a suspected drug cartel attack. Mexico's minister for public security confirmed the incident on Tuesday, stating that three women and six children were killed in broad daylight as they traveled on a highway.

The attack took place when one vehicle stopped due to a flat tire, and assailants attacked the stranded car, killing the driver and four children, including 6-month-old twins. The attackers then set the car on fire. Two other cars were attacked nearby, resulting in the deaths of two women and two children.

A family member described a harrowing scene where a child was gunned down while attempting to flee. It is believed that at least eight survivors remain, including as many as seven children who reportedly managed to escape. Some of the escaped children were seriously wounded, including a 9-month-old who was shot in the chest and a 4-year-old who was shot in the back. A 13-year-old reportedly walked 14 miles to the family's home to seek help after hiding his wounded siblings in the brush.

The targets of the attack were members of a farming community of Mormon settlers who moved south of the border nearly a century ago to practice polygamy after a dispute with the church over the practice.

In response to the incident, U.S. President Donald Trump tweeted, "Wonderful family and friends from Utah got caught between two vicious drug cartels, who were shooting at each other, with the result being many great American people killed, including young children, and some missing." He further stated, "If Mexico needs or requests help in cleaning out these monsters, the United States stands ready, willing, and able to get involved and do the job quickly and effectively."

Trump also tweeted, "The cartels have become so large and powerful that you sometimes need an army to defeat an army!" The tweets suggest a potential U.S. involvement in addressing the ongoing drug cartel violence in Mexico.

Title: World Mourns and Celebrates the Life of Evangelist Billy Graham

Article:

The world is mourning the loss of evangelist Billy Graham, a man who dedicated his life to spreading the gospel of Christ through every available means of communication. Known for his unwavering evangelistic organization and eloquent preaching style, Graham's influence spanned generations and continents.

Dana Robert, a Boston University religion professor, remembered Graham fondly, recalling her personal encounter with him at a crusade in Baton Rouge in 1970. "It's a blessing he's been released to be with Jesus," she said. "He lived a good life, and he can say, as Paul did in his letter to Timothy, 'I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.' For him, death is not the end."

Larry Ross, Graham's longtime spokesman, praised the evangelist's courage and faith during his long physical decline. "He was faithful to the end," he said. "He showed how to finish well."

News of Graham's death spread globally, from missionaries' huts in Africa to back-country Bible Belt churches to mighty Southern Baptist temples. His life was recalled by Protestants, Catholics, Muslims, and Jews; by those who attended one of his crusades, or dozens; by those who only saw him on TV or heard him on the radio; by those who knew him mostly as a pastor to presidents.

Randall Balmer, a Dartmouth College expert on evangelical Christianity, described Graham as "the most prominent religious celebrity of the 20th Century," a period that included popes John XXIII and John Paul II, the 14th Dalai Lama, Mother Teresa, and Norman Vincent Peale. Balmer estimated that, even if the audiences for Graham's many broadcasts are not counted, "he preached to more people in person than anyone in history."

Those with the strongest impressions of Graham saw him at his final big public events. Craig Allen, 74, of Finksburg, MD, heard Graham's last major sermon, delivered in Oriole Park at Camden Yards in 2006. "His perseverance despite his health was phenomenal," Allen said. "They brought him out on a cart, and they had to help him up to the mic. And then, boy, he delivered a powerful sermon. No matter how he felt, he was going to give it his all."

Michael Freeland, 59, of Metairie, LA, attended a Graham crusade in New Orleans in 2006, after Hurricane Katrina the previous year. "His presence after the storm, especially after announcing his retirement the previous year, meant a lot to us," Freeland said. "He was old, he'd lost his wife. You could see his frailty. But once he started to preach, you could feel an energy. That was the Holy Spirit. That was him doing something he was passionate about."

Maggie Rousseau and her husband, Bill, drove 14 hours from Savannah, GA, to see Graham for the first time in 2005, knowing it would be the last. "There was just something about him," Maggie said. "I don't know what it was, but you believed him. On the crusades, on TV, he spoke, and you listened."

However, some argue that Graham's impact has already diminished. When Balmer asked one of his classes at Dartmouth if they knew who Billy Graham was, only 25% raised a hand. Dana Robert described Graham as essentially a phenomenon of the Greatest and Boomer generations. "When I was young, the whole family watched him on television, like Walter Cronkite. When he came to town, everyone went to the crusade," she recalled. "But I don't think the Millennials even know who he was."

Title: The Dilemma of Balancing Public Health and Economic Recovery: A Look at the United States' Struggle Amidst the COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

The United States, like many other countries, is grappling with the challenging task of balancing public health and economic recovery amidst the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. On May 7, the U.S. reported 2,231 deaths due to the virus, bringing the total number of deaths in the country to 75,662, and over 270,000 worldwide.

The economic impact has been severe. In April, the U.S. Congressional Budget Office predicted that the second quarter of 2020 would witness the first drop in the U.S. Gross Domestic Product in six years, with the worst decline since 2008. Since March, 33.5 million people have filed for unemployment. Companies, both large and small, are facing closure, along with millions of jobs. Consumer spending, business investment, manufacturing—everything is in a freefall, and it's unlikely to improve until 2021, even if the pandemic eases and doesn't return with a second wave.

The choice seems stark: maintain strict social distancing and shelter-in-place measures to minimize the spread of COVID-19 and save thousands of lives, or end the lightweight lockdown—open all the shops, restart the factories—and save the economy. President Trump recently stated, "We can't keep our country closed. We have to open our country." However, the point of social distancing was to "flatten the curve," to slow the spread of the virus so that hospitals wouldn't be overwhelmed and governments could take public health measures like widespread testing and tracing the contacts of sick people to keep people safe.

The question of how much a human life is worth has been raised, with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo stating, "How much is a human life worth? That is the real discussion that no one is admitting, openly or freely—that we should." Cuomo emphasized, "To me, I say the cost of a human life, a human life is priceless."

The federal government has largely abandoned its own standards for when states should lift their shelter-in-place orders. A researcher at the respected Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security told Congress last week that no state looked epidemiologically ready to go back to normal.

Despite this, 31 states have decided to reopen, with Texas allowing restaurants and movie theaters to reopen at 25% capacity, while acknowledging privately that COVID-19 cases will certainly increase as a result. Georgia is lifting its stay-at-home order and allowing places from tattoo parlors to bowling alleys to reopen, while California, which battened down early, is opening some southern beaches.

The information about the virus is incomplete and sometimes contradictory. The same is true for information about its impact on the national economy. The uncertainty extends to what people will contribute to the economy even if states end official restrictions. Given this uncertainty, who is going to get on an airplane next week, or go to a crowded bar?

As a society, we have historically been willing to incur costs to save lives and improve public welfare. Government forces carmakers to reduce air pollution to help people with asthma, and the price of cars goes up. Laws prevent factories from polluting to save fisheries, and goods cost more. But that kind of tradeoff clearly has limits. Few people suggest deactivating the country's financial engines to fight opioid addiction deaths or flu or heart disease or traffic accidents. Why do it for this one very bad respiratory virus?

Title: Trump Suggests Softening Stance on Illegal Immigration, Emphasizes Deportation of Criminals and Calls for End to Sanctuary Cities

Article:

In a series of interviews, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has indicated a potential softening of his stance on illegal immigration, while maintaining his commitment to deporting criminal immigrants. During a town hall with Fox News host Sean Hannity on Wednesday, Trump reiterated that there would be "no amnesty" for illegal immigrants, but suggested a more collaborative approach, stating, "Let me go a step further- they'll pay back-taxes, they have to pay taxes, there's no amnesty, as such, there's no amnesty, but we work with them."

Trump also clarified that there would be no path to citizenship for illegal immigrants. He expressed empathy towards those who have lived in the U.S. for decades and raised families, acknowledging the complexity of deporting long-term residents.

The Republican nominee also criticized sanctuary cities, claiming they protect criminals and hinder law enforcement. He asserted, "We got to get rid of the sanctuary cities, we're protecting these people. We're protecting criminals. And the police, who are phenomenal people, they're at a point where they almost give up."

Trump is expected to announce a decision on his immigration policy "very soon." According to the Associated Press, he will unveil his new policy during a speech in Phoenix next week at the Hyatt Regency. The speech is expected to cover policy matters, with the topic of immigration being a primary focus.

Title: Pennsylvania, Nebraska, Oregon, and Idaho Hold Primary Elections on Tuesday

Article:

Tuesday will see primary elections in several key states, including Pennsylvania, Idaho, Nebraska, and Oregon. The elections will help shape the political landscape, particularly in Pennsylvania, where a court fight over redrawn districts ended just three months ago.

In Pennsylvania, primary voters will decide the fate of President Donald Trump's pick for U.S. Senate, as well as the candidates for 18 House districts. The new congressional map, implemented following court-ordered redrawing in February, has resulted in a record number of candidates - 84 - running in these districts, a phenomenon not seen since 1984 when Pennsylvania had 23 seats in the House.

Five of Pennsylvania's 13 GOP House members have quit or are not running again, creating seven House vacancies, the most since 1976. The 7th District, abandoned by moderate Charlie Dent, is one such vacancy. Hillary Clinton received more votes than Trump in this district, which was reunified with Democratic-leaning cities in the east and cut out some Republican-leaning central Pennsylvania. Six Democrats are running in this district.

In suburban Philadelphia's 5th District, where Rep. Patrick Meehan resigned last month amid sexual harassment allegations, ten Democrats are running. Clinton also beat Trump in this district.

In the Pennsylvania Republican Senate primary, Rep. Lou Barletta is heavily favored to become the Republican challenger for Democratic Sen. Bob Casey, who is seeking a third term in November. Barletta, a Trump supporter, has the president's endorsement.

In Nebraska, Tuesday's Democratic primary in the 2nd Congressional District, dominated by Omaha and its suburbs, features moderate former Rep. Brad Ashford fighting for his old seat and Kara Eastman, a children's nonprofit administrator, running to Ashford's left. Ashford, a former Republican, served one term in Congress as a Democrat before losing to Republican Don Bacon in 2016.

In Idaho, the primary goes a long way to determining the general election, as Republican Gov. C.L. "Butch" Otter is not seeking re-election after three terms. Lt. Gov. Brad Little is seeking the GOP nomination, with Otter's endorsement, while Tommy Ahlquist, an emergency room doctor turned developer, hopes his outsider status carries him as it did Indiana businessman Mike Braun in last week's GOP Senate primary.

In Oregon, ten Republicans are vying for the nomination for governor - the most in more than a century. The interest among candidates belies the uphill climb for the party in the Democratic-leaning state. Businessman Sam Carpenter, state Rep. Knute Buehler, and retired Navy pilot Greg Wooldridge have emerged as leaders in fundraising and GOP straw polls. However, Democratic Gov. Kate Brown remains the favorite to win in November.

Oregon is among eight states where Democrats control the governorship and both houses of the state legislature. Voters who identify as Democrats also outnumber their Republican counterparts by more than 9 percentage points.

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in August, Missing Expectations Amid Trade Uncertainty and Global Growth Concerns

The U.S. economy added 130,000 jobs in August, falling short of Wall Street's expectations, as trade tensions and global economic slowdown cast a shadow over the economic outlook. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.7%, near a half-century low, while the labor force participation rate remained unchanged at 63.2%. Average hourly earnings rose 3.2% over the past year to $28.11, slightly exceeding projections of 3.1%.

Economists had anticipated employers to add 158,000 jobs, in line with average growth this year but significantly below the 2018 average of 223,000. The June and July jobs numbers were revised down by a combined 20,000, according to the Labor Department's report released on Friday.

The employment in the federal government increased in the last full month of summer, primarily due to the hiring of temporary workers for the 2020 census. Excluding these employees, August payrolls grew by 105,000 jobs. Notable gains were also reported in the health care sector, which added 24,000 jobs, and the finance industry, which grew by 15,000.

The subpar job growth comes amid concerns that the current U.S. economic expansion, which has reached a record length, may be slowing and could potentially lead to a recession within the next two years. Industries on the front line of the U.S.-China trade war continued to report losses.

Tony Bedikian, managing director at Citizens Bank, commented, "The on-again, off-again U.S.-China trade talks continue to roil markets and, in some ways, are mirroring the on-again, off-again Brexit debate. Both issues are providing market participants with more theater than substance while the U.S. consumer tunes them out, keeps spending, and keeps the U.S. economic fundamentals on track."

The lower-than-expected growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates by a modest 25 basis points when policymakers meet in mid-September. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is scheduled to discuss the economic outlook in a speech later Friday in Zurich.

Title: California Imposes Statewide 'Stay At Home' Order as Coronavirus Cases Surge

In a significant move to combat the growing novel coronavirus outbreak, California Governor Gavin Newsom has ordered the state's 40 million residents to stay at home indefinitely. This directive, announced on March 19, is the most extensive measure taken by any state in the U.S. to date.

Governor Newsom, in a late-evening news conference in Sacramento, stated that the order would take effect immediately. He expressed confidence that Californians would comply with the measure, saying, "We are confident that the people of the state of California will abide by it, will do the right thing."

The order, which follows similar restrictions issued earlier this week for the San Francisco Bay Area, requires individuals to remain in their homes, with exceptions only for essential travel. Exemptions to the order include trips to grocery stores, gas stations, farmers markets, food banks, convenience stores, takeout and delivery restaurants, banks, and laundromats, among others.

California, one of the states hardest-hit by the U.S. outbreak, has over 1,000 confirmed cases of the potentially fatal respiratory infection, with 19 deaths. The governor previously stated that an official projection estimates that up to 56% of the state's residents could become infected by the virus, a figure that would equate to more than 22 million people. However, he emphasized at the news conference that the stay-at-home order is intended to make such numbers irrelevant.

The total number of cases in the U.S. has surpassed 10,000, according to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. However, officials believe that due to the small number of tests for the virus so far, the actual number of infections is thought to be significantly higher.

The global total of reported cases, according to a tally maintained by Johns Hopkins University, is nearly 250,000, with over 10,000 deaths. California Republican Rep. Kevin McCarthy, the House minority leader, expressed concern about the order, tweeting, "I hope Governor Newsom consulted with a lot of experts before he decided to shut down 12% of the nation's population."

Despite the seemingly sweeping nature of the governor's order, there are a number of exemptions, Newsom said. He emphasized that grocery stores would remain open, and individuals could still take their children outside, walk their dogs, and practice common sense and social distancing. Essential travel and critical infrastructure such as food and agriculture, health care, transportation, energy, and financial services are also exempted.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder's Mixed Legacy on National Security Issues

Article:

In his tenure as Attorney General, Eric Holder faced a complex and challenging landscape in handling national security matters. As he steps down, his legacy is marked by both successes and controversies.

Holder, who served as Attorney General since the start of President Obama's presidency in 2009, took office with a clear intention to distance the Justice Department from the Bush administration's policies on interrogation techniques and terrorism prosecutions. However, his decisions have drawn scrutiny and disappointment from various quarters.

One of Holder's most audacious proposals was to prosecute the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks and other alleged co-conspirators in a New York courtroom, rather than through the Guantanamo Bay military commission process. This idea was met with political opposition and public safety concerns, ultimately leading to the Obama administration's decision to abandon the plan.

Holder's tenure saw numerous terrorism-fighting successes, including the prosecutions of the Times Square bomb plot and the Detroit-bound airliner bomb plot. However, his watch also saw the authorization of targeted drone strikes against Americans abroad, subpoenas of journalists' telephone records in leak investigations, and the defense in court of the government's bulk collection of millions of Americans' telephone records.

Jonathan Hafetz, a Seton Hall University law professor and former senior lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union, described Holder's legacy as "too supportive of executive power and insufficiently protective of civil liberties." Stephen Vladeck, an American University law school professor, credited Holder for overseeing a large number of terrorism prosecutions but noted that the visible aspects of his legacy "don't look as good as the stuff we don't see."

When Holder took over, he signaled a new direction from the previous Republican administration. He defined waterboarding as torture, announced an investigation into CIA interrogation methods, and pushed for a shift away from the military commission system. In 2009, he announced plans to prosecute five detainees, including Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, in federal court in New York and seek the death penalty.

Critics, mostly Republicans, argued that federal courts were ill-equipped for such trials and expressed alarm at the prospect of terrorists being brought to American soil. The White House shelved the idea in 2011, a step toward closing the Guantanamo detention facility.

Despite this setback, Holder remained firm in his support for civilian courts for suspected terrorists, and his Justice Department has won many convictions before American juries. He has said his position was vindicated by the fact that, in the years since the Guantanamo proposal was spiked, Osama bin Laden's son-in-law was captured, convicted in New York, and given a life sentence. The military commission case against Mohammed remains stalled in Guantanamo by pretrial wrangling.

However, Holder's civil liberties advocates were frustrated when he later defended the administration's legal rationale to kill American-born Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen. They challenged the government's ability to kill one of its citizens without court permission and its refusal, until recently, to release the memo authorizing the strike.

Additional scrutiny came from the administration's crackdown on news media reporting involving national security matters. The Justice Department secretly subpoenaed phone records from Associated Press reporters and editors, used a search warrant to obtain some emails of a Fox News journalist in another leak investigation, and subpoenaed New York Times reporter James Risen in the case of a former CIA officer accused of disclosing government secrets. Holder has since issued new guidelines for media leak investigations.

As Holder steps down, his successor will inherit many of the same policy questions, including how to close the Guantanamo detention facility, handle potential foreign fighters trying to join extremist groups in Syria, and bring former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden into a U.S. courtroom.

"The public's perspective, I think, may be very different from the attorney general's perspective. He knows all the things that never made the front pages," said Vladeck. It remains to be seen how Holder's successor will navigate these complex issues and shape the future of national security policy.

Title: U.S. Officials Disagree on Safety of Iraqi Christians as Deportation Efforts Continue

Article:

A divide in the assessment of the safety of Iraqi Christians has emerged within the Trump administration, as U.S. immigration officials push to deport hundreds of Iraqi Christians while a senior Trump appointee at the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) insists that Christians in Iraq face terror and extortion.

Last September, Hallam Ferguson, a senior Trump appointee at USAID, told a government commission that in the part of northern Iraq where many Christians live, militias aligned with Iran "terrorize those families brave enough to have returned, extort local businesses and openly pledge allegiance to Iran." Ferguson stated that in some towns, the numbers of Christians who have returned after the defeat of the Islamic State "have reached only 1 to 2% because of persecution by these militias."

On the same day, Michael Rubin, a Middle East expert at the American Enterprise Institute, completed a sworn declaration at the request of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for use in its efforts to deport Iraqis. Rubin argued that Iraq is now a more stable country with an increasingly professional government, and that Iraqi Christians could count on the state's protection and are "largely immune" from politically motivated violence.

Government lawyers have submitted Rubin's statement, along with similar declarations by two other experts, to courts during immigration hearings. The Rubin declaration was submitted by DHS lawyers as recently as last month.

The assessments by Rubin and the other experts can have significant consequences. The administration has sought to deport hundreds of Iraqis, many of them Christians, who immigrated to the U.S. years ago. To stay in the U.S., many of the Iraqis have to prove that if they are deported, they are most likely to be tortured by, or with the tacit permission of, the Iraqi government—a higher standard than what is used in typical asylum cases. That gives DHS a strong incentive to emphasize Iraq's progress and portray the country's government as competent and willing to protect all its people.

President Donald Trump said in a January speech in Michigan that he would grant an "extension" to Iraqi Christians facing deportation, but DHS's effort to deport the Iraqis is ongoing, lawyers said. In approving one Iraqi Christian's deportation late last year, an immigration judge wrote that he found the experts' declarations "persuasive" and was convinced that "the Iraqi government has cracked down" on abuses by the majority-Shiite Muslim militias that helped defeat the Islamic State but have not disbanded since its demise.

In an emailed response to questions, Rubin said that he does not agree with the Trump administration's policy of deporting the Iraqis, but that he had been asked for an informed assessment and not his political opinion. "The only question I focus on when contributing declarations or when asked in court is whether Christians returning to Iraq are likely to be subject to detention, torture or murder upon their return, and the answer to that objectively is no," Rubin said.

Rubin said he plans to update his statement to address recent unrest in Iraq, where there have been widespread demonstrations and the killing of hundreds of mostly unarmed protesters. The two other experts who took similar positions as Rubin, Denise Natali and Douglas Ollivant, did not respond to requests for comment. Natali is now a senior State Department official.

The State Department, USAID, DHS, and the White House did not respond to requests for comment, and the Iraqi Embassy in Washington did not offer a response either. While the Iraqi government has succeeded in defeating the Islamic State and winning back control of its territory, religious and ethnic minorities have little faith the government can protect them against a multitude of active, semiofficial armed groups, experts said.

"My view aligns more closely with USAID," said Steven Cook, a Middle East expert at the Council on Foreign Relations, who visited Iraq in December. "Iraq seems to be in a situation of terminal collapse. With the continued presence of extremists and the unreliable central government, I find it hard to believe that Christians are safe and secure."

Title: Virginia Election Results Reveal Anti-Immigrant Strategy Backfires, Demonstrating Potential 2018 Trend

Article:

In the recent Virginia gubernatorial election, the anti-immigrant strategy employed by Republican candidate Ed Gillespie proved to be a misstep, as demonstrated by the election results and polling data. While each state has its unique demographics and politics, Virginia's electorate encompasses a diverse range of demographics and economic backgrounds. Majorities of voters across racial and ethnic lines rejected anti-immigrant stereotypes as unattractive and incorrect.

According to an election eve survey by Latino Decisions, Latino voters expressed disapproval of Gillespie's MS-13 ads, with a 45-point margin. However, this sentiment was not limited to the Latino community. By a 23-point margin (52 to 29), white voters in Virginia also indicated that the MS-13 ads turned them away from Gillespie, as did African-American and Asian-American voters by larger margins.

Data analysis of survey data reveals a clear trend. Exposure to Gillespie's MS-13 ads drove white college-educated voters away from the Republican party. Furthermore, when analyzing findings for white independents and Republicans, voters who were aware of the MS-13 ads were significantly more likely to vote for Gillespie's Democratic opponent.

The impact of the MS-13 ads was not confined to the governor's race. The Gillespie campaign's influence extended to Virginia's House of Delegates races, with those aware of the MS-13 ads being significantly more likely to vote for Democratic candidates.

This trend suggests that not only is it morally just for Democrats to position themselves as the party that stands against hatred and bigotry, but it is also a strategically sound position for winning votes. Simultaneously, it sends a clear, welcoming message to Latino, African-American, and Asian-American voters, while also appealing to white voters who oppose immigrant bashing.

This phenomenon is particularly relevant to voters who will decide crucial House and Senate races in 2018: people of color and white college-educated voters, also known as the Democratic base. President Trump and his fellow Republicans are reportedly gearing up for a similar anti-immigrant effort in 2018. However, the Virginia election results indicate that voters are becoming increasingly aware of such tactics and are less likely to support candidates who employ them.

Democrats have an opportunity to speak out strongly against bigotry and present themselves as a welcoming, inclusive party. By doing so, they may have a path to victory in 2018 and beyond.

Title: President Trump Calls for "Red Wave" to Pass Immigration Bill as Congressional Vote Delayed

Article:

In a series of tweets on Friday, President Donald Trump called for a "red wave" in the November midterm elections to pass an immigration bill, accusing Democrats of obstructing efforts to address the long-standing issue.

"Republicans should stop wasting their time on Immigration until after we elect more Senators and Congressmen/women in November," Trump tweeted. "Dems are just playing games, have no intention of doing anything to solve this decades-old problem. We can pass great legislation after the Red Wave!"

The president's call comes after GOP leaders abruptly scrapped a planned vote on a troubled immigration bill on Thursday, pushing the vote into next week. The House GOP Abruptly Scraps Planned Vote on Troubled Immigration Bill, Saying It Could Pass Next Week.

Congressional Republicans had earlier failed to pass a more conservative bill. A more moderate, compromise measure was expected to include a requirement that employers use E-Verify to check the legal status of employees.

Leaders have sought to assuage both conservatives and moderates in their party, while also meeting the president's four pillars: a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants brought to the country as children, border security including a wall, an end to so-called "chain migration," and an end to the diversity lottery visa.

A sticking point for conservatives is that while the compromise funds the wall, it also offers a pathway to citizenship for 1.8 million young illegal immigrants. The conservative bill offers only the 700,000 recipients of the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program the ability to apply for indefinite renewals of non-immigrant status.

"It is not a compromise," House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., told reporters. "It may be a compromise with the devil, but it is not a compromise with the Democrats."

Trump on Wednesday extended an invitation to Democrats to the White House to discuss immigration and said "it takes two to tango," although he had scathing words for what he called the "extremist, open border" lawmakers.

"They don't care about the children... They don't care about the problems. They do not care about anything. All they do is say, 'Obstruct and let's see how we do' because they have no policies that are any good," he said ahead of a Cabinet meeting.

On Thursday, he echoed that rhetoric, but without the invitation for Democrats to come to the table.

"Dems are doing nothing but Obstructing. Remember their motto, RESIST! Ours is PRODUCE!" he tweeted.

He renewed his criticism of the filibuster in the Senate, which requires 60 votes to break.

"Even if we get 100% Republican votes in the Senate, we need 10 Democrat votes to get a much-needed Immigration Bill - & the Dems are Obstructionists who won’t give votes for political reasons & because they don’t care about Crime coming from Border! So we need to elect more R’s!"

Trump's tweets come after a fiery week in which rhetoric on both sides has escalated on the question of the administration's "zero tolerance" policy, which prosecutes all illegal border crossers. That in turn led to an increase in the number of children being separated from their parents.

Trump signed an executive order Wednesday ending the practice and allowing families to be detained together, but Democrats have since pushed for ending what they described as "indefinite detention" of families at the border.

Title: Misinterpretation of Netanyahu's Remarks on Palestinian State Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a recent interview with the Israeli publication NRG, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's comments regarding a potential Palestinian state have been misconstrued by the Western media, leading to a flurry of inaccurate reports.

The misinterpretation began with a headline from the left-wing Israeli newspaper Ha'aretz, which reported Netanyahu as saying, "If I'm elected, there will be no Palestinian state." The rest of the media quickly followed suit, accusing Netanyahu of flip-flopping on his stance towards a Palestinian state.

However, the interview took place in Hebrew, a language that most Western journalists do not read or speak, and the misinterpretation appears to have stemmed from a mistranslation or misinterpretation of Netanyahu's words.

In the interview, Netanyahu was asked directly about whether his 2009 speech at Bar Ilan University, where he expressed support for the possibility of a Palestinian state, was "irrelevant." Netanyahu's response was misconstrued as a rejection of a Palestinian state, but in reality, he said:

NETANYAHU: I think anyone who is going to build a Palestinian state today will be freeing up space to give an attack area to radical Islam against Israel. This is the reality created here in recent years. Anyone who ignores this sticks his head in the sand. The left does this, burying its head in the sand again and again. We are realistic and understand…

NRG: If you are elected head of state, no Palestinian state will come to fruition?
NETANYAHU: Indeed.
NRG: Construction in Jerusalem and the West Bank will renew?
NETANYAHU: We are continuing all the time, but that's not a question about additional building. There is a real threat that the government of the left will join the international community and do their bidding…

Netanyahu continued by arguing that the left would buy into the "international initiatives to return to the 1967 borders and divide Jerusalem."

In other words, Netanyahu did not discount the possibility of a Palestinian state forever. He said that anyone who tries to build a Palestinian state "today" would be giving territory to radical Islam. He even added that this was a reality created in recent years.

To read that as a wholesale rejection of a Palestinian state is to lie, as Ha'aretz did. The entire lazy and ridiculous world media followed suit, accusing Netanyahu of flip-flopping when, in fact, he never flipped.

Netanyahu's policy is the same as the policy of Yitzchak Rabin, who created the Oslo Accords and said just one month before his assassination in 1995, "We view a permanent solution [involving] a Palestinian entity which is less than a state… We will not return to the June 4, 1967 lines… We committed ourselves before the Knesset not to uproot a single settlement in the framework of the interim agreement, and not to hinder building for natural growth… And first and foremost in our concerns is a united Jerusalem, as the capital of Israel, under Israeli sovereignty."

Ben Shapiro, Senior Editor-At-Large of ███ and author of the new book, The People vs. Barack Obama: The Criminal Case Against The Obama Administration (Threshold Editions, June 10, 2014), weighed in on the controversy. He is also Editor-in-Chief of TruthRevolt.org. Follow Ben Shapiro on Twitter @benshapiro.

Title: Ted Cruz and Donald Trump Engage in Legal Threats Over Abortion Ad in South Carolina

Article:

In a heated exchange between the two Republican presidential candidates, Ted Cruz has dared Donald Trump to sue him over an ad running in South Carolina that questions Trump's record on abortion. The ad, which features footage of Trump in a 1999 interview stating he is "very pro-choice," has sparked a legal battle between the two candidates.

Cruz, in a press conference on Wednesday, read from the cease-and-desist letter sent by Trump's campaign, calling it "one of the most remarkable letters I have ever read." He challenged Trump to follow through with his threatened lawsuit. Cruz, a Harvard Law School graduate and former Texas solicitor general, stated that a lawsuit against the ad has no chance and expressed his desire to take Trump's deposition himself.

Trump, in response, reiterated his current pro-life stance and threatened to sue Cruz over his eligibility to run for president if he does not "take down his false ads and retract his lies." The feud between the two candidates has escalated since then, with Trump regularly labeling Cruz a liar and Cruz mocking Trump's lawsuit threats.

In a statement on Wednesday, Trump said, "If I want to bring a lawsuit it would be legitimate. Likewise, if I want to bring the lawsuit regarding Senator Cruz being a natural-born Canadian, I will do so. Time will tell, Teddy."

Meanwhile, Cruz is also embroiled in a dispute with Florida Sen. Marco Rubio over alleged dirty tricks leading up to Saturday's South Carolina GOP primary. Cruz denied any involvement in any untoward activities and called for anyone with evidence to come forward. Rubio was asked on Wednesday to provide evidence that Cruz's team was behind a fake Facebook page wrongly claiming that U.S. Rep. Trey Gowdy had switched his endorsement from Rubio to Cruz.

"It's just a pattern of people around his campaign that have continuously done things like that," Rubio said. The primary is set to take place on Saturday, and the ongoing disputes between the candidates are likely to continue shaping the race in the coming days.

Title: BuzzFeed Report Alleges President Trump Directed Michael Cohen to Lie About Moscow Project

Article:

In a significant development, BuzzFeed News has reported that President Donald Trump directed his former lawyer Michael Cohen to lie about his Trump Tower project in Moscow. Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying about the deal in testimony and in a two-page statement to the Senate and House intelligence committees.

According to the report, Cohen also told the special counsel that after the election, the president personally instructed him to lie—by claiming that negotiations ended months earlier than they actually did—in order to obscure Trump's involvement.

The allegation, if true, could be the most serious threat to Trump's presidency, according to Rep. David Cicilline (D-RI), who reacted to the news on CNN Friday. Cicilline, along with Rep. Ted Lieu (D-CA), concluded that BuzzFeed has proven the president is guilty of obstruction of justice.

"If the President directed Cohen to lie to Congress, that is obstruction of justice. Period. Full stop," Cicilline tweeted. Lieu added, "Based on the Buzzfeed report and numerous other articles showing @realDonaldTrump committed Obstruction of Justice and other possible felonies, it is time for the House Judiciary Committee to start holding hearings to establish a record of whether @POTUS committed high crimes."

Given the seriousness of the allegation, the congressmen demanded they and their colleagues be given a chance to investigate. Cicilline, when asked by CNN's John Berman if he's calling for an immediate congressional investigation into the report, said, "I think we have to wait for the reports to be confirmed before we can call on that... You have one opportunity to move forward on something so serious."

However, when asked if he has evidence to prove Trump told Cohen to lie, Cicilline said, "We've all seen the conduct of the president." Berman noted that wasn't an answer and asked again, did he actually see the evidence? "I have not seen the evidence referenced in that article," Cicilline admitted.

One of the authors of the BuzzFeed report, Anthony Cormier, stood by his reporting on CNN Friday as "100 percent" truth. The report, as of now, has yet to be confirmed or corroborated.

Title: Boehner Stands Firm on Debt Ceiling and Government Shutdown Negotiations

Article:

In a Sunday interview on ABC's "This Week," House Speaker John Boehner reiterated that Republican lawmakers will not agree to a debt ceiling increase without conditions to curb deficit spending. Boehner stated unequivocally that the Republican-led House would not pass a "clean" debt ceiling increase, and that it is time to address America's problems rather than merely raising the debt limit without addressing the underlying issue.

The interview came as the country entered its sixth day of a government shutdown, with Boehner equally adamant that Republicans would demand concessions for any bill to reopen the government. Specifically, Republicans are pushing for changes to President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, known as Obamacare, as a condition for backing a measure to fund government agencies.

President Obama and the Democratic-led Senate have rejected this demand, and Obama has stated that it is the responsibility of Congress to raise the debt limit by an Oct. 17 deadline when the government will begin running short of the funds needed to pay its bills. Obama has also said he will not negotiate with Republicans over the debt limit issue.

Regarding the government shutdown impasse, Boehner said there had been no changes in the Republican position on the bill to fund the government. Boehner also stated that there are not enough votes in the House to pass a "clean" continuing resolution on the budget to re-open the government.

When asked about a group of 195 House Democrats and 21 Republicans who have said they are willing to pass a six-week "clean CR" without defunding Obamacare, Boehner responded, "There may be a back room somewhere, but there's nobody in it."

Boehner repeated the GOP line that his party has tried to compromise by passing several bills that would fund parts of the government while talks continue. However, Democrats have rejected all but a bill to fund military pay because they say the effort is a ploy to simply fund every part of government individually except the Affordable Care Act.

Boehner used the word "conversation" a total of 22 times in the interview, stating that President Obama knows his phone number and can call him any time. Host George Stephanopoulos played past quotes from Boehner in which he has said Obamacare is the law of the land and that defunding Obamacare should not be tied to the budget.

Boehner acknowledged making a promise to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to pass a clean CR that included $70 billion less than what the Senate wanted. However, Boehner said, "I and my members decided that the threat of Obamacare and what was happening was so important that it was time for us to take a stand – and we took a stand."

The interview concluded with a call to action for viewers to vote on whether they support Sen. Ted Cruz's efforts to defund Obamacare.

Title: Critics Question Limited Scope of U.S. Airstrikes Against Islamic State and Khorasan Group

Article:

In the ongoing air war against the Islamic State and the Khorasan Group, President Obama's approach is facing criticism, with some claiming that the limited scope of the airstrikes is hindering the effectiveness of the campaign. This criticism stems from the sparing of a bombing target in Syria, where a U.S.-led airstrike left intact a building housing the Islamic State's finance center, despite destroying the rooftop communications array.

The limited effectiveness of the airstrikes is further compounded by the mixed results of Iraqi security forces in combat and their inability to reverse most gains made by the Islamic State, also known by the acronyms ISIL and ISIS. Iraqi troops also lack the crucial skill of finding and designating ground targets for U.S. warplanes, making the American air campaign more challenging.

Retired CIA operative Bart Bechtel expressed his frustration, stating, "I was mad as hell when I saw the hit on a supposed ISIL building. The right question is: Why not the whole building?" He further opined that the airstrikes were a public relations move to show that Obama is taking decisive action, rather than a genuine attempt to destroy the Islamic State.

A retired Air Force general, who remains in touch with the jet fighter community, echoed these sentiments, stating that the U.S. air war is too narrow, with insufficient planes, heavy ordnance, or sorties. Before the first assaults in Syria on Monday night, U.S. Central Command had conducted 190 airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq since Aug. 8 - less than an average of four per day.

The retired officer, a former fighter pilot, criticized the choice of weapons, stating, "For example, blowing an antenna off the top of buildings. Hit the building with a 2,000-pounder, not cruise missiles." He also called for many more sorties.

At a Pentagon briefing Tuesday, Army Lt. Gen. William Mayville, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, explained the strategy behind the missile attack on the communication suite atop an Islamic State finance center in Raqqa, Syria, the terrorist group's headquarters. However, the aftermath of the attack showed that the surrounding structure remained largely untouched.

Early Wednesday, U.S. Central Command announced a reduction in the tempo of the airstrikes, conducting a few hits in Iraq and one in Syria. However, later in the day, U.S. fighter jets and aircraft belonging to two Arab partner nations began dropping missiles on Islamic State-controlled oil refineries in eastern Syria.

The targets chosen by Central Command have not been primarily aimed at degrading the Islamic State inside Iraq, but rather at preventing the terrorist group from moving in one direction or another, or to break its hold on particular locations such as dams or small towns. The air war continues without American combat troops on the ground to uproot Islamic State positions. Iraqis have shown little ability to carry out such missions or to spot targets for U.S. warplanes.

Army Gen. Lloyd Austin, Central Command chief, had initially wanted to put U.S. spotters on the ground, but Army Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, Joint Chiefs chairman, convinced him that other tactics could be used. Mr. Obama has decreed "no boots on the ground."

Under the current setup, joint command centers radio the positions of the enemy to Iraqis and U.S. pilots based on video feeds from unmanned aircraft and other intelligence assets. However, a retired military officer who visits Baghdad routinely and works with Iraqi defense officials stated, "That is a recipe for disaster once we get into close-in combat."

The former officer explained the mission gap, stating that ground spotters need a critical piece of equipment: a multiband radio that connects them to other combatants and to pilots overhead. Conventional forces also have no specialized units set up to spot targets. This capability resides with Iraqi special operations forces, but they have limited experience, the former officer said.

This role is not as important while U.S. pilots target Islamic State fighters in relatively open terrain, but it becomes crucial if the reorganized Iraqi units begin to fight in close combat in congested areas where pilots need exact locations. Retired Army Maj. Gen. Robert Scales stated, "I'd like to see more of everything, a real air campaign with sorties delivered against the ISIS leadership."

Without more intensive strikes, he warned, "Over time the enemy learns to obviate the killing effects and becomes used to seeing planes orbiting overhead." The Pentagon said the air campaign could go on for years. The Iraqi army has shown itself unable, or unwilling, to stand up to the Islamic State. The country's special operations arm, also referred to as counterterrorism units, are more proficient. They fought alongside Kurdish peshmerga fighters to take back the huge hydroelectric dam near Mosul, with cover from U.S. airstrikes.

Title: Trump Contemplates Regulating Domestic Flights Amidst Coronavirus Outbreak, Maintains Opposition to National Stay-at-Home Order

Article:

In a move aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus, President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday that his administration is considering ordering airlines to reduce domestic flights, particularly those traveling between cities currently battling the pandemic. However, Trump has yet to issue a national stay-at-home order, stating that it is not necessary in certain states.

Governors in several states have taken independent action in the travel sector. For instance, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has mandated self-isolation for 14 days for anyone flying to Florida from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut, states that have been heavily impacted by the coronavirus. Alaska and Hawaii have also implemented self-quarantine requirements for travelers arriving from other states.

President Trump expressed concerns about flights serving as a means of transporting the virus from one hotspot to another. "You have them going, in some cases, from hot spot to hot spot," Trump said during his daily briefing on the crisis. He acknowledged the potential hardship such restrictions would impose on the airlines.

Airlines, industry officials, and health experts argue that flights are an essential service, necessary for both people and cargo, and should continue during the crisis. The federal government reinforced this view with a key provision in the $2 trillion coronavirus aid package passed last week: airlines that accept a portion of the $50 billion set aside for the industry must maintain a minimum level of service through at least September.

When asked on Monday about the continued operation of airports and flights despite the coronavirus outbreak, Trump stated, "We are going to be – hopefully before we close things – we’re going to start to open things." He added, "Airports, when you close them and reopen them, it’s a tremendous deal. It’s a tremendous deal. In addition, you need them for emergencies, you have emergency flights."

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) would be the agency responsible for ordering any shutdown or restrictions, as demonstrated by their actions last year when the Boeing 737 Max was grounded following two fatal crashes in less than five months. When asked about the possibility of grounding flights nationwide, the FAA responded with a statement: "The FAA does not comment on rumors."

Airlines have significantly reduced their flight schedules in response to the dramatic decrease in passenger volume between cities. President Trump has also imposed a ban on foreign nationals visiting the U.S. from China and most of Europe, including France, Germany, Italy, and the United Kingdom. He has also implemented restrictions on non-essential travel from Mexico and Canada.

Despite the ongoing pandemic, Trump maintains that a national stay-at-home order is not necessary because "you have to give a little bit of flexibility" in states or regions where the coronavirus has not been as prevalent. He cited the Midwest and Alaska as examples.

Title: Concerns Mount Over HealthCare.gov's Performance and Insurance Plan Availability as Enrollment Deadline Approaches

Article:

As the enrollment deadline for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) approaches, administration officials are expressing concerns about the potential negative publicity surrounding high insurance plan prices and limited choices on the HealthCare.gov website. According to internal documents obtained by CNN, project managers are worried that as people begin to select plans on a more functional Obamacare site, the media attention will focus on individual plan selections and choices, potentially revealing fewer options than desired to promote consumer choice and a positive shopping experience.

The documents, known as War Room Notes dated Oct. 28, also suggest that in some cases, there will be relatively high-cost plans. This discussion appears to reference an earlier report by CNN that the Affordable Care Act has failed to lower prices for people in rural areas. The Times reported that in more than 500 counties, only one insurer is participating in the new online insurance exchanges, leaving residents with limited options.

The War Room notes also mention "problem plans" and a site issue that prevents certification, possibly due to a spelling error on the website, according to CNN. The high cost of coverage under the new law has already been a point of contention, with a Manhattan Institute analysis showing that, on average, Obamacare will increase underlying premiums by 41 percent in most states, according to Forbes.

Before the law's online healthcare markets launched on Oct. 1, the administration estimated nearly 500,000 people would enroll for subsidized private insurance within the first month. However, a computer system plagued by issues has prevented most from doing so.

Recently, at least 3.5 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their private carriers because their coverage does not meet the standards set by the Affordable Care Act. The exact number is unclear, as data from half the states is still unavailable, according to an Associated Press survey.

The administration has refused to release official Obamacare insurance plan enrollment numbers until mid-November, when a crash effort of computer fixes may be showing results. However, numbers are expected to be disappointingly low. Americans remain divided over the new healthcare law, with negative views outweighing positives. Yet, they also lean against repealing it.

Title: Romney Campaign Raises $4.2 Million Following Obama Tax Ruling, Obama Campaign Responds

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's ruling on the Obama Tax case, Mitt Romney's campaign has reported a significant influx of funds, totaling $4.2 million in the past 24 hours. The surge in donations comes as President Obama sent out an email expressing his anticipation of being outspent in his re-election campaign.

In response to the ruling, Romney has stated that he would repeal the entire bill on his first day in office should he be elected president. The influx of funds follows President Obama's statement that he may become the first president in modern history to be outspent in his re-election campaign.

The Obama campaign's fundraising efforts are not just being challenged by super PACs and anonymous outside groups, but also by the Romney campaign itself. According to the Obama campaign, the Romney campaign has raised more than three-quarters of its funds from individuals giving $1,000 or more, while the Obama campaign raised almost three-quarters of its funds from donors giving less than $1,000 during the primaries.

President Obama's email also highlighted the additional billion dollars in spending by super PACs and front groups on ads criticizing his campaign and policies. He emphasized that while the campaign can be outspent and still win, it cannot be outspent 10 to 1 and still win.

The Obama campaign has received support from more than 2.2 million Americans and expressed gratitude for their contributions. As the fundraising deadline for this week approaches, the campaign is encouraging donations of $3 or more. Donations made today will automatically enter donors to join Michelle and Obama for one of the last grassroots dinners of the campaign, with today being the last chance to get a name in.

The Obama campaign contrasted their approach to fundraising with Romney's, stating that Romney spent the past weekend at a secretive retreat for the biggest donors to both his campaign and the super PACs that support him. The Obama campaign's grassroots dinners, on the other hand, represent a different approach to campaigning.

Title: Obama's Farewell Address: A Call for Continued Action and National Unity

Article:

In his farewell address to the nation Tuesday night, President Barack Obama called for continued action, unity, and a renewed commitment to democracy. In a speech that touched on the challenges facing the nation, Obama urged Americans to stay engaged, emphasizing the importance of citizenship and the responsibility that comes with it.

Obama's call for action may be of particular significance, as he signaled a return to his roots as a community organizer. However, his post-presidency promises to be more than just a return to activism. With the surprise election of Donald Trump, who intends to dismantle much of Obama's legacy, the former president has shown a renewed energy and determination.

While Obama has pledged to honor the tradition of former presidents in refraining from critiquing his successor publicly, he has also hinted at a willingness to speak out if he perceives a threat to core American values.
