The recent report suggesting a potential crisis, with Russia allegedly possessing damaging personal information about President-elect Trump, may be a case in point.

Obama's post-presidency appears to follow multiple strands. He is doubling down on his commitment to Organizing for America, the outside group that sprang from his presidential campaigns and focused on supporting his agenda while he was in office. Now, the group is being retooled to train activists and recruit Democratic candidates.

Another post-presidential goal for Obama is the reshaping of congressional districts, due after the 2020 census. "When Congress is dysfunctional, we should draw our districts to encourage politicians to cater to common sense and not rigid extremes," Obama said.

Obama will work on redistricting with former Attorney General Eric Holder, who chairs the National Democratic Redistricting Committee. The group will invest in races for governor, state legislature, and other down-ballot offices.

Unspoken in Obama's remarks is the decline of the Democratic Party during his tenure. The party has lost roughly 1,000 state legislative seats, control of both houses of Congress, numerous governorships, and now the presidency. Democrats control the governor's chair and both legislative chambers in only six states.

Like most ex-presidents in the modern era, Obama will set about writing a memoir as soon as he leaves office. His initiative aimed at helping young men of color avoid the school-to-prison pipeline, known as My Brother's Keeper, will be another focus, as will his Chicago-based presidential library and foundation.

Obama will be based in Washington for the next two and a half years, while his younger daughter finishes high school, making him the first president since Woodrow Wilson to remain in the capital after leaving office. Obama's close proximity to his successor – he and his family have rented a house less than three miles from the White House – will only tempt involvement as an informal Democratic adviser.

Political scientist Andra Gillespie of Emory University in Atlanta suggests that Obama may maintain a significant behind-the-scenes role in helping craft Democratic strategy. However, in his remarks Tuesday night, Obama framed his exhortations on civic engagement in a broad, nonpartisan way.

"Our youth, our drive, our diversity and openness, our boundless capacity for risk and reinvention means that the future should be ours," Obama said. "But that potential will only be realized if our democracy works. Only if our politics better reflects the decency of our people. Only if all of us, regardless of party affiliation or particular interests, help restore the sense of common purpose that we so badly need right now."

In his call for national unity, Obama adopted a hopeful tone, urging Americans to reengage in the hard work of forming a more perfect union. "If you're disappointed by your elected officials, grab a clipboard, get some signatures, and run for office yourself," he said to the cheers of the crowd at Chicago's McCormick Place.

"Sometimes you'll win, sometimes you'll lose. Presuming a reservoir in goodness, that can be a risk," Obama continued. "And there will be times when the process will disappoint you. But for those of us fortunate enough to have been part of this one and to see it up close, let me tell you, it can energize and inspire. And more often than not, your faith in America and in Americans will be confirmed."

Title: Economic Performance During Obama's Presidency: A Closer Look at the Numbers

Article:

The strong economic growth in the second quarter of 2014 has sparked discussions about why President Obama is not receiving more credit for the economic recovery. However, a closer examination of the data suggests that the evidence of a robust and sustained recovery is still lacking.

While the economy grew 4.6 percent in the past quarter, it is important to remember that "a single swallow does not make a summer." One strong quarter does not necessarily indicate a healthy economy. In fact, only one other quarter during Obama's presidency has matched this growth rate. Conversely, the economy's performance in 2014's first quarter was qualitatively as bad as the second quarter was good, marking the economy's worst performance since 2009's first quarter and the worst quarter since 1990.

The Obama administration's economic performance has been characterized by a preponderance of subpar growth. In 10 out of 22 quarters, the economy's growth has been below 2 percent. Excluding the negative 2.8 percent real GDP downturn in 2009, Mr. Obama's 2010-13 average annual GDP growth was just slightly above 2.1 percent. Including 2009's figure, the president's five-year average falls to below 1.2 percent annual GDP growth. If the Congressional Budget Office's 1.5 percent estimate for 2014 economic growth holds true, Mr. Obama's six-year economic growth average will be a paltry 1.2 percent.

In terms of unemployment, Mr. Obama's record has been little better. Despite a drop in labor-force participation that has helped lower the rate, the percentage of unemployed has remained high. Last month's 5.9 percent unemployment rate was the lowest of Mr. Obama's presidency, and it was the first time it has been below 6.1 percent since he came into office. In contrast, for 30 consecutive months of his presidency, the U.S. unemployment rate was 9 percent or higher. The average annual unemployment rate for Mr. Obama's first five years in office was 6.9 percent, a level not seen since 1993.

The economy has not lacked substantial assistance, with the Federal Reserve's unprecedented monetary-policy accommodation and an equally "stimulative" fiscal policy. Federal debt held by the public more than doubled during Obama's time in office, growing 106 percent, while the overall economy has grown just 12.6 percent.

Supporters argue that Mr. Obama faced a recession when he came into office and that, relative to the blow, the economy has at least endured. However, from an economic perspective, the greater the blow, the stronger the recovery should be, too. Such has not been the case.

The president's problem with the economy runs deeper than just economics. It is rooted in politics for two important reasons. First, Mr. Obama is now firmly associated with the subpar economy of the past five years. Given that America has suffered a prolonged and painful economic performance for more than six years, it is natural to associate the president with it. It is a test of most people's memory—if not credulity itself—to try attaching today's economy to George W. Bush, who is out of office for almost six years.

Second, America is not accustomed to persistent failure. Americans expect excellence, particularly in the economy. Given his record, what is truly surprising is not that the president does not receive credit for a good economy, but that he does not receive more blame for the economy being so poor. If anything, Mr. Obama should be counting his blessings for the little respect he has earned for his economy's dismal performance.

J.T. Young served in the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget from 2001 to 2004 and as a congressional staff member from 1987 to 2000.

Title: Second-Term Challenges and Achievements: A Comparative Analysis of Presidential Legacies in the U.S.

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the second term of a president often presents unique challenges and opportunities. This is no different for President Barack Obama, who has faced criticism for being too passive, a claim that his advisor, David Plouffe, dismisses as simplistic.

Presidential second terms have historically been marked by significant events, both positive and negative. For instance, Ronald Reagan faced the Iran-contra affair, while Bill Clinton was impeached. President Obama, like his predecessors, has also encountered setbacks, such as his failed attempt to pass gun control legislation early in his second term. Similarly, President George W. Bush's fifth-year initiative to reform Social Security met with resistance, and the escalating violence in Iraq made it difficult for him to regain momentum.

However, it is worth noting that presidents have managed to make significant strides in their second terms despite Congressional investigations. Reagan signed the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty with the Soviet Union, Clinton balanced the federal budget, and Bush, in the face of broad opposition, implemented a troop surge in Iraq, contributing to a turnaround in the situation.

President Obama, too, may find that the health of the economy at the end of his term could have a more significant impact on his legacy than the setbacks he currently faces. The recent announcement by the Congressional Budget Office of a sharp drop in the projected deficit serves as a reminder of this potential.

Yet, the current furors could reinforce the impression that the Obama presidency has expanded the role of government more than many Americans are comfortable with. These controversies can also undermine the president's ability to focus public attention, a powerful tool of the presidency.

As a senator, Obama recognized the dynamic nature of the presidency, understanding that a president could drive only 15 to 20 percent of the public agenda, with the rest requiring a reactive approach. In this light, Obama's famed equanimity and his ability to take a longer view are attributed to his experience in office.

"Being in office for nearly four and a half years gives the president some perspective—it helps separate the signal from the noise," said Dan Pfeiffer, a White House senior adviser. "When you have dealt with real life-and-death problems, the political ones seem much smaller and affect you less."

Title: Controversy Surrounding Fast and Furious Operation Intensifies as Terry Family Accuses Attorney General Holder of Hiding Information

Article:

The Terry family, parents of slain U.S. Border Patrol agent Brian Terry, have accused Attorney General Eric Holder and other Justice Department officials of withholding information regarding the botched anti-gunrunning operation Fast and Furious. In an interview with Fox News' Sean Hannity on Thursday, the Terry family expressed their belief that the Obama administration is concealing details about the operation that led to their son's death in December 2010.

The Fast and Furious operation, which allowed illicit guns to "walk" in the hope of tracking them to larger traffickers, has been under scrutiny since two of the guns used in the operation were found at the crime scene where Terry was killed. A House panel voted Wednesday along party lines to recommend holding Holder in contempt of Congress for not handing over a trove of documents related to Fast and Furious. President Obama has asserted executive privilege in keeping many of the documents out of public view.

The full House would still need to approve the resolution in order for Holder to be formally held in contempt of Congress. Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) suggested that the vote can be avoided if the attorney general turns over more emails and memos about the Fast and Furious sting. Holder has testified that he only found out about Fast and Furious after Terry's death, and he has condemned the tactics used in the operation.

However, GOP lawmakers have suggested that top officials at the Justice Department knew more about the operation than they have admitted. The Terry family, in their interview with Hannity, expressed their frustration at the Obama administration's perceived efforts to prevent them from learning the full story about their son's death.

"They're lying... They're passing the buck," said Kent Terry, Brian Terry's father. "I just know that they're hiding something big. Something happened out there."

The Terry family's statement comes a day after they released a statement expressing their disappointment with the Obama administration's latest actions. "Attorney General Eric Holder's refusal to fully disclose the documents associated with Operation Fast and Furious and President Obama's assertion of executive privilege serves to compound this tragedy. It denies the Terry family and the American people the truth," they said.

The controversy surrounding Fast and Furious has raised constitutional questions and challenges about the power of the presidency. The immediate question was whether the documents contained information so damaging that the president was willing to risk bad PR by moving to lock them down. GOP lawmakers also questioned whether Obama's assertion was legitimate, later voting in committee that it was not appropriate in this case.

The Department of Justice has defended its response, with Holder stating that Issa rejected what he thought was "an extraordinary offer." Wednesday's developments follow a flurry of activity Tuesday, as Holder tried to negotiate a way to avert the contempt proceedings. Issa had earlier indicated a willingness to postpone the vote after Holder indicated a willingness to make compromises and supply some documents in response to House Republicans' subpoena.

Title: White House Proposes 5% Domestic Spending Cuts in 2020 Budget, Maintains Border Wall Funding

Article:

In a move aimed at reducing the federal budget deficit, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow announced on Sunday that President Trump has proposed a 5 percent across-the-board cut on all domestic spending as part of his 2020 budget. The announcement was made during an appearance on "Fox News Sunday."

"It will be a tough budget," Kudlow said. "We're going to do our own caps this year, and I think it's long overdue." Kudlow added that the recent budget deals have not been favorable towards spending, and this proposed reduction is the "exact right prescription."

The proposed budget comes as a Government Accountability Office report predicts the U.S. budget deficit to hit $897 billion. Kudlow, however, stated that there's no reason to "obsess" about the budget deficit as long as it remains below 5 percent of the overall economy.

Like previous spending blueprints, Trump's plan for the 2020 budget year will propose cuts to many domestic programs favored by lawmakers in both parties but leave alone politically popular retirement programs such as Medicare and Social Security.

The budget proposal is expected to face months of negotiations in Washington, as lawmakers grapple with erasing the last remnants of a failed 2011 budget deal that would otherwise cut core Pentagon operations by $71 billion and domestic agencies and foreign aid by $55 billion.

Trump's 2017 tax cut and sharp increases in spending for both the Pentagon and domestic agencies, as well as the growing federal retirement costs of the baby boom generation, are major contributors to the growing deficit. Promises that the tax cut would stimulate so much economic growth that it would mostly pay for itself have been proven wrong.

The 2020 proposal will also maintain the 3 percent tax cuts implemented in 2018, according to Kudlow. One area that won't see a cut in the proposed budget is for funding for the president's border wall.

The Washington Post reported on Sunday that Trump will request at least $8.6 billion in new funding to build additional sections of a wall along the Mexico border. Trump also wants $5 billion in additional funds for the Department of Homeland Security and another $3.6 billion in military construction funds.

All this would come in addition to the $6.5 billion Trump vowed last month to redirect for the construction of the wall. "The whole issue of the wall and border security is a paramount of importance," Kudlow said on Sunday. "We have a crisis down there. I think the president has made that case effectively. It's a crisis of economics, it's a crisis of crime and drugs, it's a crisis of just of humanity."

Title: Graham Urges Direct Confrontation with Putin, Praises Supreme Court Nominees

In an exclusive interview with Fox News Sunday, Republican Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina called on President Trump to challenge Russian President Vladimir Putin over alleged meddling in the 2016 U.S. elections during their upcoming meeting in Helsinki. Graham suggested that Trump should not accept Putin's denial of involvement in the election and instead, should confront him about the ongoing attempts to disrupt the 2018 election cycle.

Graham also addressed the issue of Russian influence in Turkey, acknowledging it as problematic but viewing it as a new chapter following the re-election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan amid sweeping government purges.

On the international front, Graham attributed North Korea's criticisms of U.S. rhetoric to Chinese influence, stating, "I see China's hands all over this." He added that the U.S. should not let China use North Korea to back off from the ongoing trade dispute.

Domestically, Graham expressed optimism about the four Supreme Court nominees President Trump is reportedly considering, stating, "Republicans are holding four lottery tickets, and they're all winners." The nominees under consideration are federal judges Thomas Hardiman, Brett Kavanaugh, Raymond Kethledge, and Amy Coney Barrett.

Graham particularly praised Thomas Hardiman, comparing him favorably to Associate Justice Samuel Alito in terms of personality and legal bent. However, he criticized the partisanship in the Senate, stating that even a conservative nominee would struggle to secure many Democratic votes.

Graham also suggested that the nomination process could be a "nightmare for red-state Democrats," who risk alienating their constituency if they oppose Trump's pick. The increasingly partisan nature of Supreme Court confirmation hearings has led some analysts to urge Trump to try to defuse the tension. Juan Williams, a Fox News political analyst, noted the potential for a conservative justice to be appointed, which could be perceived as the court becoming a "rubber stamp for a conservative social agenda."

The article concludes with Trump's scheduled announcement of his pick to replace retiring Associate Justice Anthony Kennedy in a primetime address at 9 p.m. ET.

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Discuss Allowing Voters to Change Ballots in Future Presidential Primaries

Article:

In the state of Colorado, voters who have already cast their ballots for presidential candidates who have since dropped out cannot redo their ballots this year, but lawmakers are discussing whether this should be an option in future presidential primaries.

Elections officials have been encouraging voters to turn in their Super Tuesday mail ballots early to have results available earlier in the state's first presidential primary in 20 years. However, this means that some voters selected candidates who are no longer in the race, such as Pete Buttigieg.

Secretary of State Jena Griswold noted on Sunday via social media that Colorado voters who have filled out ballots but have not turned them in can still obtain new ballots or cross out their previous selection and pick a new candidate by 7 p.m. on Tuesday.

House Majority Leader Alec Garnett told reporters on Monday morning that there should be a discussion about a possible statutory change to allow voters in the future to make their voices heard through Election Day.

"Every voter should have the opportunity, even if their vote was cast for a candidate who has dropped out, to go to the county clerk and have the opportunity to pull a provisional ballot and vote for who remains in the race," Garnett said.

Garnett added that this is an issue that lawmakers did not discuss during the bill's process, and it is something that they should be talking about with both sides of the aisle.

Boulder County Clerk Molly Fitzpatrick also tweeted on Monday that voters who still have their ballots can change their vote by following the voter instructions on how to correct a mistake. However, if a voter has already voted, they cannot be issued a replacement ballot.

Only three other states hold all mail-ballot statewide elections, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, making the issue of voting early for a candidate that may drop out early fairly unique.

Garnett said he has not spoken to lawmakers about specific solutions, but after the results came in from South Carolina's caucus and former mayor Buttigieg's announcement on Sunday, he has heard from constituents asking what they can do.

"I think it was a little frustrating on my end to say, 'There's nothing you can do,'" he said.

Senate Majority Leader Steve Fenberg also said he has heard from people who are frustrated by being unable to change their votes, and he thinks this is an issue lawmakers can tackle this year for future elections, though he doesn't yet know what the exact solution should be.

"It could be logistically difficult, but I think it's worth looking into," Fenberg said.

The problem is exacerbated by the fact that the primary election for presidential candidates is how the state parties select delegates, and some of the candidates who dropped out, such as Buttigieg, could still receive delegates because they had a significant amount of support.

Title: Michael Cohen Admits to Hiring IT Firm to Manipulate Polls for Trump Campaign, Owes Money

Article:

In a bombshell report by The Wall Street Journal, it has been revealed that Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer to President Donald Trump, hired an IT firm to manipulate polls in favor of Trump during his presidential campaign in 2015. Cohen reportedly owes a significant amount of the money he owed the firm, RedFinch Solutions LLC, for their services.

Cohen confirmed the revelations on Twitter Thursday, stating, "As for the @WSJ article on poll rigging, what I did was at the direction of and for the sole benefit of @realDonaldTrump @POTUS. I truly regret my blind loyalty to a man who doesn’t deserve it."

According to the report, John Gauger, owner of RedFinch Solutions LLC, went to Trump Tower in 2015 to collect the $50,000 that Cohen had promised for trying to influence the polls in Trump's favor. However, Gauger received a blue Walmart bag containing approximately $12,000 to $13,000 in cash and a boxing glove, instead of the promised check.

Cohen denied to The Wall Street Journal that he paid in cash, stating that the money was given by check. The report also states that Gauger was asked in 2014 to manipulate the results of a CNBC poll for the top U.S. business leaders, but he was unsuccessful in getting Trump into the top 100. The following year, he was asked to influence a Drudge Report ranking of potential Republican primary picks, where Trump came in fifth.

Gauger told the newspaper that he performed other services for Cohen, unrelated to the president, and said Cohen paid for some of them. One project was to create the “@WomenForCohen” account, which still exists on Twitter. Its bio describes Cohen as "strong, pit bull, sex symbol, no nonsense, business-oriented, and ready to make a difference!"

In 2017, Cohen requested a $50,000 reimbursement for "tech services" from the Trump Tower Organization, according to federal prosecutors in a charging document filed in August 2018. Cohen was sentenced to three years in prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations, bank fraud, and lying to Congress. None of the charges are connected to his dealings with RedFinch.

The Trump Organization did not give a comment to The Wall Street Journal, but Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of Mr. Trump's lawyers, told the newspaper that Cohen is a thief. "If one thing has been established, it's that Michael Cohen is completely untrustworthy," the former New York City mayor said.

Title: Pelosi Contemplates Delaying Transmission of Impeachment Articles to Senate as Calls for Fairer Trial Mount

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi is reportedly considering withholding the transmission of the articles of impeachment to the Senate, following the House's passage of the impeachment articles against President Donald Trump on Wednesday. This decision comes as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has declared his intention to coordinate trial strategy with the White House, raising concerns among some legal scholars and Democrats about a fair trial.

The idea of delaying the transmission of the articles gained momentum in recent days, as McConnell has made it clear he has little interest in serving as an impartial overseer of the Senate trial. Constitutional lawyer Laurence Tribe, in an op-ed, called on Democrats to delay sending the impeachment articles to the Senate until McConnell agrees to run a fairer process.

During a press conference, Pelosi's remarks about the impeachment process were unexpected, prompting a flurry of questions from reporters. When asked if she would not transmit the articles, Pelosi responded, "You're asking me, 'So are we all going to go out and play in the snow?' That has not been part of our conversations."

Following the press conference, Pelosi huddled with top committee chairs leading Trump-focused investigations, and they emerged with a consistent message: The only story that matters is the president has been impeached.

Some Democrats believe a delay in transmitting articles is under consideration, as House leaders decided against naming impeachment managers – the set of lawmakers who would argue their case on the Senate floor – until an undetermined later date. In the past, House leaders have identified their impeachment managers the same day, but Pelosi will now be empowered to pick managers at her discretion and without a deadline.

Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) has approached every member of House leadership about the idea and received responses ranging from interest to outright support. Blumenauer argued that the delay could allow the House to continue building on its evidence for impeachment and potentially score additional legal victories that could unlock troves of new evidence and witness testimony the Trump administration has withheld from Congress.

Early discussions about the timing of transmitting articles of impeachment to the Senate are "not in the context" of Tribe's proposal, according to House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer. However, he acknowledged that colleagues have been discussing the idea.

As the impeachment process unfolds, it remains to be seen whether Pelosi will delay the transmission of the articles to the Senate and what impact this decision might have on the impeachment trial.

Title: "Obamacare in the Spotlight: A Political Test in New Hampshire's Midterm Elections"

Article:

In the upcoming midterm elections on November 4, the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is set to play a significant role in several key races, particularly in New Hampshire. The state, which is closely divided between Democrats and Republicans, is one of about 10 states where Republicans hope to make gains in order to take control of the Senate.

Senators Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Kay Hagan of North Carolina, along with Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, are among the Democratic targets of anti-Obamacare ads by conservative groups. The law, aimed at expanding health insurance coverage to millions more Americans, has come under sustained attack from Republicans.

President Barack Obama has urged Democrats campaigning in the midterm elections not to shy away from "Obamacare," but instead to "forcefully defend" it. Obama has stated that a surge in enrollment shows the system is running smoothly now, after its disastrous debut last October.

In the New Hampshire Senate race, Shaheen's leading Republican opponent, Scott Brown, is betting that the healthcare issue will resonate in New Hampshire, where the state's famous motto is "Live Free or Die." Brown, a former senator from neighboring Massachusetts, says the act should be completely repealed and the issue of healthcare reform should be left to the states.

While Obamacare may now be working better, national polls clearly show more people disapprove than approve of the law. In New Hampshire, a recent WMUR-Granite State poll reported that 51 percent of adults oppose Obamacare, while just 37 percent support it. Sixty-one percent of the state's voters think medical costs will increase under the act.

Derek Gagnon, a 33-year-old auto mechanic, is one of the skeptics. He has no health insurance and has no intention of signing up for the private insurance offered through the government-run website, HealthCare.gov. Gagnon's distaste for the individual mandate dovetails with a principal line of conservative attacks nationally on the law.

In the race for New Hampshire's other Senate seat, incumbent Senator Jeanne Shaheen still has political capital in the state, and political analyst Dean Spiliotes doubts the healthcare issue alone could defeat her. However, the healthcare issue is a significant factor in the race, and the outcome could be influenced by how effectively each candidate addresses the concerns of voters about Obamacare.

In the House of Representatives race, Representative Carol Shea-Porter, a fellow Democrat, and Ann Kuster, the state's other Democratic Representative, were among the earliest advocates of the healthcare law. Enrollment in Obamacare in the state of 1.3 million people has reached 40,000, double the number that had been expected.

In one hopeful sign for Democrats, enrollment in Obamacare in the state has reached 40,000 - double the number that had been expected. Shea-Porter, a former social worker who came to Congress in 2006 campaigning on healthcare reform, said she would never run away from Obamacare because she considers the law to be a "great joy and triumph." However, she understands the political perils for Democrats of Obamacare. She lost her seat in Congress in 2010 elections after her vote for the law, only to be re-elected in 2012. Her 2014 race is considered a toss-up although her Republican opponent has yet to be chosen in a September primary.

In conclusion, the midterm elections in New Hampshire will serve as a test of whether Democrats can overcome voter skepticism about Obamacare and use the law as a draw rather than a liability. The outcome of the elections could have significant implications for the future of the Affordable Care Act and the balance of power in Congress.

Title: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman Resigns Amid Allegations of Domestic Abuse

Article:

In a swift turn of events, New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, a prominent figure in the #Resistance movement and a vocal critic of President Trump, has resigned following allegations of physical and emotional abuse by four women. The New Yorker published an article on Monday detailing the graphic accusations, which include choking, threats, and demeaning language.

Schneiderman, who had built a high-profile reputation during the Trump era for his legal pushback and criticism of the President's agenda, was hailed as an icon of the anti-Trump left. He also became a key figure in the #MeToo movement, taking legal action against Harvey Weinstein and advocating for a "critical national reckoning" about the harassment of women.

However, the article revealed that Schneiderman had allegedly abused four women, including choking a former girlfriend, controlling what she ate, and demanding that another girlfriend, who was born in Sri Lanka and whom Schneiderman referred to as his "brown slave," call him "Master."

Michelle Manning Barish, one of the women speaking out, told The New Yorker, "You can't be a champion of women when you are hitting them and choking them in bed, and saying to them, 'You're a f--king whore.'" Tanya Selvaratnam, another woman, said, "He needs to be called out."

Schneiderman responded to the allegations, stating, "In the privacy of intimate relationships, I have engaged in role-playing and other consensual sexual activity. I have not assaulted anyone. I have never engaged in nonconsensual sex, which is a line I would not cross."

Within three hours of the article being published, Schneiderman announced his resignation, effective at the end of Tuesday. The accusations brought a wave of condemnation from both the right and the left, with fellow New York Democrat Andrew Cuomo calling the pattern of facts and corroboration "damning" and calling for Schneiderman to resign.

Trump allies, whom Schneiderman had targeted, made little attempt to hide their glee at their foe's sudden downfall. Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway tweeted, "Gotcha," referencing a tweet of Schneiderman's in which he said that "no one is above the law." Donald Trump Jr. dug up past statements Schneiderman had made about the #MeToo movement, snarking, "Self awareness level 0."

In a November interview with Full Frontal's Samantha Bee, Schneiderman laid out his achievements in the Trump era, boasting about his legal victories against the President. Now, Samantha Bee's "Full Frontal" has tweeted a screenshot of Schneiderman boasting on Twitter of the superhero mockups the TBS show had made for his November appearance.

Title: Obamacare Repairs: A Delicate Balance Amidst Political and Actuarial Challenges

Article:

In the heart of Washington, D.C., a flurry of activity is underway as lawmakers grapple with the intricacies of the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare. On Thursday, President Obama proposed a fix, followed by the House's approval of a separate solution on Friday, with more ideas emerging from various corners. However, these well-intentioned repairs could potentially exacerbate the issues plaguing Obamacare.

The primary aim of these proposed changes is to allow millions of Americans, whose health insurance plans are being canceled under Obamacare, to retain their existing policies and doctors, as originally promised. According to an Associated Press survey, over 4.2 million Americans have received cancellation notices from their insurers. This group, healthier on average compared to the uninsured, is causing concern due to the potential actuarial implications.

If healthier individuals remain outside the Obamacare pool, the system could face actuarial trouble, much like removing a piston from an engine and expecting it to run smoothly. The fear is that the Obamacare exchanges could attract a disproportionate share of higher-cost, sicker individuals, leading to higher premiums and a potential inability for the system to sustain itself.

Insurers and state insurance commissioners express reservations about reversing course, with some arguing that bringing back canceled policies could violate new state laws that forbid "substandard" plans. California and New York, two prominent states, are among those with such laws in place.

A reversal could exacerbate the confusion and lack of confidence already surrounding Obamacare. A crisis of confidence in the new health-care system could be debilitating, as noted by Larry Kocot, a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution who helped roll out Medicare Part D during the George W. Bush administration.

The political pressure to address the cancellations is significant, with the backlash reaching "Category 5 political hurricane" intensity, as described by Rep. Greg Walden (R-OR). The drop in President Obama's approval rating to 39% and the personal stories of those affected by the cancellations have put immense pressure on lawmakers, particularly Democrats who are up for re-election in 2014.

The political landscape is further complicated by the fact that most Democrats dislike the current House-approved bill, with President Obama promising to veto it due to concerns about enlarging the pool of people who could be attracted to the plans and worsening the outlook for Obamacare's sustainability.

As the situation unfolds, it remains to be seen where this will lead. The rollout of Obamacare has revealed problems beyond a broken website, and fixing them could result in a delicate unraveling of the system.

Title: AllSides Report Suggests Google News Shows Bias Toward Left-Leaning Perspectives

Article:

A new report from media technology group AllSides has suggested that Google News and Google Search results show a strong preference for media outlets with a left-leaning perspective in the United States political spectrum. The report, which reviewed Google News' homepage and search engine results over a two-week period, found that the overall bias of Google News was about 65 percent toward the left, with about 20 percent toward the center and about 16 percent to the right.

The timeframe of the study coincided with President Donald Trump's tweets criticizing Google for allegedly biasing its search results in his favor. In late August, Trump tweeted, "Google search results for 'Trump News' shows only the viewing/reporting of Fake News Media... Google & others are suppressing voices of Conservatives and hiding information and news that is good."

The report found that left-leaning news was almost always one of the top two results displayed, with news from the center of the political spectrum less visible but usually in the top five or six results. News from the political right was often found further down the page, with users having to scroll down before seeing their first news article from the right.

The report also found that when news from the left competed with news from other viewpoints, the left won just about every time. In 91 percent of cases where there was bias of one political slant over another, the left won over the right. When the competition was between the center and the left, the left's dominance was still strong at 80 percent.

The report did not suggest that Google intentionally favored media sources from the left, but rather that the resulting choice of links provided by Google News showed a significant bias in favor of the left. The report attributed this bias to the fact that most news outlets and journalists have political views that represent the left side of the US political spectrum, and that online news consumers are younger and lean farther left than the average American.

Google has previously denied setting a political agenda and stated that its goal is to provide the most relevant answers to users in a matter of seconds. The company has not yet responded to the AllSides report.

This study does not suggest that there is intentional favoritism for media sources from the left, nor does it suggest the opposite. It only demonstrates that the resulting choice of links that Google News provides do have a significant bias in favor of the left, according to the report.

We are committed to truth and accuracy in all of our journalism. Read our editorial standards.

Title: Indonesia Raises Minimum Marriage Age for Girls to 19, A Step Towards Ending Child Marriage

Article:

Indonesia, the eighth-highest country in terms of child brides globally, has taken a significant step towards eradicating child marriage. This month, the country's parliament raised the minimum age at which girls can marry from 16 to 19. The decision was prompted by a Constitutional Court ruling in December that deemed it discriminatory to mandate a lower minimum age of marriage for girls than for boys.

While this development is commendable, Indonesia is not the worst offender in this regard. According to UNICEF, 14% of Indonesian women marry before they reach 18 years old. In contrast, the figures are 59% in Bangladesh and 76% in Niger. Nineteen of the 20 countries where child marriage is most prevalent are in Africa.

The practice of marrying off daughters at a young age is often a means for families to secure their daughters' lives. Factors associated with this practice include rigid gender norms, conflict, and poverty. Education, particularly for girls, is a crucial factor. A study by the World Bank involving 15 countries found that girls without schooling are three times more likely to be married by age 18 than those with secondary education. However, in many cultures, education for girls takes a backseat to marriage and its associated duties.

Cutting a childhood short can have severe consequences. Girls who marry have an increased risk of sexual violence, poorer health, and higher school drop-out rates. They are also less likely to participate in the labor force, which incurs significant economic costs. A paper published in 2015 found that child marriage cost Indonesia's economy 1.7% of its GDP in 2014. The global welfare benefit of ending the practice is estimated to be around $22 billion.

Indonesia's new policy is a significant stride towards ending child marriage. However, in the context of controversial new revisions to the country's criminal code—which would criminalize extra-marital sex and endorse chauvinistic local by-laws—lawmakers will need to demonstrate that the new marriage age for girls is more than a token gesture towards gender equality. Indonesia's parliament could resolve to tackle the social and economic forces that make child marriage so common. Ensuring that girls complete their 12 years of compulsory schooling would be a start. Reducing unintended pregnancies by improving access to contraception and sexual-health education would also help. Giving girls more control over their bodies would allow them to exercise more sway over their future, including who they marry. That is worth saying yes to.

Title: U.S. Marshals Prepared to Guard National Monuments Amid Ongoing George Floyd Protests

The Trump administration has directed the U.S. Marshals Service to be on standby, ready to protect national monuments across the country amid ongoing protests following the death of George Floyd. In an email, Marshals Service Assistant Director Andrew C. Smith stated that the agency has been asked to immediately prepare to provide federal law enforcement support to safeguard national monuments.

The email, labeled as an "Attorney General Assignment," suggests it originated from Attorney General William P. Barr. Smith noted that the assignment is challenging due to the wide range of potential targets for criminal activity.

According to CNN, the Marshals are part of a "major effort" by the administration to bolster security around national monuments, with the Marshals expected to begin their work before the end of the week. The Daily Wire reported that unarmed National Guard troops will also be deployed in Washington, D.C., to assist the U.S. Park Police in protecting monuments in the nation's capital.

The security reinforcements were prompted after weeks of statues being toppled nationwide. Initially, rioters primarily targeted Confederate monuments, but in recent days, tributes to the founding fathers and even abolitionists have been destroyed.

President Trump warned on Tuesday that those damaging federal property, such as monuments, would face prosecution under the full extent of the law. He tweeted, "I have authorized the Federal Government to arrest anyone who vandalizes or destroys any monument, statue or other such Federal property in the U.S. with up to 10 years in prison, per the Veteran's Memorial Preservation Act, or such other laws that may be pertinent."

He added, "This action is taken effective immediately, but may also be used retroactively for destruction or vandalism already caused. There will be no exceptions!"

The president reiterated his stance on Wednesday night, tweeting, "Very sad to see States allowing roving gangs of wise guys, anarchists & looters, many of them having no idea what they are doing, indiscriminately ripping down our statues and monuments to the past. Some are great works of art, but all represent our History & Heritage, both the good and the bad. It is important for us to understand and remember, even in turbulent and difficult times, and learn from them. Knowledge comes from the most unusual of places!"

Title: NSA's X-KEYSCORE Program: Unveiling a Vast Surveillance Tool for Foreign Signals Intelligence

Article:

The latest revelation from Glenn Greenwald's disclosures from the Snowden files has shed light on a powerful surveillance program called X-KEYSCORE, operated by the National Security Agency (NSA). This program provides access to an extensive amount of internet data, potentially encompassing phone conversations, emails, chats, and more.

The quantity of data accessible through programs such as XKeyscore is immense. The XKeyscore system collects such a vast amount of internet data that it can only be stored for short periods, with content remaining on the system for only three to five days, while metadata is stored for 30 days. One document explains that at some sites, the NSA receives 20+ terabytes of data per day, which can only be stored for as little as 24 hours.

To manage this data influx, the NSA has developed a multi-tiered system. Analysts can store "interesting" content in other databases, such as Pinwale, which can store material for up to five years. It's unclear exactly what's available through X-KEYSCORE, but it appears to be exclusively foreign signals intelligence.

An NSA tool called DNI Presenter, used to read the content of stored emails, also enables an analyst using XKeyscore to read the content of Facebook chats or private messages. Analysts can monitor Facebook chats by entering the Facebook user name and a date range into a simple search screen. They can search for internet browsing activities using a wide range of information, including search terms entered by the user or the websites viewed.

The XKeyscore program also allows an analyst to learn the IP addresses of every person who visits any website the analyst specifies. However, it's unclear whether this includes U.S. persons or only foreign nationals. Under U.S. law, the NSA is required to obtain an individualized Fisa warrant if the target of their surveillance is a 'U.S. person,' though no such warrant is required for intercepting the communications of Americans with foreign targets.

X-KEYSCORE seems to provide the technological capability, if not the legal authority, to target even U.S. persons for extensive electronic surveillance without a warrant, provided that some identifying information, such as their email or IP address, is known to the analyst. The NSA documents assert that by 2008, 300 terrorists had been captured using intelligence from XKeyscore.

While the Fisa Amendments Act of 2008 requires an individualized warrant for the targeting of U.S. persons, NSA analysts are permitted to intercept the communications of such individuals without a warrant if they are in contact with one of the NSA's foreign targets. For instance, an XKeyscore document shows an NSA target in Tehran communicating with people in Frankfurt, Amsterdam, and New York.

Greenwald suggests that this validates Snowden's statement in an earlier interview that "I, sitting at my desk, certainly had the authorities to wiretap anyone, from you, or your accountant, to a federal judge, to even the President if I had a personal email." However, it's not clear at all whether X-KEYSCORE gives anyone "authority" to wiretap a U.S. citizen. Rather, it provides access to tremendous volumes of foreign communications, which can then be searched by NSA analysts.

There are known "compliance problems" with the NSA's surveillance programs, as communications by U.S. persons end up in this database if the other end of the conversation is overseas—and these communications can therefore end up on an analyst's desktop. The NSA's minimization procedures are supposed to prevent such "inadvertent" targeting of U.S. persons, but as Greenwald reported earlier, there are plenty of exceptions to this rule.

In conclusion, the X-KEYSCORE program, as revealed by Glenn Greenwald, appears to be a powerful tool for foreign signals intelligence, potentially granting access to vast amounts of internet data, including phone conversations, emails, chats, and more. However, the legality and implications of its use in targeting U.S. persons remain a subject of debate and further investigation.

Title: GOP Health Care Bill Faces Uncertain Future as Key Republicans Oppose Measure

Article:

Washington ( CNN ) - The White House and congressional Republicans are in a precarious position as they struggle to garner enough votes to pass their health care bill. Several Republicans have publicly voiced their opposition to the current measure to repeal and replace Obamacare, bringing CNN's whip count to 21 Republicans - mostly moderates - opposed to the bill, with at least 17 lawmakers still undecided.

As of Monday, no vote has been scheduled, and it remains unclear if there will be one before the House recesses for a week-long break this Friday. Vice President Mike Pence, who has been working with congressional leaders on the health care effort from the start, visited Capitol Hill on Monday and Tuesday to lobby lawmakers.

President Donald Trump, whose White House was initially optimistic the House could pass a bill on Wednesday, has added to the uncertainty by suggesting the measure may still be changed. "I want it to be good for sick people. It's not in its final form right now," he said during an Oval Office interview with Bloomberg News. "It will be every bit as good on pre-existing conditions as Obamacare."

The Republican Party can only afford to lose 22 votes, assuming all Republicans are able to attend the vote and no Democrats cross over. As they count votes, GOP Rep. Jason Chaffetz, who was expected to be out for three to four weeks after surgery, returned Monday from Utah and will back the bill, his office said.

Notably, Rep. Billy Long, a Republican from Missouri who serves on the Energy and Commerce Committee, announced his opposition to the legislation on Monday. Reps. Brian Fitzpatrick of Pennsylvania, Daniel Webster of Florida, and Chris Smith of New Jersey will also vote against the current bill, making their decisions public in succession Monday afternoon.

Heading into a Republican whip meeting Monday afternoon, some members were still undecided, including Reps. Kevin Yoder, David Valadao, Erik Paulson, Elise Stefanik, and Adam Kinzinger.

Rep. Patrick McHenry, the chief GOP deputy whip, told reporters that he had no predictions on when and if a bill would come up this week.

The hope is that leadership can sell moderates on the fact that this bill is going over to the Senate where it might be significantly reworked. Rep. Peter King, R-New York, is already talking to members in the Senate about changes he'd like to see.

As hard as it is, Republican congressional leaders know they can't simply abandon their effort now. "I hope we keep going. I don't think we can stop," said Rep. Brett Guthrie, a Republican who serves on the House's Energy and Commerce Committee, last week.

White House chief economic adviser Gary Cohn sounded optimistic Monday morning when asked if he thought Republicans' plans for health care had enough votes. "I think we do," Cohn told CBS. "This is going be a great week. We're going to get health care down to the floor of the House. We're convinced we've got the votes and we're going to keep moving on with our agenda."

The fight over how pre-existing conditions are covered is at the center of the fight. Trump said Sunday the White House is pushing forward, and that the GOP plan "guarantees" coverage for Americans with pre-existing conditions. "Pre-existing conditions are in the bill. And I mandate it. I said, 'Has to be,'" Trump said on CBS's "Face the Nation" Sunday.

However, under the GOP bill, insurers could charge those with pre-existing conditions higher rates than others in the plan if they allow their coverage to lapse. Republicans seem to be in a never-ending cycle of trying to please the moderate and conservative wings of their party, but pressure from the White House to deliver a legislative win for Trump is real. Also real: the repeated pledges to their constituents over the past seven years to repeal and replace Obamacare if given the chance.

A new amendment sponsored by moderate leader Rep. Tom MacArthur of New Jersey gave states the ability to opt out of more Obamacare regulations. The amendment was also enough to finally bring the conservative House Freedom Caucus on board.

However, the amendment, which experts noted could drive up the cost of insurance for older Americans and those with pre-existing conditions, spooked moderates and left some - who had been supportive of the legislation before - scrambling to publicly voice their discontentment. All of a sudden, it was moderates in the hot seat.

It seemed that even though leadership may have gained upwards of 30 new votes from the Freedom Caucus, they were suffering significant enough losses from the other side of the party that they still could not bring a bill up to the floor for a vote in order to mark Trump's first 100 days in office.

This week, leadership's focus remains trying to help those moderates get comfortable with the new MacArthur amendment. Over the weekend, House leaders, as well as Pence and Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price, spoke with members hoping to flip enough votes to move the bill forward. Leadership aides emphasize that there is not much room to change the proposal at this point, but many deputy whips are trying to get members to keep the process in perspective.

"You remind them there is a United States Senate, and it will change things. What we send over there is not going over there on stone tablets," said Rep. Tom Cole, R-Oklahoma. "Going back to the drawing board would be death to repeal and replace."

After last week, many moderates are frustrated with the process. Some say they see their party making the same kind of mistakes Republicans criticized Democrats for making back in 2010.

"We didn't learn anything from their mistakes," said Rep. Mark Amodei, a moderate Republican from Nevada, last week. "We learned nothing from their mistakes."

As to promises the bill will be changed once it's in the Senate?

"Seriously, you want me to go back and tell the people in my fourth of Nevada 'the Senate will make it better?'" Amodei said. "What the hell?"

Title: High School Students Protest Alleged Lack of Action Against Bullying in Oklahoma

Article:

-Start of Article-

Hundreds of students from Norman High School in Oklahoma walked out of their school on Monday to protest the school's response to alleged bullying of three classmates who claim they were raped by the same individual. The students were joined by parents and members of the community outside the school, with junior Sophia Babb telling CNN that the crowd waved signs and chanted slogans such as "No justice, no class" and "No more bullying."

The students' protest stems from allegations by three female Norman High School students who say they were mercilessly bullied after reporting separate instances of rape by the same person. The teens and their families claim that school administrators failed to take adequate action after the rapes and bullying were reported.

The story gained traction on social media after Jezebel published a detailed account of the incidents last Friday. No arrests or charges have been made yet, Norman Police Department Captain Tom Easley told CNN. An investigation began a month ago, and no details will be released until it concludes. A Norman High School spokesperson had not returned CNN's request for comment by publication time.

In a letter to the school community, Norman Public Schools Superintendent Joe Siano encouraged parents to talk to their children about alternatives to the walkout, such as wearing stickers and ribbons provided by the school "in symbolic support." He also said the school was enlarging a task force to study the implementation of a "targeted, research-based sexual assault curriculum for students," and that the school will continue to respond quickly to reports of sexual assault and bullying.

The three teens told Jezebel that they stopped attending classes and left school voluntarily after the teasing became unbearable. Friends of the teens started a Facebook page, YES ALL Daughters, two weeks ago to show support for them. Babb said the page drew nearly 10,000 likes in two weeks. With the help of their mothers and relatives, they organized Monday's protest.

"After hearing the story, we felt compelled to help the kids do something," said Stacie Wright, whose niece started the Facebook page.

The group posted a long list of "Protest Do's and Don'ts" on its Facebook page to ensure the event remained peaceful. The list included instructions such as "Be Peaceful, Law-Abiding Citizens that do not disturb local businesses" and "Be a Good Neighbor."

The Daily Oklahoman reported that the crowd of protesters on Monday was in the hundreds. However, organizers estimated that 1,500 attended the protest outside the school, which has an enrollment of about 1,800 students.

"It shows that students won't put up with this harassment and bullying," Babb said. "We stand in solidarity with all victims and we want to show that we support them."

-End of Article-

Title: Analysis of Ryan's Speech at the Republican National Convention: Focus on Debt, Lack of Clarity on Economic Growth

Article:

Republican vice-presidential candidate Paul Ryan delivered a passionate speech at the Republican National Convention in Tampa on Wednesday, receiving a standing ovation from the audience. The speech, while effective in its delivery, was criticized for its lack of clarity on economic growth solutions.

Ryan, in his speech, dismantled the Obama administration's economic policies, particularly the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. He also defended the Republican party against the common Democratic attacks on Medicare reform, often referred to as "Mediscare" by the opposition.

However, the speech was met with disappointment as Ryan's economic growth solutions were deemed unclear. Instead of discussing Mitt Romney's tax rate proposals, Ryan used the term "tax fairness," a term often used by President Obama and other liberal Democrats. This was surprising, as Ryan is known for his association with supply-side economics and the Reagan tax reform.

In the speech, Ryan failed to mention the proposed 20% across-the-board reduction in marginal tax rates and the 25% corporate tax rate reduction, which have been proposed by Mitt Romney. Instead, the speech focused heavily on the issue of debt, a point that some argue may not resonate with the unemployed or marginally employed.

The article argues that the Republican party traditionally loses when they run on debt and deficits, but wins when they run on growth, limited government, lower spending, lower tax rates, and deregulation. The author expresses disappointment in the lack of clarity on growth solutions in Ryan's speech and hopes that Mitt Romney will clarify his own growth policies during his speech on Thursday.

The article concludes by stating the author's desire for growth, growth, growth, but did not find it in Ryan's speech, instead hearing debt, debt, debt. The author's call for growth solutions to be made clearer ahead of the upcoming election is a reminder of the importance of economic growth in the minds of voters.

Title: Narendra Modi: From Tea Vendor to India's Potential Prime Minister

Article:

In the aftermath of India's recently concluded parliamentary elections, Narendra Modi, the charismatic leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), is poised to become India's next prime minister, with his party heading towards a landslide victory. Modi, who began his political journey as a tea vendor's son, has been chief minister of the state of Gujarat since 2001, where he is credited for the state's strong economic growth. However, the 2002 religious riots in Gujarat remain a contentious issue in Modi's political legacy.

Modi's rise to power is remarkable in a country known for political dynasties. He joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization, at a young age and rose through its ranks. The BJP, Modi's party, maintains close ties with the RSS.

Modi's personal life has been the subject of much speculation. He is married but only acknowledged his wife's existence in April, when he filed his nomination papers. Despite this, Modi has been chief minister of Gujarat for 13 years, during which he made it one of India's best-performing states economically. He is known for his self-discipline and austerity.

Under Modi's leadership, the economy of Gujarat has nearly tripled in size. He is also known for his decisiveness, efficiency, and his ability to root out corruption, stimulate investment, and cut through bureaucratic red tape. Indian business executives frequently rank Gujarat as one of the easiest states in India in which to do business.

However, not everyone has benefited from Gujarat's economic progress. Half of all children under the age of 5 suffer from malnutrition, and two-thirds of rural households lack toilets. Furthermore, Gujarat's entrepreneurial tradition predates Modi, but he is credited with making the government machinery accountable.

The 2002 anti-Muslim violence that occurred under Modi's watch remains a significant concern for many Indians. Hundreds of Muslims were killed in the riots that followed the burning of a train compartment carrying Hindu pilgrims; 59 of those pilgrims died. Some of Modi's close aides were found guilty of participating in the violence. Modi has denied any responsibility, but critics argue that he did not take sufficient action to stop the violence.

The Indian government's own data show urban Muslims in Gujarat are worse off than Muslims in the rest of the country. However, Gujarat is one of the top states in the country for Muslim employment. While Modi is praised for his organizational skills and governance style, he is also criticized as vindictive and abrasive, and capable of holding grudges for years and intolerant of dissent.

Modi's potential prime ministership has raised concerns in the international community due to the 2002 Gujarat riots. Modi was denied a U.S. visa following the riots, but it is likely he would be granted one if he becomes prime minister and applies for a visa. Modi has met with U.S. and European officials, and it appears that, if he becomes prime minister of the world's largest democracy, Modi would not be isolated in the West or the international community.

In conclusion, Narendra Modi's political journey from a tea vendor's son to a potential prime minister is a remarkable one. His economic policies have been praised, but his handling of the 2002 Gujarat riots remains a significant concern for many Indians and the international community. As India prepares for a new government, the future of Modi's leadership will be closely watched both domestically and internationally.

Title: Hurricane Sandy Disrupts Presidential Campaign Schedules as East Coast Braces for Impact

Article:

As Hurricane Sandy approaches the eastern United States, both President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney have adjusted their campaign schedules in response to the impending storm. The National Hurricane Center projects that tropical storm conditions will soon affect the North Carolina coast, with landfall expected around Delaware and New Jersey late Monday or early Tuesday.

President Obama has canceled campaign events in Northern Virginia on Monday and in Colorado Springs, Colo. on Tuesday. Mitt Romney has canceled all of his events scheduled for Virginia on Sunday and will instead campaign in Ohio on Monday morning.

The storm currently sits off the coast of Florida, and tropical storm watches and warnings are in effect in the Carolinas. Federal officials warn that the East Coast from South Carolina on up should be prepared for heavy rains and winds, with inland areas potentially seeing up to 2 feet or more of snow.

Federal Emergency Management Agency Administrator Craig Fugate emphasized that the storm's reach will extend to areas far inland, such as the Ohio Valley and Appalachian regions, and may cause flooding in the D.C. area's rivers. FEMA and other federal partners are already sending teams and resources into potentially impacted areas to support state and local preparedness efforts.

Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano urged those along the East Coast to closely monitor the progress of Hurricane Sandy and follow the guidance and direction of their state and local officials. Both Napolitano and Fugate reached out to governors up and down the East Coast throughout Saturday.

President Obama is expected to leave Washington for Florida on Sunday afternoon before the brunt of the storm hits the D.C. metro area. He will hold an event in Youngstown, Ohio, before returning to Washington to monitor the storm. Vice President Joe Biden is set to appear in Ohio on Tuesday.

Both White House and campaign officials downplayed the storm's potential effect on turnout in swing states as well as the optics of campaigning during a looming disaster. The safety of staff, supporters, and volunteers is the top priority for both campaigns.

Title: Trump Cancels Planned Veterans Day Parade in Washington DC Over High Cost Estimates

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, US President Donald Trump has announced the cancellation of a planned Veterans Day military parade in Washington DC due to high costs associated with the event. The parade, initially set for November 11, the centenary of the end of World War One, was estimated to cost around $90 million (£71m), more than three times the original estimate.

In a series of tweets, President Trump criticized local politicians for requesting an exorbitant figure for the parade. He wrote, "The local politicians who run Washington, D.C. (poorly) know a windfall when they see it. When asked to give us a price for holding a great celebratory military parade, they wanted a number so ridiculously high that I cancelled it."

Washington Mayor Muriel Bowser responded to the president's tweet, emulating his tone. Meanwhile, a Pentagon spokesperson, Col Rob Manning, stated in a statement that the Department of Defense and the White House "have now agreed to explore opportunities in 2019."

Initially, the budget director had estimated costs of between $10m and $30m when the White House announced its request in February. However, a US official later provided a new estimate of $92m. The parade's budget director had also noted that no tanks would be used to avoid damaging the roads of the nation's capital.

The District of Columbia Council, Washington's legislative body, was critical of the plan when it was announced, voicing displeasure on Twitter. Members of the Democratic party were similarly sceptical, with congressman Jim McGovern declaring it "an absurd waste of money" on Twitter and saying Mr Trump "acts more like dictator than president."

The Pentagon had planned for the military to march from the White House to the Capitol, with the parade featuring a "heavy air component at the end." The focus was set to be the work of US military veterans through the ages, starting with the American revolution.

It is worth noting that President Trump had previously cancelled planned military exercises with South Korea in June after his meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, citing the need to "save a fortune." The US had a military parade in 1991 following the end of its successful campaign to force Saddam Hussein's troops out of Kuwait.

Paris will hold its long-planned parade on the same day, while the event at Maryland's Andrews Air Force Base is scheduled for a "different date," according to the president. Mr Trump had previously expressed admiration for France's Bastille Day parade during a visit to Paris in 2017, stating he wanted the US to "top it." The president has not ruled out the possibility of a future parade in Washington DC.

Title: GOP-Authored Obamacare Repeal Bill Clears House, Faces Uncertain Future in Senate

The House of Representatives has passed a bill, known as the Restoring Americans' Healthcare Freedom Reconciliation Act, that aims to repeal key components of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The bill, which defunds Planned Parenthood for one year, was passed with a vote of 240-189. However, the bill's future in the Senate is uncertain, as some vocal conservatives argue that the bill does not go far enough in repealing Obamacare.

The bill, if enacted, would repeal the individual and employer insurance mandates, as well as taxes on medical device sales and the so-called "Cadillac tax" on generous health plans. The bill's passage in the House was facilitated by a tool known as budget reconciliation, which allows the bill to pass with a simple majority in the Senate and avoid a filibuster.

President Obama can still veto the bill, but Republican leaders are hoping to demonstrate their ability to dismantle Obamacare with a simple Senate majority and a GOP president in 2017. Majority Whip Steve Scalise, a Louisiana Republican, stated, "Let's get this bill to the president's desk and let him make a decision. Is he going to finally stand up for American workers and sign this bill? Or is he going to continue to support a law that's destroying jobs and destroying health care in this country?"

Democrats criticized the bill, with Rep. Louise Slaughter, a New York Democrat, stating, "I don't know why the American public is not outraged over the fact that none of their business is taken care of, but over and over and over again we talk about taking health care away from people."

The bill's path through the Senate will be challenging, as it must first win the approval of the chamber's parliamentarian, who will rule on which provisions meet reconciliation's arcane rules. Already, Republican sponsors have stripped out a provision that would repeal Obamacare's Medicare spending board, as the parliamentarian was likely to rule it out of order.

A trio of Senate Republicans, including two 2016 presidential hopefuls, have stated that the legislation "simply isn't good enough" and reneges on repeated vows to repeal the entire law. The bill passed on the strength of Republican votes, with only seven GOP members rejecting it and one Democrat, Rep. Collin Peterson of Minnesota, voting "yes," though he has been opposed to Obamacare in the past.

The bill's passage in the House marks a significant step in the Republican effort to repeal Obamacare, but its future in the Senate remains uncertain. The bill's success will depend on the parliamentarian's rulings and the ability of Republican leaders to win over conservative senators who are demanding a full repeal of the law.

Title: Congressional Hearing Raises Questions Over DHS Ammunition Purchases

Article:

In a hearing on Thursday, Republican Rep. Jason Chaffetz questioned the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) over its ammunition purchases, stating that the department is using roughly 1,000 rounds of ammunition more per person than the U.S. Army.

Chaffetz, R-Utah, expressed his bewilderment over the department's need for such a large quantity of ammunition, stating, "It is entirely inexplicable why the Department of Homeland Security needs so much ammunition."

The hearing, which was unusual in its public scrutiny of the department's ammunition purchases, had previously been a topic of discussion on blogs and occasional news articles. However, as the DHS found itself defending the purchases, lawmakers showed increasing interest in the issue.

Democratic Rep. John Tierney, D-Mass., dismissed the concerns as "conspiracy theories" with "no place" in the committee room.

However, Republicans argued that the purchases raise "serious" questions about waste and accountability. Chaffetz, who chairs one of the House oversight subcommittees, revealed that the department currently has more than 260 million rounds in stock. He said the department bought more than 103 million rounds in 2012 and used 116 million that same year, among roughly 70,000 agents.

Comparing that with the small-arms purchases procured by the U.S. Army, he said the DHS is churning through between 1,300 and 1,600 rounds per officer, while the U.S. Army goes through roughly 350 rounds per soldier.

Nick Nayak, chief procurement officer for the Department of Homeland Security, did not challenge Chaffetz's numbers. However, Nayak sought to counter what he described as several misconceptions about the bullet buys.

Despite reports that the department was trying to buy up to 1.6 billion rounds over five years, he said that is not true. He later clarified that the number is closer to 750 million. He said the department, on average, buys roughly 100 million rounds per year.

He also said claims that the department is stockpiling ammo are "simply not true." Further, he countered claims that the purchases are helping create broader ammunition shortages in the U.S.

The department has long said it needs the bullets for agents in training and on duty, and buys in bulk to save money. While Democrats likened concerns about the purchases to conspiracy theories, Republicans raised concern about the sheer cost of the ammunition.

"This is not about conspiracy theories, this is about good government," Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said.

Rep. Darrell Issa, R-Calif., who chairs the full Oversight and Government Reform Committee, said he suspects rounds are being stockpiled, and then either "disposed of," passed to non-federal agencies, or shot "indiscriminately." If that is the case, he said, "then shame on you."

Title: Romney Accuses Obama Administration of Misunderstanding Radical Islam, Criticizes Response to Middle East Attacks

Article:

In a major foreign-policy speech at the Virginia Military Institute on Monday, Mitt Romney accused the Obama administration of fundamentally misunderstanding the threat of radical Islam. The Republican presidential nominee argued that President Obama's response to the assault on American diplomatic posts in Egypt and Libya, as well as his overall approach to foreign affairs, is emblematic of this misunderstanding.

Romney, who delayed for nearly a month before delivering the speech, sharpened his attack on the way Mr. Obama handled the attacks, stating that the president's initial reaction was to blame an Internet video mocking Islam, and only belatedly to acknowledge "the deliberate work of terrorists who use violence to impose their dark ideology on others."

The former Massachusetts governor will argue that Mr. Obama's response to the attacks is indicative of his overall approach to foreign affairs, which Romney said he will change by asserting more American influence. He plans to use foreign aid to pressure Egypt to protect democracy, build the Syrian opposition, and restart negotiations toward a two-state solution for the Israelis and Palestinians.

"I believe that if America does not lead, others will — others who do not share our interests and our values — and the world will grow darker, for our friends and for us," Romney will say. "America’s security and the cause of freedom can not afford four more years like the last four years."

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney's foreign policy credentials, stating that he has not demonstrated his ability to handle foreign policy. "We’re not going to be lectured by someone who has been an unmitigated disaster on foreign policy every time he’s dipped his toe in the foreign policy waters," Obama campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki told reporters traveling aboard Air Force One on Sunday.

The economy has dominated the presidential race, but Iran's nuclear program and the Sept. 11 attacks on the American Embassy in Cairo and the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, have thrust foreign affairs into the headlines. Mr. Obama and his advisers initially said the attacks were sparked by a video mocking the Prophet Muhammad, but have since acknowledged that the attack in Benghazi was orchestrated by terrorist elements linked to al Qaeda.

Romney's advisers have stated that he starts from a completely different philosophy that begins with the belief that the fight against terrorism can't be conducted surgically. "While drones and drone attacks are worthwhile and it’s good to kill bad guys, you fundamentally misunderstand this struggle if you think that’s the answer to it," said Richard S. Williamson, a former assistant secretary of state who is advising Romney.

Romney chose VMI, in Lexington, Va., to deliver the speech because it was the alma mater of George C. Marshall, who, as secretary of state and secretary of defense, helped craft the foreign policy that guided Republicans and Democrats after World War II.

Over the past week, the presidential race has turned into a bit of a roller coaster, with Romney's strong debate performance and then the release of unemployment numbers benefiting Mr. Obama. Mr. Obama also announced his campaign and allied party organizations collected $181 million in donations in September. The campaigns have spent several days wrestling over their contrasting economic messages, with both sides exchanging rhetorical blows on the television talk-show circuit and the battle spilling onto the television airwaves in Florida, a key state come Election Day.

Title: Trump's Embrace of American Health Care Act: A Betrayal of Promises Made to Voters

Article:

In a move that has been widely criticized as a betrayal of his campaign promises, President Donald Trump has endorsed the American Health Care Act, a bill authored by House Republicans and other establishment-minded members of his administration. The bill, which represents a significant departure from Trump's repeated promises to the American people, is set to cut millions from health insurance coverage and Medicaid spending, while providing tax cuts for the wealthy.

During his campaign, Trump made clear promises on health care policy, stating that he would not cut Social Security, Medicare, or Medicaid, and that he would offer patients a more generous deal than they were getting from the Affordable Care Act (ACA). However, the centerpiece of the Trump-endorsed American Health Care Act is a $600 billion tax cut, with the majority of the benefits going to the top 0.1% of income earners.

In May 2015, Trump told the conservative Daily Signal, "I'm not going to cut Social Security like every other Republican and I'm not going to cut Medicare or Medicaid." He reiterated these promises throughout his campaign, telling 60 Minutes in the fall of 2015, "I am going to take care of everybody."

However, the American Health Care Act, if passed, would result in 6 to 15 million people losing insurance, according to estimates by Standard & Poor's and Brookings analysts. The bill shifts $370 billion in Medicaid costs onto state governments, and drastically reduces federal subsidies to help people pay for insurance, particularly in high-cost states.

The bill also specifically disadvantages certain groups of people, such as older Americans and residents of rural areas where the cost of health insurance is inherently higher due to reduced competition.

While Trump's promises on health care policy may have been popular, it remains to be seen whether his voters will care about the betrayal of those promises. However, it is clear that the American Health Care Act represents a significant departure from Trump's campaign promises and a potential harm to the very people who voted for him.

Title: Opinion: Pelosi's Remark on Trump's Weight Sparks Debate on Political Decorum

Article:
